headline: Pakistani Soldiers Died Near Long-Disputed Border
text: One day after Pakistan’s Army rejected an American characterization of airstrikes that killed 24 Pakistani soldiers on Saturday as accidental — calling them instead “an unprovoked attack of blatant aggression” — the military’s public relations wing released video of the two border posts hit in the raid.

headline: New York State's Testing Director Resigns
text: The director of New York State's testing program resigns on the same day state officials drop a plan to extend the length of reading tests given to students in grades three through eight, which principals had opposed.

headline: In a San Francisco Home, a Vibrant Mix of Life and Work

headline: Spruced Up for the Season
text: MY vision was fairly good until I bought a home. Then a sort of blindness set in. The holes I drilled in my kitchen ceiling five years ago completely disappear whenever I walk into the room. I fail to see the pockmarks in the staircase. A light switch in my office has been covered by duct tape since early 2010, or so I’ve been told.

headline: A Wonderland of Stage Toys
text: ON summer evenings in the 1980s, in the garden of our home in London, my little brother and I would scale the stern of the H.M.S. Bounty. We would hoist ourselves up her sides and climb her invisible rigging. From high in the crow’s nest we could see Tahiti on the horizon. I would be Fletcher Christian; my little brother, William Bligh. Armed with a half-dozen wooden spears, he fought valiantly against the mutinous children and the natives from down the street and across the gardens, until the sun cast the sky red-violet and we were avenged, or called in for dinner, battle-weary.

headline: Jewelry Inspired by Architectural Details
text: In high school, Rebecca Schiffman was embarrassed about living on the Upper East Side, which she considered uncool. But now she embraces the neighborhood, writing a blog about it called the U.E.S. Journal, and living in the same apartment on 88th Street where she grew up.

headline: The Gimme Guide
text: IT may be better to give than to receive, but it sure is getting harder.

headline: Branded Garbage Cans Stay Put
text: Chad Silver, an artist, and his wife, Colu Henry, a public relations manager at Bon Appétit magazine, were having trouble with their garbage cans, which kept vanishing from outside their Williamsburg, Brooklyn, apartment. So Mr. Silver, inspired by “Gucci Gucci,” a song by Kreayshawn, a West Coast rapper whose lyrics can’t be printed in this newspaper, decided to brand his cans with gold stickers replicating the logos of the luxury labels Gucci, Fendi and Prada.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Altered Photos and Shopping Apps
text: Fashion, beauty and entertainment magazines have been retouching photographs for decades, but picture-editing software like Adobe Photoshop makes it so quick and easy that some photos bear no resemblance to the real person. Steve Lohr, a technology reporter with The New York Times, talks about a recent article he wrote about computer scientists at Dartmouth who developed software tools that can objectively measure the amount of alterations that have been applied to photos.

headline: David Adjaye, Design Miami’s Designer of the Year
text: The 2011 Designer of the Year chosen by Design Miami, the annual design fair that runs concurrently with Art Basel Miami Beach, is not just a designer. This year, the selection committee picked an architect — albeit one who works frequently with artists and art collectors.

headline: Illinois: Prison Sought for Blagojevich
text: Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor convicted of trying to sell or trade the Senate seat once held by President Obama, should go to prison for 15 to 20 years, federal prosecutors said in legal papers filed Wednesday. Lawyers for Mr. Blagojevich, a Democrat convicted of 18 corruption-related counts, have indicated they will seek probation when a judge sentences him next week. Mr. Blagojevich is the second consecutive Illinois governor to face prison; George Ryan, his predecessor and a Republican, is serving a corruption sentence. In their filing, prosecutors wrote, “On the heels of one corrupt governor and after running on a campaign to end ‘pay-to-play,’ Blagojevich took office and immediately began plotting with others to use the office of the governor for his personal gain through fraud, bribery and extortion.”

headline: Giants Lose Umenyiora; Bradshaw May Play
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Michael Strahan visited the Giants’ practice center Wednesday, and it would have been understandable if Coach Tom Coughlin had tried to give him a uniform. The Giants’ pass defense has gone from feared to fragile over the past few weeks, and the latest development — Osi Umenyiora’s sprained ankle will keep him out of Sunday’s game against the Green Bay Packers and probably another week or two after that — figures to only make things worse.

headline: Colorado: Spill Near Refinery Is Investigated
text: Cleanup crews with Suncor Energy were trying to contain a small spill near a Denver-area oil refinery on Wednesday after liquid began seeping into a creek this week. Suncor was investigating the source of the leak and what precisely was oozing into the creek near its refinery in Commerce City. Workers were trying to keep the liquid from flowing into the South Platte River. Curtis Kimbel, an Environmental Protection Agency coordinator, described the material as a petroleum-type substance. Workers had contained the spill to an area of about 75 yards, he said. The National Wildlife Federation said it was concerned that the material could contain Canadian oil sands crude, which can be difficult to clean because it is so thick.

headline: Jaguars Buyer Had His Eye on Ownership of a Franchise
text: Shahid R. Khan, who agreed this week to acquire the Jacksonville Jaguars, has coveted an N.F.L. team for several years. Khan’s love of football was nurtured at the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana, and his riches as an auto parts manufacturer made the dream possible.

headline: Andrew Kazdin, Record Producer, Dies at 77
text: Andrew Kazdin, a producer known for his recordings of the New York Philharmonic, the pianists Glenn Gould, Murray Perahia and Ruth Laredo, and the organist E. Power Biggs, and who revolutionized classical recording by using techniques more common to popular music, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 77.

text: The National Labor Relations Board on Wednesday tentatively approved proposals that would speed up unionization elections, a move that labor leaders say will help unions sign up more members but that employer groups oppose.

headline: Sins of the Parents

But largely unnoticed, it is Florida, home to nearly one million Cuban refugees and their descendants, that has come up with perhaps the most bizarre and pointless anti-immigrant policy of all.

headline: Primary Sources
text: A few days ago, we posted an article by Thomas B. Edsall analyzing the arguments of Democratic strategists who suggest that the Democratic Party has lost its chance to win over a majority of the white working class and that party leaders should concentrate their efforts on other constituencies. The response was swift and fierce. Readers posted nearly five hundred comments. Edsall’s column was picked up, dissected, lambasted and praised in dozens of blog posts and newspaper articles, with headlines like “Different Flavor Kool-Aid For Democrats,” “Is Obama ‘Abandoning’ the White Working Class?” and “NY Times: Democrats Not Interested in Voters Who Work, Target Losers Instead” (thank you, Rush Limbaugh).

headline: Brilliant and Bold, in Any Language
text: Early in his tenure as manager of the Chiba Lotte Marines in Japan, Bobby Valentine decided to run a drill to practice pickoff moves at second base. He instructed his pitchers to throw behind the runner, but for some reason they refused to do as he asked.

headline: New Suit Says Coach Abused Boy for 4 Years
text: The former Penn State assistant football coach Jerry Sandusky sexually abused a boy more than 100 times in a four-year period and threatened the boy and his family to keep them from reporting the abuse, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday in Philadelphia. The alleged victim, now 29, is not one of the eight who were mentioned in a grand jury report revealed last month in the child sexual abuse case against Sandusky.

headline: More Children Need a Free Breakfast, Lunch — and Dinner
text: “I never thought a program like this would apply to me and my kids.” That’s what parents in the Gates Chili school district outside  Rochester are telling Debbi Beauvais, who administers the school meals program there. In a front-page article on Wednesday, The Times reported that around Rochester and across the country, suburban poverty means that schools are finding themselves serving more free or low-cost lunches — and breakfasts. And last year, when the proportion of students who qualified for free or subsidized lunches in the Hickman Mills C-1 district of Kansas City, Mo., hit 80 percent, the school began offering a third meal after the end of classes, paid for by the state.

headline: A Gallery That Helped Create the American Art World Closes Shop After 165 Years
text: After 165 years, Knoedler & Company, one of the oldest and most prestigious art galleries in the country, is permanently closing its doors. Opened at a time when there were no major museums in New York, Knoedler helped shape the tastes as well as decorate the homes of America’s new class of wealthy barons.

headline: As Always, Ryan Leaves No Room for Doubt With the Jets

So big that a victory could brighten Rex Ryan’s mood for days, as long as his son Seth’s Summit Hilltoppers can defeat Madison on Friday night in the New Jersey state championship.

headline: Obama Refrains From a Formal ‘I’m Sorry’ to Pakistan

headline: High Stakes, Little Time
text: At the end of this month, a federal payroll tax cut for all working Americans will expire, as will federal unemployment benefits. If Congress fails to renew both, the effect on the economy would be grim, or worse.

headline: In Police Trial, Ruling Urges Firing of Detective in Sean Bell Case

headline: Pac-12 Doormat Hires Quirky Coach
text: Mike Leach, one of college football’s most colorful characters before his controversial firing two years ago, was named the coach at Washington State on Wednesday. Leach’s deal, worth more than $11 million over five years, according to a person with direct knowledge of the situation, will put him in the top echelon of Pacific-12 Conference coaches by salary.

headline: The Supreme Court’s Recusal Problem
text: Liberals in Congress have called for Justice Clarence Thomas to recuse himself from the review of the health care reform law because his wife, Virginia, has campaigned fervently against it. Conservatives insist that Justice Elena Kagan should remove herself from the case because, they claim, as solicitor general she was more involved in shaping the law than she lets on.

headline: Judy Lewis, Secret Daughter of Hollywood, Dies at 76

headline: Watergate? Whatever Was That?
text: House Republicans will surely invoke their all-purpose rationale — deficit savings — as they try on Thursday to repeal the public financing option for presidential campaigns. This is the highly effective reform enacted after the Watergate scandal. It is revealing that just as a new era of unbridled corporate and special-interest money engulfs the 2012 elections, Republicans are determined to kill off the public financing option.

headline: Bad Call on Farm Drugs
text: The Food and Drug Administration last month denied two longstanding petitions asking it to limit the routine feeding of antibiotics to farm animals, a practice that poses a serious risk to human health. Eighty percent of the antibiotics sold in this country are fed to farm animals. The drugs make the animals grow faster, but their overuse increases the likelihood of antibiotic-resistant pathogens. Some antibiotics are used only in animals, but farmers are also using antibiotics vital in human medicine. This is the class of drugs that the petitions, sponsored by several consumer advocacy groups, had hoped to restrict.

headline: Most Regions Experienced Modest Growth
text: A roundup of regional economic conditions in the Federal Reserve’s 12 districts.

headline: Study Shows Worse Picture of Meltdown in Japan
text: TOKYO — Molten nuclear fuel may have bored into the floor of at least one of the reactors at the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, the complex’s operator said Wednesday, citing a new simulation of the accident that crippled the plant in March.

headline: Student’s Death Turns Spotlight on Hazing
text: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. — Before they even arrive at Florida A&M University here, the freshmen who are hand-picked for the famous marching band know all about the hazing, an unsanctioned tradition that goes back decades.

headline: A Note to Our Readers
text: As Jill Abramson, The Times’s executive editor, announced on Wednesday, we have introduced an improved comment system. It will put readers’ responses on the same page as the article, provide threading of comments so readers can respond directly to one another, and allow them to share their comments, and those of others, to Twitter and Facebook. The new system will also offer some of our most engaged readers the opportunity to post their comments on the Web site without moderation; they will appear shortly after they are written.

headline: Belarus: 2 Get Death Sentences in Subway Bombing
text: A court in Belarus handed down a death sentence on Wednesday against two men who had been found guilty of setting off a bomb in a subway station in Minsk, the capital, in April, killing 15 people and wounding hundreds. Judge Aleksandr Fyodortsov said the defendants “pose an exceptional danger to society, and an exceptional penalty should be applied to them.” Belarus is the only country in Europe in which the death penalty remains legal. After the verdict was read, Lyubov Kovalyova, the mother of one of the defendants, tearfully told reporters that the case against her son had been fabricated.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Thursday
text: The New Delhi police have arrested six people suspected of planning several terror attacks in India. A multi-city sweep brought in suspects said to be linked to the Indian Muhajideen, a shadowy terror group that has carried out multiple bomb attacks across the country. The men arrested Wednesday are suspected of carrying out unsolved bombings in Pune, Delhi and Bangalore, the Indian Express reported.

headline: The Big Mismatch: Jobs and Skills

In other words, he was trying to improve his command of English and become more confident and expressive.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 1, 2011

headline: West Tightens Iran Sanctions After Embassy Attack
text: Galvanized by the pillaging of Britain’s Embassy in Tehran, Western nations moved Thursday to significantly tighten sanctions against Iran over its suspect nuclear program, with the European Union expanding an Iranian blacklist and the United States Senate passing a measure that could severely disrupt Iran’s oil income.

headline: Dec. 1, 1959 | Antarctica Is Set Aside as Scientific Preserve
text: On Dec. 1, 1959, representatives of 12 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, signed a treaty in Washington, which designated Antarctica as a scientific preserve, free from military activity.The signatories included the seven nations to have claimed control over a part of Antarctica: Argentina, Australia, Britain, Chile, France, Norway and New Zealand. The treaty did not affect these claims though it did ban all future claims. The New York Times noted that overlapping claims by Britain, Argentina and Chile had caused tension and that many hoped the treaty would “ultimately permit the claims issue to die a natural death.”

headline: Marathon Swimmer Diana Nyad Takes On the Demons of the Sea
text: Today Diana Nyad is swimming for four hours. She does this four days a week in the 50-meter pool at the Rose Bowl Aquatic Center, in Pasadena, Calif. Her stroke is rhythmic, high in the water. It’s hard to judge how old she is by looking at her. Her back is well muscled. Her legs are girlish — shapely and short. Her skin is as weathered as a crocodile handbag. Her arms are covered with jellyfish scars. When Nyad swims in a pool, she counts in her head, ticking off laps, first in English, then in German, then in Spanish, then in French. (Nyad is fluent in all but German.) The goal is to focus her mind on repetitive thought, as a yogi does with a mantra. But when Nyad swims in the ocean for a long time — 8 or 10 or 12 or even 24 hours — she doesn’t just count, she sings. She’ll do “It Ain’t Me, Babe” 10 times, interspersed with the quatralingual counting, then sing “Paperback Writer,” 10 times, followed by quatralingual counting again. Nyad keeps in her head a playlist of 65 songs. Some are for daytime swimming; others for nighttime. Nyad knows each one intimately, how many seconds each takes, how many strokes. “When I complete 2,000 ‘It Ain’t Me, Babe’s, Bob Dylan version, I know I’ve gone 4 hours and 45 minutes exactly,” Nyad says. “I never lose track.”

headline: A Drug That Wakes the Near Dead
text: The moment she saw him, Judy Cox knew her son was dead. It was an October morning in 2008, and she had just stepped out the door to run an errand when she found him lying faceup in the driveway, ghost white, covered in purple splotches. He wasn’t breathing, and when she couldn’t revive him, she ran screaming into the house where her husband, Wayne, was still asleep. “Chris is dead,” she cried. “Call 911!”

headline: Tastings and Classes at Paris Wine Fair

Organized by Michel Bettane and Thierry Desseauve, two wine authorities, it takes place on Dec. 2 and 3 at the Carrousel du Louvre (99 rue de Rivoli; carrouseldulouvre.com). Distinguished labels like Veuve Clicquot and Louis Latour; wine-world stars like Hervé Bizeul and Marcel Richaud; and newcomers including Beaucastel, Pichon Comtesse, Angélus and Chateau de Bellet are among the participants this year.

headline: Yotam Ottolenghi’s International Cuisine
text: Yotam Ottolenghi has no trouble embracing complex issues or producing complex, difficult-to-define food. He was born in Jerusalem of European immigrants (his mother is German, his father Italian). His primary business partner, Sami Tamimi — who also grew up in Jerusalem — is Palestinian. Ottolenghi studied philosophy and literature (he has a master’s in comparative literature), and though he attended Le Cordon Bleu for six months, he lacks the bossiness of most chefs. His cooking at his London restaurant, Nopi, and in four gorgeous shops (all called Ottolenghi), is usually thought of and described as broadly Mediterranean, but in fact it’s far more international than that. Not only does he offer out-and-out Asian dishes on the menu; he is also comfortable using soy sauce in what might be thought of as Provençal dishes or hitting tofu with rosemary. What most of the dishes have in common, he says when asked, are “sun” and “intense flavors.”

headline: Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 1
text: The rapper Kanye West received the most nominations for the 54th Annual Grammy Awards during a ceremony broadcast on Wednesday night on CBS, but it was the pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars who dominated the Song of the Year, Record of the Year and Album of the Year nominations, The ArtsBeat blog reported. Adele, the British soul singer, received six nominations for her album “21,” which included the hit “Rolling in the Deep.” (Her singing voice has been temporarily silenced by vocal cord surgery, and it is not clear, The Los Angeles Times reported, whether Adele will have recovered sufficiently to perform when the awards are handed out on Feb. 12.) Mr. Mars also received six nominations, three for “Grenade,” his song about unrequited love, and three for the album “Doowops and Hooligans.” Mr. West was nominated seven times based on two albums — his complex solo set “My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy” and his collaboration with Jay-Z, “Watch the Throne.” Both were left off the Album of the Year list, but were nominated for Rap Album of the Year. (The snub of MBDTF, as Mr. West’s album is known, was certainly the hot topic on Twitter.)

headline: Among Hundreds of Dead Dolphins, an Intriguing Survivor
text: Four more dolphins washed up on the shores of the Gulf of Mexico this week. For coastal residents from Louisiana to Florida, the beached animals are a familair sight: hundreds of decomposing dolphin carcasses have turned up over the last two years.

headline: Daily Report: A Deluge of Data in DNA Sequencing
text: The study of genomes is caught in a “data deluge,” reports Andrew Pollack in Thursday’s New York Times. Although DNA sequencing is becoming faster and cheaper, researchers are drowning in the amount of resulting data, which is expensive to store, transmit and analyze.

headline: Love (and Law) in the Time of H.I.V.
text: JOHANNESBURG — A couple of years ago, courtesy of a joyous English summer, Cupid shot his arrow straight through my student heart. I fell in love with a charming American filmmaker. A blustery romance ensued. In the era of Skype, the ocean separating us had no chance of drowning our romantic spirits, and a few months later, I visited him in New York.

headline: Citigroup Appoints New Head of Russian Banking
text: LONDON — Citigroup said on Thursday that it had appointed Slava Slavinskiy as the head of banking for Russia and the Commonwealth of Independent States, which were formerly Soviet republics.

headline: Only One Thing on His Mind
text: The cruel paradox of addiction is that it transforms a source of pleasure into an inescapable, insatiable need. An abundance — an overdose — of movies and books explores the logic of this condition, mostly with respect to drugs or alcohol. “Shame,” the relentless new feature from the British artist turned filmmaker Steve McQueen, has a lot in common with films that plumb the toxic romance of the bottle or the needle. The crucial difference is that its protagonist, a handsome, youngish Manhattanite named Brandon (Michael Fassbender), is hooked on sex.

text: Over in our non-bloggy column today, the Bagger explores the idea that there is a bumper crop of dude-oriented films among the Oscar hopefuls this year. “The Descendants,” “Beginners,” “The Tree of Life,” “Margin Call,” “Take Shelter,” “J. Edgar,” “The Artist,” “Midnight in Paris,” “50/50” and “Drive” all deal with fatherhood, or living up to notions of masculine identity, sexuality and power, or bashing someone’s head in. (And let’s not even go near the Michael Fassbender vehicle “Shame” for the moment. We will get to the double entendres for that later, or the good folks at Fox, which is releasing the NC-17 movie, will do it for us.)

headline: Jane Addams High School Accused of Credit-Switching
text: Teachers and staff at Jane Addams High School for Academic Careers in the South Bronx told The Daily News that for the last few years, students who took courses in cosmetology were given credit for chemistry and students who took a tourism course were given credit for geography, among other credit switches listed on a “Dual Credited Course Table" that was given to teachers. The Department of Education is investigating.

headline: A Libel Law and a Balancing Act
text: JERUSALEM – Israel is still a journalistic heaven, but Israeli journalists have good reason to forget it these days. Yes, Israeli informality means that it’s still relatively easy for reporters to call high officials on their cellphones at all hours. Yes, the country’s smallness means that they can quickly reach its every corner. But last week the Knesset member Yariv Levin of the Likud Party cast a dark shadow on these advantages by getting a proposed amendment to Israel’s libel law through a first vote.

headline: Spain’s Star Chefs Are Branching Out
text: It may be too late to try Ferran Adrià’s molecular gastronomy at El Bulli in Catalonia, which closed in July. But with the opening of several Michelin-starred hotel restaurants in Spain, travelers can experience cutting-edge cookery in places outside remote areas of the Basque Country or Catalonia. The chef Dani García runs Calima in the resort town of Marbella; and the twin chefs Sergio and Javier Torres run Dos Cielos in Barcelona. Both restaurants, part of the Melia hotel chain, are making Spain’s new cuisine easier to reach (if not easier on the wallet).

headline: The Republican Attack on Federal Workers
text: Congressional Republicans said yesterday they would support an extension of the payroll tax cut, but refused President Obama’s proposal to make millionaires pay for it with a small surcharge on their earnings. Instead, they want middle-class federal workers to offset the cost.

headline: Leading Off: What’s Gotten Into Hockey?
text: N.H.L. seasons are usually fairly predictable. Teams muddle around during the fall when most people think the season hasn’t (or shouldn’t have) started yet. Everyone is within three points of a playoff spot in February. Teams throw players around like throw pillows at the trading deadline. Everyone makes a riveting mad dash at the playoffs, which end ridiculously late in the year when people have sunscreen on their shopping lists.

headline: Cloud Computing as a Threat to Older Tech Companies
text: The International Data Corporation, whose technology analysis and predictions influence a lot of corporate purchases, foresees the creation of a new high-technology industry in the convergence of mobile devices, social networking, and cloud-based computing and data storage. As a result, the company says in a new study, many industry giants will scramble to sustain relevance, and some upstarts will achieve leadership positions or be purchased.

headline: How Hard Is It to Adapt a Hit Book? Ask the Makers of ‘Tinker, Tailor’
text: Over at Gold Derby, Adam Waldowski takes a look at the strong competition for the best adapted screenplay Oscar. When it picked up a nod from the New York Film Critics Circle on Tuesday, “Moneyball,” the adaptation of Michael Lewis’s business-of-baseball best seller, got an early lead; it may also be helped by having recognizable writers in Aaron Sorkin and Steve Zaillian. On the other hand, Mr. Sorkin won an Oscar just last year, for “The Social Network,” and Mr. Zaillian picked up one in 1993, for a little film called “Schindler’s List.” (He also adapted this year’s “Girl With the Dragon Tattoo.”) Who else is on deck?

headline: A Second Arrival for ‘Once’
text: WHILE preparing for the lead role of Girl in the new Off Broadway musical “Once,” Cristin Milioti made a choice common among performers in screen-to-stage adaptations: She avoided watching the original film, a 2006 indie romance from Ireland that won an Academy Award for the song “Falling Slowly.” Her concern was that she might slip into mimicking Marketa Irglova, the spirited young Czech musician who became a fan favorite as Girl in the movie.

headline: Steve Case Raises $450 Million Venture Fund
text: The AOL co-founder Steve Case and two former AOL colleagues, Ted Leonsis and Donn Davis, have raised $450 million for a new venture capital fund.

headline: Look! Up in the Sky! It’s an Astronomical Price for a Comic Book!
text: An auction for a copy of Action Comics No. 1 from 1938 set a record Wednesday night. After 50 bids the closing price was $2,161,000 — the most ever paid for a comic book — to be the owner of the first appearance of Superman. (And that new owner’s identity is currently secret.) The copy of the book was graded at 9.0 on a scale of 1 to 10, a full grade better than a copy of Action Comics No. 1 that sold for $1 million last year. (For a look at other notable debuts, and what they have fetched, click here.)

headline: Union Leader Foresees Teacher Evaluation 'Nightmare'
text: An official of the principals' union writes that when training expands in New York City, his members are likely to view the new teacher evaluation system as punitive to teachers and damaging to students, who would be far better off if the money being spent to develop new tests were invested in true classroom instruction.

text: Shortly before he died of cancer in January, the designer Charles Nolan made an unexpected request. He wanted his store in the meatpacking district to remain open, no matter what happened to his label.

headline: Is a Tablet Computer for Babies the Worst Toy of 2011?
text: Each year, the Campaign for a Commercial-Free Childhood nominates a few “select” toys for a Toady award: Toys Oppressive and Destructive to Young Children. In 2010, the award went to Nickelodeon’s Addicting Games Web site, not just for its games (like Perry the Sneak, which allowed players to earn points by trying to catch glimpses of naked women showering) but for its decision to market those games on its Nick Jr. Web site. In 2009, the winner was the Dallas Cowboy Cheerleader Barbie.

headline: ‘Missing Arms, Legs, Fathers and Mothers’

And like those mines, the legacy of Pol Pot’s Khmer Rouge exacts a constant — and hidden — toll, leaving the country mostly poor, politically repressive, corrupt and violent.

headline: Bob the Builder Goes to Haiti

As The Miami Herald reported, President Michel Martelly, Prime Minister Garry Cornille, former President Bill Clinton and the head of the I.D.B., Luis Alberto Moreno, have spent the last few days cutting ribbons and making speeches, all to emphasize the idea that reconstruction is gaining momentum and that Haiti is open for business.

headline: Note to Readers
text: The Times has introduced an improved comment system, which will provide threading of comments so you can respond directly to one another, and allow you to share your comments to Twitter and Facebook. Our new system will also offer some of our most engaged readers the opportunity to post their comments on the Web site without moderation.

headline: Seen on Video: A Smoke Shop Theft
text: On Black Friday, as shoppers across the nation busied themselves pepper-spraying and shooting at each other, a quieter but perhaps no less brazen crime was committed at a head shop – er, smoking accessories store — in the East Village. Several young men helped themselves to six vaporizers worth a total of about $2,500 from the store, Smoking Tattoos.

headline: In Advertising, MDC Names Its First Woman as Managing Director
text: MDC Partners, which owns advertising agencies like Crispin Porter & Bogusky, is hiring its first woman to be managing director.

headline: Springsteen to Make Trip to SXSW
text: Bruce Springsteen will be the keynote speaker at next year’s South by Southwest Music and Media Conference and Festival, Mr. Springsteen and organizers of the event, which is based in Austin, Tex., jointly announced on Thursday. His participation is scheduled for March 15 at the conference’s main space, the Austin Convention Center.

headline: Out There | Art Basel Miami Beach Pregame Show
text: The forecast for Tuesday in Miami Beach was for overcast skies, scattered parties and a chance of art as jet-lagged travelers convened for the prelude to Art Basel 2011. The Fairchild Tropical Botanic Garden in Coral Gables hosted its annual brunch, this year for the sculptor Will Ryman, whose monochromatic roses (most recently seen on Park Avenue) are scattered around the grounds in the form of petal chairs and towering, long-stemmed arrangements. Valuable trees and interesting fauna abounded, including a black crocodile and coconut-size baby raccoon mingling in dangerous proximity: what kind of omen is that?

headline: ‘Make Me a Mitt Romney Weeble!’
text: It’s not every day an art director is charged with this task. I came out of the meeting thinking that it seemed easy enough. Break apart Weeble toy. Hire someone to illustrate Romney’s caricature. Piece Weeble together. Photograph. Done.

headline: 36 Hours in Mérida, Mexico
text: Mérida, a languid city of pastel mansions and evening promenades, is in the midst of a restoration boom, and the city’s cultural and restaurant scenes are flourishing.

headline: 36 Hours in Mérida, Mexico
text: YUCATECANS are fiercely proud of their culture, sprinkling their Spanish with Mayan words and quick to recount the stories of resistance and revolution that set this region apart from the rest of Mexico for centuries. Somehow, those tales seem a little distant now in Yucatán’s capital, Mérida, a languid city of pastel mansions and evening promenades. The city, now one of the safest in Mexico, is an architectural jewel, and has one of the country’s largest historic centers outside Mexico City. Block after block of houses dating to the mid-19th century and earlier are in the midst of a restoration boom, and the city’s cultural and restaurant scenes are flourishing.

headline: Cunningham Countdown: Saying Goodbye to the RUGs
text: It’s no longer news that the Merce Cunningham Dance Company is due to shut up shop at the end of 2011. But another, attached troupe has already given its farewell. The Cunningham company’s Repertory Understudy Group ended with a season of six performances in the Cunningham studio over the last six days of November. Known as the RUGs, its four dancers were never quite a second company. The group, formalized in 1990, served as an apprentice program for the Cunningham company, with whose members its four dancers shared studios and took class.

headline: At Home in Hotels
text: Guy Trebay on some of the hotels he has stayed at, including the Park Hyatt in Tokyo, the Bauer in Venice, a parking-lot motel in New Mexico and the Sunset in Los Angeles.

headline: Popcast: The Black Keys and Paul Motian
text: This week Popcast examines the return of a surprise pop juggernaut and remembers a seminal jazz drummer.

headline: TimesCast | December 1, 2011
text: Islamists say they have a majority in early voting in Egypt; a Bahraini blogger stands up to the riot police; and why the Grammys are still relevant.

headline: Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s Atlanta Neighborhood on the Upswing
text: As a cradle of culinary and artistic innovation, the area is seeing a wave of new art galleries, nightclubs and restaurants.

headline: Kicking Could Decide Oklahoma-Oklahoma State Bedlam game
text: Batten down the hatches in Oklahoma, it’s bedlam time again. For those outside of the Sooner state, that means the annual football showdown between Oklahoma and Oklahoma State. It’s another installment in the heated “Bedlam Series” sports rivalry between the schools, set for Saturday night in Stillwater.

headline: Obama Says He Will Seek More Money for AIDS Programs
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama won plaudits from AIDS groups that have criticized him in the past with his announcement on Thursday that he is seeking additional federal money for efforts to prevent and treat the disease in the United States and globally.

headline: Spain and Argentina Meet in Davis Cup Final
text: The Davis Cup final, the last major event of the tennis season, begins Friday in Seville, with host Spain facing Argentina. Rafael Nadal, coming off a disappointing fall and hoping to end his season on a high note, opens play for Spain against his good friend Juan Monaco. Fifth-ranked David Ferrer will play Juan Martín del Potro in Friday’s second match.

headline: Blue-Eyed Boy and His Possessed Puppet
text: JUILLIARD doesn’t really prepare you for puppetry. It certainly doesn’t prepare you for satanic puppetry, at least. But Steven Boyer — who plays the lead(s) in “Hand to God,” an acclaimed comedy about a meek teenager whose sock puppet appears to be possessed by the Devil — has been learning on the job.

headline: Mazda Takeri Carries the Kodo Standard Forward
text: At the Tokyo auto show this week, Mazda unveiled the Takeri concept car, the clearest indication yet from the automaker of the future shape of the Mazda 6 midsize sedan.

headline: The Impact of Grazing? Don’t Ask
text: Millions of cattle graze on public lands all over the West and have done so for more than a century. But a new complaint filed by an environmental group charges that despite Clinton-era moves to examine and diminish the impact of grazing in the arid West, Interior Department employees have blocked the use of federal data on the impact in regional scientific studies.

headline: A Blizzard of Tickets for Texting While Driving
text: New Yorkers who took to the roads over the Thanksgiving weekend could not keep their hands off their phones. As a result, 816 drivers received tickets for texting while driving, the governor’s office said on Thursday.

headline: Political Holiday Gifts
text: In my inbox: Holiday Gifts from Cato! Somehow, not something I could imagine myself, or for that matter anyone, rushing to check out. But Robin and I immediately began thinking of other conservative-themed gifts:

headline: $3 Million Gift for New Signature Theater Company Home
text: The family foundation of Barry Diller and Diane von Furstenberg has made its largest donation to an arts organization, $3 million to Signature Theater Company for its new Off Broadway home set to open in February. James Houghton, artistic director of the theater company, announced the gift for the Signature Center complex on Thursday and said that in appreciation the centerpiece stairway would be named the Diller-von Furstenberg Grand Staircase.

headline: Haul Me Up by Richard Thompson
text: A performance of “Haul Me Up,” by Richard Thompson Band, part of a DVD called Live at Celtic Connections, due out in January.

headline: Hoping for Mammals, but Getting Mostly Ants

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit Against Dallas Art Museum
text: A Federal judge on Wednesday dismissed a lawsuit against the Dallas Museum of Art involving a collection of some 1,400 works of art, including paintings by van Gogh, Renoir, and Pissarro.

headline: Week 13 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

text: Bruce Boudreau’s unemployment lasted all of 65 hours.

headline: BMW and Toyota to Collaborate on Battery Development
text: At a press conference Thursday in Tokyo, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the BMW Group jointly announced they would collaborate on specific advanced powertrain technologies. The effort would initially be focused on research in lithium-ion batteries.

headline: Gingrich’s Immigration Plan Could Benefit Millions, Study Finds
text: How many illegal immigrants could gain legal status under an idea proposed by Newt Gingrich? Perhaps as many as 3.5 million, according to figures published Thursday by the Pew Hispanic Center in Washington.

headline: Six Ways to Master Your Hotel Stay
text: SEE THE THIRD ROOM FIRST It’s anyone’s guess why the first room that check-in clerks invariably offer is the cubbyhole with a romantic view of the air handling system. No matter how travel fatigued, I make it a point to apply the advice of a friend with decades of international travel experience. “Show me the third room first,” this woman says at check-in, telegraphing a willingness to keep at it until she’s offered a room she likes.

headline: My Life in Hotels
text: IF you travel a lot, it happens that you are expected to keep a list of dream destinations. Friends are understandably curious to learn where somebody fortunate enough to have visited a fair number of places would voluntarily go if given the chance. It surprises people, then, to learn that where I would most like to be is often a great hotel.

headline: Symbolically Attired for an Arrest on World AIDS Day
text: Demonstrators wearing Robin Hood costumes were arrested after stopping traffic near City Hall on Thursday, in an attempt to persuade elected officials to “make Wall Street pay to fight AIDS at home and abroad,” as one protest group put it on its Web site. Approximately eight people were taken into custody, a police spokesman said.

headline: A Calculator to See if You’ll Be Snared by the A.M.T.
text: Right after the holiday season comes tax season. So to help you with your year-end tax planning, Kiplinger is offering a new calculator to help you determine if you will fall prey to the dreaded alternative minimum tax.

headline: Kelli O’Hara to Star in ‘Bridges of Madison County’ Musical Workshop
text: The director Bartlett Sher and the actress Kelli O’Hara, who collaborated previously on the Tony Award-winning revival of “South Pacific” and the musical “Light in the Piazza,” will reunite for a developmental workshop in New York this month of their latest project, “The Bridges of Madison County,” a musical adaptation of the best-selling novel and hit film. The Broadway producers Jeffrey Richards, Stacey Mindich and Jerry Frankel confirmed on Thursday that they were holding the workshop; no plans for a full production have been announced.

headline: Guess Where This Is?
text: Before falling into decay, this gentrifying neighborhood in an American city was a bustling hub with factories and shotgun houses.

headline: Art Meets Leisure in Arkansas
text: THE drive into Bentonville, Ark., from the region’s airport provides vistas of cattle pastures and open fields that occasionally give way to lonely, treeless subdivisions, which in turn lead to commercial strips. A massive Wal-Mart distribution center provides the first indication of that corporation’s influence here, where it has its headquarters.

headline: It’s the Season to Earn, and Spend, Points
text: BRIAN KELLY started planning his father’s work trips — and managing his travel awards — when he was still a kid. At 13, he had collected enough points to book a family vacation in the Cayman Islands. Now Mr. Kelly’s blog, thepointsguy.com, helps frustrated travelers who don’t know how to make the most of their awards. With so much gift-giving and family visiting, Mr. Kelly said, the holidays are the season for racking up travel points. Below are his five tips for giving — and getting.

text: UPSHOT

headline: Accel Invests in Brazilian Review and Search Site
text: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Accel Partners has invested in Kekanto, a local review and search site based here, reinforcing its interest in the booming Brazilian consumer Internet market.

headline: The Island From a Board
text: A trip to St. John as seen on a stand-up paddle board offers wide-ranging views of the land and fish beneath.

headline: The Life Report: Regina Titus
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: Everyone’s a Critic: Analyzing Sitcoms as Cultural Texts
text: Overview | What can television sitcoms teach us? In this lesson, students investigate the claim recently made in The New York Times that new hit sitcoms are proof that “we’ve reached the End of Comedy.” They watch sitcoms with a critical eye and ultimately choose a writing project that demonstrates a close viewing that treats the shows like literary texts.

headline: Stand-Up Paddle Boarding in the Virgin Islands
text: IF John would just raise his arms skyward, I would have a better view of him streaking across the Narrows, northward toward Tortola, leaving me far enough behind that I have to squint to see him. He wants to cross the 1.5-mile strait on his paddle board, abandoning United States territory to storm British waters. This is not recommended for those who are likely to give out halfway across, like me, which is why I am still on this side of the divide, straddling my board, in a lagoon off St. John in the United States Virgin Islands.

headline: Regulators Pledge New Rules After MF Global’s Demise

headline: The Waimea Valley Reveals Its Secrets
text: IT’S not often that a hike begins with a ceremonial chant. We were standing outside the visitor center at Waimea Valley, on the North Shore of Oahu, when our guide, Kahokulea Haiku, started our excursion by singing an oli, a traditional Hawaiian chant that honors the history of the land and its people, and can be used as a blessing or to give thanks. As bright morning light shone down on us, Mr. Haiku’s voice resonated across the gardens that surround the center. And with that, we were off.

headline: Time to Accelerate the Housing Recovery
text: It’s housing, stupid. More precisely, it’s housing finance.

headline: Osteria dei Mulini in Polignano a Mare, Italy
text: The limestone entablature above the entrance to Chiesa del Purgatorio, a church in Polignano a Mare, on the Adriatic coast of Puglia, features an assemblage of skulls and crossbones and, situated squarely among them, an hourglass, a reminder that the only thing separating life from the afterlife is the slippage of a few grains of sand. Thankfully, for those who would spend as much of what precious time remains eating, right next door is a restaurant that through various iterations has been serving traditional Puglian cuisine for centuries.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach: Wednesday Night
text: Dueling beach parties for MoCA and Art.sy.

headline: ‘Rebecca’ Musical Names Its Mrs. Danvers and Mr. de Winter

headline: My 20 Years as a Dad Columnist
text: My children have spent most of their lives under my magnifying glass. This year I pulled it away.

headline: Ante Markovic, Last Premier of Yugoslavia, Dies at 87
text: Ante Markovic, who as the last prime minister of Yugoslavia tried to stave off the ethnic warfare that led to the disintegration of that nation, died on Nov. 28 in Zagreb, the Croatian capital. He was 87.

headline: National Board of Review Picks ‘Hugo’
text: There’s something for everyone – except Brad Pitt, Meryl Streep and Michelle Williams. The National Board of Review picked “Hugo,” Martin Scorsese’s 3D ode to early cinema, as its top film, and named Mr. Scorsese best director, thereby ensuring that Mr. Scorsese will show up for the ceremony on Jan. 10. Also likely to appear: George Clooney, who won best actor for “The Descendants,” which earned a best supporting actress win for Shailene Woodley, who plays Mr. Clooney’s petulant teenage daughter, and a best adapted screenplay award for Alexander Payne, Nat Faxon and Jim Rash. The incomparable Tilda Swinton was named best actress for “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” and Christopher Plummer will take home the best supporting actor trophy for his turn as a father coming out late in life in Mike Mills’ “Beginners,” which could signal the start of his ascent to a best supporting actor nod at the Oscars.

headline: Don’t Worry About Social Security
text: It was surprising this morning to hear Senator Joe Manchin, Democrat of West Virginia, denounce President Obama’s proposal to extend the payroll tax cut. Mr. Manchin, one of the very few Democrats to break with the president on this issue, said it would jeopardize the future of Social Security.

headline: Dogs and Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder
text: It’s well known that post-traumatic stress is one of the major problems facing many veterans returning from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan. But now researchers are finding that a large number of military dogs may be grappling with the condition as well.

headline: Watching the Iowa Ground Game
text: Since we first put out the call  for photos of presidential campaign material, we’ve received several dozen submissions from readers, many of them pictures of grass-roots support for Ron Paul, the Republican congressman from Texas. The billboard shown here is in Wisconsin, and was produced independent of Mr. Paul’s presidential campaign.

headline: Jane Addams H.S. Students Fear They Lack Credits to Graduate

headline: Viewers Don’t Hate New Fox Sitcom
text: The series premiere of “I Hate My Teenage Daughter” posted decent numbers for Fox on Wednesday, helping the network win the night in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic. Some 6.8 million viewers sampled the new sitcom while it held 75 percent of the 18-to-49 audience from its lead-in, “The X Factor.”

headline: The Economist’s Progress: Better Living Through Fiscal Chemistry
text: As Sylvia Nasar tells it, the story of “the dismal science” of economics is a bright one of onward and upward progress. Never mind that Irving Fisher and John Maynard Keynes, two of the central figures in this book, were blindsided by the Great Crash of 1929. Never mind that lessons from the Great Depression and the warnings of a few farsighted economists were ignored by Wall Street in recent years, leading to another harrowing crash in 2008 and lingering fiscal woes.

text: 6:32 p.m. | Updated Yes, he gave her money. And no, his wife did not know.

headline: Winter Wonders | The Cool Class
text: We all revert a little during the holidays — we go home, childhood memories surface, and the next thing we know girlish uniforms and naïve dresses have curious appeal. Here, Britain’s most popular sister-in-law, Pippa Middleton, takes to the skating rink in a coat with a modlike pouf skirt; the actress Sienna Miller gets gold stars for her prim A-line look; and Kate Moss sticks to the straight and narrow with a midthigh peacoat and high leather boots.

headline: Write an Invitation? Be My Guest
text: My husband wants to throw a holiday party this year and promised to do all the work himself. He created the guest list, mostly from our neighborhood, and bought invitations that required him to fill in names and dates. The trouble is, he has the worst handwriting imaginable. He doesn’t know some of our neighbors’ last names (or the correct spelling of many of their first names). Still, he got them out. Am I wrong to be bothered by his invitation etiquette? C. Z., San Francisco

headline: $15 Million Gift Changes Miami Art Museum to Jorge M. Pérez Art Museum
text: The Miami Art Museum will be renamed the Jorge M. Pérez Art Museum of Miami-Dade County after a $15 million gift from Mr. Pérez, the museum announced Thursday. Mr. Pérez, a developer of multifamily residences, had already given $5 million to the museum’s capital campaign for its new downtown building, designed by Herzog & de Meuron and due to be completed in 2013.

headline: How to Police Geoengineering?
text: When people consider using engineering techniques to counter the effects of climate change, they usually think first about the technical difficulties involved. But a new report points out challenges that may be even more important: regulating the research on such technologies, and their potential deployment.

text: Dec. 1, 2011 — The Lede’s Robert Mackey interviews a Bahraini blogger who confronted riot police officers.

headline: In Something Familiar With All Her Black
text: The actress Archie Panjabi, 39, won a 2010 Emmy for her role as the intriguing investigator Kalinda Sharma on the CBS drama “The Good Wife.” A native of England who grew up there and in Mumbai, India, she now lives in New York.

headline: More on Coke’s Role in a Shelved Bottle Ban
text: Jon Jarvis, the director of the National Park Service, has said that its decision to scuttle a planned ban on small plastic water bottles at Grand Canyon National Park had nothing to do with opposition from the Coca-Cola Company.

headline: Duke Freshman Bloomed in Unlikely Place
text: A few years ago, Kelly Cobb, a freshman forward on the Duke women’s soccer team, decided to go for a run in Chugiak, Alaska, her hometown. Her street was slicked with snow and ice, so she strapped ice grips over her shoes. She kept her eyes on the ground to avoid slipping and did not notice the black bear in the road until it was about 20 feet away. They stared at each other for a few seconds until the animal wandered off. Cobb ran home.

headline: As Soldiers Leave Iraq, Bomb-Sniffing Dogs Stay
text: BAGHDAD – Dogs have emerged as the most valuable bomb detectors in Iraq and Afghanistan. As a result, some of the canines used by United States forces in Afghanistan are coming down with post-traumatic stress disorder. And in Iraq, just as the American army is leaving, a large shipment of American dogs has arrived, though the Iraqis have been slow to use them.

headline: Unfurling a Thousand Years of Gods, Demons and Romance
text: “Storytelling in Japanese Art,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is a captivating combination of show and tell, read and look. Curatorially speaking, the exhibition takes us gently in hand and, through text panels, captions and diagrams, reveals the narrative side of Japanese art with memorable clarity.

headline: YouTube Redesigns Its Web Site to Promote Personalized Video Channels
text: YouTube, though one of the most popular sites on the Web, has always been a bit overwhelming, with its avalanche of videos, more than 48 hours of which are uploaded each minute.

headline: What a Scale Can’t Measure
text: I HAVE outweighed most of the men I’ve loved in my life. To be fair, most of them have been thin: my first boyfriend was 6-foot-2 and weighed just 135 pounds, and he was followed by a string of maddeningly slender sorts.

headline: Russian Authorities Pressure Elections Watchdog
text: MOSCOW — With parliamentary elections only days away that are expected to reflect dwindling public support for Vladimir V. Putin’s party, Russian prosecutors have opened a case against the country’s only independent election monitoring organization.

headline: Extended Interview with Zainab Alkhawaja
text: More of an interview with Zainab Alkhawaja, an opposition activist in Bahrain whose Angry Arabiya Twitter documents the protest movement.

headline: House’s Sergeant-at-Arms Retires After 17 Years
text: Wilson Livingood, the sergeant-at-arms of the House of Representatives and known as Bill, is retiring after 17 years. Mr. Livingood, who spent 33 years in the United States Secret Service, was the first person to serve in the position with a significant law enforcement background; the position was historically filled by a political appointee.

headline: The Physical Ecstasy of Worship, and the Travails of Those Who Tread Its Path
text: The spiritual utopian movement known as the Shakers has all but disappeared in America. (The group’s tenet of celibacy does a number on recruitment.) But its allure for artists appears to be holding steady, with choreographers, including Twyla Tharp and Tero Saarinen, especially drawn to the Shaker tradition of worship through movement and song.

headline: Madison Square Church Survives in Fragments
text: Madison Square Presbyterian Church was one of New York’s shortest-lived houses of worship. Designed by Stanford White, this Palladian building opened on 24th Street in 1906 and was razed in 1919 to make way for insurance offices. Architects and preservationists mourned its demise and descended on the wreckage for souvenirs.

headline: Out There | Miami’s ‘It’ Couple
text: Tropical, blinged-out hedonism aside, there is actually such a thing as community in Miami. After the droves who come for Art Basel pack up and go, there are folks — artists among them — who stick around, living and working here throughout the year. They do tend to be at their busiest during the fairs, and the artists Jim Drain and Naomi Fisher are no exception.

headline: Starting a New Era With Graciousness, Taste and Tradition
text: When Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opened its annual season at City Center on Wednesday, it did so under a new artistic director, Robert Battle. But an Ailey gala is a set ritual, a glamorous fund-raiser as much about donors as about dancers, and in conforming to the standard of years past, this one sent a message of continuity.

headline: Shadowy Lure of Scandinavia Fights the Bright Pull of Paris
text: The Armory Show was not the first or only ambitious effort to open American minds to European modern art in the early 20th century. Just two months before that show’s New York debut in February 1913, another big exhibition of progressive art appeared here. Organized by the nascent American-Scandinavian Foundation, “Exhibition of Contemporary Scandinavian Art” offered more than 150 works by Danish, Norwegian and Swedish artists, many of whom favored Post-Impressionist, Expressionist and Symbolist modes that were still viewed with suspicion on this side of the Atlantic.

headline: Funkadelic Sold Here, on Vinyl

headline: He’s the Hero of the People, and He Hates It
text: As soon as a thrilling Ralph Fiennes appears on “Coriolanus,” it’s clear why he chose this lesser-known Shakespeare tragedy for his directing debut. Dressed in camouflage fatigues, Mr. Fiennes — as the mythic Roman military hero first known as Caius Martius and later Coriolanus — enters a raucous scene and commands it with just a glare. What power! The city’s hungry, rioting citizens, some carrying protest signs and one holding a camera phone, have descended, demanding food. Martius charges at them and then lets loose the contempt that will aid in his downfall: “What’s the matter, you dissentious rogues, that, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion, make yourselves scabs?”

text: Rachel Uffner Gallery

headline: Tommy Thompson to Run for Senate

headline: A Rising Generation of Artistic Resistance
text: Nearly three years ago they were “Younger Than Jesus.” Now that generation of emerging artists (born between the mid-1970s and the mid-’80s) is being called “The Ungovernables,” at least by curators at the New Museum, organizing its second Triennial.

headline: Peter Thiel’s Founders Fund Raises $625 Million
text: There is no cash crunch for Silicon Valley’s 1 percent.

headline: Glocer, Chief Executive of Thomson Reuters, Is Being Replaced
text: Thomson Reuters said Thursday that it was replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, who had struggled to turn around the financial news and information service in an increasingly competitive market.

headline: Looking Back at Lincoln
text: Once seen as a top luxury brand, Lincoln has been struggling to reinvent itself.

headline: Ford Strives for Elegance in Lincoln Brand
text: DEARBORN, Mich. — Every successful luxury car needs an identity for which consumers will pay a premium. Mercedes has its classic looks. Lexus epitomizes creature comforts. For BMW, performance is important.

headline: For Mets, Bullpen Remains a Priority
text: The members of the Mets front office will head to Dallas this weekend for the baseball’s winter meetings with their priorities in this still-developing free agent market unchanged since September.

headline: An Activist Stands Her Ground in Bahrain
text: During a protest in Bahrain on Saturday, an American journalist named Matthew Cassel reported on Twitter that he had just witnessed something remarkable: a lone female protester who refused to move as police officers in riot gear charged past her, firing tear gas shells just a few feet from her head.

headline: Just One Look | Michael Kors
text: The Michael Kors pre-fall collection, which was shown earlier this afternoon, paid homage to Ann Taylor — not the retail chain but the Southern socialite whom Kors described as “Nan Kempner on the range.” Graphic country looks came with built-in leather harnesses (rodeo-girl waistlines were key), appaloosa prints and a sinewy Chesterfield coat, all of it accessorized with cowboy hats and silver-studded satchels. Here, a dip-dyed goat-fur vest paired with wool riding shorts and a black leather bandolier bag is Southampton meets Santa Fe.

headline: United Nations Says Unrest in Syria Amounts to Civil War
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations declared Thursday that Syria was in a state of civil war, as the death toll from nearly nine months of bloodshed rose to more than 4,000 people and more soldiers were reported to have defected from the army to join an armed uprising against President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Tailgating Recipes: Puff Pastry Samosas
text: One thing we’ve learned about tailgating parties this year is that they’re inclusive — everybody’s welcome. Now we’ve got to feed all of those people, even the vegetarians. Nithya Das, a Giants fan and vegetarian living in Brooklyn, has been to plenty of pregame festivities only to find brats and barbecue.

headline: Songs About Friendship, Performed With His Pals
text: The pursuit of aloneness — in a deep-focus, self-obliterating sense — seems to mean a lot to the trumpeter Nate Wooley. An improviser with a tactile, patient, interrogatory approach to his craft, he belongs to the avant-garde jazz tradition but doesn’t press the issue of lineage. His two most recent albums are solo trumpet recordings: sealed-off worlds of serenely disquieting technique, with and without electronics. His baseline tone is unvarnished and autumnal, but he does so much else, in the realm of scrunches and striations, that it’s a fair question whether he has a baseline tone at all.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Vulnerable Printers and Siri’s Politics
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web.

headline: Pop Stars Dominate Major Grammy Categories
text: If the Grammys are a barometer of trends in popular music, then old-school pop songs about unrequited love made a comeback this year. The pop stars Adele and Bruno Mars dominated nominations for the top prizes — to be given out at the 54th annual Grammy Awards in February — while hip-hop and country musicians were largely shut out.

headline: A Portrait of the Artist as Exuberant Collector
text: “Selections From the Private Collection of Robert Rauschenberg” at the Gagosian Gallery is a kind of mash note to the art world. Wending through spaces on three floors and numbering 130 items, it testifies both to the loose constellations of artists and to the congeries of artworks, objects and memorabilia that often form just in the process of living around artists, especially important, instinctively generous ones.

headline: Assemblyman’s Chief of Staff Is Arrested in Bribery Case
text: The chief of staff to William F. Boyland Jr., an assemblyman arrested this week on charges of soliciting and accepting thousands of dollars in bribes from undercover federal agents posing as eager businessmen, was arrested on Thursday in connection with the alleged scheme.

headline: Out There | Art Basel, More Parties and, Yes, Some Art
text: Wednesday morning, the 10th edition of Art Basel opened for preview. But first a stop at the Rubell Collection was in order for an experiential snack by the artist/cook/daughter Jennifer Rubell. Her breakfast installation this year is called “Incubation,” with yogurt incubating in a grid of sleek fermentation machines and honey perpetually drizzled from overhead — a commentary, according to the press release, on “the creation of food, the creation of life and the creation of art,” among other things, surely.

headline: Women’s Soccer College Cup Will Produce a First-Time Champion
text: The 2011 College Cup, for many, will be a weekend filled with firsts.  The women’s soccer N.C.A.A. semifinal games take place Friday evening at the Kennesaw State University Soccer Stadium in Kennesaw, Ga. — and though the field is filled with the traditionally successful soccer programs, none of the four remaining teams has yet won a national championship.

headline: Julia Leigh on 'Sleeping Beauty'
text: Julia Leigh, the director of the drama "Sleeping Beauty," discusses her film.

headline: Benevolent Monarchs Of the Songbook Realm
text: To watch Michael Feinstein and Barbara Cook share musical lore onstage is the next best thing to attending a master class on how to sing popular standards. Ms. Cook, who actually conducts master classes on “living” inside a song while singing it, never hits a false emotional note. And Mr. Feinstein is the ultimate singing professor, whose perfect pitch coincides with a photographic memory for lyrics. Woe to the performer who takes liberties with words that he views almost as sacred texts.

headline: Disparate Players, Evoking Familiar Sounds
text: Not so long ago female musicians’ effort to gain entry to major professional orchestras was a subject for hot debate. Today, however, women constitute a healthy proportion among most American orchestras and a majority in more than a few. Progress remains to be made, not least on the conducting podium. But for the most part the situation appears to have improved dramatically for rank-and-file players and even for principals.

headline: Newt 2.0
text: A resurgent Newt Gingrich tops the polls in the campaign to be the Republican candidate for president.

headline: State Fracking Hearings Drew 6,000, N.Y. Says
text: Proposed regulations governing the natural gas drilling process known as horizontal hydraulic fracturing drew 6,000 people to four public hearings in New York State and have so far elicited more than 10,600 written public comments, the state Department of Environmental Conservation said on Thursday.

headline: An Illicit Romance, a Revenge Wrought and an Escape From Egypt
text: Some people still find Rossini’s serious operas a little, well, tedious. Even the writer of the program synopsis for “Moïse et Pharaon” (“Moses and Pharaoh”), which the Collegiate Chorale and the American Symphony Orchestra performed at Carnegie Hall under James Bagwell on Wednesday evening, evinced frustration with the opera’s plot. “It takes another three acts to let the people go,” he or she dryly summarized after describing the opening.

headline: Hard-Core Gamers Try Building Social Games
text: Social game makers like Zynga have gotten hundreds of millions of people to play their games, but one of the big raps on FarmVille, CityVille and other Facebook time-wasters is that they’re too shallow to appeal to hard-core players.

headline: Objectification Is Also in the Eye of the Beheld
text: Sexuality can be a puzzle — just ask Carl Jung, the kinky and conflicted psychoanalyst played by Michael Fassbender in “A Dangerous Method,” or Brandon, the sex addict played by Michael Fassbender in “Shame.” Or, if you insist on exploring the complexities of eros in a new movie not starring Mr. Fassbender, you might check out “Sleeping Beauty,” Julia Leigh’s sly and elusive film, which is itself something of a puzzle.

headline: For Wall Street Watchdog, All Grunt Work, Little Glory
text: ROCKVILLE, Md. — Last week, when a former Boston Red Sox infielder faced accusations of insider trading, the Securities and Exchange Commission got credit for levying a $100,000 fine. The Department of Justice in May heralded a guilty plea from a one-time senior executive at the Nasdaq Stock Market who traded on secret information. And earlier this year, after a lawyer was accused of stealing insider tidbits, federal prosecutors in New Jersey boasted of the arrest.

headline: Foot Stomping in Bluegrass Time
text: AFTER Jennifer Shaoul’s tae kwon do instructor died five years ago, she struggled to find a replacement for the exercise she so dearly loved. Ms. Shaoul found an unlikely substitute this fall: clog dancing.

headline: Punishing Wrongdoing on Wall Street
text: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Storytelling in Japanese Art’
text: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: At Thomson Reuters, Corporate P.R. Mirrors Real Life
text: In an unfortunate bit of symbolism, Thomson Reuters is sponsoring a team race to the South Pole at the same time that the fortunes of its chief executive, Thomas Glocer, appear to be headed south, as well.

headline: Opponent of Antipiracy Bill Backs Counterproposal
text: LOS ANGELES — Senator Ron Wyden, who has said that he would filibuster the antipiracy Protect I.P. Act because it threatens a free Internet, now has a counterproposal on the table: let the International Trade Commission go after those who sell pirated copyrighted material on the Web from abroad.

headline: Theater Listings for Dec. 2-8
text: Theater

headline: Winged Migrants in Their Brooklyn Pied-à-Terre
text: “THERE are rumors of an owl,” Michele Dreger told me in a hushed voice, as if the great bird might hear her and be scared off. “Maybe, maybe, there might be, maybe, an owl.”

headline: The Violence That Japanese Gangsters Do: Betrayal Among the Yakuza
text: In “Outrage,” a new yakuza story from Takeshi Kitano, the assaults on the human body are frequent, brutal and at times accompanied by cruel comedy. One man nearly loses his sight; another surely loses his hearing (chopsticks go where none should); and a third suffers a gruesome, teeth-shattering assault during a dental exam, an attack that suggests that Mr. Kitano may have watched “Marathon Man” in the decade since he directed “Brother,” his last yakuza film. Whatever their inspirations, these baroque spasms of violence — evoking see, hear and speak no evil — are just a few of the tortures that he rains down on his characters like a vengeful, mocking god.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: With the holidays coming up, the Miser has been on the lookout for entertainment to satisfy both visiting in-laws and antsy children on school break. Here is a roundup of group-friendly winter activities that will raise your spirits without gouging your budget:

headline: Negotiations Under Way for Special Session in Albany on Budget Shortfall
text: Facing an increasingly worrisome budget outlook, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders are in negotiations to return to Albany for a special session later this month, an official briefed on the negotiations said on Thursday.

headline: The Blood Runs Freely, but the Dogs Can’t
text: This being the season for Oscar puffery and pretention, it’s also the time of the year when moviegoers who yearn for more action and less talk can be forgiven for thinking that what’s missing from the big screen is a good beat down. It could use one: this hasn’t been a memorable year for cinematic action, aside from a quicksilver move here and there and that gone-in-60-seconds moment in “Drive” when Ryan Gosling glides a car into park. But now there’s “The Yellow Sea,” a rush of a movie from South Korea that slips and slides from horror to humor on rivers of blood and offers the haunting image of a man, primitive incarnate, beating other men with an enormous, gnawed-over meat bone.

headline: Bloggingheads: The 3-3-3 Plan
text: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Mickey Kaus of kausfiles debate raising taxes and the Occupy movement.

headline: Perfectly Perfect | Tory Burch
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Off the Mat, Into Court: Lawsuit Pits Bikram and Yoga to the People
text: Thursday’s 11:30 a.m. session at the Bikram Yoga NYC studio in the Flatiron District began as usual: a handful of half-dressed students slowly flapped their elbows as they decelerated their breath and stared at themselves in the mirror. After paying as much as $25 each, they began their mindful workouts in the 105-degree “Torture Chamber,” while outside on Fifth Avenue, pedestrians scurried past in coats.

headline: The Solyndra Loan Inquiry
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fury, Up Close and Personal, at the Lingering Effects From the BP Oil Spill
text: “The Big Fix” is an enraged exposé of the crimes of Big Oil, specifically BP, which has been accused of negligence and of taking shortcuts that helped lead to the explosion of the Deepwater Horizon rig off the Louisiana coast in April 2010. Eleven workers on the platform died and nearly five million barrels of oil spilled into the Gulf of Mexico over the next five months, killing vast numbers of marine animals before much of it washed ashore, where it wrought incalculable damage.

headline: In Egypt, No Alliance With Ultraconservatives, Islamist Party Says
text: CAIRO — The Muslim Brotherhood’s political arm on Thursday distanced itself from a more conservative Islamist party as early vote tallies indicated that the two factions would claim the two largest roles in the first Parliament elected since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: French President Warns of Dire Consequences if Euro Crisis Goes Unsolved
text: PARIS — Saying that he wanted to tell the truth to the French people, President Nicolas Sarkozy said Thursday night that Europe could be “swept away” by the euro crisis if it does not change. He said that Europe would “have to make crucial choices in the next few weeks,” and that France and Germany together were supporting a new treaty to tighten fiscal discipline and promote economic convergence in the euro zone.

headline: Dear Humans: The Planet Needs Your Help
text: Sturla Gunnarsson’s “Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie” is constructed around a speech that its Japanese-Canadian subject — an engaging, erudite scientist, educator, broadcaster and eco-activist — calls his “legacy lecture.” The talk, given in Vancouver last December, is a dire warning delivered in a reasonable, friendly voice about the imminent destruction of the biosphere that sustains humankind. Dr. Suzuki’s upbeat tone is the spoonful of sugar that makes the bitter medicine go down.

headline: For Women Only; Wear Your Sorority Pin
text: THE soaring Beekman Tower Hotel, at First Avenue and 49th Street, was an out-of-place landmark for years, until the United Nations went up. These days its dramatic Art Deco profile is not quite as prominent, a streamlined orange brick shaft built in 1928 as Panhellenic House, a residence for college women. The 61-year-old developer was Emily Eaton Hepburn, a real estate novice who created one of New York’s most distinctive skyscrapers.

headline: The Loneliness of a Brother’s Caregiver
text: Some fine performances and an embrace of understatement make Matthew Leutwyler’s oddly titled “Answers to Nothing” a respectable entry in the multiple-stories-that-interlock genre. It’s a bit jarring that the event around which these delicately told vignettes coalesce — the kidnapping of a girl — seems borrowed from a cheesy police thriller, but the film has its satisfactions nonetheless.

headline: The Dogs of War
text: The number of working dogs on active duty has risen to 2,700, from 1,800 in 2001, and the training school at Lackland Air Force Base in San Antonio, Texas, prepares about 500 dogs a year.

headline: The Time-Is-Now Apartment
text: IN an attempt to keep her living costs down in the dozen years she had lived in New York, Jessie Weber lived nomadically.

headline: Higher Loan Limits, Again, for Pricey Markets
text: LESS than two months after lowering the maximum loan amount that could be backed by the Federal Housing Administration, lawmakers in Washington reversed course just before the Thanksgiving holiday and once again raised that limit, offering home buyers more financing options in a tight credit market.

headline: Georgia Has a Chance to Put Its Mark on the SEC
text: ATHENS, Ga. — In Southeastern Conference play this season, No. 1 Louisiana State won its eight games by an average of 26.6 points, while No. 2 Alabama’s seven victories came by an average of 29.5. The reason for this dominance was simple: the Tigers and the Crimson Tide are ruthless at the point of attack, that spot where linemen crash into linemen and where being bigger and meaner is often the difference.

headline: ‘Zero-Energy’ Construction Crosses the Ocean
text: ENVIRONMENTALLY friendly and conservation-minded building techniques have been around for decades. But only in recent years have standards, like the LEED certification from the U.S. Green Building Council, been developed for builders to follow.

headline: Daughter’s Bittersweet Memoir of a Humanitarian Mother
text: The actress Dina Rosenmeier’s self-distributed documentary debut begins, innocently enough, as a work of impeccably trite ambitions. Retracing the jet-setting itineraries of Jessie Rosenmeier, a Ladies Circle humanitarian with a philanthropic interest in adorable children, “A Journey in My Mother’s Footsteps” retreads some familiar vanity-project trajectories: armchair travelogue, bittersweet filial memoir, feel-good humanitarian crusade.

headline: City Councilman’s Lawyer Calls Charges ‘Speculation’
text: During closing arguments in the federal corruption trial against City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook on Thursday, a defense lawyer urged the jury to weigh 30 years of public service against “so-called evidence.”

headline: Giants See Opening vs. Packers: Vulnerability to Big Plays
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On the first play of the fourth quarter Monday night, Giants wide receiver Victor Cruz knew right away that he had the opportunity to hit what he called the receiver’s equivalent of a grand slam.

headline: Lacrosse Player Comes Undone, and Grows
text: Ostensibly an inspirational film about a high schooler’s development of character, “A Warrior’s Heart” is factory-issue jingoism, yielding no surprises and frightfully few insights. Conor Sullivan (Kellan Lutz of the “Twilight” franchise, toting six-pack abs and an empty emotional quiver) is a lacrosse player from California newly arrived at a Virginia prep school. A showboating hothead lacking teamwork skills, he has much to learn. Why, he’s even mystified by the sight of a teammate praying before a game. (Some classmates facetiously address him by the nickname West Coast; others call him, yes, Captain America.)

headline: G.M. Offers to Buy Back Hybrid Volts From Owners
text: DETROIT — In a rare move, General Motors said Thursday that it would buy back Chevrolet Volts if owners were concerned about fire risks. It also promised to comply with any changes to its battery pack recommended by federal regulators.

headline: School Lunches
text: To the Editor:

headline: Teacher Evaluations
text: To the Editor:

headline: Q & A
text: Heavy Rain Causes Floors to Buckle

headline: ‘Walkable’ Steps Into Spotlight
text: WALKABILITY is an asset of an increasing number of Island communities as the fabric of suburbia changes, and it was a must for Judy Rosenthal, a health care writer from Great Neck, when she recently sought a new home for her mother not far from her own.

headline: An Intimate Tour of a Gleaming German Nuclear Plant
text: If “The China Syndrome” had been directed by Frederick Wiseman, it might have looked a little like “Under Control,” a gleamingly intimate tour of German nuclear power plants and the policies that sustain them.

headline: Some Like It Hothouse
text: THE sprawling 19th-century greenhouse owned by Dr. Alvin Friedman-Kien in Garrison is more than just a place to start tomatoes in advance of spring. With its wicker and wrought-iron furniture, a dining table that seats 12 and a fireplace, the 55-foot-long greenhouse is also an inviting backdrop for entertaining friends.

headline: Ex-Governor Is Said to Be Focal Point of Inquiry
text: PHOENIX — Bill Richardson, the former governor of New Mexico who ran for president in 2008, is being investigated by a federal grand jury for possible violations of campaign finance laws, according to people with knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: Lincoln’s P.R. Coup
text: In addition to the domestic challenge it presented, the fledgling Confederacy posed a foreign policy dilemma for Abraham Lincoln’s administration.
