The Confederacy hoped to use its position as a crucial source of cotton to secure recognition from foreign powers and boost its legitimacy, and it sent commissioners abroad to sway other countries into supporting its cause.

headline: Can Russia Help Us Withdraw From Afghanistan?
text: Washington

headline: ‘Are We Getting Some Money?’
text: Following are excerpts from the criminal complaint against Ry-Ann Hermon, the chief of staff to Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr., in which Ms. Hermon is recorded asking a cooperating witness about money. A few days later, another conversation was recorded between Ms. Hermon and an undercover federal agent.

headline: Firsthand Dangers of Reporters in Combat Zones
text: It didn’t used to be like this, says a correspondent interviewed in the documentary “Under Fire: Journalists in Combat.” “Once upon a time,” Ian Stewart says, “you could put ‘press’ up on your window, and you’d be fine, you’d be safe.”

headline: Help Line Open for Jets’ Ailing Offense
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — While the Jets’ offense has sputtered this season, Tom Moore has been watching from his home in South Carolina, where he works as the team’s offensive consultant.

headline: A New Google Venture, and Another Web Boundary Line Is Nudged
text: SAN FRANCISCO — In another foray into commerce, Google is working on a delivery service that would let people order items from local stores on the Web and receive them at their homes or offices within a day.

headline: Raids Don’t Keep Tunnel City From Humming Underground
text: TIJUANA, Mexico — Squatting and sweating inside the latest drug tunnel found here in this Pacific border city, it was easy to understand the amazement expressed by Mexican and American officials. This one was a stunner.

headline: Linked Stories From the Months of the Rwanda Massacre
text: “From my heart, I ask for forgiveness,” a Hutu killer says near the end of the weighty “Kinyarwanda.” Forgiveness would have to be a precious natural resource in Rwanda in 1994, after the genocide that left more than 800,000 dead, mostly Tutsis. Those atrocities are the horrific backdrop of the six linked story lines in this dry but thoughtful drama.

headline: Court Says Some Donors of Stem Cells Can Be Paid
text: A federal appeals court ruling on Thursday could make it easier for patients with diseases like leukemia to find matching bone marrow donors.

headline: Help With a Down Payment
text: WITH most lenders requiring home buyers to put down at least 20 percent — and sometimes, with more expensive properties, an even greater amount — the best holiday gift some people might receive would be help with the down payment.

headline: Santa Ana Winds, Unusually Strong, Rattle More Than Nerves in California
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Raymond Chandler famously described the winds here as “those hot dry Santa Anas that come down through the mountain passes and curl your hair and make your nerves jump and your skin itch.”

headline: Barbara van Beuren
text: Ms. van Beuren, 55, is a managing partner of Anbau Enterprises, a Manhattan developer that specializes in for-sale residential real estate. The company’s projects have included 110 Central Park South and 120 West 72nd Street.

headline: Two Research in Motion Employees Fined for Disruption on Plane
text: The police say that drunken unruliness by two executives of the BlackBerry maker Research in Motion forced the diversion and delay of a Toronto-to-Beijing flight on Monday. The two pleaded guilty to a criminal count of mischief and were suspended from their positions pending an investigation.

headline: A Big Uranium Deposit, and a Big Debate on Mining It
text: CHATHAM, Va. — Atop Coles Hill, a crown of oak trees encircle an old plantation house from which generations of Coles have looked down gently sloping lawns to fields that once grew tobacco.

headline: As a Financial Center, London Needs an Air Hub
First-Race Terrors and Last-Place Humiliations at a Horse-Racing School
text: At 5 a.m. in a very special boarding school not far from Paris, circus music blares from a bedside alarm clock. “I’m ill,” a sleepy boy moans, hoping to postpone the rigors of his day. Once we have seen those rigors, we can hardly blame him.

headline: For Jobless, Little Hope of Restoring Better Days
text: People across the working spectrum suffered job losses in recent years: bricklayers and bookkeepers as well as workers in manufacturing and marketing.

headline: Coach’s Plan to Rouse Ovechkin Produces Little
text: WASHINGTON — Two games into the new regime here, anxiety about the decline of the Capitals star Alex Ovechkin has yet to subside. On Thursday, Washington lost, 2-1, to Sidney Crosby and the Pittsburgh Penguins, the Capitals’ eighth defeat in their last 10 games.

headline: As Tastes Change in Harlem, Old-Look Liquor Store Stirs a Fight
text: Many neighbors agree that their genteel enclave of brownstones in the heart of Harlem does need a shop where they can pick up, say, a good cabernet for a dinner party.

headline: Gun Nuts in a Rut
text: PHOENIX — When it became clear in the early fall of 2008 that Barack Obama, son of a Kansan and a Kenyan, would be the 44th President of the United States, many citizens rushed to their gun shops, stocked up on ammo and camo, and tried to fortify their nests with all manner of lethal weapons.

headline: For-Profit Colleges
text: To the Editor:

headline: Sharing a Guarded Legacy
text: WHEN a curator from the Palazzo delle Esposizioni in Rome contacted Betty and George Woodman a dozen years ago, he made what would be, for most parents, a welcome request. He wanted to borrow from the Woodmans’ cache of rare vintage prints by their daughter — the photographer Francesca Woodman, who died in 1981 — to mount a show of her work.

headline: Chicanery Far Beyond a $156 Bagel
text: In the annals of deranged expense accounts, a City Council member’s claim of $156 for a bagel may be small in scale, but worth every cent in audacity.

headline: After Pushing Gay Marriage, Cuomo Is Thanked With Money
text: In the aftermath of New York’s legalization of same-sex marriage this summer, gay men and lesbians lionized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, showering him with gratitude, praise and awards. Now, they are rewarding him with something more tangible: campaign cash.

headline: Senate Declines to Clarify Rights of American Qaeda Suspects Arrested in U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Thursday decided to leave unanswered a momentous question about constitutional rights in the war against Al Qaeda: whether government officials have the power to arrest people inside the United States and hold them in military custody indefinitely and without a trial.

headline: Health Care for a Changing Work Force
text: Big institutions are often slow to awaken to major social transformations. Microsoft was famously late to grasp the importance of the Internet. American auto manufacturers were slow to identify the demand for fuel-efficient cars. And today, the United States government is making a similar mistake: it still doesn’t seem to recognize that Americans no longer work the way they used to.

headline: Syracuse Criticized for Its Handling of Sexual Abuse Case
text: When Bobby Davis sent an anonymous e-mail to Syracuse University in 2005, saying that the associate men’s basketball coach Bernie Fine had molested him, the university asked its legal counsel to start an investigation.

headline: Luden’s Recasts the Lozenge, Emphasizing Taste and Versatility
text: NOBODY wants to be on the tip of consumers’ tongues more than a lozenge maker, and Luden’s, the brand known for its wild cherry flavor, is renewing its efforts to do just that.

headline: Contractor’s Work Faulted at U.S. Pension Guarantor
text: A small company with a big contract to determine how much the government pays people whose pension plans have failed got the numbers wrong, a new audit has found.

headline: Democrats See an Advantage in Debate Over Payroll Tax
text: WASHINGTON — After struggling all year for an economic message that resonates broadly with Americans in hard times, President Obama and Congressional Democrats have settled on one they believe can carry through next year’s election as they use a fight over payroll taxes to portray Republicans as defenders of the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.

headline: 18 Months After Vote, Belgium Has Government
text: BRUSSELS — The financial markets have finally done what 18 months of talks, a large protest march and a series of bizarre demonstrations failed to do: broken Belgium’s political deadlock.

headline: The Spirit of Enterprise
text: Why are nations like Germany and the U.S. rich? It’s not primarily because they possess natural resources — many nations have those. It’s primarily because of habits, values and social capital.

headline: The Ball Still Belongs to the Stars
text: In one of the N.B.A. lockout’s signature moments, Commissioner David Stern wagged a scornful finger and Dwyane Wade snarled back. The testy exchange offered a convenient prism for viewing the labor crisis.

headline: The Tantalizing Lure of the Outsider Candidate
text: In what may yet be the last turn in Herman Cain’s bizarre journey through the world of presidential politics, the candidate will return home to Atlanta this weekend for a meeting with his wife and family, so they can decide whether it still makes sense for Mr. Cain to continue his campaign.

headline: For Afghan Woman, Justice Runs Into Unforgiving Wall of Custom
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — When the Afghan government announced Thursday that it would pardon a woman who had been imprisoned for adultery after she reported that she had been raped, the decision seemed a clear victory for the many women here whose lives have been ground down by the Afghan justice system.

headline: Killing the Euro
text: Can the euro be saved? Not long ago we were told that the worst possible outcome was a Greek default. Now a much wider disaster seems all too likely.

headline: German Fears About Inflation Stall Bold Steps in Debt Crisis
text: BERLIN — Norbert Schulze was not yet born when the hyperinflation of the 1920s deeply scarred the German psyche. But he still remembers the Reichsmark notes denominated in millions and billions that years later were tucked into a box with the family’s old black-and-white photographs.

headline: The Quiet Regulators
text: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, Wall Street's nonprofit self-regulator, has quietly been building a small army of market police in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: After Fetus Is Found in Trash, a Rare Charge of Self-Abortion
text: A superintendent in Washington Heights was tying up a garbage bag on Tuesday evening when he felt an errant piece of plastic. He reached into the bag to put it in the recycling bin, and to his horror, he said, “that’s when I saw the baby.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
The Bill of Rights Doesn’t Come Cheap
text: Palo Alto, Calif.

headline: Valentine and Red Sox Start Afresh
text: BOSTON

headline: ‘Bonnie & Clyde’
text: Photos from the new Broadway musical.

headline: Friday: Ones Who Might Get You Into Hot Water
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — The comedian Emo Philips once did a bit about using chocolate Easter bunnies as a diagnostic tool in psychotherapy. I don’t remember exactly how it went, but to paraphrase, he was told that the first part he bit off would clue the therapist in to where his problem lies: if he bit off the ears first, for example, it meant that he was relatively normal; if he bit off the feet first, it meant he felt he wasn’t getting anywhere in life. His reply: “What if I bite out the eyes and scream ‘Stop staring at me!‘?”

headline: Lebanon Sends Funds to Court
text: The United Nations-backed tribunal investigating the killing of a former Lebanese prime minister said Thursday that it had received the long-overdue half of its budget from Beirut, about $32 million. Many in Lebanon’s government, dominated by the militant group Hezbollah, had opposed cooperating with the court. The court has indicted four Hezbollah members as suspects in the 2005 killing of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri. Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, said Thursday that although he disagreed with the payment, his party and its allies would not stop it. “We reject the legality and constitutionality of financing the court or cooperating with it in any way, but we will not cause a problem in the country, and we will serve the higher national interest,” he said in a televised address. He has promised, however, that the government will never arrest the indicted Hezbollah members. The court is debating whether to try them in absentia.

headline: The Fed and the Euro
text: The Federal Reserve’s move on Wednesday to make it easier for European banks to acquire dollars shows that American policy makers understand the gravity of Europe’s turmoil and will do what they can to prevent a financial collapse across the Atlantic. European leaders, however, seem paralyzed and, even at this point, fail to share the Fed’s sense of urgency.

headline: Insight Into Dropping of Charges for Developer
text: A newly released court transcript offers an unusually frank statement by a federal prosecutor in Manhattan about why the government agreed to drop charges against a real estate developer who was a co-defendant in the broad public corruption case that ensnared State Senator Carl Kruger.

headline: Lots of Company After Lonely Session
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — When a team official entered the press room at the Knicks’ training center shortly after noon on Thursday and informed everyone that Carmelo Anthony was in the building, about half of the two dozen reporters who were waiting for some Knick, any Knick, to talk to jumped up in anticipation. And then they waited some more.

headline: Woeful, Cynical Misconduct
text: The depth of prosecutorial misconduct in the 2008 trial of Senator Ted Stevens is shocking. An inquiry ordered by Judge Emmet Sullivan of Federal District Court in Washington has found “serious, widespread and at times intentional” concealment of evidence by the Justice Department that could have helped Mr. Stevens prove his innocence. The department has a separate inquiry that must point the way to repairing the public integrity section, which is responsible for prosecuting public officials.

headline: Savoring Bogs and Moose, Fearing They’ll Vanish as the Adirondacks Warm
text: PAUL SMITHS, N.Y. — Jerry Jenkins, an ecologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, narrates with encyclopedic precision the serene, timeless landscape of the Osgood River, as he moves past it with each dip of his canoe paddle.

headline: Exam Cheating on Long Island Hardly a Secret
text: GREAT NECK, N.Y. — The suspected test takers came from prominent, respected families, some of them in financial distress — among the five facing felony charges were the sons of a well-known lawyer, the president of the local library board and a wealthy philanthropic family.

headline: Sneaking Up on Defenses, Until He’s Past Them
text: GREEN BAY — Eleven games into his breakout season, Green Bay Packers receiver Jordy Nelson did not need a calculator or even his fingers to count the number of times that he had faced double coverage this year.

headline: Louis Silverstein, Who Gave a Bolder and Airier Look to The Times, Dies at 92
text: When The New York Times began publishing on Sept. 18, 1851, it was the New-York Daily Times. — without a “The” but with a period. When the newspaper took its present name six years later, the hyphen stayed (until 1896), and so did the period, until 1967. That was the year that Louis Silverstein, with the nervous approval of his tradition-minded superiors, got rid of it, ending more than a decade of debate.

headline: Bach to Brooklyn
text: When she first tied up an old steel barge next to the Brooklyn Bridge 35 years ago, curious longshoremen noted tiny, mop-haired Olga Bloom coming and going with a violin, mysterious as a Magritte figure. But Ms. Bloom soon charmed the men into hefting a grand piano aboard. She repaid them with what was one of her first classical musicales by the fireplace tucked in the wood-paneled coffee barge.

headline: Armed and Amorous, Committing Cold-Blooded Musical
text: That Clyde Barrow is such a cutup. Why, the boy will do most anything to stir up his sluggish fellow Americans: slap at them, tickle them, shoot them in cold blood. He’ll even punch his fist clean through a wall and drive a big old car right onto the stage, just to try to get a rise out of somebody. But Clyde, honey, t’ain’t nothing you can do to raise the pulse of something that’s as near to dead as the show you’re in.

headline: Egypt’s Vote
text: Egyptians proved their mettle again this week by turning out in huge numbers to begin electing their first freely chosen Parliament. To get to this point, they had to force the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, and tens of thousands braved a vicious crackdown in recent days to protest the army’s hold on power. Voters showed courage and will to move to build a new democratic order.

headline: Drilling Down: Archive of Oil and Gas Leases
text: The New York Times has collected over 110,000 oil and gas leases and related documentation through open records requests sent about hydraulic fracturing and land leases in more than six dozen counties in which the practice is common.

headline: A Layman’s Guide to Lease Terms
text: Lawyers and consumer advocates say that leases often contain or lack fine print that landowners should not overlook in signing leases. Here are some examples of key clauses that landowners have come to regret:

headline: Learning Too Late of the Perils in Gas Well Leases
text: After Scott Ely and his father talked with salesmen from an energy company about signing the lease allowing gas drilling on their land in northeastern Pennsylvania, he said he felt certain it required the company to leave the property as good as new.

headline: Documenting Climate Change in the Adirondacks
text: Jerry Jenkins, an ecologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society, has been documenting climate change closer to home, specifically in the Adirondacks.

headline: Shop at Work, and Save America?
text: Should employers be worried about lost productivity, or grateful to workers who are always online?

headline: Behind the Scenes of the Front Office’s Decision
text: BOSTON — Larry Lucchino, the Boston Red Sox president, recently took Ben Cherington, the team’s new general manager, to a conference in Hartford to meet Bobby Valentine for the first time.

headline: François Lesage, Who Led Embroidery Atelier, Dies at 82
text: François Lesage, who for more than a half-century led the embroidery atelier that has served couture designers from Charles Frederick Worth through Karl Lagerfeld of Chanel, died on Thursday in Versailles, France. He was 82.

headline: Republican Leaders Still Seem Torn About Romney
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — Republican leaders remain bullish about their party’s chances of winning the White House, but after spending much of this year unsuccessfully trying to recruit new candidates, they are coming to the conclusion that their eventual nominee will carry substantial flaws into the general election.

headline: How the Auto Industry Fared
text: Winners and losers in the auto industry.

headline: Yankees’ Rivera to Have Surgery
text: Yankees closer Mariano Rivera said Thursday that he would have surgery on Friday to remove polyps from his vocal cords, an ailment that for the last month had bothered him whenever he tried to speak.

headline: Leader Says Qaeda Holds Abducted American Aid Worker
text: WASHINGTON — The leader of Al Qaeda said Thursday that the terrorist group was holding a veteran American aid worker kidnapped in Pakistan in August and demanded the end of airstrikes on militants and the release of prisoners held in the West in return for his freedom.

headline: After Opening a Door, Watching Anxiety Fade
text: Atom Thomas leafed through his little black sketchpad filled with intricate pencil and ink drawings of landscapes, street scenes and portraits of family members and celebrities like Jay-Z and Michael Jackson. He stopped on one drawing of an angel, wings spread, standing atop a cloud.

headline: Shades of the Old Woods on a Windy Day
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — Tiger Woods is the native Californian, but K. J. Choi of South Korea was the golfer who felt more at home Thursday during the first round of the Chevron World Challenge.

headline: Lawsuit Is Settled in Penn State Case
text: A lawsuit by one of the accusers in the Penn State sexual abuse case, which was meant to prevent the Second Mile charity founded by Jerry Sandusky from transferring its assets, was settled Thursday.

headline: South African Court Invalidates a Presidential Pick
text: JOHANNESBURG — President Jacob Zuma — at odds with the judiciary and critics who accuse him of improperly appointing loyalists to public posts — suffered a blow on Thursday when an appeals court ruled that he had violated the Constitution two years ago with his highly contentious pick for the country’s top prosecutor.

headline: The Hague: New Prosecutor Picked for International Criminal Court
text: A Gambian lawyer, Fatou Bensouda, is expected to succeed Luis Moreno-Ocampo next June as chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague. She emerged as the consensus candidate after the only other finalist, Mohamed Chande Othman of Tanzania, agreed to withdraw, diplomats said. All six cases before the young court are linked to African nations, and the majority of the 119 countries that recognize the court had favored an African candidate. Elections for the prosecutor and six judges will be held at the members’ annual meeting on Dec. 12. Mrs. Bensouda, 50, has been deputy prosecutor at the court, and served at the United Nations tribunal dealing with the genocide in Rwanda and as minister of justice of Gambia.

headline: Kentucky Sinks the Red Storm
text: LEXINGTON, Ky. — The St. John’s players gathered for strength through the flashing lights and pounding bass rhythms of the Kentucky Wildcats’ intimidating introductions. They faced the biggest challenge of the season in their first game on the road Thursday night, coming off a Nov. 26 loss to Northeastern to take on the No. 1-ranked Wildcats.

headline: China: Explosion at Bank Kills 2
text: A explosion shook a branch of the China Construction Bank late Thursday afternoon in Wuhan, a provincial capital in south-central China, a municipal police official there said, and state media reported that at least two people were killed and more than 10 were injured.

headline: Christa Wolf Dies at 82; Wrote of the Germanys
text: Christa Wolf, a leading writer from the former East Germany whose novels, stories and essays explored the weight of history on ordinary individuals, especially and controversially including her own struggles with the legacy of Nazism and life in a Communist society, died Thursday in Berlin. She was 82.

headline: Germany: Funds Increased for Jewish Organization
text: The German government will double its financing of the country’s Jewish community from next year on, the Central Council of Jews in Germany said in a statement. The group will receive an annual grant of $13.4 million a year, twice the current amount, for rebuilding Jewish life in Germany. The financing is part of an agreement that replaces a 2003 accord that gave the Jewish organization the same legal status as the major churches. The funds will be earmarked for the integration of Jewish immigrants; the training of rabbis, cantors and teachers; the support of religious research centers; and work with young people.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 76
text: “Scared to death” by Occupy Wall Street, the Republican strategist Frank Luntz shared some strategies for discussing the protest movement at the Republican Governors Association convention Wednesday. Among his suggestions: don’t say capitalism (“I’m trying to get that word removed”), and when referring to proposed tax increases on the 1 percent, call it “taking from the rich,” rather than taxing. [Yahoo’s The Ticket]

headline: Names Proposed for 2 New Elements on Periodic Table
text: Add two names to the periodic table of elements, although you may want to write them in pencil for now.

headline: Craigslist Used in Deadly Ploy to Lure Victims in Ohio
text: AKRON, Ohio — They were men thrown hard against the rocks of bad fortune — out of work, their marriages broken, their youth, with its possibilities, behind them.

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/02/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/02/2011

headline: Formerly Outlaws, Now Artists of Renown
text: Before they were in, they were out. Before crowds swamped the galleries and celebrities wrote checks, KC Ortiz and Jordan Nickel wielded spray cans, hopped fences, provoked the citizenry, got arrested — all to make Chicago’s streets, rooftops and el tracks their canvas.

headline: Word of the Day | deciduous
text: deciduous •\di-ˈsi-jə-wəs, -jü-əs\• adjective

headline: As Tax Receipts Lag, Another Hole Opens in Budget
text: Like any government budget, Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s first annual fiscal plan projects exactly how much the administration expects to reap in 2012 from the recently approved tax and fee increases, including the municipal tax on every hotel room stay.

headline: Education Group Tries to Rebound After Diatribe
text: An Oregon-based education group, whose deep pockets and skillful maneuvering made it a surprising powerhouse player in Springfield earlier this year, is regrouping after an embarrassing outburst by its founder forced a leadership shuffle within the organization.

headline: Manuel Gilman, Influential Racetrack Veterinarian, Dies at 91
text: Dr. Manuel Gilman, a veterinarian whose procedure for examining thoroughbred racehorses in New York became standard at racetracks around the country, improving safety for horses and jockeys and bolstering the sport’s integrity for bettors, died on Nov. 25 in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 91.

headline: In Detroit, an Effort to Prevent a State Takeover
text: Facing mounting pressure from Michigan’s governor to solve Detroit’s financial crisis, Mayor Dave Bing on Thursday stood beside union representatives and City Council members in a public show of unity, a last-ditch effort to keep the state’s largest city out of state control.

headline: Problems With Credits at School in the Bronx
text: The chances that a student at Jane Addams High School for Academic Careers in the Bronx would graduate in four years were already poor, but seniors there said this week that they had been told of a new obstacle: a problem with credits that could cost some of them their diplomas.

headline: My Kind of Town, and Now Maybe Your Kind of Domain Name
text: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Newswallah: In the English-Language Press Friday
text: The parliamentary panel drafting the anti-corruption bill has abruptly decided to exclude India’s graft-ridden “lower bureaucracy,” the six million municipal workers, policemen and clerks who interact most with the average person, from the proposed Lokpal bill. (Times of India). Expect the anti-corruption group Team Anna, which had fought for a tougher version of the Lokpal, to accuse the government of trying to pass a toothless law.

headline: Child Labor’s Fashionable Face
text: Chetan and Sarju wear low-waist, ice-wash, medium-skinny jeans that cost 500 rupees (about $9.60); open-neck cotton shirts with the sleeves rolled up to their elbows (150 rupees); and medium high-top canvas sneakers (300 rupees). Chetan’s sneakers are pink and inscribed with the letters “D&G”. Sarju’s blue sneakers simply say “Sports.” The 17-year-old cousins are from the Mumbai suburb of Jogeshwari.

headline: Can We Get Serious?
text: To select someone worthy of sitting in George Washington’s chair, sleeping in Abraham Lincoln’s bed and governing from Franklin Roosevelt’s desk, Americans crave a substantial presidential campaign, as long as they don’t have to endure too many boring speeches. Like every human decision-making process, presidential campaigns seesaw between the serious and the silly.

headline: Fatal Suicide Attack Outside U.S. Base in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber driving a truck inflicted scores of casualties outside a small American military installation on Friday and destroyed several government buildings, but failed to enter the American base, according to witnesses and Afghan officials.

headline: Hermon Complaint
text: United States vs. Ryan N. Hermon

headline: Boyland Complaint
text: U.S. vs. William F. Boyland, Jr.

headline: A Little Matter of 11 Weeks That Could Change Voting Results
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: New Air Quality Rules for Power Plants in Dispute
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Thursday that a series of new air pollution rules for power plants would not cause power shortages, although the expert panel designated by the government to ensure electricity reliability warns that compliance with these rules could strain generating capacity.

headline: Poor Economy Leaves More Children at Risk
text: Judge Darlene Byrne sat on the bench one Monday in November hearing the 28th case of the day on her Child Protective Services docket. The young woman before her was pregnant with her ninth child and wanted to reunite with her other eight children who were scattered among various homes.

headline: Schools Are Resigned to Robin Hood
text: When David Thompson is asked about Texas’ long history of school finance litigation, he likes to make a Harry Potter analogy.

headline: Corrections: December 2
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Newsom Stakes a Claim With Student Protests
text: Dozens of chanting protesters disrupted a public meeting of the University of California Board of Regents on Monday, driving all but one of the regents from the room.

headline: A Few Temporary Stores or a Neighborhood
text: To Alfonso Dominguez, calling his project to populate a mostly vacant stretch of downtown Oakland with locally minded retailers Popuphood is both literal (“The stores are popping up!”) and a bit of a tease.

headline: Dissident Leader in Myanmar Endorses U.S. Overtures
text: YANGON, Myanmar — The heroine of Myanmar’s democratic opposition, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, endorsed the new American engagement with the country’s autocratic government on Friday and called on other countries, including China, to support Myanmar’s nascent efforts to build a freer, more open society and economy.

headline: In Apartment Hunt, Looking Isn’t Free
text: When Divanny Lamas decided to move to San Francisco from Silicon Valley, she knew the hunt for an apartment would be competitive — but it was far worse than she imagined.

headline: Analysis Finds Incorrect Use of Ranked-Choice Voting
text: The results are in: San Francisco voters have trouble with ranked-choice elections.

headline: Older People Are a Larger Portion of U.S. Population
text: WASHINGTON — Elderly people are now a greater portion of the population than at any time since the government began keeping track, with those age 65 and older rising to 13 percent of the population over the past decade, the Census Bureau said.

headline: Massachusetts: Camp Allowed to Stay
text: A judge in Boston said Thursday that the Occupy Boston encampment in Dewey Square could stay for now, extending a temporary restraining order barring the city from removing tents or protesters from the area without a court order. Lawyers representing four demonstrators are seeking an injunction that would offer longer-term protection to the protesters. Judge Frances McIntyre said she would rule by mid-December, at which time the temporary order will expire.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 2, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Dec. 2, 1954 | Anti-Communist Senator McCarthy Is Condemned
text: On Dec. 2, 1954, the United States Senate voted, 67-22, to condemn Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, a Republican from Wisconsin, on two counts for conduct that “tended to bring the Senate into dishonor and disrepute.” The New York Times explained that he was condemned for “contempt of a Senate Elections subcommittee that investigated his conduct and financial affairs, for abuse of its members, and for his insults to the Senate itself during the censure proceeding.”The Senate’s resolution used the word “condemn” rather than the traditional “censure,” which sparked a debate over whether Mr. McCarthy had actually been censured — one senator went so far as to read from Webster’s Dictionary. The Times reported that, when asked if he thought he had been censured, Mr. McCarthy replied, “Well, it wasn’t exactly a vote of confidence.”

headline: Hazing Suspected in Death of Drum Major
text: WHO died at Florida A&M?

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 2, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “A Family’s Billions, Artfully Sheltered.”

headline: Intimate Moments Among Grand Gestures
text: How imperfect a pairing it seems: the silent, still, small-scale, black-and-white photograph and the sonorous, tumultuous, extravagant and kaleidoscopic opera.

headline: What Would You Put in Your Emergency ‘Go-Bag’?
text: A “go-bag” is defined by the New York City Office of Emergency Management as “a collection of items you can use in the event of an evacuation,” but in a recent Styles article, a reporter asked some well-known New Yorkers what other items they’d put in their bags besides basic emergency provisions. If you were leaving your home in a hurry in the event of a disaster, what items — irreplaceable because of their practical, sentimental or monetary value — would you make sure to include in your bag?

headline: Merkel Seeks Swift Action on What May Be Long Job to Save the Euro
text: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel on Friday called for swift action to amend European treaties to address the underlying causes of the debt crisis that has shaken Europe and jeopardized the future of the common currency.

headline: Indian History and Mystery in Liz’s Jewels
text: A part of Indian history is being auctioned off on December 13th in New York City when the late Elizabeth Taylor’s legendary jewelry will be up for bidding at Christie’s: the Taj Mahal diamond from 1627. Taylor received the stone, which is set as pendant, as a gift on her 40th birthday in 1972 from Richard Burton, whom she was married to at the time. Burton bought it from Cartier for 350,000 pounds, and Taylor had the jeweler replace its original silk chord with an adjustable diamond and ruby chain.

headline: Does Romney Have a Moderate Problem?
text: Mitt Romney is enduring a tough week. He now trails Newt Gingrich by 20 or more points in some state and national surveys. He had a testy interview with Brett Baier of Fox News, and then compounded the problem by complaining about Mr. Baier’s questioning later. A candidate whose presence in the race probably helped Mr. Romney, Herman Cain, is now in jeopardy of dropping out. Both Democrats and Mr. Romney’s opponents are putting out ads that hit Mr. Romney on what is perhaps his core vulnerability, his reputation for flip-flopping. Meanwhile, one of Mr. Romney’s greatest strengths, his strong positioning in New Hampshire, is at least a bit less certain now following the endorsement of Newt Gingrich by the Manchester Union-Leader.

headline: Not to be Outdone by Santa, St. Mikulas Brings Cheer to Prague
text: On the night of Dec. 5, don’t be nervous if you spot a bishop, angel and devil sitting together in a pub in Prague. Saturday is the celebration of St. Mikulas (Nicholas) — a Czech figure similar to Santa Claus — and while primarily an evening for children, it still brings a smile of remembrance to adults’ faces.

headline: Graffiti Muralists Reach Settlement in Case of Contentious Fiat 500 Commercial
text: After a series of highly public missteps over a Fiat commercial featuring Jennifer Lopez, in which the entertainer was depicted cruising past a copyrighted graffiti mural in the Bronx, a settlement has been reached with local artists who claimed to have never granted permission for their mural to be used in the spot.

headline: The Early Word: Framing the Fight
text: Today’s Times:

headline: ‘Sports for Dorks,’ and the Missing Ingredient in Football
text: The second of two excerpts from a new book, Sports for Dorks College Football, co-edited by Ferhat Guven and Mike Leach, the former Texas Tech coach who was hired this week by Washington State. The book is an anthology of ideas by various experts on innovations taking place in college football.

headline: Week 13 Matchups: We Don’t Want to Brag
text: Packers (11-0) at Giants (6-5)Sunday, 4:15 p.m.Line: Packers by 7.

headline: Student Loan Debt: Who Are the 1%?
text: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

headline: Zynga Sets Offering Price at $8.50 to $10 a Share
text: 8:03 p.m. | Updated

headline: Student Contest | Celebrate 2011 by Writing Raps About the Year’s News
text: The Year in Rap: 2010 from Flocabulary.

headline: Opening Big Without Spending a Fortune
text: This year, there was one Thanksgiving leftover that stuck with me more than the buttermilk pecan pie. It was a story my sister shared of a turkey-related grand opening event that sounded especially memorable. When Academy Sports and Outdoors, a Houston chain, opened a location in Auburn, Ala., a few years ago, it teamed up with a couple of local radio personalities to host a turkey-tossing event.

headline: For Federer, No Fading Away
text: After winning on the indoor courts in Europe for most of November, Roger Federer was in the sunshine at a distant, undisclosed resort with his wife, Mirka, and twin daughters. But even with sand between the toes and the rackets in temporary storage, tennis remained part of the lounge-chair conversation.

headline: Hope for the Giant Manta Ray
text: Efforts to protect declining populations of the giant manta ray are advancing: the sea animal, a peaceful cousin of the shark, has gained protection under the United Nations Convention on Migratory Species of Wild Animals.

headline: Profligate Zombies
text: Dean Baker has a series of posts about bad reporting on the euro crisis; he is evidently, and with good reason, upset at the way just about every report states as a fact that excessive borrowing caused the crisis.

headline: R.B.S. Sells Pub Business to Heineken
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland announced Friday the sale of its British pub chain to the Dutch brewing giant Heineken for £412 million, or $646 million.

headline: Cain Support Plummets in Iowa
text: As Herman Cain returns to Atlanta on Friday to discuss the future of his Republican presidential campaign with his family, a new poll in Iowa shows that his support has dramatically fallen in the state that opens the Republican nominating contest on Jan. 3.

headline: Your Questions for India’s Temp Workforce Guru
text: A recent article by Vikas Bajaj about India’s labor market has sparked a fierce debate about the difference between American and the Indian capitalism. We would like to know what you think and invite you to pose questions to Manish Sabharwal, the chairman of TeamLease, the company profiled in the article.

headline: Now Reading | ‘DarkMarket’
text: If style, per Gore Vidal, is about not giving a damn, then one might say cybercriminals have lots of style. “DarkMarket” (Knopf, $27), the new book by the T contributor Misha Glenny, disturbingly catalogs the capabilities of these nefarious Internet trolls — imagine, as Glenny does, that they could not only clog your in-box and steal your financial identity but attack your government, cripple your power grid or disable your national banking system. Still, the most common illicit activity on the Interwebs —  pornography aside  —  seems to be some form of personal credit card fraud. In fact, Glenny’s title, “DarkMarket,” comes from the name of a Web site where thousands of hackers coordinated the cloning and selling of credit card numbers and pins, often culled from illegally placed “skimmers” in A.T.M.’s and card machines. The site was infiltrated by an F.B.I. agent and taken down in 2008, resulting in many arrests.

headline: Walking New York’s Public Spaces
text: The best public spaces encourage diverse urban experiences, from people watching to protesting, daydreaming to handball, eating, reading and sunbathing to strolling and snoozing.

headline: Treasuring Urban Oases
text: Alexander Garvin, natty in bowtie and jacket, watched commuters hustle through the gray, sunken concrete plaza at Citigroup Center on Lexington Avenue. Across 53rd Street, in the fading afternoon light, more New Yorkers ducked into a faceless subway kiosk on the triangular patch of wind-swept sidewalk — ostensibly a second public plaza — that occupies the southeast corner. This is the city’s public realm, or part of it.

headline: Taking Back the Favelas
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Not long ago a city bus drove me by Rocinha, a sprawling favela of 100,000 people in southern Rio with a global reputation for violence. From the safety of my seat I watched the chaos. Beauty parlors were packed. Young people on motorcycles crisscrossed the paths at shocking speeds. A group of school girls giggled as they took pictures with their phones of flirtatious boys strutting by. Funk and samba music blared out of the bars. I loved the scene, but I wasn’t about to get off the bus for a walk.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: U.N. Says Action Needed to Prevent Civil War in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations high commissioner for human rights on Friday called for international intervention to protect Syrian civilians from the government’s crackdown, amid warnings that the country is headed toward civil war.

headline: Building a Weather App That Sees the (Near) Future
text: Weather forecasts are great at letting you know whether to grab an umbrella before leaving the house — but what if you needed to know if you had enough time to sprint to a car before a thunderstorm hit?

headline: ‘X Factor’ Watch: Payback for Simon Cowell
text: Simon Cowell finally paid a price on Thursday night for the weeks of verbal abuse he has hurled at his fellow “X Factor” judges, as they formed a voting bloc against him and tossed the first of his contestants from the competition. To say that he looked displeased at the end would be an understatement. He looked as if he were ready to bust some heads open.

headline: Opinion Report: Ted Stevens
text: From the editorial page

headline: Jobless Rate Dips to Lowest Level in More Than 2 Years
text: Somehow the American economy appears to be getting better, even as the rest of the world is looking worse.

headline: Design Miami | Back to the Future
text: Among Buckminster Fuller’s visionary designs was the “Fly’s Eye Dome,” a prefabricated fiberglass structure that was meant to be mass-produced and energy-efficient. This 24-foot prototype of the dome, which is now part of the Craig Robins Collection, is on display during Art Basel Miami Beach and Design Miami at the Palm Lot, at 140 Northeast 39th Street in the Miami Design District, which Robins developed; the dome will ultimately be installed in a pedestrian plaza in the district. It’s being shown along with a reconstruction, by the British architect Norman Foster, of the Dymaxion car, Fuller’s “omnidirectional transport system,” in the exhibition “Architecting the Future: Buckminster Fuller and Norman Foster,” curated by Daniel Reiser and Elizabeth Thompson. Here’s a time-lapse film that shows the dome’s installation in Miami.

headline: If Teaching Improves, Bloomberg Says Large Classes Are Fine by Him
text: UPDATED | In a talk at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology this week, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said he would choose higher quality teachers over smaller class sizes: “If I had the ability, which nobody does really, to just design a system and say, ex cathedra, 'this is what we’re going to do,’ you would cut the number of teachers in half, but you would double the compensation of them, and you would weed out all the bad ones and just have good teachers. And double the class size with a better teacher is a good deal for the students."

headline: Cookie Tray Theory Propels Student to D.C.
text: Packing cookies in a tray. That is the analogy a Stuyvesant High School senior, Brian Kim, of Bayside, Queens, uses to describe the math project that has put him in the finals of the annual Siemens Competition in Math, Science and Technology. Brian, whose parents are Korean immigrants, will compete this weekend in Washington for the top prize of a $100,000 college scholarship.

headline: RIM Says It Will Take a $485 Million Writedown on Heavy Discounts for Its PlayBook Tablets
text: OTTAWA — Research In Motion said on Friday that its previously unwanted BlackBerry PlayBook tablet was finally selling. But the steep discounts that prompted consumer interest in the device have forced the company to restate its earnings expectations.

headline: Verizon Wireless Buys Spectrum for $3.6 Billion
text: Verizon Wireless said Friday it had agreed to purchase spectrum licenses for $3.6 billion from a group of companies that included Comcast and Time Warner Cable, part of a push to meet growing consumer demand for wireless services.

headline: If This Acting Thing Doesn’t Work Out, Tilda Swinton Has a Plan B
text: The Bagger was lucky enough to interview Tilda Swinton the other night, for a TimesTalk, and sartorially and conversationally, she was a thrill, as always. Among La Swinton’s revelations: she hates the theater; doesn’t believe in the notion of fixed identity; prefers to think of herself as a “schizophrenic” writer-performer rather than an actor; and used to make a bundle betting on horses. (That’s her Career Plan B.) Ms. Swinton also talked about her work in “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” Lynne Ramsay’s controversial adaptation of Lionel Shriver’s novel about the mother of a son who goes on a Columbine-style rampage. In this clip, Ms. Swinton explains why she believes the film, which recently won the top prize at the London BFI Film Festival, is about more than the familiar facts of that story. “It’s about the inside of someone’s mind,” she said. “If you go into the film expecting that, you are much more likely to have a good trip.”

headline: Daily Report: Google May Step on Amazon’s Turf
text: In Friday’s New York Times, Claire Cain Miller and Nick Bilton report that Google is developing a package delivery service geared toward near-instant gratification. The service would let people order items on the Web from nearby stores and receive them within a day.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Hitchhiking to Heaven: Quince are in season, people: the ones I bought yesterday at the Greenmarket are destined for this recipe. And yes, they are supposed to have a downy gray fuzz on the outside. — Julia Moskin

headline: It’s More Than Holiday Spirit; It’s Having a Place to Call Home
text: As the afternoon sun sinks behind a row of two-family cookie-cutter houses on White Plains Road, Ana Jimenez’s front yard stirs to life. Within minutes, pancake-flat plastic blobs plump up with air, revealing jiggling Santas and a Nativity scene rising alongside wire-frame robo-reindeer, all ringed by strands of twinkling lights.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting for Dec. 2
text: The news and financial services giant Thomson Reuters announced a shakeup in its leadership late Thursday afternoon, Amy Chozick reported, replacing its chief executive, Thomas H. Glocer, after he had struggled to turn around the company in an increasingly competitive market. The Wall Street Journal put those declining fortunes starkly, quoting the projected 2011 breakdown of the $24 billion financial-data market by Burton-Taylor International Consulting: Thomson Reuters at 31.4 percent of the market, down from 37.4 percent in 2005; Bloomberg LP at 30.8 percent of the market, up from 25.1 percent in 2005.

headline: Parties Can Look to ’92 as a Guide for 2012
text: It was the last time a challenger defeated an incumbent to take the White House. The campaign was dominated by unemployment and the budget deficit. The party out of power coalesced around a nominee and drove him to victory only after a tumultuous primary season and complaints that the best potential candidates were sitting it out.

headline: Case Study | Gifts for Drinkers
text: As the season draws nigh, the calls begin from friends asking what they should get their bibulous spouses. Gifting, as a verb, needs a strategy, of course, and the one at work here supposes that most people have a semi-bar at home, a bit of this and a bottle of that, but could use another well-chosen item to connect the dots, to add a dash of panache to the occasional drink. That’s what 6 p.m. was made for, right?

headline: Commenting Shifts Into a New Gear
text: A new day has dawned in the comment-sphere on City Room and across nytimes.com, as many of you may have noticed when you’ve reached the bottom of an article or post, with a host of added features aimed at enriching the group conversation.

headline: Twelfth Tibetan Self-Immolates, but Survives
text: BEIJING — A former Tibetan monk set fire to himself as an anti-China political protest in Tibet’s Chamdo township on Thursday but survived, according to reports on Friday by Tibet advocacy groups. It was the 12th self-immolation by a Tibetan this year and the first inside Tibet.

headline: A Personal Walk Through Public New York
text: For my Arts & Leisure essay on public space in New York, I talked to Alexander Garvin. At “Zoning the City,” a recent conference held on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the city’s landmark 1961 zoning resolution, Mr. Garvin, a veteran urban planner, kept hammering away at the notion that government should zone more – and more wisely — for public space, as opposed to private development. Mr. Garvin is well known as a big fan of Paris, which Baron Haussmann largely demolished and redesigned for Napoleon III in the 19th century around grand boulevards, streets and pedestrian-friendly spaces. Paris today has become a museum city, for all its glories. Still, Mr. Garvin thinks Haussmann’s priorities provide a lesson for New York.

headline: SAT Cheating Investigation Continues on Long Island
text: Jenny Anderson and Peter Applebome take a deeper look in Friday’s Times at the SAT cheating scandal on Long Island.

headline: Friday Reading: A Layman’s Guide to Oil and Gas Leases
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: On Our Radar: China Hints at Emissions Timetable
text: For the first time, a Chinese official suggests that Beijing is “likely” to agree to a target for limiting its greenhouse gas emissions after 2020. But that depends on the outcome of international climate change negotiations in Durban, South Africa, he says. [China Daily]

headline: Israel Cancels Ad Campaign Aimed at Luring Expats Home From U.S.
text: Updated | 12:37 p.m. In response to anger from leading figures in the American Jewish community, on Friday Israel’s government halted an ad campaign that aimed to persuade Israelis living in the United States to return home by suggesting that living among Americans is a sad and lonely experience.

headline: With Leaves Gone, the City Comes Into View
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week’s image.

headline: Should Children Write Their Own Holiday Gift Lists?
text: Writing to Santa is an iconic holiday tradition, and one of the few that I dislike. Sure, that carefully penned letter — Dear Santa, please bring me a pony — is cute, what with the backward letters and the lopsided picture of a sleigh and such. But why should Santa, whose gifts come from the goodness of his heart, be told what to give? And how can someone whose toys are made by elves in a workshop be expected to produce a Wii? Then, there’s the obvious fact that a pony will never fit in the sleigh. (Please don’t ask for a puppy.)

headline: Pros and Cons of a Two-Bedroom
text: Vivian Toy has visited nearly 600 Manhattan co-ops and condos, mainly for the Real Estate section’s “On the Market” page. Here she casts a critical eye on a typical Manhattan two-bedroom.

headline: The Apartment Critic
text: RESTAURANT critics eat, and film critics watch movies. I check out apartments.

headline: ‘Tinker, Tailor’ and the Smell of Damp Tweed
text: 11:47 a.m. | Updated The Bagger has already discussed how difficult it was to adapt “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,” John le Carré’s classic thriller. But it was also difficult to cast the right actor to play the dour intelligence expert George Smiley, who had been memorably portrayed by Alec Guinness in the 1979 British mini-series.

headline: Q. and A. With Vivian Toy: The Apartment Critic
text: 7:07 p.m. | Updated  We are no longer accepting questions. Stay tuned for Vivian Toy’s answers on Friday.

headline: Loans Without Profit Help Relieve Economic Pain
text: When Hirshy Minkowicz was growing up in a Hasidic enclave of Brooklyn 30 years ago, he often noticed visitors arriving after dinner to meet with his father. They would withdraw into the study, speak for a time, then part with some confidential agreement having been sealed.

headline: Ethics Office Releases Report on Jackson’s Push for Senate Seat
text: House investigators examining the 2008 push by Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. to take the Senate seat being vacated by Barack Obama found “probable cause” that Mr. Jackson, an Illinois Democrat, directed one of his supporters to raise money for Rod Blagojevich, who was then the Illinois governor, in exchange for the appointment to the Senate, a detailed investigative report released Friday shows.

headline: Apple, and Planet, Low on Cats
text: Here’s a note I just posted on Twitter, with a bit of expanded context below:

headline: Honda Adds 273,000 Vehicles to Long-Running Air Bag Recall
text: In its fifth action to handle the same defect, Honda announced that it would recall 273,000 vehicles for defective air-bag deployment systems, a problem that has led to the recall of nearly 2 million Hondas since 2008.

headline: Weekend TV Guide, Dec. 2-5: Tracking U.S. Players … 4 Games in 4 Days
text: For fans of the United States national soccer team, there is usually a dearth of televised activity during the week and then a flurry of interesting games to watch on Saturday and Sunday. This weekend, not so much.

headline: Will 5,000 Passing Yards Eventually Be the Norm?
text: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers’ questions:

headline: Weekend Fare
text: A holiday tradition continues this weekend, when Le Parker Meridien hotel, 119 West 56th Street (between Sixth and Seventh Avenues) in Midtown West, will display gingerbread houses created by bakeries and restaurants across the city in its lobby. The exhibit, which runs through Jan. 6, is free but the public can vote for its favorite with a $1 ticket, to benefit City Harvest, sold at the concierge desk.

headline: Dispatch From a Hydrofracking Hearing
text: Governor Andrew Cuomo’s administration is considering whether to allow drilling companies to blast millions of gallons of water and other chemicals into underground shale formations in New York State to extract natural gas.  His Department of Conservation put out 2,000 pages of documents about this process, known as hydraulic fracturing or hydrofracking, in September, and wants all public comments by January 11.

headline: Come and Get It!
text: T’s Sally Singer discovered the work of Walter Martin and Paloma Muñoz, the artists who designed the T for our holiday issue, at the Museum of Art and Design, where a selection of their whimsical snow globes was on display as part of the group show “Otherwordly: Optical Delusions and Small Realities.” Indeed, the duo known for fabricating and photographing miniwinters in glass seemed a perfect fit for the season at hand. Here, the artists talk about their favorite storms, their preferred presents and the resolutions that rarely get made in the new year.

headline: House Panel Subpoenas Corzine to Testify in MF Global Inquiry
text: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

headline: Chennai’s Magical, Musical ‘Season’
text: Come December and Chennai begins to hum with the start of the kutcheri (classical music concert) season, referred to in the city simply as  the “Season.” It’s one of the largest music festivals in the world, with more than 1,500 concerts over six weeks at various locations.

headline: With Verizon’s $3.6 Billion Spectrum Deal, Cable and Wireless Inch Closer
text: In a deal that could remake the boundaries of the cable and wireless industries, Verizon Wireless said on Friday that it had agreed to acquire wireless spectrum from three cable companies at a cost of $3.6 billion.

headline: The Radical Transparency of Tilda Swinton
text: The Swintons are a distinguished old Scottish family. I heard that you guys have been living in the same home for over 1,000 years.

headline: Mom and Pop and More
text: MEETINGS of the leadership of A Child’s Place — a family-owned day care center, elementary school and afterschool program in northern Queens — do not always follow an agenda.

headline: Third-Generation Businesses
text: Three family businesses in New York City have managed to survive for three generations and counting.

headline: The Ninja Gold Miners of Mongolia
text: They’re called ninja miners not for their stealth but for the ubiquitous green panning bowls they sling over their backs.

headline: Nik Cohn’s Fever Dream
text: Barely a month after his 22nd birthday, the British reporter, novelist and pop critic Nik Cohn hunkered down in a cottage in Connemara, on Ireland’s craggy western coast. It was the spring of 1968. Political storms were whipping up in Prague and Paris and America. Connemara couldn’t have been farther away from it all, and that was the idea: writing 10 hours a day, no distractions and no breaks, and, at the end of a mere seven weeks, a book.

headline: Nerves or Something Worse?
text: It felt like a knife slicing through his right side. The young man lay in bed and tried not to move. He’d had this pain off and on for years — usually when he was nervous, and he was very nervous that Sunday morning. He was supposed to start a new job the next day.

headline: The Reckoning
text: After reading an article on Bosnia’s tourism boom, my brother, Eldin, and I decided it was time to face down our past. We reasoned that we were really doing this for our 72-year-old father, Senahid. If he didn’t see the country of his birth or his childhood friends soon, he never would. Yet within days I became obsessed with creating a to-do list for our trip: 1) Take a picture of the concentration camp my brother and father survived; 2) visit the cemetery where the karate coach who betrayed us was buried; 3) confront Petra, the neighbor who stole from my mother.

headline: Caveat Vendor
text: I work for a small retail company that is on the verge of going under. Some suppliers have already cut us off for nonpayment. The owner has asked me to place large orders with our remaining vendors, to buy some time to turn the company around. I think it’s more likely that these vendors (many of whom are sole proprietors or small businesses themselves) will never be paid. Placing those orders without telling the vendors about our situation isn’t illegal, but I think it’s unethical. What should I do? NAME WITHHELD

headline: Diablo Cody and Adult Onesies
text: Also: Matt Bai on F.D.R.-lust and Adam Sternbergh on things neither hot nor not.

headline: Hot Toddies at the Beagle in the East Village
text: With a snap in the air, the classic cocktail revival turns to traditional warmers like hot toddies. “In the old days, they’d warm the drink by putting a hot poker into the glass,” said Matthew Piacentini, who owns the Beagle in the East Village, which just started serving what he calls “twilight toddies.”

headline: Heaven Is a Place Called Elizabeth Warren
text: Elizabeth Warren may not be able to get huge, important bills through. That is not under the control of one person, even a senator. But imagine a really good law professor asking the questions in hearing after hearing after hearing. So many of the current members of Congress spend their time listing dull talking points. A good law professor knows how to call out a student who tries to duck a question. I want to see her do the same thing with a few bankers.

headline: Teaching Good Sex
text: As a 17-year-old girl, I have always found the traditional approach to sex ed, both in school and from parents, to be rather counterproductive. They aim to educate you in a manner that will allow you to have safe sex, but I feel that it teaches girls to feel bad about sex. It becomes a question of pleasing your parents or your boyfriend and not yourself. This article literally had me shedding tears of joy to think that an educated adult recognizes the confusion surrounding sex and seeks to address it in a manner that is free from shame or the pressure to do the “right thing,” whatever that may be. It’s not that I’m going to go out and sleep with someone tomorrow; I simply feel that I am free to operate how I see fit, regardless of cultural stereotypes that could make sex a negative experience.

headline: The Cardboard Beginnings of the Credit Card
text: In “Looking Backward,” Edward Bellamy’s 1888 novel about a socialist utopia more than a century hence, citizens are issued “credit cards” entitling them to shares of the national wealth. In today’s dystopian reality, people use a different sort of card to buy stuff on the Internet. Yet according to Robert Manning, a historian and author of “Credit Card Nation,” plastic remains “one of the top 10 innovations in the post-World War II period.” Even if it owes its ubiquity, in part, to a New York businessman named Frank X. McNamara, who forgot to bring cash to a lunch meeting. In 1950, McNamara introduced a cardboard charge card. He called it the Diner’s Club.

headline: The Foul Reign of Emerson’s ‘Self-Reliance’
text: My first exposure to the high-flown pap of Ralph Waldo Emerson’s “Self-Reliance” came in a basement classroom at the private boys’ school where I enrolled to learn the secrets of discipline and because I wanted, at age 14, to wear a tie. The class was early American literature, the textbook an anthology with the heft of a volume of the Babylonian Talmud; a ribbon for holding your place between “Rip Van Winkle,” by Washington Irving, and “Young Goodman Brown,” by Nathaniel Hawthorne; and a slick hardcover the same shade of green as the backside of a dollar bill.

headline: New Pollution Rules for Boilers and Incinerators
text: The Environmental Protection Agency on Friday released its much-delayed and oft-revised air quality regulations for industrial boilers and incinerators. The proposal is a modest refashioning of boiler rules introduced earlier this year, which were themselves a major revision of a 2010 plan by the agency that drew heavy political and industry opposition.

headline: The Bon Iver Grammy Quandary
text: One of the final topics that came up over the course of many sit-downs with Justin Vernon of Bon Iver when I was working on my magazine profile of him was the Grammy Awards. Or more precisely, his discomfort with them, and his incredulity that he’d ever be in contention for one.

headline: Justice Department Approves Google’s Purchase of Admeld
text: The Justice Department on Friday approved Google’s roughly $400 million acquisition of Admeld, an online display advertising company.

headline: Bad Mothers and Worse Mothers
text: For the first five years of my twin boys’ lives, I visited our town’s library each week, but only to scoop up heaps of picture books, diversions, when all else failed, that filled the time and calmed down their fighting. Now the boys are in kindergarten, learning to read, and so, in a way, am I again. On a recent Saturday, I let my sons page through books on their own in the children’s area of the library while I finally wandered among the tall shelves of fiction, which is where I stumbled on Penelope Lively’s “Moon Tiger,” a Booker Prize winner in 1987. Just a few days earlier, I had heard the writer Moni Mohsin on NPR describe the book on a terrific weekly segment called “You Must Read This.” So inspired had she been by the novel’s ambitious, selfish, literary hero, Claudia Hampton, Mohsin, at age 22, had quit the “worthy, dreary job” she had accepted shortly after finishing university and jumped into a job at an upstart newspaper. “Like Claudia,” she said, “I was determined to lead my life, not be led by it.”

headline: Syrians Say They Are Feeling the Grip of Sanctions
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — The walls are suddenly closing in around enterprising young Syrians who bought into the idea of a modernized economy promised by President Bashar al-Assad — their simplest money transfers are blocked, and their credit cards are useless outside Syria as the growing list of international sanctions darkens their financial future.

headline: The Strategy and Consequences of the N.F.L. Coin Toss
text: There are many ways to measure the lucklessness of the Cleveland Browns. The team has suffered through freakishly botched fourth-quarter field goals in each of the last three games, losing two of them as a result. Peyton Hillis, arguably the team’s best player, has come down with a severe case of the Madden Curse, and it seems likely that he will play for another team next season. During a trip to Indianapolis in September, the team showed up four hours later than expected after its plane got stuck in mud at the Cleveland airport.

headline: The Despair Index
text: President Obama never expected to campaign for re-election on lowering the jobless rate to pre-recession levels; all he really needs is a trend in the right direction. He got that this morning with the announcement that unemployment had fallen to 8.6 percent from its sticky 9 percent level most of the year, and you can expect to hear about that drop from the president and his surrogates for some time. It’s one of the best job reports in a long while.

headline: Ailey’s Torch Bearer Honors Another of His Inspirations
text: ON a recent afternoon at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, where dancers were about to perform a run-through of “Arden Court,” the sunny studio was a little too glaring for comfort. The choreographer Paul Taylor, 81, his scruffiness offset by a pair of twinkling blue eyes, watched as state-of-the-art automatic blinds worked their magic. “My new studio has an elevator,” he told Robert Battle. “I’m not even sure where it is.”

headline: In Yemen, a Photographer With No Name
text: It has been hard much of this year for Western photojournalists to enter Yemen to cover the political turmoil of the Arab Spring. It took Samuel Aranda more than a month to find a safe way into the country, giving him plenty of time to ponder what it would be like working in the deeply divided nation, where hundreds have died in protests.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 13’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Quarterbacks in Motion
text: Vince Young threw four interceptions in Thursday’s loss to the Seahawks, a figure that matches the Eagles’ victory total this season. The Vikings released quarterback Donovan McNabb, who could go to the Bears, who, with Caleb Hanie at quarterback in place of the injured Jay Cutler, play the Chiefs on Sunday. Kansas City will have Tyler Palko (yes, the Tyler Palko) at quarterback, unless the recent arrival Kyle Orton starts. Orton, of course, was released by the Broncos after he lost his starting job to Tim Tebow. He used to be a Bear — before Cutler, who once started for the Broncos himself.

headline: The 100 Notable Books of 2011
text: This week, the editors of the Book Review on the 100 Notable Books of 2011; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Andrew Graham-Dixon talks about his new biography, “Caravaggio: A Life Sacred and Profane”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Plants That Attack, and a Well-Traveled Rat
text: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

headline: Off the Charts: The Charm of the Third Year
text: Since World War II, investors in American stocks have always made money during the third year of presidential terms. But with one month left, 2011 could be the first such year to see losses since 1939.

headline: Jobs: Good Headline, Better Details
text: The job market seems to be getting better, and it is doing so in surprising areas. Jobs seem to be going to people with less education, and the number of long-term unemployed is coming down.

headline: We Are Everywhere
text: Each year, the numbers get bigger. There are 42 million family caregivers now, a cohort that includes more than just adult children watching over their aged parents, although they predominate. Tens of millions of us are engaged in this hard, transformative task; this dance in which who leads and who follows changes by the minute; this time in life that can’t be over quickly enough and that we want to last forever; this labor of love.

headline: Viggo Talks and Talks
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: From ‘Pariah,’ an Ingénue in Her First ‘Fancy-Fancy’ Dress
text: The ingénue is an established category in Oscar’s best actress race: the performer who comes out of nowhere, often with her first film, to charm and beguile audiences and Academy voters. Think Gabourey Sidibe in “Precious,” Jennifer Lawrence in “Winter’s Bone” and Carey Mulligan in “An Education.”

headline: In This Mardi Gras, the Beads Are Made of Pearls
text: “WHAT is that, like a cult or a religion or something?” Angel L. Calle, a Miami Beach taxi driver asked a fare exiting the Wolfsonian museum, where the venerable art journal Artforum was hosting a dinner, one of many competing for the same time slot and the same group of deep-pocketed art worshipers almost every night this week.

headline: Hollywood’s Own Hollywood Endings
text: IN 1937 Frank S. Nugent, a film critic for The New York Times, cast an amusing and jaundiced look at what had become a favorite subject for the movies: Movies! “Before our somewhat astonished eyes,” he wrote, Hollywood “has begun shedding its 7 and 70 veils, dropping a shoulder strap here, discarding a wrap there.” But Nugent, who went on to write films like “The Searchers,” was wise to this crafty tease. In the end “back-studio pictures” like “A Star Is Born,” he wrote, “flounced offstage with protective hands over the greatest of its mysteries.”

headline: A Trusted Market Predictor Falters
text: ONE of the most reliable guides to investing in the American stock market — to buy during the third year of a presidential term — is in danger of failing for the first time since the Great Depression.

headline: Oh, for the Good Old Days of Rude Cellphone Gabbers
text: Is talking to a phone the same as talking on it?

headline: 10 Questions for Haley Barbour
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi has been engrossed in presidential politics since dropping out of college to work on Richard Nixon’s second run for the White House in 1968. From county committees to the West Wing, he has been in the middle of Republican politics at every level.

headline: When Family or Close Friends Miss a Milestone Celebration
text: WHILE I’m no professional event planner, I do play one in my personal life. Or at least on occasion, like last Saturday when my younger son had his bar mitzvah.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 77
text: Philip Glass delivered a statement (or perhaps more of a poem) in support of Occupy Wall Street at Lincoln Center via the People’s Mic. rotesters invited audience members leaving the performance of Mr. Glass’s opera “Satyagraha,” about the life of Gandhi, to come down the stairs and join them, shouting, “Your life is the play! Your life is the opera!” [The Rest is Noise via West Side Rag]

headline: Trump to Moderate Republican Debate
text: It’s officially a reality television Republican primary now.

headline: Draw Sets Stage for Euro 2012
text: In many quarters, the European Championship is the soccer tournament, ahead of the World Cup, because there is no fluff, no Saudi Arabia, no United States, no Paraguay, no North Korea, no Honduras, no New Zealand, but also no Brazil and Argentina.

headline: TimesCast | December 2, 2011
text: The Republican race for president focuses on Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney; the unemployment rate drops while many stop looking for work; and wildlife conservation efforts in Afghanistan.

headline: Give Teague a Chance
text: Throughout the 2010-2011 season, Atlanta Hawks Coach Larry Drew demonstrated a startling lack of faith in the second-year guard Jeff Teague. Initially, Drew preferred Mike Bibby over Teague for most of the minutes at point guard, despite Bibby’s defensive failings and limitations as a creator.

headline: Minaya Is Hired by the Padres
text: Fourteen months after he was fired by the Mets, Omar Minaya is back in baseball. Minaya accepted a job with the San Diego Padres to assist General Manager Josh Byrnes with player acquisitions at all levels, according to a baseball executive with direct knowledge of the agreement.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.2
text: The day in sports included rugby in Dubai, biathlon in Sweden and USA Swimming’s winter national championships in Atlanta.

headline: Kathy Mabry and Tom Prost
text: WHAT if?

headline: A Glimpse of Death Row in China
text: A group of Chinese women, photographed inside death row at a Chinese prison, engage in seemingly banal tasks — painting their nails, brushing their hair, discussing clothes with uniformed guards — that take on tragic resonance in the final 12 hours before the women’s execution.

headline: ‘Miss Piggy Is a Dude’
text: Several of our articles, on Elizabeth Warren, on the Muppets and on morning people set Twitter off:

headline: Russian Court Fines Election Monitor $1,000
text: MOSCOW — A Moscow court on Friday ruled that the country’s sole independent election watchdog had broken Russian law by publishing citizens’ complaints of campaign abuses during the run-up to parliamentary elections this weekend.

headline: House G.O.P. Is Split on Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — Deep rifts among House Republicans over a payroll tax break became evident Friday as rank-and-file members of the caucus told their leaders that they did not want to extend the cut in Social Security taxes for another year, as demanded by President Obama.

headline: Two Velázquez Works Gallop Back to Prado Walls
text: When the Prado completed the rehanging of its unparalleled Velázquez collection last year two works were conspicuously missing from the walls. But now, after several months of restoration work long urged by experts, the paintings, “Philip III on Horseback” from 1634-35 and “Margaret of Austria on Horseback,” created during the same years, have returned to the company of Velázquez’s royal portraits.

headline: Living In | Oradell, N.J.
text: A central Bergen County community with a wide variety of housing, from grand Victorians to split- and bilevels to Dutch and center-hall colonials.

headline: Latin America, the Land of Opportunity and Caution
text: I SPENT the late 1990s and early 2000s reporting on the financial crises in Latin America, when Argentina, overwhelmed by foreign debts, defaulted and Brazil narrowly avoided the same fate. But in the last month or so, Latin America kept coming up in conversations I had with various money managers and investment strategists as a place that has new opportunities.

headline: Bloomberg on Cutting Teachers
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggested to an audience of academics that New York City schools would do well with half as many teachers. Video courtesy of the Office of the Mayor.

headline: Face Time | Ashley Greene
text: I recently chatted with Ashley Greene at a photo shoot for Mark Cosmetics. (She’s worked with the brand since 2010.) The fourth installment in the “Twilight” series, “Breaking Dawn – Part 1,” just opened, and her next two movies are wrapped and ready to go. Fans, take note: she appears this Sunday on the TV show “Pan Am.” Greene was warm and easy to talk to, and we were able to touch on many topics in a short amount of time.

headline: Wife’s Word to Decide Cain Campaign’s Fate
text: What will Gloria say?

headline: Dec. 4-10
text: Film

headline: Waiting for a Decision in Nebraska
text: ORLANDO, Fla. – The fight for control of the United States Senate will intensify next year, with Republicans trying to capture a majority by seizing upon the political headwinds facing Democrats. The pieces to the puzzle are nearly all in place, with one exception: Nebraska.

headline: Town May Activate Your Homing Device
text: IS Oradell, in central Bergen County, endowed with a magnetic field? That would be one explanation for why so many residents choose to stay, and so many others who grew up there but left now find themselves coming back. Another, probably more likely, is Oradell’s reputation for good schools, attractive neighborhoods and an easy commute into the city.

headline: Michael Kors Readies to Go Public
text: Michael Kors, the fashion apparel and accessories maker, disclosed plans to go public, an offering that could value the company at $3.63 billion.

headline: Channel Surfing: A 3-D Look at the Civil War
text: “Fields of Valor: The Civil War” is being billed as “the first Civil War documentary presented in 3D technology,” but the three-dimensionality of it isn’t all that compelling. There are scenes in which it results in impressive images, but with the still-evolving technology of 3-D television there are also scenes in which it detracts.

headline: Video Celebrating Euro Anniversary Draws Anger and Mockery
text: With Europe’s debt crisis threatening the cohesion of the euro zone, it is an awkward time to celebrate the tenth anniversary of Europe’s single currency.

headline: Few Avenues for Justice in the Case Against Citi
text: Is anyone going to be held legally accountable for the financial crisis?
