When the Securities and Exchange Commission announced recently that it was settling fraud charges against Citigroup for a paltry (for Citigroup) $285 million, the only person actually named in the S.E.C.’s charges was Brian Stoker.

headline: The Education of a Quarterback
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — In his rookie season, in 2005, Aaron Rodgers almost never played on Sundays. Instead, he played on Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, in practice, against increasingly agitated teammates.

headline: Inside the List
text: MAN VS. NATURE: Michael Crichton died in 2008, but he hasn’t let a little thing like that keep him from the best-seller list. His first posthumous success was “Pirate Latitudes,” a daffy high-seas adventure discovered among his files, which hit No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list in December 2009. Now Crichton returns with “Micro,” a techno-thriller left mostly unfinished at the time of his death; to complete it, his estate turned to Richard Preston of “The Hot Zone” fame. The novel, at No. 6 in its first week, is vintage high-concept Crichton — a group of science graduate students, hoping to score jobs with a nanotechnology start-up, are instead reduced in size to half an inch and have to battle the microfauna in a Hawaiian rain forest. Think of it as “Honey, I Shrunk Jurassic Park,” with spiders in place of T. rex and wasps in place of raptors. Did Preston have a hard time filling Crichton’s shoes? Not really. He told NPR recently that when he was working with an editor on an earlier book, “at one point she put her hands on her head and said, ‘Oh, Richard, you’re just a 14-year-old boy who likes to gross out the girls.’ I think Michael Crichton had something of that in him too.”

headline: Wheelies: The Me-Too Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Caucus Video: A Two-Man Race?
text: Richard W. Stevenson, the Times’s political editor, reports as the Republican race for president narrows to Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney.

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: AND SO IT GOES. KURT VONNEGUT: A Life,  by Charles J. Shields (Holt, $30.) This diligent but sad biography presents Vonnegut as a Man of Sorrows, haunted by wartime experience, unhappy marriages and lack of respect from the literary establishment.

headline: Paperback Row
text: HERO: The Life and Legend of Lawrence of Arabia,  by Michael Korda (Harper Perennial, $17.99.) The Englishman T. E. Lawrence (1888-1935) was a scholar and a warrior, a politician and a rebel, a publicity seeker and a recluse. Separating myth from reality, Korda presents a rousing account of Lawrence’s leadership of the Arab revolt against the Ottoman Empire during World War I and his diplomatic championing of Arab nationalism.

headline: Read It Again, Sam
text: “My dear Lady Kroesig, I have only read one book in my life, and that is ‘White Fang.’ It’s so frightfully good I’ve never bothered to read another.” (Nancy Mitford, “The Pursuit of Love,” 1945)

headline: A Remarkable Season by Any Measure
text: Aaron Rodgers may be having the quietest record-shattering season for an undefeated team in N.F.L. history.

headline: In Turkey, Biden Talks About Iran and Syria
text: ANKARA, Turkey — Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. completed his 16th trip to Iraq this week to inaugurate a new, postwar relationship. But as he left behind the farewell rituals with troops for meetings in neighboring Turkey, crises afflicting relations with two nearby countries, Iran and Syria, were already replacing Iraq as Mr. Biden’s major preoccupations.

headline: The Graveyard Shift
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Presaging the Occupation, and Intersecting With It
text: In an only-partly-intentional case of life imitating art imitating life imitating art, “We Are the Hartmans,” an indie movie about an occupation made before Occupy Wall Street by people who later took part in the demonstrations is being screened Friday night at the Lower East Side bar where it was filmed.

headline: Parkour Gaza
text: With the politics on both sides raging around them, Gaza youths turn to a novel form of athleticism and self expression.

headline: Even on the 11th Floor, There’s Parking Right Out Front
text: FROM two expansive windows in Glauco Lolli-Ghetti’s 11th-floor condominium in West Chelsea, there are sweeping views of the Chrysler Building and the Empire State Building. But visitors will not find an inviting sofa in this room, no place where a guest might sit back and admire the cityscape.

headline: Parking With a View
text: Suburban drivers have long been able to park their car in an attached garage. A new Manhattan luxury condo building with an auto elevator makes driving home, even on the 13th floor, possible.

headline: Nurturing Wildlife in War-Torn Afghanistan
text: When Wildlife Conservation Society scientists talk about their work in Afghanistan, they typically draw puzzled reactions. “Wildlife conservation in Afghanistan?”

headline: Visuals
text: These are indeed happy holidays for film-title fans like me, who have spent sleepless nights anticipating the arrival of SAUL BASS: A Life in Film and Design (Laurence King, $75), by Jennifer Bass and Pat Kirkham. Weighing in at 424 pages, with a foreword by Martin Scorsese, this collection is gratifyingly complete. It ought to be: Jennifer Bass is Saul Bass’s daughter, and she has unlimited access to the treasures of his archive.

headline: Embracing Home: Books About Cooking
text: See America First. Or, better, Cook America First. And cook at home. That’s how chefs, food writers and publishers are reacting to the economy this year: with continuing exploration of American regionalism and a near-universal embrace of home cooking, even by chefs who are so modernist — the new preferred term for molecular gastronomy — that you might’ve assumed they didn’t have home kitchens, or at least not stoves.

headline: The Antarctic
text: On this day in 1911 Robert Falcon Scott, en route to the South Pole, was on the Ross Ice Shelf near the gateway to the Beardmore Glacier. “One has a horrid feeling that this is a real bad season,” he wrote in his diary. It would get worse. When he finally reached the pole on Jan. 18, 1912, he found that his party had been beaten by Roald Amundsen’s Norwegian expedition, which had arrived a month before. By the end of March, Scott and his four companions would have perished on the return journey, only 11 miles from a lifesaving depot.

headline: Reliable Resources: Books About Gardening
text: When I was the editor of House & Garden, I was often asked what every gardener should have on her shelves. Contrary to popular belief, gardeners are bookish sorts — all those fallow winters, you know. It just so happens that this holiday season, publishers are offering a whole library’s worth of collectibles.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach: Thursday Night
text: Aby Rosen hosts A-list dinner and after party at the W.

headline: Music Chronicle
text: RIFFTIDE  The Life and Opinions of Papa Jo Jones.  As told to Albert Murray.  University of Minnesota, paper, $18.95.

headline: Harsh Adventures: Books About Travel
text: A passion for adventure in some of the world’s harshest environments courses through many of this season’s travel books. Following in the footsteps of polar explorers, wandering novelists and tropical archaeologists, writers test their mettle in spots as varied as Greenland, Peru and Liberia. Along the way, they offer a wealth of cautionary tips to would-be extreme adventurers: don’t slip even the smallest ancient artifact into your backpack, be careful of unlabeled cans of food and never wear only one pair of socks when hiking through the jungle.

headline: Album Covers
text: As strange as it may now seem, not only were albums once the state-of-the-art format for recorded music, but they were once literally albums: booklike objects, similar to photo or stamp albums, that contained multiple 78-r.p.m. discs — and whose covers rarely bore anything more than words. Presumably someone would eventually have thought of decorating those covers with original illustrations if Alex Steinweiss hadn’t, if only because the idea made so much sense from a marketing standpoint. But Steinweiss was the person who got the ball rolling, and who showed the world that album covers could be works of art in their own right.

headline: Private Colleges That Keep the Average Student Debt Low
text: While the average college student graduates with about $28,000 in personal debt and two out of every three students borrow money for school, according to the College Board, the extent to which a student is in the red at graduation can vary dramatically by institution.

headline: Notable Crime Books of 2011
text: I’m always stumped when someone asks me to find them “a good mystery,” because I might recommend a serial killer thriller like Jo Nesbo’s fiendishly clever novel THE SNOWMAN (Knopf, $25.95) to someone hankering for a civilized British detective story like Peter Lovesey’s STAGESTRUCK (Soho Crime, $25)  So let’s play favorites — but pick your poison first.

headline: Ticketmaster Offers Credits to Settle Lawsuit Over Fees
text: 6:30 p.m. | Updated Ticketmaster’s various fees and surcharges, which sometimes add 40 percent or more to the cost of a ticket, have long infuriated its customers. But next year, thanks to a recent class-action settlement, many of those fans will be able to get some money back.

headline: Picture Books About Hanukkah
text: I believe in scaring children a little. My daughter has never totally forgiven me for reading to her when she was not yet 3 Maurice Sendak’s “Outside Over There,” with its faceless goblins and their theft of a little girl’s baby sister. I like to think, though, that being haunted by that macabre book led to my daughter’s fanatical devotion to fairy tales, with which she now alarms her dolls. So I was disposed to adore “The Golem’s Latkes,” by Eric A. Kimmel, a Hanukkah story entwined with the legend of the golem, the Jewish Frankenstein. And I like the book fine. But it would be too tame for my daughter.

headline: Picture Books About Christmas
text: What’s with Christmas? So anxious. So self-conscious. Always fretting about its “true spirit.” Always taking its own temperature or rummaging around for “the real meaning of.” Increasingly paranoid about the “war against.” Begging, inevitably, to be saved — December after December after December. Does any other holiday demand magic when a mere day off and a pleasant dinner would suffice? If Christmas were a friend, I’d beg her to go on Zoloft or maybe Thorazine — at least talk to someone, for God’s sake. Or eat some fudge and shut up.

headline: TimesCast | Protecting Afghan Wildlife
text: December 2, 2011 - Despite decades of war and environmental destruction, scientists discover several large cat species in Afghanistan, once thought to be extinct.

headline: Bookshelf: Nativity
text: Children’s books about the birth of Jesus.

headline: Bookshelf: Nativity
text: ONE STARRY NIGHT  By Lauren Thompson. Illustrated by Jonathan Bean.  32 pp. Margaret K. McElderry. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 1 to 5)

headline: Up Front
text: This year’s Holiday Books issue includes, once again, our selection of 100 Notable Books, drawn from all those reviewed in our pages since last year’s big winter issue. The nonfiction choices feature a wide range of biographies — many of them of 20th-century giants like Clarence Darrow, Mahatma Gandhi, Pauline Kael, George F. Kennan, Malcolm X and Kurt Vonnegut, ­not to mention the ageless Rin Tin Tin.

headline: Kennedy’s Cuba Crises
text: To the Editor:

headline: Culinary Alliance
text: To the Editor:

headline: Hollywood Treatment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Updike the Incomparable
text: To the Editor:

headline: Listening to the Doors
text: Within an electrifying few years during the 1960s, rock ’n’ roll was transformed from a brash diversion of antsy teenagers into a serious genre that threatened to rival the traditional fine arts. Instrumental in this swift development was a Los Angeles band, the Doors, whose charismatic but tormented and self-­destructive lead singer, Jim Morrison, attained cultlike status after his mysterious death at age 27 in Paris in 1971, only four years after the release of their first album.

headline: Judy Collins: Sweet Soprano
text: “Gentle voice amid the strife” is how Life magazine described the folk singer Judy Collins on the cover of its May 2, 1969, issue. The label accompanied a photo of a young woman whose distant, blue-eyed gaze hinted at strife of her own. Just months before, Collins had scored a top-10 hit with Joni Mitchell’s pained lament “Both Sides Now.” The record broke through in an age of Vietnam protesters and social revolutionaries, out to save the world but often floundering personally; of young Americans caught between the conformity of their parents’ generation and the pressure to rebel. Collins spoke to the lost soul in all of them when she sang, in Mitchell’s words, “I really don’t know life at all.”

headline: The Rock Days of Disco
text: Although Nile Rodgers makes the grade as a B-list celebrity, he isn’t as famous as the musical record warrants. A longtime co-leader of the so-called disco band Chic, he’s best known for the bass line his partner Bernard Edwards devised for the monster single “Good Times,” which later drove the seminal “Rapper’s Delight” and several lesser records. But many A-listers have capitalized on his talents and quite a few valued his friendship. And as this eventful and engaging autobiography emphasizes, that was how he and Edwards planned it. Chic cultivated anonymity. They saw their way to success as an “opening act.”

headline: The Age of Def Jam
text: Never mind Kevin Bacon. Let’s play six degrees of Def Jam.

headline: The Look of Life
text: The frenzy that usually erupts when a new iPhone hits stores — wild anticipation, long lines, jacked-up resale prices — was more than matched 75 years ago in the exuberant public reaction to the launching of an innovative (how quaint it sounds today) print magazine. When the first issue of Life appeared on Nov. 23, 1936, the 200,000 newsstand copies sold out within 24 hours, leaving disappointed customers and vendors clamoring for more. Defying expectations in the midst of the Depression, the magazine’s circulation rapidly soared to nearly two million readers.

headline: Spencer Tracy: Leading Man
text: If you’re going to hunker down with a thousand-page biography of Spencer Tracy — specifically, James Curtis’s “Spencer Tracy: A Biography” — you may be somewhat interested in Tracy’s youth and school years, his career as a young actor in stock theater, his courtship of, and subsequent marriage to, his fellow actor Louise Treadwell. But what you really want to hear about is Tracy’s complex and sometimes fraught relationship with Katharine Hepburn, an open secret that spanned some 25 years, even though Tracy never divorced his wife.

headline: On the Climate High End, Methane Time Bombs and the Lure of the New
text: Most attention on climate science is focused on the new and the provocative, while the picture of growing risk from rising levels of greenhouse gases is best delineated by decades of work that is old and not contentious. That makes for a bad fit between this scientific enterprise and the world of public opinion, policy and politics. It can also produce a chronic feeling of intellectual whiplash.

headline: The History of Caricature
text: Nobody’s sure who invented the caricature. It might have been Leonardo da Vinci, whose studies of “bizarre heads” led his admirers to the realization that distorted aspects of physiognomy could serve a satirical purpose more directly than strict representation, or so INFINITE JEST: Caricature and Satire From Leonardo to Levine (Metropolitan Museum of Art/Yale University, $45), by the Met curators Constance C. McPhee and Nadine M. Orenstein, suggests. “Scholars still puzzle over the function of these drawings, which appear to have had a comic intent,” Orenstein deadpans in her commentary on an etching of a pair of grotesque heads copied from Leonardo. Or it might have been some kid who noticed that if you draw somebody’s nose and chin bigger it looks pretty funny.

headline: The Joys of BAM
text: Twenty-five years ago my husband and I moved to Brooklyn, lured by the promise of more space than we could afford in Manhattan. We loved our big, sunny apartment and its proximity to Prospect Park, but if we wanted to eat in a restaurant that was not a pizzeria, or see a movie whose protagonist was not a superhero, we had to return to our old neighborhood, the Village.

headline: Getting to Carnegie Hall
text: To celebrate the 120th birthday of Carnegie Hall, whose very name is synonymous with musical excellence, its overseers have put together a lavishly illustrated volume and accompanying trove of memorabilia. CARNEGIE HALL TREASURES (Harper Design/HarperCollins, $75), by Tim Page and the Carnegie Hall staff, is a sort of glorified publicity kit — the kind of thing you might give donors as a souvenir or sell to members of the public who wish they had been there. Do not look for complexity, skepticism or critical analysis, much less sober institutional history. What we have here is an orgy of self-congratulation that is both awkward and touching.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Highlight Reel
text: In 2010, The Wall Street Journal reported that after you take away commercials, clock stoppages, huddles and just about everything else, a typical three-hour National Football League game contains merely “10 minutes and 43 seconds of actual playing time.” The average play, between the snap and the whistle, lasts but four seconds and, The Journal found, “the ratio of inaction to action is approximately 10 to 1.” Which helps explain why nobody likes to watch professional football on television. Heh.

headline: Howard Cosell: Admired and Abhorred
text: Once upon a time, Howard Cosell roamed television draped in the ­canary-colored blazer of ABC Sports, smoking a cigar the length of a sequoia, covering his baldness with a toupee the size of a featherweight boxer and speaking of sports in a way no one ever had. He was loud, audacious, obnoxious, perspicacious, brilliant, narcissistic, provocative and haughty. He would doubtlessly agree with those descriptions — and add more if only to prove that he was, as he was wont to enunciate slowly, “HOW-id Cyo-SELL.”

headline: Cecil Beaton in New York
text: Almost anyone would have hankered to have a personal portrait shot by Cecil Beaton. He made his subjects, many of them distinguished or celebrated to begin with, seem impeccably elegant and disarmingly good-looking, seldom employing any of the irony or social commentary that other photographers often used.

headline: The Magic of Magnum
text: It’s not often that a lavish coffee-table book comes trailing equally lavish doubts about the wisdom of its existence. “It’s generally rather depressing to look at my contacts,” Elliott Erwitt tells Kristen Lubben, the editor of MAGNUM CONTACT SHEETS (Thames & Hudson, $150), a magnificent compendium of raw images from the photography cooperative. “One always has great expectations, and they’re not always fulfilled.” Henri Cartier-­Bresson, a Magnum founder, so hated the idea of someone pawing through his outtakes that he once bragged about throwing out his negatives “in the same way as one cuts one’s nails.” Contact sheets “are mostly a waste of money,” the photographer Leonard Freed once declared, though he added: “Because it is a waste of money, I love them.”

headline: Looking Back in Vogue
text: The fashion world is, with apologies to William Butler Yeats, no country for old men — or for anything old, really. It traffics in the new because it has to: if styles never changed, Barneys and Bergdorf would have nothing to sell us. But its ­single-minded celebration of the “now” (the latest look, the fresh new face, the next big thing) also betrays a philosophical bias against the “then.” Perhaps nowhere has this bias been more memorably expressed than in a quip often attributed to Karl Lagerfeld, whose career with Chanel has consisted precisely in reinventing and refreshing an aesthetic the company’s founder developed almost a century ago: “The worst is when friends say, ‘Remember the good old days?’ Forget about the good old days! . . . What is interesting is now.”

headline: The Golden Age of the Paparazzi
text: Sometime in the last couple of decades, paparazzi became not so much the buzzing mosquitoes their namesakes in “La Dolce Vita” were meant onomatopoeically to conjure, as the predatory peckers of “The Birds.” Since descending on Princess Diana’s crashed limousine in 1997, they seem to have entered a cruel purgatory: the endless stakeout of reality-show contestants — Kendra! Amber! Over here! — in the parking lots of Whole Foods. And now that anyone can snap a “gotcha” picture with his smartphone, what possible status remains in being a professional celebrity chaser?

headline: The Making of ‘Maus’
text: “Survival is having children even if they hate you,” Art Spiegelman wrote in his notebook in 1985, while still working on his two-volume comics masterpiece, “Maus,” which would eventually win a Pulitzer Prize. Subtitled “A Survivor’s Tale,” “Maus” recreated the horrors of the Holocaust — as experienced by Art’s father, Vladek, and mother, Anja — casting Jews as mice and Germans as cats. But it also explored the difficult relationship between tetchy skinflint Vladek and his resentful son with touching and discomfiting honesty.

headline: Spinoza, Plums, and Why We Draw
text: In the spring of 2008, while sketching at the National Gallery in London, John Berger rested his satchel on an empty chair. A security guard approached Berger and asked him to remove it. Berger placed the bag between his feet, but the guard was not satisfied, and insisted that the bag be carried. Berger became obstinate and was thrown out of the museum.

headline: A Museum in a Book
text: The more popular digital books become, the bigger print books grow, or so it seems, especially around holiday time when jumbo is at a premium. THE ART MUSEUM (Phaidon, $200), the size and weight of a suitcase filled with rocks, is the latest piece of material evidence.

headline: Diane Keaton: Soulful, Unselfish Maturity
text: Diane Keaton is admired for her ease in performing the difficult and for making the sensible glamorous. She minted a wildly original style of dressing while moviegoers were just learning her name. For three and a half decades, she’s starred in films spanning from younger woman’s nightmare (“Looking for Mr. Goodbar”) to older woman’s fantasy (“Something’s Gotta Give”), while somehow not being punished for the fact that no role ever quite equaled the luster of her Best Actress-winning turn in “Annie Hall.” She sashayed into arty endeavor — working on books about architecture and photography, directing a documentary on concepts of heaven — without waxing aloof. She rode out the “age thing” (she’s 65) that all female stars face, with minimum humiliation. And she’s been self-sufficient. She forthrightly says, “I never found a home in the arms of a man.” Yet she’s furnished an awfully big home in these pages.

headline: Wall St. Groups Sue Regulator to Challenge New Trading Rule
text: 9:06 p.m. | Updated

headline: How We Got to Dessert
text: Eel in marzipan and goose-liver macaroons may sound like outtakes from Monty Python’s “Crunchy Frog” skit, but in SWEET INVENTION: A History of Dessert (Chicago Review Press, $24.95), Michael Krondl tells us that the eel was offered at a 16th-century Italian banquet while the cookies, known more elegantly as foie gras macaroons, are the creation of a 21st-century Parisian pastry chef. These two dishes show how the relationship between sweet and savory has come full circle — from medieval and Renaissance Europe, when there was no division between them, to their segregation during the 20th century and back again to the current era, in which cutting-edge chefs delight in toying with our expectations.

headline: Think Before You Eat
text: The three subjects in its subtitle are sure to propel Adam Gopnik’s new essay collection, THE TABLE COMES FIRST: Family, France, and the Meaning of Food (Knopf, $25.95) stockingward. But a word of advice to those seeking a book of heartwarming tales and wry culinary observations in the vein of Gopnik’s popular 2000 collection, “From Paris to the Moon” — babies and baguettes it is not. This is Gopnik as gastronomist.

headline: The Novelist Who Loved Food
text: When Balzac’s Eugénie Grandet falls in love, she defies her maniacally miserly father — for the first time — by taking the sugar he’s hidden and returning it to the breakfast table so her beloved can take another lump. “Most certainly,” we are told, “the Parisian lady who holds up a silken ladder with her fragile arms to help her lover escape shows no greater courage.” For Balzac, food expresses character and class; and meals provide high drama.

headline: Robert Hughes Tours Rome
text: If we could be reborn wherever we chose, how crowded Rome would be, populated by souls who had spent their previous lives longing to inhabit a villa on the Janiculum Hill or a room overlooking the Piazza Navona. I intend to be among them. And Robert Hughes’s ambitious, panoramic paean to the Italian capital suggests he may have similar plans for the afterlife, despite his complaints — the noise, the traffic, the tourist hordes in the Sistine Chapel! — about the 21st-century version of the Eternal City.

headline: Italy’s Fragile Union
text: Recent fissures in the European Union remind us that no political union is historically inevitable. Such federations are human creations, established either for expediency or through expansionism, frequently artificial: sometimes so much so that, as in the case of Yugoslavia, they simply fall apart.

headline: The Lure of Everest
text: Nothing endures quite like a mystery frozen in time at the top of the world. The story of George Mallory’s pursuit of Mount Everest in the 1920s has done just that. But behind the legend, of which most of us know only the bullet points, is a heap of story: the gruesome realities and bitter fallout of a nation gutted by World War I, the character of hegemony in pursuit of a peak, the gasping of empire.

headline: Miranda July Is in Your House
text: PennySaver is a classified rag that arrives weekly in American mailboxes. It inspired the artist and filmmaker Miranda July’s latest book, IT CHOOSES YOU (McSweeney’s, $24), a revolving adventure that takes July and the photographer Brigitte Sire into strange Los Angeles homes and the sad, joyous, weird lives of the people who dwell in them — like Michael, a 60-something man in a magenta blouse who’s going through a gender transformation and happens to be selling a large black leather jacket for $10.

headline: P. J. O’Rourke on the Road Again
text: In March 1998, right here in the pages of the Book Review, the humorist P. J. O’Rourke wrote a satire de force entitled “Putting the Moi Back in Memoir.” It contained jokes like: “My parents also neglected to abuse me. They’re gone now, alas. . . . I’ve thought about asking my wife’s parents to abuse me, but it seems too little, too late. I did have a stepfather who bowled.” And: “I’ve had to endure enormous prejudice. True, since I’m a middle-aged white male Republican, most of the prejudice came from me. But I still had to endure it.” And two dozen or so others we don’t have time for.

headline: Pinocchio’s Tribe
text: No one better illustrates the evolution of academic literary criticism into poetry than Kenneth Gross. An admired Shakespeare scholar (as well as the author of a kind of precursor to this new book called “The Dream of the Moving Statue”), he moves in “Puppet” way out there beyond mere scholarship. There are myriad internal references (“as Susan Stewart suggests”), back-of-the-book footnotes and a generous bibliography, yet Gross rises serenely above his apparatus, shaping his own vision. He dreams and muses, offering endless insights into the strange and archaic world of puppets, inanimate things breathed to life. This is a book of literary mysticism, rich with accrued culture yet never weighed down by it. It’s a summation of what Gross calls the “vast literature” about puppets, yet never didactic or preachy. It makes arguments and tells stories about wildly diverse puppet traditions, but it can also be dipped into like a book of poetry, savored for its lapidary insights on every page.

headline: Revisiting Camelot
text: Peter Ackroyd’s vigorous retelling of the Arthur legends, based on Thomas Malory’s 15th-century classic “Le Morte d’Arthur,” begins with a reptilian king, “a dragon in wrath as well as in power,” lasciviously whispering in the ear of another man’s wife. “This dragon will not bite,” he assures her, but she’s grossed out anyway — who wouldn’t be? — and complains to her husband. Kings tend to get what they wish for, especially if Merlin is available to make the magic happen. The husband is killed off, and three hours later the dragon, assuming the dead man’s shape, sleeps with the oblivious woman. Presto, Arthur is conceived, not quite a bastard, as Merlin explains, on a technicality clear only to him. The price for Merlin’s matchmaking is baby Arthur, whom Merlin entrusts to a rustic knight. Only when Arthur, in search of a sword for his foster brother, Sir Kay, conveniently finds one stuck in a stone, is his special destiny disclosed.

headline: The iPhone, Weaponized
text: The setting for “iBoy,” in the projects and high-rises of South London, as well as its violence, meted out by marauding pubescent gangs, cannot help cutting close to the bone after this past summer’s riots in England. Kevin Brooks’s “iBoy,” his latest gritty sci-fi thriller (“Black Rabbit Summer,” “The Road of the Dead”), is a vengeance tale that even offers a philosophical take on the criminal actions of these young offenders, a prescient view currently shared by many British politicians: “The application in my iBrain doesn’t care why they do it. It doesn’t care if they’re poor or uneducated or bored or addicted or troubled or lonely or if they simply don’t know any better.”

headline: Post-Apocalyptic Teenagers in Love
text: Overpackaged, over­hyped first novels are done a disservice by their publishers, with untested authors expected somehow to justify all the gloss and glitter of a full-bore prepublication promotional blitz. Too many just don’t merit the attention. I could only stand up and cheer, therefore, for Marie Lu’s “Legend.” A fine example of commercial fiction with razor-sharp plotting, depth of character and emotional arc, “Legend” doesn’t merely survive the hype, it deserves it.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $11.5 Million
text: A duplex penthouse apartment overlooking Union Square, with an outdoor fireplace and an infinity pool on its more than 2,000 square feet of terrace space, was the biggest apartment sale of the week, at $11.5 million, according to city records.

headline: The Archaeologist as Titan
text: His introduction to the wonders of the ancient world could hardly have been less auspicious. While in Cairo in the summer of 1815, awaiting an audience with Mohammed Ali Pasha, Turkish viceroy of Egypt, the Italian monk-turned-peddler-turned-hydrologist-turned-circus impresario Giovanni Belzoni paid a visit to the Great Pyramid and became so tightly wedged in one of its internal passages that his guides had to forcibly extract him. It was merely the first of many indignities endured by this 6-foot-6 “giant,” whose adventures in the Nile Valley would yield some of the most imposing treasures in the British Museum. They would also earn him the undying enmity of his successors in a field that only later acquired the polish of a professional discipline — archaeology.

headline: The Caucus | Two-Man Race
text: The Republican race for president focuses on Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney.

headline: Study Says Wall Street Pay Is Tilted Toward White Men
text: To get rich on Wall Street, it may help to be white and male.

headline: Awakenings Caused by Sleeping Pills
text: Ambien is one of the nation’s most popular sleep medications, widely used to treat insomnia. But this week’s New York Times Magazine explains how the drug is being used to help awaken patients in comalike states. One of them is Chris Cox, a 26-year-old who suffered brain damage after an accidental overdose of pain medication.

headline: Pizza Brutality: Police Devour Protesters’ Pies
text: First there was pepper spray. Then came the batons. But on Thursday night, bad relations between the police and protesters entered a new dimension. While arrested demonstrators sat in their cells at a Lower East side station house, the police, protesters say, stole their pizza and drank all their soda pop.

headline: Bloomberg Eulogizes Aide Who Led Office for Disabled
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg paid tribute on Friday to a close aide, Matthew P. Sapolin, his disabilities commissioner, who died of cancer on Tuesday at age 41. At a funeral at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, the mayor praised Mr. Sapolin, who was blind from the age of 5 as a result of his cancer, as someone who refused to feel sorry for himself and who fought up until the end of his life to improve the lives of disabled New Yorkers.

headline: Parental Quandary: The Broken iPod
text: Parenting, as so many have so famously said, isn’t something we do alone. It takes a village, and in that village we sometimes find ourselves faced with, well, situations. Sticky situations. Dilemmas, of a perplexing ethical nature. Moments when we’re not sure how to do right by our kids, other kids, our fellow parents, and the people around us.

headline: Valentine to Cashman: It’s On
text: Maybe they will call it High Noon. When Brian Cashman went to the top of a 22-story building in Stamford, Conn., on Friday to practice what will be his second annual holiday descent down the building’s side, he issued a mischievous, but friendly, challenge to Bobby Valentine: come and join me next year.

headline: Fill-In | December Events in History
text: Fill in the blanks in these 31 summaries of famous historical events that took place in the month of December. You can use your own words and phrases, or choose from a scrambled list of the words and phrases that were removed.

headline: A Diesel for the Long Haul
text: FIFTY miles per gallon may not be a big deal for a tiny hybrid. But it seems like a minor miracle in a big, road-tripping sedan.

headline: Achtung, Kmart Shoppers
text: VOLKSWAGEN, a slugger around the globe but a bench player in the United States, has redesigned its Passat to suit American tastes. If those tastes run to fast food, Toyotas and Costco family packs, so be it.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, West Bank, Myanmar and India.

headline: Design Miami | Radical Chic
text: The 16-year-old Wolfsonian-Florida International University museum has become a favorite Miami Beach destination, thanks to its intriguing Mediterranean Revival architecture and consistently impressive exhibitions, the latest one of which — “Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity” — opened last week. It represents a tiny revolution in exhibition design, which is led by the French!

headline: Sotheby’s Workers in Labor Dispute Confront Mayor’s Girlfriend
text: Art handlers for Sotheby’s, locked out of their jobs since August in an increasingly bitter union contract dispute with the auction house, have been both inventive and voluble in their protest tactics, traveling to London to picket auctions and even showing up at businesses owned by Sotheby’s board members.

headline: A Credit Score That Tracks You More Closely
text: There’s no hiding now.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, Israel, Myanmar and India.

headline: Studying, Testing or Paying Their Way In
text: I was as shocked as anyone to read the recent news that a sophomore at Emory University was arrested for getting paid to take the SAT exam for some students at Great Neck North High School. But it wasn’t the crime that shocked me; it was that a person could be arrested for such a thing. When I was in high school, back in 1987, my best friend, Liz, came home from taking the SATs at the next town over and reported that during attendance, some anonymous administrator had called out the name of a boy we’d known since kindergarten, someone who was supposed to be sitting next to Liz. Just as she was about to call out, “Absent,” a boy she’d never laid eyes on raised his hand casually.

headline: In a Brooklyn Church, Lining Up to Erase Legal Sins
text: George Walker was sitting outside his brother’s house, drinking beer with his buddies, as he has for decades on the block of brownstones in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, where he grew up.

headline: The Many Faces of Coco
text: LET the Coco catfight begin.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Clinton condo, a Gramercy area co-op and a Clinton Hill double carriage house.

headline: The Bobcats Should Use Maggette — Just Not Too Much
text: It didn’t take long for Rich Cho, the Charlotte Bobcats’ new general manager, to make a substantial mark on the future of the franchise. After years of the Bobcats toiling away on the fringe of playoff contention, Cho took one huge step toward a team reboot in his first weeks on the job by trading Stephen Jackson and Shaun Livingston for the right to select intriguing young big man Bismack Biyombo with the seventh pick in the 2011 draft. Biyombo – along with Kemba Walker, whom the Bobcats selected with the ninth pick – figures to be a substantial part of Charlotte’s rebuilding future.

headline: The Bronx Savors Its Second-Place Marathoner
text: Buzunesh Deba enjoyed the South Bronx on Friday at a lot more leisurely pace than the last time she was there. Granted, that was during the New York City Marathon, where she was on the way to a second-place finish among the elite women. This time, she was savoring the praise and love of students and fans at a luncheon in her honor at Hostos Community College.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in New York City for this week: A Beekman area co-op with a garden; a Battery Park City condo with many amenities; and a Ditmas Park Victorian built in 1910.

headline: An Interview With Diane Von Furstenberg
text: At the I.H.T. Luxury Conference in Brazil, Suzy Menkes talks to the designer about her label and her love of jewelry.

headline: TimesCast | Good News on the Job Front
text: December 2, 2011 — The United States unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped 8.6%, the lowest level in two and a half years.

headline: Courtship of Cuban Prospect Yoenis Cespedes Intensifies
text: The suitors for the outfielding prospect Yoenis Cespedes, who defected from Cuba to the Dominican Republic over the summer, appear to be lining up in baseball’s off-season. Cespedes is carrying serious buzz, thanks to his speed, power and fielding abilities shown of in a promotional video put together by his representation.

headline: On the Markets in the Region
text: A five-bedroom contemporary in Westport, Conn., and a two-bedroom co-op in Yonkers.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Lifts Fox Past CBS
text: With CBS in repeats Fox was the No. 1 broadcast network on Thursday night in total audience and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, the age group most coveted by advertisers.

headline: Alan Sues, a ‘Laugh-In’ Cast Mainstay, Dies at 85
text: Alan Sues, an actor whose loud, clownish comedic style made him an invaluable cast member on “Rowan & Martin’s Laugh-In,” one of the top-rated shows on television in the late 1960s, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 85.

headline: Gifted | Big and Bigger
text: What a year! For these talented 10, name recognition at last. See our slide show >>

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: Click the slide show to view the On the Market properties in the region for this week: A Huntington Bay cottage on a wooded half-acre and a Greenwich colonial with a stone fence and heated pool.

headline: To Tell a Dark Tale, Avoid Bright Stars
text: AT first the Polish film director Agnieszka Holland wanted nothing to do with the script that became “In Darkness,” a new drama based on the true story of Jews in Poland who escaped the Nazis by hiding in sewers. She had already made two films about the Holocaust, “Angry Harvest” in 1985 and “Europa Europa” in 1990, both of which were nominated for Academy Awards, and she had no desire to revisit that wrenching subject.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: There were no madcap stampedes to the cash register. But at the symbolic start of the online holiday shopping season, consumers encountered a far more sinister scourge.

headline: This Week’s Tryptophan-Induced Links
text: Best news of the week? Dutch researchers have found that cheese doesn’t raise but actually lowers LDL (or “bad”) cholesterol.

headline: A French Auteur’s Bleak Visions of Confinement
text: WATCHING a film by the French master Henri-Georges Clouzot, you often feel as if the walls were closing in on you — even when there are no walls. “The Wages of Fear” (1953), the movie that opens the Museum of Modern Art’s Clouzot retrospective on Thursday, takes place almost entirely out of doors, yet it’s as claustrophobic as a stretch in solitary confinement. This picture, which was his first big international success, and which remains one of his most popular, tells the story of four men driving truckloads of nitroglycerine over some very poorly maintained South American roads.

headline: Hard Plastic Bottles, Reborn as a Bridge
text: The town of York, Me., is putting up what could be a bridge to a better future, not because of it where it goes but because of what it is made of: plastic.

headline: A New Credit Report Tracks More of Your Financial Life
text: This week’s Your Money column discusses a new credit report from a company called CoreLogic, which includes all sorts of information about your financial life that is not captured by the reports from the traditional credit reporting agencies.

headline: 1964 Pontiac Banshee: A One-of-a-Kind Concept Looks for Love, Again, on eBay
text: The 1964 Pontiac Banshee prototype bears many attributes of a blue-chip collector car, yet blue-chip sale prices have eluded its owner, the longtime Pontiac collector Len Napoli. The one-of-a-kind concept was recently listed by Mr. Napoli on eBay at the buy-it-now price of $750,000.

headline: A Singular View of Movie History
text: ONE of the major works of Jean-Luc Godard, the eight-part essay film “Histoire(s) du Cinéma” has revealed itself slowly over a period of more than 30 years, as a sort of intellectual striptease.

headline: Volkswagen’s Everyman Sedan
text: The 2012 Passat overcomes its bland styling with interior comforts and a smooth driving experience.

headline: Mistrust of Institutions May Touch G.O.P. Itself
text: Perhaps the fundamental challenge in analyzing this year’s Republican nomination race is the unusual divergence between the popular support for the various candidates, as can be measured through opinion polls, and their support among the party establishment, as can be measured through endorsements.

headline: High-Profile Conservative Endorses Romney
text: Newt Gingrich may have The Union Leader of New Hampshire, but on Friday, Mitt Romney landed his own high-profile media endorsement — Ramesh Ponnuru, a senior editor at National Review.

headline: War Dogs of Guam
text: In response to our article about military working dogs that get post-traumatic stress disorder and our post Thursday about bomb-sniffing dogs in Iraq, the writer and historian Chris Dickon pointed out that American military working dogs played an important role in World War II. In his book, The Foreign Burial of American War Dead, Mr. Dickon notes that 25 dogs were killed in Guam while serving alongside American troops. Those American-born and bred dogs were buried and reburied in three different locations and have been memorialized on plaques and in ceremonies, Mr. Dickon says.

text: Subjects include developments in the Occupy movement, a bribery case, “American Pie” and building blocks.

headline: Grim Findings in Latin Crash Tests
text: SOME of the best-selling cars in Latin America and the Caribbean provide extremely poor crash protection, new safety tests show.

headline: In a Rollover, You’re Safer Inside
text: HOLLYWOOD’S action heroes may thrill audiences with well-timed leaps from crash-bound cars, but trying such a stunt in the real world is bound to be painful. In fact, federal statistics make it clear that exiting a vehicle in the course of an accident almost always leads to serious injury — and is often fatal.

headline: Q&A: Banking by Mobile Phone
text: Q.

headline: Show of Support | Seven Miami
text: At Seven Miami, now in its second edition, seven progressive galleries — Hales Gallery, Ronald Feldman Fine Arts, Postmasters Gallery, PPOW, Winkleman Gallery, BravinLee Programs and Pierogi — from New York, Los Angeles and London have banded together to prove that an art fair doesn’t have to be a sardine-can-style trade show. “Art fairs are noise,” says Postmasters’ Magdalena Sawon. Unless a collector shops for names, “it’s not easy to spot, take in and think about works on display. We want to slow it down a bit and bring back what seeing and buying art in galleries means.”

headline: Who’s That Great Performer?
text: We already gave you one sneak peek at our Great Performers shoot. Now, with this year’s set of original short films set to go live next week, we’re willing to let you get a little bit closer. Can you guess who this is? Predictions are welcome in the (newly redesigned!) comments section below. The winner gets to see this actor star in an online film.*

headline: U.S. Official Says Missile-Defense Shield Will Move Forward
text: WASHINGTON — The American ambassador to NATO on Friday dismissed recent expressions of outrage from Moscow over proposed missile defenses in Europe, saying that the NATO deployment will proceed “whether Russia likes it or not.”

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Feel Me Flow: An Invitation to Rhyme
text: For high school seniors scrambling to shape a snappy, modern — perhaps rhythmic — application statement by Jan. 1, The Choice is glad to suggest a source of inspiration and a road-map for loosening up in the writing process.

headline: Producers Guild Offers Its Documentary Nominations
text: Documentary-watchers, keep your eyes on “Project Nim” and “Bill Cunningham New York”: both films made the cut for the Academy’s documentary shortlist and today they were also named to the Producers Guild list of candidates. The stories of an ape experiment gone terribly awry and our own beloved street style photographer join “Senna,” “The Union” and “Beats, Rhymes & Life: The Travels of A Tribe Called Quest” on the Producers Guild shortlist. The latter three films did not make the cut for the Oscars.

headline: Little Overall Change in Credit Scores
text: The distribution of FICO credit scores showed little change from 2006 — before the financial crisis — to 2011. While some people’s credit scores declined during the economic crisis, many others’ scores remained high or actually improved, because they became more conservative in managing their finances.

headline: The Latin American Alternative
text: The stock market has been volatile, to say the least, for much of this year, as investors follow each bit of news about the finances of countries in the euro zone. Some investors, looking for an alternative, have started to consider Latin America, Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week — quite a turn of events since the 1990s and early 2000s, when countries there were in dire financial straits.

headline: Firebrand Attracts Votes in Congo, Dismaying West
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Could Étienne Tshisekedi, a 78-year-old career rabble-rouser who is immensely popular in the streets of his country but definitely unpopular inside Western embassies, actually win the presidential election in the Democratic Republic of Congo?

headline: One More Thing Goes to the Web: Subway Ogling
text: AS a personal trainer, Ed Norman knows he has good biceps. But he didn’t realize they had their own secret admirers until he rode the London Underground earlier this year.

text: Who: The hair mogul Frédéric Fekkai.

headline: Readers’ Responses
text: After this article ran in the Think Like a Doctor column on the Well blog on Nov. 17, more than 300 people wrote in with their suggested diagnoses. Nearly one in four of the amateur diagnosticians came up with the right answer. Others looked to more common causes of such symptoms – including diet and stress.

headline: Easier Linzer Cookies
text: Cutting out cookie rings to expose the marmalade filling makes for very pretty linzer cookies. But if rolling out cookies isn’t your thing, there is an easier way. Simply form the dough into logs instead of disks, and wrap it in plastic. Chill until quite firm, at least 6 hours or up to 5 days. Then unwrap the logs and use a sharp knife to slice off 3/16-inch-thick rounds of the dough. Bake as directed for in the recipe, then form sandwich cookies with the marmalade filling. Sprinkle with confectioners’ sugar. Just as tasty, much quicker. You could even skip the marmalade. But I wouldn’t.

headline: The jobs and unemployment report may not be as positive as it seems.
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with David Gillen on the Nobel in economics, Catherine Rampell on jobs and unemployment, Gretchen Morgenson on bailouts, and Greg Mankiw on a walkout from his Harvard classroom.

headline: A Swinging Time at P.S. 75
text: Music was thumping and ropes were whizzing across the gymnasium of Public School 75 Emily Dickinson on Friday morning, where champion double dutch jump-rope teams from Japan performed to honor the school’s latest health and exercise initiatives.

headline: Yemen’s Opposition May Be Caught by Its Own Double Game
text: SANA, Yemen — For years, Islah, the country’s largest and best organized opposition group, played a double game in Yemeni politics, maintaining close ties to the government of President Ali Abdullah Saleh while it also cultivated a network of supporters to defeat him.

headline: Experimenting With a Holiday Favorite
text: IN my pre-motherhood years, I approached the holidays like some butter-crazed elf, creating a sugary mountain of dainty morsels. I’d tint royal icing in a dozen hues, dredge up the dragées, pipe out decorations.

headline: Italian Prime Minister Is Set to Unveil New Austerity Plans
text: ROME — Prime Minister Mario Monti enjoys broad popular support as he takes on the daunting mandate of turning around the moribund Italian economy. But the honeymoon may end as soon as Monday, when he is scheduled to announce austerity measures aimed at saving up to $25 billion to balance the budget by 2013.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Off Leash

headline: Older Workers and Joblessness
text: As I wrote in an article on Friday, even those who are back at work are not necessarily doing so well: only 7 percent of those who lost jobs after the financial crisis have recovered their income and standard of living. What’s more, the downturn and its aftermath have disproportionately hit people with less education. Even though the unemployment rates of high school dropouts and graduates have fallen from recent highs, they are still much higher than the rate for college graduates.

headline: Head of ABC’s Daytime Programming Is Leaving
text: Brian Frons, the ABC executive who angered legions of soap opera fans earlier this year by canceling “All My Children” and “One Life to Live,” will leave the network next month when his contract expires.

headline: Island Life | Raquel Zimmermann on Brazil and Brooklyn
text: The model Raquel Zimmermann recently visited the island of Fernando de Noronha in Brazil for a shoot with T. Here, she dishes about life in Brooklyn, her love for moqueca (a traditional fish stew) and what to play if you want to get her dancing.

headline: Ex-Police Chief Loses Appeal of Conviction in South Africa

headline: On This Game Show, There Is No Right Answer
text: Some shows this season have tried to entertain with pricey special effects (“Terra Nova”) or drawer-dropping stars (“Two and a Half Men”). But “Would You Rather ...? With Graham Norton” on BBC America proves that a fair amount of fun can be generated simply by putting people in chairs and letting them crack wise. All you have to do is ask them the right questions. Ridiculously incongruous questions.

headline: After the Years’ Ups and Downs, Beginning Again
text: TOM NISHIOKA twirled his wife, Alexandra Bloom, up and down the aisles of the Park Slope United Methodist Church on a recent Saturday afternoon in Brooklyn. As Dr. Bloom danced, the skirt of her strawberry red silk dress fluttered, and her cheeks glowed. She and her husband were there to renew their vows after eight years of a marriage that has included twin daughters and her diagnosis of breast cancer.

headline: At the End of the Night, Satisfaction
text: PASTA at midnight. It’s not a new idea, but it’s definitely worth remembering, rediscovering or reinventing.

headline: Out There | ABMB’s Second Wind
text: Thursday brought dramatically high winds to Miami, but also more art. At 10 a.m., the New Art Dealers Alliance (NADA) Art Fair opened its door for preview at the Deauville Beach Resort. Since relocating to the beach a couple years back, NADA has gotten better and better with an influx of very young galleries like West Street and 47 Canal (where Josh Kline’s three consumer-conceptual infusions — “Blue Listerine With Dentyne Ice,” “Mountain Dew With Claratin-D” and “Red Bull With Vivarin” — were displayed on a pedestal in Bodum coffee presses). The Night Gallery, from Los Angeles, took advantage of the fair’s hotel setting, luring collectors and company back to a boudoir (Room 1010) upholstered in black velvet and hung with artwork, all of which was for sale, naturally.

headline: The Only Way to Put Time in Reverse
text: THE list of truly classic watches — the timeless icons of the watchmaker’s art — is quite short, and what belongs on it is always arguable. A Patek Philippe Calatrava and a Cartier Santos will make it onto most collectors’ lists, alongside the Audemars Piguet Royal Oak, Rolex Submariner and Omega Seamaster.

headline: Egyptians Want Justice for Protesters Shot in the Eyes
text: As thousands of Egyptians rallied in Cairo’s Tahrir Square on Friday, some members of the crowd wore bandages over one eye. The demonstration was part of an ongoing campaign to draw attention to the dozens of protesters who sustained serious eye injuries last week, after being hit in the face with pellets or rubber bullets fired by police officers.

headline: Nothing Succeeds Like Contentment

headline: Obama Announces Backing for Energy-Efficiency Initiative
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama joined former President Bill Clinton on Friday to announce $4 billion in government and private-sector commitments to finance building renovations to make properties energy efficient and to create tens of thousands of jobs in the process.

headline: Two Last-Minute Partners Go On to Win a National Title
text: SEATTLE — At the Fall Nationals here on Thursday, the winners of the three-day Kaplan Blue Ribbon Pairs were Joshua Donn of Las Vegas and Roger Lee of Pasadena, Calif. They finished more than two boards ahead of Billy Cohen of Sherman Oaks, Calif., and Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif. Third were Steve Weinstein of Andes, N.Y., and Thomas Bessis from France.

headline: An Innovative Chef Looks South to Oaxaca
text: SINCE 2000, diners have come to know Prasad Chirnomula as the chef and owner of the innovative Thali Indian restaurants in New Canaan, Ridgefield and New Haven, as well as two casual, vegetarian eateries, called Thali Too, in New Haven and Westport. Last year, he turned his considerable energies to Mexican cuisine. The result is Oaxaca Kitchen, in New Haven. Here, Mr. Chirnomula interprets traditional Mexican cuisine through the bright contemporary lens that characterizes the food at his other restaurants. Some of his dishes work better than others, but given the chef’s creativity and the excellent service, the experience is well worth the adventure.

headline: Art Fair: Business Over Activism
text: MIAMI BEACH — Would this year’s edition of Art Basel Miami Beach be a private spectacle or a public one? I wondered that as I headed off to the art world’s ritualistic week of gawking, power schmoozing and peacocking, which is now a decade strong.

headline: Rivera’s Vocal-Cord Surgery Goes Well, His Agent Says

headline: Now Online | T Holiday 2011
text: Celebrate the holiday season with T’s cover star, Viggo Mortensen, as he speaks his mind in an in-depth interview with Zoë Heller. Inside, Miranda Kerr, Richard Thompson and Taissa Farmiga wear the latest fashions, Sarah Mower meets Her Highness and The Selby drops in on Copenhagen’s Noma. Need shopping tips? Read our gift guide, which offers groupings of joy for the people on your list. When you’re done, settle back and enjoy Will Self’s take on whether hotels are new community centers, join Joan Juliet Buck as she reminisces about a Christmas in Venice, visit with the model Raquel Zimmermann as she returns to her roots in Brazil and meet the Gifted, the breakout talents of 2011, including Charlie Day and Tyler, the Creator.

headline: Will China Stumble? Don’t Bet on It
text: HARDLY a day goes by without news of yet another economic problem facing China. A frothy real estate market. Quickly rising wages. A weakening manufacturing sector. Tightening lending standards. The list can seem endless and frightening.

headline: This Sunday: A Picture You Can Feel
text: I don’t usually pay attention to people trying to be the first to, say, circumnavigate the world on a raft made of Wikki Stix. So while I had vaguely heard the name Diana Nyad, I never gave much thought to her or why she felt the need to swim very long distances. Until the magazine’s photo department showed me some pictures that Catherine Opie had taken of Nyad after a failed attempt at swimming from Cuba to Miami. Then I became very interested.
