text: Dr. Jacqueline Toby Bork and Dr. Eric Solomon Ginsberg were married Saturday evening at 583 Park Avenue, an event space in Manhattan. Rabbi Scott A. Hoffman officiated.

headline: Oklahoma State Makes Its Case, Point by Point
text: STILLWATER, Okla. — The chant of “L.S.U., L.S.U.” that erupted in the third quarter of Oklahoma State’s rout of Oklahoma on Saturday night sounded more like wishful thinking for the third-ranked Cowboys.

headline: How the Top 25 Fared
text: 1. LOUISIANA STATE (13-0)  beat. No. 12 Georgia, 42-10

headline: Cotto Stops Margarito in Rematch
text: Antonio Margarito started with the taunting early, at the opening bell, or thereabouts. The more Miguel Cotto landed his fists on Margarito’s face, the more Margarito shook his head, the more he smiled, even as blood dripped from his right eye down his cheek.

headline: For Stanford Women’s Soccer Team, the Time to Win Is Now
text: Entering Sunday’s game against Duke (22-3-1), here are five things that Stanford (24-0-1) has to do if it wants to win the university’s first women’s soccer championship.

headline: Ohio Wesleyan Celebrates After a Week When All Seemed Lost
text: Ohio Wesleyan beat Calvin, 2-1, on Saturday night in San Antonio to win the N.C.A.A. Division III national championship. The title was the second for Ohio Wesleyan and its coach, Jay Martin, who earned his 608th career victory in the final. That set a record for the most wins by any coach at any level in college men’s soccer.

headline: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
text: Ashok Malik of Tehelka  analyzes the costs and benefits of India’s decision to allow foreign retailers to open stores in the country in an even-handed essay. He argues that many of the opponents of the policy change are trying to “scare Indians by raising the bogey of the foreigner.” But he also points out that allowing foreign retailers will likely also put pressure on some domestic businesses and industries. “Every economic initiative is a mixed blessing,” he writes. “Even if it expands the cake, there will still be some losers.”

headline: In London, a Festival for Chocolate Lovers
text: A lifelong lover of chocolate, Yael Rose is as happy sipping a cup of hot chocolate as she is nibbling sea-salted caramel or cocoa nibs. “To be honest, I think it’s an addiction,” she said. “There’s something about the smell and colors of chocolate I simply can’t resist every single time.”

headline: Is It Bad Strategy for Fans to Boo?
text: In a little bit of turnabout, Giants and Jets fans have been booed recently.

headline: Steering Telecom Italia With a Steady Hand
text: ROME — In April 2007, as the global economy was beginning to unravel, Telefónica, the Spanish telecommunications company, led a group of Italian investors who bought a 22.4 percent stake in Telecom Italia, one of the pioneering mobile operators in Europe.

headline: With Cain on Sideline, His Rivals Try to Prove Their Conservatism
text: With the Republican field reshaped by the suspension of Herman Cain’s campaign, six Republican presidential candidates tried to show their conservative credentials during a policy-heavy forum shown on Fox News Channel on Saturday night.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, December 4
text: Herman Cain  suspended his presidential campaign on Saturday amid accusations of sexual harassment and of an affair, thinning the Republican field. This latest development and the strategies of the other Republican candidates as they head into the Iowa caucuses are expected to dominate the Sunday shows.

headline: Japan Poll Finds Record Good Will for U.S.
text: A record 82 percent of Japanese report having friendly feelings toward the United States, according to results of an annual government poll released Sunday, in the first such survey taken since the American military’s huge humanitarian effort last spring in Japan’s tsunami-ravaged northeast.

headline: China Signals Reluctance to Rescue E.U.
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese government over the weekend sought to tamp down international expectations that Beijing might use its large financial reserves to help ease the European debt crisis.

headline: To the Battlements, Mark Ruffalo
text: Major environmental groups are lobbying for strict regulations on natural gas drilling in New York State, which could begin as early as next year. But activists like the actor Mark Ruffalo are seeking an all-out drilling ban, arguing that the country should move quickly toward reliance on renewable energy sources rather than reinforce dependence on a fossil fuel.

headline: Italy’s Leader Unveils Radical Austerity Measures
text: ROME — Telling Italians that the fate of their country and the euro was at stake, Prime Minister Mario Monti unveiled a radical and ambitious package of spending cuts and tax increases on Sunday, including deeply unpopular moves like raising the country’s retirement age.

headline: ‘Evgeny Starodubtsev: Piano Recital’
text: EVGENY STARODUBTSEV: PIANO RECITAL

headline: How Safe Is Gingrich’s Lead in Iowa?
text: Two new surveys out this morning, from the Des Moines Register and NBC News, show Newt Gingrich with the polling lead for the Iowa Republican caucuses. Although these results are broadly in line with other recent polls of the state, it is good to get the confirmation since these are extremely high-quality surveys. On average, Mr. Gingrich is at 25 percent in the two polls, with Mitt Romney and Ron Paul each at 17 percent.

headline: Alarmed by Independent Candidates, Chinese Authorities Crack Down
text: BEIJING — Periodic elections to neighborhood People’s Congresses are as close to participatory democracy as this nation comes. Of the many grass-roots candidates running here this year, Qiao Mu, an energetic 41-year-old journalism professor in the capital, seemed one of the better bets.

headline: Long Lines and Scalpers: Rock Star? No, Leonardo
text: LONDON — It’s hard to think of anything that Alexander McQueen and Leonardo da Vinci have in common. One made clothes out of feathers, flowers, shells and lace. The other painted intensely naturalistic religious scenes and animated portraits. But both, it seems, have the rare power to please modern crowds.

headline: Latest ‘Twilight’ Remains Leader at Box Office
text: It was a weekend of Thanksgiving leftovers at the multiplex. With no new broad-audience movies arriving in theaters, “The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn — Part 1” (Summit Entertainment) repeated as the No. 1 picture in North America for the third weekend, taking in an estimated $16.9 million for a new total of $247.3 million. “The Muppets” (Walt Disney) was second with about $11.2 million in ticket sales, bringing its two-week total to $56.1 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics.

headline: Carbon Emissions Show Biggest Jump Ever Recorded
text: Global emissions of carbon dioxide from fossil-fuel burning jumped by the largest amount on record last year, upending the notion that the brief decline during the recession might persist through the recovery.

headline: Obama Offers ‘Condolences’ in Deaths of Pakistanis
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama phoned the president of Pakistan on Sunday to offer “condolences” for the deaths of two dozen soldiers killed in NATO airstrikes along the Afghan border, the White House said.

headline: Current Cuts Staff of ‘Vanguard’ Documentary Series
text: As Current TV turns itself into a channel for liberal talk, it is turning away from its original source for news, a critically acclaimed documentary unit called “Vanguard.”

headline: British Debt History
text: I’ve been playing around with the IMF’s historical public debt database, which has long-term information on ratios of debt to GDP. And you really have to marvel, given that historical record, at the deficit panic now so widespread. Here’s debt as a percentage of GDP in Britain, back to 1830:

headline: Sócrates, Brazilian Soccer Star and Activist, Dies at 57
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Sócrates, the soccer great and medical doctor who transcended the sport through his involvement in Brazil’s pro-democracy movement and his outspoken defense of his own bohemian excesses, died on Sunday in São Paulo, Brazil. He was 57.

headline: A Scramble for Cain’s Supporters
text: The Republican presidential candidates were competing on Sunday, openly or more subtly, for the backing of former supporters of Herman Cain, a day after he suspended his presidential campaign with the defiant vow that, accusations of sexual misconduct aside, he “would not go away.”

headline: Majority for Putin’s Party Narrows in Rebuke From Voters
text: MOSCOW — United Russia, the governing party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, suffered surprisingly steep losses in parliamentary elections on Sunday and was barely clinging to a 50 percent majority, with 95 percent of the votes counted.

headline: Nadal Leads Spain Past Argentina for Davis Cup Title
text: SEVILLE, Spain — Rafael Nadal mounted a comeback Sunday to beat Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina and secure Spain’s fifth Davis Cup title.

headline: Lives Crisscross Through Tumult in Hungary
text: The physical copy of Peter Nadas’s “Parallel Stories” does not hold up well to a particularly aggressive reading. In at least one reader’s experience, cracking the book’s spine to make the 1,133-page tome into a more manageable bedtime read caused pages to break loose from their binding; by novel’s end piles of disordered pages were scattered every which way.

headline: Lies, Damned Lies, And Elections
text: As we wait to see whether the GOP nominates the guy who claims that his health plan was nothing like Obamacare, oh no, or the guy who claims that Freddie Mac paid him $1.6 million as a historian, one thing is obvious: this election is going to pose a major challenge to the news media. How will they handle the lies problem?

headline: Airwaves Getting Crowded in Early Nominating States
text: 4:50 p.m. | Updated The airwaves in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina are about to become a lot more crowded with political ads this week.

headline: Behind the Scenes at a Forum for Republican Candidates
text: Backstage can be something of an inner sanctum at a presidential debate: even though they are appearing on live television before millions of Americans, the candidates are used to having their clubhouse hermetically sealed from the public before and after they take the stage.

headline: New Plan on Payroll Taxes Expected From Reid
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate Democratic leader, Harry Reid, is expected to offer a new plan on Monday for extending the payroll tax cuts and jobless benefits that otherwise would expire this month, a fellow Democratic senator said on Sunday.

headline: Brazil’s Sócrates Is Dead at 57
text: Sócrates, the elegant midfielder and Renaissance man who served as captain of Brazil’s 1982 World Cup team, died Sunday in São Paulo. He was 57. In addition to playing soccer, Sócrates practiced medicine and dabbled in coaching and painting. He also wrote newspaper columns, delving into subjects as varied as soccer, politics and economics, and made forays into writing fiction and acting on the stage.

headline: Where the Tango’s Heat Finds a Home in the Sauna
text: A Finnish tango? That may sound like an oxymoron. But there has been a tango craze in Finland since World War II, especially since the 1980s. And not for mere imports from Argentina, but for home-grown varieties.

headline: Art and the Limits of Neuroscience
text: What is art? What does art reveal about human nature? The trend these days is to approach such questions in the key of neuroscience.

headline: At Fall Nationals, a Redouble Wins a Board
text: SEATTLE — The last two major championships at the Fall Nationals here, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams and the Keohane North American Swiss Teams, finished on Sunday evening.

headline: Jets Still in Running for A.F.C. Berth After Ragged Win Against the Redskins
text: LANDOVER, Md. — Rex Ryan, the Jets’ full-time coach and part-time philosopher, is fond of talking about the lasting effect that a victory has on a team. For days, he says, food tastes better, cars drive faster, sleep comes easier.

headline: On the Trail of a Murderer Still Alarmingly at Large
text: Whether you have been following the continuing Long Island multiple-murder case closely or only somewhat, the bluntly titled documentary “The Long Island Serial Killer,” Monday night on A&E, will hold a grim fascination.

headline: Films Clash Over Access in Crime Case
text: A newly announced documentary about the West Memphis Three murder case in Arkansas carries the imprimatur of Peter Jackson, the Academy Award-winning director of the “Lord of the Rings” movies, and the goal of exonerating three men who were released from prison in August.

headline: Giants’ Andrews Is Hospitalized
text: Stacy Andrews, a reserve offensive lineman for the Giants, missed Sunday’s game against the Green Bay Packers after being hospitalized with pulmonary embolisms in his lungs.

headline: After Prison, a Squeaky-Clean Return to Reality
text: “Ain’t I been to jail enough times for you to know how to treat me when I come home?” the rapper T.I. asks his wife, Tameka, better known as Tiny, on the first episode of “T.I. & Tiny: The Family Hustle,” which has its premiere with back-to-back episodes Monday night on VH1, about two months after his most recent incarceration.

headline: Stars Peruse a Shoebox’s Worth of Childhood Memories
text: Everybody has a shoebox. You know the one: it’s deep in the closet or attic and has your second-grade report card in it, perhaps a couple of kiddie drawings in pencil or crayon.

headline: Monday: Midnight Visits to the Refrigerator
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t seen a puzzle from Kenneth J. Berniker since 2010 (Across Lite, Solution, blog), but we welcome him back today as he offers us a very simple short vowel run theme. What do I mean by a vowel run?

headline: Bent Notes Suffused With Blues
text: The Kalichstein-Laredo-Robinson Trio, long in effect the resident chamber group at the 92nd Street Y, is touring some of New York’s other halls this season and bringing new music to each stop. Having already offered the premiere of a Stanley Silverman work there in September, the trio turned up at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening with a lively new work by Ellen Taaffe Zwilich. Still to come are performances at Town Hall, with a fresh Richard Danielpour score, and at Alice Tully Hall (as guests of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center) with the latest from André Previn.

headline: ABC Daytime Chief to Leave Network
text: Brian Frons, the ABC executive who angered many soap opera fans this year by canceling “All My Children” and “One Life to Live,” will leave the network when his contract expires next month. The Disney/ABC Television Group said that Vicki Dummer, ABC’s senior vice president for current series and specials, would take over Mr. Frons’s responsibilities for daytime programming. The soap opera “General Hospital” and talk shows like “The View” will be incorporated into Times Square Studios, a division of the ABC/Disney Television Group that will manage and create daytime and syndicated shows. Ms. Dummer’s title will be executive vice president of Times Square Studios. “General Hospital,” which has an uncertain fate as ABC’s remaining soap opera, looks like the odd one out at Times Square Studios: a news release on Friday said the division would mostly develop “nonscripted lifestyle and health” programming. Along with “The View,” it will manage the two shows that are replacing the soap operas — “The Chew” and “The Revolution” — as well as the game show “Who Wants to Be a Millionaire” and Katie Couric’s forthcoming syndicated talk show. “The Chew,” which features a panel of five chefs and foodies who cook and drink and chat, began in September in place of “All My Children”; “The Revolution,” described by ABC as a talk show “about health and lifestyle transformations,” is to begin in January in place of “One Life to Live.” Mr. Frons has headed the daytime hours of ABC since 2002. “While my decision to try something new was not arrived at easily, nine years is a long time in television terms,” he said in a statement.

headline: Town Hall Season Is Announced
text: The “30 Rock” comedian and Tony Award winner Jane Krakowski, below,  is set to return to the stage for a one-woman show as part of Town Hall’s 91st anniversary season, the theater announced. Ms. Krakowski will perform a range of musical numbers on June 8 in a season that will also include solo concerts from Lea Salonga (“Miss Saigon”) on May 4 and the Grammy Award winner Loudon Wainwright III on May 18. Other highlights include the musical-comedy troupe Capitol Steps (March 23) and a double bill of Judy Collins and Madeleine Peyroux on June 1. Information: the-townhall-nyc.org.

headline: More Radioactive Water Leaks at Japanese Plant
text: TOKYO — At least 45 tons of highly radioactive water have leaked from a purification facility at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power station, and some of it may have reached the Pacific Ocean, the plant’s operator said Sunday.

headline: Punched Out | Part Two
text: A long shot to even make the N.H.L., Derek Boogaard embraced the violent role of enforcer for the Minnesota Wild. But, it was a brutal way to make a living.

headline: Anatomy of a Hockey Fight
text: An analysis of a D.J. King - Derek Boogaard fight

headline: Todd Fedoruk on Addiction
text: Todd Fedoruk, former N.H.L enforcer and Boogaard teammate, on addiction.

headline: Derek Boogaard: Blood on the Ice
text: ‘I DIDN’T SEE it coming at all. I was in a bad position and he hit me hard, hardest I’ve ever been hit. I instantly knew it was broken. I didn’t lose consciousness, but I went straight on the ice. And I felt where it was, and my hand didn’t rub my face normally. It was a little chunky and sharp in spots and there was a hole there about the size of a fist.”  — TODD FEDORUK, former N.H.L. enforcer

headline: Footnotes
text: Performers and other protesters, above, gathered in the theater district from Friday night to Saturday for Occupy Broadway, called by the organizers a 24-hour “creative resistance” action to promote the right to assemble in privately owned public spaces. Zuccotti Park in Lower Manhattan, the scene of Occupy Wall Street, is also such a space. ... The Public Theater has announced a five-week reprise of “The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,” Mike Daisey’s exploration of Apple and Mr. Jobs, who died in October. The second round is to run from Jan. 31 to March 4.

headline: One Woman, Three Works
text: The suggestion behind “The Heist Project,” a one-woman show created by the dancer Belinda McGuire, is that it shares something in common with a jewel heist. Alas, the choreography on display at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night — three solos in total— is hardly tempting swag.

headline: A Fado Traditionalist, Embracing Torment, Suffering and Song
text: Fado, the Portuguese tradition of elegant, emotive songs filled with tragedy and longing, was named to Unesco’s Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list in late November. By happy coincidence the Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music had scheduled two nights of fado that began Friday with a concert featuring the United States debut of Camané, 44, a major star in Portugal who is one of his generation’s leading fado singers, or fadistas. At this concert fado’s past was never far from its present.

headline: Private-College Presidents Getting Higher Salaries
text: Presidents at 36 private colleges earned more than $1 million in 2009, up from 33 the previous year, according to a study by The Chronicle of Higher Education.

headline: Couples Loving and Fighting Between Multiple Pirouettes
text: At City Center this month Robert Battle, the new artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is introducing himself to Ailey audiences. And for at least the first three evenings of the season he has done so in person, speaking from the stage. Amiable and welcoming, he has that part of the job down.

headline: ‘Melancholia’ Picks Up European Film Awards
text: The European Film Awards, voted on by 2,500 members of the European Film Academy, offered its year-end prizes on Saturday in Berlin. “Melancholia,” starring Kirsten Dunst, below, from the Danish director Lars von Trier, was named best picture; it also won awards for cinematography and production design. Last year’s big Oscar winner, “The King’s Speech,” which was released in Europe in 2011, earned another best-actor prize for its star Colin Firth; Tilda Swinton took home best actress for playing the mother of a son who goes on a Columbine-style rampage in “We Need to Talk About Kevin.” Susanne Bier won best director for “In a Better World,” which also won best foreign film at the Oscars last year. “Pina,” Wim Wenders’s 3-D take on the choreographer Pina Bausch, won best documentary. Mr. von Trier sent his wife, Bente Froge, to accept the award on his behalf. Ms. Froge said that Mr. von Trier had taken a vow of silence after he made comments sympathizing with Nazis at the Cannes Film Festival. “I should say from Lars that he has no statement for you,” Ms. Froge said, according to The Guardian of London. “But he did ask that I should wave to you in a kind and gentle way.”

headline: At UConn, Teaming Pledge and Anthem, to Mixed Reviews

headline: Chicken Chain Says Stop, but T-Shirt Maker Balks

headline: Packers Are Unbeaten; Giants Are Unbowed
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Was it better for the Giants on Sunday? Of course it was. After last week against the New Orleans Saints, it almost had to be. Some of the players grudgingly said as much in the locker room after the game, whispering slivers of positivity through gritted teeth.

headline: Investors Anticipate Clearer Picture From Europe
text: After weeks of pressure from investors, European leaders won themselves a breather last week amid hopes for quick action on the debt crisis there. For the markets, the question this week is whether they can deliver.

headline: After Two-Year Drought, Woods Wins With Flourish
text: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif. — The scoreboard showed Tiger Woods locked in a duel with Zach Johnson over the final holes at Sherwood Country Club on Sunday. In fact, Woods’s real battle down the stretch was with himself.

headline: 31 Are Arrested at Occupy D.C. Building Site
text: WASHINGTON — Police arrested 31 people on Sunday night and tore down a barnlike building Occupy D.C. protesters began to erect that morning in a park two blocks from the White House where they have been camping out. The episode, in which police officers plucked some protesters from the building’s rafters with a cherry picker or coaxed them to jump off it onto an inflated cushion, lasted into the evening.

headline: Underwater Drones Giving More Eyes to Police Harbor Unit as Searches Grow
text: With President Obama in town last Wednesday, things were busy for the New York Police Department’s Harbor Unit. Federal security agents were disseminating lists of city locations that had to be swept for bombs, cleared and guarded.

headline: Bring Health Care Home
text: ONE of my patients called me with a high fever, chills and dropping blood pressure. He was 48 and had been a quadriplegic since he was shot during a robbery in the hardware store he owned. I called an ambulance and admitted him to the hospital, where we soon brought his urinary tract infection under control. But he developed a bedsore, which became infected with an antibiotic-resistant bacterium that breeds in hospitals. He didn’t survive the hospitalization.

headline: Charismatic Church Leader, Dogged by Scandal, to Stop Preaching for Now

text: The B.C.S. rankings are determined by three components: the Harris Interactive poll, the USA Today coaches poll and the average of six computer rankings. Each component counts one-third toward a team’s B.C.S. Score.

headline: Send in the Clueless
text: There are two crucial things you need to understand about the current state of American politics. First, given the still dire economic situation, 2012 should be a year of Republican triumph. Second, the G.O.P. may nonetheless snatch defeat from the jaws of victory — because Herman Cain was not an accident.

headline: Weekly Grind Pays Off in a Rematch for the Title
text: College football’s quarterback-centric offenses, with their multiple formations and 30-plus passes a game, were dropped out of a second-story window Sunday. They landed with a thud, and will have nothing to do with deciding the national championship.

headline: What, Is It Because He’s Slow? This Time, an Animal Escape Elicits Shrugs
text: They swooned over the Egyptian cobra, gone rogue inside the Bronx Zoo’s Reptile House last March. They cheered the peacock from the Central Park Zoo, who crossed Fifth Avenue to spend an August day on the ledge of an Upper East Side apartment building, only to return, on his own, the following morning.

headline: Leaders Piece Together an Effort to Keep the Euro Intact
text: PARIS — European leaders are working overtime on a tentative deal to try to save the euro, which they hope to complete at a crucial summit meeting in Brussels this week. But rather than one transformative leap, the deal will have several moving parts, together meant to show resolve to protect Italy and Spain, revise the economic governance of the euro zone and prevent further debt crises, officials involved in the talks say.

text: This video draws on ideas and material from a larger film we are making called "Teenage.”  That project examines the history of youth and shows how teenagers, as we know them today, were born.

headline: Lessons in Coping for Children of Deployed
text: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C. — “Can we talk about deployment?” Gregory Bole, a counselor, asked the kindergartners last week at Tarawa Terrace Elementary, one of seven schools on the Marine base here.

headline: Tent to Vanish, Taking With It Some Bowery Spirit
text: Billy Leroy stood outside his antique shop on East Houston Street on Saturday afternoon wearing a brown overcoat with a fur collar and holding a long brass hunting horn. Raising it to his lips, Mr. Leroy used the horn as a speaking tube, announcing, “Billy’s Antiques is having a sale.”

headline: Lloyd J. Old, Champion of Using Cells to Fight Cancer, Dies at 78
text: Dr. Lloyd J. Old, who made seminal discoveries about the relationship between cancer and the immune system, and despite setbacks in the field steadfastly promoted the development of vaccines and other immunological means to fight cancer, died on Nov. 28 at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

text: Critics claim the exams can be gamed. If that's the case, why are they still so important in college admissions?

headline: Text Messages to Woo Patrons
text: With the holiday shopping season in full swing, retailers are trying everything to get consumers into stores. Now consumers who visit any of the 27 open-air malls owned by DDR, the commercial real estate company, will be able to receive text messages offering deals from any one of the hundreds of retailers in each of those malls.

headline: Cuomo Pushes New Tax Rates for Big Earners
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Sunday called for “comprehensive reform” of New York’s tax code that would mean higher tax rates for the wealthy and a tax cut for the middle class, according to officials briefed on the plan.

headline: Print Empire Embraces a New Order
text: There have been creeping indications that the magazine business isn’t really about magazines anymore. In 2010, Hearst Magazines bought iCrossing, a digital marketing agency, and the company has since christened publications that have no print version. Every day, my in-box swells with announcements that this or that glossy now has an iPad app, nearly all of them trumpeting “amazing interactive features that take you far beyond a traditional magazine experience.” Over and over we are told that a magazine is really just one vehicle for a brand that scales across platforms.

headline: Billy’s Antiques

headline: Judd Woldin, ‘Raisin’ Score Composer, Dies at 86
text: Judd Woldin, a pianist and theater composer who wrote the score for the Tony-winning musical “Raisin,” died Nov. 27 in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Ted Ligety Finishes Second in World Cup Giant Slalom
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. —Ted Ligety’s surgeonlike precision on giant slalom racecourses has prompted rivals to pore over his technique on video. And that mechanical, mistake-free style was on display during Sunday’s World Cup giant slalom race here — Ligety won the first run in just that fashion.

headline: Anti-Abortion Groups Are Split on Legal Tactics
text: A widening and emotional rift over legal tactics has split the anti-abortion movement, with its longtime leaders facing a Tea Party-like insurrection from many grass-roots activists who are impatient with the pace of change.

headline: Pain in the Public Sector
text: Buried in the relatively positive numbers contained in the November jobs report was some very bad news for those who work in the public sector. There were 20,000 government workers laid off last month, by far the largest drop for any sector of the economy, mostly from states, counties and cities.

headline: Cashman’s Stunt Could Be Yankees’ Off-Season Highlight
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — For all the attention that the Yankees brand commands, there are some institutions that are hard to outdo. And so it was that General Manager Brian Cashman was an afterthought next to Santa Claus for the hundreds of children at a Christmas tree lighting Sunday night.

headline: A Broken, Dangerous System
text: After reports of chronic abuses — of detainees beaten and sometimes left to die of untreated injuries and illness — the Obama administration in 2009 vowed an overhaul of the nation’s immigration detention system, the sprawling patchwork of prisons and prison-like institutions that confines nearly 400,000 people a year as they await deportation or asylum.

headline: Undermining the Executive Branch
text: The House will soon consider a bill called the Regulations From the Executive in Need of Scrutiny Act, Reins for short. Its proponents — more than 200 co-signers, mostly Republicans — may hope the stupefying title will lull voters into forgetting what the bill would do. That would be a mistake. Reins is a terrible piece of legislation that would undermine a functioning regulatory system that protects people from harm. It would also do a great disservice to Congress itself.

headline: Explosion Seen as Big Setback to Iran’s Missile Program
text: WASHINGTON — The huge explosion that destroyed a major missile-testing site near Tehran three weeks ago was a major setback for Iran’s most advanced long-range missile program, according to American and Israeli intelligence officials and missile technology experts.

headline: Where Schools Fall Short
text: Millions of students attend abysmally weak school systems that leave them unprepared for college, even as more jobs require some higher education. The states have an obligation to help these students retool.

headline: The Force of a Personality Can Conjure Up a World
text: That’s an awful lot of space for one mere mortal to fill up. The stage that has been created at St. Ann’s Warehouse for “Misterman” — Enda Walsh’s gripping (as in by the throat) monologue of a play — looks to be roughly half the size of a football field. And Cillian Murphy, the sole and slender actor who appears in it, is definitely not as big as your average football player.

headline: ‘The Cherry Orchard’

headline: With a Click of the Remote, Impulse Purchases

headline: Stanford Edges Duke to Win Its First Women’s Soccer Title
text: KENNESAW, Ga. — Avenging consecutive 1-0 losses in the N.C.A.A. tournament final, Stanford held on to beat Duke by that same score on Sunday to win its first national title in women’s soccer.

headline: City Cracking Down on Performers in Washington Square Park
text: Colin Huggins was there with his baby grand, the one he wheels into Washington Square Park for his al fresco concerts. So were Tic and Tac, a street-performing duo, who held court in the fountain — dry for the winter. And Joe Mangrum was pouring his elaborate sand paintings on the ground near the Washington Arch.

headline: Despite Surge, Gingrich Faces Major Hurdles
text: Surging in polls is one thing. But as Newt Gingrich seeks to turn his impressive performance in surveys into votes, he is scrambling madly to build the kind of organization that Mitt Romney has methodically put in place for a year, one that will let him compete through all 50 contests, often in multiple states at once.

headline: Reasons to Stop a Utility Merger
text: Northeast Utilities, New England’s biggest electric utility, failed in the duties that come with its monopoly. With the release of a new report, regulators have all the evidence they need to stop Northeast Utilities’ $4.7 billion takeover of Massachusetts rival Nstar.

headline: Economic Reports This Week

headline: Vice President of Harvard Will Lead Bates College
text: Clayton Spencer, the vice president for policy at Harvard University, has been named the eighth president of Bates College, a small liberal arts institution in Lewiston, Me., effective July 1.

headline: Yankees’ Interest in Free-Agent Pitchers Is Not High
text: DALLAS — As baseball executives began to assemble Sunday at the Hilton Anatole for the annual winter meetings, the man with the biggest checkbook in the sport and with a long history of bold off-season transactions was not among the early arrivals.

headline: At TV and Radio Outlets, Little-Known Trove of Kudos and Complaints
text: Angered by the tendency of Judith Sheindlin, the television jurist Judge Judy, to address young women as “babies,” an elderly man wrote to WCBS-TV (Channel 2) in protest, proclaiming that it was “Balderdash!” and proceeding, in neat cursive script, to chronicle his marriage, and the war service he rendered, when he was just 21.

headline: For Turkey, Lure of Tie to Europe Is Fading
text: ISTANBUL — As economic contagion tarnishes the European Union, a newly assertive Turkey is increasingly looking east instead of west, and asking a vexing question: Should Turkey reject Europe before Europe rejects Turkey?

headline: Plan to Close Westchester’s Nature Centers Meets Resistance
text: It has become as much a ritual for nature lovers in Westchester County as it has for salamanders: every spring at Cranberry Lake Preserve, a county sanctuary in West Harrison, residents arrive, armed with flashlights, to watch the amphibians emerge from their winter dens.

headline: Book Shopping in Stores, Then Buying Online
text: Bookstore owners everywhere have a lurking suspicion: that the customers who type into their smartphones while browsing in the store, and then leave, are planning to buy the books online later — probably at a steep discount from the bookstores’ archrival, Amazon.com.

headline: Two Giant Radio Groups Form Daily-Deal Alliance
text: Two of the fastest-growing trends in media have been daily-deal Web sites and the aggregation of entertainment content online. Now the two biggest radio companies have formed an alliance to compete on both fronts.

headline: Biden, in Visits to Middle East and Europe, Tries to Reassure Allies of U.S. Support
text: ATHENS — As he traded the political upheaval of the Middle East for the economic storms of Europe, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has preached a consistent message on his travels: “The United States isn’t going anywhere,” as he put it on Sunday.

headline: Reyes Is Set to Leave Mets for Marlins
text: DALLAS — Jose Reyes has been a member of the Mets organization since he signed with the organization as a 16-year-old out of the Dominican Republic, but he has finally grown out of the struggling franchise. With the Mets unable to meet his financial demands, Reyes had agreed in principle to a six-year, $106 million contract with the Miami Marlins on Sunday night, according to a person with direct knowledge of the talks.

headline: Plunging Deep (in Pockets) to See Titanic at 100
text: Down, down, down you go, for two and a half hours, jammed with two other people in a tiny submersible, all the way to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean — and all for a glimpse, through a five- or eight-inch porthole, of the ravaged remains of the once-grand ship where the Astors and the Strauses played, dined and, in some cases, died.

headline: More Principals Join Teacher Evaluation Protest
text: Almost 100 more principals have signed a letter of protest about a new state evaluation system that will rate teachers and principals based on student scores on standardized tests. The tally is now 756 principals, including 35 from New York City.

headline: How to Use Blocks to Teach
text: With building blocks making a comeback, an educator provides some tips for using blocks in the classroom to deepen the understanding of concepts and topics, and provide a time for children to explore, make choices and work with their hands.  It all starts with a school trip and ends with "pick up."

headline: Reyes, Longtime Mets Star, Is Set to Join the Marlins

headline: U.S. Tightens Its Security in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD — The American Embassy in Baghdad has placed sharp new restrictions on how government workers can travel inside the walled-off International Zone, citing serious threats of kidnapping and terrorist attacks across Iraq and near the embassy’s own doorstep.

headline: Blast in Bahrain Near British Post
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A canister containing what Bahrain officials described as highly explosive material damaged the front of a minibus on Sunday near the British Embassy in the capital, Manama, though there were no injuries or serious damage.

headline: Kennedy Center Honors Five Virtuosos
text: WASHINGTON — On Nov. 29, 1962, a 7-year-old named Yo-Yo Ma gave a dazzling cello performance here at a televised concert that kicked off fund-raising efforts to build what is now the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

text: The old-fashioned cable television set-top box — long the hub of living-room entertainment for most people — is about to become less relevant.

headline: Sending of Sexual Images by Minors Isn’t as Prevalent as Expected, Study Finds
text: One in 10 children ages 10 to 17 has used a cellphone to send or receive sexually suggestive images, but only 1 in 100 has sent images considered graphic enough to violate child pornography laws, a new study found.

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: The End of the Affair
text: There had been some dread in the “Good Wife” community before Sunday night’s episode, “Parenting Made Easy” (otherwise known as the kidnap episode), but it turned out there was nothing to worry about. Grace’s temporary disappearance — a plot device to crystallize all the troubles in Alicia’s life, bringing together Alicia, Peter, Will, Kalinda and both of the children (only Jackie was absent, conspicuously) — was suspenseful but not overplayed; no sharks were jumped.

headline: Sarkozy and Merkel Push for Changes to Europe Treaty
text: PARIS — Under the pressure of financial crisis and with the euro currency at stake, the two main leaders of the euro zone said Monday that they would together push to remake the European Union into a more integrated political and economic federation, with tight legal restraints on how much debt national parliaments can issue.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 5, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: U.S. Asks South Korea to Cut Petrochemical Imports From Iran
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A senior American diplomat urged South Korea on Monday to suspend imports of Iranian petrochemicals as Washington tried to rally international pressure on Iran to stop its nuclear program.

headline: Dec. 5, 1933 | Ratification of 21st Amendment Ends Prohibition
text: On Dec. 5, 1933, national Prohibition came to an end, as Utah became the 36th state to ratify the 21st Amendment to the Constitution. The amendment repealed the 18th Amendment, which had taken effect nearly 14 years earlier.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 5, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Pete Diamantis at Math for America from the article “Congress Blocks New Rules on School Lunches.”

headline: Even in Egypt, a Long Way to Go
text: Moises Saman has been covering the Arab Spring for The New York Times since its beginning in Tunisia. In July, he moved to Egypt — where, for the last four weeks, he has been photographing the run-up to the Egyptian elections. Mr. Saman, a nominee for membership in the Magnum Photos cooperative, spoke with James Estrin and David Furst last Wednesday. This conversation has been edited and condensed.

headline: Commercial Metals Rejects Icahn’s Bid
text: LONDON — The Commercial Metals Company on Monday rejected a proposed takeover by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, calling his offer, which values the company at more than $1.7 billion, a “bargain basement price.”

headline: WikiLeaks Founder Can Make Final Bid to Avoid Extradition
text: LONDON — The High Court gave permission on Monday for Julian Assange, the founder of the WikiLeaks antisecrecy organization, to begin a final appeal to Britain’s highest judicial authority against extradition to Sweden on allegations of sexual abuse, the latest step in a yearlong legal battle in which he has been under house arrest at a friend’s country mansion.

headline: South Korea to Send $5.7 Million in Aid to North Korea

text: “Pensions melting like polar ice” was chalked on a London wall I passed while returning to my hotel after giving a talk at the London School of Economics last week.

text: On Dec. 10 and 11, a new music mini-festival hits Paris. 48h00 InfiNé takes its name from the the internationally acclaimed independent record label InfiNé Music, and will feature 10 artists from the label, resulting in an intense 48-hour dose of an eclectic mix of sounds.

headline: Protecting Friendships During the College Admissions Process
text: Susannah Griffee, a sophomore at New York University pursuing a double major in journalism and politics, is an intern this fall on The Choice blog and The New York Times Learning Network.

headline: What Artists or Bands of Today Are Destined for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame?
text: The Beastie Boys. Rufus with Chaka Khan. Guns N’ Roses. Heart. The Cure. Do you know these artists? They are among the 15 nominees who, if chosen, will join likes of Elvis, Madonna, the Eagles and hundreds of other music luminaries in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Do you think this year’s nominees are good choices?

headline: Voters Watch Polls in Russia, and Fraud Is What They See

headline: After 85 Years, Y&R Plans to Leave Madison Ave. for Columbus Circle
text: Madison Avenue has become synonymous with the advertising industry because so many agencies were originally located there. Now, one that still actually calls Madison Avenue home will be leaving after more than eight decades.

headline: India Asks Google, Facebook to Screen User Content
text: The Indian government has asked Internet companies and social media sites like Facebook to prescreen user content from India and to remove disparaging, inflammatory or defamatory content before it goes online, three executives in the information technology industry say.

headline: Gore Has Niners’ Record, but Where Does He Rank?
text: Here’s a discussion for Niners fans to have: Where does Frank Gore rank on your team’s running back list? Statistically, he’s now No. 1. His 73 yards rushing Sunday gave him 7,396 for his career, moving him past Joe Perry. It’s difficult to compare Gore to Perry given that Perry played some 50 years ago. As for comparing Gore with more modern Niner running backs…

headline: This Week in Small Business: Are Consumers (and Jobs) Back?
text: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

headline: At College Cup, a Crowning Moment for Stanford Women
text: Four straight trips to the women’s soccer Final Four for Stanford have ended in 1-0 games. Only this time, the Cardinal walked away with the College Cup in hand.

headline: Complaint Box | Overperfumed
text: As any New Yorker can attest, our city is permeated by smells: curbside garbage, street carts selling nuts or kabobs, impromptu barbecues, fresh marijuana and the odoriferous mélange produced by the subway system, especially in the summer.

headline: Australian Mining Companies in Talks on $5 Billion Merger
text: LONDON — The coal developer Aston Resources said on Monday that it was in discussions with another Australian miner, Whitehaven Coal, on a potential merger valued at almost $5 billion.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 5
text: Madonna is to perform during the halftime show at Super Bowl XLVI in Indianapolis, set to air Feb. 5 on NBC, the network announced on Sunday night during its football broadcast. The idea had been in play  for some time, with Madonna seen as fitting the N.F.L.’s trend of looking to older performers since the controversy over the “wardrobe malfunction” of Janet Jackson in 2004. She will collaborate with a team from Cirque du Soleil, the choreographer Jamie King and artists from Moment Factory, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Jason Garrett Too Cautious in Cowboys’ Defeat
text: Forget that the regular-season overtime rules prevented the Cowboys from even touching the ball after regulation of a 19-13 loss at Arizona – that was merely karmic justice. Any coach that mismanages timeouts and field position as spectacularly as Dallas Coach Jason Garrett did in the final minutes deserves to lose. First, Garrett seemingly iced his own kicker by calling a timeout just before Dan Bailey’s 49-yard field goal on what would have been the game’s final play. (Bailey made the initial kick, but couldn’t repeat it.) Analyzing timeout usage as it pertains to a kicker’s rhythm is like analyzing how your day might have been different if you’d only brushed your teeth three minutes earlier. It’s a fruitless practice that’s all hindsight and presumption.

headline: Those Romantic Wood Stoves
text: We’re one cord into an expected six-cord winter and starting the colder part of our year in the Maine woods off the grid with three kids and two cats from the New Jersey suburbs. It’s the first time I have heated with wood, and I miss the simplicity of a thermostat connected to a furnace.

headline: HSBC Fined for Selling Unsuitable Investments to the Elderly
text: LONDON — British authorities on Monday fined HSBC £10.5 million, or $16.4 million, for selling inappropriate financial products to elderly customers, the largest penalty related to a retail product.

headline: Week 13 Quick Hits: In Praise of Packers Receivers

headline: Newswallah: Foreign Direct Investment in Retail
text: A roundup of news and opinion on the big issues.

headline: Amid Loss, a Little Hope for the Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – The Giants said all week that they did not believe in moral victories. Then, after they put together a performance that felt like the very definition of one against the Green Bay Packers, they (mostly) said it again.

headline: New Violence Erupts in Yemeni City

headline: A Good Day for Jets’ Scoreboard Watching

headline: Global Witness Quits Group on ‘Blood Diamonds’
text: JOHANNESBURG — An advocacy organization that helped to establish an international certification program to prevent the sale of so-called blood diamonds withdrew from the coalition on Monday, saying the effort was no longer effective.

headline: ‘The Help’ Stars Improvise on the Lunch Script
text: There are a lot of commonalities at the awards season lunches organized by Peggy Siegal, the PR doyenne: the seating is highly managed, the guests are notable and the desserts, poor things, go largely untouched. One thing the Bagger doesn’t usually see: impromptu Q & As between stars and sports legends.

headline: The Super Bowl Gets Its (Material) Girl: Madonna to Perform at Halftime Show
text: Having been burned by artists who proved too controversial, the National Football League has chosen a halftime performer for Super Bowl XLVI with a nice, safe, biblically inspired name. Well, not exactly.

headline: Gingrich in New York, and Cain in the Dust
text: There was a rare political development in New York on the weekend: A Republican candidate for president did some campaigning in the city. He didn’t come just to raise money, or just to meet with the well-known reality television personality with implausible hair. No, Newt Gingrich actually met New Yorkers on Saturday.

headline: Biden Treads Softly in Greece
text: ATHENS — What do you do if you’re a voluble American official whose words have been known to raise eyebrows, and you’re visiting the epicenter of Europe’s debt crisis at the start of a crucial week for the euro?

headline: SAP’s Strategy with SuccessFactors
text: SAP made a big move into the cloud computing world over the weekend, buying the human resource management software company SuccessFactors for $3.4 billion. But its first steps after the purchase are going to  involve a lot of old-time selling.

headline: Auction Alert | ‘The Goddess Adorned’
text: Gaia, the ancient Greek earth goddess, is being sold to the highest bidder, but it’s for a good cause. A collaboration between the Turkish home accessories company Gaia & Gino, the New York designer Harry Allen and Swarovski Elements has produced “The Goddess Adorned,”  an auction of 15 of Allen’s shapely Gaia vases, which have been customized by a glittering list of celebrities in the worlds of fashion, design and style, including Ashley and Mary Kate Olsen for  Elizabeth and James, Kenneth Jay Lane, Doo.Ri, Waris Ahluwalia and Allen himself. The vases will be auctioned online for two weeks starting Tuesday to benefit Housing Works, and will be on view at the Swarovski Crystallized concept store, at 499 Broadway in SoHo. The original vase, which was designed by Allen for Gaia & Gino but never produced, was always meant to be “dressed,” with jewelry or ribbons, for instance. “I designed the vase to be transformed,” Allen explains, citing Gaye Cevikel, Gaia & Gino’s fashionable founder, as his inspiration. A number of samples of the vase were made, and Allen had the idea to auction them for charity.

headline: Fielder’s Weight Is the $150 Million Question
text: With the winter meetings opening Monday, speculation will be rampant as to where the high-profile free agents will end up.

headline: Gimme an E! Gimme a C! Gimme a B!
text: Markets clearly believe that the Europeans have found a formula that will make it possible for the ECB to step in and buy lots of Italian bonds.

headline: No, It’s Not The Welfare State
text: Dean Baker takes on a favorite pet peeve of mine — the incessant claim that Europe’s woes are being caused by the burden of the welfare state.

headline: Syria Offers to Allow Observers, With Strings
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria said Monday that it would agree to allow an Arab mission of military and civilian observers into the country as part of an Arab League proposal to end months of bloodshed there, but it attached a number of conditions, among them the cancellation of economic sanctions decreed by the league.

headline: Are Parks a Boon to State Economies?
text: Challenging the notion that protecting public land locks it up, more than 100 economists, including three Nobel laureates, are calling on the president and Congress to create more parks and other protected preserves in the West as a way to bolster state economies.

headline: School Chess Team Wins a Big Battle
text: Monday morning brings happy news about an intermediate school chess team that is so good that it whipped the brainiacs at Google last week. But there is also disturbing news about how money for school lunches is being spent.

headline: What We’re Reading

Rahm Emanuel, Chicago’s Mayor, is trying to jack up the fees the city gets for the Park Grill at Millennium Park, suing to invalidate a generous 2003 concession deal the city made under former Mayor Richard M. Daley. — Glenn Collins

headline: Monday Reading: Hotels Add Perks as Airlines Cut Back
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Tebow, ‘Numbers Geeks’ and Yet Another Victory
text: In his Monday Morning QB at Sports Illustrated’s site, Peter King wrote:

headline: Cunningham Countdown: A Monday With Merce
text: On Monday Merce Cunningham will appear on screen in the first public showing of his final interview. It is 18 minutes long and unedited. The interview was filmed in June 2009, the month before his death. When his face first appears on screen – he was 90, had been largely confined to a wheelchair for some years, and in recent months had suffered various medical setbacks – you’re aware of the depredations of age. Then he talks, and it’s evident that the mind was still sharp, the interest in precise verbal articulation still alert, the passion for dance unrelenting. It is an exciting revelation of his unflagging intelligence.

headline: The Get | Mark Cross Madison Mini Doctor Bag
text: As far as shapes go, the Madison Mini Doctor bag from the all-American leather goods label Mark Cross is an interesting one –– extra-long strap, compact size, structured handles. It’s a saddle bag (the company was established in 1845 as a source for saddles and harnesses) turned on its head. “We want all of our bags to reflect the brand’s legacy and history,” says the company president, Neal Fox, about its strategy and recent re-entry into the marketplace. “This one reflects an especially modern approach to classicism.” At $1,495, it is a princely price to pay for timeless style. The only question is, where to wear it first, Los Angeles or Monaco?

headline: On Our Radar: Smog Grounds Flights in Beijing
text: Thick smog prompts officials to cancel hundreds of flights and shut down some major highways in Beijing. The American Embassy describes current air quality there as “hazardous,” and the official Xinhua news agency says the pollution is likely to reach “dangerous” levels. [Agence France-Presse]

headline: Big Brother in the Home Office
text: Tens of thousands of programmers, writers, accountants and other workers labor at home doing contract work for companies like Google, Hewlett-Packard and NBC. The computers they use contain software that takes snapshots of what they are doing six times an hour. The snooping occurs randomly, making it impossible for the computer user to game the system.

headline: The Philosophy of Dev Anand
text: Dev Anand wasn’t a star. He was a philosophy. The 88-year-old actor, who died of cardiac arrest on December 4, symbolized six decades of Hindi cinema and a spirit that insisted that the show must go on. No matter that the films ceased to seduce or that viewers stopped showing up decades ago. Dev Anand continued to create and despite the mostly substandard quality of his output, he never lost his icon status or the affection of his audience and colleagues.

headline: Street Style: Playing With Proportions
text: The best of readers’ street style for the week of Nov. 28.

headline: Madoff Had Everything to Do With Reyes’s Leaving
text: It is easy for Sandy Alderson to say that the leering face of Bernard L. Madoff does not haunt the Mets each and every day.

headline: Sarkozy and Merkel’s Delicate Dance
text: For weeks, attitudes toward Europe’s debt crisis have gone through a recurring cycle: markets flail, spurring leaders to gather and confer; grim-faced, they issue statements of guarded optimism and determination. Rinse. Repeat.

headline: The Monday Matchup: Could the Jaguars Get Any More Jumbled?
text: Chargers at JaguarsMonday, 8:30 p.m.Line: Chargers by 3.

headline: At Conference, Afghans Say They’ll Need Aid for Years
text: BONN, Germany — As dozens of nations and organizations met here on Monday to plan a transition beyond the withdrawal of American and other international forces from Afghanistan in 2014, the Afghan government had a new deadline in mind: 2024.

headline: Keeping Score: Bad Day for Mets, Good Day for Kranepool
text: As the Mets get dressed up for their 50th anniversary season, it is worth noting that they have never had a standout position player who stuck around long enough to produce big career statistics for the team. The departure of shortstop Jose Reyes, who is set to join the Miami Marlins as a free agent, continues this trend.

headline: The Film With the Broken Embargo
text: David Denby, rule breaker? That is exactly what the folks at Sony are saying about that film critic at The New Yorker.

headline: Zynga Rival in Japan Prices $1.2 Billion I.P.O.
text: TOKYO – The online game company Nexon, a fast-growing Asian rival to Zynga, on Monday set the price for its initial public offering at 1,300 yen a share, a debut that could value the company at 560 billion yen, or $7.2 billion.

headline: Astronomers Find Biggest Black Holes Yet
text: Don’t get too close.

headline: Daily Report: Online Learning, Through the Khan Academy
text: In Monday’s New York Times, Somini Sengupta reports on the Khan Academy, a program of math and science lessons developed by Salman Khan that has become a YouTube hit, attracting up to 3.5 million viewers a month. This fall, at least 36 schools across the country are using software to try out Mr. Khan’s lessons in the classroom, combining traditional teaching with computer-based lessons and exercises.

headline: Author Says She’s Found a Portrait of Jane Austen
text: For as few novels as Jane Austen published in a literary career that has long outlasted her brief 41 years, even fewer portraits of her are believed to have survived. Only two are officially recognized as representations of Austen, including a watercolor sketch by her sister, Cassandra, and neither looks particularly like Anne Hathaway. (But really, who does?)

headline: Spot Pornography on Facebook for a Quarter-Cent an Image

headline: Next-Day Mail Faces Postal Service Cuts

headline: Right Back Where We Started
text: For all the action of the weekend, all the dramatic games and frantic finishes, today feels a bit anticlimactic. Because for everything that felt like a crazy twist and turn, we are essentially left back where we started. The Packers are still undefeated. The Bowl Championship Series is still designed to keep the power conference teams on top. Fighting is still a part of the N.H.L., although the more people who read about Derek Boogaard’s heart-rending fate, the less defensible that is, and the Mets’ fortunes are still sinking like a rock.

headline: At $106 Million, Mets Were Wise to Pass on Reyes
text: After news broke Sunday that the Miami Marlins and Jose Reyes had agreed on a contract, Mets General Manager Sandy Alderson made a revelation of his own: the team had lost $70 million last year.

headline: Have N.B.A. Questions? Howard Beck Has Answers
text: Are the Heat the favorites for the N.B.A. championship this season? Will Chris Paul stay in New Orleans? Do the Nuggets have anyone or anything left? Howard Beck, the N.B.A. reporter for The New York Times, will answer questions from readers.

headline: Senators and Congressmen, All Trying for a Laugh
text: As I was working on my argument about political parody on “Saturday Night Live,” I traveled to our nation’s capital to see if the humor of our political elite was also suffering from malaise. Wednesday was the 18th annual Funniest Celebrity in Washington Contest, a benefit whose proceeds go to the Susan G. Komen for the Cure, which fights breast cancer. The evening featured a bipartisan bill of stand-up performances by politicians, journalists and lobbyists who all seem to agree on one thing: People from Washington are not funny.

headline: Labor Department Seeks Tougher Rules on ‘Multiple-Employer’ Plans
text: Federal officials hope to crack down more effectively on operators of “multiple employer” health plans that have defrauded small businesses and their workers of hundreds of millions of dollars, often leaving them stuck with unpaid medical bills, according to new rules proposed Monday by the Obama administration under the health care legislation.

headline: Cain Supporters in Iowa Examine Options
text: With Herman Cain suspending his presidential campaign, the other campaigns are making a play for his supporters, particularly on the ground in Iowa. Much of the speculation is that Newt Gingrich stands to benefit the most as conservatives look for a viable candidate, but Cain supporters in the state say they are up for grabs.

headline: Another Tablet Bites the Dust: Dell’s Streak 7

headline: Welfare Minister’s Tears Show Italians Pain of Austerity
text: As my colleague Rachel Donadio reported, Italy’s new government, hastily assembled after Silvio Berlusconi’s departure, announced sweeping austerity measures Sunday night. The package of deep spending cuts and tax increases is intended, said Prime Minister Mario Monti, to “save Italy.”

headline: Chipper Remnants of a Life Turned Sour
text: She didn’t leave much behind. That’s the inescapable fact of Amy Winehouse‘s posthumous collection, “Lioness: Hidden Treasures.”

headline: Notes From the Underground | Austra
text: Austra’s recent sold-out performance at the Echo brought the club to a thundering halt with heavy beats and ethereal vocals, provided by the band’s Katie Stelmanis. Flanked by bejeweled identical twin backup singers, Stelmanis, who previously performed as a solo artist, flaunted her prowess for fronting an act, taking Austra through a tight, deep set, each song better than the last.

headline: Dear Best Buy: Don’t Mock Santa
text: I would like to come straight out and say that I am a delicate flower on the matter of Santa Claus and the “magic of Christmas.” I would prefer that you not show any disrespect to the big guy in a mainstream setting, both because I have children who still believe, and because as much as I worry that Christmas has become a season of getting, I think Santa creates, for kids, an atmosphere of giving, as well.

headline: Entergy to Spin Off and Sell Electric Transmission Unit
text: Entergy said on Monday that it planned to sell its electric transmission business to ITC Holdings in a two-step process that avoids taxes.

headline: Smog Closes Beijing Airport
text: BEIJING — Capital International Airport in Beijing was forced to cancel hundreds of flights on Monday because of heavy smog and weather conditions. The cancellations were the latest sign that pollution in China’s largest cities, among the worst in the world, is leading to significant economic losses.

headline: Pumpkins of Kane Street, Twisted and Shriveled
text: Wrinkled and tortured, the pumpkins of Kane Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, are all the more frightening. They persist at their posts, five full weeks after Halloween. City Room will continue to follow their inevitable decline.

headline: Bittersweet Moment as Santo Is Elected to the Hall
text: Ron Santo was elected to the Hall of Fame on Monday, barely a year after his death.

headline: For a Veteran, Finding Reasons to Move Forward
text: I cannot place where it became an instinct. An inherent part of who I am, where I pray “Oh Lord, I wanna go…” — the old call-and-response taught by drills. I still count my lefts from rights. Something that clicks and passes on each step without hesitation. A reminder of years passed.

headline: Beirut Blues
text: BEIRUT — The crisis in Syria is crossing the border into Lebanon. Beirut has regularly witnessed bloody clashes between pro- and anti-Syrian groups since the Syrian Army withdrew from Lebanon in 2005. But with the Syrian revolution intensifying, pro-Syrian groups in Lebanon have dispatched their thugs, known as the “shabiha,’’ to keep an eye on Beirut’s main streets.

headline: Touring Valentino’s Museum, Virtually
text: Valentino Garavani is expected to unveil what he is describing as a “virtual museum” this morning with a to-do at the Museum of Modern Art. (Anne Hathaway is presenting, along with Amit Sood, the creator of the Google Art Project.)

headline: On Two Continents, the Prize Machine Works Overtime
text: Do you think the awards elite rest over the weekend? Au contraire! The work of the trophy-hungry is never done.

headline: A Parker Reviewer Departs After Questions About Payments
text: Jay Miller, who covered Spain, Oregon, Washington, South America and Australia for Robert M. Parker Jr.’s Wine Advocate, has stepped down in the wake of allegations  that his representatives in Spain sought payments in return for appearances.

headline: Former N.H.L. Enforcer Todd Fedoruk Answers Questions from Readers
text: 8:09 p.m. | Updated The recently retired N.H.L. player Todd Fedoruk answered questions from readers of the “Punched Out” series about Derek Boogaard and the role of enforcers. Fedoruk, 32 and now an assistant coach with the minor league Trenton Titans, engaged in more than 100 fights in his nine-year N.H.L. career. Off the ice, Fedoruk, like Boogaard, battled an addiction to prescription painkillers. He sustained a career-altering injury in a 2006 fight with Boogaard, but they later became teammates and close friends. (Questions are no longer being accepted for this feature.)

headline: Tory Burch's Love Letter to New York
text: The fashion designer reveals her favorite haunts.

headline: Rooftop Films Gives Occupy Wall Street Its Own Film Series
text: As a political movement, Occupy Wall Street has attracted plenty of headlines, buzz and creative energy. Now, this being New York, it has its own film series. Rooftop Films, in partnership with several movie houses throughout the city, is presenting a free series of four films from Dec. 13 to 16 featuring issues that ignited the demonstrations.

headline: Now Playing | Tory Burch’s Love Letter to New York
text: In a film by Tabitha Denholm, Tory Burch takes a heartfelt tour through the city she loves most. From JG Melon to the Frick and Lincoln Center, Burch’s New York is all about “surprises and newness and evolution,” she says. Inspiring and nostalgic, the short film makes its debut here on The Moment.

headline: Gifts to Savor, Bite by Bite
text: This year I’m giving edible Christmas gifts, and I’ve already begun to make them. I’m focusing on flavored oils and marinated things right now, as they’ll benefit from a few weeks of steeping.

headline: A Spouse’s Bill of Rights
text: My wife lost the use of her legs when radiation to shrink a growth destroyed part of her spinal cord. I have confidence in our physicians and had no doubt that a malpractice suit would be a mistake, but her disability led to another ethical issue. A marketing person for the lifetime-care institution we selected understated its price by $300 a month. Should we hold them to it? We would have come regardless, and we can afford the higher price. DON CELL, CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA

headline: Why Start-Ups Need ‘Crowd-Funding’
text: Are you familiar with “crowd-funding?” You should be. I have been following the progress of new crowd-funding platforms in recent months, and it is now clear that this new financing mechanism can help strapped early-stage ventures, especially social enterprises. In case you’re hearing about crowd-funding for the first time, let me bring you up to speed.

headline: A Catalog of Six-Stringed Cool
text: Hendrix, transcendent. Slash, in repose. Elvis … well, being Elvis.

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on Churches’ Use of Schools
text: Updated, 2:26 p.m. | The United States Supreme Court declined Monday to hear a Bronx church’s appeal of a city ban on holding worship services in public schools.

headline: Bloomberg Wary of Reports on Cuomo’s Tax Agenda
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg reacted cautiously but skeptically Monday to reports that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was considering raising taxes on the wealthy to help close a looming budget gap.

headline: Power in Numbers: China Aims for High-Tech Primacy
text: BEIJING — In an otherwise nondescript conference room, Wu Jianping stands before a giant wall of frosted glass. He toggles a switch and the glass becomes transparent, looking down on an imposing network operations center full of large computer displays. They show maps of China and the world, pinpointing China’s IPv6 links, the next generation of the Internet.

headline: A Maine Farmer Speaks to Wall Street
text: Jim Gerritsen lives a far piece from New York City, in a remote part of northern Maine that what was once known as the Potato Empire. But there he was on Sunday — at age 56 making his first trip to the city — to speak at the Farmers March on Wall Street.

headline: In Sports Car Pileup, a Spotlight on Japan’s Rich
text: TOKYO — A botched lane change led to a spectacular traffic pileup in Japan over the weekend that left a highway strewn with the smashed wreckage of eight Ferraris, a Lamborghini and three Mercedes sports cars.

headline: The Bookends of Reyes’s Mets Career
text: Jose Reyes began his Mets career with a single, batting ninth and leading off the third inning in an interleague game against the Texas Rangers on June 10, 2003. Eight years later, Reyes said goodbye with a single, too, beating out a bunt against the Cincinnati Reds in the first inning of the final game of the season, on Sept. 28, 2011.

headline: TimesCast | December 5, 2011
text: Western monitors criticize Russian elections; France and Germany push for fiscal discipline; and presidential parodies on Saturday Night Live.

headline: Newt Gingrich Meets With Donald Trump and Other Strange Events
text: I was out of the country last week, and I think I may have developed unreasonably high expectations for the American primary campaign.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Ferrari and Red Bull Abandon Formula One Teams Association
text: The body created to represent the mutual goals and grievances of Formula One teams is losing two highly visible members of its rank and file.

headline: Huntsman to Miss Debate in Iowa
text: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. will once again watch from the sidelines on Saturday night as his Republican rivals debate, a victim of poll numbers so low in Iowa that he failed to qualify for the televised event in Des Moines.

headline: Susan Loomis’s Lemon Olive Oil
text: I was introduced to this fragrant oil by my friend and fellow cookbook author Susan Hermann Loomis, who runs a cooking school called On Rue Tatin in her wonderful home in Normandy. I went to visit her one summer evening, and she served roasted peppers doused with this oil and garnished with fresh thyme leaves as part of a first course. The lemon oil goes beautifully with vegetables or fish, and is lovely on a salad or drizzled over bread.

headline: Seabrook Jurors Say They Cannot Reach a Verdict
text: Halfway through the second full day of deliberations on Monday, the jurors deliberating in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook sent a note to the judge saying they were at an impasse in considering all of the counts against Mr. Seabrook.

headline: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
text: Q: (Reader)

headline: Accounts and People of Note in the Advertising Industry
text: Steve Albertini joined the Star Group, Philadelphia, in a new post, managing partner for strategic initiatives. He had been running his own consultancy, the Albertini Group, and before that worked in Philadelphia for agencies like Tierney Communications and Earle Palmer Brown.

headline: New Endeavor for Trevor Project
text: An organization that provides young Americans with suicide prevention and crisis intervention services is adopting a new identity.

headline: The Search for an Era of Labor Peace
text: When the Boeing Company announced its far-reaching, precedent-setting agreement with the machinists’ union last week, all the talk was about the ushering in of a new era of labor peace between a company and union that were long known for their horrendous labor relations record. That record included five strikes since 1977, among them a 58-day walkout in 2008 that cost Boeing $1.8 billion.

headline: A Little Confection Behind the Ear
text: TWENTY years ago, when a roomful of perfumers smelled the sweet scent Thierry Mugler Angel for the first time, most of them were crinkling their noses in disgust.

headline: Students and Principal Are Pepper-Sprayed at Bronx High School
text: Updated, 4:33 p.m. | A student at a Bronx public high school pepper-sprayed at least 14 people, including students and the principal, in the cafeteria and hallway Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.5
text: The day in sports included the world handball championships in São Paulo, Brazil, and the European curling championships in Moscow.

headline: Stifling Returns Beyond Expectations
text: When the Green Bay Packers’ Randall Cobb returned a kickoff 108 yards for a touchdown in the N.F.L. season opener in September, it played out as a rejoinder to the hand-wringing over a rules change that seemed destined to nearly eliminate returns by moving the kick to the 35-yard line from the 30. The adjustment was made to improve player safety — few hits are as explosive as the ones delivered at full speed on kickoff returns — and the N.F.L. figured it was willing to sacrifice the thrill of a possible highlight for fewer concussions.

headline: When Minny Met Talley
text: At Peggy Siegal’s lunch for “The Help” on Friday, what is usually a highly managed affair went off-script, as we noted here, with Billie Jean King getting in on the act. She wasn’t the only guest with something to say. Andre Leon Talley, the Vogue editor and king of pronouncements, played a lively role, commenting, from his seat, about the look of the film, set in the early 1960s, and praising the costume designer, Sharen Davis.

headline: Making Noise About People Who Talk to Their Cellphones
text: My article in Saturday’s New York Times, “Oh, for the Good Old Days of Rude Cellphone Gabbers,” stirred a vocal response among readers, many of whom decried the boorishness of cellphone users in all of its many forms in several hundred comments posted over the weekend. The piece was about people who use voice technologies like Siri in the new iPhone 4S to orally search for restaurants, dictate texts and schedule appointments while in public.

headline: A Magic Number for the Rangers: 2,500
text: The Rangers are seeking the 2,500th victory in club history Monday night when they host the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden. They’re also out for their sixth straight win, their eighth straight at home, and the 13th victory in their last 15 games over all. If they do win, they’ll maintain their position as the team with the N.H.L.’s best overall winning percentage.

headline: The Latest A.T.M. Skimmer Scam
text: Thieves using card readers and hidden cameras stole more than $250,000 from 11 Chase A.T.M.’s near New York City’s Union Square earlier this year, according to a recently unsealed indictment.

headline: Students, Principal Pepper-Sprayed in the Bronx
text: UPDATED | A student at a Bronx public high school pepper-sprayed at least 14 people, including students and the principal, in the cafeteria and hallway Monday afternoon, the authorities said.

headline: Lions Lose Their Cool, Another Game
text: 4:23 p.m. | Updated Appearing on NBC’s Sunday night game could have been an opportunity for the Detroit Lions to showcase how much progress the team has made.

headline: Beware of Female Drivers
text: Many ridiculous reasons have been given over the years for Saudi Arabia’s de facto ban on women drivers (de facto because there is no formal law, but women cannot obtain licenses). If women drive, it’s been said, they will lose their modesty and overcrowd the streets. In a sad Thelma and Louise meet Ishtar moment, it is also said that women who drive will find it easier to rebel against their husbands.

headline: TimesCast | Russian Elections
text: Election monitors and everyday Russians document blatant fraud in the weekend’s parliamentary vote.

headline: In Ireland, Austerity Is Praised but Painful
text: DUBLIN — As European leaders scramble to overcome the Continent’s debt crisis, many are pointing to Ireland as a model for how to get out of the troubles.

headline: Bronfman Is Stepping Down as Warner Music Chairman
text: 8:48 p.m. | Updated  Edgar M. Bronfman Jr., who has been a top executive in the music industry since the mid-1990s, is stepping down as chairman of the Warner Music Group.

headline: Amid New York History, Caffè Storico Speaks Italian
text: Stephen Starr, the Philadelphia restaurateur who also owns Buddakan and Morimoto in Manhattan, won the contract to create a restaurant in the newly renovated New-York Historical Society. The result, named Caffè Storico (Italian for “historic”), will open on Saturday.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach: Friday Night
text: Parties for VMan, Dsquared and Visionaire bring out supermodels and artists.

headline: The Maxx for the Minimum? Discount iPads at TJ Maxx
text: Reports are surfacing about $399 16GB iPads being sold at TJ Maxx tomorrow. That’s a $100 discount, people. Limited supplies (like, 15) are expected at each store, so check it out and get up early.

headline: Inattentional Deafness Disorder
text: We’ve all had the experience of being so engrossed in something (a book, an e-mail, an episode of “Dexter”) that we simply don’t hear our partner trying to remind us that the trash needs to go out. But when our children do the same, who else secretly believes that they’re doing it on purpose?

text: Photographs from Russia, South Africa, Yemen and France.
