headline: A Slow Exodus From Nursing Homes
text: If you’ve helped an older relative move into a nursing home in the past year, you’ve likely heard a nurse or administrator pose The Question: “Do you want to talk to someone about the possibility of returning to the community?”

headline: Manish Sabharwal Answers Readers’ Questions
text: India Ink asked Manish Sabharwal, chairman of the temporary-employment agency TeamLease, who was profiled in a recent New York Times article, to answer readers’ questions about the Indian labor market and his company’s philosophy. Readers posed tough queries about his business model, his competitors and the hurdles that employers and job seekers face in India. The questions and Mr. Sabharwal’s answers have been edited.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 6
text: The production of “Cloud Atlas,” a film version of the David Mitchell novel that has a $100 million budget, is an example of how sophisticated filmmakers “are turning to a globe-straddling independent finance system for their most expensive projects,” rather than American studios, Nicholas Kulish and Michael Cieply report. The talent connected to the project includes Andy and Lana Wachowski, the American-born team behind the “Matrix” movies, and Tom Hanks and Halle Berry. But investors from China, South Korea, Singapore and beyond contributed roughly $35 million, without which the film could not have been made. German subsidies account for $18 million more.

headline: New Iowa Poll: Who Can Beat Obama?
text: Just weeks before the first votes are cast in the 2012 presidential campaign, likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa are closely divided over which candidate has the best chance of defeating President Obama, the latest New York Times/CBS News poll finds.

headline: My Health Insurance Rates Just Went Down Again
text: I got an e-mail last week with my health insurance renewal rates for 2012. (I have written extensively on this subject: on previous rate declines, on the subsequent feedback, on the health care overhaul, and on rates for older workers.) I opened the e-mail with some trepidation, given the general trend of substantial increases every year. Surprise! Another decrease: 6 percent less for single workers, married couples, and families.

headline: Newark Receiving Billions From N.Y.C. Taxpayers (for a Few Hours Each Day)
text: Over the next five years, Newark can expect to receive tens of billions of dollars intended for the New York City treasury and paid by New York City taxpayers, it has been learned.

headline: What We Think We Learn as an N.F.L. Season Progresses
text: It’s tempting to think that we know much more than we did at the start of the season. As of Sunday night, we learned — or, at least, we thought we learned — that San Francisco was really good, that San Diego had gone from unlucky to just plain bad and that the Rams were again one of the league’s doormats. One day later, and maybe the Chargers are getting ready for another late-season run.

headline: Researchers Question Coverage for a Spine Procedure
text: What happens when a medical treatment is not found to clearly benefit patients? The answer may depend on whether the barn door is already wide open, according to a new analysis that reviews the history of a common spine procedure that was shown to be of unclear value long after Medicare and other insurers chose to pay for it.

headline: European Inquiry Focuses On Setting of E-Book Prices
text: BRUSSELS — The European antitrust authority said Tuesday that it was investigating possible collusion between Apple and five large publishing houses in the growing market for electronic books.

headline: ‘Any Normal Human Being Would Be Offended’
text: The Indian government has asked social media operators to delete information on the Internet that might offend  the ‘‘sensibilities’’ of people in India, Kapil Sibal, India’s minister of communications and information technology, said  Tuesday, confirming an earlier India Ink report.

headline: Economic Troubles in Europe and U.S. Start to Affect Asia
text: HONG KONG — An interest rate cut in Australia and lowered economic growth estimates by the Asian Development Bank on Tuesday highlighted the extent to which the economic woes of Europe and the United States are spilling into the Asia-Pacific region.

headline: Is Gingrich This Year’s Huckabee?
text: In 2007, Mike Huckabee snuck up on Mitt Romney. He surged in Iowa in December and ended up robbing Mr. Romney of a victory that he desperately needed.

headline: Russia Cracks Down on Antigovernment Protests
text: MOSCOW — The Russian authorities acted decisively to quash a second day of protests against the government and Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin on Tuesday, flooding the appointed site with throngs of pro-government activists who banged on tin drums, drowning out the chants of “Russia without Putin!”

headline: The Slang Patrol
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: The Slang Patrol
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: E-Commerce Sales Are Booming, Thanks to Discounts and Free Shipping
text: Online, at least, shoppers are spending money. Lots of it.

headline: The Culture Was Corrupt at Olympus, Panel Finds
text: TOKYO — An outside panel appointed by Olympus to investigate its financial scandal issued a harsh report Tuesday, calling the company’s recently departed management “rotten to the core.”

headline: Bombings Kill Scores of Shiites in Afghanistan
text: Bombers struck Shiite religious observances in three cities, in the first such sectarian attacks in Afghanistan since the fall of the Taliban.

headline: A Mismatch Between Grid Regulation and Modern Needs
text: Rooftop solar power is unfairly subsidized yet draws excessive opposition from utility companies because of the way the grid allocates costs for power distribution, according to a new study released by the Massachusetts Institute for Technology.

headline: A Word to the ‘Wise and Honest’ on Washington Sq. Park
text: For lovers of tranquillity, Washington Square Park was a splendid place to be Monday afternoon. Tourists snapped pictures. Young mothers pushed strollers along the paths. Homeless men dozed on benches. Even drug dealers preserved the peace, resorting to a sort of pantomime to hawk their wares.

headline: Opinion Report: Romney’s Hazy Plan
text: From the editorial page

headline: Weekend Roundup of Racing News
text: The Formula One season ended just a week ago, but the news has been piling up. In fact, much of the news coming through now is probably information that some put off announcing until after the season.

headline: Weekend Roundup of Racing News
text: The Formula One season ended just a week ago, but the news has been piling up. In fact, much of the news coming through now is probably information that some put off announcing until after the season.

headline: Hypothetically, What Would Your Ideal School System Look Like?
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was speaking hypothetically last week when he said his ideal school system, which he also said could never be attained, would have teachers of the highest quality (and highly paid), even if it meant fewer of them and class sizes double what they are now. What is your ideal school system, hypothetically speaking?

headline: Mine Owner Will Pay $209 Million in Blast That Killed 29 Workers
text: In what officials say is the largest settlement ever in a government investigation of a mine disaster, Alpha Natural Resources agreed to pay $209 million in restitution and civil and criminal penalties for the role of its subsidiary, Massey Energy, in a mine explosion last year that killed 29 men in West Virginia.

headline: Irish Pfizer Smiling
text: The Times has a good article on Ireland, focusing on the dissonance between the praise of outsiders and the grim realities for the Irish themselves. And as the Times notes, all this “successful” austerity has still left the interest rate on Irish debt at a completely unsustainable level.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Now Booking | Papaya Playa Project
text: The pop-up phenomenon may be old news in retail and restaurants, but temporary hotels is a concept just gaining ground (makeshift bedrooms in Kreuzberg or Nakameguro art galleries excepted). Today the Berlin-based Design Hotels group is staking the first big claim to the trend on the beach in Tulum, Mexico. The company’s founder, Claus Sendlinger, who moved with his family to Tulum last year, is spearheading the opening of Papaya Playa, a spiffed-up campus of cabanas once belonging to three now-shuttered resorts on about a half mile of beachfront land.

headline: A Setting, and Score, Befitting a Thoroughbred
text: If any premiere had the cinematic sweep and heft – and orchestration – of a John Williams score, it would have to be “War Horse” at Lincoln Center. Oh wait: the premiere did have exactly that; the music of Mr. Williams – which even a casual moviegoer would recognize from “Superman,” “Jaws” and “E.T.,” among many, many others – was piped into the afterparty on Sunday night. The soundtrack was just one reason that the world premiere of “War Horse,” Steven Spielberg’s adaptation of the children’s book-turned-theatrical hit felt grand.

headline: Hearing May Be an Ex-Governor’s Last Stand
text: CHICAGO —  Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois, is expected to speak on his own behalf on Wednesday before the federal judge who will decide his sentence for 18 felony corruption convictions, including trying to sell or trade the Senate seat that President Obama left behind when he moved to the White House.

headline: In Surprise Move, China Jails Australian for 13 Years
text: BEIJING — An Australian businessman whose business dealings with a state-owned Chinese company soured last year has been sentenced by a Chinese court to 13 years in prison on bribery and fraud charges, his lawyer and Australian officials said Tuesday.

headline: Tuesday Reading: Public Workers Retiring Earlier in Tight Times
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Kuwaiti Leader Dissolves Parliament
text: The emir of Kuwait dissolved Parliament on Tuesday, setting the stage for elections in the oil-rich Persian Gulf nation that has faced some protests but has thus far been spared the revolutionary wave of the Arab Spring.

headline: Grammys Statement Deepens Mystery of Promised Band Reunion
text: 1:16 p.m. | Updated

headline: Policy Indifference
text: One crucial thing you need to understand about political journalists is that with some honorable exceptions, they don’t know or care about actual policy. In a way, that makes sense — the skills needed to cultivate contacts, to get the inside scoop on what’s going on in Congressional scheming or campaign war rooms, are very different from the skills needed to interpret CBO spreadsheets. The problem, however, is that all too often political journalists mistake the theater of policy for reality (or don’t care about the difference).

headline: European Leaders Question Timing of Credit Downgrade Warning
text: BRUSSELS — European Union leaders reacted angrily Tuesday over the timing of a warning of a broad credit rating downgrade days before a European summit meeting. And German officials portrayed the threat by Standard & Poor’s as impetus for leaders to make a deal to rescue the euro.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: 2 Minutes to Dinner: A writer and cooking and teacher finally comes out and says it: She’s tired of pork belly. Also offal. And a few of the other rich, fatty meats that chefs love. … — Julia Moskin

headline: Graphic Content | Good Chemistry
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Imposing Presence on Iraq’s Streets
text: The streets of Baghdad looked like a different place in 2008--both to the American soldiers peering down and the Iraqis looking up.

headline: Markets Optimistic a Resolution To the Euro Crisis Will Be Found
text: Stocks rose on Tuesday, sending the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index higher a second day, on speculation that European leaders may act to contain the debt crisis after S.& P. put 15 euro nations on review for possible downgrade.

headline: You Like Walking in the City? So Do Plenty of Others
text: Feeling congested? Not your nose, your toes. City surveys confirm that sidewalks are becoming more crowded. And transportation officials say that’s good for the economy, the environment and for your physical, if not necessarily emotional, health.

headline: Video From Kabul Shows Shock as Bomb Explodes
text: Updated | 12:20 p.m. As Sharifullah Sahak and Rod Nordland report for The Times from Kabul, a suicide bomber killed dozens of people watching a religious ceremony in the Afghan capital on Tuesday.

headline: Whalen Joins Tangent Capital as Money Manager
text: Christopher Whalen, the outspoken bank analyst known for his critical industry research, has joined an investment bank after nearly a decade as a managing director of Institutional Risk Analytics, the firm he co-founded.

headline: City Bungled Tavern on the Green Concessions, Audit Says
text: New York City has badly mishandled the creation of concessions at the former Tavern on the Green, said an audit released on Monday by the city’s comptroller, John C. Liu.

headline: City Policies Undermined Jane Addams High
text: Two teachers who taught at Jane Addams High School for Academic Careers in the South Bronx ask: Why did the Education Department let Jane Addams continue on its failing path, and how can it get away with claiming ignorance about the current credit scandal when its interventions provided it with boundless access to the school’s data?

headline: In Nepal, Farmers Struggle as City Dwellers Fight Monsanto
text: Kashish Das Shrestha is a Nepal-born, New York-based photographer and writer who alternates between covering fashion shows and Maoist rebels, celebrities and refugees. In recent e-mail exchanges he alerted me to a building protest effort in Nepal following an announcement in September by the United States Agency for International Development that it was teaming up with Monsanto and Nepali agricultural agencies to promote the benefits of high-yielding hybrid corn varieties and to train Nepali farmers how to grow such crops.

headline: Other Than That, Mr. Cain, How Was the Campaign?
text: This chart should tell you pretty much everything you need to know about the rise and fall of Herman Cain:

headline: Villagers Become Refugees in Myanmar as Rebels Clash With Troops
text: YANGON, Myanmar — Intensifying clashes between ethnic rebels and Myanmar’s army have forced tens of thousands of villagers into refugee camps near the Chinese border, according to aid workers and members of the clergy.

headline: At Dans Le Noir, Dining in the Dark
text: This gives a whole new meaning to “mystery meat.” At Dans Le Noir, which started in Paris eight years ago and has branches in London, Barcelona and St. Petersburg, Russia, customers dine in a pitch-dark room without knowing the details of the menu. The waiters are all blind or visually impaired.

headline: Tiny Tax on Financial Trades Gains Advocates
text: They call it the Robin Hood tax — a tiny levy on trades in the financial markets that would take money from the banks and give it to the world’s poor.

headline: Asked & Answered | Lexi Thompson
text: With her five-stroke victory at the Navistar L.P.G.A. Classic in Prattville, Ala., in September, Lexi Thompson became, at age 16 years, 7 months and 8 days, the youngest winner by nearly two years in the tour’s 61-year history. She made more history shortly thereafter when the L.P.G.A. commissioner, Michael Whan, waived the minimum age requirement of 18 years to allow Thompson to become a full-fledged tour member in 2012.

headline: For Havelange, a Reckoning Long Delayed
text: With a resignation so covert it had to be virtually pried from FIFA and the International Olympic Committee, the Brazilian João Havelange appears to have finally left the scene of high-ranking governance over global sports.

headline: Gifts for Foodies, Cyclists, Geeks and More
text: Whether you are looking to reduce the environmental impact of your gift-giving or win the heart of a green-minded friend, the hunt for holiday gifts that are legitimately planet-friendly can be daunting.

headline: Wheelies: The Unlicensed Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Blunt Talk by Regents Chief for City’s Schools
text: Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott was preparing to meet with the chancellor of the State Board of Regents, Merryl H. Tisch, when a reporter called.

headline: Clinging to the Egyptian Army
text: NAG HAMMADI, Egypt — The citizens of Cairo learned a small lesson in the banality of evil last week when they saw the face of Mahmoud al-Shennawy, the police sniper who allegedly aimed for Tahrir Square protesters’ eyes. When Shennawy’s photo came out, the city gave a collective gasp at his youth. He looks about 15. Is it really possible that that those rosy cheeks were fed by such icy blood?

headline: On the Streets of Baghdad, an Invisible American Withdrawal
text: BAGHDAD — Only a few miles to the west of here, Camp Victory, the vast American military headquarters, was handed over to the Iraqis just a few days ago and the remaining American bases, soldiers and equipment will follow soon.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘The Manchurian Candidate’
text: “The democratic process can often seem like the theater of the absurd,” A. O. Scott says in this week’s Critics’ Picks video, which looks back at John Frankenheimer’s political thriller “The Manchurian Candidate.” The film tells the story of Raymond Shaw (Laurence Harvey),  a soldier who is given the Congressional Medal of Honor for his heroism in Korea, but more about what happened to him in battle soon emerges. Shaw and his troop were kidnapped and brainwashed by Chinese and Soviet Communists who sent Shaw back to the United States as a pawn for their plans of world domination.

headline: Shopping for a Better Deal on Home Services With WhiteFence
text: One of my least favorite tasks is dealing with utilities and other service providers, like the cable company, to see if I can get a better deal. It’s unpleasant, but something that needs to be done periodically — especially when you notice your monthly bills ticking inexorably upwards.

headline: Racial Profiling Versus Affirmative Action
text: My post yesterday about Representative Steve King and racial profiling drew a few responses from readers who argued that racial profiling is no different, really, than affirmative action.

headline: Bank of England Urges Cuts in Bank Pay and Dividends
text: 7:33 p.m. | Updated

headline: Sharp Spate of Killings Traumatizes a Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In one of the worst episodes of sectarian carnage in Syria since the uprising began nine months ago, dozens of corpses were recovered from the streets of Homs this week, some of them dismembered, decapitated and bearing signs of torture, activists and residents said Tuesday.

headline: First Leg of Ocean Race Is an Adventure
text: The last place the professional sailor Ryan Godfrey expected to be this week was hiking around a remote volcanic island in the South Atlantic in long underwear and a T-shirt.

headline: As Seabrook Awaits Verdict, His Lawyers Are Cautioned by Judge
text: Prosecutors in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook have accused defense lawyers in the case of making comments outside of court that could influence the jury’s deliberations.

headline: Myths of the Hispanic Vote
text: Not every liberal is publicly chortling over the prospect of facing Newt Gingrich in the general election. According to the Washington Post, some Democratic strategists fear Gingrich’s ability to … win Hispanic voters:

headline: Macarons for What Ails You
text: THOSE delectable pastel macarons from Ladurée, the French patisserie open in New York since late summer, with lines still up the block, have been given the Judith Leiber treatment. That is, the Leiber company, known for its sparkling evening bags, has modeled a collection of crystal pillboxes after the iconic confection. The inspired idea came about after Jana Matheson, the creative director of Judith Leiber, returned from a trip to Paris with macarons for her office. “Over a tea and macaron meeting, we matched crystal colors to the desserts,” she said. “It was one of our most delicious meetings.” The pillboxes, true to size, come in 14 flavorful colors including champagne, lemon, rose and mint.

headline: Horses That Should Have Their Own IMDB Page
text: The Bagger has already noted that, to our delight, it’s an animal-heavy awards season. Well, there’s a new creature in the celeb barnyard: the star of “War Horse.”

headline: Cisco’s Bigger Bundle of Networking
text: Cisco introduced a comprehensive collection of computer networking hardware for cloud computing on Tuesday. The parts are not particularly new, but the packaging is — and that matters for both customer education and sales.

headline: Minor Bounce for Commercial Metals as Icahn Goes Hostile
text: 5:03 p.m. | Updated

headline: Chinese Bank Pairs Up With Private Equity
text: LONDON — The state-owned China Development Bank announced strategic agreements on Tuesday with the private equity firms K.K.R., TPG Capital and Permira as it continued its international expansion.

headline: A Breakdown at Sea
text: A broken mast forced the Puma race crew and boat to a remote island, where crew members awaited assistance during the first leg of the Volvo Ocean Race, from Alicante, Spain, to Cape Town.

headline: Leading Off: The Sounds of Mostly Silence (So Far)
text: As the final installment in the story of the life and death of the hockey enforcer Derek Boogaard by The Times’s John Branch rolls out Tuesday, the waiting begins. Waiting to see if the sport reacts to something that has laid out the devastating effects of fighting in painful detail. Waiting to see if fans will continue to cheer fights, knowing they are likely trading those players’ brains for their entertainment. Waiting to see if pundits can still manage to proffer the absurd arguments about the violence preventing more violence.

headline: Suno’s New Footprint
text: Remember what we said about printed shoes this season? Now from Suno, the out-of-Africa label designed by Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, come five pairs of supercolorful, print-happy sneakers. “By doing this we can further our company’s mission to create jobs within Kenya, and by using excess fabric from past productions we can make darn cute shoes at a really attractive price,” Osterweis says. Darn cute is right. These classic slip-ons and lace-ups not only have names like “clustered caviar” and “bandana flower,” but their soles are made from recycled rubber, too. “And we’re helping baby elephants,” adds Beatty, noting that a portion of all of the shoes’ proceeds will go to the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust in Kenya. Here’s to walking the walk.

headline: Tax Deal Expected Between Cuomo and Lawmakers
text: Update, 2:05 p.m. | A tentative deal has been reached to raise taxes on the wealthy and cut taxes on the middle class. See article here.

headline: Boston University Doctor Answers Questions from Readers
text: Dr. Robert A. Stern, a neuropsychologist and a co-director for the Center for the Study of Traumatic Encephalopathy, is answering questions Tuesday afternoon about C.T.E. and John Branch’s series “Punched Out.”

headline: An Encore in Los Angeles for ‘Follies’
text: The “Beautiful Girls” are headed west: the Center Theater Group announced on Tuesday that it will transfer the acclaimed Broadway revival of “Follies” to the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles for a six-week run beginning May 3, 2012. The Broadway production, which opened in September, will continue its run at the Marquis Theater through Jan. 22, as scheduled.

headline: Some Perspective on Reyes
text: The animation team at NMA.tv has done it again, with a clear and concise wrap-up of Jose Reyes signing with the Marlins, the Mets’ future plans, Miami’s pursuit of Albert Pujols and for good measure the news that the Mets and Red Sox are now (apparently) rivals.

headline: Wall Street Women Optimistic About Investment Opportunities
text: It’s been a difficult year for the alternative investment industry, as hedge funds, private equity firms and venture capital funds have been buffeted by worldwide market volatility.

headline: Bipartisan Push for Vast Transportation Bill
text: While Republicans and Democrats fight over how to pay for the extension of a payroll tax cut — or whether to let it continue at all — a bipartisan cadre of House members has quietly been coalescing around the notion of a large-scale, long-term transportation bill to address the country’s myriad infrastructure needs.

headline: U.S. to Aid Gay Rights Abroad, Obama and Clinton Say
text: GENEVA — The Obama administration announced on Tuesday that the United States would use all the tools of American diplomacy, including the potent enticement of foreign aid, to promote gay rights around the world.

headline: Gingrich on Climate – The 2007 Version
text: Now that Newt Gingrich is a front runner, his foes from both parties are sifting for past statements that clash with his current agenda. On climate, there are plenty of examples of his shifts. I offer some fresh fare — a video interview I conducted with him in 2007 on climate science and policy (related to a much-discussed article of mine on the middle ground in climate policy). It had been off the grid for awhile but is restored here. Have a listen and see whether he’s changed his tune on global warming.

headline: Travel Lessons From the World of Academia
text: If I’ve said it once, I’ve said it thousands of times: “Substantial Amounts of Domain Importance Heterogeneity exist in the contribution of vacations to people’s Quality of Life.”

headline: Talking Restaurants and Closings, One Owner to Another
text: Southfork Kitchen is closed for the season. It took weeks to complete the physical task, what with inventory, cleaning, canceling vendors and preserving whatever foods we could. It’s taking much longer to shut down internally. I miss the hustle and bustle. I miss the staff. Change was never my friend, especially unscheduled change, a change that brought unexpected sadness, a sense of failure and an empty freedom.

headline: Android Marketplace Tops 10 Billion App Downloads
text: Android continues to nip at Apple’s heels. On Tuesday, Google announced that more than 10 billion applications had been downloaded to Android devices from its mobile software shop.

headline: Hezbollah Leader Backs Syrian President in Public
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, made a rare public appearance on Tuesday in Beirut, reiterating his support for Syria’s government and saying that his group was better trained and armed than ever.

headline: Nadler Wants Police Activity at Wall St. Protests Scrutinized
text: Representative Jerrold Nadler, ranking member of the House Judiciary Committee’s Subcommittee on the Constitution and representative of the district that includes Zuccotti Park, sent a letter to Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Tuesday urging him to examine reports of police misconduct at the Occupy Wall Street protests.

headline: Campaign Ads Show Sharp Declines From 2008
text: At this point in 2007, Iowa residents had been subjected to 26,037 television commercials from presidential candidates and political groups in a barrage of advertising that was unparalleled.

headline: A Campaign Against Bed Sharing
text: Last month, Milwaukee introduced two public service announcements intended to stop parents and caregivers from bringing infants into their beds. In the wake of nine infant deaths associated with an “unsafe sleep environment” in 2011 (including one discovered on the day the new campaign was announced), two ads went up citywide on buses and billboards, each showing a young baby (one white, one black) asleep in an adult bed amid much soft bedding, with a butcher knife tucked in alongside. “Your baby sleeping with you can be just as dangerous,” the ads say.

headline: Plus/Minus: The N.H.L.’s Realignment Plan
text: Gary Bettman is well aware the N.H.L.’s drastic realignment into four conferences is ripe for criticism from league commentators, fans, and even some of the team executives that voted on it.

headline: City Opera, Leaving Lincoln Center, Will Have Offices in Lower Manhattan
text: The New York City Opera, which is moving out of Lincoln Center, said on Tuesday that it had found office space in Lower Manhattan. The company said it would move its administrative operation to 75 Broad Street on Dec. 16, taking residence in temporary quarters there before occupying 14,000 square feet of renovated space in March or April. The company is also renting 4,000 square feet of storage space in the building, partly for its archives.

headline: The Giving Spree | Pat McGrath
text: Who: The makeup artist Pat McGrath

headline: Plan for Online Freedoms Stalls at European Meeting
text: VILNIUS, Lithuania — The United States and two dozen other nations called for the adoption of a declaration of freedoms in cyberspace at a European security conference here on Tuesday, but the proposal stalled in the face of opposition from Russia and countries that view the Internet as a threat to their political systems.

headline: Gingrich Holds Strong Lead in South Carolina Poll
text: Although the political world is laser-focused on the coming presidential contests in Iowa and New Hampshire, the South Carolina primary is looming on Jan. 21, and former Speaker Newt Gingrich now holds a commanding lead in the state, according to a new poll released Tuesday.

headline: Lens: 7 Bill Final
text: Lens: 7 Bill Final

headline: Marni Store Enlivens Sleepy Stretch of Meatpacking District
text: Whether it is because of its unusual triangular footprint or the fact that a sumptuous Yohji Yamamoto boutique occupied it previously, the new Marni space at 1 Gansevoort Street, (646) 532-6015, empty for many months, seemed destined for a special tenant. Indeed, Consuelo Castiglioni’s quirky Marni Edition designs for women and men, as well as her children’s collection, have enlivened the space and a sleepy stretch of the meatpacking district. Though there are Marni outposts in SoHo and on the Upper East Side, this is the first United States location for Marni Edition, a slightly less expensive line with prices that may still keep us waiting for Ms. Castiglioni’s H&M debut in March.

headline: Can The Raptors Turn It Around?
text: The Toronto Raptors were a truly unfortunate team last season, plagued by performance deficiencies in virtually every facet of the game. Their league-worst defense turned the Air Canada Centre into a sanctuary for visiting teams, and the Raps’ offense was only slightly less hospitable. Overall, Toronto managed the fifth-worst efficiency differential in the entire N.B.A. last year, a mark truly representative of their failings in some of the game’s most crucial areas.

headline: On Our Radar: Gingrich on Climate Change
text: Three years after appearing in a commercial with Representative Nancy Pelosi to warn that human-caused climate change is under way, Newt Gringrich, the Republican presidential hopeful, tells Glenn Beck that there is “evidence on both sides of the climate change argument.” [Huffington Post]

headline: Albany Tax Deal to Raise Rate for Highest Earners
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders announced on Tuesday that they had reached an agreement to overhaul New York State’s income tax, creating a higher tax bracket for the highest-income residents and reducing the tax rate for millions of middle-class residents.

headline: Orchestra of St. Luke’s Names Conductor
text: Pablo Heras-Casado will become the principal conductor of the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, the ensemble said on Tuesday. Mr. Heras-Casado, a 34-year-old Spaniard, has been making guest appearances with major orchestras recently and is considered a rising talent.

headline: 70 Years Later: Using Historic Times Articles and Social Media to Remember Pearl Harbor
text: Overview | What happened on Dec. 7, 1941? Why is the attack on Pearl Harbor such a historically important event? In this lesson, students learn about the 1941 attack by reading an archival Times article from the day after, and then either create a series of Twitter posts that document the attack and resulting declaration of war, or write a “Historic Headlines”-style summary and analysis of the event and its repercussions — and their connection to today.

headline: Chris Wallace to Interview Mitt Romney
text: After a much-panned interview with Bret Baier of Fox News Channel last week and facing a growing perception that he has kept potentially tough interviews to a minimum, Mitt Romney has agreed to sit for a Dec. 18 interview on “Fox News Sunday with Chris Wallace.”

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.6
text: The World Cup men’s Alpine skiing circuit continued in Beaver Creek, Colo.

headline: Paul Takes On Gingrich in New Ad
text: Representative Ron Paul of Texas has emerged as the Republican presidential candidate most willing to attack his rivals with hard-hitting commercials.

headline: From Russia, With Fraud
text: Having spent four years covering the Soviet Union in the mid-1980’s, and as a student of Russia and Russian history since I was in my teens, I’ve been watching the elections in that long-suffering country with fascination.

headline: Vain Glorious | Home Fragrance
text: Who: The designers Shipley & Halmos and the perfumers D.S. & Durga

headline: City Sidewalks, Busy Sidewalks
text: Traffic congestion isn’t just for the highways. In New York City, it’s the sidewalks that are overcrowded.

headline: Dodge Dart: A Familiar Name Returns From an Unlikely Place

headline: Council Committee Endorses Cuomo’s Tax Plan
text: As elected officials in Albany put the final touches on a deal to raise taxes on wealthy New Yorkers, they got a vote of support from the New York City Council finance committee, which passed a resolution Tuesday morning endorsing Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s effort to institute a more progressive tax code.

headline: TimesCast | December 6, 2011
text: Three sectarian bombings in Afghanistan; a study shows brain damage in some N.H.L. players; and a poll shows Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney competing for the Iowa Republican caucuses.

headline: Banks Rely Too Heavily On Social Security Numbers, Report Finds
text: Banks can do better at protecting their customers from the risk of identity fraud, a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research finds.

headline: The World Is Ending, Please Update the Home Page
text: Let’s say, just for giggles, that the word was ending. Could be an alien invasion, a pandemic or nuclear annihilation. If one of those scenarios became a news event, how would it be covered?

headline: New European Bank Chief Takes a Bold Approach
text: FRANKFURT — For someone with a reputation for caution, Mario Draghi is off to an audacious start as president of the European Central Bank.

headline: Gingrich Surges Ahead in Iowa
text: DES MOINES – A month before the Republican nominating contest opens here, former Speaker Newt Gingrich holds a substantial lead among voters who say they are likely to participate in the Iowa caucuses, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: TimesCast | Attacks On Afghan Shiites
text: December 6, 2011 - Three coordinated bombings in Afghanistan targeted Shiites celebrating a holy day, in the first such sectarian attacks since the fall of the Taliban in 2001.

headline: ‘Girl Walk//All Day': A Conversation With the Director
text: Last January, Jacob Krupnick posted online a nearly eight-minute video featuring a young woman with cropped brown hair dancing with abandon on the Staten Island ferry. A few passengers gawk, but for the most part she’s ignored. The video soon went viral. Now, almost a year later, it’s a feature film called “Girl Walk//All Day.” In the last few weeks, chapters of the movie have been released on the Gothamist Web site, while the Dia Art Foundation featured several of the performers at its gala. And on Thursday the film will make its public debut at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple.

headline: Just One Look | Jason Wu
text: “Charles Harper’s Birds and Words” (Ammo) by Charley Harper set the tone at Jason Wu’s prefall presentation, where rich peacock colors and jersey tees with sporty palm frond appliqués stood out most. There were day looks: a double-stripe sweater with skinny pants or leather pencil skirt; a number of knee-length dresses with pockets and belts attached. Meanwhile, dramatic evening looks inspired by a maharajah coffee table book featured lavish details like silver lead collars and floaty, handkerchief hemlines. Here, a glowing blue brocade suit. “It’s a bit darker and more sinister, which I love,” Wu says about the collection. “She totally has a raspy voice!”

headline: Reviewing Family Recipe
text: What should we call the cuisine offered by chef Akiko Thurnauer at Family Recipe, an idiosyncratic little restaurant on one of the less trafficked blocks of the Lower East Side (and the subject of this week’s $25 and Under)?

headline: Israeli Ex-President Avows Innocence on Eve of Prison
text: KIRYAT MALACHI, Israel — A day after Moshe Katsav, Israel’s former president, turned 66, his modest home in this immigrant town was filled on Tuesday with grandchildren and well-wishers. Phones rang. Neighbors with sun-creased faces offered hugs. Rabbis in tall hats gave their blessings.

headline: British TV Crew Reports From Homs, a Syrian City Under Siege
text: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, “In one of the worst episodes of sectarian carnage in Syria since the uprising began nine months ago, dozens of corpses were recovered from the streets of Homs this week, some of them dismembered, decapitated and bearing signs of torture, activists and residents said Tuesday.”

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Cameras in the Court?

headline: Conclave to Open on Mekong’s Fate
text: The Laotians call it Mae Nam Khong, the Mother of Water. The Vietnamese refer to it as Song Cuu Long, or the Nine Dragons River. The Khmer prefer Tonle Thum, or simply Great River. Whatever its name, the Mekong River is a lifeline for millions in the countries touched by its muddy waters, the world’s largest inland fishery.

headline: Family Recipe
text: ON top of the pancake, something was writhing: a clew of bonito flakes in silent riot, the diaphanous curls lurching and shuddering. A diner whipped out her iPhone and started shooting. (“For the kids,” she explained.)

headline: Meanwhile, in the Race Involving Pandas and Geese …
text: The nominations for the Annies, the animation world’s Oscars, were announced on Monday, and it was a good year for DreamWorks. The studio – which won the first-ever animation Oscar, with “Shrek,” in 2002 – has two films in the running for best feature Annie, “Puss in Boots” and “Kung Fu Panda 2,” both considered Oscar hopefuls. The competition is strong though, with “Rango,” from Paramount and Nickelodeon; “Cars 2,” from Pixar; “Arthur Christmas,” from Sony, and “The Adventures of Tintin,” from Steven Spielberg’s Amblin Entertainment, all making the cut. (The complete list of nominations is here.)

headline: Mama and Papa Versus Life Upon the Wicked Stage
text: “The Jazz Singer” is best known as the first feature-length talkie, a 1927 cinematic artifact assigned in every introductory film class. Before it was a movie, though, it was a hit Broadway play.

text: OSAWATOMIE, Kan. — Laying out a populist argument for his re-election next year, President Obama ventured into the conservative heartland on Tuesday to deliver his most pointed appeal yet for a strong governmental role through tax and regulation to level the economic playing field.

headline: Touch-Up Software for Smoothing Over Imperfections Like a Pro
text: THE professional photographer’s dirty little secret is that not all photos look so professional straight from the camera. The pros make digital touch-ups to profoundly enhance their shots.

headline: The Get | Moncler + Mykita Sunglasses
text: Today, the winter-sports outfitter Moncler announced its collaboration with Mykita, the sunglasses brand best known for shading Lady Gaga and Sarah Jessica Parker from sun and camera flashes alike. The two styles, both of which are oversize and fabulously buglike, come in three colors: black, blue and red. We see stocking stuffers!

headline: A Reputation Staked, and Shattered, on the Forged Diaries of Hitler
text: The English historian Hugh Trevor-Roper (1914-2003) is best remembered, if at all, for a humiliating blunder. He was the Oxford and Cambridge scholar who, in 1983, was called upon to authenticate diaries, discovered by the German magazine Stern, said to be Hitler’s. Trevor-Roper didn’t merely pronounce the Hitler diaries genuine. He also declared them “the most important historical discovery of the decade.” He maintained that they were, in an odd comparison, “a scoop of Watergate proportions.” The diaries turned out to be crude forgeries, and his reputation was shattered.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Hidden City’
text: In the early part of the century, one of my primary guilty pleasures was A&E’s “City Confidential,” a true-crime show that was the closest thing on television to a dirty little B-movie. There’s been no lack of docu-reality crime shows since it went off the air in 2006, but none has had the same combination of regional flavor, hard-boiled attitude and lurid, literate narration. “City Confidential” made your skin crawl in the best way.

headline: Amazon Acquires Children’s Book Titles
text: Amazon expanded its publishing ambitions on Tuesday by acquiring more than 450 titles from Marshall Cavendish Children’s Books, a niche publisher.

headline: Beijing's Smoggy Skies
text: As a brownish gray haze sits atop the Chinese capital, people are starting to ask if the government is giving the public an accurate picture of the country's air quality.

headline: CBS Wins Monday Night Ratings
text: With the most recent season of ABC’s “Dancing with the Stars” completed, CBS dominated the remaining competition in prime time on Monday and won every half-hour in total viewership and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for a ratings sweep. “How I Met Your Mother” started the night off with its largest audience since Jan. 12, 2009, (11.7 million total viewers), followed by “2 Broke Girls” and its largest audience (12.8 million) since its premiere. “Two and a Half Men” was the most-watched program of the night with 15 million viewers.

headline: The Turtleneck Comes Out of Its Shell
text: Chalk it up to a need for a little sartorial dignity in an overly confessional culture; or to the grass-is-greener yearning for a cold-weather garment when 60-degree temperatures have steadily been reported on the East Coast; or even to Steve Jobs.

headline: When Will We Stop the Scapegoating?
text: As the 2012 presidential election approaches, it has been difficult for me to listen to the political scapegoating of Muslims and those perceived to be Muslims. A decade ago, as an attorney at the Department of Justice, I worked with colleagues in the civil rights division to address the unprecedented backlash in the wake of the 9/11 attacks. We investigated complaints of brutal hate crimes in neighborhoods, vandalism at places of worship, bullying at schools, and discrimination in the workplace aimed primarily at those who traced their origins to South Asia and the Middle East, or those who practiced Islam, Sikhism and Hinduism.

headline: Video Games for All Tastes and Attention Spans
text: It wasn’t long ago that video games were on the verge of being marginalized in American culture — like comic books. (When was the last time you saw an adult reading a comic book, err, excuse me, a “graphic novel,” in public? Never?)

headline: Some Instant Motivation for the Fitness Conscious
text: LOOKING for something to place under the tree for the health buff in the family? Skip the Zumba DVDs and consider a fitness gadget. They can make a great present for anyone on your list, whether that person is an ardent athlete or simply wants a little help working off holiday indulgences like eggnog and pecan pie.

headline: Are You Now or Have You Ever Been a Muppet?
text: There’s a certain breed of right winger who likes to pick on Hollywood. Who says it’s a bastion of liberal thinking that promotes lefitst ideas in movies and on television. And who claims this leads to the brainwashing of Americans, especially children, with liberal values.

headline: Coming Out of Its Shell Once More
text: AT the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund awards last month, where the red carpet teemed with actresses and designers dressed in complicated evening numbers of varying slits and cuts, the designer Rachel Roy was covered neck to toe in a floor-length black skirt from her own collection and a sheer, flesh-colored turtleneck by Stella McCartney.

headline: Former Schools Official Is Fined for Ethics Violation
text: The former chief financial officer for the Department of Education has agreed to pay a $6,500 fine to the city’s Conflict of Interest Board for using his public e-mail account to promote a personal business and plot his exit into a private-sector job.

headline: Outrage Grows Over Air Pollution and China’s Response
text: BEIJING — The statement posted online along with a photograph of central Beijing muffled in a miasma of brown haze did not mince words: “The end of the world is imminent.”

headline: On the Calmest Red Carpet With Angelina Jolie
text: It has been a good few days for getting a glimpse of highly glam directors: On Sunday, Madonna was totally zen as she screened her new movie, “W.E.,” at the Museum of Modern Art (“It seemed like she entered the Modern after taking a yoga class,” said Stephen Schaefer, a reporter who covered the scene for Variety) and on Monday night, Angelina Jolie was the picture of placidity as she strolled the red carpet for the premiere of her directorial debut, “In the Land of Blood and Honey.”

headline: When Daddy’s Cafeteria Is in Afghanistan
text: Marine stoicism is no longer expected from the kindergartners at schools on the Marine base at Camp Lejeune, N.C., who are waiting for Dad or Mom (women make up 11 percent of forces serving in Iraq and Afghanistan, and 40 percent of them have children) to come home. Instead, an impressive array of high-quality support services are available for children with parents at war. How much can any club or counseling do to help a child manage the hopes and fears and confusion that come with watching a parent get on that plane, or come home injured or changed (or not at all)? Maybe not much, but the military is trying. In 2008-9, it spent $6 million to train 420 school counselors and psychologists in methods for helping children affected by parents serving in wartime. Michael Winerip’s recent article in The Times, “Lessons in Coping for Children of Deployed,” is a reminder that not all sacrifices come from our troops.

headline: Livestreamed Me
text: The Times tells me that tonight’s event — a discussion of the economy by Carmen Reinhart, Joe Nocera, and me me me, moderated by Tom Friedman, will be livestreamed from the opinion front, starting I assume at 7:30.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 81
text: Occupy Our Homes began nationwide demonstrations on Tuesday to protest the foreclosure crisis. Protesters in New York are visiting neighborhoods with high foreclosure rates and plan to “reoccupy” a foreclosed home. [Mother Jones, The Guardian]

text: Iran’s foreign minister promised that Iranian protesters will not overrun and vandalize any more embassies in Tehran, the way they did Britain’s diplomatic facilities in Tehran last week.

headline: Conditions at Fukushima Plant Improve, but Return Home Will Take Years
text: Some predict that one area around the plant, about twice the size of Manhattan, will be uninhabitable for at least two decades, though steps like removing soil could shorten that time.

text: TOKYO — Traces of radioactive cesium thought to be from the crippled Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant were detected in Japanese baby formula on Tuesday as concerns about food safety continue almost nine months after the accident.

headline: Welcome to the Club
text: NOT everybody yearns for Brooklyn, or even for what Brooklyn has come to represent among New York restaurants. The guys in beards and knit hats have their place, as do the tattooed servers, the avant-garde wines and turn-of-the-last-century cocktailians, and all the rest.

headline: Reviewing Monkey Bar, and Its Wines
text: With few exceptions, wine lovers complain regularly that restaurant reviews pay short shrift to wine. I understand the position, yet I’m not exactly sure what the wine lovers would have restaurant critics do.

headline: Poll Shows Age Gap in G.O.P. on Immigration

headline: The Stuff That ‘Dream School’ Is Made Of
text: The touchstones seem to be everywhere these days: the plaid-wearing, goateed bicycle messengers of “Portlandia”; the grunge heiress Frances Bean Cobain’s recent Hedi Slimane photo shoot; the chortling return of “Beavis and Butthead” to MTV. Yes, the ‘90s are totally back — so much so that some culture observers are probably busy deciding at this very moment that they’re already over again. And there’s no doubt that “Dream School” (Figment), Blake Nelson’s sequel to his beloved 1994 teenage bildungsroman, “Girl,” owes its publication, at least partly, to our current fascination with that halcyon age of mix tapes and Doc Martens. Nelson himself said, “I finished writing the book in 2000, but nobody would publish it, so it sat in my drawer for 10 years.”

headline: Fukushima’s Ripple Effects Continue
text: The triple meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in March startled many people in the American nuclear industry, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Tuesday, although the success in ultimately gaining control of the reactors did not.

The Nets, however, are in the awkward position of trying to embrace their 35 years in New Jersey while preparing to depart for Brooklyn at the end of the season.

headline: Colbert Pushes ‘Corporations Are People’ Referendum
text: Ever since August, when Mitt Romney declared that “corporations are people,” Stephen Colbert, the host of “The Colbert Report” on Comedy Central, has taken a particular interest in the matter of corporate personhood, and has argued, among other things, that parents should allow their daughters to date corporations.

headline: Limited Choices for Yahoo, Each One With Its Own Risks
text: Yahoo shareholders should brace themselves again for disappointment. While the board is seeking a deal for the company, Yahoo faces limited options — all with significant downsides and risks.

headline: Save a Tree, Eat a Panettone
text: Panettone, the yeasty, lightly sweetened mound with a smattering of dried fruits, usually has a shelf life surpassed only by that of fruitcake. But here is a panettone that will be reduced to crumbs in a short time. Scarpato, a pastry company founded in Legnano, Italy, in 1888, is baking a not-so-traditional Christmas version, using organic olive oil in the dough. The result — moist, rich and aromatic — is excellent plain with a glass of sweet wine after dinner, or turned into French toast for breakfast. The olive oil comes from a company called Nudo, which supports a collection of small growers in Central Italy, and encourages the public to “adopt” an olive tree to help the farmers — in return for tins of oil.

headline: Pairings: Poached Fruit Flambé
text: Typically smoky Islay Scotches may be a little more challenging to pair with food than something from Speyside, but as long as the food is assertive — perhaps briny, meaty, sharp, earthy, even sweet, and especially if it has a whiff of smoke to complement the drink — an Islay will fit right in. Oysters, smoked salmon or other smoked fish, mushrooms, barbecue, cheeses, steak, offal, game, roast chicken, Caesar salad, chocolate cake, the list goes on and on.

headline: Vodka That’s More Eastern Parkway Than Eastern Europe
text: Its name, Brooklyn Republic Vodka, radiates the borough’s prickly pride. And though this crystalline new spirit does not begin life in Kings County, it achieves its clean aroma, bright flavor and smooth finish there. It’s the work of a troika of resident Brooklyn vodka lovers: Gary Shokin, who came to New York from Lithuania some 30 years ago; his daughter Kary Laskin, born and raised in Brooklyn; and Mark Krupkin, originally from Latvia. The vodka starts in Missouri, where it is distilled from corn mixed with organic upstate New York wheat. The overproof distillate is shipped to Brooklyn Republic’s Clinton Hill plant, where it is brought down to 80 proof with filtered Brooklyn tap water, then filtered several more times before being sealed in handsome bottles.

headline: From Scotland, Fog and Smoke and Mystery
text: TASTING whiskies can be a clinical, prosaic task, nosing and assessing, jotting notes, reconsidering, lips compressed in concentration, brow furrowed. Yet, as the spirits panel tasted 20 single malts from Islay, we reminded ourselves to step back a moment, to contemplate with no small amount of awe the magic of what was in the glass. Islay demands a sense of wonder.

headline: Methods for Finding a Lost Fresco by Leonardo Lead to a Protest
text: ROME — More than 300 scholars have signed a petition to Florence’s mayor and that city’s top art authority to stop a project that hopes to find a Leonardo da Vinci masterpiece behind a fresco by Giorgio Vasari in the Palazzo Vecchio, now city hall.

headline: Touch of Evil: Cinematic Villainy From the Year’s Best Performers
text: A video gallery of cinematic villainy featuring the best performers from the year in film.

headline: The Myths of the Bar, Debunked
text: EDUCATING the average drinker on the qualities of firewater, and how to best enjoy it, has been one of the central credos of the new generation of mixologists. “Knowledge!” they cry, as they throw back shots of Fernet-Branca.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: A New Name Hits the New-Music Scene
text: New York City’s new-music world is densely populated, with groups of just about every size, instrumentation and stylistic persuasion jostling for the spotlight. But there seems always to be room for more, and on Sunday evening the Ensemble Moto Perpetuo introduced itself with a short but alluring program at the DiMenna Center for Classical Music in Manhattan.

headline: Verizon Is Reported to Be Planning a Streaming Service
text: On Tuesday, Reuters reported that Verizon planned to introduce a service that would let customers stream television shows and movies over the Web. The service could be introduced as early as next year, according to the report, and would offer a limited lineup of movies and television shows.

headline: Behind the Camera, but Still the Star
text: Once the red carpet follies were over, the war correspondent Christiane Amanpour introduced the film, calling it “remarkable and courageous” while warning that there was “no way to sugarcoat” the atrocities it portrays. The afterparty, at a nightclub high atop a hip New York hotel in the meatpacking district, complete with the usual supercilious doormen, rotating disco ball and thumping music, was co-sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations and the human rights group Women for Women International.

headline: When the Country Was Attacked, and There Were No TV Updates
text: A disastrous attack catches the United States by surprise, and in the hours that follow, the president and other leaders must make major decisions hindered by communication problems and a lack of clarity as to what exactly has occurred and whether more attacks are coming. What? Someone is still commemorating the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11?

headline: New Breast Cancer Test May Help Curtail Treatments
text: A new test might allow some women with the earliest phase of breast cancer to forgo the most aggressive treatment, researchers are reporting this week.

headline: With Rude Names, Wine Stops Minding Its Manners
text: IT’S peppery and full of fight. The tannins have grip. The nose takes no prisoners. This shiraz is a bitch.

headline: Fleet Fingers Illustrating Eclectic Influences on Composers From Bach to Ligeti
text: The choice of encores reveals much about a musician’s programming aesthetic. Instead of a popular bonbon, the pianist Jeremy Denk rewarded the audience at his recital at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening with a thoughtful interpretation of “The Alcotts,” the third movement of Ives’s “Concord” Sonata.

headline: To Artfully Capture Memories, Try These Cameras
text: CAMERA phones are terrific for documentation, capturing those spur of the moment snapshots of your pals downing sushi, your child finding a turtle in the driveway or even the damage someone did sideswiping your car. But the images you get probably are not frame quality.

headline: Resisting Renaming of Miami Museum
text: MIAMI — Walking across a sun-baked construction site in his hard hat the other day, Jorge M. Pérez said he was proud that this city’s major art museum, whose new home is being built here beside Biscayne Bay, is now going to bear his name.

headline: Netflix’s Chief Sees HBO as Its Main Rival
text: As Netflix starts to stock up on original TV shows, it is identifying its biggest competitor as HBO, the premium cable channel.

headline: The Roots: 2 Albums, One Quest
text: One mission isn’t enough for the Roots, who have released two albums almost simultaneously. “Undun” (Def Jam), the Roots’ own 13th studio album, arrived on Tuesday, and a collaboration with the soul singer Betty Wright, “Betty Wright: The Movie” (Ms. B/S-Curve) came out on Nov. 15.

headline: In Wake of Terror Attacks, Unlikely Bonds
text: Rachid Bouchareb’s tidy little two-character film, “London River,” demonstrates how great acting can infuse a banal, politically correct drama with dollops of emotional truth. This cozy tale of the rapprochement between two cultures, each personified by an individual, is likable in the same way as “Driving Miss Daisy,” though “London River” is tougher and sadder and not as well written.

headline: New York Times Poll on Iowa Voters
text: Two-thirds of likely Iowa voters say they are remain open to changing their minds, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll said.

headline: How the Iowa Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted with 642 likely Republican caucusgoers throughout Iowa from Nov. 30 to Dec. 5.

headline: In Iowa, Gingrich Is Gaining Favor, New Poll Shows
text: DES MOINES — Newt Gingrich enters the final four weeks of campaigning before the Iowa caucuses with Republican voters in the state viewing him as more prepared to be president than Mitt Romney, more attuned to their concerns and just as capable of defeating President Obama, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: Bus Workers Rally at City Hall
text: At a rally, the union representing school bus drivers said the city should be focusing on the safety of children who ride the buses.

headline: Plummeting, Surfing, Off-Roading, and Getting It All on Camera
text: VIDEO is all about capturing the moment to relive later, but some moments are not exactly camera-friendly. You may not want to have your hands on a camera with your eyes glued to an LCD screen while hurtling around a racetrack, plummeting earthward on a bungee cord or surfing a 20-footer in Maui. Especially if you want to live long enough to relive the moment.

headline: Voices From the Iowa Poll
text: Jeff Zeleny reports on the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, focused on Iowa voters. In one month, the state’s caucuses will kick off the presidential election cycle.

headline: Going the Distance to Make Craft Cocktails at Home
text: IT was while my station wagon sat stuck behind a dump truck as I inched across Westchester County trying to find a bottle of Italian chestnut honey distillate that I realized I was probably not cut out for this mixology thing. I had the passion, to be sure, even if my after-work bartending adventures only sporadically get beyond the pour-bourbon-on-top-of-ice stage. And the mission had seemed simple enough. The idea was to attempt to make a few recipes from the most buzzed-about cocktail guide in the country, “The PDT Cocktail Book” (Sterling Epicure; $24.95) by Jim Meehan.

headline: Mix-and-Match Headphones from Fanny Wang
text: If you have ever looked at a garish pair of over-the-ear headphones and thought, “I could design something better than those clown cans,” here’s your chance.

headline: A Tech Gift for the Kitchen, and for the Bath...
text: THE gadget-obsessed spend a lot of time thinking about the living room, especially this time of year, when new devices for watching television and movies and listening to music are destined to take up prime real estate under the Christmas tree.

headline: E-Ink on Your Wrist
text: E-ink, the passive displays popular on many e-readers, just found a home on your wrist.

headline: Tip of the Week: Changing Outlook’s Navigation Pane
text: That column full of buttons (officially known as the Navigation Pane) on the left side of the Microsoft Outlook 2007 and 2010 window makes it easy to jump around among Mail, Contacts, Calendar and the other parts of the program. You are not stuck with the default version of the Navigation Pane, though, and if you like to put the buttons in your own preferred order, you can customize it.

headline: Mixing Drinks for Credit
text: IN the typical culinary classroom, students go through their paces slicing, dicing, butchering and baking. If they mix a martini it will probably be to relax after all the hard work.

headline: Cans of Wine Join the Box Set
text: FIRST, winemakers poured their vintages into bottles and corked them. Then they lost the corks and added screw tops. Then they lost the bottles and sold wine in boxes, next to beer and pretzels at supermarkets. And now, winemakers seeking some pop are canning wine.

headline: Putting Technology to Work for Play
text: TOYS embedded with technology are everywhere. It seems every toy can light up, talk, walk and sing, occasionally in your choice of languages. They can even sell themselves, via motion-activated displays that see you coming and respond with a commercial. This is the age of the iPad, and children have no shortage of things pulling at their limited playtime, which, let’s hope, includes some time to build a snowman.

headline: Smartphones Graduate to Higher Level
text: IS that certain someone on your shopping list still carrying a sad little flip phone? Are you?

headline: Untether Your Music With a Wireless Stereo
text: THE digital age has made our musical lives more complex. Subscription services and online radio mean that our music is coming from many sources, and the proliferation of smartphones and tablets means that it is stored in more places than ever.

headline: Gadgets to Outfit Everyone
text: TECHNOLOGY is a bit like clothing. Here’s how: Hundreds of thousands of years ago, a single item of clothing (a well-tailored pelt or loincloth) would probably suffice. Clothing did one thing, provide cover.

headline: Even Before Off Broadway Opening, ‘Once’ Announces a Move to Broadway
text: Just as the musical “Once” was about to open at New York Theater Workshop Tuesday night, the show’s commercial producers announced that it would go directly to Broadway after the Off Broadway run.

headline: After a Break to Run Somalia, Back at His Cubicle
text: BUFFALO — At his cubicle at the State Transportation Department building here, Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed recounted what he did during a recent leave of absence. He trimmed the size of the federal government. He instituted regular paychecks for the military. He campaigned against corruption. And he avoided being shot.

headline: Occupy Protesters Move Indoors to Fight Home Foreclosures
text: Participants of the Occupy Wall Street movement began a new campaign of protests against the banking system on Tuesday called Occupy Our Homes, which is focused on “the liberation of vacant bank-owned homes for those in need, and the defense of families under threat of foreclosure and eviction.”

headline: Citigroup to Lay Off 4,500 Workers
text: Facing stalling growth prospects around the globe, Citigroup’s chief executive, Vikram S. Pandit, said on Tuesday that the bank would lay off 4,500 workers in the coming months.

text: A few of the icons who inspired the photographs.

headline: The 2011 Spectrum of Villainy
text: The year’s notable bad guys, from the absolutely evil to the morally murky.

headline: Riffs: The Year in Movies
text: Michael Bay’s “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” touched off a debate in film-blogger circles: does this assaultive approach to action-film-making signal the coming annihilation of narrative logic? Or the emergence of a visual grammar that’s 2 fast and 2 furious for fusty old movie grumps to understand? In a much-passed-around video essay, the critic Matthias Stork even gave this aesthetic a name: Chaos Cinema.

headline: Our Own Worst Enemies
text: Earlier this year, one of the defining villains of the age met his end. A generation of children grew up frightened by his legend and haunted by the image of his face. More than just an evildoer, he seemed at times to be the embodiment of evil itself, the ruthless leader of a vast and shadowy network whose very principle was terror. His death was unsurprisingly violent, widely celebrated (with a few qualms expressed here and there) and also curiously anticlimactic. His diabolical charisma — the power of his name alone to inspire shudders of dread and revulsion — dissipated almost instantly. Life resumed its ordinary, anxious course.

headline: Vamps, Crooks and Killers
text: The best performers from the year in film, recast as nefarious villains.

text: The iPad isn’t the easiest gadget to type on. Although it comes with a large on-screen keyboard, some people find it difficult to write large amounts of text, opting instead for a physical keyboard with actual buttons.
