headline: A New York Map Service Saves Brokers’ Shoe Leather
text: “Location, location, location” did not become the most overused slogan in real estate without reason: a property’s surroundings are as important as the property itself. So for decades, most commercial brokerage firms have had full-time canvassers or even entire departments of agents relentlessly pacing city blocks to keep up-to-date maps of fast-changing storefront businesses.

headline: N.B.A. Schedule a Cram Course for Teams
text: An N.B.A. schedule unlike any other — short, compressed, frantic, unwieldy in some spots and incomplete in others — was finally unveiled Tuesday night. It may be greeted with as much angst as excitement.

headline: Presidential Aging Doesn’t Cut Life Short
text: Even when a study calculated presidential life expectancy by subtracting two days of life for every day in office, it found that presidents who died of natural causes lived longer than predicted.

headline: The Defense Department in Their Midst
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — On a recent Friday afternoon, employees trickled out of two new office buildings here; some waited at bus stops, while others retrieved cars from a sprawling above-ground garage. Traffic leaving the office complex and turning onto public streets was light.

headline: Virginia: Man Jailed for 27 Years Is Exonerated
text: The Virginia Court of Appeals on Tuesday exonerated a man convicted in a series of sexual assaults in 1984. DNA evidence showed that the man,  Thomas Haynesworth, could not have committed the crimes in which such evidence had been preserved, and it pointed to another man. Gov. Bob McDonnell released Mr. Haynesworth on parole in March, but Mr. Haynesworth petitioned for full exoneration. Prosecutors in the counties where the assaults occurred supported his effort, as did the commonwealth’s attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli. The Court of Appeals initially heard the appeal and then asked for further briefs. Shawn Armbrust, executive director of the Mid-Atlantic Innocence Project, said, “After serving nearly 27 years for crimes that he didn’t commit, Mr. Haynesworth has had to register as a sex offender and abide by degrading conditions while the Court of Appeals took nearly nine months to conclude that the attorney general and the prosecutors were right that Mr. Haynesworth didn’t commit these crimes.”

headline: Canceling Stay, U.S. Orders 72 Indonesians in New Jersey to Leave
text: Two years ago, a community of Indonesians in central New Jersey was spared deportation after a Protestant pastor brokered an unusual agreement with immigration authorities that allowed them to stay in the country temporarily. The agreement was clear: The Indonesians would be able to stay and work, but the permission could be rescinded at any moment.

headline: U.S. and South Korea Renew Talks on Nuclear Technology
text: SEOUL, South Korea — United States and South Korean negotiators on Tuesday resumed their low-key but highly sensitive talks on whether South Korea should be allowed to do what Washington has tried to stop North Korea from doing: enrich uranium and reprocess spent nuclear fuel.

headline: China’s Allure in Drug Research
text: Drug research tends to follow spending. Take Merck’s pledge on Tuesday to invest $1.5 billion in research and development in China over five years. Citizens of emerging economies are growing wealthier and living longer, while the fiscal health of their governments is robust. Merck’s step suggests that the pharmaceutical industry’s center of gravity is shifting eastward accordingly.

headline: A Reluctant Enemy
text: San Francisco

headline: Ohio: Charges Planned in Craigslist Killings
text: Prosecutors in Akron will file charges accusing Richard Beasley, 52, of the murders of three men who were lured to their deaths through a fake Craigslist advertisement, a spokeswoman for Sherri Bevan Walsh, the Summit County prosecutor, said on Tuesday, adding that Ms. Walsh would seek the death penalty. Mr. Beasley, who was arrested this month on other charges and is being held without bail, will also be charged with the attempted murder of Scott Davis, 48, of South Carolina, who responded to the advertisement but escaped after being shot in the arm. The Craigslist advertisement offered $300 a week, a trailer to live in and a stocked fishing pond for someone who would serve as a caretaker on a farm near Caldwell, in Noble County. Brogan Rafferty, 16, was also charged this month in connection with the murders. A Noble County judge will decide next week whether Mr. Rafferty will be tried as an adult.

headline: F.A.A. Chief Leaves Job After Arrest
text: WASHINGTON — The chief of the Federal Aviation Administration, J. Randolph Babbitt, resigned on Tuesday after being arrested and accused of drunken driving over the weekend. Aviation experts said he was unlikely to be permanently replaced soon, raising concerns about the agency’s progress in modernizing air traffic control, maintaining vigilance on safety and completing a recent reorganization.

headline: Egypt, the Beginning or the End?
text: The fact that the Muslim Brotherhood and the even more fundamentalist Salafist Nour Party have garnered some 65 percent of the votes in the first round of Egypt’s free parliamentary elections since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak should hardly come as a surprise. Given the way that the military regimes in the Arab world decimated all independent secular political parties over the last 50 years, there is little chance of any Arab country going from Mubarak to Jefferson without going through some Khomeini.

headline: The Wisdom of George McGovern
text: George McGovern’s impact on food policy could have been greater, but not through more effort on his part. The 1972 presidential candidate, now 89, was a bomber pilot at the end of World War II when the decision was made to distribute remaining medicine and food to Europeans before heading home. “We were feeding our former enemies two days after bombing them,” he told me over breakfast last week, two days before falling and being hospitalized. “It was an unprecedented gesture of good will.”

headline: Remembering Sócrates, Who Made the Game Beautiful
text: Sócrates is dead, at 57. He taught me to love an entire sport, and that is no small thing.

headline: Council Hears Transit Plans for a Blizzard
text: For the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, an A train in the Rockaways, stranded for hours during the blizzard last December, became an enduring example of the agency’s bungled response to the storm.

headline: Remembering Pearl Harbor
text: It was only a few days after the attack in December 1941 that the phrase “Remember Pearl Harbor” first appeared in The New York Times. It took barely a week for Hollywood to register it as a movie title. Today that film is justly forgotten. The phrase lives on, and 70 years have not dimmed the meaning and memory of that day.

headline: The Wrong Fix
text: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France issued an ultimatum on Monday demanding that all 17 nations using the euro agree to a change in European treaties that would force them to move toward balanced budgets or face sanctions.

headline: Cardinals’ Hold on Pujols Put to Test
text: DALLAS

headline: For Family on the Mend, a Dinette to Gather Around
text: When the new dinette set and the chest of drawers arrived in October at Desire Baez’s apartment, she took photographs and showed them to friends as if they were snapshots of her newborn children.

headline: Online Insults Lead to Calls for Inquiries of N.Y.C. Police
text: Politicians and officials criticized the New York Police Department on Tuesday and called for investigations after the release of comments on Facebook in which users claiming to be officers heaped scorn on revelers at the annual West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn. But, despite repeated requests, one person refused to comment: the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly.

headline: Scenes: Leo Friedman
text: A look back at the career of the photographer Leo Friedman.

headline: Caught Out of Time
text: One hundred and fifty years after the Civil War, historians have the benefit of a perspective not accessible in earlier remembrances. One interesting angle is to look at older histories of the war, tracing its place in our national consciousness and rediscovering details that take on new relevance today.

headline: Celebrated in Asia, Little Known in America
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — It is the all-American girl’s study as conceived by a Hollywood set director. In addition to her growing collection of trophies, Yani Tseng has displayed two dozen Starbucks mugs from all over the world, an ad for a local pizzeria and a plush Angry Bird scowling from a loving cup. Only the 8 ½-by-11 certificate noting Tseng’s completion of a Level 4 English class hints at her deepest roots.

headline: Whimsical Texting Icons Get a Shot at Success
text: Say you wanted to invite a friend to happy hour. You could send a simple text message, but that would be boring. Instead, why not send a cartoony picture of two clinking beer mugs?

headline: Amazon Publishing Push Grows to Children’s Books
text: Amazon expanded its publishing ambitions on Tuesday by acquiring more than 450 titles from Marshall Cavendish Children’s Books, a niche publisher.

headline: Republican Candidates Aim at Obama Foreign Policy
text: A small but revealing episode unfolded in the closing minutes of the last Republican presidential debate. After the candidates were asked to name the national security issue they most worry about, which had not yet been discussed, Rick Santorum cited radical Islamists in Central and South America.

headline: Leo Friedman, Photographer of Broadway’s Glamour Years, Dies at 92
text: Leo Friedman, whose photograph of an ebullient Carol Lawrence and Larry Kert as lovebirds chasing down a Manhattan street became the enduring emblem of the musical “West Side Story” and the signature image of a career spent taking pictures of actors in action, died on Friday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 92.

headline: After a Son Is Killed, Facing a Police Runaround
text: The Lefevres — mother, father and one of their surviving sons — took the first flight to New York, spent the night with a friend, and the next morning went directly to the city morgue on Winthrop Street in Brooklyn. The second of the Lefevre sons, Mathieu, 30, had been run over by a truck two days earlier, just after midnight on Oct. 19, while he was biking home to Williamsburg. The truck did not stop.

headline: Lottery Numbers
G.O.P. Leadership Job Is Contested
text: The fifth-ranking leadership position for Congressional Republicans is up for grabs, setting the stage for a battle between two freshmen senators. Senator Roy D. Blunt of Missouri announced on Tuesday that he would compete against Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin for the job of vice chairman of the Senate Republican Conference.

headline: Congress Discusses Enacting Stricter Insider-Trading Laws
text: Democrats and Republicans on the House Financial Services Committee on Tuesday advocated new restrictions on insider trading to help lift waning public trust in Congress.

headline: Johnson Becomes Face, and So Much More, of Bid for the Dodgers
text: For a moment, imagine Magic Johnson, the symbol of Showtime, as a part-owner and the public face of the Los Angeles Dodgers. He stands outside Dodger Stadium greeting fans numbed by the Frank McCourt era. He sits by the Dodgers’ dugout listening to fans telling him how to improve the team.

headline: Albany’s Tax Deal
text: Less than a month before New York’s so-called millionaires’ tax is set to expire, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has managed to convince Republican legislators to agree to a new, supposedly fairer tax structure. It is expected to bring in about $2 billion in new revenue — or about half of the $4 billion that would have come from extending the income tax surcharge for New York’s wealthier residents.

headline: Study Raises Concerns About a Faster Radiation Therapy for Breast Cancer
text: A faster form of radiation therapy that is becoming increasingly popular for women with early-stage breast cancer may not be as effective and safe as conventional radiation treatment, according to a study being presented on Wednesday.

headline: Good, Old Times for Valentine and Ventura
text: He was later fined $5,000 and suspended two games for doing so.

headline: Filibuster by Senate Republicans Blocks Confirmation of Judicial Nominee
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Tuesday blocked confirmation of Caitlin J. Halligan, a prominent New York lawyer, to be a federal appeals court judge, raising the question of whether a political deal to prevent the filibuster of most judicial nominations has broken down.

headline: Iowa Poll: The Candidates and the Issues
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll poll found that Newt Gingrich is rated more favorably than the other candidates among voters who say they are likely to attend the Republican caucuses in Iowa, but two-thirds remain open to changing their minds.

headline: Safety Nets for Freelancers
text: This is a follow-up to Friday’s column, “Health Care for a Changing Work Force.”

headline: At Top Public Schools, the Arts Replace Recess
text: In the art room at P.S. 188 in Bayside, Queens, a group of 9-year-olds was busily putting the finishing touches on an enormous poster for the fourth-grade play. Its topic: saving the Earth. Down the hall in the music room, beneath portraits of Mozart and Bach, classmates were breaking into a spirited rendition of “Hear Those Bells” on fluorescent-colored recorders. Cheerleaders in the gym were perfecting a victory chant, jumping, twisting and stamping their feet. And in the library, children in a Suzuki violin class were toiling away at “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star,” while their music teacher, a professional violist from Iceland, coached them “to stand straight and tall.”

headline: Bettman: Fans ‘Like the Level of Physicality’
text: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif. — The N.H.L. board of directors met for three and a half hours Tuesday and never broached the subject of fighting, Commissioner Gary Bettman said. Fighting is an aspect of the game that has come under scrutiny by others in the wake of the recent deaths of three of the game’s enforcers.

headline: A Moment in the Sun for Television
text: THIS week, about 2,000 people are attending an annual event known as the UBS global media and communications conference. Based on the presentations so far, perhaps it ought to be renamed the global television and video festival.

headline: Greenpeace Leader Visits Boardroom, Without Forsaking Social Activism
text: DURBAN, South Africa — The bearded South African in the blood-red dashiki took a seat in the front row amid a sea of dark-suited executives on Monday morning at a side meeting of the United Nations climate change  conference here.

headline: Obama in Osawatomie
text: After months of Republican candidates offering a cascade of bad ideas about the economy, President Obama’s speech in Osawatomie, Kan., Tuesday came as a relief. He made it clear that he was finally prepared to contest the election on the issues of income inequality and the obligation of both government and the private sector to enlarge the nation’s shrinking middle class.

headline: Judge Chides Defense in Official’s Trial
text: The jury in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook was sent home on Tuesday evening after deliberating for a third full day without reaching a verdict.

headline: Dip in Consumer Spending Slows Growth in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s kinetic economy sputtered in the third quarter, officials announced Tuesday, ending a long stretch of growth and pointing to some of the headwinds now facing Brazil and big economies in Asia, notably India and China.

headline: Mets Deal Pagan Away and Overhaul Bullpen
text: DALLAS — Swiftly and significantly, the Mets altered their roster Tuesday night, adding three right-handed relievers and a center fielder within a couple of hours.

headline: Wednesday: Lose One’s Marbles
text: Administrivial Avatar Alert!  The ability to upload a photo to your Times account has been fixed. Please powder your noses, take a snapshot of yourself, and upload it by going to the upper-right-hand corner of this page. Notice that your screen name now features a drop-down menu. Click that drop-down arrow, go to “My Profile,” click on “Edit My Profile”, and you will see a box where you can upload a photo that is no larger than 5 cruciliters, or megaspleens, or something like that. At any rate, you can upload a photo now.

headline: A Love Affair With Music, Maybe With Each Other
text: Charm is fragile. What’s enchanting in one context, subjected to stress, exaggeration or self-consciousness, can seem soppy or strident in another.

headline: Pearl Harbor Still a Day for the Ages, but a Memory Almost Gone
text: HONOLULU — For more than half a century, members of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association gathered here every Dec. 7 to commemorate the attack by the Japanese that drew the United States into World War II. Others stayed closer to home for more intimate regional chapter ceremonies, sharing memories of a day they still remember in searing detail.

headline: Gathering to Remember for the Last Time
text: For the members of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association, the 70th Anniversary of the World War II attack will be their last gathering. The New York Times has documented final commemorations by other survivors of tragic events.

headline: Working Out the Final Details in an Effort to Reopen on Friday
text: The final chaotic days of a chaotic N.B.A. off-season are winding down, with the league pushing to reopen business Friday after a flurry of last-minute negotiations and formalities.

headline: Yankees Still Searching for Rotation Help
text: DALLAS — Joe Girardi joined the Yankees’ staff at the winter meetings Tuesday, and he did not sound any more optimistic than his general manager about obtaining a top-end starter to slot in behind C.C. Sabathia in the rotation.

headline: Paul Doty, Biochemist and Arms Control Advocate, Dies at 91
text: Paul Doty, a biochemist who furthered understanding of the chemical secrets of heredity, then became a leader in bringing Soviet and American scientists together to try to control nuclear arms, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 91.

text: Brooklyn football was in the House That Steinbrenner Built on Tuesday evening.

text: The Knicks’ 66-game schedule for the 2011-12 lockout shortened season has them playing four games in five nights on four occasions.

headline: Merkel’s Path: Brinkmanship for Debt Crisis
text: BERLIN — When the ratings agency Standard & Poor’s warned this week that it might lower the credit ratings of 15 euro zone countries, including Germany, Chancellor Angela Merkel seemed unmoved. “What a rating agency does is the responsibility of the rating agency,” she told reporters in Berlin on Tuesday.

headline: How to Help the Post Office
text: No one likes the changes at the U.S. Postal Service. What should be done instead?

headline: At the Garden, the Guest List Looks a Bit Incomplete
text: Carmelo Anthony will not return to Denver for a visit this season. Nor will Amar’e Stoudemire go back to his old home in Phoenix.

headline: Pakistan: President Travels to Dubai for Medical Tests
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan – An unexpected announcement that President Asif Ali Zardari has left Pakistan for a medical checkup in Dubai caused a swirl of wild rumors on Wednesday about his hold on power.

headline: Admissible Evidence, or a Backdoor Ploy? Justices Ask
text: WASHINGTON — The lawyers were listless and the justices lively at a Supreme Court argument on Tuesday on how prosecutors may use crime laboratory reports at a trial.

headline: Big East Is Poised to Add Five Teams for Football
text: The Big East will expand in 2013 to include Boise State and San Diego State as football-only members and Houston, Southern Methodist and Central Florida in all sports, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: City Champs
text: The Railsplitters of Lincoln High School used their smothering defense to shut down Erasmus Hall in the second half.

headline: Romney Tells Trump He Can’t Make Debate
text: Mitt Romney said Tuesday that he would not take part in a debate moderated by Donald J. Trump, casting doubt on whether other candidates would take part.

headline: The Tempting of the Christian Right
text: More than any other Republican constituency, religious conservatives have good reasons to be wary of Newt Gingrich. As the leader of a right-wing insurgency in the early 1990s, he often kept their causes at arm’s length — deliberately excluding issues like abortion and school prayer from the Contract With America, for instance. As Speaker of the House, he undercut their claim to the moral high ground by carrying on an extramarital affair even as his party was impeaching Bill Clinton for lying under oath about adultery.

headline: Flipboard Introduces an iPhone App for Killing Time Standing in Line
text: Updated 3:50 p.m.: Added information  about Flipboard’s service problems on Wednesday, which delayed access to the iPhone app for new users.

headline: Champions League Wednesday Preview: In Manchester, Nail-Biting Time in Red and Blue
text: On Matchday 6, four teams are playing only for bonus money and four teams are playing for precious spots in the group stage.

headline: Big Firms Limit Paying State Taxes, Study Finds
text: As states have struggled to balance their budgets by cutting services, laying off workers and raising taxes, a study to be released on Wednesday suggests that many profitable Fortune 500 companies have not been paying as much in state corporate income taxes as the average levied on American companies, with some big firms paying none at all in recent years.

headline: Criminal Justice Expert Named to Lead Soros Foundations
text: George Soros, the billionaire investor, on Wednesday named Christopher Stone, a well-known expert on criminal justice, the new leader of his unconventional philanthropic empire.

headline: J.C. Penney to Buy Stake in Martha Stewart Living
text: 4:01 p.m. | Updated J.C. Penney confirmed on Wednesday that it would buy a 16.6 percent stake in Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, drawing the two companies closer together in an effort to lift their sagging fortunes.

headline: A New Worry for Soccer Parents: Heading the Ball
text: What happens inside the skull of a soccer player who repeatedly heads a soccer ball? That question motivated a provocative new study of the brains of experienced players that has prompted discussion and debate in the soccer community, and some anxiety among those of us with soccer-playing offspring.

headline: Word of the Day | glacial
text: glacial •\ˈgla-shəl\• adjective

headline: New Details in Dodgers’ Sale
text: The Los Angeles Dodgers asked a federal bankruptcy court judge Tuesday to approve the agreement to sell the team reached last month with Major League Baseball.

headline: Homeless In Delhi, Victims Of Gender Disparity
text: “Invisible Among the Uncounted“, Nilanjana S. Roy writes about the plight of homeless women in Delhi, a city of sixteen million people.

headline: Indian Network in Silicon Valley Backs Start-Ups
text: In 1992, a handful of immigrant engineers from the Indian subcontinent who lived in the Bay Area formed a group called the Indus Entrepreneurs — or TiE — with what now seems like a quaint mission: to inspire one another to establish their own technology start-ups and cash in on the Silicon Valley dream.

headline: Corrections: December 7
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 7, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Rock Hall Welcomes Guns N’ Roses, Red Hot Chili Peppers and the Beastie Boys
text: Three American groups that helped to shape pop music in the 1980s and early ’90s — Guns N’ Roses, Red Hot Chili Peppers and the Beastie Boys – will be inducted into The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in the spring, the Hall was to announce Wednesday.

headline: Varanasi Found
text: I had been living in India for more than two years when a visiting friend wanted to see Varanasi. I had never been, but I had seen hundreds of pictures of it. There are the famous bathing ghats, where thousands of people daily take their purifying dips into the Ganges, or attend to more quotidian tasks, like brushing teeth, shampooing hair and washing clothes.

headline: Avowing Innocence, Israeli Ex-President Enters Prison
text: KIRYAT MALACHI, Israel — A day after Moshe Katsav, Israel’s former president, turned 66, his modest home in this immigrant town was filled on Tuesday with grandchildren and well-wishers. Phones rang. Neighbors with sun-creased faces offered hugs. Rabbis in tall hats gave their blessings.

headline: Dec. 7, 1941 | Japan Attacks Pearl Harbor
text: On Dec. 7, 1941, Japanese warplanes attacked the home base of the American Pacific fleet at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, drawing the United States into World War II. More than 2,300 Americans were killed.

headline: Found: Biggest Black Holes Ever
text: WHO did not believe in the existence of black holes?

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 7, 2011
text: Test your math skills with this question created by Scott Matthews at Math for America from the article “Learning to Play the Game to Get Into College.”

headline: ‘Chilling’ Impact of India’s April Internet Rules
text: Kapil Sibal’s demand that Internet companies self-censor users’ content is just the latest move by the Indian government to restrict information on Facebook and other social media Web sites.

headline: Rare Attacks on Shiites Kill Scores in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Pakistan-based extremist group claimed responsibility for a series of coordinated bombings aimed at Afghan Shiites on Tuesday, in what many feared was an attempt to further destabilize Afghanistan by adding a new dimension of strife to a country that, though battered by a decade of war, has been free of sectarian conflict.

headline: The Wild West of Finance
text: Human beings, at heart, are wild animals in love with the thrill of the hunt. I can prove it merely by pointing to the existence of the exchange-traded fund FAZ, which one friend calls “day trader’s crack.” For most of us, the stock market has been moving far too much, far too quickly. For those who buy FAZ, though, that speed is not fast enough.

headline: Syria, Under Siege Inside and Out, Does Not Budge
text: DAMASCUS, Syria — During his most recent news conference, Foreign Minister Walid al-Moallem interrupted the flow of questions by waving a small white piece of paper indicating that he had important news.

headline: What’s Next for Computing?
text: The Science Times section is looking back to innovations in computing, as well as into the future, and they are asking Times readers to look into their proverbial crystal balls, too. What lies ahead for computing? What predictions and hopes do you have for what computers will be able to do in the future?

headline: British Police Arrest Man in Scandal Over Hacking
text: LONDON — A 41-year-old man arrested Wednesday in connection with the phone hacking scandal that has rocked Rupert Murdoch’s media empire was identified in British news reports as Glenn Mulcaire, the private detective at the scandal’s center.

headline: Industry Group Sees Tough Year for Weakened Airlines
text: A collapse of the euro could suppress growth in global air traffic next year and push airlines into a collective loss of more than $8 billion, an industry group said Wednesday.

headline: In Paris, Celebrating London on the Big Screen
text: New York, with its glittery skyline, yellow cabs and steaming potholes, and Paris, with its cafe-lined streets, Eiffel Tower, and winding Seine, have been the objects of rapturous attention from filmmakers all over the world. If London — sprawling, grey and less predisposed to visual clichés — has not been fetishized on the big screen in the same way, it has nonetheless provided a vibrant setting for movies spanning virtually every mood, genre and style.

headline: Species Protection and Technology
text: Advances in genetics may change aspects of environmental policy in the future.

headline: The Early Word: Populist
text: Today’s Times

headline: India Suspends Plan to Let in Foreign Retailers
text: NEW DELHI — Facing a harsh political reaction that has paralyzed the Indian Parliament, the governing Congress Party announced on Wednesday that it would suspend plans to allow foreign multibrand retailers like Wal-Mart to open stores in India.

headline: Mine Attack Kills 19 Civilians in Afghanistan
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Nineteen civilians, some of them women and children, were killed on Wednesday by a mine planted on a highway in southwestern Afghanistan, Afghan officials said.

headline: Maybin and Rodgers: The Accidental Aarons of the N.F.L.
text: As Chase Stuart wrote on Tuesday, we think we know more than we actually do during an N.F.L. season.

headline: This Christmas, Atheists’ Billboard Tries a Softer Tack
text: Nearly $40,000 was spent during the last Christmas season on a billboard war between atheists and Roman Catholics at the New Jersey entrance to the Lincoln Tunnel. But so far, this year’s version of the atheist billboard has failed to generate much of a fight.

headline: Why I Swore Off Debt (for a While)
text: Breakups are never pretty. It was September 2008, and the economy, the stock market, real estate, and my business were all crashing (as did many businesses). Like an engineer figuring out how much oxygen is left in a mine tunnel after a collapse, I turned quickly to cash analysis.

headline: U.S. and China Meet in Annual Military Review
text: BEIJING — Top American and Chinese military officials began an annual review of major issues here on Wednesday pledging to seek greater cooperation and trust in a relationship that, to many, more resembles a budding rivalry.

headline: Pakistanis Taking to the Streets
text: KARACHI, Pakistan — It’s an unusual sight for a Sunday morning: a dozen Karachiites armed with brooms, rakes, sand and rubble crouch along a road on which none of them live or work in order to mend a large, sewage-filled pothole. The workers come in all shapes and sizes: a man in his 80’s uses his walking stick to knock large rocks out of the way; a boy of 12 watches for traffic and waves passing cars to the side of the street. They are members of the Greener Karachi Trust, a volunteer group committed to showing its fellow Karachi dwellers that they needn’t wait for the government to repair the city’s crumbling infrastructure.

headline: A Wish List for Cooks, Bug Lovers and the Well-Shod
text: On Tuesday, we offered several ideas for inspirational green gifts for gastronomes, cyclists, spa rats and others. For those still seeking the perfect holiday present for that environmentally minded someone, here are more suggestions for a range of ages and interest groups.

headline: Romney Losing Among Fox News Viewers
text: If there were a Fox News primary, Mitt Romney would be losing it.

headline: Forecasting Playoff Chances for Giants and Jets
text: According to the playoff race simulations at NFL-Forecast.com, the Giants have a 36.3 chance of making the playoffs, and the Jets a 29.6 percent chance.

headline: Obsession, Reignited
text: IN anticipation of the movie version of Stieg Larsson’s “Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” which stars Daniel Craig and Rooney Mara and opens Dec. 21, Knopf has printed two different tie-in editions of the original novel, more than a million copies all told.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 7
text: One of the takeaways from the annual UBS global media and communications conference in Midtown Manhattan, Stuart Elliott and Amy Chozick report, is the primacy of video content “regardless of the type of screen on which it is watched.” Based on the talks there, “marketers remain keen on buying commercial time during video programming despite the uncertain outlook for the economy.” Spending on TV ads around the world next year will increase 6.7 percent from 2011, said one forecaster, Vincent Létang, as compared with a predicted overall 5 percent increase in advertising. (Online ads will have the greatest growth, he predicted, 11.2 percent.)

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: In Rare Interview, Assad Denies Ordering Crackdown in Syria
text: PARIS — A defiant President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, speaking in a rare television interview broadcast on Wednesday, denied ordering the bloody crackdown that has convulsed his land for the past nine months and disputed a United Nations estimate that 4,000 people had been killed as protesters took to the streets of cities across his land demanding that he step down.

headline: I Was a Suburban Mixologist
text: Back in his college years in Wisconsin, Jim Meehan would find himself working at a bar and wondering about the “odd bottles” that kept gathering dust on the back shelves.

headline: David Fincher’s Embargo Solution
text: Dragon Tattoo-gate (Denby-Rudin-gate? Rudin-Denby-gate? Ruby-gate?) continues to roll along. In an interview with The Miami Herald, David Fincher, the director of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” weighed in on the controversy involving David Denby, a film critic for The New Yorker, positively reviewing his movie before he was supposed to, defying an embargo he’d agreed to – in writing, apparently – and angering the studio, Sony, and the producer Scott Rudin in the process. (There: just saved you having to click a link to get the back story.)

headline: Santander to Sell Colombian Unit for $1.23 Billion
text: Grupo Santander, seeking to bolster its capital reserves, announced on Wednesday that it would sell its Colombian unit to CorpBanca of Chile for $1.225 billion.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Campaign Against Co-Sleeping Sparks Controversy
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: It’s My Birthday! (Said With Hand Outstretched)
text: It’s your birthday, so how do you celebrate? Maybe you gather a few close friends. Or you go out for a quiet dinner with your spouse or partner or significant other or lover or whatever term suits your situation and temperament. Or perhaps — it happens — the passage of time has you down, and you just want to be alone.

headline: Opinion Report: European Austerity
text: From the editorial page

headline: When It Comes to the Greats, Who Do You Remember?
text: Sport endures on first impressions. We all remember the first time we walked into a stadium and saw the green grass. Saw Walter Payton or Barry Sanders break into the clear. Saw Evert and Navratilova pick up where they had left off in the last tournament. Saw Wayne Gretzky slip between two defenders.

headline: Callers Take Issue With Mayor's Teacher Comments
text: WNYC listeners weigh in on the controversy stirred up last week by the mayor's comments about doubling class sizes, doubling teacher salaries and firing half of the city's teacher force. One teacher said no matter how good a teacher was, it would be impossible to handle much larger classes, much less all the paperwork generated.

headline: Recess Has Some New Competition
text: Jump rope, freeze tag and the jungle gym, once staples of lunchtime play, are being squeezed out at some of the city’s highest-rated public elementary schools, where recess is now being viewed as prime time for enrichment classes.

headline: Plastic Fantastic
text: In this photograph and stop-motion video, the French-born artist Damien Florébert Cuypers translates his longtime fascination with Legos into a quirky version of our trademark logo. Cuypers, who splits his time between Lyon, Berlin and New York, is refreshingly down-to-earth about working with the toys. “You can end up with some dramatic color/shape structure,” he says. “Or a stupid-looking bunch of bricks.”

headline: Gingrich and the Christian Right
text: My column for Campaign Stops this week argues that religious conservatives should think twice about their flirtation with Newt Gingrich:

headline: Dollar-Loan Demand Swells In Europe After Rate Cut
text: The European Central Bank said demand for three-month dollar loans surged after it cut the cost of the financing almost in half in a coordinated action last week with five other central banks including the Federal Reserve.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The New York Post: An entertaining roundup of high-end restaurants in Hong Kong, including the first Michelin three-star in China. — Julia Moskin

headline: They Have Made A Desert, And Called It Adjustment
text: It continues to be a source of amazement to see what passes for a success story among austerity advocates. Ireland is proclaimed a huge success despite 14 percent unemployment and a very slow recovery in incomes. And then there’s Latvia.

headline: A Devil of a Time to Root for the Mets
text: Based on five decades of field research, I’ve reached this careful conclusion: Joan Payson, the original owner of my beloved Mets, probably did something really nasty with the devil atop the dugout at the old Shea Stadium.

headline: Daily Report: Holiday Gadgets
text: The most important period for consumer electronics is, of course, the holiday shopping season. For anyone wanting to understand how the industry is doing in the here and now, there is no better place to study than a holiday buying guide.

headline: BBC Adds More Hours and More Characters to ‘The Hour’
text: The British love their period pieces and meta-media dramas as much as Americans, it appears. The BBC has ordered a sequel to “The Hour,” its hit mini-series about the competitive world of 1950s British television journalism, which will add new cast members and which BBC America will co-produce and broadcast in the United States, that cable channel said on Wednesday.

headline: China Clears Nestle’s Deal for Candy Maker
text: Chinese regulators have approved Nestlé’s $1.7 billion acquisition of a 60 percent stake in the confectioner Hsu Fu Chi International, in a sign that Beijing may be warming to large cross-border transactions.

headline: Taylor Rules
text: Via Mark Thoma, Noah Smith reports on a conference held at Hoover in which right-wing economists reached right-wing conclusions. Surprise!

headline: Last Night’s Event
text: Thanks to a commenter who found the video here. I don’t know if this is official or sanctioned, although it looks like it; I also don’t know why the Times tech people didn’t alert me. But anyway, it seems that those who missed the discussion can watch it via that link.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: Will the Lions make the playoffs? Houston? Just how good (or bad) are the Falcons? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

headline: Despite Economic Slump, Europe Gets More Tech Start-Ups
text: While Europe as a whole continues to suffer major economic troubles with slow fiscal growth and abnormally high unemployment rates, one industry continues to grow steadily: tech.

headline: Vain Glorious | Dolce’s Velvet Hour
text: What: Velvet, Dolce & Gabbana’s new fragrance collection.

headline: New York’s Math Scores Dip on U.S. Student Tests, Diverging From Trend in Other Big Cities
text: New York City students scored slightly lower on federal math tests this year compared with two years ago, according to results released on Wednesday, even as test scores of their counterparts in other big cities inched upward.

headline: ‘MythBusters’ Turns Into House Buster With Wayward Cannonball
text: A “MythBusters” stunt went awry on Tuesday, leaving cannonball-shaped holes in the wall of a home and in the window of a minivan in Dublin, Calif. Or, as the local sheriff’s department spokesman put it, “The cannonball took a few unfortunate bounces.”

headline: Have Yourself a Retro Little Christmas
text: This is a season for nostalgia — and also for picture books that can and should mean more than just “ ’Twas the night before Christmas.” Three splendid reissues of Christmas tales from the 1950s, ’60s and ’70s offer old-timey takes on the evergreen theme of “All I want for Christmas is . . . . ”

headline: Gorbachev Calls for New Vote in Disputed Russian Elections
text: MOSCOW — Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last leader of the Soviet Union, added his voice to a nascent anti-Kremlin protest movement on Wednesday, calling for the results of increasingly disputed parliamentary elections last weekend to be scrapped.

headline: A Deer and a Minivan: A Holiday Travel Story
text: 2:20 p.m. Updated to add details about insurance coverage.

headline: Mets Fans Can Tolerate Pain, but This Much?
text: On City Room, Michael Powell wonders if the Mets once made a deal with Mephistopheles. Just one reason for that question: “We have professional hitters who bang their heads and forget how to hit — see Church, Ryan, and Bay, Jason.” Read more at City Room.

headline: Goodbye to Quail, for Now
text: Jennifer Calkins, a biologist who teaches at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., writes from Mexico, where she is studying the ecology, behavior and evolution of the elegant quail.

headline: Crowds at Höller Exhibition Force Price Increase
text: Participatory art, as it turns out, is not all fun and games. The New Museum, whose exhibition of the work of the Belgian-born artist Carsten Höller has been packing in crowds since it opened last month, has raised its general admission price to $16, from $12. The higher price will help it pay for the extra staff needed to shepherd museumgoers through Mr. Höller’s carnival-like pieces, which take up all the museum’s floors: goggles that turn the world upside down; a three-story tubular slide; and a heavily salinated sensory deprivation tank (complete with a shower and hooks for the clothes of those who decide to undress and get in for a float).

headline: Former Marvell Employee Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading
text: 2:23 p.m. | Updated

headline: Q&A: Controlling iTunes Remotely
text: Q.

headline: How Dangerous Is Heading a Soccer Ball?
text: Soccer parents, watching their children use their head to send the ball rocketing in an age of increased worry about the long-term effects of minor sports concussions, have been arguing for years about the practice. On the Well blog, Gretchen Reynolds reports on new research showing frontal lobe damage and weaker verbal and visual recall among players who had headed a ball more than a thousand times in the last year, even those who reported no concussion, and among college players who were frequent headers in a Division 2 program.

headline: A Business Ponders Whether Its Location Is Perfect, or a Disaster
text: Pulling Down the Moon provides services like yoga classes, acupuncture, massage therapy and nutritional counseling to women undergoing fertility treatments. Based in Chicago, with satellite locations in Arlington Heights, Ill., and Rockville, Md., the nine-year-old company has grown to 35 employees with $1.3 million in annual revenue.

headline: Gangster in Italy Arrested After 16-Year Manhunt
text: The Italian police on Wednesday arrested a powerful leader of a criminal group based outside Naples, dealing the group, known as the Camorra, one of its most powerful blows in years.

headline: The French Flock to a Feel-Good Movie
text: PARIS — When it was released last month, “Intouchables” seemed an unremarkable, lowbrow French comedy, a small-budget film with actors little known outside France hamming it up in a story about a stodgy, disabled aristocrat and the good-humored ex-con whom he hires as his aide.

headline: On Climate Change, a Gloat and a Warning
text: DURBAN, South Africa — If anyone at the United Nations climate change conference here wondered why the United States is unwilling or unable to take decisive action on the warming of the planet, they could tune in to the Web site of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee on Wednesday morning.

headline: Harry Morgan, Colonel Potter on ‘M*A*S*H,’ Dies at 96
text: Harry Morgan, the prolific character actor best known for playing the acerbic but kindly Colonel Potter in the long-running television series “M*A*S*H,” died on Wednesday morning at his home in Los Angeles. He was 96.

headline: Is It Worth Risking Disaster for the Perfect Location?
text: We just published a case study that describes the dilemma faced by Pulling Down the Moon, a Chicago business that was hit by not one but two floods in just less than a year. Tamara Quinn and Beth Heller, co-owners of the company, a provider of supplemental holistic services like yoga, acupuncture, and massage therapy to women undergoing fertility treatments, chose to facilitate referrals by subleasing first-floor space just down the hall from one of the country’s biggest fertility clinics.

headline: Lousy Filibusters: Caitlin Halligan Edition
text: Fifty-four Senators voted yesterday to confirm the nomination of an experienced and accomplished lawyer, Caitlin Halligan, to the D.C. Circuit, which in the twisted and blindly ideological world of the United States Senate means she didn’t get confirmed.

headline: Share Your Stories of Sleep on the Subway
text: Have you slept through your stop only to awaken at the end of the line? New Lots Avenue or 179th Street Jamaica, perhaps? Or do you shudder at the thought of R.E.M. on the IND, for fear of lush workers?

headline: To Sleep on the Subway, Maybe, but to Dream? Poor Chance
text: A ride on the New York subway can be a sensory overload: musicians perform for change; conductors plead to those who hold open train doors to relent; and passengers, often in unimaginably close proximity, subject one another to all sorts of sights, sounds, smells and touches, preferably inadvertent.

headline: Apple Readies New Store in Grand Central
text: Apple unveiled its newest store on Wednesday, one that looks out over the main hub and busy concourse of the historic Grand Central Terminal in New York.

headline: Iran Blocks American ‘Virtual Embassy’
text: Not even the virtual embassies are safe in Iran.

headline: After Six Months as Anchor, Pelley Is Still Taking In the View
text: Tuesday marked six months for Scott Pelley as anchor of the “CBS Evening News,” the nightly newscast he inherited from Katie Couric.

headline: This Democrat Prefers Gingrich
text: The Democrat responsible for helping the party retake control of the House next year said on Wednesday that he would rather have Newt Gingrich at the top of the Republican ticket.

headline: Iowa and New Hampshire Stand Apart
text: With much of the political field focused on the testing grounds of Iowa and New Hampshire, it’s easy to forget that these two early states — in economic and demographic makeup — are markedly different from much of the rest of the country.

headline: Below the Line: The World-Ending Sounds of ‘Melancholia’
text: What might the moment before world annihilation sound like? While most would prefer not to experience the sound firsthand, it is one that has been imagined and portrayed cinematically in several ways, from a whimper (Sidney Lumet’s “Fail-Safe”) to a bang (the 1983 TV movie “The Day After,” which didn’t depict the end of everything, exactly, but did portray the unthinkable). Lars von Trier’s “Melancholia,” the apocalyptic drama that has received as much critical praise as its director has received public scrutiny, chooses to end the world with Wagner.

headline: How to Find Lift Tickets for Less
text: IF you are waiting until the last minute to buy lift tickets, you are probably missing out on major savings.

headline: The Dating Travails of Young Bankers
text: Between Excel marathons and 3 a.m. pitchbook proofreads, some young finance guys find the time to look for romance. But that may not be a good thing in some cases.

headline: The Giving Spree | Elettra Wiedemann
text: Who: The model and food activist Elettra Wiedemann, who opened the pop-up restaurant Goodness during New York Fashion Week in September.

headline: Beard and All, a Rabbi Is Joining the Army
text: There are, to be sure, fellow Hasidic rabbis with much more impressive beards. But Rabbi Menachem Stern has had his for years, so he had no intention of getting rid of it to join the army.

headline: Plot to Smuggle Qaddafi Son Into Mexico Is Disrupted, Government Official Says
text: MEXICO CITY — The Mexican government said Wednesday that it had broken up a plot to smuggle into Mexico one of the sons of the former Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and hide him and his family at a Pacific beach resort.

headline: At Climate Talks, a Familiar Standoff Between U.S. and China
text: DURBAN, South Africa — China, the world’s biggest greenhouse gas emitter, has once again emerged as the biggest puzzle at international climate change talks, sending ambiguous signals about the role it intends to play in future negotiations. This week, the nation’s top climate envoy said that China would be open to signing a formal treaty limiting emissions after 2020 — but laid down conditions for doing so that are unlikely ever to be met.

headline: Military Reads
text: Nytimes.com has an array of military-related items around the site today that are worth reading.

headline: Gingrich Surge Brings Added Scrutiny
text: DES MOINES – A year ago, as Newt Gingrich was beginning to seriously explore whether to seek the Republican presidential nomination, he bristled a bit when asked how his three marriages would be viewed by conservative voters.

headline: Excerpt: 'Maple and Vine'
text: Marin Ireland and Trent Dawson in a scene from Jordan Harrison’s new play at Playwrights Horizons. (Video courtesy of the theater.)

headline: Bernie Fine Can’t Be Charged, District Attorney Says
text: The former Syracuse assistant men’s basketball coach Bernie Fine cannot be prosecuted for allegations that he sexually abused two boys in the 1980s because the statute of limitations had run out, William Fitzpatrick, the district attorney for Onondaga County, N.Y., said Wednesday. Fitzpatrick added he believed the accusers were telling the truth about the abuse.

headline: CNL Adds Stevens Pass to Its Ski Resorts
text: Stevens Pass, a snow-smothered ski area 78 miles east of Seattle that is beloved by Northwesterners, was sold last month. It wasn’t big news, unless you noticed the buyer: CNL Lifestyle Properties.

headline: Romney Ad Highlights Stable Family
text: 11:35 p.m. | Updated  Read the full report here.

headline: Is the Tools of the Mind Curriculum Effective?
text: Being able to sit at a desk in kindergarten can be just as important as learning the A B C’s. The curriculum of one popular pre-K program, Tools of the Mind, that tries to enforce those kinds of skills in young children is finally being studied by researchers at New York University, who are trying to determine whether it really does make a difference.

headline: The First Marking Period Is Over. How Did SchoolBook Do?
text: At SchoolBook, we are assessing the site every day, discussing tweaks and larger changes, and testing the experience against our expectations. If we were issuing ourselves a progress report, SchoolBook at three months has probably earned a ... well, you tell us. Meanwhile, here are a few things that are on our agenda for improvement.

headline: Karzai Says He Will Talk to Pakistan Over Attacks
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai paid an emotional visit on Wednesday to a hospital full of survivors of a series of suicide bombings claimed by a Pakistani extremist group, and he promised to pursue the issue with Pakistan’s government.

headline: Tax Cut or Tax Increase?
text: The overhaul of the state’s income tax structure agreed to by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders will tax income over $2 million (for married couples filing jointly) at 8.82 percent. That is significantly higher than the state’s highest base income tax rate, which is 6.85 percent, but slightly lower than the 8.97 percent rate that for the last three years has been imposed on high incomes under a surcharge that was set to expire Dec. 31.

headline: Blagojevich Sentenced to 14 Years in Prison
text: CHICAGO — Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois who for years proclaimed he was innocent of federal corruption charges, apologized on Wednesday for his crimes. He apologized to his trial judge. He apologized to his family. He apologized to the residents of Illinois, who had heard his voice on secretly recorded phone calls as he crassly spoke of what he might get in exchange for a United States Senate seat.

headline: 2011 Versus 1910, an Editorial Change of Heart
text: One of the marvelous things about my job as the editorial page editor of a 151-year-old newspaper is that I occasionally happen upon curious editorial positions from days of yore. I’m not talking about the paper’s onetime opposition to women’s suffrage, although that was strange.

headline: Top Agent in Hip-Hop Is Leaving William Morris
text: Cara Lewis, the top booking agent for hip-hop and R&B acts, with a client roster that includes Eminem, Kanye West and Rihanna, is leaving her longtime job at WME, the agency formerly known as William Morris Endeavor.

headline: On Our Radar: Weakening Brazil’s Forest Protections
text: Brazil’s Senate approves a controversial forestry bill supported by growers and ranchers that would relax limits on tree-cutting. If it becomes final, environmentalists say, the measure would undo recent progress in reining in the deforestation of the Amazon. [The Wall Street Journal]

headline: The Life Report: Charles Darwin Snelling
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: A Climb and a Cause
text: R.A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, will climb Mount Kilimanjaro in January, in part to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats.

headline: Police Commissioner Criticizes Officers’ Slurs Against Paradegoers
text: Updated, 2:38 p.m. | Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly made his first statement on Wednesday about the latest scandal to hit the New York Police Department, condemning the kind of hateful speech attributed to several police officers on a Facebook page dedicated to the unpleasantness of working the annual West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn.

headline: Designer of Piaggio Vespa Is Honored by Former Employer
text: One of the most influential but commonly overlooked designers of the 20th century is getting his due.

headline: Execution Case Dropped Against Abu-Jamal
text: Prosecutors in Philadelphia announced Wednesday that they had halted the state’s effort to execute Mumia Abu-Jamal, the death row inmate convicted of killing a police officer 30 years ago, whose subsequent legal case based on claims of innocence has received international attention.

headline: An Interview With Gideon Rosen
text: The philosopher Gideon Rosen on culture and value.

headline: Despite Promises From Assad, ABC News Crew Encountered Restrictions in Syria
text: Updated | 5:51 p.m. As my colleague Alan Cowell reports, President Bashar al-Assad denied responsibility for the violence in Syria that has left an estimated 4,000 people dead in a television interview with Barbara Walters of ABC News.

headline: IPad Faces Trademark Trouble in China
text: 3:58 p.m. | Updated  Adding quote from lawyer at end.

headline: A Holiday Break
text: Gail Collins: David, let’s talk about something other than the Republican primaries. Newt Gingrich is just not a holiday subject.

headline: Perry Ad Focuses on Gays and Christianity
text: In an appeal to hard-right conservatives, Gov. Rick Perry of Texas is broadcasting a new campaign ad that seems to contrast Christianity with homosexuality, vows to end what he calls “Obama’s war on religion,” and highlights Mr. Perry’s criticism of overturning the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy for gays serving in the military.

headline: McCarver Is Honored by Hall of Fame
text: Tim McCarver was thinking about his broadcast partners at the Philadelphia Phillies on Wednesday when he won the National Baseball Hall of Fame’s Ford C. Frick Award.

headline: Leading Off: Scandal Makes Penn State a Fixture in Headlines
text: The Penn State scandal has the dubious distinction of having what seems to be a permanent place in the headlines sections of sports Web sites.

headline: A Proposal to Simplify Credit Card Agreements
text: Credit card agreements are typically something you’d want to read only if you suffered from insomnia. A glance at a few lines of the dense type, printed on filmy paper, is sure to help you drift off.

headline: First Look | Valentino’s Timestrings Collection
text: At first glance it’s hard to find a common thread running through Valentino’s spring capsule collection, Timestrings. The studded peep-toe booties, satin flats, polka-dot platforms and bow-embellished kitten heels carry many of the brand’s signatures, but share none of them collectively. What all of the shoes do share is a handwritten time stamp — a numerical record of the amount of time it took to make each pair. For example, the sequence etched into a pair of silver chain wedge heels is 47.41’50”, denoting 47 hours, 41 minutes and 50 seconds. “When we talk about luxury and time, it’s clear that there’s a strong connection between the two,” says Maria Grazia Chiuri, one of the house’s two co-designers. “Time is the new luxury, and luxury does not exist without time and the consciousness of a unique tradition.” Classic Italian craftsmanship still exists (Valentino is known for its old Florentine factories), but in an age of fast everything it’s easy to forget our Old World cobblers: the one devoted to flowers, the one who specializes in crystals and another with expertise in lace, for example. Pierpaolo Piccioli, Chiuri’s design partner, adds, “It’s nice to know that you’re buying a kind of cultural process.” Milled plexiglass and velvet wedges marked 38H? At $1,295, that’s $34 an hour, if you break it down. And yes, it’s worth it.

A dreamer and newcomer to Manhattan by way of Buffalo, he opened that establishment, Caffe Cino, in 1958 and over time became a veritable spokesman for the intimate and uncommercial productions mounted on its shabby, makeshift stage.

Dancing is on the show’s agenda, in addition to an interview, and we can’t wait to assess Stephen Colbert’s technique. Hee Seo, a soloist with American Ballet Theater, will also perform. headline: Underworld to Create Music for Opening of 2012 Olympics in London
text: The members of the electronic dance music group Underworld have been named the musical directors for the opening ceremony of the 2012 Olympics in London, organizers announced on Wednesday. The duo, Rick Smith and Karl Hyde, will work alongside the artistic director, the British filmmaker Danny Boyle, to produce the music for the three-hour performance on July 27. It is not the first time Mr. Boyle has chosen Mr. Smith and Mr. Hyde to provide the soundtrack for one of his projects. The group is perhaps best known for its dance track “Born Slippy,” which first appeared in a scene from Mr. Boyle’s 1996 film “Trainspotting.” Since then, they have created music for four other projects by Mr. Boyle, including a National Theater production of “Frankenstein” that received high praise from critics. Mr. Boyle said the hiring of Underworld to write music for the Games was “the last piece of the jigsaw puzzle” and praised the duo’s creative range. Mr. Hyde said the chance to compose for the Olympics was a great honor. “We want to leave people with a musical memory of the show rather than a purely visual one,” he said in a statement.

headline: 21st-Century Frocks | Azzedine Alaïa at the Groninger Museum
text: Azzedine Alaïa has never obeyed the fashion calendar and shows only when he — and his clothes — are good and ready. In fact, in recent years, the designer, who is now in his 70s, has probably had as many runway presentations as museum exhibitions, including the one that opens this weekend at the Groninger Museum in the Netherlands. “Azzedine Alaïa in the 21st Century” focuses solely on his output from roughly the past decade, and yet there is more substance there than many designers could ever hope to achieve in a lifetime, including the fierce tailcoat above and a toothsome evening dress with a zipper that spirals suggestively around the body from the neck to the floor. Always the perfectionist in the pursuit of beauty (he’s often referred to as a “sculptor of women’s bodies”), Alaïa apparently recut or totally remade many of the pieces in the show to the exact proportions of the mannequins. In an open love letter to the designer, Mark Wilson, who curated the exhibition, writes, “I’m sure that certain people may wonder why we are doing this one more time?” referring to a massive Alaïa exhibition at the Groninger Museum back in in 1997-98. Wilson promptly answers his own question: “Because you are the last great couturier working today.”

headline: By Winning a Fourth, U.S.C. Records a First in Water Polo

Berkeley’s Spieker Aquatics Complex and the U.S.C. water polo starters turned to face their fans from their positions in the pool with fists raised. The announcer couldn’t be heard once the clock hit zero and every Trojan player poolside jumped into the water.

What’s this oil got to do with virginity? This is a whore.”

But no, the actor and performance artist John Fleck grabs a handful in his spirited, heartfelt, one-man show “Mad Women” at the Club at La MaMa. Mr. Fleck and three other artists — Karen Finley, Holly Hughes and Tim Miller — were at the center of a controversy over content in the early 1990s when the National Endowment for the Arts revoked their grants. There is no controversy in “Mad Women,” only affection for Garland and bittersweet recollections of Mr. Fleck’s past.

headline: The Predictability of Tantrums
text: Of course you knew that kids have tantrums. But you probably didn’t know that kids who have tantrums mostly have them in a neat, predictable pattern. Michael Potegal, a neurology professor, teamed up with James Green, a developmental psychologist, to look not at what causes tantrums but at how they work. They found three standard phases (video documented on NPR’s Shots blog). Phase 1: yelling and screaming. Phase 2: physical actions. Phase 3: crying and whining.

headline: On Eve of Key Meeting, New Rifts on Euro Emerge
text: PARIS — Disagreements over how to enforce better economic discipline and centralized oversight over nations in the European Union emerged on Wednesday, the day before a crucial summit meeting to deal with the euro crisis, including disputes over how extensively and how quickly to change European treaties.

headline: African Fashion in Its Multifaceted Designs
text: A new book called “New African Fashion” highlights designers — some established, some fledgling — whose work is African made or inspired.

headline: Designers Take a Fresh Look at Africa
text: IN the years since Yves Saint Laurent showed his iconic 1967 “African” collection, fashion designers have repeatedly tapped the heritage of Africa in search of inspiration. Just last season Burberry and Michael Kors were among several labels that mined the continent as a source of ideas. Yet in the popular imagination, especially in the Western hemisphere, African fashion more often than not means animal prints, mud cloth and cowrie shells. In her new work, “New African Fashion” (Prestel; $35), Helen Jennings, a fashion journalist, hopes to broaden that view. Part coffee-table book, part glossary, it highlights designers — some established, some fledgling — whose work is African made or inspired.

text: LIKE movie theaters and libraries, many fitness clubs have insisted for years that their workout areas should be cellphone-free. Their logic is as simple and straightforward as a push-up: they want to prevent people from yakking on their phones and annoying the fitness buffs who want to crank out reps and mileage in relative peace. Safety is another reason, because texting while running on a treadmill can be hazardous to your health.

headline: Central Park, the Soundtrack
text: Clamp on headphones, start up the iPhone app by the musical duo Bluebrain and walk into Central Park. The music does not begin until you pass through an entrance and head into the trees. Then it sounds like an orchestra tuning up, a chaotic jumble of wind chimes, electronic moans and discordant strings. Push farther into the park, and a sweet violin melody emerges over languid piano chords.

headline: Destination Unknown, but a Quest Pushes Gentle Motion to the Fore
text: A woman in white is roaming, searching. Slowly her movements fill each of the long, unusual, quiet chords of “The Unanswered Question,” by Charles Ives. Now she advances through space; now, staying on the spot, stretching her upper body, she arches her neck up to face the sky. There’s a sense that she does not know what she is seeking, but that she cannot stop her quest. It does not, however, agonize her: her motion has gentleness, and a strange mixture of restraint and luxuriance.

headline: After Vote, Congo Braces for Expressions of Discord
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — With a contentious election still unresolved more than a week after the voting, an uneasy quiet held here on Wednesday, punctuated by occasional blasts of tear gas, hurled rocks, gunshots and promises of more intense confrontations to come.

headline: The Futility Of Bipartisan Outreach
text: President Obama has tried — desperately, and far beyond the point at which it made any kind of sense — to reach out across the partisan divide. He has bent over backwards to be nice to bankers. He has clearly been uncomfortable with any kind of populist rhetoric, although that may finally be changing.

headline: Winter Wonders | Sunglasses Optional
text: The coat that does the most usually comes in a neutral color — black, white, camel — and leans a little (or a lot) toward one of three classic styles: trench, peacoat or blazer. Here, Angelina Jolie steps out in New York in a crisp white version of the latter with just the slightest bit of sheen; the actress Liv Tyler wears the season’s lengthy proportion on a version of the perennial peacoat; and the actress Jessica Biel pairs black with orange and blue –– note the matching bag and shoes — in the most effortless way.

headline: Penguins Say Crosby to Miss Next Two Games as Precaution
text: Sidney Crosby will be held out of the Penguins’ lineup for the next two games, the team said in a statement released late Wednesday afternoon.

headline: Wisecracks, Scattered Among Slow Tunes
text: “Now I’m going to play a ballad,” Ryan Adams deadpanned partway through his solo concert on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall. The joke was that he had been playing virtually nothing but ballads: one slow, perfectly poised song after another, presented so quietly that listeners leaned forward to catch each delicate moment. Between songs he wisecracked, drawing hoots and guffaws. “I don’t know why I write these kinds of songs,” he said. “I’m not sensitive at all. I’m a bastard.” Then the next song would create another gorgeously hushed communion.

headline: Frédéric Malle | ‘On Perfume Making’
text: Have you ever walked down Madison Avenue, stumbled upon a grungy overfilled trash can and inhaled the scent of roses? It may very well have been the work of the renowned perfumer Frédéric Malle of Les Editions de Parfums.

headline: Venerable Choir and Its Guests Burnish a Holiday Tradition
text: For listeners who prefer the historical approach to Baroque style, the annual performances of Handel’s “Messiah” at St. Thomas Church set a standard that is hard to surpass. Granted, there are other period-instrument “Messiah” readings in town, most notably those offered by Trinity Church. (This year’s run begins on Sunday and includes a performance at Alice Tully Hall on Dec. 19.) But where St. Thomas has the edge is in its use of a chorus of men and boys, the younger singers drawn from its own choir school, a British tradition that stretches back beyond the time when Handel worked in England. Not that the superb, fully professional Trinity Choir has any reason to feel second best. But there is a purity in the sound of trained boy sopranos that a mixed adult choir cannot match.

headline: Amid a Horrific Scene, Tears
text: Massoud Hossaini has never cried like this before.

headline: Now Exposing | The 2012 Pirelli Calendar
text: For most every year since 1964, Pirelli, the Italian tire maker, has bankrolled a very unusual, very expensive promotional calendar. It typically involves a coterie of the world’s hottest models jetting to an exquisitely remote clime — the Seychelles, say, or Botswana — to be photographed, nude, by an elite fashion photographer. The calendar began inauspiciously as a pinup that grease monkeys would post at continental service stations. But just like in the case of Michelin’s influential guidebook, it took on a life of its own and now its connection to motoring seems completely incidental. (One must give props to all these European tire makers for their enduring contributions to world culture; the best thing our own Goodyear has come up with so far is a blimp.)

headline: A Ticket to East Egg, Please
text: YOU could be forgiven for thinking that the spring 2012 fashion collections were an open call for costumes for the Baz Luhrmann remake of “The Great Gatsby,” in theaters late next year. Flapper shapes and Art Deco lines lindy-hopped down runways from New York to Milan. There was flapper fringe at Etro and Marchesa, Glad-wrapped chorus girls at Marc Jacobs, zigzagging patterns at J. Mendel, BCBG and Alberta Ferretti. And at Gucci there were so many flapper numbers, their architectural patterns outlined in black and gold, that the show was a study in Jazz Age opulence.

headline: Making Short Work of Shopping for Tablet Users
text: Those days of dashing through the mall on Christmas Eve, searching for the perfect book or DVD, may be history. Procrastinators this year can sit at home, alone and unruffled, and send books, music and even video in time for Christmas delivery — on tablets like the Kindle Fire, the Nook and the iPad.

headline: For the Big Apple, a Gift That Grows

headline: Team of Italians and Americans Defends Its Reisinger Title
text: SEATTLE — As the Fall North American Championships ended here on Sunday, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams proved to be a comfortable repeat victory for James Cayne of New York City; Michael Seamon of Dania, Fla.; and Giorgio Duboin, Antonio Sementa, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace from Italy. They finished four boards ahead of Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Fulvio Fantoni, Claudio Nunes, Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness, who represent Monaco.

headline: Daily Deals, Sent Right to Your Pocket

headline: Beauty as Their Business
text: WITH a swirl of honey-blond hair, feline green eyes and a blue bloodline (her great-grandfather was Marcellus Hartley, the 19th-century philanthropist, whose funeral in 1902 drew Andrew Carnegie and J. Pierpont Morgan), Lauren Remington Platt ticks off all the checkboxes of a successful socialite. She is frequently photographed at fashion galas and charity balls, including the recent M Missoni for OrphanAid Africa party and the fall benefit for the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

headline: Lens: Visual Power in a Horrific Scene
text: In case you missed it, our colleagues on the Lens blog carry a post today about Massoud Hossaini, one of the few photographers at the scene in Kabul, Afghanistan, following a series of coordinated bombings on Tuesday, which also struck the cities of Kandahar and Mazar-i-Sharif, killing at least 63 Shiite worshipers. Taken through his own flowing tears, Mr. Hossaini’s gripping pictures of the aftermath were striking enough to appear on the front page of this newspaper, as well as The Los Angeles Times and The Washington Post. You can read Mr. Hossaini’s very personal recollection of the chaos here.

Crew catalog, turned up in Memphis with Rena DeAngelo, a decorator. Joined by two producers and led by a Southerner with an eye for period detail, they went in search of the setting for what would become one of this year’s blockbuster movies, “The Help.”

headline: From Rick Owens, Fashion to Sit On
text: “Anyone creating their own environment is following a utopian vision,” the fashion designer Rick Owens said of his new furniture collection, introduced this week at Maxfield Gallery in Los Angeles. “Mine is a Brutalist fur on a Brutalist rock next to a Brutalist fire in a Brutalist cave.” It includes 15 “shamelessly big” pieces (including chairs, a screen, a couch, a table and a bed), made from materials like black plywood, 500,000-year-old petrified bark and alabaster. “Making furniture is my version of couture: it’s time-consuming artisanal work made in limited quantities in rare materials, customized for my favorite client, my better half, the Hun,” Mr. Owens said, referring to his wife, Michele Lamy. Prices start at about $10,000 (the Boudeuse couch, pictured, is $78,750). Maxfield, 8818 Melrose Avenue, Los Angeles; (310) 275-8818 or maxfieldla.com.

headline: China: Hundreds Arrested on Child-Selling Charges
text: More than 600 people across China have been arrested on suspicion of selling children, according to a statement released Wednesday by the Ministry of Public Security. The statement also said 178 children had been freed. There has been greater scrutiny of trafficking in children this year, in part because of news reports by Caixin Century Weekly that shed light on child abductions and child-selling in Hunan Province. Some children were later adopted by foreigners, Caixin reported. Experts say the kidnapping and sale of children is a problem in China because of the country’s one-child policy and the cultural preference among many parents for boys. Families in many areas are fined heavily if they have more than one child and refuse to give up the others, and some officials have abducted children from such families. In addition, some parents are willing to sell girls so they can keep or try to conceive a son as their only child.

headline: 4 Accused in Theft of Aid Meant for Nonprofit
text: In 2006, a Queens state senator, Shirley L. Huntley, set up a nonprofit group called Parent Workshop that was intended to help parents navigate the inner workings of New York City’s school system. Then she began funneling state aid to the group, whose executives had close ties to her.

headline: Washington’s Black Codes
text: Rising to speak to the Senate on Dec. 4, 1861, the third day of the Congressional session, Henry Wilson of Massachusetts brandished a report on the sordid conditions in the Washington jail and, in particular, on 60 African-American prisoners held within it. Wilson had been to the jail to witness the stunning “scene of degradation and inhumanity.”

text: WASHINGTON — The stealth C.I.A. drone that crashed deep inside Iranian territory last week was part of a stepped-up surveillance program that has frequently sent the United States’ most hard-to-detect drone into the country to map suspected nuclear sites, according to foreign officials and American experts who have been briefed on the effort.

text: At an appearance in Iowa on behalf of Mitt Romney, New Jersey governor Chris Christie seemed to get more questions about his own future prospects than about the candidate he was representing.

headline: Vonn’s Super-G Victory Is a Hometown Triumph
text: BEAVER CREEK, Colo. — Even after three consecutive wins last weekend in Lake Louise, Alberta, Lindsey Vonn was unusually nervous as she waited at the start of Wednesday’s super-G race. The super-G was the first running of a women’s World Cup event in this location — almost an extension of Vonn’s hometown, nearby Vail. With friends and family looking on, the pressure was compounded.

headline: Millions? Private Jet? Columbia Offers New York
text: Early one morning last week, inside Columbia’s subterranean athletic center in Upper Manhattan, M. Dianne Murphy leaned over a conference table and wrapped her fingers around a disposable cup of coffee. There was no time to sleep these days, she said.

headline: Drone Crash in Iran Reveals Secret U.S. Surveillance Program
text: Crash of Stealth C.I.A. Drone in Iran Reveals Secret U.S. Surveillance Effort | The C.I.A. RQ-170 drone that crashed in Iran last week has blown the cover off of one of the United States’ most secret intelligence-collection efforts against the country. While American and Iranian officials dispute the cause of the drone’s demise — Iranian officials say the military hacked into the drone’s control systems, Americans say the drone malfunctioned — an essential question remains: What will happen with the centerpiece of a once covert program, now that the aircraft is in Iran’s hands? Scott Shane and David E. Sanger report that the United States considered it too risky to retrieve or destroy the drone, which leaves open the possibilities that Iran could reverse-engineer the drone’s technology, or turn the aircraft over to China or Russia. You can read the full report here.

headline: Always a Bed-Wetter, Never a Bride
text: As a travel writer for a luxury magazine, I get to sleep in exotic locations on top of memory-foam mattresses with 800-thread-count sheets. It is a major indulgence, since for most of my childhood and my early teens, I slept on the floor on wet sheets and a rubber mat.

headline: Hope in the Age of Man
text: SCIENTISTS interested in drawing attention to the human transformation of planet Earth have begun calling the current geological epoch the Anthropocene — the age of man. Naming an epoch is serious business — and in this case the new name is well deserved, given humanity’s enormous alteration of the Earth.

headline: Not What Mr. Putin Planned
text: Prime Minister Vladimir Putin of Russia has cynically dominated his country’s politics for the last 11 years and intends to do it for many more years to come. Given the way he has muzzled independent media and hobbled opponents, it looked as though nothing could challenge his reign. Then came Sunday’s parliamentary election in which a surprising number of voters made clear that they are tired of the status quo and Mr. Putin.

headline: Politics and the Morning-After Pill
text: Once again, the politics of birth control have trumped science and sound public policy.
