And President Obama has been on the phone almost every other week — including on Wednesday — with either Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany or President Nicolas Sarkozy of France.

headline: Constantly Checking In, Without Ever Checking In
text: This summer and fall, I spent 156 hours in some of New York’s finest hotels. I did not sleep, or shower, or earn rewards points. But it remained to be seen how far those arguments will carry them, especially given the candidates’ rightward tilt on other issues that have traditionally been important to American Jews.

headline: U.S. Agency Is Ordered to Change Wind Rules

It ordered the agency, the Bonneville Power Administration, to rewrite its rules.

headline: Jets’ Consultant Takes a Closer Look

Every play of every game is magnified, particularly for teams seeking a playoff berth, teams like the Jets.

headline: Crosby Out for Two Games
text: Sidney Crosby will be held out of the Penguins’ lineup for the next two games as a precaution, the team said. Crosby appeared to have difficulty putting weight on his right leg after he collided with his teammate Chris Kunitz in the third period of Pittsburgh’s 3-1 loss to the Boston Bruins on Monday. Crosby played the remainder of the game.

headline: Turkey: More Trade Measures Imposed Against Syria
text: Turkey will levy taxes of about 30 percent on Syrian goods after President Bashar al-Assad of Syria suspended a free-trade agreement and imposed taxes on Turkish exports, Hayati Yazici, the Turkish minister of customs and trade, said Wednesday. Relations between the two countries have deteriorated since August, when Mr. Assad failed to take steps to end a deadly crackdown on dissent. Since then, Turkey has halted joint energy exploration, joined the Arab League’s sanctions against its once-close ally, threatened to expand embargoes, and started shipping routes to Egypt and Lebanon to circumvent Syria, which has blocked Turkish trucks.

headline: Iran Shutters U.S. Embassy on the Web
text: Iranians shut down the United States’ Tehran embassy 32 years ago. They shut down its virtual Tehran embassy on Wednesday.

headline: Dobie Gray, Singer Known for ‘Drift Away,’ Dies
text: Dobie Gray, a versatile singer and songwriter who had a handful of hits in various pop genres but who was probably best known for his enduring 1973 soul anthem, “Drift Away,” a wistful paean to all songwriters and their songs, died on Tuesday in Nashville. He was believed to be 71.

headline: Florida: Punishment Delayed in Drum Major’s Death
text: At the request of the Florida Department of Law Enforcement, Florida A&M University said on Wednesday that it was delaying disciplinary action in the wake of the possible hazing death of a marching band drum major. Earlier, the university fired its longtime band director, Julian White, and said it would suspend some students in the death of the drum major, Robert Champion. Those moves have been halted for now while the investigation continues into the death. Mr. Champion was found unresponsive on a bus parked outside an Orlando, Fla., hotel last month after a football game. He was vomiting and had complained he could not breathe before he collapsed.

headline: F.B.I. Board Votes to Broaden Definition of Rape
text: An F.B.I. advisory board voted this week to modernize an archaic definition of rape that the agency has used for more than eight decades in its tally of national crime statistics. The current definition used by the F.B.I., “carnal knowledge of a female, forcibly and against her will,” has been criticized by law enforcement officials and women’s advocates as far too narrow, with the result that many rapes are excluded from the yearly Uniform Crime Report. The new definition approved by the advisory board, which met in Albuquerque on Tuesday, includes the rape of men and crimes that involve oral or anal penetration or penetration with objects. The definition must be approved by the F.B.I.’s director, Robert S. Mueller III, before it is adopted.

headline: Woman Is Fatally Struck by a Sanitation Truck in Brooklyn
text: A sanitation truck struck and killed a woman on Wednesday night in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the police said. No crime was suspected, they said.

headline: Dugald Stermer, Illustrator and Ramparts Art Director, Dies at 74
text: Dugald Stermer, who achieved renown and sometimes angered the government as the art director of the influential left-wing magazine Ramparts in the 1960s, died on Dec. 2 in San Francisco. He was 74.

headline: Marion Dougherty, Hollywood Star-Maker, Dies at 88
text: Marion Dougherty, who cast some of Hollywood’s biggest stars in their earliest parts, including Al Pacino, Dustin Hoffman and Warren Beatty, and who suggested Carroll O’Connor for the role of  Archie Bunker in the long-running hit television show “All in the Family,” died Sunday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88.

headline: G.E.-Microsoft Venture to Create ‘Windows’ for Health Care
text: Any discussion of the challenge of trying to improve health care and curb costs with computer technology quickly turns to “silos.” Not the kind that store corn in Midwestern farms, obviously.

headline: I.B.M. Using Bits of Watson for Drug Research
text: When I.B.M.’s Watson computer beat two human “Jeopardy!” champions earlier this year, it was a triumphant demonstration of the company’s technology. It was great for Big Blue’s image, but it was not a moneymaker on its own.

headline: Researcher Creates Online Library About Concussions
text: Saying that parents whose children play contact sports should “not accept public health policy from the N.H.L., but do it for themselves,” a doctor heading a team of Canadian concussion specialists on Thursday created an online concussion library fully accessible to both the public and to research and medical professionals.

text: DALLAS – In another economic climate, Prince Fielder might be the perfect addition for the Mets. They are coming off three losing seasons, they could use a power hitter, and Fielder is only 27 years old.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Watch: A Glitch and Then the Singers Are on Their Own
text: “The X Factor” didn’t even try to make its manufactured drama convincing on Wednesday night’s show, which was supposed to include performances of songs chosen by viewers. There was a problem with the public voting, the host, Steve Jones, announced midway through the show, not even making a pretense of giving details or a reasonable explanation. The result, he said: Just 24 hours before going live, each of the five remaining contestants had to prepare a new song of his or her choice.

headline: Was FDI Just a Smokescreen?
text: In New Delhi, much like in other capitals, political gossip is often dominated by theorizing about why politicians do the things they do. In Delhi, this theorizing often arrives at an intriguing answer: Indian politicians often do one thing in order to accomplish something else altogether.

headline: Dec. 8, 1991 | Republics Declare End of Soviet Union

Kravchuk and the Belarusian leader Stanislav Shushkevich, released a declaration known as the Belavezha Accords, which declared that the Soviet Union was to be dissolved and succeeded by the Commonwealth of Independent States, a loose confederation of former Soviet states.

For what emotions, situations or activities do you wish there were emoticons? If you were to invent a new emoticon (or an “emoji,” the more elaborate Japanese cousins of emoticons featured in this article), what would it look like?

headline: Dickens Anniversary Kicks Off in London
text: Charles Dickens, considered by many to be the first great novelist of the modern city and the age of mass culture, will be widely celebrated throughout Great Britain in 2012, the 200th anniversary of his birth. The first major exhibition will take place from Dec. 9 to June 10 at the Museum of London (150 London Wall; www.museumoflondon.org.uk/dickens). He will be commemorated with paintings, photographs, costumes and objects that illustrate themes from his works, as well as rare, hand-written manuscripts of his novels “Bleak House,” “David Copperfield” and “Great Expectations.” Visitors will also get a chance to see his writing desk and chair. And William Raban’s documentary film “The Houseless Shadow” compares his London with the London of today.

headline: Indian Fashion Expands Online
text: Last June, the Web site Exclusively.in debuted in the United States with much fanfare. The concept seemed promising: Indians and Indophiles stateside could choose from a range of India-style clothing, art and home furnishings in a flash-sale format similar to Gilt.com’s and receive their purchases in three to five business days.

headline: Glogg Before ’Nog
text: Long before I was old enough to enjoy fully the pleasures of glogg — the Swedish yuletide wine mulled with orange peel and spices — its aroma had made me an admirer. I can still summon that first whiff, when, as a child, I stepped inside a small inn where a caldron of the stuff was simmering. Though this admission will make Scandinavians cringe, the fragrance evoked a warmed-up bowl of Froot Loops, a 10-year-old girl’s idea of olfactory heaven.

headline: In a Dusty Drawer, a Trove of Theatrical Voices

headline: The Frustrations of Trying to Connect On the Go
text: Not so long ago, I could handle being without an Internet connection as long as I could check e-mail and do bare-bones browsing on my cellphone. But now that I keep moving more and more of what I do to the cloud, from accounting to scheduling to collaborating to storing books and documents, I find myself practically incapacitated when I’m cut off from a laptop connection.

headline: Quiz: Do You Have a Generous Relationship?
text: How does your relationship rate on the generosity scale? Click on the box in front of your answer and then check your score. And to find out more about how generosity affects your relationship, read the New York Times Magazine column, “The Generous Marriage.”

headline: Most European Leaders Agree to Work on Fiscal Treaty
text: BRUSSELS — European leaders, meeting until the early hours of Friday, agreed to sign an intergovernmental treaty that would require them to enforce stricter fiscal and financial discipline in their future budgets. But efforts to get unanimity among the 27 members of the European Union, as desired by Germany, failed as Britain and Hungary refused to go along for now.

headline: Once a Prom Queen, Still a Spoiled Princess
text: Shorter than a bad blind date and as sour as a vinegar Popsicle, “Young Adult” shrouds its brilliant, brave and breathtakingly cynical heart in the superficial blandness of commercial comedy. More radically than “J. Edgar” or even “Greenberg,” this movie, written by Diablo Cody and directed by Jason Reitman, challenges the dreary conventional wisdom that a movie protagonist must be likable. Along the way, it systematically demolishes a china shop full of shopworn sentimental touchstones about — for starters — high school, small-town life, heterosexuality, Minnesota and the capacity of human beings to change, learn and grow.

headline: Week 14 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Cowboys vs. Giants
text: One of the more overlooked statistics in football is penalty rate. Penalty yards per play is one of the more consistent attributes of N.F.L. teams, second only to offensive pass efficiency. Penalty rate’s effect on game outcomes isn’t as large as that of other team attributes, but in terms of predicting winners its consistency makes it as important as things like running efficiency and interception rates.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 8
text: Adam Nagourney writes about Jay Carson and Chris Lehane, two former Democratic operatives in Washington who serve as the models for political consultants in different Hollywood movies. The Carson-inspired character was at the heart of “The Ides of March,” directed by George Clooney; Mr. Lehane is a writer and producer of “Knife Fight,” slated for release early next year, which also focuses on a political consultant. Both worked for President Bill Clinton, Mr. Nagourney writes, and “not surprisingly, each movie has an older male candidate who has sexual relations with an intern.” But more generally, he writes that the movies “go beyond the usual Hollywood glorification of political consultants, offering dark and at times unsettling accounts of what is done in the name of winning elections.”

headline: Seeing Things | Matthias Merkel Hess
text: Buckets, trash cans, gas cans, laundry hampers and milk crates. Matthias Merkel Hess, a Los Angeles artist, reimagines mundane containers, made to hold everything from gasoline to dirty socks, as ceramic sculptures that are clever, quirky and surprisingly graceful. In his show “Bucketry,” at L.A.’s Acme Gallery, on view through Dec. 21, he has expanded his quotidian repertory to include several new forms, including those of Styrofoam coolers and laundry hampers, the latter rendered in stoneware in various shapes and sizes.

headline: 36 Hours: Lake Placid, N.Y.
text: Over the last few decades, this two-time Winter Olympics host has been adding non-Olympic attractions.

headline: 36 Hours: Lake Placid, N.Y.
text: LAKE PLACID can feel cryogenically frozen in time — 1980 to be exact, which was when this secluded pocket of the Adirondacks hosted its second Winter Olympics. The towering ski jumps and toboggan runs, not to mention the “Miracle on Ice” hockey rink, look much as they did when Jimmy Carter was in office. But over the last few decades Lake Placid has quietly been adding non-Olympic attractions, including sophisticated farm-to-table restaurants, higher-grade lodgings and a gleaming convention center. Luckily the downtown has not lost its aura of Adirondack authenticity, with A-frame cottages and unpretentious boutiques drawing plenty of nonskiers. If the town were not smothered in Olympic logos, visitors might forget about its Olympics connections and think they had wandered into an idyllic Swiss hamlet.

headline: A Veteran in Billy Crystal’s Corner
text: The director Garry Marshall’s career has spanned 50 years of television and movies and produced classics and blockbusters from “Happy Days” to “Beaches” and “Pretty Woman.” He is a member of Hollywood’s old guard, which means he’s a transplanted New Yorker with a borscht belt sense of humor, and he’s still on his first wife (49 years and counting). He’s also a veteran of ensemble pieces (“Valentine’s Day”) and light, family-pleasing fare (“The Princess Diaries”).

text: It’s been a decade since the uproar over President Bill Clinton’s eleventh-hour pardon of Marc Rich—the fugitive financier whose ex-wife gave $450,000 to the Clinton Presidential Library—prompted his successor to reform the pardons process. headline: Huntsman Lashes Out at Romney and Gingrich

headline: Hugh Jackman Keeps His Pants On
text: IT takes two to be Hugh. The most adored performer on Broadway at the moment is, without question, Hugh Jackman, both of him. “Hugh Jackman: Back on Broadway,” at the Broadhurst Theater, has created this season’s most virulent case of box office fever by presenting the snazziest single double act New York has known since Alice Ripley and Emily Skinner played Siamese twins in “Side Show” 14 years ago.

headline: A Case of Whines
text: Fans of college sports have to wonder what rabbit hole they stepped into on days like Wednesday, when the headlines are full of developments involving sexual abuse charges against coaches, alongside the news that the Big East just absorbed five teams whose only common trait is that they are east of Guam. Not that they are remotely comparable events, but put them together with the N.C.A.A.’s sudden belief that it can step in and cure everything and more rumblings that a so-overdue-the-fines-are-tripling football playoff is “inevitable,” and well, we’re expecting Alice to join our Wonderland any minute now.

headline: The Holiday Finger-Food Combination Generator
text: Unless you have servants, there is an inclination toward panic when guests drop by, invited or not. I get that. But given that you are likely to entertain at some point in the next two weeks, you might as well arm yourself, by which I mean: buy some stuff. If you lay in a few good-tasting and versatile supplies, you can produce some pretty mean little canapés (or canapé-like creations) without much effort.

headline: Kids, Want Some Cereal With Your Sugar?
text: The key to a healthy cereal breakfast is to roll down the cereal aisle, grab your tried-and-true box of Cheerios, and get out before your child even asks about Tony the Tiger or that toucan dude on the box of Froot Loops. Of course you can say no. But it’s all too easy to agree to a little experimentation and come home with a box of Honey Nut Cheerios, only to realize that a serving contains more sugar than three Chips Ahoy cookies.

headline: Signing for Rodriguez Money Is the Easy Part
text: It appears as if the Albert Pujols sweepstakes is over and that Arte Moreno and the Angels have landed baseball’s greatest active hitter for a whopping 10 years and at least $250 million.

headline: Radio Had a Voice. Louie Gave It a Face.
text: Someone had to take the promotional picture for the Mutual Broadcasting System’s “Deadline” program, showing the host, Louise Snyder, holding a large turkey. (It was Thanksgiving, after all.) Mutual’s publicity photographer in the 1950s and ’60s was Louis Nemeth, who had a much greater talent — and a much more interesting story — than his 8-by-10 glossies ever revealed. Over the course of 93 years, he moved all of three blocks in Hungarian Yorkville, from East 68th Street to East 65th Street. But his career also took him to the Buchenwald concentration camp during World War II. There, in April 1945, as a member of the 165th Signal Photo Company, he spent three days documenting the horrors uncovered after the camp’s liberation. Maybe he used the next decades to create so many innocuous photo fantasies because he had already seen enough reality to last a lifetime. A video and a longer article are on Lens.

headline: New N.B.A. Deal Is Expected to Be Approved Thursday
text: The second-longest labor crisis in N.B.A. history is expected to reach its conclusion Thursday afternoon, with a vote to adopt a new collective bargaining agreement.

headline: Pearce to Ride for First Time Since 2009 Accident
text: In the weeks and months after the champion snowboarder Kevin Pearce sustained a traumatic brain injury while training on a halfpipe, and even while he was in a coma in a Utah hospital nearly two years ago, his friends and fans provided support through a simple slogan: I Ride for Kevin.

headline: Extreme Cleaning for the Holidays
text: Children love to wake up to a house full of presents during the winter holidays. But for the grown-ups, one of the best gifts of all is waking up to a clean house. Today’s Home section offers advice from extreme cleaners.

headline: Romney Super PAC Assails Gingrich
text: 7:31 p.m. | Updated A well-financed but largely unseen independent political group supporting Mitt Romney surfaced on Thursday in a big way, saying it was putting $3.1 million down on advertising in Iowa.

headline: The Case Against Ending Food Drives
text: Over on Slate yesterday, the new Moneybox columnist Matthew Yglesias sounded off on food drives. Having to pick up or sort your donations of random cans is highly inefficient. Much of the stuff that people remove from their pantries is unusable because it’s old or it’s junk food, he said. Plus, most food banks, he noted, can buy highly discounted bulk food in a variety of ways.

headline: Dispatch | Eating in Barbados
text: There are worse fates than being stuck in Barbados for a long weekend, as I was last month, having tagged along with my lady friend to a conference at the University of the West Indies. I had been told that Barbados, the most British of Caribbean isles, is also among the most delicious, so I resolved to eat my way across it, a journey that involved much driving on roads with no signs and much sipping of Mount Gay Extra Old rum, but of course never at the same time. (If you visit Barbados, you will be extolled the virtues of house-made rum punch — it is often poured out of bottles that look as if they once held bleach — but this cloying potion guarantees a terrible hangover. Instead, drink the local rums neat or with fresh juice.)

headline: The Nursing Home Exodus, Part 2
text: In January, when he was only 91, Edwin Murphy awoke in a hospital in Albuquerque, N.M., and learned that he’d had a heart attack.

headline: Now 80, George Washington Bridge Will Undergo Repairs
text: The George Washington Bridge is a cathedral of steel cables and beams, a stark, glimmering span that has become a civil engineering landmark, not to mention the busiest vehicular bridge in the world.

headline: Record Number of Journalists in Jail, Report Finds
text: A new report from the Committee to Protect Journalists found that the number of journalists and employees imprisoned for doing their jobs around the world rose sharply in 2011, with the largest jump seen in the Middle East, where popular uprisings have toppled governments and dominated the news.

headline: John Hurt in 'Krapp's Last Tape'
text: John Hurt in Samuel Beckett’s “Krapp’s Last Tape,” now at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The video was recorded by the Shakespeare Theater Company during the show’s run in Washington.

headline: The Heisman View From Wisconsin: Montee Ball
text: Throughout the day Thursday, The Quad will feature posts about Heisman Trophy contenders by sports writers at the candidates’ universities.

headline: Audio of Egyptian Military Briefing to Foreign Reporters
text: As my colleague David D. Kirkpatrick reports, the Egyptian military leadership on Wednesday held a news conference with foreign journalists in which it revealed its intention to control the constitutional process despite the results of parliamentary elections, which have been dominated so far by Islamist parties.

headline: Lens: Alex Webb 2
text: Lens: Alex Webb 2

headline: Commissar Putin Speaks
text: I said half-jokingly the other day that it’s sometimes hard to tell the difference between Soviet-era Russia and Putin-era Russia. Prime Minister Vladimir Putin has proved me wrong. If you ignore the relatively bountiful supply of toilet paper, it’s impossible to tell the difference. His reaction to the elections on Sunday and his complaints about foreign agitators were straight from Pravda.

headline: Taiwan Vote Draws Mainland Interest, and One Mainlander
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — A resident of mainland China was apparently so beguiled by this island’s coming elections and the promise of democracy that he spent seven hours paddling through the sea in an effort to see them with his own eyes.

headline: City Targets Jane Addams High for Closing
text: Staff members at Jane Addams High School for Academic Careers, a large high school in the South Bronx near Yankee Stadium, received news that the Department of Education planned to phase out the school for poor performance, pending a vote by the Panel for Educational Policy.

headline: An Earth Where the Droids Feel at Home
text: THE images simmering in the French photographer Cédric Delsaux’s “Dark Lens” series are an unsettling confluence of hyper-real cityscapes, a post-postmodern sense of humor ... and characters from “Star Wars.”

headline: Keep Watching the Skies
text: The cityscapes of the photographer Cédric Delsaux are infiltrated by characters from “Star Wars.”

headline: Alex Webb’s Dialogue With the Streets
text: Alex Webb’s photographs have the compositional complexity befitting the best street photographers. But instead of wandering among urban canyons or cosmopolitan boulevards — which he has — he has redefined the genre over the course of three decades in dusty border towns and tropical climes where the streets may not even be paved.

headline: Europe Disappoints. Again.
text: This week some smart people thought they knew what was going to happen in Europe.

headline: Gingrich, Ahead in Polls, Is Still Selling Books
text: Even as he widens his lead in the polls, Newt Gingrich spends substantial time on an activity that raised questions about his ultimate motive when he was a back-of-the-pack candidate: selling and signing $25 copies of his books.

headline: Iran Shows Video It Says Is of U.S. Drone
text: Iran paraded what its military described as a captured C.I.A. stealth drone on national television on Thursday and lodged an official diplomatic protest, portraying the visual images as an intelligence and propaganda windfall in its conflict with the West over its nuclear program.

headline: TimesCast | December 8, 2011
text: Russia’s prime minister accuses the United States of inciting election protests, and Mexico’s booming business of recycling car batteries leads to growing cases of lead poisoning.

headline: Two Dead in Shooting on Virginia Tech Campus
text: For more on the shooting, see the later report, “Violence Revisits Virginia Tech After Two Are Killed in Shooting.”

headline: Stress Test Reveals European Banks Need More Capital
text: 8:59 p.m. | Updated

headline: Fees Climb in Tribune Company Case
text: Thursday is the third anniversary of the bankruptcy case of the Tribune Company, which was purchased in a highly leveraged deal by the real estate magnate Sam Zell in 2007 and went broke a year later. The lack of resolution in the $13 billion deal has tested the patience of employees, but according to a report issued on Wednesday by Fitch Ratings, the credit agency, there’s been plenty of upside for the lawyers involved in the case.

headline: Boston Mayor Issues Deadline to Occupy Protesters
text: BOSTON — Protesters at Occupy Boston began preparing for the possibility of a police raid on Thursday, after Mayor Thomas M. Menino issued his first ultimatum for them to decamp.

headline: Coaching Searches Continue at U.C.L.A. and Arizona State
text: The coaching searches at Arizona State and U.C.L.A. have recently taken more more twists than a low-budget reality show.

headline: Could a Reconceived ‘Cinderella’ Get Invited to a Broadway Ball?
text: The first Broadway production of “Rodgers and Hammerstein’s Cinderella” is in the works for the 2012-13 theater season, with a new libretto by Douglas Carter Beane (“Lysistrata Jones,” “Sister Act”) based on the 1957 television musical that starred Julie Andrews, the producer Robyn Goodman said on Thursday.

headline: Trailer: ‘In Darkness’
text: The trailer for "In Darkness," a drama based on the true story of Jews in Poland who escaped the Nazis by hiding in sewers.

headline: Obama Backs Limit on Sale to Teenagers of Morning-After Pill
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, noting that he was the father of two daughters, threw his wholehearted support on Thursday behind a decision by his health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, not to allow emergency contraceptives to be sold over the counter to young teenagers.

headline: NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse Consider Deal Options
text: LONDON — The $9 billion merger between Deutsche Börse and NYSE Euronext could be in jeopardy if European antitrust authorities force more concessions from the exchanges, including the potential sale of lucrative derivatives businesses.

headline: Perry Would Not Demand Discharge if ‘Don’t Ask’ Returned
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has sharply criticized President Obama‘s repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gays serving in the military. But if the policy were reinstated, he would not demand the expulsion of service members who have disclosed their homosexuality since the policy was repealed in September.

headline: Trading Anthony and Calling Nets Makes Sense for Knicks
text: Finally and fittingly, the Knicks appear to have woken up to a not-so-harsh reality and to a world of immediate possibility. Gone, apparently, is their three-superstar agenda, replaced by a more original, and practical, championship-contending blueprint.

headline: The Heisman View From Baylor: Robert Griffin III
text: Throughout the day Thursday, The Quad will feature posts about Heisman Trophy contenders by sports writers at the candidates’ universities.

headline: Finding Reasons to Deploy to Afghanistan
text: I distinctly remember how sunny it was on the beach in Barcelona, Spain, when I received the e-mail about deploying to Afghanistan. It was May 2011, and I was living in Barcelona partly to improve my Spanish, but mostly to just enjoy life.

headline: Perry and Bachmann Also Pass on Trump Debate
text: 6:51 p.m. | Updated MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. – Gov. Rick Perry of Texas and Representative Michele Bachmann have joined other candidates, including Mitt Romney, in passing on Donald Trump’s Dec. 27 debate in Iowa. Mr. Perry’s campaign issued this statement on Thursday:

text: The Department of Education released the names of 12 schools it is proposing to phase out, and identified three from which it wants to remove some of the grades.

headline: State Taxes Rise Across the U.S.
text: State tax revenues rose last quarter compared with a year earlier, according to preliminary data from the Rockefeller Institute of Government at the State University at Albany. This was the seventh straight quarter of growth, and is happy news for states struggling with budget shortfalls in the wake of the Great Recession.

headline: Warner Music Says Losses Grew in the Quarter
text: The Warner Music Group reported increased losses for its fourth quarter and fiscal year on Thursday, with growth in digital music not enough to offset the company’s interest costs and lagging overall music sales.

text: A scene from Lydia R. Diamond's play at the Cort Theater. (Video courtesy of the production.)

headline: Republicans Unveil Plan for Payroll Tax
text: WASHINGTON — Pivoting to challenge President Obama and Senate Democrats, House Republicans said Thursday that they would forge ahead with a payroll tax holiday bill that includes an oil pipeline opposed by the president and that looks to changes in social programs to pay for the tax cut and added unemployment benefits.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Congo and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Congo, Syria and Russia.

headline: All That Work for 2 Points
text: When Minnesota Vikings defensive end Jared Allen tackled Denver’s Willis McGahee in the end zone last Sunday, he rose to his feet and clapped his hands together over his head, the instantly recognizable signal for a safety.

headline: Ford, Feeling Secure, To Resume Dividends
text: DETROIT — The Ford Motor Company on Thursday said it would resume paying quarterly dividends to its shareholders for the first time since 2006, as it closes out its third consecutive profitable year.

headline: Despite Higher Admission Fee, Höller Show Draws Record Crowds to New Museum
text: The New Museum, which recently raised its general admission price to pay for extra workers to accommodate the crowds for its exhibition of the work of Carsten Höller, said Thursday that the show – a highbrow funhouse with a slide, a sensory deprivation tank and a slow-motion carousel – had become the most highly attended show in the museum’s 35-year history.

headline: In $2.5 Million Judgment, Court Finds Blogger Is Not a Journalist
text: Academics and Web thinkers have spent a lot of time jawboning about whether a blogger fits the definition of a journalist. It’s an endless discussion, but this week in Oregon, the debate turned costly for one blogger.

headline: N.F.L. Fast Forward: Week 14 and Beyond
text: Judy Battista sits down with Connor Ennis to discuss the playoff chances of the Giants and Jets, whether any team can stop the Green Bay Packers and the future of Peyton Manning and the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: Three Artists Expanding Their Horizons
text: This week we talk to three artists who are expanding their horizons: the jazz violinist Jenny Scheinman, the Australian pop star Gotye and the indie folk singer-songwriter Sharon Van Etten.

headline: Lyon’s Walkover Untainted by Fraud, UEFA Says
text: Lyon’s eye-popping 7-1 win at Dinamo Zagreb on Wednesday, which helped it rescue a spot in the 16-team knockout round of the UEFA Champions League, was untainted by suspicious gambling patterns that could indicate match-fixing.

headline: In Uniform at Protests, and in Trouble as a Result
text: Among the more colorful protesters to emerge from Occupy Wall Street was a uniformed former police commander from the Philadelphia police. His name is Ray Lewis, and, after retiring as a captain in 2004 after 24 years of service, he became active in the world of social justice.

headline: Twitter Tries to Simplify Its Service
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter unveiled an ambitious new design on Thursday that is intended to draw new users, keep them on the social network longer and attract more advertisers.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.8
text: Toronto Raptors forward Linas Kleiza prepared for the coming N.B.A. season, and the European short course swimming championships began in Poland.

headline: A Community on the Cliffs
text: In 2008, Ester Jove Soligue, a Spanish photographer, began documenting a collection of shacks tucked along cliffs in Union City, N.J.

headline: Field Notes From This Year’s Application Season
text: To get an on-the-ground glimpse of this year’s admissions cycle, The Choice reached out this week to a handful of college counselors across the country to hear what trends they had been observing.

headline: Fight Fans, Get Ready for Thatcher vs. Nobbs
text: Do we have a diva showdown on our hands? Next week awards-o-philes will have a difficult choice between “The Iron Lady” (Meryl Streep as Margaret Thatcher) and “Albert Nobbs” (Glenn Close as a woman passing as a male butler in Victorian Dublin), whose premieres and splashy afterparties are scheduled for the same night. (Never fear, the Bagger will miraculously figure out a way to be in both places at once.)

headline: Answers to Questions About China’s Economy
text: On Wednesday, Economix asked readers to submit questions for David Barboza, who has reported for The Times from Shanghai since 2004. Mr. Barboza’s article, “Entrepreneur’s Rival in China: The State,” was published on the front page of Thursday’s paper.

headline: Why Nene Should Be in Demand
text: Free agency officially begins on Dec. 9, but the chase has already begun. There are no traditional superstars in the bunch, but the best relative talents will still land maximum or near-max contracts under the league’s new collective bargaining agreement. Here’s look at one of the terrific — if likely overpaid — candidates for such a deal.

headline: TimesCast | Putin Blames Sec. Clinton
text: December 8, 2011 - In a strikingly personal tone, Russia's Prime Minister accuses Secretary of State Hillary Clinton of inciting election protests.

headline: Identity Theft and a Happy App
text: Daniel Mohan of ID Watchdog explains how people’s identities can be stolen (and what to do about it) and Will Lucas discusses Thankyouaga.in, a new social app for positive posts.

headline: Irish Archbishop Who Died in ’73 Is Linked to Abuse
text: DUBLIN — The former archbishop of Dublin, John Charles McQuaid, widely regarded as the most powerful Catholic prelate in modern Irish history, stands accused of serial child sexual abuse, The Irish Times newspaper said Thursday.

headline: Europe’s Debt Crisis Brings Two Former Foes Closer Than Ever
text: BERLIN — In the battle over how to save the euro, Germany has plenty of leverage but not many friends. Among its staunchest supporters is also one of the most surprising, its historic enemy, Poland.

headline: Lousy Filibusters: Richard Cordray Edition
text: It seems like only yesterday that Republicans blocked President Obama’s nominee for the D.C. Circuit appeals court, Caitlin Halligan, for no good reason. Actually, it was two days ago, and the Republicans have already moved onto yet more obstruction. Today, they blocked the confirmation of Richard Cordray: President Obama’s pick to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.

headline: A Somber New Year’s Eve for Solar?
text: While renewable energy advocates have long argued that government subsidies for the sector are dwarfed by those for more traditional energy industries, they have had a more poignant complaint since the onset of the recession: one of the subsidies they do get, an investment tax credit, has been rendered nearly useless by the general business downturn.

headline: The Jig Is Up, Or Is It? ‘Bonnie & Clyde’ Only Selling Tickets Through End of the Year
text: In an unusual business move, a lead producer of the new Broadway musical “Bonnie & Clyde” said on Thursday that performances beyond December have been cancelled and tickets are only on sale through Dec. 30 – yet a closing notice for the show has not been posted.

headline: In Syria, Expelling the Peacemakers
text: Jerusalem

headline: What Wasn’t Passed On
text: THREE years ago, while my mother was recovering from major abdominal surgery, I made a trip to upstate New York to help my parents. The visit went surprisingly well. Within 48 hours, my mother was up and about. In the evenings, my brothers stopped over to drink beer and eat whatever my father and I had cooked up. Things seemed easier with us than they had been in a long time.

headline: Virginia Tech Shootings
text: Two killed in shootings on Virginia Tech campus.

headline: Five Ways to Flip Your Classroom With The New York Times
text: What is a “flipped classroom”?

text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Lens: Darshan by Niko

headline: The President’s Osawatomie Speech
text: A little over a month ago, I wrote a column about the problems with contemporary liberalism’s prescription for what ails the American middle class. My argument, in a nutshell, was that wage stagnation and social immobility are real issues, but that simply soaking the rich in order to invest more money in our existing public institutions (propping up Medicare and Social Security, preserving and expanding government employment, etc.) wouldn’t necessarily do much to increase prosperity and mobility for the next generation of Americans, and might actually have perverse consequences instead.

headline: Former Bon Appétit Editor to Run Digital Food Magazine
text: Barbara Fairchild, who stepped down last year as editor of Bon Appétit, was named editor in chief of Real Eats, a weekly digital magazine about food.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 83
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared Representative Jerrold Nadler’s call for a federal investigation of police conduct at Occupy Wall Street “ridiculous.” “This is not a federal issue,” the mayor said. “There are plenty of investigations going on.” He added, regarding Mr. Nadler, “If he would spend more time getting us homeland security money, maybe he’d make the streets safer.” [Inside Politics]

headline: Pretzel Twists Onstage, Not at the Snack Bar
text: Wonderment comes roughly in four-minute intervals at the New Victory Theater these days.

headline: Rare Ten Commandments Text Added to Dead Sea Scrolls Exhibition
text: Discovery Times Square – the crowd-pleasing exhibition space on West 44th Street that is now the host to “The Dead Sea Scrolls: Life and Faith in Biblical Times”  – announced that it planned to briefly add a new scroll to the show, one of the oldest and best-preserved manuscripts of the Ten Commandments.

headline: Viewpoint: Large Troubled Schools Are Better Off Closed
text: A former deputy chancellor writes: "It’s long past time to agree that failed organizations never reinvent themselves, no matter how much money we throw at them. The rules, roles and relationships that develop in schools over years, sometimes over decades, have historically proven impervious to change."

headline: Lucky Cheng’s, East Village Drag Cabaret, Is Moving Uptown
text: Lucky Cheng’s, the popular East Village cabaret restaurant where drag queens entertain tourists and assorted other partiers, is going uptown. Its owner, Hayne Suthon, said Wednesday that it would move in the next six months to a spot on West 52nd Street.

headline: 2011: The Year in Memes
text: What Internet memes and online fads captivated the Web in 2011?

headline: In Vail, a Burger Gets a Lift
text: IT has always been a challenge to serve good food at ski resorts, where restaurants and cafeterias might be 10,000 feet above sea level. Part of the problem is that much of the food in this snowy environment arrives at the mountaintop, appropriately enough, completely frozen.

headline: Just One Look | Maria Cornejo
text: Becoming one with an urban environment is not something easily achieved through clothes alone, but that’s what Maria Cornejo sought to do with the pieces in her pre-fall collection. The prints –– a photorealistic rendering of the Brooklyn Promenade (abstracted from a picture that Cornejo snapped with her iPhone); a stretched camouflage; a pixilated jacquard that looks equally industrial and luxe––all mimic city landscapes in ways that might let their wearers fit seamlessly into the city’s graphic sprawl. Mix the collection’s stripe-like jacquards, like so, and leave the countryside behind.

headline: Star Turnout for Valentino, Rain or Shine
text: Wednesday night’s torrential rainfall had a few unexpected effects at the party for Valentino Garavani’s new virtual museum at the IAC Building. For one thing, many of the late-arriving guests were torn between watching the streaming videos of the designer’s career highlights along one wall and the streaming deluge of rain on the West Side Highway, seen through the opposite wall of windows.

headline: Matta: ‘A Centennial Celebration’
text: Pace Gallery

headline: From Kenwood House, Borrowed Treasures
text: Kenwood House in North London is known for its extraordinary collection of paintings by Rembrandt, Vermeer, van Dyck and Gainsborough. Its last owner, Edward Cecil Guinness, the first Earl of Iveagh, was a passionate collector who bequeathed Kenwood along with its art to Britain when he died in 1927. A year later the neo-Classical house and gardens opened to the public, and they have been a magnet for tourists ever since, attracting a million visitors a year.

headline: Corin Hewitt: ‘Medium/Deep’
text: Laurel Gitlen

headline: American Letters 1927-1947: Jackson Pollock & Family
text: Jason McCoy Gallery

headline: Paul McCarthy: ‘The Dwarves, the Forests’
text: Hauser & Wirth

headline: What Sets Us, and Keeps Us, Apart
text: What are we all so afraid of? From spiders to rogue asteroids and beyond, but certainly people would be near the top of any list. Of particular concern would be people who are not like us. Speaking in different languages, dressing oddly, believing in strange gods, motivated by shadowy purposes and desires, they threaten everything we hold dear. So we build walls to keep them away. But since they often live among us, we also create internal systems to police them and keep them under surveillance, lest they conspire and act on their alien intentions.

headline: Jean-Frédéric Schnyder
text: Swiss Institute Contemporary Art

headline: The Life of 'Stick Fly'
text: Condola Rashad talks about performing in Lydia R. Diamond's new Broadway play.

headline: Columbia Hires Coach With Ivy and N.F.L. Ties
text: Columbia’s two-week search for a football coach culminated Thursday with the hiring of Pete Mangurian, a former Ivy League head coach who has worked as an assistant with five N.F.L. teams.

headline: The Coming Car Electronics Revolution
text: On Wednesday, Broadcom announced  a series of products that will bring the same kind of communications connectivity seen in home appliances and large data centers to cars.

headline: Despite Losses From Strike, Detroit Symphony Voices Optimism
text: The Detroit Symphony Orchestra detailed the financial effects of last season’s bitter six-month strike on Thursday, citing lost ticket sales and donations, but found optimism in many new audience members and better than expected revenues so far this season. “The signs this fall have been enormously positive,” said Anne Parsons, the president. Another sign was the recent three-year extension given to Leonard Slatkin, the music director, who now will have the title through the 2015-2016 season.

headline: Knicks’ Pursuit of Chandler Could Be Costly
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Amar’e Stoudemire finally arrived at the Knicks’ training site Thursday and walked straight into a firestorm of speculation that would give him the center he has always wanted alongside him, but one who would all but dash the team’s hopes of acquiring Chris Paul.

headline: Wedding Q&A
text: When Cash Is Preferred

headline: Trader Pleads Guilty in 17-Year Investment Scheme
text: A trader implicated in a 17-year scheme pleaded guilty on Thursday to receiving confidential tips about company takeovers from a lawyer who worked at some of the nation’s most prestigious law firms.

headline: The Caucus Click: The Scope of History
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, the Republican presidential candidate, looked down the barrel of a vintage 1928 Thompson submachine gun on Thursday at the Rhett Gallery  in Beaufort, S.C.

headline: CBS Clips Fox and ABC on Wednesday Night
text: For the first time this season, CBS was the No. 1 network in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on a Wednesday night, narrowly surpassing Fox and ABC while also pulling in the highest number of total viewers. The victory was at least partly the result of some key programs on the other networks underperforming. “Modern Family” on ABC had a below-average showing in the 18-to-49 demo and hit a season low in total viewers — 12.1 million. On Fox, a 90-minute episode of “The X Factor” was also down 11 percent in that demo when compared to last week, and that singing show had 10.6 million total viewers.

headline: Clinton Urges Countries Not to Stifle Online Voices
text: THE HAGUE — Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and other international leaders urged countries and private businesses on Thursday to fight increasing efforts to restrict access to the Internet by repressive governments and even some democratic ones.

headline: Of Mice and Coffee
text: S. Amanda Caudill, a doctoral student at the University of Rhode Island, writes from Costa Rica, where she is assessing mammal diversity on coffee farms.

headline: Holiday Shows, in Many Permutations
text: Holiday theater divided into three loosely defined, Dickens-inspired categories: past, present and future.

headline: Holiday Theater, in Three Flavors
text: Instead of making Ebenezer Scrooge watch those instructive scenes from his past, present and future, perhaps the ghosts would have completed their Grinch-eradication mission faster if they’d taken him to a show. They might have come up with a list like this one, which divides some of this year’s notable holiday productions into three loosely defined, Dickens-inspired categories: Past (for nostalgia lovers), Present (for current-events followers) and Future (for tech geeks or more adventurous-minded theatergoers). Tiny Tim may have wished God’s blessings on everyone, but be aware that not all these shows are good for families with children.

headline: Jury in Seabrook Trial Says It Is Still Deadlocked
text: Updated 5:44 p.m. | The jury in the federal corruption trial of City Councilman Larry B. Seabrook indicated on Thursday that it remained unable to reach a verdict on any of the 12 counts against him after more than five days of deliberation, and suggested that jurors should be discharged no later than Friday.

headline: Afghan General Survives Assassination Attempt
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — The bomb under the general’s chair was pretty clearly an inside job.

headline: Theater Listings for Dec. 9 — 15
text: Theater

headline: Pictures of the Day: Congo and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Congo, Pakistan, Syria and Russia.

headline: ‘Magic/Bird’ Gets Its Larry Bird
text: A 6’9’’ leading man who could match the height of basketball great Larry Bird was probably too much to hope for in “Magic/Bird,” the new play whose producers are aiming for Broadway in the spring of 2012. But 6’5’’ will do. The producers, Fran Kirmser and Tony Ponturo, said in an interview Thursday that they have cast actor (and former college basketball player) Tug Coker in the role of Bird, the former Boston Celtic forward whose on-court rivalry and off-court friendship with Magic Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers point guard, are the heart of the play.

headline: Weekend Miser
text: Committing to a love affair with New York is hard work for a Miser. As with any long-term relationship, you have to keep discovering new ways to get to know each other if you want to preserve the thrill. That’s what Avi Millman’s “New York, the Game” is all about: rediscovering the city in a way that’s new and fun. To play, you need $12 and a cellphone.

headline: The Happy Houseplant | Indoor Gardening with Richard Chai
text: What Richard Chai calls his orchid cemetery is a narrow, north-facing window sill in the kitchen area of his Financial District loft. There, five flowerless orchid plants in uniform terracotta pots are getting indirect sunlight and enough water to keep the soil moist most of the time, and that’s it. “Just ignore them,” says Chai, who is literally –– a word he uses quite frequently –– bringing the gentle plants back to life (maybe rehab is a better word for the facility). “I used to obsess about orchids. But if you ignore them, they’re so much happier.”

headline: Two Soldiers, Their Girls, Those Doubts
text: In an essay about Mozart’s “Così Fan Tutte” in his book “On Opera,” the English philosopher Bernard Williams wrote: “Nothing is denied of what has happened; that is what is sad in this comedy, that all that dimension of feeling exists, but the world will rumble on as though it did not.”

headline: Think Big, Build Small: Inventors’ Prototypes
text: American inventors in the 19th century shipped operable miniatures by the hundreds of thousands to the federal government, as models for potential patent approval. Tinkerers in every realm, from piano keyboards to collapsible lifeboats, were required to submit three-dimensional scale prototypes.

headline: Lead From Old U.S. Batteries Sent to Mexico Raises Risks
text: NAUCALPAN DE JUÁREZ, Mexico — The spent batteries Americans turn in for recycling are increasingly being sent to Mexico, where their lead is often extracted by crude methods that are illegal in the United States, exposing plant workers and local residents to dangerous levels of a toxic metal.

headline: A Brooklyn Store Offers Astounding Variety, With Patter
text: NOT all of Brooklyn glows with gentrification. Deep in the borough’s southwest pocket is Bath Beach, a few dozen blocks sandwiched between Bensonhurst and the Belt Parkway. Shuttered storefronts and signs in competing languages testify to economic hardship and ethnic flux. But amid the comings and goings is a monument to fortitude: Nick’s Discount Store.

text: Mexico’s booming business in recycling car batteries leads to growing cases of lead poisoning.

headline: Japanese Star Pitcher Available, for a Price
text: DALLAS — A little after 1 a.m. Eastern time Thursday, the market for available pitchers was restocked with perhaps the best talent available. The Japanese star right-hander Yu Darvish will be posted by his team, the Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters, according to a Twitter message from Don Nomura, one of Darvish’s agents.

headline: Romney Campaign Looks to Draw ‘Contrasts’ With Gingrich
text: And so it begins.

headline: Homage to a Picture-Book Rebel
text: IN 1962 Ezra Jack Keats started a quiet revolution that in its own way had as much influence as some of the decade’s louder protests. An author and illustrator, Keats published “The Snowy Day,” about a small boy’s delight in his first snowstorm. Nothing radical there. But the story differed profoundly from virtually all the mainstream American picture books preceding it: Peter, the little boy, was black.

headline: A New Look for Senator Coburn
text: There is a great deal occurring in Congress right now, but let us stop for a moment to ponder Senator Tom Coburn’s beard. For weeks now, the usually baby-faced Republican from Oklahoma has been strolling about the Capitol with a new look, his push-broom head of hair complemented by a slightly scruffy goatee.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Say Nice Things
text: With the holiday shopping season in full swing, credit-card numbers and other personal bits of information are flying around the Web in a flurry. But while some shoppers may be nervous about identity theft, the problem goes far beyond just getting your credit-card number stolen, as Daniel Mohan explains. Mr. Mohan, the president and chief operating officer of ID Watchdog, describes what else thieves are after and how his company’s identity-monitoring service works. He also offers some tips for staying safer online.

headline: Derring-Don’t
text: It looks like the tightrope walker Nik Wallenda won’t able to cheat death at Niagara Falls, at least not the way he originally proposed — on 1,800 feet of cable between the American and Canadian sides. On Wednesday, Canada said no. Its Niagara Parks Commission rejected Mr. Wallenda’s request, in keeping with its 100-year history of rejecting daredevil acts at the falls.

headline: Demand for ‘Estate’-Like Condos
text: REAL ESTATE optimists have been picking up blips on the radar in Bergen County lately, most recently this one: 24 of 68 “attached manor” condominiums with prices starting at $1.25 million sold in a single weekend — before they went up, and before a sales office had time to open.

headline: Potently Moving Music and Imagery to Match
text: In any successful opera performance, all the various parts of the presentation — music, text, singing, playing and staging — add up to more than the sum of the parts. The stage being by its nature a precarious and dangerous place, true parity among all those elements is a rare and difficult achievement. But a successful evening can still result when, on balance, the stronger aspects of a performance rise to compensate for the weaker ones.

headline: Slavery Is Freedom, And All That
text: One of my many radicalizing moments during the Bush years came when a number of the usual suspects began attacking John Kerry because he was, wait for it, too rich. Even with all the cynicism I’d developed over the previous four years, the idea that Republican operatives would invoke class envy for political advantage — and that voters would fall for it — caught me off guard.

headline: The Minimalist: Chicken Cutlets Meunière
text: The most famous meunière preparation is probably sole — it’s a slam dunk for pretty much any thin, delicate, white fish fillet. But it’s also one of the best ways to treat chicken cutlets. The recipe, which I wrote about in an early Minimalist column, is infinitely variable, but here I’ve done it about as simply as possible. Dredge the chicken in flour, cook it in a skillet with oil or butter until nicely browned and just cooked through — as long as you get really nice browning on one of the sides, you’re fine — and finish with lemon juice and chopped parsley. The brown butter is luxurious and totally optional.

headline: Eavesdropping on Sondheim
text: “But then I met James Lapine.” Thus ends, on a cliffhanger worthy of an artist who cherishes a passion for mystery tales, the first volume of Stephen Sondheim’s collected lyrics, published last fall and already well thumbed and argued over by this composer-lyricist’s legion of passionate admirers, second only to Wagnerians in their obsessive dedication.

headline: Israeli Strikes Kill Two Palestinians in Gaza
text: JERUSALEM — In an airstrike in central Gaza City, the Israeli military on Thursday killed two Palestinians whom it described as terrorists involved in a plot to attack Israelis.

King Jr., and the Board of Regents chancellor, Merryl H. Tisch -- hope it will help mollify some of the opposition the bill is bound to face.

headline: Better With Words
text: My husband’s elderly parents and brother live in England. We exchange gifts for Christmas and birthdays. Recently his mother said the logistics were becoming difficult for her. My husband suggested we stop, and she agreed. Then he e-mailed the same suggestion to his brother, who sent a blistering reply. My husband apologized by e-mail and suggested we go back to the status quo. But he’s still hurt by his brother’s angry message. How can we resolve this?

headline: In Protest, Islamists Quit Egypt Council
text: CAIRO — The Muslim Brotherhood, the Islamist group whose political party is leading in parliamentary elections here, on Thursday accused Egypt’s interim military rulers of attempting to undermine the legislature’s authority and interfering in the writing of a new constitution.

headline: N.J. Pension Fund Commits Up to $1.8 Billion to Blackstone
text: New Jersey’s pension fund has committed up to $1.8 billion to funds managed by the Blackstone Group, a big win for the money-management giant and the latest signal that the fund-raising climate, at least for the largest private equity firms, is on the upswing.

headline: A Griot for a Global Village
text: Across the country institutions large and small, art-specific and otherwise, are celebrating the Romare Bearden centennial year. There’s a reason for this. In Bearden’s embracing art all borders are down — between personal and universal, town and country, history and myth. Africa, Europe and the Americas too are borderless. Bearden is artist in chief of the modern cosmopolis, griot in residence of the global village. All hail.

text: Whether you cherish the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center’s presentations of Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos during its annual Baroque Festival as a developing holiday tradition or dismiss them as an easy out, you know pretty much what to expect (this year on Dec. 18 and 20).

headline: A Varied Dreamscape That’s Also a Farewell
text: In a famous letter from 1871 about the poet as visionary, the 17-year-old Arthur Rimbaud wrote of “le dérèglement des sens”: “the derangement of the senses,” which he argued should be “long, immense and deliberate.” In the performing arts of our time, there has been no better exemplification of this principle than the dance theater of Merce Cunningham.

headline: Number of Bicyclists Keeps Climbing, City Says

headline: Suffocated by Motherhood, and a Child Whose Hold Still Lingers
text: “Every parent’s nightmare” would be the evening news boilerplate description of “We Need to Talk About Kevin,” Lynne Ramsay’s disturbing movie about the mother of a child who goes on a killing spree at his high school. That trite phrase is accurate in an almost technical sense: Ms. Ramsay (who adapted Lionel Shriver’s novel with Rory Stewart Kinnear) follows a kind of dream logic in telling a chronologically splintered story, weaving patterns of associated images and sensations into an intense and claustrophobic web of fear.

headline: Sharing the Regrets, and the Sex and Drugs
text: “I Melt With You” may set a record for the movie in which the most drugs are consumed and the most tears shed by grown men. That is a dubious distinction for any film but especially for one whose unofficial theme song is the Sex Pistols’ “Pretty Vacant,” which is not exactly a tearjerker.

headline: 2 Dead of Gunshots as Violence Revisits Virginia Tech

text: DARIEN’S attitudes toward affordable housing are once again under scrutiny, this time in a federal civil rights action accusing the town’s planning and zoning commission, and its chairman, Frederick B. Conze, of trying to keep out black residents.

headline: Knicks Close to Adding Chandler to an Already Strong Frontcourt
text: Tyson Chandler, whose defense and grit helped deliver a championship in Dallas, is close to joining the Knicks, two people involved in the talks said Thursday. The deal faces some hurdles, however.

headline: The Spy Who Emerged From the Fog
text: Dread throbs like a heartbeat in “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy,” a superb new adaptation of the 1974 spy novel by John le Carré. It’s a deep pulse that maintains its insistent rhythm throughout the film’s murmured conversations, life-and-death office intrigues, violence and yearning loves. The throbbing does a number on your nervous system — this is a movie you watch on high alert — and brings you into the state of mind that can feel like a state of siege and goes by the name of British secret service, or just the Circus. For those inside the intelligence service, like George Smiley, played with delicacy and understated power by Gary Oldman, knowledge is power, but so too is fear.

headline: Rolling Stones Members to Pay for Bluesman’s Funeral
text: Mick Jagger and Keith Richards have offered to pay for the funeral of Hubert Sumlin, a great Chicago blues guitarist to whom they owe a musical debt, a spokeswoman for the Rolling Stones, Fran Curtis, confirmed.   Mr. Sumlin died on Dec. 4.  He was 80.  He was the longtime guitarist for Howlin’ Wolf and inspired a generation of rock and blues players with his emotional solos, among them Mr. Richards.

headline: Shipping Batteries to Mexico
text: Many companies now legally export batteries for recycling to plants in Mexico, where they face less stringent regulation. These export plans were submitted to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency in 2010, but many batteries also cross the border illegally and go unrecorded.

headline: Fine, Former Syracuse Assistant, Is Sued by an Accuser

headline: Libya Will Allow British Police to Visit for Lockerbie Inquiry, Briton Says

headline: Cereal? Cookies? Oh, What’s the Diff?
text: We all know the importance of real food in the morning: kids who eat high-sugar breakfasts have a harder time in school, and a growing body of research suggests that foods sweetened with sugar or high-fructose corn syrup can be as addictive as nicotine or cocaine. It’s clear, too, that for most of us the eating patterns we develop as children hang around forever.

headline: Unlikely Hero in an Underground Hideout, Away From the Nazis
text: Agnieszka Holland’s “In Darkness,” inspired by the real exploits of a Polish sewer worker and sometime burglar named Leopold Socha, who helped Jews during the Nazi occupation of Lvov (now Lviv, in Ukraine), provides the latest evidence that the Holocaust movie has become a genre in its own right. Even a true story can follow the familiar conventions of film narrative, and this tale of a righteous gentile selflessly assisting in the survival of a handful of persecuted Jews is no exception.

headline: What Blagojevich’s Sentence Says About Corruption and Greed
text: Even as Rod Blagojevich said he was “unbelievably sorry” on Wednesday, one wondered whether he was, unbelievably, sorry — and if a central premise of his 14-year-sentence was as naïve as this glad-handing felon.

headline: A Nod to Willing Flesh Entangled in Dispiriting Words
text: LONDON — The existence of the Bad Sex in Fiction award immediately raises the question, Why not a Good Sex in Fiction award?

headline: No Upgrades Elsewhere, So Yankees Draft Relievers
text: DALLAS — A league rival added perhaps the most threatening hitter in baseball, so Yankees General manager Brian Cashman was asked Thursday if he would react to it. The Los Angeles Angels now have Albert Pujols, but would that make Cashman redouble his efforts to add pitching?

headline: A Twitter for My Sister
text: In the early days of Twitter the company’s founders repeatedly said that expanding the service was like building a rocket ship in mid-flight. Twitter grew so quickly that it was almost impossible to add new features because engineers spent their time trying to keep the rocket ship from stalling — which often happened anyway.

headline: Holder, Grilled on Gun Inquiry, Says He Won’t Resign
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans pummeled Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. on Thursday over the disputed gun-trafficking investigation called Operation Fast and Furious, accusing the Justice Department of hiding the truth and lying to Congress in a slugfest of an oversight hearing.

headline: Pujols Leaves Behind Fractured Legacy in St. Louis
