headline: Mr. Putin Seeks a Scapegoat
text: Twenty years after the fall of communism, Prime Minister Vladimir Putin of Russia seems determined to resurrect the Soviet playbook. His United Russia Party tried to steal a parliamentary election on Sunday, and, when the results still delivered a stinging rebuke, he claimed the United States was whipping up protests and demonstrations.

headline: Proposition 8 Appeals Case Winds Down
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The legal battle over California’s voter-approved ban on same-sex marriage came one step closer to resolution on Thursday as lawyers argued before a federal appeals panel over whether a federal judge’s decision to strike down the ban should be vacated because the judge is gay.

headline: Goodbye to ‘Gays, Guns & God’
text: How do you praise the sanctity of traditional heterosexual marriage when the best-known nuptials of the year, between a Kardashian and a basketball player, lasted all of 72 days? Or, for that matter, when a possible Republican nominee for president, Newt Gingrich, cares so much about marriage that he’s tried it three times?

headline: Judge Allows  Dodgers’ Plan for TV Rights
text: A federal bankruptcy judge ruled Thursday that the Los Angeles Dodgers can accelerate the sale of their future television rights over the objections of Fox Sports, whose Prime Ticket channel has a contract to carry the team’s games through 2013.

headline: Jerry Robinson, Godfather of a Comic-Book Villain, Dies at 89
text: Jerry Robinson, a prolific comic-book artist, comics historian and editorial cartoonist who is credited with having created the Joker, the archenemy of Batman with devilish eyes and ghoulish smile, died on Wednesday at a hospice on Staten Island. He was 89 and lived in Manhattan.

headline: Brawling for Money, Clan and Just Because
text: The fighting families in the documentary “Knuckle” are blood relatives with a vengeance. The movie, a no-frills affair from the first-time Irish director Ian Palmer, offers a circumscribed look inside the often-closed world of Irish travelers through their bare-knuckle fistfights. Historically nomads who were once better known as tinkers and described by Yeats as “the people of the roads,” the travelers long lived outside the mainstream, but from their on-camera showboating — as they duke it out, crow about their wins, taunt the losers and bang the drums for the next slugfest — they’re ready for their collective close-up.

headline: A Wartime Leader Ends a War He Never Wanted
text: WASHINGTON — In October 2002, a little-known Illinois state senator joined a rally in Chicago against the Iraq war, declaring: “I’m not opposed to all wars. I’m opposed to dumb wars.” It was a defining moment for the young politician, who used this position to set himself apart in the race for the White House in 2008.

headline: Americans Got Much Poorer Last Quarter
text: Americans got much poorer last quarter, as their collective household net worth suffered the biggest decline in three years.

headline: Deep Roots of Fraud at Olympus
text: Blame it on James A. Baker III. The “Plaza Accord” that halted the appreciation of the United States dollar in 1985 was largely his doing, as Ronald Reagan’s Treasury secretary. It set in motion a series of events that led to a huge fraud at the Olympus Corporation, the Japanese maker of cameras and medical imaging equipment, that lasted more than two decades.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,833 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Joseph E. Robert Jr., Investor in Real Estate, Dies at 59
text: Joseph E. Robert Jr., an international real estate investor with a talent for turning troubled properties into profits — including billions of dollars’ worth of assets from the collapse of the savings and loan industry in the 1980s — died on Wednesday at his home in McLean, Va. He was 59.

headline: Race to the Bottom
text: Campaign ads are often deceitful, offensive or infuriating, cynically exploiting religion or families and distorting an opponent’s record. The latest ones from the Republican primary, however, are so brazen and the politicians so unapologetic that it is only bound to get worse.

headline: Prince of the Universe, and His Maid
text: In “My Piece of the Pie,” Gilles Lellouche, a handsome, rough-around-the-edges French star who could be the next generation’s Gérard Depardieu, nails the essence of a predatory capitalist shark. Having spent 10 years in London, his swaggering character, Stéphane (in England he’s called Steve), is dispatched to Paris to start a hedge fund. Before he leaves, his Mephistophelean mentor counsels, “Business is not a sport for gentlemen; it’s not for good people.” To which Stéphane assures him, “I’m bad!” And he is.

headline: The Real Way to Help Small Business
text: With only a week to go before Congress adjourns for the holidays, Congress has yet to renew federal unemployment benefits or the payroll tax cut that will expire at year-end. Unfortunately, Republican leaders seem far more interested in advancing their partisan aims than helping millions of struggling American families.

headline: You Mean Those People Who Put Me Here?
text: New York’s legislators began arriving in Albany on Tuesday morning, and, by late Wednesday night, the Legislature had voted to revamp the entire state income tax code. The Senate voted less than half an hour after Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s 19,000 word bill was made public. As for the voters and taxpayers? They were out of the loop.

headline: N.B.A. Owners and Players Ratify Labor Deal
text: Officially calling an end to a costly and contentious five-month-long lockout, Commissioner David Stern said Thursday that the 30 N.B.A. owners had ratified a new collective bargaining agreement that was approved simultaneously by the players.

headline: Anthony Says Chandler ‘Would Fit in Very Well’
text: Carmelo Anthony spent his last official basketball-free night hosting a premiere of “Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked” at a Manhattan theater.

headline: N.B.A. Rejects Trade Sending Paul to Lakers
text: An epic trade that would have made Chris Paul and Kobe Bryant teammates in Los Angeles was vetoed Thursday night by N.B.A. Commissioner David Stern in a decision that rocked the league just as it emerged from a five-month lockout.

headline: In Tough Times, a Boom in Cremations as a Way to Save Money
text: As Toni Kelly battled lymphoma, first with a bone marrow transplant and then with brutal rounds of chemotherapy, she worried obsessively that her four-year struggle would destroy her family’s finances.

headline: U.S. Finds No Link Between Vieques Bombings and Health Risks
text: A federal agency announced Thursday that it had found no evidence that decades of live fire and bombing exercises by the Navy on the Puerto Rican island of Vieques had caused health problems documented among its residents.

headline: Keeping the Water Flowing in Rural Villages
text: Keeping projects in business for the long term has been a constant theme of the Fixes column, and if sustainability has a poster child, it would be a water pump.   Travel anywhere in Africa or South Asia or Central America, and you will find a landscape dotted with the rusting skeletons of dead water pumps or wells..

headline: Don’t Bother Checking In With This Baby Sitter
text: Noah, the nobody’s fool played by Jonah Hill in the breezily indifferent comedy “The Sitter,” is a character in search of a movie, a setup in search of a punch line. Less directed than doodled by David Gordon Green, this on-and-off funny rehash of “Adventures in Babysitting” centers on a college dropout who, at his mother’s urging, reluctantly agrees to mind three children for pay. Somewhat of a big baby himself, Noah sets off with a pout, apparently unaware that most American excursions in comedy these days come with mandatory opportunities for growth.

headline: Marketers, and Media Companies, Set Their Sights on Latin Women
text: WITH the Census Bureau counting nearly 25 million Latin women in the United States, marketers and media companies have started getting excited about the potential to reach them.

headline: The Gingrich Tragedy
text: Of all the major Republicans, the one who comes closest to my worldview is Newt Gingrich. Despite his erratically shifting views and odd phases, he continually returns to this core political refrain: He talks about using government in energetic but limited ways to increase growth, dynamism and social mobility.

headline: Auto Club and Port Authority Fight in Court Over Rise in Toll
text: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey raised bridge and tunnel tolls in September, officials said the increased revenue was necessary to ensure the financial health of the infrastructure the authority controls, including the World Trade Center project.

headline: Leader in the Cancer Fight, and Son of an Illegal Immigrant
text: A few minutes before Ronald DePinho was to give a speech to his graduating class at Fordham College in the Bronx, he sat with his father in a student lounge. It was May 1977. His father had been in the United States for nearly 40 years. The son was on his way to a career in medicine and research that would bring him to the presidency of the biggest cancer center in the country. It was a time for the father, Alvaro DePinho, to pass along some history.

headline: Obama Endorses Decision to Limit Morning-After Pill
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, who took office pledging to put science ahead of politics, averted a skirmish with conservatives in the nation’s culture wars on Thursday by endorsing his health secretary’s decision to block over-the-counter sales of an after-sex contraceptive pill to girls under age 17.

headline: Factional Splits Hinder Drive to Topple Syria Leader
text: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Even as the government of President Bashar al-Assad intensifies its crackdown inside Syria, differences over tactics and strategy are generating serious divisions between political and armed opposition factions that are weakening the fight against him, senior activists say.

headline: All the G.O.P.’s Gekkos
text: Almost a quarter of a century has passed since the release of the movie “Wall Street,” and the film seems more relevant than ever. The self-righteous screeds of financial tycoons denouncing President Obama all read like variations on Gordon Gekko’s famous “greed is good” speech, while the complaints of Occupy Wall Street sound just like what Gekko says in private: “I create nothing. I own,” he declares at one point; at another, he asks his protégé, “Now you’re not naïve enough to think we’re living in a democracy, are you, buddy?”

headline: Texas Instruments Forecasts Lower Sales for 4th Quarter
text: Texas Instruments, the chip maker, gave a fourth-quarter sales forecast on Thursday that fell short of analysts’ estimates, citing weaker demand for electronics components.

headline: Chiefs Get a Left-Handed Compliment
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Rex Ryan was asked Thursday what he thought about Tyler Palko, who is the Kansas City Chiefs’ starting quarterback more or less by default. Ryan, whose Jets face Palko on Sunday, carefully considered the question.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Perry’s Anti-Gay Rights Focus Is Divisive Even to Staff
text: OKATIE, S.C. — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas’ hard turn the past two days on gay issues, in which he has suggested that gay rights are inconsistent with both American and Christian values, has generated enormous criticism from lesbian and gay organizations and some religious groups, and has even helped split Mr. Perry’s top campaign aides over a new ad.

headline: For Latin America, a Zone of its Own
Girls Just Wanna Shoot Up a Diner
text: Three bad gals and assorted bad guys spread a lot of gunfire around in “Catch .44,” a drug-deal tale featuring top-drawer actors trying to have fun with a medium-strength script. Sometimes they succeed, but not often enough to elevate the film to “Pulp Fiction” territory.

headline: And Now She’s Got a Fantastically Mean Spike
text: Recent offerings from the distributor China Lion, which specializes in mainstream Chinese movies — “Beginning of the Great Revival,” “The Butcher, the Chef and the Swordsman” — have tended to be blustery, leaden or galumphing affairs. Its latest bid to beat Hollywood at its own game, the fantasy “Magic to Win,” has, for all its derivative special effects and conceits, an agreeable light-footedness (a clue to its Hong Kong, not mainland, provenance). Its buoyancy may not redeem its predictability, but it makes the movie bearable and even enjoyable at times.

headline: Tributes to Romare Bearden
text: The artist’s work is on display in exhibitions at the Studio Museum, the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: E.P.A. Links Tainted Water in Wyoming to Hydraulic Fracturing for Natural Gas
text: DENVER — Chemicals used to hydraulically fracture rocks in drilling for natural gas in a remote valley in central Wyoming are the likely cause of contaminated local water supplies, federal regulators said Thursday.

headline: Manning Keeps Calm as Injuries Multiply
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Shortly before the Giants took the field against the Green Bay Packers last Sunday, players began to murmur that two of their offensive linemen would not be available. Eli Manning took it as an occasion for some gallows humor.

headline: Friday: Removed From the Can
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Ahh, wide open spaces. Where the pencils are sharp, the long entries are fresh, and the deer and the buffalo roam. Where a person can stretch out without hitting all sorts of black squares and actually get some thinking done.

headline: To Fix Health, Help the Poor
text: New Haven

headline: So Many Secrets, Soon to See the Light
text: The daytime soaps are being bug-zapped from the networks one by one, disappearing into oblivion after decades of reliably dishing out startling coincidences and staggering secrets. Where to go for a sustaining dose of torrid, troubled romances and the occasional heated catfight?

headline: Unspooling Memories From the Soul on a Machine
text: A command of the speaking power of silence is almost a prerequisite for performing the plays of Samuel Beckett. This is particularly true of his sparer works, in which the Irish-born playwright reduced his theatrical means to a minimum, the better to concentrate his ideas and underscore the echoing emptiness that is forever threatening to swallow his characters whole.

headline: Home for the Holidays, Oh Joy
text: “Fanny, Annie & Danny” may be an unpleasant story about unpleasant characters, but the acting is fabulous. Under Chris Brown’s direction, an ensemble cast of unknowns works the reunited-for-Christmas-dinner theme beautifully, which is to say, repugnantly.

headline: More Detail on Risk Urged for a Contraceptive Label
text: Labels on the popular birth control pills Yaz and Yasmin should be strengthened to include more information about the possibility that the pills could lead to greater risk of blood clots in women, an advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration said on Thursday.

headline: A Trade Edge in China
text: China has a large trade surplus of goods with the rest of the world but is running a growing trade deficit in the service sector.

headline: Long Island Gets Big Grant in Cuomo’s Competition
text: Long Island and three struggling upstate regions were the big winners Thursday in a competition for $785 million in one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s signature development initiatives.

headline: Air Force Apologizes for Disposal of Remains
text: WASHINGTON — The Air Force expressed regrets Thursday for any grief to surviving family members caused by a previous mortuary practice in which incinerated partial remains of service members were deposited in a landfill.

headline: Only the Brain-Dead Know Brooklyn
text: “I just got laid off from work, and I’m sleepin’ with my niece,” the hot and aggressively unpleasant hero of “Red Hook Black” announces midway through this awkward drama, helpfully summarizing its plot. His name is Marco (Kyle Fields), he was once a longshoreman and he has exactly two moods — angry and sullen — both of which look the same though one requires a louder voice.

headline: 12 With Low State Test Scores Are Put on School Closing List
text: In the first part of a two-step effort at weeding out some of the poorest-performing schools, the Education Department announced on Thursday that it would move to close 12 of New York City’s struggling schools and eliminate middle school grades at three others.

headline: Paperback Row
text: SUNSET PARK,  by Paul Auster (Picador, $15.) Unfolding after the economic collapse, Auster’s novel concerns Miles Heller, a college dropout “trashing out” foreclosed houses in Florida. His underage girlfriend, Pilar, is mature beyond her years, but the discovery of their relationship forces Miles to flee to New York, where he hides out among a group of young artists and intellectuals squatting in an abandoned house.

headline: Anarchist Anthropology
text: The anthropologist David Graeber has a strong claim to being the house theorist of Occupy Wall Street. A veteran of the antiglobalization uprisings in Seattle and Genoa, he helped orchestrate the first “General Assembly” in New York this summer, and has since become one of the movement’s most outspoken defenders. For him, the encampments in cities across the country prefigure the kind of anti-hierarchical, stateless society that ought to be our future. In a recent opinion article in The Guardian of London, Graeber proclaimed OWS “the opening salvo in a wave of negotiations over the dissolution of the American Empire.” For a movement that has attracted an array of political sympathies, his voice reminds us that at its organizational core, Occupy Wall Street cleaves to anarchist principles.

headline: David Montgomery, 84, Dies; Chronicled Lives of Workers
text: David Montgomery, a labor historian whose experience as a machinist informed his influential writing about the culture of the factory floor, died last Friday in Philadelphia. He was 84.

headline: A Struggling Actor Strays, and Pays
text: There’s no business as disliked as show business in “Seducing Charlie Barker,” an intermittently interesting but fatally clichéd comedy of personal and professional suicide.

headline: China’s 10-Year Ascent to Trading Powerhouse
text: HONG KONG — As China heads into a weekend of speeches celebrating its 10 years as an official member of the global trade community, the rest of the world may want to contemplate the exported $49 microwave oven and the imported $85,000 Jeep Grand Cherokee.

headline: Anchor Baby: A Term Redefined as a Slur
text: What does the term “anchor baby” mean? If you were to look it up in the American Heritage Dictionary, you would find a new definition since last week.

headline: Renovation Complete, City Council Goes Home
text: The gilded moldings and the polished mahogany gleamed. The 1903 ceiling murals, depicting civic virtues, were newly free of decades’ worth of grime. The walls, previously a yellowish cream, were now turquoise, to complement the murals and the woodwork.

headline: Honduras: Killings Prompt a Ban on Motorcycles Carrying Passengers
text: After two high-profile killings this week, legislators approved a decree late Wednesday banning motorcyclists from riding with passengers. Alfredo Landaverde, a former antidrug and security adviser to the government, was killed in the capital, Tegucigalpa, on Wednesday. On Tuesday, a radio journalist, Luz Marina Paz Villalobos, and her driver were killed. The suspects in both cases were passengers on motorcycles, who got away. The killings come amid a widening scandal of accusations of police involvement in killings and drug trafficking. Mr. Landaverde was an outspoken critic of police and political corruption.

headline: Hotel Video in Strauss-Kahn Case Resolves Little
text: The surveillance images show Dominique Strauss-Kahn striding from an elevator at the Sofitel New York, standing at the front desk and crossing through the lobby to jump into a taxi.

headline: A Quest for a Better Life, Interrupted by Sudden Grief
text: Janet Brown is an expert at stealing naps. The driver’s seat of her minivan often doubles as a mattress, allowing her to sleep briefly during breaks in her duties as a single mother, a full-time student, a chiropractic intern and a counselor. She sleeps two to three hours each night.

headline: Tax Plan Passed, Legislature Faces Smaller Budget Gap
text: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and lawmakers declared the income tax overhaul that was approved early Thursday to be a victory for millions of New Yorkers, many of whom will enjoy a modest tax cut next year.

headline: In a Loss, a Ranger’s Gesture Leads to a Fight
text: Sniper is a common term for goal scorer, so in that respect perhaps Artem Anisimov’s response was fitting after he put the Rangers ahead with a second-period goal: He pointed his stick at the Tampa Bay net and pretended to fire.

headline: A Coach Trades Up by Going to a Midmajor
text: Perhaps only in the nonrevenue-producing universe of collegiate men’s soccer would Creighton University, a small Jesuit college in Nebraska, be considered a more desirable destination than the University of North Carolina.

headline: City Plans Staff Audit With Eye Toward P.R.
text: Called the “leaker in chief” for his aggressive approach to spinning reporters when he was the White House chief of staff, Mayor Rahm Emanuel is a voracious and careful reader of the news. He has even remarked on the tweeting habits of the City Hall press corps.

headline: The Prayerful Young Man Can Also Nail a Jumper
text: A bevy of college scouts and curious fans flocked to the University of Illinois at Chicago Pavilion on Saturday for Jabari Parker’s first game of the season.

headline: Low Marks for a Medical Training Institute, and the State Lags in Oversight
text: Rebecca Solomon struggled during her brief internship at a women’s clinic in Salinas.

headline: Single Brand Retail May Get Green Light
text: Wal-Mart might have to wait to enter the Indian retail market – perhaps for years – but Ikea, the furniture and furnishing retail chain, might soon be selling its trademark Billy bookcases here.

headline: Inflation Cooling Off in China
text: HONG KONG — Inflation and industrial activity in China cooled markedly in November, according to data released Friday — an important development that raises the likelihood that the authorities in Beijing will seek to inject more momentum into an economy that has become a key engine of global growth.

headline: Word of the Day | surreptitious
text: surreptitious •\ˌsər-əp-ˈti-shəs, ˌsə-rəp-, sə-ˌrep-\• adjective

headline: An Unexpected Debut
text: Boyd Lee Dunlop found his musical talent during the Great Depression. But after years of playing in bars and nightclubs, it took a damaged piano in a Buffalo nursing home for him to be discovered.

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/09/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/09/2011

headline: Rhythms Flow as Aging Pianist Finds New Audience
text: BUFFALO

headline: City Crackdown Looming as the Dog Population Rises
text: Call it a sign of the times: At food establishments around San Francisco, fliers are popping up with the words “No Animals Allowed” in bold red letters, and an image of a dog in a circle with a line through it. They are stamped with the official city and county seal.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Watch: Nicole Scherzinger Casts the Nondeciding Vote
text: If you’re ever the defendant in a bench trial, pray that Nicole Scherzinger is the judge weighing your fate. Turns out she can’t make a decision. You’ll get a mistrial for sure.

headline: A Behind-the-Scenes Dispute, This Time at the Oscar Factory
text: All season long – all two weeks of it, for us – the Bagger has been wondering if Occupy Wall Street would crop up in our Oscars coverage. After all, the Occupy movement has touched on everything from the foreclosure crisis to cultural institutions to Halloween. Why couldn’t there be an Occupy Red Carpets?

headline: Live Hip-Hop Music, an Airport Amenity That Can Lure Even Non-Travelers
text: Mark Braun had just landed at San Francisco International Airport after a business trip to Florida. But rather than heading directly back to his home in Burlingame, he found himself lingering. “Normally I’m ready to get out of here,” he said, standing next to his roller bag.

headline: Start-Ups Mixing Food and Technology Vie for an Edge
text: Rajat Suri was excelling at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology when he dropped out and became a waiter — not the typical direct path to fame and fortune in the technology industry.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 9, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Illegal Border Crossings Dip Sharply
text: Campaign rhetoric to the contrary, statistics show that the number of illegal immigrants crossing the border is less of a problem now than it has been for four decades.

headline: Forget Pujols, Cashman Praises Montero
text: DALLAS – For two days, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman has been conducting a one-man promotional campaign for Jesus Montero, his precocious 22-year-old catcher. On Wednesday, Cashman compared the development of Montero’s catching skills to those of Jorge Posada when he was breaking in back in the 1990s, and on Thursday, Cashman compared Montero to the best hitter in the game.

headline: Corrections: December 9
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Questions Surround Unregulated Institutions
text: HURST — Sitting in his new office — the sparsely decorated basement of an unassuming 9,000-square-foot building just outside Fort Worth — Christopher Cone cut to the chase during a discussion of academic accreditation.

headline: Hey, You Look Familiar. Didn’t You Run for Office Before? Didn’t You Lose?
text: Maybe the voters didn’t mean it. Could be they have reconsidered. It may have been a mistake, or a bunch of them got busy and never made it to the polls. Perhaps they were just as surprised the morning after the elections as the losers were, and maybe now the voters want their former incumbents back.

headline: German Vision Prevails as Leaders Agree on Fiscal Pact
text: BRUSSELS — Europe’s worst financial crisis in generations is forging a new European Union, pushing Britain to the sidelines and creating a more integrated, fiscally disciplined core of nations under the auspices of a resurgent Germany.

headline: The New Evangelicals
text: Though public support for both major political parties is very low, one group of voters is usually exempted from this malaise: evangelicals. It’s assumed that at least these “values voters” are getting what they want. But we should look more carefully.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Anisimov Apologizes for Gesture
text: Like Arron Asham two months earlier, Artem Anisimov momentarily lost his way in the middle of an intense hockey game. After knocking down Washington’s Jay Beagle in a fight on Oct. 14, Asham gestured like he had put Beagle to sleep. After scoring a goal in the second period Thursday to give the Rangers a 2-1 lead, the usually reserved Anisimov pretended to fire his stick toward the Tampa Bay net.

headline: Latest Plan for Europe Fails to Wow Investors
text: Financial markets on Friday welcomed Europe’s grand new plan to bring budgetary discipline to its members but investors were skeptical that it offered any long-term fix.

headline: Video Revives Mystery of Missing Former F.B.I. Agent
text: The mystery surrounding the disappearance nearly five years ago of a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent in Iran was rekindled Friday with the release of a hostage videotape showing him alive as of a year ago.

headline: Virender Sehwag Hits for Six Off the Pitch Too
text: For 14 years Virender Sehwag has set cold fear into the hearts of bowling attacks all over the world, culminating in Thursday’s brutal yet beautiful innings of 219 against the West Indies in Indore.

headline: Dec. 9, 1992 | Charles and Diana Announce Royal Separation
text: On Dec. 9, 1992, Britain’s Prince Charles and Princess Diana released a statement announcing their separation after 11 years of marriage. The news was made public by Prime Minister John Major, who read the statement in nationally televised address before the British House of Commons.

headline: Toyota Cuts Profit Forecast by 54%
text: TOKYO — Toyota Motor cut its annual profit forecast by half Friday after destructive floods in Thailand, a crucial manufacturing hub, hurt production in a year already marred by natural and nuclear disasters in Japan.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 9, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the Op-Ed column “How Garbo Learned to Stand on Her Head,” by Maureen Dowd.

headline: 94 People Die as Private Hospital in India Burns
text: NEW DELHI — To all appearances, the Advanced Medical Research Institute hospital in Kolkata was state of the art. It had some of the latest, most precise radiation therapy equipment for patients in its cancer center. It offered special deluxe suites for its wealthiest patients. Its trauma surgery unit was said to be one of the best in eastern India, as well as its highly efficient emergency room.

headline: A Plea for Robert Levinson
text: The former F.B.I. agent disappeared in March 2007 while on a trip to a Persian Gulf resort.

headline: U.N. Peacekeepers Wounded in Southern Lebanon Attack
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A bomb exploded near a United Nations convoy helping patrol southern Lebanon on Friday, wounding five peacekeepers in the third attack on the contingent this year, a United Nations spokesman and security officials said.

headline: Kolkata Hospital Fire Kills Dozens
text: A vast inferno ripped through a Kolkata hospital, killing scores of patients who were trapped inside the smoke-filled building as rescue workers struggled to tame the blaze. The fire, which took place at a 161-bed private hospital, broke out in the basement, according to rescue officials, and sent huge plumes of smoke throughout the building. More than 70 people died in the blaze, many due to smoke inhalation, according to television news reports from the scene.

headline: Moody’s Downgrades Top French Banks
text: PARIS — In another sign of how Europe’s debt crisis is rippling through the banking system, Moody’s Investors Service on Friday downgraded the three largest banks in France, saying there was a “very high” probability that the French government would step in to support them if conditions worsened.

headline: Central Park Soundtrack
text: WHO are Bluebrain?

headline: Should the Morning-After Pill Be Sold Over the Counter to People Under 17?
text: The United States secretary of health publicly overruled the Food and Drug Administration this week, refusing to allow emergency contraception known as the “morning-after pill” to be sold without a prescription to people under 17. (If taken soon after unprotected sex, the pill halves the chances of a pregnancy.)

headline: The Beauty and Chaos of the Gods
text: “Darshan” is a Sanskrit term meaning sight, in the Hindu sense of beholding a deity and making an immediate spiritual connection. Overwhelmingly in India, Hindu gods and goddesses are rendered in paintings or sculpted from stone and clay.

headline: Playing With Dedication
text: DIONNE COE has a sweet outside shot and eyes that light up when she sees a loose ball on the court. Shequana Harris has quick hands and an explosive first step to the basket. Both seniors, they arrived at school in September confident that this would be their year — college scouts, scholarship offers, a brilliant star teammate and a chance to lead their school, Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers, toward its 14th consecutive city championship.

headline: The Real G.O.P. Dark Horse: None of the Above
text: Two of my favorite analysts, Rhodes Cook and Josh Putnam, have a good debate going about just how plausible it is that a Republican who is not currently running for president could enter the race later and potentially win it (probably necessitating a brokered convention). Those of you who follow my Twitter feed will know that I think Mr. Cook has the stronger side of the argument; I think there is a small but nontrivial chance that the Republican nominee could be someone like Jeb Bush, Paul Ryan, Mitch Daniels, Tim Pawlenty or Chris Christie. (In fact, I was speculating about these scenarios as long as a month ago.)

headline: Week 14 Matchups: Offenses Tighten Their Belts
text: Texans (9-3) at Bengals (7-5)Sunday, 1 p.m.Line: Bengals by 3

headline: Tiësto’s Club Life Finds a New Home on Sirius XM
text: Tiësto, long a major figure in European electronic dance music, will begin hosting a music channel on Sirius XM satellite radio early next year, a spokesman for the radio network said. The channel will broadcast dance music in a variety of styles selected by Tiësto, the Dutch D.J. who is known for his six-hour live sets and his memorable performance during the opening ceremony of the 2004 Olympics in Athens. A master of trance and progressive house music, he has sold more than 761,000 records in the last decade. His new channel, called Tiësto’s Club Life Radio, will feature Tiësto’s own mixes and music by artists on his label, Musical Freedom, which he started in late 2010. “It will be an awesome way to showcase the incredible artists on my own label, play new material of my own as well as other music that I’m really passionate about,” said Tiësto, whose real name is Tijs Verwest. Tiësto currently hosts a Saturday show on Sirius’s Electric Area channel, but that program will be moved to the new dial setting: Channel 340 on Edge satellite radios and on the Sirius XM Internet radio site.

headline: Social Insurance and Individual Freedom
text: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

headline: Ford E-Series: Requiem for the Band Van
text: The Ford Econoline, marketed by Ford in its later years as the E-Series, is being replaced by the Transit, a model developed by Ford’s European division and undergoing tests at the automaker’s proving grounds in Michigan. But as the Econoline nameplate goes, so goes a legacy steeped in rock ‘n’ roll — and in exceptional cases, chlorine and pizza sauce.

headline: Whimsical Works Join a Museum’s Menagerie in Paris
text: The Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature (62, rue des Archives; 33-1-53-01- 92-40, www.chassenature.org) is a singular space. Dedicated to exploring man’s interaction with nature, it has a permanent collection featuring hunting scene tapestries, ornately carved firearms, curiosity cabinets and taxidermied animals. And now, the museum is juxtaposing its rather sober items with whimsical pieces by the contemporary artist Françoise Pétrovitch, whose works will be on display through Jan. 22.

headline: Merger Planned Between Travel-Focused Ad Agencies
text: Two agencies that specialize in campaigns for travel advertisers are combining to create what they describe as the largest travel marketing firm.

headline: Refusing to Compete on Price
text: Jessica Johnson knows she must continue to innovate if she wants her business, Johnson Security Bureau, to maintain its impressive growth rate in 2012. This year, the company’s annual sales have doubled — just as they did in 2010.

headline: Japan Calls for Action Against Citigroup and UBS
text: TOKYO — Japanese financial regulators called on Friday for penalties against Citigroup and UBS, accusing them of trying to manipulate interest rates at which they borrow from each other, broadening an international inquiry into some of the world’s biggest banks.

headline: Daily Report: Clinton Pushes for Internet Freedom
text: At the opening of a two-day conference on digital freedom in the Netherlands, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and other international leaders argued that countries and businesses should fight increasing efforts to restrict access to the Internet by repressive governments and even some democratic ones, reported Steven Lee Myers and Heather Timmons in Friday’s New York Times.

headline: Next Two Debates Likely to Be Nasty
text: In a political year when debates have repeatedly reshaped the course of the Republican presidential campaign, the next two televised gatherings of candidates, on Saturday and next Thursday, are shaping up to be the most important — and nasty — yet.

headline: The True Meaning of the Season: Holiday Movies We’d Actually Watch
text: So many Christmas-theme movies on television, so little time. The next few days bring “Christmas Comes Home to Canaan,” “Christmas Magic,” “Dear Santa” and assorted others, some new, some recycled. You know the ingredients: a single parent, a plucky child or two, a hardship of some kind, a serendipitous meeting that leads to love. Perhaps a little angelic intervention.

headline: The Heart That Beats in Albert Nobbs
text: MOST failed auditions are quickly forgotten. Rarely does one generate a part that haunts an actor for three decades, lingering like an unresolved relationship that refuses to be eclipsed by successes across film, theater and television. But a botched stab at the title role was the beginning of Glenn Close’s enduring fascination with “Albert Nobbs.”

headline: Opinion Report: New York’s Tax Code
text: From the editorial page

headline: Romney Meets the Press
text: Mitt Romney — buttoned-down and buttoned-up — appears most comfortable in structured situations that he can control, like roundtable discussions about business and industry.

headline: Water Transfer to San Diego Is Upheld
text: Eight years ago, California’s Imperial Valley, a blooming desert that has access to more water than any place in the West, agreed to transfer 10 percent of its bounty to San Diego and Los Angeles and other metropolitan areas of Southern California.

headline: Letter Bomb Explodes in Italian Tax Office
text: ROME — An Italian anarchist group claimed responsibility for a letter bomb that injured the national director of Italy’s tax collection agency after it exploded in his hands on Friday, the Italian police said.

headline: Fire Kills Dozens in India
text: A fast-moving fire raged through a private hospital in Kolkata on Friday, killing scores of people.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: Corzine Defends His Actions at MF Global  |  Jon S. Corzine, who came to Washington in 2001 as a Democratic senator from New Jersey, made a humbling return on Thursday, defending his tenure as MF Global’s top executive and sounding a note of contrition about the brokerage firm’s startling collapse.

headline: Thoma Bravo Acquires Blue Coat Systems for $1.3 Billion
text: An investor group, led by the private equity firm Thoma Bravo, announced on Friday that it had agreed to purchase Blue Coat Systems, a maker of enterprise security and network software, for $1.3 billion in cash.

headline: The Summit To End All Summits
text: European stocks are up today, and I have no idea why. I’m with Felix Salmon — this looks like a disastrous meeting. More austerity, more posing of the crisis, wrongly, as being all about fiscal deficits; no mechanism for ECB funding. Somehow southern Europe is supposed to deflate its way to prosperity, while everyone runs a trade surplus, presumably against that potentially habitable planet we’ve discovered 600 light-years away.

headline: Imitation Occupation Begets the Real Thing
text: Click to read the updated version of this article that appears in the newspaper.

headline: Ex-Philippine Leader Moved to New Location Ahead of Trial
text: MANILA — The former president of the Philippines, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, was moved through heavy traffic and pounding rain to a government hospital Friday to await trial on charges of election fraud.

headline: Peripheral Stories
text: A few notes about things surrounding core Europe.

headline: Updates on the European Debt Crisis Talks
text: The Lede followed developments in negotiations over the debt crisis in Europe, where leaders of most — but not all — of the countries in the European Union agreed on Friday to sign an intergovernmental treaty committing their countries to stricter budgetary discipline. The live blog has ended. Check the business and world sections for the latest developments.

headline: Will The Real Hari Seldon Please Stand Up?
text: Teresa Nielsen Hayden takes on an article claiming, ludicrously, that Newt Gingrich is playing a role from Isaac Asimov’s Foundation novels. As she says, that’s ridiculous; I’m the one playing that role.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 9
text: Tanzina Vega writes about Hearst’s introduction of Cosmopolitan Latina, which will begin publishing in May. The planned new magazine — with one issue in the spring and one in the fall, and, at first, a print run of 545,000 copies — is a recognition of the growing economic power of Latino women, who number nearly 25 million in the United States, she writes. Latino women account for one in every four subscribers of Cosmopolitan, and the Cosmopolitan Web site will have separate tab for Latino-focused content. The new magazine will be competing with Latina magazine, which just celebrated its 15th anniversary.

headline: Sadness and Anger Over School Closings
text: The proverbial other shoe will drop Friday, when as many as 10 more New York City public schools will be placed on a list to be closed, but the fallout has already begun after the city's announcement Thursday recommending a dozen school closings and the "truncation" of grades from three additional schools.

headline: Walcott: School Choice Is Not Too Much of a Good Thing
text: A few hundred people, the vast majority of whom were parents, turned out for SchoolBook's first community event on the campus of the Pratt Institute, where Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott staunchly defended the school choice process. Audience members were able to validate feelings of anxiety and confusion, but came away with few concrete tips to help navigate the process. So those of you who have been through choosing a New York City public school: Please share your tips and advice.

headline: The Early Word: Going Head to Head
text: In Today’s Times:Redistricting has pitted several incumbent House members against each other next year for redrawn districts, Jennifer Steinhauer writes. In California’s San Fernando Valley, the matchup between the veteran Democrats Brad Sherman and Howard L. Berman is expected to draw in independent political groups with deep pockets, she adds.

headline: All Wrapped Up
text: Shopping for holiday gifts can be an exhausting proposition. At least the wrapping part just got a little easier.

headline: Where Are the Women Executives in Silicon Valley?
text: Updated 6 p.m.: Clarified the number of women among Intuit’s highest-paid executives.

headline: Motive a Mystery in Killing and Suicide at Virginia Tech
text: BLACKSBURG, Va. — The man who shot and killed a campus police officer at Virginia Tech and then turned the gun on himself was a part-time student at a nearby college who had stolen a car at gunpoint the day before but had no apparent link to the officer, the police said Friday.

headline: Israeli Planes Attack Gaza Targets
text: GAZA — Israel carried out more airstrikes in Gaza early Friday, accidentally killing a Palestinian man and his 12-year-old son as militants continued to fire rockets into southern Israel.

headline: The Huntsman 2016 Fallacy
text: Jon Chait points out, correctly, that Newt Gingrich should be hoping against hope that a Jon Huntsman surge in New Hampshire cuts into Mitt Romney’s support. But then he veers off into implausible speculations about Huntsman’s 2016 ambitions:

headline: Yahoo’s Alibaba Quandary
text: As Yahoo explores its future, one of the board’s top considerations is what to do about the company’s 43 percent stake in Alibaba, the Chinese Internet giant.

headline: Ownership of Maple Leafs and Raptors May Change Hands
text: Rogers Communications and Bell Canada, two giant communications firms, said Friday that they would pay more than $1.3 billion Canadian, or about $1.2 billion American, for a controlling stake in Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment, Canada’s largest sports conglomerate. The assets of the conglomerate include the Toronto Maple Leafs of the N.H.L., the Raptors of the N.B.A. and the Air Canada Centre.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Details: Why are more and more American men so obsessed with the cleanse? And is a “detox diet” even good for you? — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Morning T | Nicholas Kirkwood
text: T’s Jane Herman talks to the shoe designer Nicholas Kirkwood about his early days in fashion and some of the shoes that have made him a star.

headline: Fill-In | Code-Cracking
text: Directions: Fill in the blanks in several paragraphs in this article from the World section, “Go Online, Beat a Puzzle and Become a British Spy.”

headline: Live Blog: MF Global Bankruptcy Hearing
text: MF Global is in bankruptcy court again on Friday, one day after the failed brokerage’s chief executive, Jon S. Corzine, testified before a congressional panel about the girm’s demise.

headline: Planning Child-Friendly Flights
text: Planning Child-Friendly Flights

headline: Former Chairman of Anglo Irish Bank Arrested
text: LONDON — Sean FitzPatrick, the former chairman and chief executive of the bankrupt Anglo Irish Bank, was arrested Friday in connection with an investigation into alleged fraud at the firm, according to a person familiar with the situation.

headline: Lindsey Vonn on the Cold and the Cool
text: AFTER learning to ski on tiny Buck Hill in Minnesota, the Olympic skier Lindsey Vonn took her first ski trip to Keystone, Colo., when she was 7 years old. Since then, the gold medalist has gone on to ski all over the world, from her home in Vail, Colo., to the frigid slopes of Finland. Here, excerpts from an e-mail exchange on some highs and lows. DANIELLE MATTOON

headline: The Family Ski Trip: Why Do We Do It?
text: SKIING has never been easy. Fun as all get-out, reliably exhilarating, but a hassle. Triple that if you are trying to pull it off as a family.

headline: The Oscars’ Music Mash-Up
text: It’s not quite Ice Cube on Eames, but this year’s music consultants for the Oscars are a bit of an odd pairing: the composer Hans Zimmer and the producer and singer Pharrell Williams will take the audience on a “musical journey,” the telecast’s producers, Brian Grazer and Don Mischer, said in a statement released by the Academy on Thursday.

headline: Six Women-Only Ski Clinics Go Way Beyond the Snowplow
text: SKI clinics for women have been around for years, but in past decades the emphasis was more on basic skills than jumping off cliffs, with ample time set aside for shopping or going to the spa. Now women who want to maximize their skills may want to take another look at these multiday programs. In recent years resorts have been adding more and more women-only clinics that are aimed at serious skiers and taught by prize-winning experts.

headline: Friday Reading: Cremations Boom in Tough Economic Times
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Holiday Gifts From Your Kitchen
text: Some of my favorite holiday gifts, both given and received, have come from the kitchen. One year I made homemade bread, flavored with cherries and nuts and twisted to look like a candy cane. A good friend of mine regularly gives decadent raspberry chocolate truffles.

headline: His Mission: Telling Stories to Grown-Ups
text: NICASIO, Calif.

headline: A New Jay Peak, in Vermont
text: SEVEN miles from the Canadian border in northern Vermont, Jay Peak has always been so remote that only the ardent found it. For those who did, the mountain’s miles of out-of-bounds terrain became a cultlike destination, drawing a loyal, if limited, following that included many Canadians.

headline: In Utah, the Canyons Resort Gets a Facelift
text: Two years ago this long-neglected cousin to Deer Valley and Park City received a makeover, complete with near chair lifts, food carts and restaurants.

headline: Answers From Vivian Toy: The Apartment Critic
text: Vivian S. Toy, a real estate reporter for The Times, answers some questions readers submitted about buying, selling and renting in the city.

headline: Reaching for the Sky in Utah
text: A FEW years ago, I packed my skis and did something every winter sports enthusiast should do at least once in a lifetime: take a trip to Utah, a place known for its powder. I met a friend in Salt Lake City and spent a week bouncing between four resorts. We flew around aspens at Deer Valley and nailed jump turns off a ridge at Robert Redford’s Sundance Resort. At Snowbird I sailed weightlessly through three feet of the airiest, steepest, untracked powder I’d ever skied.

headline: Hotel Review: Viceroy Snowmass, Snowmass Village, Colo.
text: UPSHOT

headline: Faith and Family Values at Issue for Republicans
text: For the first time in American history, a major political party may be choosing between two leading presidential candidates who are not Protestant. If current polling holds through the Jan. 3 Iowa caucuses and beyond, the Republican nomination will come down to a choice between a Latter-day Saint, or Mormon, and a Roman Catholic.

headline: Now Do You See the Smog?
text: BEIJING — This week, as smog forced the closure of roads and the cancellation of flights in northern China, my Beijing landlord called. “The pollution is awful,” he said. “Don’t open your windows, and definitely don’t go outside.”

headline: With Trade Voided, Score One for the Laker Haters
text: 9:25 p.m. | Updated

headline: Ford Recalls 129,000 Fusions and Mercury Milans After Studs Fracture on Steel Wheels
text: Ford is recalling almost 129,000 of its 2010-11 Ford Fusions and Mercury Milans because the wheel studs on vehicles equipped with 17-inch steel wheels could break, potentially leading to a wheel coming loose and falling off.

headline: Ski Trivia!
text: Number  of ski areas in New York (the most in the  U.S.): 52

headline: On Ledge and Online: Solitary Sport Turns Social
text: Last month the climber Tommy Caldwell lived on a nylon ledge hung 1,200 feet up El Capitan, the massive sweep of granite that stands sentinel over Yosemite Valley, for more than two weeks.

headline: On the Road with Jamie Oliver
text: While plenty of people know all about “Jamie Oliver’s Food Revolution,” the controversial ABC series in which the British chef and activist butted heads with bureaucrats as he quixotically endeavored to improve school lunches in West Virginia and Southern California, fewer Americans know that Mr. Oliver created a whole other TV series about the United States and its food.

headline: The Ten Best Books of 2011
text: This week, the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2011; Gerald Marzorati on “Love Goes to Buildings on Fire”, Will Hermes’ book about the New York music scene in the 1970s; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; the Times’s Susan Chira discusses “No Higher Honor”, the new memoir by Condoleeza Rice; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Announcing the ‘Lives’ Contest Winners
text: Back in October we announced a contest, in collaboration with our friends at Figment, in which students were invited to use first lines from The Times Magazine’s weekly “Lives” column to start their own short work of fiction.

headline: The Giving Spree | Sasha Pivovarova
text: Who: The model and artist Sasha Pivovarova.

headline: Zite Introduces a Personalized Magazine for the iPhone
text: Updated 6:05 p.m.: Clarified the business relationship between Zite and Lululemon.

headline: In Baseball, Star Power; in the N.B.A., Not So Much
text: If you thought that the N.B.A., which had just spent months proving itself arrogant and remarkably tone-deaf with its nonsensical lockout, would enter the era of labor peace with a desire to prove it was worthwhile for the good of the game, well, the league just proved you dead wrong. Apparently, it decided the season for arrogance and tone-deafness has just begun because it promptly squelched any budding good will by squashing the trade of Hornets guard Chris Paul to the Lakers.

headline: Obama Tries on the Cowboy Hat
text: It’s been clear for years that President Obama hates the crass salesmanship of American politics, the desperate need to absorb personal credit for governing, like a mayor who puts his name on every new railroad trestle. Although that diffidence has had a price—even now, most Americans have no idea what road projects were in the president’s 2009 stimulus act—it also kept him from appearing insecure in office, and made him look occasionally magnanimous.

headline: In Rejecting Treaty, Cameron Is Isolated
text: LONDON — When he rejected a new European accord on Friday that would bind the continent ever closer, Prime Minister David Cameron seemingly sacrificed Britain’s place in Europe to preserve the pre-eminence of the City, London’s financial district. The question now is whether his stance will someday seem justified, even prescient.

headline: Congo Leader Is Declared Winner in Disputed Vote
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Columns of black smoke from burning tires rose over parts of this capital on Friday as Joseph Kabila, the incumbent president, was declared the official winner of Congo’s troubled election, defeating his nearest rival by more than 16 percentage points in an outcome that many here feared would stoke new spasms of political violence.

headline: Morning T | Nicholas Kirkwood
text: T’s Jane Herman talks to the shoe designer Nicholas Kirkwood about his early days in fashion and some of the shoes that have made him a star.

headline: Reining In the ‘Soft Costs’ of Solar
text: Reducing the cost of installing solar power systems for homes and small commercial properties remains near the top of the Department of Energy’s to-do list. Early this year, Steven Chu, the energy secretary, unveiled the department’s SunShot Initiative, fashioned at least in spirit on the moon shot program, in which the Kennedy administration set out to put a man on the moon.

headline: Labor Board Drops Case Against Boeing After Union Reaches Accord
text: The National Labor Relations Board announced on Friday that it was dropping its politically charged case against Boeing, in which it had accused the company of violating federal labor law by opening a new aircraft production plant in South Carolina instead of Washington State.

headline: Painting Ryan Gosling, the Video
text: For our video of Ryan Gosling as the Invisible Man, the director’s sister, Vanessa Prager, created a painting of the actor. Gosling liked it so much, he bought it.

headline: A Coffee Shop Loses Its Nighttime Alter Ego
text: Anybody want to buy a custom-made portable bar, cheap?

headline: Club Kids Are Storming Music Museums
text: WE critics have long argued vehemently that if major musical institutions hope to be regarded as vital, modern institutions, they must keep their listeners (and performers) in touch with the ideas, trendy or otherwise, that excite the composers of their time. But truth be told, we are a little bipolar on that subject. Though we criticize the big organizations for fostering a museum culture, we actually value the museums they have become.

headline: ‘Tell Them That I Love Photography’
text: Jose Gaytan wore lots of hats — dog lover, camera salesman, guitarist. But he topped off all of that by being a dedicated photographer who chronicled the ever-changing Brooklyn waterfront. A masterly colorist, he found beauty in unlikely places and could render the Gowanus Canal into something worthy of Renoir.

headline: Arpaio Is Criticized Over Handling of Sex-Crimes Cases
text: GUADALUPE, Ariz. — Although Joe Arpaio calls himself “America’s Toughest Sheriff,” a growing chorus of local critics want another title for him: Retired.

headline: Don’t Mess With Gloria Allred
text: During a news conference with your client Sharon Bialek, you said that Herman Cain “decided to provide her with his idea of a stimulus package.” Are humorous phrases a hallmark of yours? In some instances? Yes. Is it in every? No. Is it appropriate in every one? No. Is it appropriate in some? Yes. Do feminists have a sense of humor? Yes.

headline: The Fracturing of Pennsylvania
text: I take issue with Eliza Griswold’s description (Nov. 20 )of the farmland in Washington County, Pa., as “hardscrabble.” As a young man, George Washington surveyed this land for Virginia, of which state Western Pennsylvania was then part. He purchased huge tracts for himself, because he knew it was valuable. Rich and prosperous farms developed, once he sold the land to settlers, and these continued to flourish well into the 20th century.

headline: The Dixie Ghostbusters
text: Except for the eerie flickering of our flashlights, we batted away low branches and overgrown shrubs of the old cotton plantation in total darkness. There was no moonlight. It was, Grady Carter noted, “a perfect night for ghosts.” At that point his nephew Andy held up a hand and pointed into the woods. “I heard voices,” Andy said. We all stopped. Chris Carter, his cousin, whispered, “I see a red light.” “The spirits of dead slaves,” Grady confirmed. “A demonic orb.”

headline: Can the Bulldog Be Saved?
text: Benoit Denizet-Lewis highlights the lifetime of misery that bulldogs have to endure. In my eight years of clinical veterinary practice, 100 percent of the bulldogs I have seen suffer respiratory distress. Anybody persuaded by this article to place welfare first — and disregard what is deemed to be cute — when it comes to choosing a dog saves one more deliberately handicapped animal a lifetime of struggle.

headline: The Stop Sign Wasn’t Always Red
text: In the early automobile age, American streets existed in a Hobbesian, drive-or-be-plastered state of anarchy. “Not only were the streets in those days completely disgusting and filthy, but there were horses and bicycles, and it was just completely chaotic,” says Joshua Schank, C.E.O. of the Eno Transportation Foundation, whose namesake and founder, William Phelps Eno, is widely credited with conceiving the stop sign at the turn of the 20th century.

headline: Everyone Speaks Text Message
text: When Ibrahima Traore takes his sons to a park in Montclair, N.J., he often sits on a bench and reads. He reads English, French and Arabic, but most of the time he reads N’Ko, a language few speakers of those languages would recognize. N’Ko is the standardized writing system for Mande languages, a family of closely related tongues — among them Traore’s language of Mandinka, but also Jula, Bamana, Koyaga, Marka — spoken, for the most part, in eight West African countries, by some 35 million people. N’Ko looks like a cross between Arabic and ancient Norse runes, written from right to left in a blocky script with the letters connected underneath. Traore types e-mail to his family on his laptop in N’Ko, works on his Web site in N’Ko, tweets in N’Ko on his iPhone and iPad and reads books and newspapers written in N’Ko to prepare for the N’Ko classes he teaches in the Bronx and for his appearances on an Internet radio program to discuss cultural issues around the use of N’Ko.

headline: Weekend TV Guide, Dec. 10-11: Catching Up With Clint
text: Clint Dempsey is the one to watch.

headline: A Building With a Heart of Gold
text: ON Columbia Place in Brooklyn Heights, improbably sandwiched between a Sardinian restaurant and a brick-walled cafe, stands a landmark in the history of housing for the poor. Its name is Riverside Houses, and it was created by the 19th-century philanthropist and urban visionary Alfred Tredway White.

headline: Elizabeth Lee Sample
text: BACKGROUND The child of a deep-pocketed, deep-rooted family — she is a member of the Daughters of the American Revolution — she came to New York City via Alabama, Bronxville, N.Y., and Fairfield County, Conn. “I’m just a dumb American,” she says.

headline: Enjoy the Horses; Skip the Urban Circus
text: THEY may have lost a lot of pastureland to subdivisions over the years, but Connecticut’s horses aren’t galloping off in retreat. There are 11 of them per square mile, according to the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources at the University of Connecticut. That makes the state’s horse population among the densest in the country (Kentucky has a mere eight per square mile).

headline: Brenda S. Powers
text: BACKGROUND The daughter of a Swiss diplomat, she came to New York via the world: Canada, India, Switzerland and Morocco, she says, not mentioning other ports of call, including Bordeaux, London, Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo.

headline: A Miss Golden Globe Who Gets It
text: We came to the party with every intention of pooh-poohing it. The annual naming of Miss Golden Globe? With pomp and circumstance? It’s frankly the kind of event we wait all year to mock.

headline: The Big Spender? They’ll Never Tell
text: ON the list of life’s many mysteries, Manhattan real estate can rank high. Yes, there are the usual metrics — supply, demand and location, location, location — but best not to look to them to explain why something costs what it does, because the answer ultimately is in the cosmos.

headline: Emboldened Orchestras Are Embracing the New
text: RECENTLY Bartok trounced Schubert in an impromptu audience poll at Carnegie Hall. I was surprised and delighted. It seemed an indicator, albeit fanciful, that the battle for contemporary music had been won.

headline: Mixed Messages at the Puck Building
text: Since September, Jared Kushner has been trying to win approval from the Landmarks Preservation Commission to construct a residential penthouse atop the Puck Building, at Houston and Lafayette Streets, which his family has owned for many years. His first proposal was all but tossed off the roof by the commission in October.

headline: Falcone Receives Wells Notice From S.E.C.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission is putting Philip A. Falcone on alert.

headline: Just One Look | Thakoon
text: When asked what the focus of this collection is, the designer Thakoon Panichugal pointed to its textures –– the cable knits, heathers, mohairs and wool felts; even the prints have a roughness to them. Favorites from the group include a yellow A-line cable-knit dress (“bonded to give it bounce,” Panichugal says), an oatmeal colored wool coat that’s tucked in the back in the prettiest way and a number of pieces made from a combination of crisp white shirting and soft grey cashmere. Here, a shrunken knit-leather jacket over a shirtdress with a built-in sweater and the coolest cable-embellished loafers.

headline: Rats to the Rescue in Cage Experiment
text: In the Chinese zodiac, rats are considered witty, imaginative and curious. Now scientists have discovered another attribute.

headline: Marc Gasol: A Big Man Worth Big Money
text: Free agency officially begins on Fridayth, but the chase has already begun. There are no traditional superstars in the bunch, but the best relative talents will still score max or near-max contracts under the league’s new collective bargaining agreement. Here’s an in-depth look at one of the candidates for such a deal.

headline: Big Deal | Where Holly Golightly Maddened Mr. Yunioshi
text: The film “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” spawned many iconic items. The little black dress. The oversize sunglasses. The wide-brimmed black straw hat.

headline: A Nighttime Pop-Up in Brooklyn, Nanny Goat Hill Closes
text: It popped up, seemingly out of nowhere, most evenings in Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn, then disappeared during the day. And now Nanny Goat Hill, a portable wine bar and restaurant, has closed after two and a half months.

headline: An App to Take You Deep Into Dickens’s London
text: A tourism app that evokes slums, starveling waifs, child labor, pickpockets, brutal jails and gallows might not be everyone’s idea of a good way to promote their city’s past. But for Charles Dickens fanatics – who began Friday to flock to the Museum of London’s exhibition celebrating the 200th anniversary of his birth on Feb. 7, 1812 – it will undoubtedly be Dickensian in the best sense of the word.

headline: Boston Police Pass on Evicting Occupy Protesters
text: BOSTON — Relieved protesters at Occupy Boston let out cheers and danced in the streets early Friday morning after learning that, despite an eviction notice, the police would not evict or arrest members of the tent city that has existed here since Sept. 30.

headline: Undriving.org: Combatting the Associative Guilt of Car Love
text: No matter where you live or what you drive, we all share a common problem: driving can be annoying.

headline: A Ghostly Architecture of Naked Trees
text: See a larger version of the forest from this week. Compare with the enlarged version of last week’s image.

headline: Popcast: Jenny Scheinman, Gotye and Sharon Van Etten
text: The violinist Jenny Scheinman is most often associated with jazz — this week she’s performing in a trio with Bill Frisell and Brian Blade at the Village Vanguard — but her eclectic career has taken her all over the musical map. She’s played on projects ranging from country tracks and tours with artists like Rodney Crowell and Jimmie Dale Gilmore to less easily definable efforts like “Lulu,” this year’s collaboration between Lou Reed and Metallica. She’s not only an accompanist — her last album, 2008’s “Jenny Scheinman,” was her first vocal record.

headline: Spotted on the Street | Ana Lisboa
text: The Girl: Ana Lisboa, a model with IMG Worldwide.

headline: Heidi Mount's Utah
text: The model Heidi Mount scales the heights of Moab, Utah.

headline: Nearly a Knick, Chandler Will Fill a Big Need in the Team’s Middle
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Seven players, none of them named Tyson Chandler, worked out Friday as the Knicks officially opened training camp.

headline: Four Afghan Men Held in Acid Attack on Family
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — It was after dark when the four gunmen battered their way into the small home in the northern city of Kunduz, threw the father of the family into his cowshed and broke into his house to throw corrosive acid on his three school-age daughters.

headline: Tebow, Eli Manning, Rex Ryan: Answers to Readers’ Questions
text: Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answers readers’ questions:

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 9
text: Subjects include Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s birthday, a beard competition and a study of sleep on the subway.

headline: U.N. Chief Pays Surprise Visit to Somalia
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Ban Ki-moon became the first United Nations secretary general to set foot in this war-ravaged country in almost 20 years on Friday, and he promised to relocate the United Nations’ political office for Somalia to Mogadishu next year, though other United Nations officials were skeptical.

headline: Pay for Our Mistakes? Not Us
text: It is nice to have the power to never have to pay for your errors. To get that kind of clout, you have to have a credible threat to make the rest of the world miserable if you are inconvenienced.

headline: Library President Loses License in D.W.I. Case
text: The president of the New York Public Library had his driver’s license revoked after he pleaded guilty on Friday to having driven while intoxicated last month.

headline: On Our Radar: A European Warning to Big Emitters
text: The European Union warns that unless China, the United States and India agree to commit themselves to setting a legally binding target next year for restricting emissions, United Nations climate talks could collapse. [Reuters]

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Alain Ducasse will be the first chef to be awarded the Trophee des Arts, which the French Institute Alliance Francaise established in 1992 to recognize a person who enhances the cultural relationship between France and the United Sates. The presentation is a black-tie gala at the Institute, 583 Park Avenue (63rd Street), on the Upper East Side, and starts at 7 p.m. Some tickets are still available and can be purchased by calling (646) 388-6632. They are $500 for those 34 and under and $1,500 for patron tickets.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $9.79 million
text: A five-bedroom penthouse at the Laureate, a new condominium at Broadway and 76th Street, was the biggest sale of the week, going for $9.79 million, according to city records.

headline: The Euro Has Been Very Good — for Germany
text: In the first years of the euro, which was introduced in 1999, countries on the edge of the euro zone benefited economically more than Germany. But over the last five years, the situation has been reversed. The charts show data for euro zone countries divided into four groups. Germany and France, the two largest countries, are shown individually. Five Northern Europe economies, which some have speculated could join Germany and France in a new “strong euro” zone, are shown as a group labeled “Northern countries.” The other 10 countries are combined in a group labeled “Peripheral countries.” These include all the countries currently receiving European assistance, as well as Spain, Italy and other countries.

headline: More Post-Season News and a Look Back at 2011
text: The post-season news is still piling in this week as Formula One makes a slew of announcements before taking a break for Christmas.

headline: More Post-Season News and a Look Back at 2011
text: The post-season news is still piling in this week as Formula One makes a slew of announcements before taking a break for Christmas.

headline: Inside Aldea
text: Although this Portuguese restaurant has a clean, sleek and relatively spare look, it has a much more complex taste.

headline: TimesCast | December 9, 2011
text: The European Union members agree to modify a treaty, but Britain refuses; the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof in Cairo; and Russian opposition activists plan a protest in Moscow for Saturday.

headline: Bloomberg Defends Police Treatment of Reporters
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday vigorously defended the New York Police Department’s treatment of the news media during the clearing of the Occupy Wall Street encampment from Zuccotti Park.

headline: Gingrich Calls Palestinians an ‘Invented’ People
text: Does Newt Gingrich believe in a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict? Democratic and Republican administrations have adopted that framework, but Mr. Gingrich raised the possibility he might break with it, calling Palestinians an “invented” people and the current stalled peace process “delusional.”

headline: Eli’s Bread Opens at Grand Central Terminal
text: The departures and arrivals have come quickly this fall for Grand Central Terminal’s shops and vendors. Now Eli Zabar has opened a bakery, Eli’s Bread in the Grand Central Market space previously occupied mainly by Corrado Bread and Pastry.

headline: A Now-You-See-It, Now-You-Don’t Ad Attacks Gingrich
text: It’s one of the oldest political tricks in the book. And it seems to have worked brilliantly.

headline: French Press | Laurence Doligé Makes Her Stateside Debut
text: The Parisian designer Laurence Doligé makes exactly the kinds of clothes that give French dressing a good name: not too complicated, not too self-conscious, but still a little sexy. Now in its sixth season, Doligé’s namesake line will finally be made available stateside this spring, at Mick Margo in Greenwich Village, Jill Robert’s in Los Angeles and at shopbop.com. “To be sold in America feels like such an achievement,” says the designer. “If you make it in the U.S., you can make it anywhere.” The collection’s clean white boat neck sundresses, plaid trousers and workman’s denim jackets pair beautifully with her handbags, which come in two basic styles: a two-tone tote and a more structured satchel. “My collection is literally my wardrobe” says Doligé. “I love designers like Poiret and Yves Saint Laurent, but my collection is special to me because I can actually afford to wear it every day!”

headline: Corzine’s Testimony Came With Plenty of Caveats

headline: Mary Boyle and Matthew Long
text: DURING the transit strike of 2005, the New York City firefighter Matt Long hopped onto his bike to ride from his East 48th Street apartment to the Randalls Island fire academy where he helped train the city’s bravest. As he crossed 52nd Street, a chartered bus made a right turn from a middle lane and hit him. When he awoke a month later, he learned the grisly details: he had been impaled by his bike and dragged under the bus, his body held together by little more than his bike shorts. He was given 68 pints of blood and a 1 percent chance of survival.
