headline: Theater Talkback: Diminishing The ‘Hat’? About That Casting Controversy
text: Last month the playwright Stephen Adly Guirgis went public on Facebook with his concerns about the casting of non-Hispanic actors in the roles of Puerto Rican characters in a production of his play “The __________ With the Hat” at TheaterWorks in Hartford, Conn. After attending a recent performance, Mr. Guirgis said that while the two actors were “talented and dedicated,” he found the production to be “dangerously close to a minstrel show.” ArtsBeat asked Mr. Guirgis to write about why he raised the issue publically.

headline: A Vision of Dance, Preserved in 3-D
text: “PINA” is a dance movie like no other. This documentary, by Wim Wenders, focuses on the German choreographer Pina Bausch and her company Tanztheater Wuppertal, but in a disarming twist it uses 3-D technology to take audiences inside the artist’s universe. It’s an immersive experience that at moments makes viewers feel as if they were dancing too. The film, one of 15 on the shortlist for the best documentary feature Oscar, was in the works when Bausch died unexpectedly at 68 in 2009. So Mr. Wenders, director of “Buena Vista Social Club” and “Wings of Desire,” decided to cancel it. Only after her dancers pressed him did he decide to finish the movie, which features excerpts from four major pieces and scenes of the performers in and around Wuppertal, Germany — on hilltops, in coal mines, in monorails and on medians — bringing to life a dreamscape only Bausch and Mr. Wenders could have conjured. Julie Bloom spoke with Mr. Wenders in New York about the film, which opens on Dec. 23. Here’s an edited version of their talk.

headline: What Bill Clinton Would Do
text: Bill Clinton’s new book, “Back to Work,” is less a bold plan to create jobs than it is a passionate rebuttal of “our 30-year antigovernment obsession.” That obsession, he insists, is public enemy No. 1. He also seems to be sending a barely disguised message to Barack Obama to join him in confronting the anti­government chorus.

headline: Condoleezza Rice Looks Back
text: They were an unlikely pair: the cerebral A-student from a striving black family and the son of privilege who as a candidate for president couldn’t name Pakistan’s military ruler. But together they forged a vision of a muscular United States striking out on its own.

headline: William F. Buckley Jr.: Right Man, Right Time
text: William F. Buckley Jr. was an immodest man with much to be immodest about. Not only was he the high priest of the modern American conservative movement and the founding editor in chief of its leading intellectual publication, National Review; he was also a gifted polemicist, best-selling novelist, sesquipedalian speaker, television star, political candidate, yachtsman, harpsichordist, wit and bon vivant. Small wonder that I once saw him nod approvingly when a tongue-tied freshman referred to his 1951 autobiographical best seller as “God as Man at Yale.” He performed his many roles with such panache, and such obvious enjoyment of being William F. Buckley Jr., that he captivated people who otherwise would have despised someone who did much to move the United States politically to the right from the early 1950s until his death in 2008. But even liberals had to laugh when Buckley, asked whether he slouched in his chair as host of the TV program “Firing Line” because he couldn’t think on his feet, drawled, “It is hard . . . to stand up . . . under the weight . . . of all that I know.”

headline: Anita Desai on Longing and Striving
text: Sometimes a mango is just a mango. This is rarely the case in Indian novels, where mangoes tend to be luminescent orbs dangling in steamy air, glistening with sweetness, sex and Being itself, waiting to be plucked, caressed, birthed. Either that or they’re muddy and rotten and piled high on a dirty road, surrounded by rancid garbage, rank cooking fires, beggar children and grinning, greasy swindlers. In other words, mangoes in India’s literary fiction are much like India in literary fiction: distinguished by pleasing aromas or permanent anarchy, if not some chutneyed combination.

headline: Searching for Love in the Windy City
text: “Love and Shame and Love”: It looks more like a line of free-form, possibly adolescent, poetry than the title of a novel, with the repeated “love” trying to buffer the fragile “shame”-filled center. Then again, that verbal image applies well to Alexander Popper, known to all simply as Popper, the melancholy, searching main character of Peter Orner’s third work of fiction. With its short and evocative chapters, its charged and playful language, its movement to and fro in time, the novel is indeed poetic. It’s epic too, encompassing Popper’s life from childhood into his early 30s as well as chunks of the life spans of his parents and two of his grandparents, with check-ins on various other relatives.

headline: The Deputy Sheriff as Misfit
text: New Mexico is a place of great beauty and great melancholy, and, like all of the American West, a magnet for misfits. Willa Cather captured these aspects in her classic 1927 novel “Death Comes for the Archbishop.” Now Percival Everett, author of genre-bending novels like “I Am Not Sidney Poitier” and “Glyph,” vividly evokes the same elements in “Assumption,” his new trilogy of interwoven murder mysteries. Investigating all three cases is the enigmatic Ogden Walker, deputy sheriff in Plata, a fictional county in the northern part of the state, physically not far from the health farms and art galleries of trendy Taos, but in all other respects a world away. Plata is the opposite of trendy. It’s a blink-and-you-missed-it burg of shabby adobe dwellings and aging pickup trucks and trailers like the one Ogden lives in.

headline: Before the Wall Fell
text: The novelist Ingo Schulze was born in 1962 in Dresden. He was born, therefore, into a country called the German Democratic Republic — a country that no longer exists. The Berlin Wall fell on Nov. 9, 1989, and when Schulze was 27 East Germany disappeared.

headline: The Rediscovery of Luis de Góngora
text: “But what is this poem about?” This dread question stalks almost every poetry classroom, and it’s vanquished only to return with a tenacity that would intimidate Michael Myers. Most recently, Ernie Lepore, a professor at Rutgers, took a swing at it in The New York Times’s philosophy blog, The Stone. Lepore is interested in what’s sometimes called “the heresy of paraphrase” — the idea that what a poem is really about is best represented by the poem itself. He concludes that while the usual reasoning behind the heresy claim is suspect, the idea itself is basically right. Poetry, Lepore argues, is not just about its paraphrasable data (and what we might make of that data), but also about the way that data is articulated. So Frost’s “Mending Wall” is about a not-so-bright farmer, a bunch of rocks and their various symbolic accouterments; yet it’s also about the break between the word “balance” in Line 18 and “Stay” in Line 19.

headline: Grim Tales of Clarity and Chaos
text: Bradford Morrow’s work has won him acclaim, but this inescapably grim collection of stories may not bolster that reputation. Here’s a taste of what his readers will encounter.

headline: The Risks and Rewards of Exploring the Nile
text: In the early 1870s in what is now Zambia, David Livingstone, the greatest of all Victorian explorers, led several expeditions in search of the source of the Nile. At times, he could barely walk, ulcers having chewed through the “muscle, tendon and bone” of his feet. Riddled with malaria, plagued with piles and weakened by pneumonia, he had pulled out several of his rotting teeth using strong thread and a heavy pistol. He had been attacked by roasting heat, pouring rain, tick fever, hostile slavers and leeches “as close as smallpox.” By 1873, he had an excruciatingly painful blood clot in his intestine the size of a fist. In this extremity of suffering, he found time to appreciate the “sweet” voice of a tree frog, but it is another entry in his diary — of truly towering understatement — that most perfectly sums up the wry fortitude of men like Livingstone: “It is not all pleasure this exploration.”

headline: The CBGB Effect
text: The first record made by Talking Heads, a single released in February 1977, was called “Love → Building on Fire.” If you knew about Talking Heads then, you might have been the kind of person who thought the formula-like vector tucked into the title was inspired by the deadpan propositions that the conceptual artist Lawrence Weiner was stenciling at that time on the walls of SoHo galleries — which, in turn, might have made you think that the song itself was some sort of self-conscious concept art, sonically and lyrically examining the idea of a soulful pop song even as the insistent beat and David Byrne’s strained shouts and warbles made the song a real one, exuberant, funny in its way, and infectious.

headline: A Novel of Sisters Unbound
text: The ties that bind three generations of women also wrench them apart in “The Sisters,” Nancy Jensen’s first novel, which spans almost a century, from the 1920s to the current moment. Like so many painful family stories, this one begins with a miscommunication. The novel opens in 1927. Two sisters live in the hardscrabble town of Juniper, Ky. Bertie, about to receive her eighth-grade diploma, dreams of marrying her beau, Wallace, “just maybe, in another year.” Meanwhile her older sister, Mabel, secretively plans to leave home and escape their monstrous stepfather. Alas, things go wrong — disastrously and not quite plausibly. The stepfather is found dead. Mabel and Wallace vanish. Bertie assumes she has been betrayed. The sisters are lost to each other.

headline: Inside the List
text: BIG DADDY BARNES: As literary prizes go, nothing beats the Pulitzer for securing a novel’s place on the best-seller list: 9 of the last 10 fiction winners have spent time here. (The exception is Geraldine Brooks’s “March,” which won in 2006 but never cracked the list.) What about the Man Booker Prize in Britain? It’s almost as powerful. Seven of the last 10 winners have gone on to become New York Times best sellers, including this year’s pick, “The Sense of an Ending,” by Julian Barnes, which has logged five weeks thus far and is still lurking on the hardcover extended list at No. 18.

headline: Up Front
text: This week we present our 10 Best Books of the Year, drawn from all the books reviewed in these pages in the past 12 months. Choosing the 10 was not an arbitrary process, but neither was it a scientific one. How could it be, when the editors here are, first and foremost, readers, whose responses to any work of fiction or nonfiction are inevitably subjective and, as is the case with all readers, captive to predilections and tastes, histories and habits?

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: INTO THE SILENCE: The Great War, Mallory, and the Conquest of Everest,  by Wade Davis (Knopf, $32.50.) This exhaustive and defining book presents the gruesome realities behind the legend of George Mallory’s pursuit of Mount Everest in the 1920s.

headline: ‘Batman’ Soars to No. 1
text: “Batman: The Black Mirror” enters our hardcover graphic books best sellers list at No. 1. The story features Dick Grayson, the former Robin, filling in for the Dark Knight and encountering a new evil: a man called the Dealer who traffics in the weapons of supervillains. Complicating things is the return of Commissioner Gordon’s son, James, who is a psychopath. The story, written by Scott Snyder and illustrated by Jock, is incredibly compelling and reads even better as a collected edition than it did as single issues. You can read our profile of Mr. Snyder here.

headline: Happy Golden Days of Yore
text: WITH its bleak, film-noir imagery and barely suppressed undertone of suicidal despair, Frank Capra’s “It’s a Wonderful Life” has somewhat mysteriously assumed an unshakable position as America’s official holiday film. But for those in search of a more vibrant, warmhearted and subtly melancholic seasonal celebration there is Vincente Minnelli’s 1944 musical “Meet Me in St. Louis,” which Warner Home Video will release this week in a superbly restored Blu-ray edition.

headline: The Cost of Cutting the Public Transit Benefit
text: Many employees are allowed to set a certain amount of money aside each year for commuting costs before paying taxes on it. Starting Jan. 1, however, the monthly cap on that public transportation contribution may be cut roughly in half to $125. Here’s what that could cost one family, in a particularly bad case.

headline: Romney Taps Brake on Gingrich Attacks

headline: Former Notre Dame Quarterback to Visit Kansas

In search of his first big recruiting coup as the new coach at Kansas, Weis may go back to one of his highly regarded prospects at Notre Dame: quarterback Dayne Crist.

headline: Latkes Party Planning
text: Latkes really do taste best when savored immediately after frying while they are still crisp-edged and brittle. Still, frying them during your average holiday party can be a somewhat arduous endeavor.

headline: Just One Look | Calvin Klein
text: “Buy now, wear now,” is a phrase we hear a lot during the pre-fall presentations, with designers showing clothes better suited to summer (when they’ll be delivering to stores) than to the fall they’re prefacing. Not so at Calvin Klein, where Francisco Costa showed a stunning and focused collection of wool and leather suits, dresses and coats (lots of coats), all of which carried their tight seams and rather ’90s silhouettes with terrific poise, and all of which will transition beautifully into chillier climates. Here, a wool felt single breasted coat over a sleeveless dress of the same fabric with a skirt tucked into the softest, rolling pleats says it all.

headline: Perry and Romney Seek Iowa Paper’s Endorsement
text: Mitt Romney and Rick Perry both appeared before The Des Moines Register editorial board on Friday, hoping for an endorsement by the influential newspaper in the weeks before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Gospel Themes and Punkish Dirges
text: Jason Nelson

headline: ’90s Angst Bobbing to Dubstep Beats
text: DULUTH, Ga.

headline: Inflating Your Way To Prosperity
text: One thing I often see in comments is people attributing to me, or to others, the notion that you can inflate your way to prosperity — which is presented as self-evidently absurd.

headline: Bon Iver, Fitness Guru?
text: If you sometimes suspected that the fitness guru Richard Simmons was actually perpetrating a hoax, then wait until you see the trailer for a workout video that has recently been making the rounds, featuring the auto-tuned folk singer Justin Vernon, known as Bon Iver.

headline: In Poll, Fans Still Have Favorable Opinion of Paterno
text: College football fans in Pennsylvania are evenly divided over the firing of Penn State football coach Joe Paterno in the wake of the child sex-abuse scandal, although most still have a favorable opinion of him, according to a recent Quinnipiac University poll.

headline: Parental Quandary: Drinking (or Not) in the Basement
text: This week’s parenting dilemma finds a mom unsure of how much to tell another parent about her child’s possible drinking, and how to show her teenage daughter the best way to respond to rumors about another student.

headline: Death Penalty for 2nd Man in Connecticut Triple-Murder Case
text: One of Connecticut’s most agonizing courtroom dramas came to an end on Friday as a jury voted to impose the death penalty on the second of two killers of three family members after an ordeal of violence and sexual assault that challenged suburban ideals of safety.

headline: Rustic French Pork and Chicken Pâté
text: Time: About 2 hours

headline: A French Butcher at Home (That Would Be You)
text: O.K., this is a little bit of a project, but not too taxing for an adventurous home cook. How about making your own pâté for the holidays?

headline: Institutions that are too big to fail, and improving government agencies.
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Diana Henriques on Bernard Madoff, Gretchen Morgenson on institutions that are too big to fail, and Robert Frank on improving government agencies like D.M.V.’s.

headline: Perry Survived Even as His Big Plan for Texas Failed
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — In the bachelor-style apartment of his legislative years, where Rick Perry liked “to kick back and watch football with a cold one,” the future Texas governor forged a lasting bond with a hard-charging roommate who preferred smoking a pipe, studying flip charts and strategizing.

headline: Scenesters and Occupy Wall Streeters, Together at Last
text: It was Radical Chic  redux. This week, the Bagger stopped by an event organized by a slew of New York scenesters and hot young things — including Alexa Chung, the MTV host turned designer; the photographer Aaron Stern; Zoe Kravitz, the young actress, and her boyfriend, Penn Badgley, a star of “Gossip Girl” and “Margin Call” — in support of the Occupy Wall Street movement. It was held at the swank Bowery Hotel, in a space normally reserved for Strokes afterparties and other downtown bacchanals. There were doormen and bowtied waiters (but no open bar).

headline: Friday Night Music: Suzanne Vega
text: Suzanne Vega was actually at the reception before Tuesday’s event — and I, of course, was completely inane on meeting her, with nothing to say except how much I love her music.

headline: Editors and Critics Pick Their Favorite Books of 2011
text: To complement the Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2011, we asked assorted editors and critics at The Times to name their own favorite book from the year nearly past. We received a variety of answers, including works by a Booker Prize winner, a confessional rapper and a global optimist.

headline: So Long, Water Cooler; Hello, Hashtag
text: IN one of the feistiest arcs on “Parks and Recreation” this season Tom returns to his old workplace at City Hall to pick up his former co-worker Donna for their yearly day of pampering and conspicuous consumption. Their motto: “Treat yo self.”

headline: Now Playing | Mr. Favela
text: “I just hope that New York feels what I feel,” the Brazilian rapper Criolo said just before making his American debut on Wednesday night at Nublu in the East Village. “I hope they feel my heart and soul.” Now 36, Criolo was born Kleber Gomes in São Paulo and grew up (and still lives) in one of the city’s poorest neighborhoods, the infamous Grajaú favela. It’s a place where “one million people fight for life every day,” he said.

headline: Caption Contest: Showdown in Madison Square Park
text: What did the squirrel say to the red-tailed hawk? And/or vice versa. Answers below please.

headline: It’s the Holidays — Make a Pâté
text: In this week’s City Kitchen, we’re not featuring a quick delicious meal. Or actually, we are, but it will require a 2 hour investment of time (though not necessarily consecutive hours). For cooks who want to have a little fun, here’s a recipe for a pork and chicken pâté — the rustic, old-fashioned kind a French grandmother might make. True, it’s a bit of a project, but the end result provides easy hors d’oeuvres for a holiday gathering, a great first course, or a fine sandwich. And once your pâté is made, it can wait in the refrigerator for a week before serving, all the while improving in flavor.

headline: DealBook’s Week in Review
text: A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: How a Music Site Disappeared for a Year
text: 11:42 a.m. | Updated

headline: Space Travelers and Dragonflies, in Galaxies of Life and Death
text: More than two years after his death, the choreographer Merce Cunningham has grown only more unknowable. Even if you can keep track of the restless ways in which he made formal inventions with human movement over the course of 60 years, the ways in which he shaped choreography as drama keep defying categorization.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 9
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: Can School Zones Change?
text: A reader looking for a new apartment asks: What are the rules and regulations surrounding how often school zones can change?

headline: More School Choice Questions From Parents
text: "What happens to students that schools don't 'compete' for?' "Why do all the kids have to be tutored to get into the specialized schools?" "I just moved to Harlem and found out I'm in District 5 with almost no choice for middle schools. Why is this?" These are a few of the questions that were never presented to Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott at a SchoolBook event because of time limitations. We will do our best to get some answers for you.

headline: Podcast: Too Big to Fail, Global Growth, Robert Frank and a Madoff Update
text: In the recent financial crisis, the federal government spent billions of dollars bailing out institutions that were deemed too big to fail.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 9
text: More Photographs

headline: Rousing Russia With a Phrase
text: MOSCOW — The man most responsible for the extraordinary burst of antigovernment activism here over the past week will not speak at a rally planned for Saturday, or even attend it, because he is in prison.

headline: Traffic Deaths Fall to Lowest Level Since 1949
text: America’s traffic safety numbers are in for 2010, and they are, with some qualifications, good. Last year, the rates of roadway fatalities and injuries fell to their lowest recorded levels and to their lowest numbers since 1949.

headline: Lens: Canada’s NFB
text: Lens: Canada’s NFB

headline: Chic in Review | Pizza Spas and Angry Birds Black Tie
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: For Anchorwomen, Family Is Part of the Job
text: WHEN Megyn Kelly was starting out in television, a prominent TV newswoman told her, “You’re going to need to choose: you can either have a family or you can be a major anchor.”

headline: A Risk Once Unthinkable
text: Are customer accounts at brokerage firms safe?

headline: Totes as “It” Bags
text: The tote bag has become a recessionary, post-luxury status symbol and useful social identifier.

headline: A Message on Every Arm
text: BEFORE the Fendi baguette grew stale and Marc Jacobs Stam knockoffs were sold on Canal Street, a young woman in the city’s creative fields might have considered a luxury bag a necessary investment. These days, thanks to the ascent of the humble cloth tote, she can save her shoe budget and still look, well, smart.

headline: Russia Allows Protest, but Tries to Discourage Attendance
text: MOSCOW — The calls started coming in the afternoon and tied up phones for hours at the headquarters of at least two organizations strongly critical of the Kremlin. “Putin is life; Putin is the light; love Putin and your life will have meaning; Putin will give you happiness; Putin will open your eyes,” a woman’s ethereal voice chanted over and over and over.

headline: Excellent Play by Declarer Helps Win the Fall Nationals
text: SEATTLE — The Keohane North American Swiss Teams was won last Sunday at the Fall Nationals in Seattle by Les and Gloria Bart, a married couple from Bradenton, Fla.; Nader Hanna of Toronto; and Piotr Klimowicz of Edmonton, Alberta.

headline: An Ordinary Woman Knowingly Enters a Serial Killer’s Gruesome World
text: Let’s get one thing straight: “Appropriate Adult” is Emily Watson’s movie. She plays the title character, she’s on screen nearly throughout and everything that’s important happens in her face as she signals the worry, grief, excitement and terror of an ordinary woman thrust into extraordinarily ugly circumstances.

headline: Book Review Podcast: CBGB and Condoleezza Rice
text: In this Sunday’s Book Review, the editors choose their 10 Best Books of 2011, which include four first novels, Stephen King’s 52nd novel (by our count), and nonfiction books that are models of their various forms — biography, memoir, history, argument and scientific analysis. The issue also includes Gerald Marzorati’s review of “Love Goes to Buildings on Fire,” Will Hermes’ book about the New York music scene in the 1970s. Mr. Marzorati writes:

headline: The Superhighway Texas Rejected
text: Gov. Rick Perry intended his plan for a public-private $175 billion toll road and railway system to be a major part of his political legacy. Instead, the Trans-Texas Corridor was unpopular and finally abandoned.

headline: A Writer Faces Something Far Scarier Than Ghosts
text: The title may be “Stephen King’s Bag of Bones,” but the reason to watch, if any, is Pierce Brosnan.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Frosty
text: Outerwear moved onto center stage with last week’s blast of wintry weather. The cloth coat, swathed in fake or real fur, was a standout.

headline: Gauging the Strength of a European Firewall
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration has applauded the euro zone for moving to save its common currency and enforce fiscal discipline among its members. Yet the deal has done little to calm American concerns about an inadequate “firewall” — financing put up by European governments to ensure that all euro zone countries maintain access to the debt markets at sustainable interest rates.

headline: Occupy Boehner’s Doorway
text: On Thursday, the police cleared dozens of protesters from the hallway in front of House Speaker John Boehner’s Congressional office, but a woman from St. Paul, Minn., returned to continue knocking.

headline: Amazon Backlash
text: Amazon’s effort to pay shoppers to scorn physical stores is promptinga bit of a backlash. The retailer is offering a bounty for those whoventure to the mall or Main Street on Saturday and compare the priceof items against Amazon’s price. Customers who use a special pricecheck app on their smartphone will get up to $5 off on up to threequalifying products from Amazon in eligible categories (electronics,toys, sports, music and DVDs).

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: War Propaganda and Facebook Fury
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors at The New York Times have been reading on the Web. For more, go to the right column of this page.

headline: Afghanistan Play, With Experts in the House
text: “Blood and Gifts,” J. T. Rogers’s play about the history of America’s involvement in Afghanistan in the 1980s, has gotten strong reviews from the critics, who have praised its subtle depiction of a Central Intelligence Agency operative who thinks he is financing anti-Soviet freedom fighters only to see them morph into something more menacing.

headline: A Hands-On Art Exhibition
text: MIAMI BEACH

headline: Reliving the Year in Notable Automotive Books
text: For these short, chilly days, this weekend’s Automobiles section offers a potential cure for enthusiasts exhibiting symptoms of driving-fun withdrawal.

headline: A Composer Still Vital in His Second Century
text: If the composer Elliott Carter had been able only to attend a concert in celebration of his 103rd birthday, that would have been remarkable enough. But on Thursday night, Mr. Carter, who turns 103 on Sunday, was not only in the audience at the 92nd Street Y for a tribute presented by a top-notch roster of musicians under the artistic direction of the cellist Fred Sherry, but he had also written five works this year that were included in the program.

headline: Reviewing the Subaru Impreza
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reviews the 2012 Subaru Impreza, which is available as a four-door sedan or a four-door hatchback.

headline: At the Heckscher, Works Torn From Life
text: The title “Ripped: The Allure of Collage” hinges on a bit of clever wordplay, suggesting gym-toned bodies and six-pack abs. Of course, collage originally involved torn paper rather than taut muscles. But the hint of sexiness is appropriate, since collage is one of modern art’s most seductive mediums, in which cast-off and non-art materials are assembled into avant-garde objects.

headline: Holidays and Song Hand-in-Hand
text: FROM a strictly musical perspective, holidays and the human voice are a match made in heaven. As if to prove the point, Westchester County will, in the coming weeks, resonate with a rich and varied mix of vocal offerings — among them musical-theater classics, 20th-century British choral works and jazz versions of seasonal favorites.

headline: This Sunday: Actors Turn Villainous
text: From the moment we asked Bill Murray to let us decorate his beard with fake flowers — an image dreamed up by Inez van Lamsweerde and Vinoodh Matadin, the photographer couple who shot our Great Performers portfolio for the first three years — we’ve had lots of fun with some very game actors. Clint Eastwood endured several rounds of being blasted with huge clouds of smoke. Charlize Theron sat for a portrait in the nude, painted in gold. William Hurt’s face was made up to resemble Francis Bacon’s painting of a death mask of William Blake.

headline: An Abused Boy, Betrayed by a Society’s Willful Blindness
text: Audience members heading for the restrooms before performances of “James X” at 45 Bleecker Theater in the East Village may feel uncomfortable about being directed there by a prominent arrow-shaped sign on the lip of the stage reading, “Commission to Inquire Into Child Abuse.”

headline: Airport Security That’s Not Surly
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Parody That Turns on Jokes, Not on Toes
text: Two score and several Christmases ago, three boys were growing up in Needham, Mass. Childhood friends, they went on to forge individual careers in show business.

headline: Messages Hidden in Notes
text: The New York Philharmonic opens its current program at Avery Fisher Hall, conducted by Daniel Harding, with that rarity this season: a new work. Well, not quite. “Flourish With Fireworks” is actually from 1988, but at least its composer, Oliver Knussen, is still alive.

headline: Performers in the Park
text: To the Editor:

headline: Brief Encounter: Modernist’s Take on Egyptian Myth
text: Every major international orchestra visiting Carnegie Hall of course wants to make a big impression. But that is hard to do with as curious a program as the one the Russian conductor Vladimir Jurowski presented with the London Philharmonic Orchestra on Wednesday night.

headline: Art Basel Miami Beach Wraps Up Its 10th Year
text: The art for Art Basel Miami Beach, which ran from Nov. 30 to Dec. 3, was provided by 260 galleries from 30 countries spread across five of the seven continents.

headline: Molière Meets Punch and Judy
text: You have never seen a bosom like this one. It begins at the armpits and droops down to the waist, a sort of humpback in reverse. Like any good bosom, it can heave on cue. And its rhythmic flappings signal the kind of lewd-icrous jokes we are in for at the Yale Repertory Theater’s production of Molière’s classic comedy “A Doctor in Spite of Himself.”

headline: Hip-Hop Universe, Expanding
text: This is independent hip-hop’s New Weird America moment, where rappers in every city are pursuing idiosyncratic tangents, sustaining themselves with Internet-generated fan bases that vary in size from extremely tiny to medium.

headline: School Lunches
text: To the Editor:

headline: The SAT Cheating Scandal
text: To the Editor:

headline: With Lobbying Blitz, For-Profit Colleges Diluted New Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Last year, the Obama administration vowed to stop for-profit colleges from luring students with false promises. In an opening volley that shook the $30 billion industry, officials proposed new restrictions to cut off the huge flow of federal aid to unfit programs.

headline: Afghanistan: Suicide Bomber Kills 6 Security Officers at Prayer
text: A suicide bomber in eastern Afghanistan killed six Afghan security officials, including a district police chief, during Friday Prayer in Ghaziabad District, a remote area of Kunar Province where there was an extensive NATO operation in October to clear the area of the Taliban. The bomber struck just outside a mosque where the officers had gone to pray. Two civilians were also killed, the Kunar governor said. In southern Afghanistan, seven detainees being held on narcotics trafficking charges escaped from a prison in Helmand Province, local officials said. Four employees at the prison, which is inside the police headquarters in Lashkar Gah, the provincial capital, were arrested in connection with the escape.

headline: Medicare and Private Health Insurance
text: To the Editor:

headline: The How of an Internment, but Not All the Whys
text: POWELL, Wyo. — In a region of inspiring landscapes, this certainly isn’t one of them. If you stand near where the barracks once were, not far from the Heart Mountain Interpretive Learning Center that opened last summer, this barren expanse, with its craggily eccentric mountain in the distance, could almost seem cruelly mocking.

headline: A Warm Welcome, Made in a Whisper
text: IL SOGNO is in many ways surprising. Tucked within a gantlet of brightly lighted gas stations and fast-food operations, this roadside restaurant hardly shouts its presence. Its location — just past a complicated intersection where Boston Post Road meets Regent Street — creates an additional distraction for first-timers trying to find the place.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 9
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s birthday, a beard competition and a study of sleep on the subway.

headline: My Mother-in-Law’s One High Day
text: WHEN my mother-in-law was in the final, harrowing throes of pancreatic cancer, she had only one good day, and that was the day she smoked pot.

headline: #OccupyWallSt Roundup, Day 84
text: New York City was briefly reoccupied on Thursday, after a Zuccotti Park-like set for the television franchise “Law & Order” was taken over by protesters. [City Room]

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,833 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Waiting to Leave, Last U.S. Troops in Iraq Stay Vigilant
text: BAGHDAD — Every other American soldier in Iraq, it seemed, was strapping duffel bags to the roofs of armored trucks, dismantling bases and joining the convoys hurtling south through the desert, toward the Kuwaiti border and the promise of home.

headline: Confiscated Money Helps Create Haven for Students in the Bronx
text: From her window on a hill in the Bronx, Verdell Mack watches her grandchildren walk the few blocks to Intermediate School 229 each morning. Otherwise, she doesn’t let them outside alone in a neighborhood where violence is common.

headline: For 29 Dead Miners, No Justice
text: Ann Arbor, Mich.

headline: Army’s Goal Is Win First, Sing Second
text: WEST POINT, N.Y. — New white jerseys hung in a row in the Army football team’s equipment room this week. Each bore an American flag on the right sleeve, the seal of the United States Military Academy seal on the left, a United States Army unit patch near the right shoulder and the words “West Point” above the numbers on the back.

headline: Feeling Welcome, Even Before the Wine
text: THE first thing to meet your eye as you enter Bacchus is a large trompe l’oeil painting of a wine cellar interior. There was something about those wine barrels that prompted a feel-good response from the moment we arrived at this lively Italian restaurant, which re-opened last April in the historic district of South Norwalk after a two-and-half-year hiatus (a result of a legal dispute). The good food and wine that followed confirmed our initial impression.

headline: Iran Complains to Security Council About Spy Drone
text: Iran said Friday that it had formally complained to the United Nations Security Council about what it called the hostile and aggressive behavior of the United States in sending a sophisticated radar-evading spy drone over Iranian territory, one that Iran’s military said it had intercepted and captured last weekend.

headline: Giants Guard Mitch Petrus Rocks on the Field and on the Bass
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — At the end of a long day of studying film, lifting weights and trying to fend off mobile and mammoth defensive linemen, Mitch Petrus likes to go back to his apartment in Clifton, N.J., take out his Fender Stratocaster guitar and slide his weathered, callused fingers over the strings.

headline: Plenty of Peppers, Pickles and Oils
text: PORT JEFFERSON, N.Y.

headline: Rescue for the Gulf
text: The Obama administration this week officially began what it hopes will be a sustained push to reverse decades of man-made degradation in the Gulf of Mexico. The trigger for this effort is last year’s disastrous BP oil spill. But the administration’s strategy goes beyond repairing immediate damages, to the task of restoring the entire ecosystem to good health.

headline: Canadian Charged in Iraq Bombing
text: A federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted a house painter in Edmonton, Alberta, on Friday for aiding in a 2009 suicide bombing that killed five American soldiers in Iraq. In addition to five murder charges, the suspect, Sayfildin Tahir Sharif, was charged with conspiring to kill Americans abroad and providing material support to a terrorist conspiracy. Mr. Tahir Sharif, 39, who also goes by other names, has been jailed since his arrest in Edmonton in late January. His lawyer, Bob Aloneissi, said Mr. Tahir Sharif denied the charges, adding that officials seem to have exaggerated the impact of his client’s remarks about the war in Iraq. “It’s hard to understand how he had a hand in murder in Iraq when he was here in Edmonton,” Mr. Aloneissi said. An extradition hearing is scheduled for next month.

headline: Court to Hear Texas Dispute on Drawing New Districts
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday evening agreed to hear a tangle of lawsuits over how Texas should conduct elections for its Legislature and for Congress next year.

headline: Trades Are Linked to Missing MF Global Funds
text: The trustee liquidating MF Global’s brokerage unit has spotted suspicious trades in customer accounts that appear connected to a $1.2 billion shortfall, the trustee’s lawyer said Friday.

headline: Expanding the Fight Against AIDS
text: Important new findings show that very early treatment of people infected with H.I.V. enhances their health and greatly lessens the likelihood that they will spread the virus that causes AIDS. We welcome the Obama administration’s announcement of a farsighted effort to treat millions more infected people abroad, especially in sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: At an Upscale Hangout, a Menu Built for Speed
text: MORRISTOWN needed a place like Urban Table: a hangout for young professionals desiring better dinners than the town’s post-collegiate watering holes dish out with their drafts. A place where medical residents and corporate clamberers could tear into a fun meal at a fair price. Where they could enjoy a citified setting that is dressed for success in subway tile, herringbone hardwood floors, hip lighting and artistic touches large and small.

headline: Euro Zone Agrees to Follow the Original Rules
text: BRUSSELS — In the fiscal accord reached here on Friday by members of the European Union, the nations that use the euro essentially agreed to go back to Plan A — that is, the principles and rules with which they created their common currency two decades ago. Only this time, they said, they mean it.

headline: Swatch, Supplier to Rivals, Now Aims to Cut Them Off
text: GENEVA — The Swatch Group may be best known for its playful, plastic watches. But it also produces mechanical movements and other watch components that it sells to most of its rival timepiece makers.

headline: Longer Standardized Tests Are Planned, Displeasing Some School Leaders
text: Students across New York State will sit longer for high-stakes standardized tests in language arts and math this April compared with past years, education officials indicated Friday, drawing criticism from school leaders and parents who believe that lengthier tests are a move in the wrong direction.

headline: Reality and Re-election Sharpen Obama’s Zigzags
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama thrilled liberals on Tuesday when, blending Theodore Roosevelt with Occupy Wall Street, he renewed his commitment to temper untrammeled, “you’re on your own” capitalism.

headline: N.B.A. Reopens to Business as Unusual
text: The N.B.A. reopened to general mayhem Friday, with enough controversy, anger and allegations to make the public nearly forget about the five-month lockout.

headline: She Finds Refuge in Art
text: Leironica Hawkins recalls always having “social problems, sensory issues and bouts of depression,” while growing up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as well as behavioral tics like self-rocking and involuntary hand twitches. Finally, at age 28, she was given a diagnosis: Asperger’s syndrome, a form of autism, for which she has never received treatment.

headline: S.E.C. Looks at Harbinger’s Dealings With Goldman
text: 8:04 a.m. | Updated

headline: Europe’s Latest Try
text: We’re losing count of how many European Union summit meetings have ended with “historic” agreements to contain the euro-zone debt crisis only to see them fall apart as markets judged they were inadequate or irrelevant to the problem of making good on old debts and generating enough growth to pay off future obligations.

headline: Parade Keeps Its Boom
text: APP Unsilent Night

headline: Chances for Sisterly Connection
text: Park Avenue Winter, which changes its name, décor and menu with the seasons, began its ode to winter on Nov. 29. The entrance on 63rd Street gives way to an icily elegant dining room inspired by the Arctic Circle. A murmur of conversation warms the room, as do the chef Kevin Lasko’s offerings.

headline: A Different Kind of Container Store
text: Starbucks is about to unveil a new store in suburban Seattle built primarily of four used shipping containers — the large steel boxes used to store goods as they are transported long distances on boats and trucks.

headline: Compassion Under Fire
text: Clara Barton, a 39-year-old single woman with New England written all over her dignified demeanor, could not rest easy until she found a way to join the Army. From the first day blood was spilled in 1861 — some of her old Massachusetts schoolmates were among the Yankee soldiers besieged in Baltimore by a mob of Southern sympathizers — the Civil War was what she lived for. She left a job in Washington as a Patent Office copyist for scenes of mass misery that broke all the record books.

headline: Gingrich Suggests a Reversal of Mideast Policy
text: WASHINGTON — Does Newt Gingrich believe in a two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict? Democratic and Republican administrations since the 1990s have adopted that framework for peace in the Middle East, but Mr. Gingrich suggested that he might break with it, calling Palestinians an “invented” people and the current stalled peace process “delusional.”

headline: Egypt’s Military Retracts Plan to Extend Influence Over Constitution
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers on Friday night appeared to withdraw a plan for extending their influence over the writing of a new constitution, evidently bowing to a chorus of criticism just days after the proposal was unveiled.

headline: Sununu, a Romney Supporter, Attacks Gingrich as Not Stable
text: John H. Sununu, the former governor of New Hampshire who recently endorsed Mitt Romney, has spent the past two days attacking Newt Gingrich on Mr. Romney’s behalf. But speaking on the Scott Hennen Show Friday, Mr. Sununu intensified his criticism of the former House speaker after the radio host asked him about comments Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma had made recently that were critical of Mr. Gingrich’s leadership abilities.

headline: Ruling Expected on Whether Madoff Trustee Can Appeal
text: A ruling is expected in federal court as soon as next week on whether the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoff’s massive fraud can appeal a decision that would make it difficult to recover potentially hundreds of millions of dollars from the owners of the Mets.

headline: Chinese Manufacturer Restricts Business With Iran
text: Huawei Technologies, a leading Chinese maker of telecommunications equipment, said it would voluntarily restrict business in Iran because of what it called the “increasingly complex situation” there. In an announcement on its Web site, Huawei said it would not seek new customers in Iran and would limit business activities with existing customers. Huawei, a privately owned company that has been seeking access to the American market, did not elaborate on its reasons for the pullback from Iran, which has become the target of increased sanctions by the United States and the European Union over its disputed nuclear program. Last year, some American lawmakers expressed concern over reports that Huawei had supplied communications technology to Iran and had sold equipment to Iraq during the regime of Saddam Hussein, in violation of United Nations sanctions.

headline: Still Active, With a Little Help
text: Henrietta Edwards prays that she may live to 100. “After that, I want to find out what’s on the other side,” she said. Ms. Edwards will celebrate her 91st birthday on Christmas Day with her energy and wit intact. To reach her goal, she eats carefully, exercises, takes dance and yoga classes, and writes poetry at the Lincoln Square Neighborhood Center next door to her apartment.

headline: On Quiet Roosevelt Island, Unease Pays a Sudden Visit
text: You hear about places where people don’t bother to lock their front doors, and maybe you smile and think of home, or, if you’re a certain breed of New Yorker, you just shake your head. Rubes with nothing worth stealing. Give me three deadbolts and a chain in the big city any day.

headline: Somalis Still Flood Yemen, Going From Worse to Bad
text: ADEN, Yemen — For two decades, Somalis fleeing their failed state found in Yemen a safe haven, a place to work, and a gateway to wealthier gulf states.

headline: House Republicans’ Bill Sets Up Pipeline Battle
text: WASHINGTON — House Republicans moved Friday toward a showdown with President Obama over the Keystone XL oil pipeline, which they included in their bill to extend tax relief for 160 million American workers through 2012.

headline: Real Madrid Threatens Barcelona’s Reign
text: MADRID — The most dominant club in soccer in recent seasons will face the biggest challenge to its reign Saturday.

headline: Saturday: Step on the Scale

headline: Japanese Islanders Cling to a Life Under Their Volcano

headline: At Elite Prep School, Abuse Case Won’t Go Away

The son of a CBS News correspondent, Mr. Culhane, who is now in his mid-40s, grew up in the Cobble Hill neighborhood and from fifth grade on went to Poly Prep, the well-regarded school in Brooklyn where his great-grandfather had gone as well.

headline: China: Nobel Winners Demand Release of Imprisoned Dissident
text: A group of five Nobel laureates has called on China to release Liu Xiaobo, the imprisoned winner of the Nobel Peace Prize last year. In 2009, Mr. Liu was sentenced to 11 years on charges of trying to subvert the state. He was a main author of a manifesto circulated online, Charter 08, that called for gradual democratic reforms. His wife, Liu Xia, is under house arrest in Beijing.

headline: Thousands Sterilized, a State Weighs Restitution

headline: Dancer as Walker, Baker, Reader
text: The first time she performed the role of Dewdrop in “George Balanchine’s The Nutcracker” with the New York City Ballet, Ashley Bouder was 17 and made a memorable entrance: she fell on her face. Now 27 and a principal dancer for the company, Ms. Bouder is in her eighth season as the Sugarplum Fairy and her 11th as Dewdrop. She will perform that role in a live City Ballet broadcast in movie theaters on Tuesday and on the PBS program “Live From Lincoln Center” on Wednesday. Ms. Bouder lives on the Upper West Side with her boyfriend, Matthew Dibble, 35, now touring in Twyla Tharp’s “Come Fly Away,” and their dogs: Scout, a Beagle; and Enid, a Boston terrier. On nonperforming Sundays, she unwinds with the dogs, naps, posts to Twitter and has a big dinner.

headline: An Ugly Undercurrent as Barcelona and Real Madrid Meet
text: MADRID — Barcelona and Real Madrid will meet on Saturday for the first time in four months, and the soccer world will be watching. The clubs not only tower over the rest of the Spanish league but are considered the best collections of talent in the world. Both teams are stocked with players who helped Spain win the World Cup in 2010 and each has one of the greatest players — Real Madrid’s Cristiano Ronaldo and Barcelona’s Lionel Messi — now playing the game.

headline: A Wanderer, the Singer Dion Returns to the Bronx

headline: Muriel Petioni, 97, Prominent Harlem Physician, Dies
text: In her last days, Dr. Muriel Petioni summoned to her bedside many of the colleagues, protégés and political allies she had amassed during a lifetime as a Harlem physician and community activist. She gave each a set of marching orders: Make sure the new geriatric center at the hospital has the homey atmosphere we agreed on. Have you recruited new volunteers for the Harlem Elders program, as we discussed? The new clinic on 146th Street — let’s make sure it has the equipment it needs.

headline: Holiday Spending Stress
text: Holiday spending is a source of concern and stress for many Americans, even as they plan to spend less money, according to recent CBS News polls. A third say they feel more stress than usual about the amount they plan to spend on gifts, and half are concerned they will not be able to afford the gifts on their list this season. And with these anxieties, few anticipate spending any more this year than last year.

headline: Updates on Protests in Russia
text: The Lede followed developments on Saturday in Russia, where tens of thousands of demonstrators gathered in Bolotnaya Square in Moscow and other cities in what organizers said were the largest anti-Kremlin protests since the fall of the Soviet Union.

headline: Giants Can’t Find Right Formula for Consistent Special Teams
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. —This season, when the Giants’ special-teams coaches screened the film from last year’s brutal loss to the Philadelphia Eagles for the first time, the players in the room were appropriately solemn. Those who had lived through DeSean Jackson’s punt return for the winning touchdown winced, while those who did not — like the rookie Jacquian Williams — were nonetheless sensitive to what they were watching.

headline: Packers May Find Lessons in Perfection From Two That Weren’t
text: The game had been over for just a few moments, and the players were still struggling out of their shoulder pads when the murmuring finally reached full pitch. For weeks, the Green Bay Packers had existed in a blissful bubble, insulated by their good nature and their distant locale from the ceaseless questions, the ballooning expectations and the mounting fatigue of a chase for football’s most elusive goal. They have been dominant this season but not domineering, oddly under the radar for a defending champion on the path to something even greater.

headline: Fighting Poor Recycling in Other Countries
text: When Americans turn in their old car batteries for recycling, they probably think they are doing good for the planet. And done well, recycling batteries is certainly environmentally responsible, since lead mining and processing cause far greater emissions of carbon dioxide than extracting lead from old car batteries for re-use.

headline: Hockey’s History, Woven With Violence
text: MONTREAL — It is one of sport’s biggest mysteries: how did hockey come to tolerate fighting? Hockey historians say that no one knows why or even exactly when the game decided long ago to tolerate fighting while other violent-collision sports like rugby and football did not.

text: The three-part series by John Branch, “Punched Out: The Life and Death of a Hockey Enforcer,” profiled Derek Boogaard, a six-year N.H.L. veteran who died of an accidental overdose of alcohol and painkillers last May at age 28. A post-mortem study revealed that he had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease. Here is a sampling of readers’ responses to the series and to the N.H.L.’s reaction. Efforts to pare down these banks have met well-financed resistance among policy makers.

headline: Christopher Logue Dies at 85; Modernized the ‘Iliad’
text: Christopher Logue, an English poet acclaimed for his multivolume modernization of the “Iliad” — a literary endeavor noteworthy for lasting four times as long as the Trojan War itself; even more noteworthy for its use of evocative anachronisms like Uzis, helicopters and aircraft carriers to conjure the world of Homer’s Bronze Age warriors; and still more noteworthy for having been accomplished without his knowing a word of Greek — died on Dec. 2 at his home in London.

headline: Scientists Say Cod Are Scant; Nets Say Otherwise
text: GLOUCESTER, Mass. — Federal regulators are considering the unthinkable in New England: severely restricting — maybe even shutting down — cod fishing in the Gulf of Maine, from north of Cape Cod clear up to Canada. New data suggest that the status of the humble fish that has sustained the region for centuries is much worse than previously thought.

headline: Two Self-Declared Leaders Help Keep Congo on Edge
text: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Police were going door to door on Saturday, taking youths out of houses in an opposition neighborhood and pushing them into unmarked vehicles, a day after the incumbent was declared the winner in a disputed presidential election here.

text: The gleaming Manhattan skyline rising over the Hudson River is about as real as a stage prop to Cruz, Emilio and their friends. They can see this illusory panorama from their wind-swept perch — a collection of shacks tucked along cliffs in Union City, N.J.

headline: Treatment for Blood Disease Is Gene Therapy Landmark
text: Medical researchers in Britain have successfully treated six patients suffering from the blood-clotting disease known as hemophilia B by injecting them with the correct form of a defective gene, a landmark achievement in the troubled field of gene therapy. Hemophilia B, which was carried by Queen Victoria and affected most of the royal houses of Europe, is the first well-known disease to appear treatable by gene therapy, a technique with a 20-year record of almost unbroken failure.

headline: The Next First (and Only) 100 Days
text: I’VE been saying this for a while, but now it feels even more acute: America’s democracy has shrunken to “the only 100 days.” Since F.D.R., we’ve measured presidents by their “first 100 days.” But now it’s really “the only 100 days.” Presidents lately seem to have just those 100 days to lay down a transformational agenda and get it passed in their first year — before they have to tailor their politics to the midterm elections — and then, if, as often happens, their party loses the midterms they have to focus on the next presidential election. China has five-year plans. We have 100 days every four. So all I’m thinking about now is how we get the most out of the first 100 days of 2013 — our next quadrennial chance to make serious policy (barring a crisis that forces our hand).

headline: A Pentagon the Country Can Afford
text: If you listen to defense industry lobbyists, hawks in Congress and the Pentagon, the sky is falling and with it, American security. It isn’t.

headline: Sprinkles of Pixie Dust
text: GROWING up in Brazil, I developed a high tolerance for ambiguity. The country had a history of political instability and was volatile and complex. You never knew what you were going to find from day to day, from the price of gas to whether your parents would still have jobs.

headline: Readers Comment on Sunday’s Egypt Column
text: My Sunday column is from Ismailia, Egypt, the birthplace of the Muslim Brotherhood. It tries to look at why so many Egyptians voted for Islamic parties, and my bottom-line feeling is that Americans are feeling a bit more panicky than is justified. It’s not that Egyptians seek a harsh Islamic regime; rather they think the Islamic candidates have a better record working in their neighborhoods and may be a little less likely to take bribes than other candidates. Plenty of the hand-wringing seems to be coming from Americans who’ve never actually met a Muslim Brotherhood member or a Salafi, and I’d suggest not overdoing the rhetoric. The picture is more complicated than some Americans seem to think (although I must acknowledge that plenty of Egyptian liberals are worried as well). Read the column and post your thoughts.

headline: Unfit for Execution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Professor vs. Professor
text: IN 2004, the Democrats were furious at what they considered the fraud to end all frauds: the selling of George W. Bush as a decisive military leader and all-American tough guy. So they nominated John Kerry for the presidency, hoping that having a real combat veteran as their standard-bearer — a bemedaled war hero, no less, who began his convention speech by announcing that he was “reporting for duty” — would finally expose Bush as the tinhorn chicken hawk that liberals believed him to be.

headline: Consultant Nation
text: FOR decades before Mitt Romney arrived at Harvard Business School in the fall of 1972, the traditional path for Harvard M.B.A.’s had been a straight one: join a major company right out of school and climb the ranks.

headline: Black, Female and Single
text: FEW things in life are more irritating than the unsolicited comments I get that black women, like me, are unlikely to marry. Family members ask, “Are you ever going to get married?” as if I am remaining single purposely to keep them from attending my wedding. Well-meaning married friends try to sell me on the idea that being single is liberating. And then there is my octogenarian aunt whom I love, but who also manages to unintentionally sucker punch me whenever I visit with the comment, “Maybe if you’d just straighten your hair you’d be able to find a man.”

headline: The Art of Listening
text: Maputo, Mozambique

headline: The National Womb
text: IN 2008, the de facto government in Nagorno-Karabakh, a disputed region in the southern Caucasus, introduced a “birth encouragement program,” which distributes cash payments to newlyweds for each newborn, with the aim of repopulating the region more than a decade after a devastating war.

headline: China’s Spies Are Catching Up
text: Washington

headline: Lady Gaga Rewrites the Script at Jingle Ball
text: Even early in Z-100’s Jingle Ball on Friday night, when the girl-screams at Madison Square Garden were not yet full-blooded, Elvis Duran, the Z-100 D.J. and the evening’s principal M.C., looked like a cat who had swallowed an eagle. He was sitting on an apotheosis, something that made Jingle Ball seem like much more than a promotional orgy for Top 40 radio and its advertisers, a place for pop acts to ram home their hits between screened advertisements for Splat hair color and Sweethearts Jewelry.

headline: If My Dad Could Tweet
text: My dad can’t tweet because he’s dead. He died in 1982, when telephones were about the only way to have a conversation with someone who was not in the same place you were.

headline: What Latin America Can Teach Us
text: IN a Bertelsmann Foundation study on social justice released this fall, the United States came in dead last among the rich countries, with only Greece, Chile, Mexico and Turkey faring worse. Whether in poverty prevention, child poverty, income inequality or health ratings, the United States ranked below countries like Spain and South Korea, not to mention Japan, Germany or France.

headline: The Pipeline We Actually Need
text: LISTENING to the debate over the proposed Keystone XL oil pipeline, you might think that all pipelines are bad. But thousands of miles of pipeline already crisscross the United States. Without them, there would not be gasoline at filling stations, or natural gas in restaurant kitchens. It is 100 percent certain that new pipelines must be built.

headline: Goodbye House, Hello Pot Plantation
text: A MAN’S home is his castle — except when it becomes someone else’s marijuana plantation, crack den, movie set, homeless shelter, farm or public park.

headline: Mr. Gingrich’s Attack on the Courts
text: In any campaign season, voters are bound to hear Republican candidates talk about “activist judges” — jurists who rule in ways that the right wing does not like. But Newt Gingrich, who is leading in polls in Iowa, is taking the normal attack on the justice system to a deep new low.

headline: Tebowing on the Gridiron, and Off
text: As football zealots channel-switch across the grim winter solstice, they are agog at the unorthodox form of Tim Tebow. He is a charismatic journeyman quarterback who cannot throw reliable forward passes, yet has run up (literally) a 6-and-1 record for the Denver Broncos after being summoned in desperation from the bench.

headline: In Euro Era, Opening Bell Is a 2:30 A.M. Alarm
text: As the European debt crisis roils the markets, American traders who once awoke at dawn are now rising in the dead of night to gain an edge when business begins in London, Paris and Frankfurt.

headline: The 1 Percent Club’s Misguided Protectors
text: The Republican right is pushing back hard against the 99 percent movement and its focus on the widening chasm between the fortunes of the few at the summit of the income scale and everybody else. Newt Gingrich, who led the field of Republican presidential candidates last week, argued that the concept of the 99 percent versus the 1 percent is “un-American.” His rival Rick Perry, who led the Republican pack in September, answered a question about taxes and inequality by saying “I don’t care about that.”

headline: Two Romneys: Wealthy Man, Thrifty Habits
text: BOSTON — Soon after Mitt Romney handed out eye-popping bonuses to top performers at his private equity firm in the early 1990s, a young employee invited him to ride in his brand-new toy — a $90,000 Porsche 911 Carrera.

headline: Wait Wait... Don’t Tell Me!
text: NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” is heard weekends on public radio stations across the country. (npr.org/waitwait)

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Putting the Justices on TV
text: Readers debate how allowing cameras in the Supreme Court would affect its proceedings and public image.

headline: Let’s Do Something About Privilege, Donors, Corporations and the Constitution
text: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: What to Watch for in Tonight’s Debate
text: Debates are always important in presidential elections. They seem to be even more critical this year. And there’s nothing like a debate just weeks before voting begins.

headline: Re-Evaluating Tebow as the Bears Gear Up
text: Dan McGrath writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Another Hole in House, With Much to Be Done
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Sunday: Taking Half-Steps
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Do you hear that? There’s music in the air. Well, there’s music in the grid at least. I haven’t seen Timothy Polin’s name before, so I’m guessing that this is his New York Times debut, and it’s a very clever one.

headline: Lessons From Europe
text: Let me return for a minute to Kevin O’Rourke’s recent piece on the European summit. Aside from pointing out just how bad an idea the new super-stability pact is, O’Rourke makes an important observation about what the European experience teaches us about macroeconomics:

headline: BMW 6 Series Gran Coupe: A Swept-Back Response to Audi A7 and Mercedes-Benz CLS
text: With the introduction of the 6 Series Gran Coupe, BMW joins a growing list of companies, mostly German, offering swept-back sedans with coupelike silhouettes. Mercedes-Benz, Audi and Volkswagen got there before the 2013 sedan, which is scheduled to go on sale in the United States next summer. The Gran Coupe joins the recently updated 6 Series convertible and coupe models, both of which went on sale earlier this year.

headline: St. Mary’s Park
text: Tucked between Bernal Heights and the Excelsior, the 320 homes in St. Mary’s Park are laid out on streets shaped like a bell. This spacious neighborhood of detached homes with sidewalks and well-kept yards seems to be from a bygone era. In some ways, it is.

headline: Several Efforts Under Way to Measure Effect of Texas’ Budget Cuts on Schools
text: Since well before the 2011 legislative session began, one question has dominated conversations about the state budget cuts to public education: How will they affect public schools?

headline: A Day of Protests
text: Protesters gathered in Moscow to challenge what they called fraudulent elections.

headline: For the Engineer, a Death on the Tracks Means Horrifying Memories
text: The number of deaths is spiking this year on the tracks of the 77-mile Caltrain commuter line between San Francisco and Gilroy. With the 15th and 16th fatalities taking place within an hour of each other on Dec. 3, the total is nearing the 1995 high of 20 fatalities.

headline: SantaCon 2011
text: Revelers from the annual SantaCon gathering amassed in New York City on Saturday.

headline: Tough Questions After Audit of Arts Panel
text: An official audit by the city controller’s office has confirmed what employees and the local arts community have suspected for years: The operations at the San Francisco Arts Commission are a mess.

headline: Retrieving Valuables Left Behind After a Raid
text: Robyn Kralique sat on a curb in front of the Department of Public Works storage yard on Wednesday, massaging a left hand made numb by zip-tie handcuffs worn during a five-hour stay in jail. She was lamenting the possible loss of her favorite possession, a half-century-old tambourine that had belonged to a Gypsy uncle who died two years ago.

headline: Drafthouse Founder Tries Hand at Film Distribution
text: Christopher Kelly wrote this column for texasmonthly.com.

headline: Court Reverses Conviction of Man Jailed for 19 Years in Rape and Murder
text: In an opinion that harshly criticizes the tactics of the police and prosecutors, an Illinois appellate court on Friday night reversed the conviction of Juan Rivera, who has spent 19 years in jail for the 1992 rape and murder of an 11-year-old baby sitter in a suburb of Chicago.

headline: Tar Heels vs. 49ers for N.C.A.A. Men’s Soccer Final
text: The College Cup soccer final is going to be played at Regions Park on Sunday in Hoover, Ala, but regardless of the outcome, the hardware is going back to North Carolina.

headline: Trailing After 1 Minute, Barcelona Is in First After 90
text: MADRID — Barcelona and Real Madrid kicked off their match Saturday at 10 p.m. A minute later, it appeared that a dynasty was about to crumble in a most humiliating, and unbelievably quick, fashion.

headline: Iowa Republican Debate Blog
text: Six candidates are on stage at Drake University in Des Moines. (Jon M. Huntsman Jr., still lagging in the polls, did not qualify; Herman Cain has dropped out.)

headline: On Russian TV, a Straightforward Account Is Startling
text: MOSCOW — Regular viewers of government-controlled television were treated to a curious sight when they tuned in to the evening news on Saturday.

headline: Behind the Bars of Supermax, Contemplating Aristotle and Islamic Extremism
text: In the highest-security prison in the United States, known as the federal Supermax, one inmate writes about prison life and his views about Islamic extremism in a year-long written correspondence with a New York Times reporter.

headline: Beyond Guantánamo, a Web of Prisons for Terrorism Inmates
text: WASHINGTON — It is the other Guantánamo, an archipelago of federal prisons that stretches across the country, hidden away on back roads. Today, it houses far more men convicted in terrorism cases than the shrunken population of the prison in Cuba that has generated so much debate.

headline: Holding Its Ground, Navy Keeps Grip
text: LANDOVER, Md. — As Navy players on the sidelines hopped up and down, pleading for even more noise, sections filled with Midshipmen from the United States Naval Academy yelled for a big and late fourth-down stop, which Navy had not had to do much in the last decade against Army.

headline: From Florida to Brooklyn to Care for Her Ailing Sister
text: When Sandra Dorne received a call in 2010 from a niece saying that Ms. Dorne’s older sister was in desperate need of care, she did not think twice. She packed her life into a small suitcase, left her waitressing job in Orlando, Fla., and three days later booked a $150 one-way plane ticket to Allentown, Pa.

headline: Lakers’ Pursuit of Paul Falls Through Again
text: The Los Angeles Lakers, frustrated in their pursuit of Chris Paul, withdrew from three-team trade talks late Saturday night and turned their focus toward a larger target: Dwight Howard.

headline: Baylor’s Griffin Wins Heisman
text: After Robert Griffin III signed his letter of intent to play at Baylor, Coach Art Briles told him that he would develop into a player worthy of the Heisman Trophy. It might have seemed laughable then that an afterthought like Baylor could produce such a talent.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec. 10
text: A look at the day in sports, including sailing in Australia, cricket in India and golf in Dubai.

headline: Braun, N.L. M.V.P., Is Said to Test Positive
text: Ryan Braun, the reigning most valuable player in the National League and one of baseball’s brightest young stars, has tested positive for a substance prohibited under the league’s drug policy, according to a person with knowledge of the results. He could be suspended for 50 games if his appeal of the result is denied.

headline: Barcelona Beats Real Madrid, 3-1, in a True Clásico
text: Barcelona surrendered a shocking first-minute goal to Real Madrid’s Karim Benzema at the Bernabéu on Saturday night, but rallied to post a 3-1 victory that moved it back to the top of the Spanish League standings. Read Jake Appleman’s article on the game here, and come back to comment.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In Anaheim, a Welcome and a Lesson for Pujols
text: ANAHEIM, Calif. — He could be forgiven for missing the distinction as he gazed out on another sea of red, after 72 hours that upended the game and redefined his life and career.

text: Michele Bachmann refutes Newt Gingrich’s and Mitt Romney’s records, saying she is a true conservative.

text: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof speaks with a cross-section of Egyptians about the rise of Muslim political parties in the country.

headline: Race Reshaped, Rivals Target Gingrich in G.O.P. Debate
text: DES MOINES — Newt Gingrich offered a robust defense of his views on the Middle East, his lucrative work after leaving Congress and his conservative credentials during a spirited debate here on Saturday night as his Republican presidential rivals urged voters to take a hard look at his candidacy.

headline: Mr. Whiteboy
text: Alex Cutler, a white man from Los Angeles, fell in love with the funk music scene in Rio de Janeiro‘s dangerous slums. Now, as the slums are being cleaned up, he has made them his home.

headline: Sarah Weintraub, Jason Rezmovits
text: Sarah Elizabeth Weintraub and Jason Israel Rezmovits are to be married Sunday at the Metropolitan Building, a restored factory in Long Island City, Queens. Rabbi Samuel Fraint is to officiate.

text: Dr. Barry Rosenthal and Alan Cohen are to be married Sunday at their Manhattan home. Rabbi Jill Hausman is to officiate.

headline: Phoebe Harlan and Joshua Anderson
text: Phoebe Hazelwood Harlan and Joshua Paul Anderson were married Saturday evening at the Wit, a hotel in Chicago. Heath W. Carter, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

text: Dr. Noëlle Starr Sherber, the daughter of Candace Somerall Sherber and Dr. Harvey S. Sherber of McLean, Va., was married Monday evening to Dr. Ariel Niroomand Rad, a son of Lydia N. Rad and Christian N. Rad of Holmdel, N.J. Alan M. Weiss, who was appointed a civil celebrant by the Circuit Court of Fairfax County, Va., for the event, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents. On Saturday evening the Rev. Charles Vere Nicoll, an Anglican priest, led a religious ceremony at St. Bartholomew’s Anglican Church in Gustavia, Saint Barthélemy, in the French West Indies.

headline: Marcio Hamerschlak, Andrew Koerner

text: Dr. Miriam Guadalupe Romero and Dr. Alexis Darryl Wong, both radiologists, were married Saturday afternoon at the Langham Hotel in Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Alberto V. Cordova, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bride, led a nondenominational ceremony.

text: Emily Elizabeth Straub and Jeremy Giles Sturchio were married Saturday evening in the rotunda of the Ohio Statehouse in Columbus. James E. Barber, a judge of the Court of Common Pleas in Fulton County, Ohio, officiated.

text: Beth Sapery and Rosita Sarnoff were married Saturday evening at their home in New York. Judge Jed S. Rakoff of Federal District Court in New York, officiated.

headline: Amanda Webb, Kevin Healy
text: Amanda Webb and Kevin James Healy were married Saturday afternoon in New York. The Rev. George M. Witt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, where he is pastor.

headline: Jessica Miely, Brandon Joseph
text: Jessica Lauren Miely and Brandon McKellar Joseph were married Saturday. The Rev. Dr. Richard Effinger performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Elisa Jorgensen and Pete Duncan
text: Elisa Mead Jorgensen and Daniel Rowe Duncan were married Saturday at the First Congregational Church in Guilford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Kendrick L. Norris, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.
