text: Kira Dawn Shalom and Peter Howard Shankman were married Saturday evening. Rabbi Norman J. Listokin performed the ceremony with Rabbi Gerald R. Sussman taking part at the Garment Center Congregation in New York.

headline: Republicans Debate in Iowa
text: The Republican presidential candidates gathered in Iowa on Saturday night for a near two-hour exchange that mostly focused on Newt Gingrich.

headline: Climate Talks in Durban Yield Limited Agreement
text: DURBAN, South Africa — After 72 hours of continuous wrangling, the 17th conference of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change wrapped up early Sunday with modest accomplishments: the promise to work toward a new global treaty in coming years and the establishment of a new climate fund.

headline: After $10,000 Offer, Some Bet Against Romney
text: Saturday night’s debate will probably be best remembered for Mitt Romney offering a $10,000 bet to Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. Mr. Perry was wise to decline the wager, which concerned the language that Mr. Romney used to describe his support for a health insurance mandate in his book.

headline: The Caucus | Debate Wrap-Up
text: Dec. 10, 2011 — Jeff Zeleny reports on the latest Republican presidential debate, with Newt Gingrich the clear front-runner and Mitt Romney offering a $10,000 bet to Rick Perry.

headline: Fisher Fights; Underwood Cheers
text: Nashville’s Mike Fisher and Anaheim’s Bobby Ryan came to blows in the third period of the Predators’ 3-2 victory Saturday. Fisher, who the broadcasters noted was usually “pretty evenly tempered,” quickly knocked down Ryan, and the players were sent to the penalty box. Fisher’s biggest fan, his country music star wife Carrie Underwood, was in attendance and cheered him from a luxury box. As the broadcasters said, “Everybody has their breaking points.”

headline: Caucus Video: Debate Wrap-Up
text: Jeff Zeleny reports on the latest Republican presidential debate, with Newt Gingrich the clear front-runner and Mitt Romney offering a $10,000 bet to Rick Perry.

headline: Democrats Shift Aim to Gingrich After Debate
text: Who worries the Democratic National Committee after Saturday night’s Republican debate?

headline: Peru Official Steps Down Amid Fight Over a Mine
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Peru’s cabinet chief, Salomón Lerner, abruptly resigned Saturday after failing to negotiate a resolution to simmering protests against a large mining project led by an American company, the Newmont Mining Corporation. Peru’s president, Ollanta Humala, replaced Mr. Lerner with his interior minister, Óscar Valdés Dancuart, a former military officer.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, December 11
text: With the presidential race heating up in Iowa and the payroll tax battle raging on in Washington, the Sunday shows get the latest from five presidential hopefuls and Senate leaders from both parties.

headline: A Show in Rome Explores the City’s Role in the Renaissance
text: When it comes to the Renaissance, Florence is usually given top billing, as the birthplace of a  movement that spread throughout Europe. But several cities played instrumental supporting roles, including Rome, a new exhibition there makes clear.

headline: As Google Preens in Paris, France Briefly Becomes the Focus of Digital Optimism
text: PARIS — Eric E. Schmidt, Google’s executive chairman, and President Nicolas Sarkozy of France acted like old friends. Karl Lagerfeld, the head designer at Chanel, introduced a new online-only fashion brand. The Ting Tings gave a private concert at the Louvre for a gathering of the global digerati at the LeWeb technology conference here.

headline: Paying for Babies in Nagorno-Karabakh
text: When a couple marries in Nagorno-Karabakh, the government gives them a cash reward of $780. More money comes their way after the birth of their first child — and their second, third and fourth. Families with six children under the age of 18 receive a house.

headline: The Silver Foot Award
text: Goes to Mitt Romney.

headline: Housekeeping
text: I seem to have a new eruption of spammers, different from the previous one.

headline: Debate Reverberates Going Into Final Stretch
text: Mitt Romney has 23 days to confront any political damage from what may become the most memorable moment of Saturday night’s debate — the image of him offering to wager $10,000 to settle a bet with Rick Perry over the contents of Mr. Romney’s latest book.

headline: ‘Face the Nation’ Plans Shift to Hourlong Format
text: The half-hour Sunday public affairs program on CBS, “Face the Nation,” will become an hourlong program next spring, matching its rivals on other television networks.

headline: ‘New Year’s Eve’ Leads Box Office but Trails Expectations
text: The Champagne was flat: “New Year’s Eve” was No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend with about $13.7 million in ticket sales. But it failed to meet the prerelease estimates of analysts, who had anticipated sales of over $20 million.

headline: Boosted by Putin, Russia’s Middle Class Turns on Him
text: MOSCOW — Here is the rub for Vladimir V. Putin: The people who stood outside the Kremlin on Saturday, chanting epithets directed at him, are the ones who have prospered greatly during his 12 years in power.

headline: Rival Campaigns Seize On Romney’s $10,000 Bet
text: Read an updated version of this post.

headline: Skating Rink Spurs Residents’ Latest Fight With Management
text: Updated with correction, Dec. 13 | In the eyes of some longtime residents of Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan, the ruin of their apartment complex has come in stages. First, the development’s former managers, Tishman Speyer, opened a green market in 2008, which drew large crowds of nonresidents, and they scheduled noisy music concerts afterward.

headline: Z100 Jingle Ball 2011
text: Photos of the concert at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Wooing to Reap Revenge
text: The Bollywood film “Ladies vs Ricky Bahl” has much to recommend it at first, not least its premise. The young, feisty Dimple (Parineeti Chopra), the daughter of a New Delhi land magnate, is smitten with a physical trainer (Ranveer Singh), who wins over her parents before skipping town with some of their money. Dimple learns that Saira (Aditi Sharma), a shy daughter to a fabric dealer in Lucknow, suffered a similar fate with a bookish merchant, as did the hardheaded corporate climber Raina (Dipannita Sharma), with an art dealer in Mumbai. All the men, it seems, were one fellow, whom they call the Bloody Scoundrel. He has victimized 30 women — not with physical seduction but with charm, assumed names and swindles.

headline: European Banks Hunt for Ways to Raise Cash
text: LONDON — As Europe continues to grapple with its sovereign debt crisis, many of the Continent’s banks are facing increased financing costs and limited access to much-needed cash, according to the Bank for International Settlements, an association of the world’s central banks.

headline: Reads and Reactions
text: In this edition: Newt Gingrich on the rise, fashionably late G.O.P. candidates and brokered convention conversations.

headline: Giants’ Cruz Already Has Reason to Dance
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Victor Cruz found two large photographs of himself at his locker when he arrived at the Giants’ practice facility Friday. Someone in the organization was requesting Cruz’s autograph, perhaps for friends or family.

headline: Israel Acts to Curb Illegal Immigration From Africa
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli government on Sunday announced plans to spend $160 million on efforts to stem the growing number of Africans who enter the country illegally, seeking jobs and political asylum. The money will go toward work on an Egyptian border fence that is already under construction, an expansion of detention centers and increased policing of companies that hire undocumented workers.

headline: British Conservative Apologizes for Attending Party With Man Dressed in Nazi Outfit
text: The video captured the camaraderie at a bachelor party earlier this month. The celebrating men sat around a table at a restaurant in the French Alps, making toasts. But something was amiss. One jovial toast appeared to refer to the “Third Reich.” One man was dressed as a Nazi Waffen SS officer in full regalia. And next to him was a member of the British Parliament.

headline: In an England of Certainties, Even in Its Undercurrents
text: “The Stranger’s Child,” Alan Hollinghurst’s fifth novel, opens on a scene in Harrow and Wealdstone, a suburb north of London chosen by the author to represent the middle ground, that is the space between the upper and lower orders — or rather, this being England in 1913, between the orders of lower upper middle and upper upper middle.

headline: Marley’s Ghost and Other Mash-Ups
text: The director Reid Farrington is a man of the moment. A multimedia collage artist who transcends genres, he makes plays that blend theater and film, drama with art installation. His work is formally impressive and conceptually fascinating, but sometimes it’s hard to tell if his experiments are a step forward or back.

headline: Geraldo Rivera Gets Talk Deal on WABC Radio
text: Geraldo Rivera’s been called a lot of names in his life. Here’s a new one: radio talk show host.

headline: Arch-Rebel Turned New-Music Luminary
text: For all that the New York composer John Zorn retains his substantial cachet as a maverick, an outlier and a nose-thumbing rebel — and for all that he might prefer to maintain that impression — a sold-out concert at the Miller Theater of Columbia University on Friday night indicated his actual status. Through durable alliances with performers and concert presenters — as well as dogged persistence and a stream of challenging, edifying works — Mr. Zorn, at 58, is a towering pillar of a new-music universe he has worked tirelessly to foster and enrich.

headline: The Winning Strategy of the Player of the Year
text: The diagramed deal occurred during the last round of the Keohane North American Swiss Teams on Dec. 4 at the Fall North American Championships in Seattle.

headline: Jets’ Offense Finds Daylight as Path to Playoffs Opens
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Just wait, the Jets kept saying, telling anyone who would listen — and even those who wouldn’t — to beware. Wait until their offense purred. Wait until their defense smothered. Wait until both happened on the same day, miracle of miracles.

headline: A Poet Lonely and Adrift in New York
text: “Wearing Lorca’s Bowtie,” a mood piece inspired by the writings of Federico García Lorca, features scenes in Spanish and English, but nothing said in either language makes as much of an impact as the quiet images in this impressionistic show.

headline: Athhilezar? Watch Your Fantasy World Language
text: At his best friend’s wedding reception on the California coast, David J. Peterson stood to deliver his toast as best man. He held his Champagne glass high and shouted “Hajas!” The 50 guests raised their glasses and chanted “Hajas!” in unison.

headline: Rosetta Throne: Learn to Speak Dothraki
text: Viewers of the HBO fantasy series “Game of Thrones” could be forgiven for thinking that the jagged, vaguely malevolent dialect spoken by the show’s Dothraki tribe is just a random assortment of guttural noises. However, such assumptions would be ojil.

headline: Central European Shadows
text: It didn’t get much media attention, but last month’s Transition Report from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development devoted a chapter to deteriorating belief in democracy and markets in the transition economies of Europe; there’s been a sharp decline in support for democracy, strongly correlated with the depth of economic crisis:

headline: Cheeseburgers
text: OK, let’s talk about the important stuff. Via Brad DeLong, Waldo Jaquith explains that eating cheeseburgers would have been highly impractical before the coming of modern manufacturing, transportation,refrigeration, and more. Eat your heart out, pin factory!

headline: A Tour Alights in Finland and France
text: In an interview with the WQXR host Jeff Spurgeon, quoted on the WQXR blog, the Finnish soprano Karita Mattila said that when giving a recital, “the challenge is always to find the intimacy and the contact with the audience, no matter how big the hall is.”

headline: Does School Choice Improve Education?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fluid States of Tension to Celebrate Connections
text: You might not expect works by Stefan Wolpe, Toru Takemitsu and Charles Wuorinen to share much common ground with Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations, and few pianists would be able to persuade you that they do. But then few pianists would assemble a program that would even raise the question.

headline: Homeland Security Dept., on Immigrant Detention
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Family Affair as Old as Oedipus
text: If it was not quite the “ick” heard ’round the world, there was a collective shudder that went up the spines of fans of serialized television at the moment it was revealed in the Dec. 4 episode of “Boardwalk Empire,” the Prohibition-era crime drama on HBO, that Jimmy Darmody, the aspiring young mobster played by Michael Pitt, had had an incestuous relationship with his mother (Gretchen Mol).

headline: Of Hume and Bondage
text: Anyone admiring David Hume as I do finds much to cheer, but much to lament in the state of academic philosophy, as this year, the 300th anniversary of his birth, comes to a close. Hume was an anatomist of the mind, charting the ways we think and feel — a psychologist or cognitive scientist before his time. The cheering feature of the contemporary scene is that plenty of people are following in those footsteps. The nature versus nurture battle has declared an uneasy draw, but the human nature industry is in fine fettle, fed by many disciplines and eagerly consumed by the public.

headline: Question for Congress
text: To the Editor:

headline: A New Primary System
text: To the Editor:

headline: Fighting Online Piracy
text: To the Editor:

headline: Disabled Host, With the Emphasis on Able
text: Zach Anner is the most engaging personality on a network that needs them badly. The host of the travel show “Rollin’ With Zach,” which has its premiere on Monday night on OWN, the floundering Oprah Winfrey Network, with two episodes, he’s witty and charming and mildly zany.

headline: It’s Back, and Even More Disgusting
text: It is probably one of the more unusual phone calls that a meat processing plant has ever received.

headline: A Propulsive, Stylized Spectacle, in Which Bodies Lurch Backward
text: Is there a better group of people to finagle into intense audience participation than the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater faithful? They are always primed for engagement: witness the anticipatory “Revelations” cheers as the lights dim or the ecstatic midperformance shout-outs. (Forget the path of righteousness; it is usually the “Sinner Man” section that draws the most raucous response, especially from women.)

headline: Visionary Offered Surprises Till the End
text: In its final week of repertory in America, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, dancing six works in three programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Wednesday to Saturday, kept hitting high after high. The highs kept extending our sense both of these dancers, an exceptionally attractive, diverse and skilled group, and of Cunningham himself.

headline: Monday: Poem For The Praiseworthy
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — He’s not even completely grown, but my son has already joined the Emergency Room Frequent Fliers club. There was a time when we were on a first-name basis with many of the nurses at our local hospital’s E.R., all of whom thankfully had the good taste and training not to keep bringing up the fact that we spent most of our time there. Those of you who have raised children or been responsible for one for any length of time know what I’m talking about. Children are innocent creatures, filled with wonderment and the joy of experiencing the world for the first time, so it is completely natural for them to get themselves into predicaments that, had they happened to any normal adult, would have gotten that adult an immediate psychiatric evaluation (“Exactly HOW did the vacuum cleaner get stuck on his tongue, Ms. Amlen?”)

headline: The Brewers’ Cornerstone Develops Unexpected Cracks
text: Ryan Braun can still tell you the high school class in which he got a B: Advanced Placement Chemistry. Otherwise, Braun said this summer, on the bench before a game in Milwaukee, he got straight A’s. He attended the University of Miami on a partial academic scholarship and has tried to apply the lessons he learned in the classroom, branching out from baseball to business.

headline: Monday Matchup: Rams at Seahawks
text: Rams (2-10) at Seahawks (5-7), 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPNLine: Seahawks by 10

headline: Merce Cunningham Dance Company
text: Photos of the company in performance at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

headline: Osgood Signs to Stay on ‘CBS Sunday Morning’
text: CBS News said on Friday that it had renewed its contract with Charles Osgood, below left, the longtime anchor of “CBS Sunday Morning,” and had promoted one of the show’s contributors, Mo Rocca, bottom left. A CBS spokesman confirmed that Mr. Osgood had signed a new contract but declined the specify the length. This fall, when the correspondent Lee Cowan returned to the network from NBC, he was named a substitute for Mr. Osgood, who has anchored “Sunday Morning” since 1994. Mr. Rocca, a satirist who has contributed to the program since 2006, will become a full-time correspondent, the network said in a news release. He will also report for other CBS News broadcasts. Separately he will remain a panelist on NPR’s “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” and the host of the Cooking Channel’s “Food(ography).” Last week the evening complement to “CBS Sunday Morning,” “60 Minutes,” named Andrew Cohen to be the program’s first legal analyst. CBS said that Mr. Cohen, who will remain the senior legal analyst for CBS Radio, would “help ‘60 Minutes’ correspondents, producers and executives with law-related stories, including deciphering legal documents, providing sources from the legal community, and otherwise guiding the program’s coverage of legal events and issues.”

headline: For Disney, a Younger Princess
text: LOS ANGELES — The Disney princesses exert a powerful hold on the imaginations of many girls, influencing everything from how they play to what they wear. Some parents think they can also send the wrong message to girls — that life isn’t complete without Prince Charming, for instance.

headline: A Widow’s Loneliness After Burying Her Children
text: When Alice Reiser, 89, wants to talk to her husband and sons, she turns to their photographs. They are all she has left of them, besides memories.

headline: Fed to Weigh Publishing a Forecast on Rates
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve’s decision three years ago to reduce short-term interest rates to nearly zero made a splash, both because the Fed had never pushed rates so low and because it said that it planned to keep rates near zero “for some time.”

headline: At Some N.F.L. Positions, Stereotypes Create Prototypes
text: During a screening of a movie about the Tuskegee Airmen on Saturday, it finally occurred to me why the absence of white cornerbacks in the N.F.L. — or the presence of so many black ones — presents a compelling snapshot of the American condition.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include retail sales for November and business inventories for October (Tuesday); import prices for November (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims; the Producer Price Index for November; the third-quarter current account deficit; industrial production and capacity utilization for November; the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for December and weekly jobless claims (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for November (Friday).

headline: Barber’s Blunders Give Tebow Big Assist
text: Tim Tebow’s latest comeback might have been his most improbable.

headline: Class Matters. Why Won’t We Admit It?

headline: Joseph Chamberlain, 88, Dies; Brought the Stars a Bit Closer
text: Joseph M. Chamberlain, who helped advance astronomical education and entertainment by leading planetariums in New York and Chicago into a new era of technology, instruction and visitor experience, died on Nov. 28 in Peoria, Ill., where he lived. He was 88.

headline: Rabbi-Chaplains of the Civil War
text: Rabbi Dr. Arnold Fischel arrived at the White House on the morning of Dec. 11, 1861, prepared to act as a one-man lobby for the constitutional rights of Jews. He had traveled alone from New York, on his own dime, bringing several letters of recommendation from prominent Republicans and one from the Board of Delegates of American Israelites, then just three years old and the country’s only national Jewish organization.

headline: American Owners Look to Turn A.S. Roma Into a Global Soccer Brand
text: It all started with some hasty scribbling on the back of a napkin at Stadio Olimpico in Rome.

headline: Joe Restic, 85, an Innovator in Football at Harvard, Dies
text: Joe Restic, who devised a complex offense known as the multiflex while coaching in Canada and took it to Harvard, becoming its longest-serving football coach, died on Thursday in Boston. He was 85.

headline: Will Congress Ban Corruption in Its Midst?
text: In a rare instance of Congressional bipartisanship, the Senate and House Judiciary Committees have quietly approved badly needed measures to tighten the anticorruption laws applicable to members of Congress. These laws have eroded across a decade of court decisions, and it remains to be seen whether the full Congress will tighten bans on fraud and bribe-taking by those in its ranks.

headline: As Kindle Fire Faces Critics, Remedies Are Promised
text: The Kindle Fire, Amazon’s heavily promoted tablet, is less than a blazing success with many of its early users. The most disgruntled are packing the device up and firing it back to the retailer.

headline: Noriega Is Sent to Prison Back in Panama, Where the Terror Has Turned to Shrugs
text: PANAMA — Nearly 22 years ago an American military plane whisked the de facto leader of this nation, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, off to Florida to face trial, and ultimately a prison sentence, for drug trafficking.

headline: This Time, Pac-12 Expansion Could Be in Another Country
text: Larry Scott, the Pacific-12 Conference commissioner, flew to Beijing on Sunday to start an apparently unprecedented effort by a college sports league to establish itself in a foreign country.

headline: Are All Bloggers Journalists?
text: A federal judge in Oregon has ruled that a blogger isn't protected by the state shield laws. What are the implications?

headline: Bill Tapia, Virtuoso Ukulele Player, Dies at 103
text: In 2001 Bill Tapia took one of his guitars to a Southern California music shop to get it fixed. A woman was buying a ukulele, and Mr. Tapia asked to see it. He began playing it, masterfully, with a distinctive jazz inflection.

headline: Romney and the $10,000 Bet
text: HUDSON, N.H. — When Mitt Romney, ever the prepared student, steps to the microphone to chat with reporters, he always has an answer ready for the big question of the day —in this case, just what was he thinking when he offered Gov. Rick Perry of Texas a $10,000 wager in Saturday night’s debate over his position on health care?

headline: North Carolina Makes Lone Shot Count to Take the Title
text: HOOVER, Ala. — Ben Speas was a part of last year’s Akron team that won the College Cup. This year, he is the reason the University of North Carolina is bringing the N.C.A.A. men’s soccer championship back to Chapel Hill.

headline: State Takeovers of Other Districts Have Had Mixed Results
text: A state takeover can bring additional resources and expertise to a troubled district, allow for more radical changes, and help deter nepotism, bickering and personal agendas among school board members. But it is usually a last resort because of staunch local opposition.

headline: A Romance With Risk That Brought On a Panic

headline: C.I.A. Leaves Base in Pakistan Used for Drone Strikes
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Central Intelligence Agency has vacated an air base in western Pakistan that it had been using for drone strikes against militants in the country’s tribal areas, the Pakistani military said on Sunday.

headline: Final: Giants 37, Cowboys 34
text: Brandon Jacobs scored on a 1-yard touchdown in the final minute and defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul blocked a field goal attempt on Dallas’s final play as the Giants held off the Cowboys, 37-34, on Sunday night.

headline: Growing Push in Newark to Retake School Reins
text: NEWARK — For a generation of Newark students, every education decision, including choices on curriculum, spending and superintendent, has been made by state officials in Trenton.

headline: Options at Point Guard With Bibby Added
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks finally had enough players for a training-camp scrimmage Sunday, and their practice gym was filled with the squeaking of sneakers and the chatter and cheering of enthusiastic players on two squads, one in white, one in blue.

headline: A Second Exit by Odom Leaves Bryant Grumbling
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — In a dizzying turn that dumbfounded players who were already reeling from the shock of recent events, the Los Angeles Lakers traded the popular veteran Lamar Odom to the Dallas Mavericks for a No. 1 pick and an N.B.A. technicality called a trade exception.

headline: Elected Official, 24, Hopes to Interest Peers in Politics
text: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. — Three blocks up from the historic brick train station — past the Grid Iron Waffle Shop, the grocer and a flock of quaint two- and three-story buildings — Alex Torpey was working at his desk one recent afternoon in South Orange’s Village Hall.

headline: Karzai Says Foreigners Are Responsible for Corruption
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan blamed foreigners on Sunday for the corruption of Afghan officials and demanded that the United States extradite the former chief of the Afghan Central Bank in connection with the collapse of Kabul Bank, the country’s largest financial institution.

headline: An Injustice for Women in Uniform
text: Republican Senate leaders have an odd way of showing gratitude for the dedication and sacrifices of the more than 200,000 women on active duty in the military. Late last month, they blocked consideration of an amendment to the National Defense Authorization Act that would have lifted the statutory ban that denies female service members coverage for abortion care in cases of rape and incest. Currently, military health plans pay for abortions only when a pregnancy endangers a woman’s life.

headline: I Am Eggbert, and I Know Your Name
text: NEW WINDSOR, N.Y. — Alexandria Krol, 5, grew wide-eyed as she walked in the darkness up to the strange-looking egg.

headline: Summitt Still Inspires, Often in Silence
text: The coach who is most credentialed in her sport to speak her mind and was never shy about expressing herself no longer addresses the news media after a game. Such is the new abnormal for Pat Summitt and her famous Tennessee women’s basketball team.

headline: Jets Keeping Drive Alive
text: A capsule look at the Jets’ 37-10 victory over the Chiefs.

headline: Detainee in Iraq Poses a Dilemma as U.S. Exit Nears
text: WASHINGTON — As United States troops prepare to exit Iraq at the end of the month, the Obama administration is facing a significant dilemma over what to do with the last remaining detainee held by the American military in Iraq.

headline: The Unprofitable Skies
text: For travelers facing down another holiday season of crowded flights, American Airlines’ filing for bankruptcy protection may be more bad news. The company’s employees and pensioners are already bracing for job and benefit cuts. Yet the pain brought on by a big bankruptcy is unlikely to transform the industry into a profitable one.

headline: To Find the Perfect New York Mayor, Only 2 Years Left
text: It is recruiting season in New York City, but the targets are not investment banking analysts or college athletes. They are potential candidates for mayor.

headline: Getting Gas Drilling Right
text: After several crowded and often raucous hearings, Gov. Andrew Cuomo agreed to give the public until Jan. 11 to comment on 2,000 pages of environmental analysis and proposed regulations designed to govern natural gas drilling in deep shale formations in New York State. The extension makes sense. The drilling decision is a momentous one, for the environment and the economy, and it is vitally important to get it right.

headline: Depression and Democracy
text: It’s time to start calling the current situation what it is: a depression. True, it’s not a full replay of the Great Depression, but that’s cold comfort. Unemployment in both America and Europe remains disastrously high. Leaders and institutions are increasingly discredited. And democratic values are under siege.

headline: Among Gingrich’s Passions, a Doomsday Vision
text: Newt Gingrich, the Republican presidential hopeful, wants you to know that as commander in chief he is ready to confront one of the most nightmarish of doomsday scenarios: a nuclear blast high above the United States that would instantly throw the nation into a dark age.

headline: The Good Newt
text: Immigration is a subject that brings out the best and the worst in Americans.

headline: After Fatal Shooting of Palestinian, Israeli Soldiers Defended Use of Force Online

headline: A Stark Step Away From Europe
text: LONDON — Has Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain hurt his country’s powerful financial services industry more than he has helped it?

headline: In Florida, Using Military Discipline to Help Veterans in Prison
text: BUSHNELL, Fla. — James R. White, a Marine Corps veteran in a blue uniform, saluted crisply as the honor guard marched around the courtyard, stopped and marched again.

headline: Iran Complains to Afghanistan About U.S. Drone
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Iranian Foreign Ministry expressed its displeasure to Afghanistan’s ambassador to Iran over an American drone aircraft that Iran says flew deep into its airspace and crashed last week, a spokesman for the Afghan Foreign Ministry said Sunday.

headline: Texans Reach Playoffs, but Remain in Shadows
text: When the star pass rusher and the starting quarterback were lost for the season, when the best running back and wide receiver missed time, when the backup quarterback broke his collarbone in his first start, this seemed like another doomed season for the Houston Texans.

headline: The Egg Is Back
text: A talking egg returns as part of a popular Christmas display.

headline: When Truth Survives Free Speech
text: Last week, a story came across my desk that seemed to suggest that a blogger had been unfairly nailed with a $2.5 million defamation award after a judge refused to give her standing as a journalist. A businessman who was the target of the blogger’s inquiries brought the suit.

headline: Reincarnation All Over Again
text: Toward the long-awaited end of the new semirevival of “On a Clear Day You Can See Forever,” which opened on Sunday at the St. James Theater, an eminent psychiatrist proposes that what we have been watching was perhaps only “my own psychoneurotic fantasy.”

headline: In Fighting Drug Test, Braun Faces a Tall Order
text: When Ryan Braun was informed in October that he had tested positive for a substance prohibited under baseball’s drug policy, his legal team set about preparing his appeal.

headline: As Fellow Candidates Mock Romney’s Offer to Bet, Gingrich Holds His Fire
text: AMES, Iowa — Mitt Romney became the target of mocking criticism on Sunday from several of his Republican presidential rivals — except Newt Gingrich, whose silence underscored his growing confidence as the party’s nominating contest enters a critical week featuring the final televised debate of the year.

headline: The Caucus Click: Prerecorded Christmas
text: President Obama, the first lady, Michelle Obama, and their daughters Malia and Sasha took part in the taping of the annual “Christmas in Washington” special at the National Building Museum on Sunday.

headline: South Korean Agency Takes a New Tack on Transformation

headline: Flaws and All, Gingrich Says Life Is an Open Book
text: DES MOINES — Running for president is serious business, Newt Gingrich sometimes says on the stump, so voters should feel free to ask anything — to leaf through his life as if it were an open book.

headline: A Baseball Star Becomes the Hot Topic Amid the Packers’ Undefeated Run
text: GREEN BAY, Wis. — The Green Bay Packers are rock stars in the state of Wisconsin.

headline: Occupy Video Showcases Live Streaming
text: Brad Hunstable started Ustream, an online video platform, with a fellow West Point graduate back in 2007 to help American troops overseas communicate with multiple friends and family members at the same time. It was not long before its uses extended well beyond the military.

headline: Chronic Pain for the Euro
text: VIENNA — The deal on Friday in Brussels to reformulate the rules of the euro zone has probably saved the shared currency for now — but there may be less to it than meets the eye.

headline: Stepan Leads Way as Rangers Cruise Past Florida
text: The Rangers were already ahead Sunday night when Derek Stepan found a little ice to play on, as he put it, and then it was showtime at Madison Square Garden in a victory that illustrated just how strong this team has become.

headline: This Time, It’s Really J. Lo
text: Her last appearance in an ad campaign may have been fraught with controversy, but Jennifer Lopez is at it again. This time, instead of (not) driving a Fiat through the Bronx, Ms. Lopez is walking through a dilapidated mansion in California promoting a home sound system by Harman Kardon.

headline: Grasping at Peace, War Zone of a City Tests Yemen
text: TAIZ, Yemen — Armed tribesmen had finally retreated from a pocket of this city, handing back to the state an education building they had occupied in recent weeks. The governor, elated, called it a breakthrough.

headline: A Leader in the Cloud Gains Rivals
text: SAN FRANCISCO — For over a decade, Marc Benioff has had to listen to dismissals of the company he founded, Salesforce.com, as a marginal player in the business software industry.

text: A weekly recap of the metropolitan area’s three hockey teams…

headline: Physicists Anxiously Await New Data on ‘God Particle’
text: High noon is approaching for the biggest manhunt in the history of physics. At 8 a.m. Eastern time on Tuesday morning, scientists from CERN, the European Center for Nuclear Research, are scheduled to give a progress report on the search for the Higgs boson — infamously known as the “God particle” — whose discovery would vindicate the modern theory of how elementary particles get mass.

text: NYT Front Page for 12/12/2011

headline: Ex-Officer Kills His Wife, a State Tax Agent, in Queens, the Police Say
text: A state tax agent who specialized in investigating the trafficking of illegal cigarettes was shot to death by her husband, a former New York police officer, the authorities said on Sunday.

headline: Price Tag Hindering Congress in Struggle to Pass Year-End Legislation
text: WASHINGTON — The costs of last-minute items pending before Congress are formidable, and lawmakers say that is a major reason they have had so much difficulty reaching a year-end agreement on payroll taxes and other issues.

headline: One Million Mobile Apps, and Counting at a Fast Pace
text: Somewhere at a computer last Wednesday, a developer pushed a button and the one millionth mobile app went to market.

headline: Legislation Would Make New Officers Live in City
text: A bill requiring recruits to the New York Police Department to live in the five boroughs will be introduced in Albany in the coming days — a response, elected officials said, to the vitriolic comments attributed to several police officers on a Facebook page dedicated to the unpleasantness of working at the annual West Indian American Day Parade in Brooklyn on Labor Day weekend.

headline: Texas Elections Are in Limbo Over Redistricting Issue
text: HOUSTON — Jim Landtroop, a freshman Republican who represents a largely rural swath of West Texas in the State House of Representatives, filed for re-election in Austin on Friday afternoon.

headline: Lottery Numbers
In India, Free Speech With Limits
text: Instead of guaranteeing free speech, India’s First Amendment allows the state to regulate it.

headline: Military Children Stay a Step Ahead of Public School Students
text: CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C. — The results are now public from the 2011 federal testing program known as NAEP, the National Assessment of Educational Progress. And once again, schools on the nation’s military bases have outperformed public schools on both reading and math tests for fourth and eighth graders.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 14
text: A look at the Jets’ 37-10 victory over the Kansas City Chiefs.

headline: Partner in British Coalition Criticizes Cameron’s Veto on Europe Treaty
text: LONDON — Serious cracks appeared in Britain’s coalition government on Sunday, when Deputy Prime Minister Nick Clegg, a Liberal Democrat, broke with the government line and said he was “bitterly disappointed” at the outcome of last week’s European summit meeting.

headline: Markets Slide on Euro and Intel
text: Stocks in the United States declined Monday and losses steepened in Europe as investors reassessed last week’s European Union summit meeting and reacted to a new warning that the sovereign debt crisis could get worse.

headline: Police Boat Rescues Dog From the Hudson
text: A dog that ran to retrieve a Frisbee jumped into the Hudson River on Sunday afternoon, but it was quickly rescued by a police boat.

headline: In California, a Plan to Charge Inmates for Their Stay
text: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — A one-night stay in this city’s finest hotel costs $190, complete with sumptuous sheets and a gourmet restaurant. Soon, a twin metal bunk at the county jail, with meals served on plastic trays, will run $142.42.

headline: Disruptions: Privacy Fades in Facebook Era
text: As much as it pains me to say this: privacy is on its deathbed. I came to this sad realization recently when a stranger began leaving comments on photos I had uploaded to Instagram, the iPhone photo-sharing app.

headline: Russian Orthodox Church Adds Influential Voice to Calls for Election Reform
text: MOSCOW — The Russian Orthodox Church added its influential voice over the weekend to calls for a just election process in Russia. The step followed demonstrations across the country that called for a recount or a fresh vote, and outpourings from individual members of the church’s clergy, who reflected popular anger at the flawed Dec. 4 election.

headline: Election Day Is Calm in Ivory Coast
text: Ballot-counting began on Sunday night in Ivory Coast, in the first legislative election in more than a decade. Results were most likely to shore up support for President Alassane Ouattara as he pushes to overhaul the cocoa industry.

headline: Putting a Price on Michael Kors
text: The fashion designer Michael Kors is seeking a luxury price tag on his stock. His company’s initial public offering, expected this week, would value it at up to $3.6 billion. The metrics are in line with Prada, which listed earlier this year. But Michael Kors Holdings may struggle to sustain the growth needed to stay in style with investors.

headline: Inquiry Set on Hospital Fire in India
text: MUMBAI, India (Bloomberg) — West Bengal’s chief minister on Sunday ordered a judge-led investigation into the nation’s worst fire in seven years, Friday’s inferno at the Advanced Medical Research Institute hospital in which 94 people died.

headline: Scandal Over Mediator, a French Weight-Loss Drug, Prompts Calls for Wide Changes
text: PARIS — In 33 years on pharmacy shelves here, the diabetes drug Mediator was prescribed to an estimated five million French patients, many of them diabetics, many others hoping simply to lose weight. When French authorities ordered the drug off the market in 2009, alerted to possible cardiovascular risks, there were 300,000 active prescriptions.

headline: Rob Lowe Lands Another Book Deal
text: One of the unlikely breakout publishing stars of 2011 was the actor Rob Lowe, whose memoir, “Stories I Only Tell My Friends,” spent months on the New York Times best-seller list and was praised by critics for an intelligence and humor that surpassed that of the typical celebrity book. Seven months after that debut, Mr. Lowe has made another book deal, this time with Simon & Schuster, for “Love Life,” a book that will focus on topics including “sex, marriage, money, work, fatherhood and sports, drawing upon Mr. Lowe’s own experiences and observations,” the publisher is to announce on Monday. “The first book proved that Rob Lowe is a great storyteller,” Jonathan Karp, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, said in a statement. “The second book will prove that he can write about anything and continue to captivate readers.” The book is expected to be released in 2013.

headline: BuzzFeed Adds Politico Writer
text: BuzzFeed, a site where the editors and algorithms sift the Web in search of viral articles elsewhere, has decided that it needs articles of its own.

headline: Word of the Day | delete
text: delete •\di-ˈlet, de-\• verb

headline: Let’s Not Talk About Inequality
text: Conservatism’s strength, its stress on the value of individual responsibility, is also its central weakness.

headline: Jets Face a Future Without Leonhard
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. – At Eric Smith’s locker after the Jets’ victory Sunday, one topic was off-limits, and it had nothing to do with the playoffs. Smith declined to answer any questions about Jim Leonhard, who hurt his right knee after a second-quarter interception. Smith did not know the severity of Leonhard’s injury, he said, so don’t bother asking. He did not want to speculate.

headline: Giants Ice Cowboys and Their Skid
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Brandon Jacobs pushed his way through the line, churning his legs and pumping his arms and straining for the end zone, his torso bowed as if the whole of the Giants’ season was lying across his back. And it was.

headline: Giants Replay: Week 14
text: A look at the Giants’ 37-34 victory over the Dallas Cowboys.

headline: In CBS Interview, Obama Makes Case for Second Term
text: President Obama on Sunday continued his populist fusillade, asserting during an appearance on “60 Minutes” on CBS that Republicans in Congress were protecting the wealthy at the expense of the middle class.

headline: The Long View: Parliamentary Paralysis
text: For nearly three weeks now, the Indian Parliament has resembled a patient in a coma, its faculties frozen, its strength ebbing, with no flickers of consciousness at all. The doctors profess themselves flummoxed. No business has been transacted in the winter session of the upper and lower houses at all; instead, the opposition has substituted debate with stubborn rabble-rousing, while the government has flailed weakly against a phalanx of internal crises.One news report has estimated that the time lost by disruptions and adjournments has already cost the taxpayer more than Rs 250 million. Improbably, this paralysis has even prompted a member of Parliament – Shashi Tharoor, in an article for Tehelka – to propose doing away with his own institution, a public gesture of limp-handed helplessness if there ever was one.

headline: Terence Winter Looks Back on the Mother of All ‘Boardwalk Empire’ Seasons
text: Warning: this post contains spoilers and a gratuitous reference to “The Walking Dead.”

headline: ‘Good Wife’ Watch: Oh, That’s What Friends Are For
text: In the aftermath of Alicia’s break-up last week, the theme of “What Went Wrong,” Sunday night’s episode of “The Good Wife,” was friendship — specifically, the need for working women to band together to counteract isolation, loneliness, chauvinism and suspicion. The title referred to the case of the week, which Lockhart Gardner lost, sort of, but also to Alicia’s life through 11 episodes this season. How did she get to this point — without Will, estranged from Kalinda, freaked out about Grace?

headline: Cowboys Find Another Agonizing Way to Lose
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Helmets off, heads dropped seemingly in disbelief, several Dallas Cowboys defensive players trudged stone-faced to the sideline with 46 seconds to play after the Giants rallied for a 37-34 lead.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 12, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Chinese Fisherman Kills South Korean Coast Guardsman
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A South Korean Coast Guard member was stabbed to death by a Chinese fisherman on Monday during a crackdown on illegal fishing near South Korea, the Coast Guard said.

headline: Cameron Says His Veto on Europe Treaty Protects Britain

headline: Dec. 12, 1963 | Kenya Gains Independence
text: On Dec. 12, 1963, Kenya gained its independence from Britain. “With Britain’s Union Jack replaced by the black, red and green flag of the new states, political power in Britain’s last East African colonial holding slipped from the grasp of its 55,759 whites and was taken up by its 8,365,942 Africans,” wrote The New York Times.

headline: Packers-Raiders: Too Long for Replay, Too Long to Play
text: Anyone who tuned in to see President Obama on “60 Minutes” on Sunday night had to wait essentially an entire television time slot while the Packers’ 46-16 victory over the Raiders wrapped up. The high volume of scoring prolonged the contest, but more time-consuming were the instant replays. Perhaps CBS’s N.F.L. and “60 Minutes” viewers could be appeased if Scott Pelley or Lesley Stahl did an investigation on what in the world happened to the league’s pledge to keep replays under 90 seconds.

headline: Are We Losing the Art of Listening?
text: Listening, like other skills, can be developed through practice, or lost if not used regularly. Good listeners focus on what they are hearing. They pause to think about what they’ve heard before responding. They ask questions because they want to know the answers, not just to keep the conversation going. Do you often find yourself in the company of good listeners? Would you describe yourself as a good listener? Why or why not?In the op-ed piece “The Art of Listening,” Henning Mankell writes about what he has learned from living a “straddled existence, with one foot in African sand and the other in European snow”:

headline: New Delhi’s Controversial Birth
text: Few cities of recent vintage have a history as complicated and contested as New Delhi, which turned 100 on Monday. Now the seat of the world’s largest democracy, New Delhi began in 1911 as a grand imperial showpiece meant to stand for eternal British rule over the Indian subcontinent. But during its two decades of construction New Delhi became the stage upon which Indians gained increasing political advantage over a crumbling Raj.

headline: L.S.E. Group to Buy Remainder of FTSE
text: LONDON — The London Stock Exchange Group agreed on Monday to buy the 50 percent of the financial index business FTSE International it did not already own for £450 million ($701 million) from the publishing house Pearson.

headline: The Power and Grace of Jason Pierre-Paul
text: The NBC analyst Cris Collinsworth said it best Sunday night: If Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul is not in the Pro Bowl, there should be an investigation. And this isn’t just because of Pierre-Paul’s otherworldly performance Sunday night, in which he started the game with a safety (the nice thing about a 2-0 score is it sets the table for a lot of lead changes – this game had eight) and finished it with a blocked field goal.

headline: Complaint Box | Pseudo Green
text: Everybody is an environmentalist. There are very few who would walk the plank and claim otherwise. These days it is cool to be eco-friendly and green. Most of my friends are. They use eco-friendly products, shun pesticides, chemical fertilizers, eat organically and celebrate Earth Day. Interestingly, most have elephant-sized carbon footprints.

headline: Rumor Fever
text: HONG KONG — China hosts some 300 million microblog accounts (including my own), and officials say that domestic social media put out more than 200 million posts every day. In hopes of getting a handle on this potentially threatening surge of information, the government has started a campaign that aims to quash what it calls “rumors” — statements that it says threaten the public order but that it has not bothered to define. After a series of public opinion disasters this past year, the Communist Party has been pressuring social media providers to weed out allegations it finds threatening, and state media have tried to whip up fear over their malignant social effects.The party’s fever over rumors began in August, following the July 23 high-speed rail collision in Wenzhou. The government took a public opinion beating over the crash, in large part because social media harnessed anger over the bungled rescue effort, the safety of the high-speed rail network and corruption in the Railways Ministry. Once party leaders wrested back control of the story, they pushed all relevant facts into the darkness, leaving only rumors to sate the public’s appetite for the truth. And this summer two other embarrassing public opinion defeats for China’s leadership originally took off on the Internet: the Guo Meimei affair, which exposed irregularities at the government-run Red Cross Society of China, and the massive and well-organized public demonstrations against a chemical project in Dalian.

headline: Veterans in Prison Get Help in Florida Program
text: Officials have created separate dorms for veterans at five prisons in an effort to help ease their transition after their release and curb recidivism.

headline: A Year-End Candidate for a 10 Worst List
text: When I was 15, slightly more than a decade or two ago, I went with a friend on New Year’s Eve to watch the ball drop in Times Square. It wasn’t the dumbest thing I’ve ever done, not by a long shot. But there are good reasons why, slightly more than a decade or two later, I haven’t repeated the experience. New Year’s Eve can be tough enough. Why make matters worse by standing for hours in the cold, packed together with thousands upon thousands of strangers?

headline: House Democrats Bullish on 2012 Prospects

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 12
text: The characters in “Game of Thrones,” the HBO series from the fantasy novels of George R. R. Martin, speak Dothraki, a language with more than 3,250 words. Dothraki was created by David J. Peterson, a 30-year-old “conlanger,” a person who constructs new languages. (Of course, even “real” languages are products of invention – for example, my dictionary doesn’t have the world “conlanger.”) The lengths the producers have gone to have a consistent language, Amy Chozick writes, represents Hollywood’s growing need “to infuse fantasy and science-fiction movies, television series and video games with a sense of believability.” It was true for “Avatar,” which included a robust language, Na’vi, that was spoken by the giant blue inhabitants of Pandora. The inventor of Na’vi is developing a Martian language called Barsoomian for “John Carter,” a science-fiction movie from Disney.

headline: Russian Mogul Joins the Race Against Putin
text: MOSCOW — There were no balloons or streamers at the hastily arranged news conference on Monday where Mikhail D. Prokhorov announced that he would challenge Vladimir V. Putin in this spring’s presidential elections: just Mr. Prokhorov on the podium, looking grave.

They are the curators of the Archive of Spatial Aesthetics and Praxis, or ASAP, an online archive that was founded by DiCarlo in 2010 with the goal of “collecting and exhibiting architecture as part of a broader social, political and aesthetic discourse.”

headline: No Draghi Ex Machina
text: So last week European leaders announced a plan that, on the face of it, was pure nonsense. Faced with a crisis that is mainly about the balance of payments, with fiscal crisis as a secondary consequence, they supposedly committed everyone to severe fiscal austerity, which would guarantee a recession while leaving the real problem unaddressed.

headline: Leading Off: Comebacks Are All in the Believing
text: After the N.F.L. produced not one, but two breathtaking comebacks with season-rattling implications, it was hard not to marvel at the quarterbacks who made them happen. Yes, both men got a lot of help. Eli Manning would not be king of a saved Giants season had Jason Pierre-Paul not blocked a field goal attempt in the final second that would have sent the Cowboys to overtime, and Tim Tebow would not be doing another victory/prayer lap had Matt Prater not kicked a 59-yarder to get the Broncos to overtime.

headline: The Loaves of New York

Rob Patronite and Robin Raisfeld pick their 13 favorite breads from bakeries (La Boulangerie, Nordic Breads) and restaurants (Roberta’s, Vandaag). There’s a name-that-loaf (and knot)  slide show, a short primer on the  qualities of good bread, a timeline  back beyond the Hessian-fly infestation of the 1780’s, and a profile of Sullivan Street Bakery‘s Jim Lahey, uncensored.

headline: Amazon Denies It Has a Small-Business Problem
text: For years — since its inception — Amazon has been at implicit war with local brick-and-mortar stores. Last week, the implicit seemingly became explicit when Amazon began a promotion that encouraged customers to check out prices at local retailers and use a specially designed “Price Check” smartphone app to report what they found back to Amazon. Customers who then purchased the same item from Amazon received a 5 percent discount, up to $5. (The deal was available only from Friday night through Saturday, and only for certain kinds of products.)

headline: The Simplest Roast Duck
text: Despite its reputation as a complicated bird, crisp-skinned, juicy-fleshed duck is nearly as easy to achieve as chicken, but it is far more festive and flavorful. This video shows what is just about the easiest way I know to roast one: just prick the skin all over with a knife, season liberally and roast until the surface is burnished and crackling. It’s perfect to serve for the holidays and all winter long.

headline: Think of ‘Rango’ as a 3-D Movie Without the Glasses
text: With a slew of critics’ groups recommending it, “Rango” is quickly becoming the leader of the pack for the animation Oscar. Directed by Gore Verbinski (the first three “Pirates of the Caribbean”), the story of a chameleon adrift in a frontier town is a richly detailed, clever western full of film references and adult jokes. As the first feature-length animated movie from the effects wizards at Industrial Light & Magic, it’s also a rare 2-D contender in a field increasingly dominated by 3-D films (“The Adventures of Tintin,” “Arthur Christmas”).

headline: Vegetable Soups, Smooth and Hearty
text: Puréed vegetable soups satisfy my craving for comfort food and prove the point that a dish doesn’t have to be rich, heavy or meaty to be comforting and filling. The classic French model is a rich affair, usually finished with cream, crème frâiche or a béchamel. But a potato or a half cup of rice added to the soup with the vegetables is just as efficient a thickener.

headline: Final Rules Set for Insurers on Spending Ratios

headline: St. Ann’s Warehouse Signs Lease for New Space in Dumbo
text: St. Ann’s Warehouse, the Brooklyn theater that has provided a home for highly regarded productions including “Black Watch” and “Misterman,” will itself continue to have a home in Dumbo, not far from its current location in that neighborhood. The theater said on Monday that it had signed a three-year lease for a new space at 29 Jay Street, where it plans to open next fall after leaving its longtime base of operations at 38 Water Street following the conclusion of its current season in May.

headline: Congo President Kabila Denies Reports of Election Fraud
