headline: U.S. Judge Grants Delay in Challenge to AT&T Deal
text: WASHINGTON — AT&T has one month to tell a Federal District Court judge and the Justice Department whether it will pursue its proposed $39 billion acquisition of T-Mobile USA in its current form, in a modified structure, or if it will drop the deal altogether.

headline: For Sale (Again): the Orson Welles Oscar
text: LOS ANGELES — The Orson Welles Oscar is back on the block. The Nate D. Sanders auction house here says it is selling the screenwriting Oscar that was awarded to Welles in 1942 for his work, with Herman J. Mankiewicz, on “Citizen Kane.” The statuette was best known in recent years as the subject of a court fight in which Welles’s daughter — having recovered it from a cinematographer who said Welles had given it to him as a gift — defeated an effort by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to block a sale.

headline: ‘I’d Be Happy to Share My Thoughts and Experiences as We Go Down’
text: On Dec. 10, 2009, I was sitting at my desk, reading this blog — I think it was a post by Jay Goltz. My business was not doing well. His was struggling, too, but clearly he wasn’t as close to the edge as I was. I sent the following e-mail to the editor of this blog:

headline: An Extension, and a Move, for ‘Venus in Fur’
text: The Broadway production of the David Ives play “Venus in Fur,” starring Nina Arianda and Hugh Dancy, will take a break after ending its run at the Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Sunday and resume performances at the Lyceum Theater on Feb. 7, 2012, for a limited engagement through June 17.

headline: The Life Report: Ann Bless
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives.

headline: The Twice-Victimized of Sexual Assault
text: Nearly every woman I know can recall one or more instances in which she was sexually assaulted, harassed, threatened, inappropriately touched or even raped.

headline: Intel Expects Lower Revenue Because of Drive Shortage
text: Intel has announced that it expects revenue in the fourth quarter to be 7 percent less than expected, or  $1 billion.

headline: Critics’ Picks Video: ‘Pulp Fiction’
text: This week, A.O. Scott looks back at Quentin Tarantino‘s seminal 1994 feature, “Pulp Fiction.” Using interlocking stories to recount the lives and travails of a selection of Los Angeles criminals, the film “defined, for a new generation, how a movie could be cool,” Mr. Scott says. Mr. Tarantino, a devoted film fan and former video-store clerk, used his encyclopedic knowledge of cinema to pay homage to the movies he loved, while also creating an original style that would become influential to many filmmakers.

headline: Iran Is Asked to Return U.S. Drone
text: President Obama said on Monday that the United States had asked Iran to return an American surveillance drone that the Iranians say they captured on Dec. 4. It was Mr. Obama’s first public comment about the drone, a remote-controlled spying aircraft, in a case that has raised American tensions with Iran.

headline: Gingrich Endorses ‘Marriage Pledge’
text: Newt Gingrich became the latest Republican candidate to endorse the so-called marriage pledge, a controversial document put forward by an influential evangelical group in Iowa that opposes same-sex marriage and abortion.

headline: Google Acquisition of Motorola Delayed in Europe
text: BRUSSELS — European antitrust regulators have suspended their investigation into Google’s acquisition of Motorola Mobility, a maker of smartphones, until Google provides additional evidence in the case, the European Commission said Monday.

headline: In Debate About Fighting in Hockey, Medical Experts Weigh In
text: The determination that the hockey enforcer Derek Boogaard had a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated hits to the head when he died in May at 28 has fueled a debate among medical experts over whether the sport should ban fighting.

headline: Two Die in Suspected Murder-Suicide in Chelsea
text: Two men were fatally shot in a public housing building in Chelsea on Monday morning, the police said. The police said the shooting appeared to be a murder-suicide.

headline: Rethinking Your Approach to the Tooth Fairy
text: In the Styles section of The New York Times this weekend, Bruce Feiler goes after the tooth fairy. What could be wrong with the tooth fairy? Plenty, he argues.

headline: Meryl Streep, Cover Girl
text: You’d think by this point Meryl Streep would have accomplished every possible feat in her professional life. But early on Monday afternoon, Ms. Streep added one or two more. She was a trending topic on Twitter (at least in New York), off the news of another first: her first Vogue cover, at age 62. Photographed by Annie Leibovitz, she’s sitting in the surf on a beach and later “striding through a crop of organic broccoli sustainably farmed” in upstate New York, according to the accompanying story. In it, she talks about feminism, politics and campaigning for a National Women’s History Museum, for which she donated $1 million.

headline: Romney-Gingrich Skirmishing Intensifies
text: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney both campaigned hard in New Hampshire on Monday, and the two Republican leaders in the polls looked like they could go 15 rounds before the day was finished.

headline: Crosby Sidelined Indefinitely by Return of Symptoms
text: Sidney Crosby, the N.H.L.’s biggest star, said Monday that he was experiencing concussion symptoms again and that he would sit out indefinitely.

headline: Lens: Maggie Taylor
text: Lens: Maggie Taylor

headline: What Goes With Glogg? Swedish Gingersnaps
text: When I heard that the talented Swedish photographer Marcus Nilsson was shooting the still-life for my column on glogg, I knew he’d get it just right: he grew up with glogg, after all. He also grew up with pepparkakor — the spicy, buttery gingersnaps that often accompany glogg — and offered to share his mom’s recipe. “I was born in spring 1972, and she started making gingersnaps that Christmas,” Nilsson told me. Since then, he said, “she has used the same recipe every year. They’re amazing.”

headline: Acura Prepares Product Blitz, Including NSX Concept, for Detroit Auto Show
text: Acura, a brand that has largely been overlooked by luxury buyers wooed by products from Lexus, Infiniti and the German manufacturers, intends to become a player again.

headline: Ray Eames: How She Dressed
text: To design aficionados the name Charles Eames conjures an image of the screen-idol handsome design visionary, studiedly natty in his tweed coats and bow ties. The figure of Ray, his wife and collaborator, is somewhat more elusive. But now a new documentary, “Eames: The Architect and the Painter,” brings Ray into sharper focus, the filmmakers Jason Cohn and Bill Jersey training their sights on her personal style, a quirky composite of diffidence and daring.

headline: Some Holiday Cheer for Homeless Families
text: On the Sunday between Black Friday and Cyber Monday, “60 Minutes” broadcast a story called “Hard Times Generation.” Homeless teens Arielle and Austin Metzger described living in their dad’s van, brushing their teeth in service stations and “doing what they can to get by” with touching self-possession and gratitude for what they did have — school, their dad, and one another. Younger kids, gathered in small forum at a local school, discussed living without a permanent home — staying up all night in the back seat to watch over a sleeping mother to “keep her safe”; moving into a hotel (and agreeing to repaint all of its rooms) for shelter.

headline: Modern Warfare 3 Passes $1 Billion in Sales in 16 Days
text: Modern Warfare 3, the first-person shooter video game, passed $1 billion in sales in just 16 days, according to Activision Blizzard, the game’s distributor. Modern Warfare 2, an earlier installment of the game, took 60 days to reach the same milestone.

headline: Learning How to Kill Trees
text: Scientists trying to understand the future of forests on a warming planet have a strange problem: They do not know how to kill trees.

headline: Asked & Answered | André Saraiva
text: The French graffiti artist, night-life impresario and hotel entrepreneur André Saraiva this year turned his talents to filmmaking, released a CD with Kitsuné, teamed up with Levi’s to create a jacket for MoCA’s “Art in the Streets” exhibition, became creative director of L’Officiel Hommes and opened a London location of his Paris nightclub, Le Baron. With all this going on, it’s little wonder New York is still waiting for its version of Saraiva’s famously hedonistic club — “my Christmas present to New York” —  rumored to be opening on Mulberry Street before the end of the year. The Moment grabbed Saraiva for a few minutes to get the lowdown on what makes a Le Baron party.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.12
text: The world sailing championships continued off Fremantle, Australia, and the Arab Games continued in Doha, Qatar.

headline: The Evangelical Bloc in Iowa
text: Divisions among Iowa's social conservatives are providing an opportunity for their least favored candidate, Mitt Romney.

headline: Class Parent: Mama, What Is Our Culture?
text: Because of baby sitter/husband communication bobbles, our undecorated flags were apparently sitting on the kitchen table rather than ready for posting outside my twins' prekindergarten classroom. No problem, the teachers said, bring them Monday. But I did have a problem: What is our culture, and how could we possibly depict it on a flag?

headline: Protest Reaches 900 Principals, and Climbing
text: The number of principals who have signed onto a letter objecting to New York State’s system of teacher evaluations has grown by 150 in the last week.

headline: The Big Sleep
text: Q. Ever since childhood, I have needed more sleep than most. Why do some people need so much more sleep than others?

headline: Another Deal for Hornets’ Chris Paul Is Off
text: 3:55 p.m. | Updated LOS ANGELES — After 24 hours as the new front-runner in the hunt for Chris Paul, the Clippers fell by the wayside Monday.

headline: Solar Walk: The Best — Maybe Only — Reason to Get a 3-D TV
text: To date, I still don’t get 3-D TV. I mean, I understand it, but I fail to see the appeal.

headline: Iowa Evangelicals Split Over Caucus Endorsement
text: DES MOINES — Bob Vander Plaats, president of the Family Leader, a conservative advocacy group popular with evangelical Christians here, has been saying supportive things recently about Newt Gingrich, suggesting that social conservatives are open to looking past his extramarital affairs and two divorces as they make a choice in the Republican presidential race.

headline: James & Richard
text: In this homemade video, James Li and Richard Dowling discuss how music brought them together at Yale University 25 years ago.

headline: Jets’ Leonhard Out for Season Once Again
text: Jim Leonhard accepted words of encouragement from his teammates Monday in a crowded training room at the Jets’ facility in Florham Park, N.J. He seemed upbeat and in good spirits, Antonio Cromartie said, though no one could fault Leonhard for wondering just what he had done to deserve this.

headline: Division II’s Football Cinderella: Wayne State
text: In one of those magical, improbable playoff runs that helps renew faith in the joy of sports, Wayne State University’s football team has pushed itself to the Division II national title game, after having never made the playoffs before this season.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Cunningham Company at the Kennedy Center
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year legacy tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 22nd in a series of graphite drawings that Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from the Kennedy Center in Washington.

headline: ‘Young Adult’ and the Path Not Taken
text: Some of the funnest pit stops on the promotional circuit so far this season have been the ones involving the “Young Adult” crew. Since their collaboration on “Juno,” the writer Diablo Cody and the director Jason Reitman have had a sardonic but sweet vibe; they don’t take themselves too seriously. And there’s a buddy comedy waiting to happen in the rapport between the film’s stars, Charlize Theron and Patton Oswalt.

headline: Compare-Contrast, Cause-Effect, Problem-Solution: Common ‘Text Types’ in The Times
text: Update | Sept. 2012: We’ll be exploring the new Common Core State Standards, and how teaching with The Times can address them, through a series of blog posts. You can find them all here, in the lesson plan category “Common Core.”

headline: A Final Farewell to François Lesage
text: Suzy Menkes speaks to designers, from Karl Lagerfeld to Anne Valérie Hash, about the master embroiderer, whose name became synonymous with craftsmanship.

headline: Unwanted Homes, Unwanted Workers
text: Once upon a time, housing looked like a rare, highly valued asset; now, the market has been flooded with unwanted homes. And as I wrote in an article Sunday, economic forces have helped reallocate those excess houses to more productive (and non-residential) uses, like a park, work of art or marijuana garden.

headline: Imagining 2076: Connect Your Brain to the Internet
text: The future, it turns out, starts in 2020.

headline: Bloomberg Criticizes Decision on Morning-After Pill
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Monday that the Obama administration was wrong not to legalize over-the-counter sales of an after-sex contraception to girls under 17.

headline: I Solemnly Pledge to Be Good as Can Be
text: We’ve reached that phase in the primary season when the candidates start intensely publicizing their private lives. (Usually this comes right before the phase where they berate news organizations for covering their wives and children.) This rite of passage is considerably more comfortable for some candidates than others (and by “others” I mean Newt Gingrich).

headline: Unpivoting Obama
text: I learned much of what I know about the political economy of the Second Gilded Age from Tom Edsall. Writing for Campaign Stops, Edsall has some important things to say about how economic narratives will play next year. He argues that the polling data

headline: Tax Policy Blowing in the Wind
text: If you want something from Congress, there are probably only about four shopping days left until Christmas, because most members of the House and Senate seem likely to go home on Friday. One big item on the green list is an extension of the production tax credit for wind energy, and the industry’s trade association, the American Wind Energy Association, released a dire study on Monday about what will happen without it.

headline: The Joy of Feeding, Without All the Parental Angst
text: Back before computers moved into our exam rooms, I tended paper growth charts ritually at every checkup. Pink for girls, blue for boys. Age on the X-axis, weight on the Y-axis. I paid particular attention to the charts of infants, plotting weight and length and head circumference with my pen month by month to show parents how their babies were growing, to reassure them when they worried that there wasn’t enough breast milk or because their babies were spitting up a little.

headline: Fairy Tale May Be Ending for ABC; ‘Sunday Night Football’ Rolls On for NBC
text: Is it possible that television viewers are no longer entranced by “Once Upon a Time” on ABC? The fantasy drama had a strong premiere and averaged 11.9 million viewers over its first four episodes, but the numbers have steadily dropped over the last month, culminating in series lows in total viewers (8.9 million) and in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on Sunday night. The series will take a holiday breather and hope to reverse the trend starting Jan. 8.

headline: Damascus on the Edge
text: A young writer living in Syria’s capital city has agreed to share some observations of the uprisings and subsequent crackdowns happening across the country. Damascus so far has avoided much of the conflict, but hints of the ongoing instability taunt its citizens. We have withheld the writer’s name for security reasons.

headline: Brewers, Potentially Leaking Sluggers, Sign Ramirez
text: 10:13 p.m. | Updated

headline: Power Savings on Auto Pilot
text: Most hotel chains delayed significant energy conservation moves during the economic downturn, but now one, Marriott International, has signed a deal to reduce its hotels’ energy use, particularly during times of peak demand.

headline: The Limits of Bigger Penalties in Fighting Financial Crime
text: President Obama, in a speech last week, called for strengthened oversight and accountability of financial firms by increasing the punishments that can be imposed for criminal violations. This comes on top of a recent proposal by Mary L. Schapiro, the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to ratchet up the available civil penalties for violating the securities laws.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Stiefel Labs and Its Ex-Chief of Fraud
text: 7:40 p.m. | Updated

headline: Is Manning the League’s M.V.P.?
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — Brandon Jacobs cracked a few jokes in the interview room late Sunday night, laughing about how he isn’t so young anymore and chuckling over his decision – which turned out well in the end – to try and hurdle over a would-be tackler on one of his runs.

headline: Snakebite: Experts Seek New Emphasis on Quiet Killer
text: Snakebite isn’t exactly a neglected disease, but since many victims die for lack of the right medicine, the World Health Organization recognized it as such two years ago.

headline: TimesCast | Protests at Goldman Sachs
text: Occupy Wall Street protesters picket Goldman Sachs.

headline: Politics and Protest in Papier-Mâché Heads
text: Peter Schumann’s Bread and Puppet company, a staple of the Off Off Broadway calendar for 40 years, is a refreshing reminder of the vitality and power of street theater. Part carnival, part protest, all pageant, Bread and Puppet productions express political outrage and satire, sometimes coarse and raw.

headline: Why Some People Sleep More Than Others
text: Excessively long nights of sleep can be a sign that something is wrong. But in some people who are otherwise healthy, a need for unusually long amounts of sleep may simply be a genetic predisposition, writes C. Claiborne Ray in this week’s Science Times.

headline: Prevention: Trial Vaccine for Norovirus Shows Promise
text: An experimental vaccine has been shown in a small study to protect people from norovirus, infamous for sickening hundreds in outbreaks aboard cruise ships.

headline: Patterns: Coffee May Help Cut Cancer Risk in Women
text: More good news for coffee drinkers: A large new study has found that women who drink four or more cups of coffee a day are at reduced risk of endometrial cancer.

headline: Regimens: Aspirin’s Benefits Before Heart Surgery
text: Current guidelines recommend that people preparing for surgery stop taking aspirin at least a week before the operation, because the drug can increase the risk for bleeding. But a new analysis suggests that in heart surgery, aspirin’s benefits substantially outweigh its risks.

headline: Beware of Raw Cookie Dough
text: Turns out mom was right: Keep your hands off the raw cookie dough.

headline: Bentley’s New V-8 Will Growl With a German Accent
text: Bentley Motors announced Monday that it would introduce a 500-horsepower twin-turbo V-8 engine for its Continental GT coupe and GTC convertible models at the Detroit auto show in January. Both automobiles will retain the W-12 engine as a higher-priced option.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, Bulgaria and Spain.

headline: ‘Detroit’ Rerouted Off Broadway for New York Debut
text: Though at one point talked up for Broadway, Lisa D’Amour’s “Detroit,” a finalist for the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in drama, will open the 2012-13 season at Playwrights Horizons, officials at the Off Broadway theater said on Monday.

headline: Drug Scarcity’s Dire Cost, and Some Ways to Cope
text: When Jenny Morrill, who has been battling ovarian cancer since 2007, went to the hospital for her scheduled chemotherapy treatment in June, the nurse greeted her with both good news and bad.

headline: Talking to Parents About Fat Babies
text: Obesity in teenagers and adolescents is a major concern for pediatricians. But the discussion gets tricky when it turns to a weight crisis in infants. As Dr. Perri Klass explains in this week’s Science Times, experts on child nutrition are debating whether some of the standard infant feeding practices and attitudes may be in need of revising, particularly the notion of getting infants to eat as much as possible.

headline: After a Fainting Spell, Learning to Fly Again
text: A FEW years ago, I was working on a proposal for a wedding while I was traveling. My seatmate was a young woman who had this huge accordion folder on her lap. There must have been a million files in it, all related to her wedding.

headline: TimesCast | Billionaire Challenges Putin
text: Russian billionaire and NBA team owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov makes a surprise challenge to Vladimir Putin’s presidential run.

headline: Top Earners Not So Lofty in the Days of Recession
text: WASHINGTON — Hold the condolence cards, but the recession cost the rich.

headline: A Measure of Restraint
text: A STATEMENT black leather belt can be the quick fix you need this holiday season. “With tailored high-waist trousers and a sheer blouse or crisp button-down, a bold belt will cinch the whole look,” said the stylist Kathryn Typaldos. If you’re heading straight out from work, Ms. Typaldos suggests adding a black belt to a tunic or a dress with a waistline. “The belt will add structure and refinement,” she said. These three styles — a wide corset wrap, a belt with a quirky feather trim and a patent leather one with a playful origami animal head — capture just the right amount of flare. Add lipstick and you’re off.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Russia, South Korea, Spain and Britain.

headline: Uganda-Canada Game to Happen After All
text: Organizers hoping to send the Canadian team to play the Ugandan team that was kept from the Little League World Series because the players’ visas were denied have announced they have raised enough money to make the trip happen.

headline: For Bridge Built Long Ago, No End to Repairs
text: On Monday, the Henry Hudson Bridge – that triumphalist crossing over the Harlem River, a steel archway slicing through a verdant vista of water, trees and cliffs – celebrates its diamond anniversary, the 75th. And like many older citizens of New York City, the bridge has had its share of wear-and-tear.

headline: A century at the South Pole, the gift of giving and the dangers of using your head.
text: A century at the South Pole, the gift of giving and the dangers of using your head.

headline: A Post-Pollution Path to Global Climate and Energy Progress
text: Some hard realities are being acknowledged as diplomats, scientists, scholars and others ponder next steps following the indeterminate Durban climate negotiations — the latest failed attempt to limit climate risk using pollution-style restrictions on carbon dioxide under a global treaty.

headline: Fox News Anchor Pushes Paid Family Leave
text: Megyn Kelly, a Fox News anchor, is proudly and unabashedly a working mother. As Pamela Paul wrote in the Sunday Styles section, the new generation of female news anchors juggles career and family life “full-throttle in front of millions of viewers,” and Ms. Kelly has become a surprising ambassador for working mothers. When Mike Gallagher, a conservative radio talk show host, mocked her three-month maternity leave, calling it a “racket,” Ms. Fox invited him onto her program and confronted him.

headline: Chairman of Credit Suisse’s Investment Banking to Leave
text: Marc D. Granetz, the chairman of Credit Suisse‘s investment banking department and a longtime mergers banker, is leaving the firm for another opportunity outside deal-making, according to an internal memorandum reviewed by DealBook.

headline: Deconstructing the Bouffant and the Bland
text: The title of Ann Beattie’s new book, “Mrs. Nixon: A Novelist Imagines a Life,” suggests that the author might be trying to channel Pat Nixon or conjure up her life with Dick, much the way Curtis Sittenfeld channeled a Laura Bush-like first lady in her 2008 novel, “American Wife.”

headline: Executive Shuffle in Microsoft Mobile Group
text: Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, has replaced the head of the company’s mobile phone group as it seeks to translate the critical success of its mobile software into strong sales.

headline: Q&A: Seeking a Picture-Perfect Tablet
text: Q.

headline: Drug-Testing and Probable Cause, a Response to Readers
text: My post today about a proposal to allow drug testing of  anyone collecting unemployment benefits produced a few comments along these lines: I had to submit to a drug test for my new job. What’s the difference?

headline: Time-Travel Tip for Constantinople: Pack Daggers
text: And when the game studios come before you, you shall judge them by their sequels.

headline: Chiefs Fire Coach, and Then Dolphins Follow Suit
text: The day after the N.F.L. regular season ends is known as Black Monday, because it is a bleak day when failed head coaches are sent packing. Black Monday came three weeks early this season, with the Kansas City Chiefs firing Todd Haley and the Miami Dolphins following a few hours later by dismissing Tony Sparano.

headline: YouTube Creates Separate Site for Schools
text: With many schools blocking access to YouTube as a way to protect students from content that is inappropriate, or worse, the online video site opened a new network that allows access only to content that can be used in the classroom.

headline: Out-of-School Time Program Faces Deep Cuts
text: An after-school program started under Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in 2005 is facing a budget cut of more than 20 percent, which some people say could cut nearly in half the number of seats for children next year. A reduction in city financing is coming even as costs for each child are going up.

headline: On a Long Train Trip, Rare Pleasures Return
text: I TRAVELED from Tampa, Fla., to Manhattan over the weekend. What a pleasure! Nobody hollered at me to sit down or turn off my electronic devices. Nobody warned me to obey all instructions from crew members.

headline: Jazz Musicians Start a Pension Push
text: New York City’s musicians’ union has begun leafleting outside a major jazz club, the first salvo in what union leaders say is a campaign to gain pension benefits and a minimum wage for jazz artists.

headline: Seeking Art in Clumsiness, or Sticking Out Tongues
text: Around 2008, foundations began throwing money at Chris Elam and his Misnomer Dance Theater: $150,000 here, $1 million there. Most of this windfall, however, wasn’t intended to honor or support Mr. Elam’s choreography directly. The money was meant to finance his projects for connecting with audiences online, particularly one called the Audience Engagement Platform.

headline: U.S. National Team Performance Review: A Seven-Game Snapshot
text: The composite player ratings (CPR) we introduced a few weeks back are not rocket science. In fact, they are not science at all.

headline: Metal, Doom and Gloom Included
text: St. Vitus, a new metal club, opened in the late spring near the northernmost point of Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a block from the Pulaski Bridge. Outside, a black unmarked door. Inside, the Age of Enlightenment: local craft ales, a “bun bar,” a small square room with a stage in back. “What more could you want?” reads a recent comment on the bar’s Yelp page. “You’re standing there watching sludge metal like COFFINWORM live and munching on a vegan sausage bao ... it’s like living the DREAM.”

headline: Rarely Heard Offerings From Busoni and Liszt
text: In the 19 years he has conducted the American Symphony Orchestra Leon Botstein has been at his best when his programs have been built around unusual works that deserve to be heard more often. With that as a goal, it’s easy to run off the rails: works that seemed promising on paper, or even in rehearsal, can turn out to have been neglected with good cause. Others may have been worthy but failed to make their mark because inadequate rehearsal time, or other technical issues, made it impossible for the orchestra to show the scores at their best.

headline: Gambian Will Lead Prosecution in Hague
text: A lawyer from Gambia, Fatou Bensouda, was named the new chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court on Monday, making her the future public face and chief strategist of the tribunal responsible for investigating the world’s grave atrocities.

headline: Amazing Race to the Bottom of the World
text: One hundred years ago, on Dec. 14, 1911, the Norwegian Roald Amundsen and four companions trudged through fog, bitter cold and lacerating wind to stand at the absolute bottom of the world, the South Pole. Nowhere was there a trace of their British rival, Robert Falcon Scott. No Union Jack mocked them, no ice cairn bespoke precedence. The Norwegians had won the race.

headline: Nine Is the Magic Number for Prokofiev
text: The Russian pianist Boris Berman is particularly associated with the music of Prokofiev. He has recorded all the Prokofiev solo piano works for Chandos, written a book on the Prokofiev piano sonatas and produced an annotated edition of those nine works. It is only natural that students at the Yale School of Music, where Mr. Berman is chairman of the piano department, would absorb some of his passion for Prokofiev.

headline: Chanel Marries Sumptuous India With Couture Detail
text: The Paris-Bombay collection by Chanel is a celebration of both India and the craftsmanship of the “petites mains” of France.

headline: Straddling Two Worlds in Search of Selfhood
text: So, the good parts first. The story of Pinocchio is deeply buried in Kyle Abraham’s autobiographical exploration of what it takes to become a real boy, “Live! The Realest MC.” For the new dance, seen at the Kitchen on Friday evening, Mr. Abraham offers a coming-out tale — his own — showing the difficulty of growing up black and gay in a hip-hop world. There’s no Disney tune in this piece that is mainly set to industrial and electronic music; and though it features an ensemble, he is clearly the star.

headline: More ‘Good Newt’
text: In response to my column, “The Good Newt,” the incoming missiles are divided so far between readers on the right upset that I support a comprehensive reform of our immigration laws, and those on the left, appalled that I would say anything nice about Newt Gingrich. Also, some flak from readers who see a national ID card – which Gingrich and I consider a prerequisite for seriously enforcing our immigration laws – as the first step toward a police state.

headline: Is the Kremlin Loosening Its Grip?
text: Russians are taking to the streets to oppose Vladimir Putin's presidency. Will the protests dislodge Putin?

headline: Cash-Poor Mets Given $40 Million Bank Loan
text: The owners of the Mets, needing cash and unable to turn to Major League Baseball for more financial help, received a $40 million loan from a major bank in the past six weeks.

headline: Snoop Dogg and Wiz Khalifa’s Collaborative Album
text: SNOOP DOGG & WIZ KHALIFA

headline: E-Books, Shmee-Books: Readers Return to the Stores
text: Facing economic gloom and competition from cheap e-readers, brick-and-mortar booksellers entered this holiday season with the humblest of expectations.

headline: Add Quakes to Rumblings Over Gas Rush
text: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio — Until this year, this Rust Belt city and surrounding Mahoning County had been about as dead, seismically, as a place can be, without even a hint of an earthquake since Scots-Irish settlers arrived in the 18th century.

headline: The ‘Fill in the Blanks’ Court Game of Indefinite Detention
text: WASHINGTON — Think of them as Mad Libs, Gitmo edition.

headline: Pay Data Sought for For-Profit Colleges
text: With for-profit colleges coming under increased scrutiny, a leading Democrat sought detailed information on Monday about the salaries and bonuses for top executives at 13 of the biggest schools.

headline: A New District Anchored Around Aurora
text: Aurora’s new congressional district.

headline: In Pursuit of the Perfect Gift? It’s a Lot Closer Than You Think
text: Traditionalists and etiquette mavens are complaining, but the rest of us can thank social scientists this season. They have come up with experimental evidence to support three revolutionary rules for people who hate shopping for holiday gifts:

headline: Speed of Light Lingers in Face of New Camera
text: More than 70 years ago, the M.I.T. electrical engineer Harold (Doc) Edgerton began using strobe lights to create remarkable photographs: a bullet stopped in flight as it pierced an apple, the coronet created by the splash of a drop of milk.

headline: High-End Sound With a Price to Match
text: The trouble with compact music systems is their compact sound. JBL has taken a shot at the laws of physics by packing quality sound into a relatively small package, the JBL OnBeat Extreme.

headline: From Finland, an Intriguing School-Reform Model
text: Pasi Sahlberg, a Finnish educator and author, had a simple question for the high school seniors he was speaking to one morning last week in Manhattan: “Who here wants to be a teacher?”

headline: A Roach With the Reach of a Grasshopper
text: Cockroach haters beware: scientists have discovered a roach that jumps.

headline: Eyes of an Ancient Predator Had 16,000 Lenses
text: Anomalocaris was a squidlike predator with grasping claws that lived more than 500 million years ago.

headline: Key Innovation Driver (1 Letter)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Technology No Cure-All (2 Letters)
text: To the Editor:

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,834 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:

headline: Yes, There’s Hockey Without Fighting
text: The recently concluded series of New York Times stories by John Branch on the life and death of Derek Boogaard contains a Large Hadron Collider’s worth of information, but at its core is an examination of the way too many hockey players are developed as fighters in the N.H.L. Still, fans are less and less enamored of fighting, in part because staged fights are the norm, and in larger part because we know the game can be so much better.

headline: Money Raised for Youths’ Trip
text: Organizers hoping to send a Canadian team to play the Ugandan team that was kept from the Little League World Series because the players’ visas were denied say they have raised enough money to make the trip to Uganda happen in January.

headline: Israel: Footbridge’s Closing Draws Ire
text: Israel on Monday closed a rickety footbridge leading to the holy compound revered by Jews as the Temple Mount and by Muslims as the Noble Sanctuary after a city engineer determined that the wooden walkway posed an immediate danger of fire or collapse. Though it is used only by non-Muslim visitors and Israeli security forces, Palestinian and Muslim authorities condemned the closing, calling it a provocation and a prelude to demolition and construction of a sturdier ramp. Palestinians object to Israel’s carrying out any work at the site in Jerusalem’s Old City on grounds that it is in occupied territory, captured by Israel from Jordan in the 1967 war. Any change in the status quo there has the potential to set off unrest. The bridge, known as the Mugrabi ramp, was erected as a temporary measure in 2004 after an older ramp collapsed. Muslims enter the compound, which houses Al Aksa Mosque, through different entrances.

headline: Canada: Government Bans Veils at Citizenship Ceremonies
text: New Canadians must remove face coverings, including niqabs and burqas, at citizenship swearing-in ceremonies, Jason Kenney, the minister of citizenship and immigration, said Monday. He said the new rule would take effect immediately. “Frankly, I found it bizarre that the rules allowed people to take the oath with a veil on,” the Conservative minister said in Montreal. Face covering, particularly by Muslim women, has become a controversial practice in Canada lately.

headline: Clive Robbins, Developer of a Method of Music Therapy, Dies at 84
text: Clive Robbins, a developer of an influential brand of music therapy designed to help people with various disabilities meet the physical, mental and social challenges that are facts of everyday life, died on Wednesday at his home in Jersey City. He was 84.

headline: Window Fixtures of Rougher Days Come Down
text: During his 15 years in the South Bronx, Nilo Montalvo says, he has lived in a neighborhood behind bars: vertical rods, child guards, wrought-iron fencing — all wedged into the windows of ground-floor apartments, like his, in a housing project on East 144th Street. “You feel like you’re in prison,” Mr. Montalvo, 64, said.

headline: No Hit Toy to Brighten Retailers’ Christmas
text: With Christmas less than two weeks away, the toy industry has no runaway hit — leaving many toy shoppers bored and complicating how stores sell holiday inventory.

headline: Canada Announces Exit From Kyoto Climate Treaty
text: OTTAWA — Canada said on Monday that it would withdraw from the Kyoto Protocol, the 1997 treaty to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Huntsman and Gingrich Square Off in Unmoderated Debate
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — If Newt Gingrich is the Republican nominee and President Obama accepts his famous challenge to seven three-hour Lincoln-Douglas-style debates, viewers might find them only on C-SPAN and should plan to have plenty of black coffee on hand.

headline: At Front of Republican Pack, Skirmishes Escalate
text: WINDHAM, N.H. — For much of this presidential primary season, New Hampshire has been perceived as being in Mitt Romney’s back pocket. He has a house in Wolfeboro, N.H., and was governor of neighboring Massachusetts, where the news media made him a constant presence in New Hampshire living rooms.

headline: Paying For Health Reform
text: I’ve noticed an odd thing in comments whenever the subject of Obamacare comes up. Many commenters scoff when I say that the Obama health reform was fully paid for; not only that, but some of them confidently assert that the Congressional Budget Office says that the reform will increase the deficit.

headline: Win That Could Save Giants’ Season Reveals Flaws That Could End It
text: The Giants’ season appeared doomed before it even started. The roster lost several familiar names to free agency in the off-season. Others disappeared because of injuries, and all the while, the Philadelphia Eagles were stockpiling talent.

headline: Romney’s Run Puts a Spotlight on Private Equity
text: On Wednesday, Mitt Romney, the Republican candidate for president, will attend fund-raisers in Manhattan given by his former private equity peers and Wall Street bankers, putting the spotlight on the private equity industry and Mr. Romney’s role in it.

headline: Inside Look at N.H.L. That Even the Players’ Families Want to See
text: As production crews for the HBO documentary series “24/7: Road to the N.H.L. Winter Classic” record every move of the players and coaches on the Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers, their lives are open books. The sanctity of the locker room is gone.

text: PARIS — The market euphoria over last week’s deal by European leaders to shore up the euro currency union succumbed to a darker mood Monday.

text: Editors’ Note: Because of a production error, the following two letters were omitted from the online version of the Sunday Dialogue, in which readers debated whether to put cameras in the Supreme Court.

headline: With N.B.A. Apparently Wanting More, the Clippers Halt Talks for Paul
text: LOS ANGELES — The hunt for Chris Paul, also known as the journey to nowhere, was back where it started on Monday, when the Los Angeles Clippers broke off talks about acquiring him.

headline: MF Global Inquiry Shifts to Two Trusted Deputies
text: 8:57 p.m. | Updated

headline: Teaching Law
text: This week marks the last sessions of my Yale law school class on law, liberalism and religion. In the course of the semester my students have learned how to read religion clause cases against the background of long-standing debates in philosophy and theology about the relationship between religious imperatives and the obligations of democratic citizenship. They have become adept at recognizing the arguments behind the arguments the justices are making explicitly. They can see how a case ostensibly about vouchers or school prayer or Christmas trees on courthouse steps is really about whether principle or history should inform a court’s decisions. They can see how a case about head coverings or beards in the military (a topic that has surfaced once again) turns on the distinctions set down in John Locke’s “Letter Concerning Toleration” (1689), a tract the justices may never have read. They can see how the majority and dissenting opinions in a free exercise case often reflect a tension between negative and positive liberty as these terms are defined by Isaiah Berlin, an author the justices will likely not have referenced. They can see how the entire history of religion-clause jurisprudence at once illustrates and is an extended critique of John Rawls’s attempt in “Political Liberalism” to devise a form of government that will be fair to religion while at the same time keeping it at arm’s length.

headline: Campaign Sends Romney to the Rescue. Ann Romney.
text: DES MOINES — Ann Romney switches off shrill TV coverage of the presidential race “all the time.” She is exasperated by the hyperpartisanship of the moment. As for the debates? “Listen,” she said in a rare interview here, “I don’t even want to go to the debates.”

headline: Toward War, Not Improvement
text: In Sadr City, Sadeq Rathi sees no bright future.

headline: Not a Democracy
text: In central Baghdad, Safi Abed believes the U.S. isn’t leaving Iraq with a real democracy.

headline: Unusual Move by Christie in Feud Over Judgeships
text: Caught in a power struggle with the State Senate, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey took an unusual tack on Monday, moving the state’s attorney general into a top job at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, but only until she can be confirmed as a judge in Essex County.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Guantánamo Forever?
text: IN his inaugural address, President Obama called on us to “reject as false the choice between our safety and our ideals.” We agree. Now, to protect both, he must veto the National Defense Authorization Act that Congress is expected to pass this week.

headline: In Dark Brooklyn Doorway, Officer Confronts Gunman, and Dies
text: The 911 caller reported a robbery in progress early Monday, and the first officers who arrived at the Brooklyn basement apartment found a tenant bloodied from a beating. They had no idea that the robbers were still there, hiding in a dark room behind them.

headline: German Official Backs Tax Vetoed by Britain
text: Germany’s foreign minister said Monday that he would like to see a new financial transactions tax imposed on markets in the European Union despite objections from Britain’s government, which vetoed changes in the European Union treaty at the economic crisis summit meeting last week partly in an effort to protect the London-based financial services industry from paying such a tax.

headline: Amid Paeans to Cuomo, Some Less Lofty Notes
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is enjoying his Emperor Hadrian moment. His many legislative victories come accompanied by festive celebrations and loud huzzahs.

headline: Maryland’s Men’s Track in Danger of Elimination
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — Lap splits and training programs are usually Andrew Valmon’s daily concerns. But in recent weeks, fund-raising and the search for possible endowment money have been added to his to-do list as the University of Maryland track coach.

headline: In California, Indian Tribes With Casino Money Cast Off Members
text: COARSEGOLD, Calif. — The six-page, single-spaced letter that Nancy Dondero and about 50 of her relatives received last month was generously salted with legal citations and footnotes. But its meaning was brutally simple. “It is the decision by a majority of the Tribal Council,” the letter said, “that you are hereby disenrolled.”

headline: The President and the Generals
text: Washington

headline: Zombie Borders
text: June 13th, 1990, was a historic day for weather forecasting in Germany. For the very first time, the weather map on the Tagesschau [1] showed the newly reunited country’s international borders.

headline: Premier’s Actions in Iraq Raise U.S. Concerns
text: BAGHDAD — Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has moved swiftly to consolidate power in advance of the American military withdrawal, offering a glimpse of how Iraq’s post-American identity may take shape, by rounding up hundreds of former Baath Party members and evicting Western companies from the heavily fortified Green Zone.

headline: Reid Vows to Keep Republicans in Town
text: In league with President Obama, the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid, served notice to Congressional Republicans late Monday that he will prevent final votes on a must-pass bill to finance government operations until Congress approves a measure to Democrats’ liking that extends a payroll tax cut and unemployment assistance.

headline: G.O.P. Bill Would Benefit Doctor-Owned Hospitals
text: WASHINGTON — The House Republican bill to hold down payroll taxes and extend unemployment benefits, coming up for a vote on Tuesday, offers a special dispensation to doctors who invest in hospitals.

headline: Amazon’s Jungle Logic
text: Camden, Me.

headline: Koch Is Backing Quinn in 2013 Race for Mayor
text: Two years before the next New York mayoral election, former Mayor Edward I. Koch said Monday that he was supporting Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: An Italian Chocolatier Revives Its U.S. Campaign
text: PERUGINA, the Italian chocolate maker best known for its Baci line of foil-wrapped, bite-size hazelnut chocolates, once enjoyed prominence with American consumers, with the brand advertising nationally on television and in magazines from the 1960s through the mid-1980s.

headline: Turkish Border Businesses Miss the Syrian Neighbors
text: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — In the old bazaar of this ancient city, long entwined with Syria, the loud chatter of Syrians’ bartering in Arabic has given way to unfamiliar silence.

headline: Helping Lift a Daughter From Illness
text: On a brisk afternoon, a mother and daughter scaled a jungle gym, crossed a bridge and took off down a pair of slides in Evergreen Park, in Ridgewood, Queens.

headline: Cardinal John P. Foley, 76, Vatican Spokesman, Dies
text: Cardinal John Patrick Foley, who heeded God’s “whisper,” as he put it, to become a priest as well as his own inclinations to go to journalism school at 31, then combined the roles as the Vatican’s communications director for almost a quarter-century, died on Sunday in Darby, Pa. He was 76.

headline: Hearing on Terror Suspect Explores Miranda Warning
text: Almost two years ago, a Federal Bureau of Investigation agent was in Nigeria to question an Eritrean man who was in custody on suspicion of supporting terrorism. The suspect, Mohamed Ibrahim Ahmed, had already been interrogated by other American officials for intelligence-gathering purposes, without having been read his rights.

headline: Slain Officer Was Devoted to His Daughters
text: Officer Peter J. Figoski worked the midnight shift in one of New York’s most dangerous precincts, apprehending robbers in and around East New York, Brooklyn, with the instincts of a 22-year veteran. Then he would go home to Long Island to drive his daughters to school.

headline: Whom Do You Trust?
text: People’s faith in Congress continues to sink like a rock.

headline: Jon Huntsman’s Path to Victory
text: Longtime readers will know that I was initially very skeptical about Jon M. Huntsman Jr.’s chances of winning the Republican nomination. Mr. Huntsman, in my view, had two fundamental challenges that would be very difficult for any candidate to overcome.

headline: S.E.C. Files Suit to Recoup Losses in Stanford Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Securities and Exchange Commission on Monday sued the Securities Investor Protection Corporation in an effort to help customers who lost money to the Stanford Financial Group file claims for reimbursement.

headline: When Cost Cuts Make Merger Sense
text: A rumble in the rock garden may presage more hostile mergers and acquisitions. That’s one way to read the unsolicited $4.6 billion offer that Martin Marietta Materials has made for its larger rival, Vulcan Materials. The all-stock deal probably won’t succeed without some more back-and-forth. But the lesson is clear: if profits cannot be mined from the ground, they can still be found by cutting costs.

headline: Tuesday: Put Down Some Chips
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — We haven’t seen Jonathan Gersch around these parts for quite a while, but he’s back with a smooth Tuesday grid that made me smile. I was a bit old for “Sesame Street” when it made its debut in 1969, but, ahem, I remember keeping my younger sister company while she watched it, and then doing the same favor for my own kids. Purely to explain the intricate nuances of what was going on, mind you. Not because it was extraordinarily entertaining, even by adult standards.

headline: Trying to Shine in the Shadow of a Neighbor
text: AURORA, Colo. — Second Banana. Tonto to the scene-stealing Lone Ranger. Name the pejorative of disrespect or neglect and this sprawling city, forever in Denver’s shadow as the gawky suburb that outgrew its britches, has probably endured it.

headline: Prokhorov’s Candidacy Doesn’t Faze the N.B.A.
text: Mikhail D. Prokhorov’s foreign roots, business practices and playboy reputation did not prevent him from buying controlling interest in the Nets last year. His political aspirations will not pose an issue to the N.B.A., either.

headline: Targeting the Unemployed
text: The House Republican leadership managed to get one thing right in its bill to extend the payroll tax cut and unemployment benefits. The bill does, indeed, extend the payroll tax cut for another year, but, beyond that, there is a lot to dislike. To help pay for the package, for instance, the bill would cut social spending more deeply than is already anticipated under current budget caps without asking wealthy Americans to contribute a penny in new taxes.

headline: Yankees Look to Lock Up Young Players
text: The Yankees announced on Monday that they would offer contracts to every unsigned player on their 40-man roster, ensuring that key players like Phil Hughes, Dave Robertson, Russell Martin and Brett Gardner will be under their control for another year.

headline: Keystone Claptrap
text: The Keystone XL oil pipeline has become the House Republicans’ weapon of choice in their fight with President Obama over jobs and taxes. Mr. Obama has said he will not make a decision on the pipeline until 2013. The Republicans are insisting that he approve it now and have attached an amendment to a bill extending the payroll tax cut in hopes of forcing his hand.

headline: The Abu-Jamal Case
text: After nearly 30 years, prosecutors in Philadelphia decided last week to end their fight to execute Mumia Abu-Jamal, who was convicted in 1982 of the murder of Daniel Faulkner, a police officer. Decades of legal proceedings have proved that Pennsylvania’s death penalty machinery is unconstitutionally flawed and should be stopped.

headline: Knick’s Plan: Speak Softly and Sign a Big Man
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

headline: Amundsen at the South Pole
text: When Roald Amundsen’s ship, the Fram, left Norway on Aug. 9, 1910, it carried, in Amundsen’s words, “nineteen men, ninety-seven dogs, four pigs, six carrier pigeons, and one canary.” The ship was nearly 20 years old, and the expedition leader, Amundsen, was 38. He was already a formidable polar explorer, but this voyage to Antarctica and the South Pole made him one of the greatest explorers who ever lived.

headline: Members of Overhauled State Ethics Panel Are Named
text: ALBANY — Four months after Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed into law a much-heralded overhaul of ethics enforcement, he named the Westchester County district attorney, Janet DiFiore, the first leader of a new state ethics commission.

headline: Libyan Army Clashes With Militia in Tripoli
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Efforts by Libya’s transitional government to assert its authority over the capital were marred over the weekend, after members of a powerful rebel militia exchanged fire with soldiers in the fledgling army, leaving two people dead.

headline: Corrections: December 13
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Tabloid May Not Be Behind Deleted Messages, Police Say
text: LONDON — The tabloid newspaper that Rupert Murdoch’s media empire shut down amid a hacking scandal may not have been responsible for a prominent episode in the scandal, the deletion of voice mail messages from a missing schoolgirl’s cellphone, a police lawyer said on Monday.

headline: Time, Distance and Clarity
text: Above Rome’s pale yellow and dusky orange buildings, the sky somehow looks bluer than it does almost anywhere else. Did I take proper note of that when I saw it all the time? When it was the canopy over my waking, my working and the all-consuming, all-distracting tedium of daily life?

headline: Sandusky Scheduled to Face Several of His Accusers
text: BELLEFONTE, Pa. — Jerry Sandusky, the disgraced former assistant football coach at Penn State, is scheduled Tuesday to face the public testimony of at least half of the 10 boys he is accused of sexually molesting.

headline: Lagging in Performance: Pennsylvania Online Schools
text: Pennsylvania was one of the first states to allow full-time online schools and it now has the third-largest enrollment in such schools. But test scores at online schools lag.

headline: At School in Cyberspace
text: Costly to taxpayers, do virtual schools get the job done?

headline: Profits and Questions at Online Charter Schools
text: By almost every educational measure, the Agora Cyber Charter School is failing.

text: The police provided an account of the shooting that led to the death of an on-duty officer.

headline: Millionaires on Food Stamps and Jobless Pay? G.O.P. Is on It
text: WASHINGTON — It’s an image many Americans would find rather upsetting: a recently laid-off millionaire, luxuriating next to the pool eating grapes bought with food stamps while waiting for an unemployment check to roll in.

headline: One of the Pentagon’s Top Women Is Stepping Down
text: WASHINGTON — Michèle A. Flournoy, the chief policy adviser to Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta and one of the highest-ranking women in the history of the Pentagon, said on Monday that she would step down from her job early next year to “rebalance” her personal life and spend more time with her three school-age children.

headline: Art World Star Doesn’t Change His Spots
text: LONDON — Just as the financial markets were heading for disaster in 2008, the British artist Damien Hirst snubbed his dealers and persuaded Sotheby’s here to sell 223 primarily new artworks. There were dead animals — sharks, zebras, piglets and even a calf — floating in giant glass tanks of formaldehyde; cabinets filled with diamonds; and cigarette butts. And paintings galore: spin paintings, spot paintings, paintings with butterflies pinned under glass.

headline: Hezbollah Station Identifies 10 Supposed C.I.A. Officers
text: WASHINGTON — The militant group Hezbollah has stepped up a public campaign against the Central Intelligence Agency in Lebanon, using a television broadcast to name 10 people who it said were C.I.A. officers who worked from the American Embassy in Beirut in recent years.

headline: Mets Part Ways With Paulino and Baxter
text: The Mets let go of catcher Ronny Paulino and outfielder Mike Baxter on Monday night before baseball’s midnight deadline for offering contracts to arbitration-eligible players.

headline: A Decade Later, Security Top Notch in India’s Parliament
text: On Dec. 13, 2001, a heavily armed suicide squad of five men, carrying grenades, AK-47s with multiple magazines and explosives drove into the six-acre Parliament grounds in a white Ambassador car with a red flashing light on the roof and a fake entry pass on its windscreen.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 13, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: A Way Forward for Mourinho
text: Toppling Barcelona was a challenge that almost broke José Mourinho last season. The psychological strain on the Real Madrid manager permeated into his touchline manner, or rather lack of manners; into his relationship with Spain’s famously difficult soccer news media; and most worryingly, into his professional judgement.

headline: Dec. 13, 1981 | Poland Cracks Down on Solidarity Movement
text: On Dec. 13, 1981, authorities in Poland imposed martial law in a crackdown on the pro-democracy Solidarity labor movement, which had made numerous strikes since August 1980 that challenged the Communist Polish government.

headline: In Her Garden of Digital Delights
text: Maggie Taylor had never been comfortable photographing people. She was so content shooting still lifes of “stuff” that she collected, that for 10 years she hadn’t even taken her 4×5 camera beyond her garden.

headline: Do You Discuss Religion With Friends?
text: Seizing on the holiday season as an opportunity to talk about spirituality, an Op-Ed writer argues that few people discuss religion in everyday life. He asserts that only devout believers and die-hard nonbelievers raise the subject in conversation. Do you agree? Do you talk about religion with friends? Why or why not?In the Op-Ed article “Americans: Undecided About God?” Eric Weiner laments “the sad state of our national conversation about God”:

headline: European Commission Chief Assails Britain Over Treaty Veto
text: LONDON — A senior European official said on Tuesday that Britain’s demands for measures to protect its financial services industry at last week’s summit meeting were impossible to meet and directly responsible for the collapse of a Europe-wide agreement meant to help save the euro.

headline: ‘Realistic’ India Through Western Eyes?
text: When my husband, Mahir, and I turned on our television in Manhattan one November evening, we were surprised to see his violin teacher from Mumbai, Jini Dinshaw, flash across the screen.

headline: The Early Word: The Deciders
text: Today’s Times

headline: Who Counts as ‘Rich’? Continued
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”.”

headline: Rob Gronkowski, and the Year of the Tight End
text: When the postscript is written on the 2011 season, Aaron Rodgers may be remembered as having the best season a quarterback has ever had. We don’t need to wait much longer to acknowledge the same at another position.

headline: Bullfighting Gets a Closer Look in Prague
text: Anyone who has seen a matador in action knows that bullfighting is an art. But the creativity it inspires is not restricted to the ring – artists from Picasso to Dalí to the Czech artist Emil Filla have created works using the sport as a theme. One hundred fifty such pieces are now on view in Prague through April 9 at the Tauromaquia exhibition  at Obecni dum.

headline: Doing It the Evliya Celebi Way
text: ISTANBUL — Whenever I set out to tour Turkey with my wife, I understand exactly what Diana, Princess of Wales, meant when she complained about there being “three of us” in her marriage. My rival’s name is Evliya Celebi, and he spent much of his life on a horse. He was born 400 years ago and Unesco decided to celebrate his birth this year. I can’t compete.

headline: The TV Watch: Chelsea Clinton Finally Embraces Her Celebrity
text: Chelsea Clinton gave a perfectly honed and utterly unsatisfying explanation on Monday for why she has made her debut as a special correspondent on NBC’s magazine show “Rock Center WithBrian Williams.”

headline: Before Tebow, There Was Blanda
text: Tim Tebow’s late-game performances are already the stuff of legend. He has captivated the nation with a string of last-minute heroics, leaving the public wanting more. Tebow’s statistics aren’t very impressive, but he is a flavor best enjoyed without serious thought. You have to see it to understand it. And that makes his run reminiscent of an improbable stretch that took place over four decades ago.

headline: In Lower Manhattan, a Light Show Looms
text: It sounds like a scene straight out of Las Vegas or Orlando: streets magically illuminated by an interactive light show, complete with 3-D effects and lights that respond to kinetic pedestrian motion.

headline: Can a Small Retailer Compete Online With the Big Boys?
text: Little Dudes and Divas is a small business with some very big competition. Started seven years ago by Steve and Susan Karasanti, husband and wife, the company has three employees and sells clothes and accessories for infants and toddlers. Ninety percent of the sales come through the Web site, the rest through a newly opened brick-and-mortar store in Rockaway Park, N.Y., where the company is based.

headline: BBC World News to Be Available Through Comcast
text: The BBC will announce on Tuesday a first-of-its-kind deal for Comcast to carry the BBC World News channel, opening the door to wider distribution for the channel within the United States.

headline: Iran Rejects U.S. Request for Return of Drone
text: Iran has rejected a request by President Obama to return an American surveillance drone that the Iranians say they captured on Dec. 4., state media in Tehran reported Tuesday.

headline: NYSE and Deutsche Borse Offer New Deal Concessions
text: 8:31 p.m. | Updated

headline: Newswallah: Four Decades of Lokpal
text: Forty-three years and at least eight versions of the Lokpal bill later, Parliament still hasn’t reached consensus on who and what, exactly, it should cover.

headline: More Talk about That Dior Job
text: For months a group of names has swarmed around the creative director’s job at Dior, with the industry joining the buzz. Among the names mentioned early on were Marc Jacobs, Riccardo Tisci, Nicolas Ghesquiere, Alber Elbaz. Then in November it was Alexander Wang, Jason Wu and Raf Simons. Today, Women’s Wear Daily, quoting industry sources, said Mr. Simons is in discussion for the Dior job.

headline: Romney and Gingrich, a Contrast in Styles
text: What is the essential difference between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich?

headline: Warming World Abets a Fish Parasite, Study Suggests
text: It sounds almost like science fiction: A parasite manipulates a fish’s behavior to make it seek out warmer water, probably by altering its brain chemistry. In the warmer environment, the parasite’s growth — and its capacity to infect other hosts — kicks into overdrive.

headline: Millions and Billions
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Millions and Billions
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Egypt’s Liberals Adrift
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s liberals are spooked. If the two-day voting in the second round of parliamentary elections that begins Wednesday goes the same way the first round did, Islamist parties will dominate the new lower house of Parliament.

headline: Opinion Report: Keystone XL
text: From the editorial page

headline: Daily Report: Intel Sees an Opportunity in Drives Shortage
text: Intel, the world’s largest maker of semiconductors, said on Monday that its revenue this quarter would fall to $13.7 billion, from $14.7 billion, because floods in Thailand had sharply cut the world’s supply of disk drives. Without the drives, manufacturers will make fewer personal computers and computer servers, which means fewer semiconductors will be needed.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 13
text: Bookstores have reported an unexpectedly strong beginning to the Christmas shopping season, lifted by “an unusually vibrant selection,” Julie Bosman writes. It has been a strong year for nonfiction, some booksellers pointed out, starting with the Steve Jobs biography by Walter Isaacson. However, the increased business is also a product of the closing of the Borders Books chain, whose customers are visiting other stores to do their book shopping. Overall sales will take a hit from the loss of Borders.

headline: An Officer Falls
text: Police Officer Peter J. Figoski never stood a chance. He didn’t even have time, the Police Department said, to pull his gun before a man described as a career criminal killed him in Brooklyn Monday morning with a bullet to the face.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: TOP STORIES

headline: Half-Filled School Bus Crashes in China, Killing 15 Children
text: BEIJING — A half-filled school bus ferrying students home from a primary school in rural China rolled into an irrigation canal, killing 15 children and injuring 8 others, officials said.

headline: Settlers Riot, Attacking Israeli Base and Post
text: JERUSALEM — Dozens of radical Jewish settlers, reacting to a rumor that several of their outposts would be dismantled, attacked an Israeli Army base in the West Bank on Tuesday, lighting fires, vandalizing vehicles and throwing stones, hours after another group of settlers occupied a border post with Jordan.

headline: Reviewing Jerry Sandusky
text: In an earlier era, crowds might have massed in State College, Pa., to vocally proclaim their displeasure at Jerry Sandusky, the former Penn State coach charged with many counts of sexual abuse of young boys. Now, in one of the less-anticipated developments of e-commerce, the mobs gather online to vent while Christmas shopping.

headline: Receding Inflation In Britain

The headline inflation number was running quite high, but even a bit of analysis showed that this largely reflected temporary shocks, mainly hikes in VAT and commodity prices plus some effects from the depreciation of the pound. Yet there was much hysteria, with many claiming that Britain was on the verge of a 1970s-type inflationary spiral. I concluded,

Here are his seven tips to get that shot of your family lit by hearth, menorah or blinking Christmas tree lights.

headline: Surrounded by Poverty, a Lifeless Capital Stands Aloof
text: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — The road leading to Myanmar’s giant Parliament building is 20 lanes wide, well suited for military processions but eerily empty the rest of the time. A half-hour drive away, down this city’s manicured avenues, is another immense edifice, still under construction: a military museum that will serve as a shrine to the country’s generals and admirals. Across the way is a military training academy; farther down the road are rows of barracks and a vast parade ground.

headline: I.R.S. Denied Lesbians Legitimate Adoption Credit
text: Since the federal government does not recognize same-sex marriage, such couples are viewed as strangers in many spheres of their financial lives. They need to file separate federal tax returns, for instance.  And sometimes, that can come with certain advantages.

headline: ‘Drive’ Picks Up Momentum With Broadcast Critics’ Nominations
text: “Drive” careened into a top spot with the Broadcast Film Critics Association, receiving nods for best picture and best director, among 10 nominations over all. Two other films surpassed that: “Hugo” and “The Artist” each earned 11 nominations (including best picture and best director). But “Drive,” Nicolas Winding Refn’s vehicular thriller, has been an outlier thus far in this awards race, though the Bagger thinks it could get some love from members of the Academy, who have been known to reward a violent automotive movie.

headline: Table Talk | The Catbird Seat in Nashville
text: Within weeks of opening, the Catbird Seat has diners in Nashville and beyond abuzz with its bold, daring approach to high-end cuisine. Run by the co-executive chefs Erik Anderson and Josh Habiger (who’ve trained in the world’s top kitchens, including Noma, the Fat Duck and the French Laundry), the restaurant offers a simple menu: one multicourse, prix fixe dinner that changes weekly.

headline: What’s in Your Kitchen?
text: What’s in your refrigerator? There’s a good chance that residing somewhere on its shelves is at least one carton of eggs and a block of Cheddar cheese.

headline: Reading, Writing and Recipes: Cooking in the Classroom at P.S. 3
text: The chef Zakary Pelaccio teaches future foodies how to taste. His students are armed with cutting boards and knives."Curl your fingers under like a claw," the chef instructs. "Then you're going to cut slowly, sawing back and forth." Fingers curl into claws and little hands brandish tiny plastic knives. After all, these cooking students are still in kindergarten.

headline: Wheelies: The Very Fine Print Edition

headline: To the City’s Top 1%, a Third of the Income
text: The very rich are, well, very rich. A new study says the 34,000 or so New Yorkers who constitute the top 1 percent of earners collected more than one-third of all the income earned in the city in 2009. Their average income was $2.2 million, and they reaped 58.3 percent of dividends and interest, 84.6 percent of business income, and 84.7 percent of capital gains.

headline: The Trouble With Debates (II)
text: O.K., I take it back. No sooner did I write a post suggesting that future primaries would benefit from more intimate debates — featuring smaller group of candidates rather than the whole field, longer answers rather than short ones, and so on — than yesterday’s Jon Huntsman-Newt Gingrich “Lincoln-Douglas” debate went and demonstrated why that could turn out to be an absolutely terrible idea. Trip Gabriel’s writeup for the Times does a good job of capturing the droning deadliness of the affair, the painful seminar-room quality, the absence any spark in the candidates’s answers to the exquisitely-polite questions. (“After an hour and a half, when the moderator offered the candidates a chance to hit the remaining five topics in a lightning round and they declined, the audience seemed to collectively sigh with relief.”) If Gingrich made good on his pledge to teach an online class while in the Oval Office, I imagine that it would turn out something like this. And if Huntsman’s supporters want to know why their man has struggled to inspire any excitement or strong support, despite an impressive record and solid conservative bona fides, the answer begins with the fact that he just spent 90 minutes on a stage with the candidate leading in the polls and never once said anything that might actually make some real news for his own struggling campaign. (And yes, I understand that it was all about tag-teaming Romney. But that’s no excuse for being lights-out boring.)

headline: There’s Plenty of Room in Coach
text: The N.F.L. has apparently gotten early holiday shopping fever. Because instead of following the wisdom of the ages — which says there is not much point in firing your head coach until the season ends because A) your season is already lost and B) almost everyone you want to interview is employed by another N.F.L. team and can’t talk to you early anyway — teams are festively dumping their coaches because apparently they expect some Black Friday-like deal on their next one. So if you see Bill Cowher propped on a bargain table at Wal-Mart, please alert the Jaguars, Chiefs and Dolphins.

headline: Bright Lights for the Party
text: Party pants, in updated styles from the resort collections, feel fresh for the holidays. Lanvin’s silk-print pants, with a high waist and tapered legs, are shiny and festive, as are Balenciaga’s metallic models, which look rather like track pants, with the contrasting fabric insets down the sides. The British label Reiss also has glittery holiday trousers, cropped with a high waist, in a dark gold sequin print. For style guidance, look to Charlotte Gainsbourg, who, for the premiere of “Melancholia,” wore her Balenciagas with a loose black shirt. For additional options, you might check out the denim brands: AG, Siwy and Genetic Denim all have versions of sequin jeans in stores now.

Consider the message above a not-so-subtle hint.

Although the respondents varied from area to area and across social and religions divides, some clear patterns emerge.

headline: Out There | Neïl Beloufa’s Brave New World
text: Like many artists responding to our duplicitous marketing- and infotainment-driven world, Neïl Beloufa, a young French Algerian video artist based in Paris, works in the interstices of fact and fiction. In “Kempinski (2007),” which was on view last year at the New Museum, Beloufa uses a simple tweak in tense to build an eerie alternate reality. Shot at night in Mali, “Kempinski” features interviews with local inhabitants in rural settings — in a crowd of oxen, in bushes, in dusty courtyards — who speak about things from telepathic communication with stars, animals and machines to teleportation via light and sound, as if they were present-day realities. The scenes are lit by handheld, corded fluorescent lights that could, if you squint, be mistaken for alien technology, and the subjects’ assertions register as farcical deadpan: Beloufa’s tone of choice. The narration plays on a viewer’s superficial ideas of where primitive magic and futuristic science might meet, hinging on that rhetorical switch from “will be” to “is.”

headline: Should We ‘Occupy’ Education?
text: Dramatic disparities separate the performance of privileged and disadvantaged students, and as complex as the education equation is, one factor — poverty — is consistently associated with lower scores for districts, schools and individual children.

headline: New Challenge to a Murdoch Over Hacking
text: LONDON — Rupert Murdoch’s son James received and responded to e-mail messages in 2008 that referred to “a nightmare scenario” of legal repercussions from widespread phone hacking at the tabloid The News of the World, a chain of e-mail messages and replies released Tuesday by a British parliamentary panel shows. It is the first documentation that Mr. Murdoch had been notified of a wider hacking problem long before he has admitted.

headline: Politics Beats Science, Again
text: Here’s a scene you may find familiar: Government experts carefully study a problem, and come to a conclusion based on scientific evidence. They get over-ruled by bureaucrats who seem more concerned about politics than science. This isn’t a historical anecdote from the Bush administration. I’m talking about the Obama administration.

headline: ‘Fear Factor’ on NBC Draws Big Audience in Return
text: After a five-year hiatus, NBC’s gross-out competition “Fear Factor” delivered strong numbers for over a two-hour period with an average of 8.6 million total viewers. It also matched the highest 8 p.m. rating in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic for a non-sports program on NBC since February 2008.

headline: ‘Dragon Tattoo’s’ New Date and Other News From the Circuit
text: The news today in awards land is all about anticipation. Fans of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” – or anybody looking to see whether Denbygate was merited or not – get to scratch their itch sooner: Sony announced on Tuesday — via Twitter — that the film will now open a day earlier, with tickets available to showings beginning at 7 p.m. on Dec. 20.

headline: Freedom of Expression, Online: Outlining the First Amendment for Teenagers
text: Overview | What are the First Amendment rights? Does freedom of speech mean you people can publish whatever they want on the Internet? In this lesson, students consider what they know about the First Amendment and a court case involving a blogger. They then research the rights and responsibilities of young bloggers and create a primer for teens who blog.

headline: Austrian Tradition, With Ambition
text: I AM not one to sneer at the manifest pleasures of a Wiener schnitzel. I have friends, however, who are not nearly so accepting of these simple joys.

headline: Quinn Attacked Over Council’s Discretionary Funds
text: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn, widely viewed as a leading contender in New York’s 2013 mayoral race, found herself on the defensive on Tuesday as another candidate attacked her over her management of the City Council’s discretionary funds.

headline: Media and Entertainment Companies Add Support to Proposed Antipiracy Legislation
text: Big media companies have ratcheted up the pressure on Washington to support legislation that would protect online content.

headline: Reviewing Seäsonal
text: In my review this week of Seäsonal, an ambitious Austrian restaurant near Carnegie Hall, I mention that it most likely offers the best list of Austrian wines in New York.

headline: For Sparrows, Terror Has Grim Consequences
text: Fear makes the wolf look bigger, or so goes a German proverb. And new research underlines the scientific basis for the adage: the mere hint of the presence of a predator can have life-or-death consequences for the terrorized prey, regardless of the true threat.

headline: Hit on McCoy Earns Harrison a One-Game Suspension
text: James Harrison and the Pittsburgh Steelers have thought that the N.F.L. has unfairly singled him out for penalties and fines since it began cracking down on hits to the head in the middle of last season.

headline: 2 Leaders in Russian Media Are Fired After Election Articles
text: MOSCOW — A high-ranking editor and a top executive from one of Russia’s most respected news publications were dismissed on Tuesday after an apparent conflict over coverage that appeared to highlight widespread anger with the results of parliamentary elections this month.

headline: Walk Through Earthquake Rubble Online
text: A toppled building; mangled cars and miles and miles of debris:Google has uploaded scenes from the Japanese tsunami’s aftermath to its Street View service, offering a unique if heart-wrenching virtual peek into the destruction along Japan’s Pacific coast.

text: The Look: Sublime. A floating white dress with cutout detailing and the slightest train needs no further embellishment (i.e. bag, jewels, lipstick or statement heel).
