text: Caterina Schenardi, mother of owner Massimo Galeano, comes to NYC a few times a year to make pasta at Grandisca, 126 West 13th St.

text: Some good news in the job market: Small businesses plan to increase hiring, according to the latest report from the National Federation of Independent Business.

headline: BMW and G.M. Discuss Collaboration on Advanced Technologies, Including Fuel Cells
text: Citing unnamed sources, a recent report in the German business magazine WirtschaftsWoche said that General Motors and BMW would collaborate on hydrogen fuel-cell technology for passenger cars. Specifically, BMW would contribute toward research costs in exchange for the technology developed by G.M.

headline: Craig Hopson Prepares for a Chinatown Opening
text: When Craig Hopson leaves Le Cirque in about a month, after three years, he will begin working on a springtime opening for the Brewster, at 177 Mott Street (Broome Street). His partners are Frank Roberts, who managed the Rose Bar, and Ross Morgan, who is developing the building, which once housed a fine horse-carriage maker.

headline: Extreme Ecology in a Polar Desert
text: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier fed streams.

headline: ‘We Are the 99 Percent’ as Told in Pictures
text: Even as many of the Occupy [Your City/Street Here] encampments around the country have been expelled by local police forces, one of its central refrains — “We Are the 99 Percent” — has become part of the national dialogue. The National Desk invited readers to submit pictures incorporating the phrase and produced a slide show.

headline: Junior Flores Shines for U.S. U-17 Team
text: Earlier this month at the Nike International Friendlies in Florida, the United States under-17 national team drew a lot of attention as it defeated Brazil and Turkey on the way to winning the tournament.

headline: It’s Almost-Presidents’ Day!
text: Eleven years ago today, Al Gore, for one important moment, was the most powerful man in our republic. The day before, the Supreme Court, in a 5-4 vote, halted the partial recount of presidential ballots in Florida that Gore had requested. But that did not mean the 2000 presidential election was over. George W. Bush could not declare victory until Gore conceded defeat.

headline: The On Again, Off Again Donald
text: Donald Trump has announced that he will not, after all, be moderating a debate in Iowa for the Republican presidential candidates with the right-wing magazine Newsmax. He says the party wanted him to promise he wouldn’t run as an independent, and he wants to preserve that possibility.

headline: JPMorgan Shares Fall as MF Global Trustee Suggests Inquiry of Bank
text: After a couple of ups and downs, shares in JPMorgan Chase were trading in positive territory by Tuesday afternoon. And then they took a quick and sharp tumble.

headline: California, With Revenue Shortfalls, Will See More Budget Cuts
text: LOS ANGELES — The California Legislature passed a budget in June relying on optimistic projections of how much money the state could bring in with a growing economy. But to the surprise of few, not all of that money has materialized.

headline: Just One Look | Helmut Lang
text: Spider webs, beetles, cicadas and other creepy crawlers inspired Helmut Lang’s Nicole and Michael Colovos this prefall season. In between quintessential Helmut Lang pieces — leather leggings and biker jackets, open-weave linen shirts and asymmetrical jersey tops and dresses — are collection-defining prints based on insects’ exoskeletal-esque wings and amphibious camouflages, as seen on this extremely graphic and sporty chiffon dress.

headline: Glamour and Munitions: A Screen Siren’s Wartime Ingenuity
text: Did you hear the one about the actress and the composer who tried to invent a remote-controlled torpedo? It sounds like the opening line of a bar joke, but it’s actually the premise of Richard Rhodes’s slim new book, “Hedy’s Folly.”

headline: Loeb Reiterates Opposition to a Yahoo Minority Investment
text: As Yahoo‘s board continues to ponder its next strategic steps, one of its biggest shareholders would like to remind directors that he’s opposed to including any plan to sell a big minority stake to an outside investor consortium.

headline: Small Businesses Plan to Increase Hiring
text: Our colleagues at the Economix blog have have just published a post about a new National Federation of Independent Business survey indicating that the net share of companies planning to hire workers is at its highest point in 38 months. In fact, the net percentage of companies that say they have already increased their employment in the last three months — that is, the percent saying they increased their staff minus the percent saying they decreased it — was positive for the first time in nearly four years.

headline: ‘Tuck Everlasting’ Musical Sets Sights on Broadway
text: A musical adaptation of the 1975 children’s novel “Tuck Everlasting” is aiming for Broadway next season with the Tony Award winner Casey Nicholaw (“The Book of Mormon”) as director, according to theater executives who attended staged presentations of the show for producers and investors on Friday.

headline: Investigation of Chevy Volt Prompts Opel to Delay Sales of Ampera
text: The Opel Ampera, Europe’s version of the Chevrolet Volt, will sit in showrooms pending resolution by American investigators of a battery fire question related to crash tests of the Volt, according to Andrew Marshall, director of product development communications at Opel.

headline: A Starring Role for the Little Humble Herring
text: IN a fancy women’s department store in Osaka, Japan, earlier this year, shoppers lined up for one of the latest food fads in the country, jars of pickled herring.

headline: ‘Giving Awards’ From JPMorgan Chase Draws Small Audience
text: Will JPMorgan Chase pay for another televised award show for charities next year? After seeing the ratings for its “American Giving Awards,” that is far from a sure thing.

headline: Philosopher Sticks Up for God
text: There are no atheists in foxholes, the old saying goes. Back in the 1950s, when the philosopher Alvin Plantinga was getting his start, there were scarcely more religious believers in academic philosophy departments.

headline: Leading the Way Through the Smoke
text: Straight-shooting, hard-hitting and fuming with contempt for the tobacco industry, “Addiction Incorporated” would be almost too exhausting to watch were it not for the folksy charm of its star witness. Nestled at the center of this relentless documentary, guiding us through a deluge of scientific evidence and corporate bobbing and weaving, is the scientist and whistle-blower Victor J. DeNoble, who reveals himself to be a born raconteur. His easygoing, self-deprecating narration is the film’s most valuable asset and the viewer’s best friend.

text: The Quick Calls section of last week’s App Smart column briefly mentioned a new weight-loss app called Noom.

text: Former executives at Washington Mutual have reached a $64 million agreement to settle a civil lawsuit with the government, according to officials with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which pursued the case after the lender collapsed in 2008 during the subprime mortgage crisis, The New York Times reports. Read more »

headline: Stony Brook University to Get $150 Million Gift
text: James H. Simons usually shuns publicity, though some attention is inescapable for a hedge fund billionaire and major philanthropist. But on occasion, he allows one cause to draw him into public view: Stony Brook University, where he was a mathematics professor long ago.

headline: Now Booking | The Yeatman, Portugal
text: Proud residents of Porto, Portugal, will tell you that the only good thing about Vila Nova de Gaia, the town across the Douro River, is its view of Porto. That’s not inaccurate — it’s just half the story. For port wine lovers, the south-bank town is a sacred place of oak-barreled Burgundy aging to perfection in a cobblestone warren on wobbly, centuries-old port lodges. Above them sits the new Yeatman Hotel, an 82-room resort and spa that takes the idea of a wine hotel (see also the Hotel Marques de Riscal) to new heights. Certainly it’s easy to get that impression after a visit to the hotel’s cork and wine museum or after a stay in suites sponsored and decorated by various Portuguese wineries. The Fladgate master suite ($430 per night) features a 50,000-liter port barrel repurposed as a king-size bed.

headline: California Creates Special Unit to Fight Computer Crimes
text: California has long led the nation in technological innovation. A lesser-known fact: It also leads the country in cybercrime.

headline: ITunes Opens in Latin America, Challenging Rival Services
text: Apple quietly announced on Tuesday that it had opened its iTunes store in Brazil and 15 other countries in Latin America, including Argentina, Venezuela, Chile, Colombia, Nicaragua and Peru. Apple now operates the iTunes music store in 51 countries.

headline: Reviewing Pulqueria
text: Pulqueria , one of this week’s Dining Briefs, is the latest venture by Heather and Christopher Tierney, the siblings behind Apothéke. The restaurant and bar is the city’s first to focus on pulque, the fermented agave sap that Mexicans have been drinking since pre-Columbian times, here mixed with fresh juices and smoky mezcal. A lively crowd dines on chef Nacxitl Gaxiola’s friendly, mildly authentic accompaniments: masa gorditos and empanadas, savory little tacos, selections of salsas from throughout Mexico, and larger, more robust plates like pork shank confit. Some of the dishes are a bit too tame, but there’s also a lot of interest. The Yucatecan pumpkin seed spread, sikil pak, and the tuna tostadas are real winners.

headline: Tere O’Connor’s ‘Cover Boy’
text: Tere O’Connor’s new dance is an all-male affair. It is performed by four men, features only one woman among its collaborators and even has the title “Cover Boy.”

headline: A Buoyant Bouquet Tossed to France
text: Donizetti knew how to make himself beloved. For his first French opera, “La Fille du Régiment,” he composed a shamelessly jingoistic ode to France, a work so ingratiating that for years it was performed in Paris on Bastille Day.

headline: An Almost-Presidents’ Day Quiz
text: Why should we care about presidential losers? Because losing candidates often change American history in more profound ways than some of the men elected president.

headline: A First Iowa Forecast: Race Is Still Wide Open
text: We’re a few days away from releasing the official version of our polling-based forecasts for the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary. But the statistical work behind the model is done, so I can give you a preview of what the forecasts will look like. Conveniently, this will also serve as an overview of the current state of play in Iowa.

headline: Exploring Eliot’s Poem Cycle Anew
text: If you’ve had the feeling that Elliott Carter has been particularly prolific lately, an essay in the program book for a concert by Axiom at Alice Tully Hall on Monday evening confirmed it. Mr. Carter has written 15 new works since his 100th birthday.

headline: U.S. Leaving Iraqi Comrades-in-Arms in Limbo
text: RAMADI, Iraq — Meeting various neighbors and supplicants on a recent evening, America’s staunchest ally in Iraq, Sheik Ahmed Abu Risha, sat in a tent sipping tea from an implausibly tiny glass cup. He greeted each new visitor with a hearty outburst of “dear one” and a kiss on the cheek.

headline: Eli’s Bread Is at the Station
text: The departures and arrivals have come quickly this fall for Grand Central Terminal’s shops and vendors. Now Eli Zabar has opened a bakery, Eli’s Bread, in the Grand Central Market space previously occupied mainly by Corrado Bread and Pastry. Everything sold at Eli’s Bread is made at Mr. Zabar’s bakery on the Upper East Side; construction of a kitchen one floor above the market is expected to be done in a few weeks, and all the breads, breakfast pastries and coffee cakes for Eli’s Bread will be baked there. “That way we can deliver fresh bread to the market several times a day,” Mr. Zabar said. Fancy pastries will still be made uptown. Among the highlights at Eli’s Bread is what Mr. Zabar calls the Grand Central baguette, a handmade bread sold plain or with a liberal scattering of green or black olives in the dough. It’s the same as the Amagansett baguette he sells in the Hamptons in summer.

headline: Tired of Hanukkah Gelt? Try a Chocolate Menorah
text: Michel Cluizel, the French chocolatier, has introduced a line of chocolates and pastries made under kosher supervision in a New Jersey plant. For Hanukkah, he has come up with a pareve chocolate menorah that allows you to observe the tradition in reverse, eating one candle each night instead of adding one. The central candle, or shamus, which is used to kindle the others, is fitted with a small container of almond oil so it can actually be lighted.

headline: Give a Gift, Help a Charity
text: Looking for a gift that will please more than just the recipient? This year there are teas, calendars and a grab bag of Brooklyn-made treats that benefit charitable groups.

headline: My Brother’s Hazing
text: To the Editor:

headline: House Passes Extension of Cut to Payroll Taxes
text: WASHINGTON — Defying a veto threat from President Obama, the House on Tuesday passed a bill extending a cut in Social Security payroll taxes for 160 million Americans for another year. But the Democratic majority in the Senate vowed to reject the measure because of objections to other provisions, including one to speed construction of an oil pipeline from Canada to the Gulf Coast.

headline: Just One Look | Narciso Rodriguez
text: The linear black and pale blue (and red) color-blocked sweaters at Narciso Rodriguez’s prefall collection were hard to ignore. “We’ve never stopped doing knits,” the designer says. “But yes, I guess there are more of them this season.” Other noteworthy pieces include the detachable (read: wonderfully transitional) fox fur sleeves and hooded toppers, and the black body-con leather-blocked dresses that are accented with a graffiti-splash print in black, white and yellow.

headline: File-Sharing Company Sues Record Label, for a Change
text: The way the cats-and-dogs legal fights of the entertainment industry usually work, it’s the big record company or movie studio that sues the offshore Internet corporation, accusing it of violating its rights.

headline: A Perfect Place for a Photo Shoot, With One Catch
text: The client wanted a grand, winding staircase for the photo shoot, something mansionlike and visually distinctive.

headline: Readers Weigh In on Life With and Without Facebook
text: Soon after my article about people who resist the lure of Facebook was posted on The Times’s Web site on Tuesday afternoon, more than 700 people had “liked” it — on Facebook itself. Many left comments about it on The Times’s Facebook page and on our site.

headline: Wall St.’s Odd Couple and Their Quest to Unlock Riches
text: Private equity and public pensions are one of Wall Street’s most peculiar love affairs. Recently, the two have tried to become even closer. But don’t get mushy — this relationship is about money, not romance.

headline: ‘Private Lives’ To Close on Broadway At Year’s End
text: The new Broadway revival of “Private Lives,” starring Kim Cattrall (“Sex and the City”) and Paul Gross, will close five weeks earlier than planned because of weak ticket sales, the producers announced on Tuesday night. The production of the classic Noel Coward play, which opened on Nov. 17 to generally good reviews, will now end on Dec. 31 instead of the original closing date of Feb. 5, 2012.

headline: Boston University Star Is Off Team
text: Corey Trivino, a Boston University center and the leading goal scorer in the Hockey East conference, was thrown off the team by Coach Jack Parker after he was arrested Sunday on charges of indecent assault and battery. Trivino pleaded not guilty to all the charges at his arraignment Monday in Brighton District Court. Assistant District Attorney Cameron Merrill of Suffolk County said in court that witnesses described an intoxicated Trivino breaking into the room of a female student and trying to kiss and grope her. He was charged with three counts of indecent assault and battery, two counts of breaking and entering and one count of assault with attempt to rape. Trivino, a senior, was drafted by the Islanders in 2008.

headline: Have Evangelicals Lost Their Sway?
text: The G.O.P. field is led by a Mormon and a twice-divorced Catholic. Does that show evangelicals' influence has waned?

headline: Massachusetts: Gambling Agency Chairman Is Named
text: Gov. Deval Patrick appointed Stephen Crosby on Tuesday to head the new Massachusetts Gaming Commission, a five-member body formed by the same legislation that legalized three resort-style casinos and one slots parlor in this state. Mr. Crosby, currently the dean of the McCormack Graduate School of Policy and Global Studies at the University of Massachusetts at Boston, previously served as a senior aide to Paul Celucci and Jane Swift, both former Republican governors. The committee will give out licenses for the state’s new gambling spots and set some of the rules that will govern their operation.

headline: City Says Few Jane Addams Seniors Lack Credits
text: After a week of reviewing students' records at a troubled South Bronx high school, Department of Education officials said that most of the school's 200 seniors were on track to graduate in June. Fewer than 10 students are missing credits they will need to graduate and five students' transcripts require further review, officials said.

headline: N.B.A. and Its Conflicts Cloud Getting Best Deal for Hornets
text: Imagine for a moment that George Shinn still owns the New Orleans Hornets. His team is struggling financially and competitively. His franchise star wants out and is threatening to leave as a free agent next July.

headline: Controversy Drives Advertisers From  ‘All-American Muslim’ — Or Does it?
text: At least two advertisers have withdrawn commercials from “All-American Muslim,” a new series on the TLC cable channel, since an activist organization called the Florida Family Association condemned the show. But others cited by the organization as pulling out as sponsors are disputing the claim.

headline: Hezbollah’s Hypocritical Resistance
text: Exeter, England

headline: Ron Paul Rising
text: The race for the Republican nomination may be coming down to Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney, but in the contest for the Iowa caucuses, their high-profile battle might still turn out to be a sideshow. The national party has spent the last two weeks resigning itself to a choice between the former speaker and the former Massachusetts governor. But Iowa Republicans may end up choosing between Gingrich and Representative Ron Paul.

headline: Park Tae-joon, Founder of a Giant in Steel, Dies at 84
text: Park Tae-joon, a former South Korean general who created Posco, one of the world’s largest steel companies, helping to lay the foundation for his nation’s rise from an impoverished postwar society into an industrial powerhouse, died on Tuesday in Seoul. He was 84.

headline: As Rivalry Tightens, Romney Is Reflective
text: MADISON, N.H. — Mitt Romney — he of the inscrutable, overly polished and occasionally robotic mien — is striving mightily to humanize himself just three weeks before the first round of voting begins. And that means no topic, be it his experience with humble toilets (“a bucket affair”) or his faith, is off limits.

headline: Bidding for Japanese Players Is a Denigrated Risk
text: Shortly after the Boston Red Sox won the rights to negotiate with the star right-hander Daisuke Matsuzaka in November 2006, the Yankees did the same with the left-hander Kei Igawa.

headline: Avon Announces Plans to Seek a New Chief Executive
text: After years of tepid earnings and turmoil, the cosmetics giant Avon Products announced late Tuesday that it planned to look for a new chief executive to replace its longtime leader, Andrea Jung.

headline: In Boxing, Not All Olympic Trial Winners Become Olympians
text: Ever since Jose Ramirez started boxing, he placed one goal above all others: to represent the United States in the Olympics. To that end, he declined to turn professional, won more than 100 amateur bouts and studied videos of past Olympians like Oscar De La Hoya.

headline: Former Gingrich Aide Forms Fund-Raising Group
text: A former top aide to Newt Gingrich formed a Super PAC on Tuesday to help bolster Mr. Gingrich’s resurgent presidential campaign, giving him a potentially powerful tool as he seeks to maintain his lead in key primary states against a flurry of attacks from other candidates and Super PACs.

headline: Democrats Find a Welcome Distraction
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama bluntly acknowledged Tuesday that winning a second term was “not a slam-dunk,” but a development outside his control is bolstering Democratic spirits: the prospect of a drawn-out Republican battle between Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich.

headline: Bursts of Economic Growth in Panama Have Yet to Banish Old Ghosts
text: PANAMA — Gleaming new skyscrapers line the waterfront like a mini-Dubai, as boosters say, including a new 70-story Trump tower that is the tallest building in Latin America.

headline: Immigration Crackdown Also Snares Americans
text: A growing number of United States citizens have been detained under Obama administration programs intended to detect illegal immigrants who are arrested by local police officers.

headline: Selling Swipes May Be a Swindle, but Don’t Call It Larceny
text: It is a classic subterranean swindle, up there with turnstile hopping and token sucking: the selling of contraband swipes from an unlimited MetroCard to unquestioning subway riders.

headline: 11th Body, Believed to Be of Missing Woman, Is Found
text: They had planned to gather on Tuesday, on the barren shore along Ocean Parkway on Long Island, to remember the victims of a suspected serial killer, the remains found scattered among the area’s shrouded thickets over the past year.

headline: A Delisting for Olympus Puts Japan in a Debate
text: TOKYO — Scandal-racked Olympus has cleared the first hurdle to avoiding expulsion from the Tokyo Stock Exchange. But a final decision on whether the exchange will carry out its threat to delist Olympus’s shares may still be months away.

headline: Egypt Drops Some Charges Against Blogger
text: Updated | Wednesday | 6:38 p.m. A civilian court in Cairo dropped two charges against a prominent blogger and activist, Alaa Abd El Fattah, the Egyptian newspaper Al-Masry Al-Youm reported on Tuesday.

headline: Anthony’s Hurt Knee Further Unsettles Knicks
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Knicks are days away from their first exhibition game but do not appear any closer to fully figuring out a roster that is still in flux. They have sought to add free agents, and have not given up. Now they are also trying to work around injuries that have made it more difficult to gather a sense of what they are working with.

headline: Archdiocese Can Demolish SoHo Church, Court Rules
text: A nearly five-year struggle over the future of a Roman Catholic parish in SoHo that began with a sudden padlock on the church doors ended on Tuesday, when New York State’s highest court affirmed that the Archdiocese of New York had the right to demolish the shuttered building despite opposition from the former parishioners.

headline: Lottery Numbers
A Troubled Girl Then, a Proud Woman Today
text: When Carmen Roman used to look in the mirror, she hated what she saw.

headline: Confusion Follows Claim That Corzine Knew of Funds Transfer
text: WASHINGTON — A Senate hearing into the collapse of MF Global was thrown into confusion on Tuesday after a main witness implied that Jon S. Corzine, its former chief executive, knew the firm had been misusing customer funds, an accusation that could not be substantiated.

headline: $4.8 Million Sought From Morgan Stanley in Price-Fixing Case
text: WASHINGTON — An electricity price-fixing scandal thought to have cost New York consumers about $300 million has led to a proposed settlement with Morgan Stanley for $4.8 million. But the proposal has brought complaints from a consumer group, which points out that the company took in four times that much in the scheme.

headline: Patents and the Public Interest
text: Next week, in a case closely watched both by analysts and retailers, the International Trade Commission will decide whether the handset maker HTC should be allowed to import its products into the United States. The controversy? A claim by Apple that HTC infringed on two of the estimated 250,000 patents covering smartphone technology. If the commission agrees, it is likely to issue an “exclusion order,” which would in effect say “keep out” (of the United States) to HTC’s Android phones during the Christmas season.

headline: With Port Actions, Occupy Oakland Tests Labor Leaders
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — In most cities, the Occupy movement has been thrown on the defensive, struggling to regroup and plan new protests after being evicted from its encampments by the police.

headline: A Tiger Execution
text: At 11:30 a.m. on the beautiful, crisp morning of Dec. 9, 1861, several thousand somber Confederate soldiers in Gen. Edmund Kirby Smith’s division formed a three-sided square around a slight natural depression outside their camp near Centreville, Va. Outside the ranks, both soldiers and civilians climbed into trees and onto rooftops to get a better view, for this was no ordinary muster. A military court had convicted two men for attacking an officer and trying to free some prisoners from a guard house. The sentence was death by firing squad.

headline: To Maintain Water Pumps, It Takes More Than a Village

headline: Aiding Disabled, Nonprofits Rake in State Money

headline: Offices With More Breathing Room
text: The 28th floor of the office building at 499 Park Avenue has 17-foot-high windows that run from floor to ceiling on four sides, and they offer views clear to the George Washington Bridge and to airplanes taking off from La Guardia and Newark airports.

headline: Morgan Stanley Has More to Do
text: Morgan Stanley’s settlement with the bond insurer MBIA leaves behind another big chunk of the financial crisis. At $1.8 billion, it doesn’t come cheap for James Gorman, Morgan Stanley’s chief executive. But it puts Mr. Gorman’s company on the right track by increasing regulatory capital and tidying up a very messy second year for him.

headline: After Officer’s Killing, a Focus on a North Carolina Warrant
text: Despite his being wanted for a shooting in North Carolina, the man accused of killing a police officer in Brooklyn on Monday was twice released from jail in New York this fall because the authorities in North Carolina declined to have him extradited, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said on Tuesday.

headline: Providence Puts Focus on Making a Home for Knowledge
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — When Brown University opened its new $45 million medical school in August about a mile from its campus here, it was the institution’s first academic department to be located away from its home on College Hill overlooking downtown Providence.

headline: Aid for Child Care Drops When It Is Needed Most
text: BALTIMORE — With states under pressure to cut their budgets and federal stimulus money gone, low-income working parents are facing a paradox. Just when they have to work longer hours to make ends meet, they are losing access to the thing they need most to stay on the job: a government subsidy that helps pay for child care.

text: They may be a little less swift on their feet or nimble in a fight, but despite the perils of their job, many have never lost their love for the electricity and unpredictability of the streets.

headline: I Wouldn’t Touch That Pie, if I Were You
text: The torture-porn movie business has an ancient and revered progenitor in the immortal Shakespeare himself. His early tragedy “Titus Andronicus” is a careering pileup of gothic horrors in which great ingenuity is shown in the matter of violent murder. Heads and hands are lopped off at regular intervals; the body count practically defies computation; and the finale is a banquet that only the meat-pie-making Mrs. Lovett of “Sweeney Todd” could love.

headline: At Aqueduct, Clubhouse and Casino Are Different Turfs
text: The opening of Resorts World’s new neon-blazing casino at the graying 117-year-old Aqueduct Racetrack — the “racino” — is more of a culture clash than a gambling hybrid.

headline: A Face Wash Campaign for the iPhone Set
text: WHAT do teenagers and young adults hope to get as holiday gifts? Smartphones? Tablet computers? Video games? If a giant marketer has its way, they may instead find face wash dispensers under the Christmas tree or Hanukkah bush.

headline: Shining Light on the Role of Drivers in Prostitution
text: Sofia, a sweet-voiced and cherubic 24-year-old, was one of the lucky ones: She managed to escape much of the suffering shared by the millions of sex workers trafficked throughout the world, and even saw two of her traffickers forced out of the country and back to Mexico.

headline: New Law Bans Mail-Order Drug Mandates
text: Mom-and-pop pharmacies will be better able to compete with mail-order companies because of a bill that Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has signed into law.

text: I have a simple motto when it comes to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. I love both Israelis and Palestinians, but God save me from some of their American friends — those who want to love them to death, literally.

text: The chart below shows the intricate money-laundering system the Lebanese Canadian Bank used to divert money to the Shiite militant group Hezbollah, according to United States officials.

headline: Richards Is Held at Bay by the Stars, His Former Team
text: The game did not go according to the script Tuesday at Madison Square Garden. Brad Richards, the Rangers’ $60 million man, was facing his former team, the Dallas Stars, and instead of a night of fireworks, it was a sleepy affair.

headline: Beirut Bank Seen as a Hub of Hezbollah’s Financing
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Last February, the Obama administration accused one of Lebanon’s famously secretive banks of laundering money for an international cocaine ring with ties to the Shiite militant group Hezbollah.

headline: Italian Leader Revises Plans for Austerity
text: ROME — Prime Minister Mario Monti on Tuesday announced changes to a pension overhaul and reintroduced a property tax to gain parliamentary support for a budget that he hopes will calm world markets and rein in Italy’s public debt.

headline: The Insidious Fine Print
text: It looks like a small throwaway line in a 2012 spending bill: no federal funds may be used to carry out chapters 95 or 96 of the Internal Revenue Code. A little digging shows that those chapters happen to authorize the presidential election public financing system. A few House Republicans, who have long hated the system, thought they could get rid of it by inserting the line in a bill to keep the government from shutting down this weekend.

headline: Stopping the Free-for-All
text: The Supreme Court’s decision to review a federal court ruling blocking parts of Arizona’s notorious immigration law is troubling. It is arguably premature to take this case because there is no split among the federal appellate courts over states’ powers to enact such laws.

headline: Donald Is Seeking Validation in Winning Majors, Not Money
text: The Englishman Luke Donald cemented his place in golf history last weekend by becoming the first player to win the money titles on the European and PGA Tours. In a teleconference call with reporters Tuesday, Donald sounded as if he would trade that coup for the one feat that eluded him during a sparkling season that culminated in his winning the PGA Tour player of the year in a vote of his peers.

headline: Candid Advice From a Health Care Visionary
text: Dr. Donald Berwick, who was blocked by Republicans from serving a full term as the administrator of the agency that runs Medicare and Medicaid, has been speaking out. He makes a compelling case about the harm caused by partisan demagoguery and about the need for health care professionals to take the lead in implementing reforms.

headline: A Cab in Brooklyn
text: As any seasoned New Yorker knows, it’s almost impossible to find a yellow cab outside the heart of Manhattan. Instead, livery cars cruise the streets of the outer boroughs and pick up passengers illegally. They haggle over rates, deal in cash and nobody knows whether the city sees any of this money as tax revenue.

headline: More Than 30 Are Killed Across Syria as Sectarian Tensions Grow
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 32 people were killed across Syria on Tuesday, including seven members of the security forces, amid rising sectarian tensions in some places, opposition groups said.

text: President Obama’s political strategists have identified a variety of paths to reach the 270 electoral votes he needs to win re-election.

headline: J. Lynn Helms, Who Led the F.A.A., Dies at 86
text: J. Lynn Helms, who as head of the Federal Aviation Administration supported President Ronald Reagan’s decision to fire more than 11,000 striking air traffic controllers and who subsequently helped restore the nation’s crippled air traffic control system, died on Sunday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 86.

headline: Bert Schneider, Producer Whose Films Reflected an Era, Dies at 78
text: Bert Schneider, a producer of “Easy Rider” and other films that reflected and helped define the social unrest of the late 1960s and early ’70s, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 78.

headline: Erica Wilson Dies at 83; Led a Rebirth of Needleworking
text: Erica Wilson, the Julia Child of needlework, who brought the gentle art of crewel — as well as cross-stitch, needlepoint and other traditional embroidery techniques — to an international audience through her books, television shows, correspondence courses, syndicated column and retail shops, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 83.

headline: Pot of Gold

headline: TaskRabbit Plans to Multiply
text: How many tasks can you perform with nearly $18 million dollars? TaskRabbit, a San Francisco-based start-up that helps people run errands, is about to find out. The company announced Wednesday that it had received $17.8 million in financing.

headline: With States Desperate to Keep Jobs, Companies Have Upper Hand, Report Shows
text: As the unemployment crisis grinds on, states are trying to both lure and retain businesses by offering tax breaks, grants, cheap loans — just about anything (short of candy and foot massages) they can think of. But how many jobs do these expensive incentives actually create?

headline: How Coffee Can Galvanize Your Workout
text: Can a cup of coffee motivate you to relish your trips to the gym this winter? That question is at the heart of a notable study of caffeine and exercise, one of several new experiments suggesting that, whatever your sport, caffeine may allow you to perform better and enjoy yourself more.

No, they were sent to Europe’s second-tier competition, the league formerly known as UEFA and currently called Europa.

text: The concussion news continued to grow worse for the N.H.L. on Tuesday, with the Philadelphia Flyers announcing that Claude Giroux would be out indefinitely with a head injury.

headline: The Panchatantra Guide to Getting Ahead

headline: New Orleans Jazz Festival Announces 2012 Lineup
text: If you want to know just how far jazz has slipped in the hierarchy of pop music, just look the line-up for next year’s New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. Sure, Herbie Hancock is a headliner, but the rest of the names at the top of the bill to be announced Wednesday morning are a hodge-podge of pop, rock and R&B stars from various eras.

headline: Leaving the Sunni Awakening in Limbo
text: Sheik Ahmed Abu Risha is seen as America’s staunchest ally in Iraq. An article in Wednesday’s Times reports on how the withdrawal of the United States will leave Mr. Abu Risha and the militia units he commands, known broadly as the Sunni Awakening, to navigate increasingly troublesome relations with the central Shiite-led government of Iraq.

headline: Google Celebrates the Season by Promoting Its Charitable Grants

headline: Police Link Belgian Gunman to a Killing Before Rampage
text: LIÈGE, Belgium — Belgians sought to make sense on Wednesday of a spasm of killing by a man with a history of trouble with weapons and drugs who unleashed his attack near a Christmas market at a historic square, bringing random death to a familiar scene of European holiday bustle.

headline: Dec. 14, 1981 | Israel Annexes Former Syrian Territory of Golan Heights
text: On Dec. 14, 1981, Israel annexed the territory on the Golan Heights that it had seized from Syria in 1967. The New York Times called it an “abrupt move” that came as a surprise not only to international observers, but also to many Israelis who felt that it was hastily pushed through parliament by Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

headline: Nasrallah’s Fighting Words
text: BEIRUT — The Shiite holy day of Ashura, which commemorates the death of the Prophet Muhammad’s grandson Hussein at the Battle of Karbala in 680, marks the birth of the schism that still divides Sunnis and Shiites. This year, Ashura had a special echo in Lebanon: on Nov. 28, Hezbollah’s secretary general, Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah, gave a speech rife with sectarian overtones, casting Hussein’s ancient tragedy as a parable of contemporary Lebanese politics.

headline: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 14, 2011

headline: The Pakistanis Have a Point
text: As an American visitor in the power precincts of Pakistan, from the gated enclaves of Islamabad to the manicured lawns of the military garrison in Peshawar, from the luxury fortress of the Serena Hotel to the exclusive apartments of the parliamentary housing blocks, you can expect three time-honored traditions: black tea with milk, obsequious servants and a profound sense of grievance.

headline: What Nail Polish Sales Tell Us About the Economy
text: Economics is all about consumption. People either spend money now or they use financial instruments — like bonds, stocks and savings accounts — so they can spend more later. A healthy economy is largely a result of a reasonable balance between consumption today and consumption deferred, and it’s pretty clear that balance has been ridiculously out of whack for a while.

headline: What Places in Your Past Do You Appreciate More Now, From a Distance?
text: Sometimes, returning to places we knew in the past can surprise us: We might notice new details, or appreciate aspects we didn’t at the time. When have you ever seen a place you’ve lived or spent time in with “new eyes”? Do you think you are conscious of what’s special in your current environment, or does the tedium of daily life make you forget to notice these details? In his Op-Ed column “Time, Distance and Clarity,” Frank Bruni reflects on the phenomenon of experiencing a familiar place in a new and different way:

headline: Putin Ally Resigns Speaker’s Post Amid Vote Furor

headline: Meet the New Motherlode Blogger
text: Welcome to Motherlode? Hardly. It is you who I hope will welcome me. Although I’ve been a reader since the beginning (and occasionally a contributor), stepping into what I think of as the “big boots” of Motherlode is daunting and thrilling. As a writer and blogger, I’ve always thought of Motherlode as, well, the motherlode: the ultimate place to start or join a conversation about the way we raise children now. I’m very happy to be here.

headline: Despite 2 Floods, a Business Decides to Stay Put
text: Last week, we published a case study about two disaster-frazzled entrepreneurs seemingly in need of some of the calming supplemental holistic health services — yoga and massage — that they offer at Pulling Down the Moon, a Chicago business that was hit by two floods within a year.

headline: Village Revolts Over Inequities of Chinese Life
text: BEIJING — A long-running dispute between farmers and local officials in southern China exploded into open rebellion this week after villagers chased away government leaders, set up roadblocks and began arming themselves with homemade weapons, residents said.

headline: German Coalition Figure Quits Abruptly
text: BERLIN — A senior figure in Germany’s junior coalition partner resigned abruptly on Wednesday, presenting Chancellor Angela Merkel with a potential political distraction as she leads European efforts to combat the euro crisis, warning that there will be “no simple and fast solutions” to rescue the beleaguered common currency.

headline: Daily Report: Safety Board Urges Cellphone Ban for Drivers
text: The National Transportation Safety Board is urging states to ban drivers from using hands-free devices, including wireless headsets. The concern was heightened by increasingly powerful smartphones that people use to e-mail, watch movies and play games.

headline: Inevitable, or in Limbo? A Dam for the Mekong
text: As The Times reported last week, environment ministers from Vietnam, Cambodia, Thailand and Laos have decided to await the results of further studies before making a decision on whether to proceed with construction of a dam in the Mekong River. Conservationists argue that damming the river, a vital and biologically diverse lifeline for people in all four countries, would be irresponsible. (Check out our slide show to get a sense of the river’s centrality to people in the basin.)

headline: Critics’ Picks: Movies of 2011
text: A look at some of the year’s top films, as selected by the co-chief film critics A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis.

headline: Old-Fashioned Glories in a Netflix Age
text: MANOHLA DARGIS As we know, it’s become ritualistic for critics to whine about the end of the year being crowded with Oscar hopefuls. Oh, pity the poor movie critic forced to watch a new Martin Scorsese movie, a new David Fincher and two from Steven Spielberg in short succession! Yet while this period seems jammed with Important Movies From Harvey Weinstein, the rest of the year looks dire only if audiences count on the major studios and usual suspects for their film fixes. The problem is that the race to the Oscars now so profoundly consumes everyone’s attention that it has distorted the perception of what’s actually available.

headline: OPEC Opts to Increase Its Level of Output
text: The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed on Wednesday to increase its production target for the first time in three years, a move that appeared to signal that Saudi Arabia and Iran had put aside their recent differences on oil policy, at least temporarily.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Visiting Manhattan on a Budget
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: U.S. Envoy Relieved by Climate Talks’ Outcome
text: The senior American climate change envoy, Todd D. Stern, is back in Washington from the double-overtime United Nations negotiations in Durban, South Africa, and has declared himself pretty well satisfied with the result, although closing the deal wasn’t easy.

text: Tina Turnbow is a professional makeup artist known for lending her celebrity clients editorial polish.

headline: Olympus Restates Earnings, Showing Loss
text: TOKYO — Hours before a critical deadline Wednesday, Olympus, Japan’s chastened camera maker, released revised financial results, owning up to more than $1 billion in losses it hid for more than a decade.

headline: Interest Rates, Inflation, and the Way the World Works (Slightly Wonkish)
text: Newish commenters here often fail to understand why I highlight things like falling inflation in Britain or the extremely low interest rates at which the governments of non-euro nations can borrow. Is it just I-told-you-so? No. It’s about economic models — how the world works. And of course such models have policy implications.

headline: Syrian Army Defectors Ambush Soldiers
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian military defectors killed at least eight members of the security forces on Wednesday in an ambush near the city of Hama, in central Syria, according to opposition groups.

headline: Marijuana Use Growing Among Teenagers
text: One out of every 15 high school students smokes marijuana on a near daily basis, a figure that has reached a 30-year peak even as use of alcohol, cigarettes and cocaine among teenagers continues a slow decline, according to a new government report.

headline: In Sandusky Case, Yet Another Sad, Strange Turn
text: To the series of sorry spectacles that has been the Jerry Sandusky/Penn State child sexual abuse scandal, we add one of the sorriest yet. To call Tuesday’s preliminary hearing-that-wasn’t a circus would be insulting the actual circus. Under this metaphorical big top, Sandusky’s lawyer all but stood on top of a car with a bullhorn urging everyone to come attend his client’s hearing — including dragging in a set of alleged victims who had to skewer up the courage to testify in open court — and then waived the hearing after they’d all arrived.
