headline: Frenchman to Join Board of Europe’s Bank
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank might become more open to intervention in bond markets after European lawmakers on Wednesday approved Benoît Coeuré, a French economist and longtime Treasury official, for a seat on the policy making executive board.

headline: Windows Phone 7 Caught in Mobile App Catch-22
text: Designers and start-up tech firms seem to agree on two things when it comes to Microsoft’s Windows Phone 7 mobile platform. First, it’s gorgeous and uniquely designed. Second, they won’t be building an app for it in the near future.

headline: A Closer Look at the Actors’ Picks
text: During all the awards hoopla, actors often talk about how meaningful it is to be recognized by their peers, and the Screen Actors Guild, which announced its nominees today, may be the highest expression of that sentiment, or at the least the ceremony where you hear it repeated in acceptance speeches the most.

headline: Woman Fatally Crushed in Midtown Elevator Accident
text: Read the updated version of this article that appears in the newspaper.

headline: Outright Ban on Cellphone Use in Car: A Recommendation Too Far?
text: On Tuesday, the National Transportation Safety Board, an independent federal agency responsible for promoting traffic safety and investigating accidents, recommended that states ban drivers from using hands-free devices, including wireless headsets. As noted Tuesday by The Times, it was the first time that a federal agency urged an end to the practice completely, rather than endorsing a partial ban, as some state legislatures have adopted to permit hands-free talking.

headline: Riding Off Into Civilization’s Sunset
text: IT was the season of apocalypse. Whether your idea of the end is reconciliatory (a family reunion on a misty far shore in “The Tree of Life”) or punishing — the collision of Earth with another planet in “Melancholia”; extinction in a metaphysical tornado in “Take Shelter” — 2011 was the year of brooding cosmic consciousness in serious films. Even the mystical “Tree of Life” is shadowed with the notion of a fearsome, authoritarian God.

headline: A Paul-Gingrich Showdown?
text: In this week’s column for Campaign Stops, I look at what could be the defining battle of the Iowa caucuses — Newt Gingrich versus Ron Paul:

headline: No Word on President’s Return to Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — President Asif Ali Zardari of Pakistan, who unexpectedly flew to the United Arab Emirates on Dec. 6 for what was officially described as medical treatment, will be discharged from a hospital there on Thursday, according to his aides and physician.

headline: Staging Your Own Theatrical Table Reading
text: I’m a fan of reading plays — new ones, old ones — as literature, and I have written before about how Americans are missing out by not keeping up, on the page, with the best theater in New York City and elsewhere. The only thing better than reading a play yourself is reading it with people you like, a fact I am reminded of by the opening tomorrow of Roman Polanski’s new film “Carnage.”

headline: Elizabeth Taylor’s Collection Breaks Records at Christie’s
text: Elizabeth Taylor’s stardust lent a profitable glow to the first night of Christie’s auction of the movie star’s extensive collection of jewelry and clothing. The sale of Taylor’s “Legendary Jewels” grossed just under $116 million, more than doubling the previous record for a private jewel collection sold at auction. The jewels of the Duchess of Windsor garnered about $50 million in 1987.

headline: Nerve.com Introduces a Hip Dating Site — Again
text: Before there were hip dating sites like OkCupid, Grindr and Grouper, there was Nerve Personals, the racy dating section of the online magazine Nerve.com, which billed itself as a home for “literate smut.”

headline: Report Seeks Far Tighter Safety System for Oil Drilling
text: Companies involved in offshore drilling and the government agencies that regulate drilling should take a more robust and systematic approach to ensuring safety, a team of scientific experts advised on Wednesday in a report on last year’s Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: As Gas Drilling Spreads, Towns Stand Ground Over Control
text: SOUTH FAYETTE, Pa. — As energy companies move to drill in densely populated areas from Pennsylvania to Texas, battles are breaking out over who will have the final say in managing the shale gas boom.

headline: Pop-Up Book Roundup
text: New pop-up editions of “Puff the Magic Dragon,” “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory” and others.

headline: At Least for Reid, Gingrich Is the 2012 Republican Pick
text: Senator Harry Reid of Nevada may not be a pollster, but he has already decided who President Obama will be facing next year. Mr. Reid, the Democratic majority leader, in describing on the Senate floor his distaste for Republican legislative techniques, alluded to a possible government shutdown, and then proclaimed former Speaker Newt Gingrich as the Republican near-nominee for the 2012 presidential race.

headline: Christmas a Good Time to Buy Used Cars, Analysis Shows
text: If you’re waiting to shop for a used car until after the busy holiday season, you might want to reconsider. An analysis from the automotive Web site CarGurus suggests that you’ll get a much better deal on a used car if you shop close to the Christmas holiday, instead of waiting until later in the winter.Demand for cars tends to flag at the end of the year. That means prices can be attractive, according to a study of seasonal price trends compiled by CarGurus. The site based its analysis on its used-car price index, with has tracked list prices on roughly 12 million used cars since 2010.

headline: Osawatomie and Opportunity
text: Jonathan Chait had an interesting response to the criticisms that both David Frum and I lodged against the President’s Osawatomie speech. We both suggested that the president offered a plausible description of the middle class’s recent woes, coupled with a weak and potentially counterproductive prescription for how to actually address them. To this, Chait basically conceded the relative thinness of the president’s opportunity agenda, and then went on to argue that it doesn’t really matter because the Republicans are worse:

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: ‘Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy’
text: This holiday season brings two spy thrillers of very different stripes: one in an explosive package (“Mission: Impossible — Ghost Protocol”) and one in which the tensions bubble beneath the surface (“Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.”) The latter has garnered strong audience interest this past weekend in its limited debut, grossing more than $310,000 in four locations. Based on John le Carré’s novel, “Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy” looks at the inner workings of the British secret service in the early 1970s. In her review, Manohla Dargis called the film “a pleasurably sly and involving puzzler — a mystery about mysteries within mysteries.”

headline: Video From Inside Rebellious Chinese Village
text: As my colleague Andrew Jacobs reports, the village of Wukan in the industrial heartland of Guangdong Province in China is in open rebellion against local authorities, residents say.

headline: The Year in Media | Record Labels Still Carry a Big Price Tag
text: Staff members of The Times’s media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

headline: Pop-Up Book Roundup
text: GUESS HOW MUCH I LOVE YOUThe Pop-Up Edition.By Sam McBratney. Illustrated by Anita Jeram. Paper engineering by Corina Fletcher.16 pp. Candlewick Press. $19.99. (Picture book; ages 1 to 5)

headline: The Politics of the Top 1 Percent
text: What are the political attitudes of the very wealthy?  How, and how much, do they differ from the less wealthy?  The combination of growing inequality, a weak economy, and Occupy Wall Street’s ability to focus political debate on inequality makes the answers to these questions particularly relevant.

headline: Independents a Problem for Gingrich, Polls Find
text: While poll after poll this month finds Newt Gingrich to be the preferred candidate among Republicans nationally, and in several early voting states, his unpopularity among all Americans in some of the same surveys underscores the deep challenges he could face in a general election.

headline: Israel Leader Sets Curbs on Settlers for Violence
text: JERUSALEM — After two days of settler violence that shocked much of Israel, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced Wednesday that some radical Israelis would be treated the same way as suspected Palestinian militants — detained for long periods without charge and tried in military courts.

headline: Boukies, a Greek Spot, to Replace Heartbreak
text: Christos Valtzoglou, who already owned Pylos, a well-regarded East Village Greek restaurant with a dramatic ceiling hung with terra-cotta jugs, hired the chef Ingrid Roettele and added a Swiss-German restaurant to his stable. He called it Heartbreak — a prescient name, since it closed in October after a brief run, just two days before Michelin awarded it a star.

headline: State of the Union Date Is Set
text: President Obama will deliver the State of the Union address on Jan. 24 before a joint session of Congress, an appearance that inevitably will set the tone and sound the theme of economic renewal for his re-election campaign.

headline: The Police, the Press and Protests: Did Everyone Get the Memo?
text: Back in November when New York police officers pushed protesters out of Zuccotti Park, many reporters were physically prevented from covering the events, ostensibly as a way to keep them safe.

headline: Gervais’s Silent Partner Talks and Gets Laughs for Himself
text: LONDON — The first thing Stephen Merchant does in his new stand-up act is seize the elephant in the room and wrestle it to the ground.

headline: The Meh List
text: Not hot. Not not. Just meh.

headline: SurveyMonkey Valued at $1 Billion as TPG Joins as Investor
text: SurveyMonkey is all grown up.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: Just how good are the Texans? Can Tim Tebow and the Broncos beat Tom Brady and the Patriots? Will any more coaches be fired before the end of the season? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will again answer selected questions from readers this week. Use the comment field below to ask your questions, and the answers will appear on The Fifth Down on Friday.

headline: Ben Brantley’s Top 10 of 2011
text: Photos of “Other Desert Cities,” “The Book of Mormon” and other shows.

headline: On Our Radar: A Serial Bird’s-Egg Thief
text: A Briton has drawn a fourth jail sentence for his persistent thefts of rare birds’ eggs. He was found with almost 700 wild bird eggs at his home in London, including eggs from such species as the osprey and golden eagle. Some of the eggs were stolen just before the chicks hatched, the authorities say. [The Guardian]

headline: Comptroller Halts Custodians' Contract
text: Comptroller John C. Liu has said no to a proposal by the Department of Education to spend $65 million for custodial services next year, an increase of $20 million. "With budget deficits still looming, contracts with huge inexplicable cost increases and other outstanding questions simply cannot be green-lighted,'' he said.

headline: The Attorney General and Voting Rights
text: There has been a coordinated attack this year on voting rights. More than a dozen states have enacted laws that are intended to make it more burdensome for Americans to cast a ballot, which President Lyndon Johnson called “the basic right, without which all others are meaningless.” New requirements – for special IDs, for example–will reduce turnout among minorities, the uneducated, the poor, the elderly, the newly arrived, students and other groups that traditionally vote for Democratic candidates. (For an explanation of why voter ID laws have a discriminatory effect, see my previous post on the subject.)

headline: Nokia Courts Smartphone Newbies in U.S. Return
text: The past few years have not been kind to Nokia in the cellphone market, especially in the United States where homegrown iPhones and Android handsets crowded out the venerable Finnish handset maker.

headline: A Start-Up Incubator That Floats
text: Technology gurus have long lamented how hard it is for foreign talent to secure American visas and create start-ups here. As Congress spins its wheels with endless debate over immigration, an ambitious venture based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is trying to chart a more productive course aboard a 600-foot boat, or possibly a barge.

headline: Canada and Mexico Aim for an Oscar Nomination Repeat
text: One of the oddities of the most recent competition for the best foreign-language film Oscar was that the five finalists included both Canada and Mexico. That had happened only once before, in 2006, and precedent would seem to dictate that films from America’s neighbors to the north and south are unlikely to be nominated together in two consecutive years. Nevertheless, both countries have strong entries again in 2011, with films that could scarcely be more different from each other.

headline: PAC Backing Romney Shows Anti-Gingrich Ad
text: How worried are Mitt Romney supporters?

headline: Plain Speaking at the End of Life
text: Dr. Stephen Workman, an internist at the Queen Elizabeth II Health Sciences Center in Halifax, Nova Scotia, takes exception to the language physicians use with patients near the end of life. In one of his recent publications, he called language the most important tool health professionals have to improve the care of dying patients.

headline: 36 Hours: Salzburg, Austria
text: WITH its medieval citadel, Baroque palaces and yodel-ready Alpine vistas, Salzburg has never had trouble luring visitors. The Austrian city abounds with tourists, most searching for the sound of music — be it Mozart or the von Trapps. Yet some of its best offerings are its least historic: contemporary galleries, fair trade coffeehouses and the futuristic Hangar 7 complex. In winter, the city is at its most hospitable, as squares transform into bustling Christmas markets, and candlelit taverns fill with skiers refueling on Teutonic comfort food. Salzburg may no longer be frozen in the past, but its appeal is timeless.

headline: 36 Hours: Salzburg, Austria
text: In winter, the city is at its most hospitable, as squares transform into bustling Christmas markets, and candlelit taverns fill with skiers refueling on Teutonic comfort food.

headline: Fête Accompli | Giving Arthur Elgort
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: With Candidates Like This …
text: David Brooks: Gail, I’m on vacation this week, and in my absence the entire political world seems to have come to bipartisan agreement: Newt Gingrich would be a terrible president. I believe this. George Will believes this. Michael Savage, the über-populist shock jock, is offering him $1 million to quit the race. Every commentator on the left believes this.

headline: Nearly 1 in 5 Women in U.S. Survey Say They Have Been Sexually Assaulted
text: An exhaustive government survey of rape and domestic violence released on Wednesday affirmed that sexual violence against women remains endemic in the United States and in some instances may be far more common than previously thought.

headline: That Should Be a Word
text: Bagri-cul-ture, n.

headline: Army-Navy Project Ventures Far Beyond Football
text: Navy beat Army for the 10th straight year last Saturday, 27-21, but CBS’s broadcast will not be the last word on the Midshipmen’s victory. Instead, footage from nine video cameras stationed at FedEx Field will form a major part of a new documentary, “A Game of Honor” (Showtime, Dec. 21, at 10 p.m.), that explores how the academies’ players balance football with military commitments.

headline: Romney Warns of Nominating ‘Zany’ Gingrich
text: 9:31 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

headline: Mick Rock Survives the ’70s to Shoot Again
text: COFFEE. Mick Rock, the rock ’n’ roll photographer as famous for his hedonistic lifestyle as for his iconic images of debauchery and excess, was drinking nothing more than coffee. It was 5 p.m. on a recent Tuesday, and while hotel guests drank cocktails at the lounge of the W New York Downtown, Mr. Rock, a slim and youthful man in his 60s in tinted glasses, got his fix.

headline: Mitt Romney on Newt Gingrich
text: In an interview with The New York Times, Mitt Romney questioned whether Newt Gingrich would be "zany" in the White House.

headline: High Court Spotlight on Right to ‘Credit Bid’
text: Despite my earlier prediction, the Supreme Court has agreed to decide whether a Chapter 11 debtor can avoid a lender’s right to credit bid when doing a sale under a plan, as opposed to the more famous Section 363.

headline: Obama Praises Troops as He Ends the War He Opposed
text: FORT BRAGG, N.C. — President Obama observed the end of the war in Iraq on Wednesday before an audience of those who fought in it, telling a crowd of returning war veterans that the nearly nine years of conflict in Iraq, a war now indelibly imprinted on the national psyche, had come to a close.

headline: How Should I Feel About the French Mitt Romney Ad?
text: Readers who think I always have an opinion loaded and ready to fire may be interested to know that I was stumped this week — by a political ad, of all things. (After 24 years of covering politics for a living, it’s hard even to find them surprising.)

headline: Obama’s Speech to Troops at Fort Bragg
W.i.P.
text: A MODERN reimagination of Andy Warhol’s Factory? That’s the idea, anyway, behind W.i.P., an art-slathered club that opened last month in the basement beneath Greenhouse, another club around the corner. W.i.P. (for Work in Progress) is a venture between Barry Mullineaux, who runs Greenhouse, and an arts outfit called Collective Hardware.

headline: Holiday Shopping at the Last Minute? No Worries Online
text: JUST because you left your holiday shopping to the last minute doesn’t mean you have to pay full price. These coupon and bargain-hunting Web sites may save you time and money at the mall. They may even save you from setting foot in the mall in the first place.

headline: Last Call | Katherine Hooker’s Pretty Pop-Up
text: Sleek, minimalist, elegant yet cozy and inviting at the same time. Tucked into a little storefront on Thompson Street in the chic art/tea/fashion triangle of New York City’s SoHo, the bespoke British designer Katherine Hooker’s clothing shop blends into the landscape as if it’s been there forever and is here to stay. But neither of those things are true. In some takeoff of Chef Ludo-meets-fashion, Hooker’s first ready-to-wear line and first storefront is a pop-up and will be open in New York only through Saturday.

headline: Diploma Rates Far Short of Goal, Report Says
text: Forty percent of people ages 25 to 34 in the United States have college degrees, putting the nation in 12th place among developed countries. President Obama has set an ambitious goal of catapulting the country to first place by 2025, and the College Board, separately, has quantified a complementary goal: to increase the percentage of young adults with degrees from 40 percent to 55 percent by 2025.

headline: Panetta Says U.S. Has Edge on Taliban
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta said Wednesday that the United States and its Afghan and foreign allies had been able to “seize the momentum” in Afghanistan and that they were winning the war.

headline: China Imposes New Tariffs on U.S. Vehicles
text: GUANGZHOU, China — The Chinese government increased trade tensions with the Obama administration Wednesday evening by unexpectedly imposing antidumping and antisubsidy tariffs on imports of sport utility vehicles and midsize and large cars from the United States.

headline: Speaking of People Whose Models Have Failed
text: The latest polls show Newt slipping in Iowa — but not to the benefit of Mitt Romney. Instead, it now seems possible that Ron Paul will win the caucuses.

headline: Players Involved in Cincinnati-Xavier Fight Won’t Face Charges
text: The players who brawled in the final seconds of the Xavier-Cincinnati men’s basketball game on Dec. 10 will not face criminal charges.

headline: Dear FloFab: I’m Not Drinking. Why Am I Paying?
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Mick Rock, The Rock ‘N’ Roll Photographer
text: “Rocked” an exhibit of photographs by Mick Rock can be seen at W New York Downtown until late December 2011.

headline: A Penthouse Gets a Second Life in Singapore
text: Eugene Yip and Mike Tay, both designers, renovated with an eye to preserving and enhancing an apartment’s midcentury roots.

headline: In Singapore, Peeling Back the Years
text: SINGAPORE — The rundown penthouse apartment that Mike Tay and Eugene Yip fell in love with in 2009 was in such a sorry state that more than 80 potential buyers had walked away from it. But Mr. Tay and Mr. Yip saw beyond its dark, claustrophobic atmosphere, the uneven floors and the frosted windows that obscured the view of the city’s skyline. And the Singaporean couple ignored the old mattresses and assorted other junk that populated the roof terrace.

headline: Charles Isherwood’s Top 10 of 2011
text: Photos of “Sons of the Prophet,” “Kin” and other shows.

headline: Poland Skirts Euro Zone Woes, for Now
text: WARSAW — Does Poland have the last healthy economy in Europe?

headline: Seclusion, With a Byzantine Flavor
text: Surrounded by palms, with a Sea of Marmara view, an elaborate wooden house displays an Eastern exoticism.

headline: House Hunting in ... Turkey
text: A SEVEN-BEDROOM WOODEN HOUSE ON AN ISLAND OFF ISTANBUL

headline: Baryshnikov Arts Center Announces New Season
text: The Baryshnikov Arts Center’s spring 2012 performance season, running Jan. 12 to June 17, will include several premieres by international artists from the worlds of theater, dance, music and film. The season includes the company’s first co-presentation with Performance Space 122, as well as the New York premiere of a project organized by the theater artist Robert Wilson.

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 15
text: Necklaces, leather restraint-like fashions and shiny party pants.

headline: Looted Dishes Used in Art Project Returned to Iraq
text: Over the last several years, as cultural patrimony cases have roiled the art world, federal marshals have made surprise visits to numerous American museums and galleries to cart away artifacts that foreign governments claimed were looted.

headline: Suspicious Packages Prompt Evacuation of Credit Suisse
text: Credit Suisse staff members were briefly evacuated from their Manhattan offices on Wednesday morning after the Swiss bank received two suspicious packages in the mail, days after Deutsche Bank intercepted a letter bomb addressed to its chief executive in Frankfurt.

headline: In Latest Gun Inquiry, City Finds Willing Sellers Online
text: Updated 8:03 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has dispatched private investigators to gun stores and gun shows as far away as Arizona to illustrate how some dealers are willing to sell firearms to people they believe are disqualified from owning them.

headline: Times of London Cancels Comedy Podcast That Mocked Murdoch
text: 8:06 a.m. | Updated

headline: What Lies Ahead? Predicting the Future of Computing
text: Overview | What might the future of computing and technology look like? What innovations are on the horizon? In this lesson, students consider predictions about the future of fields including artificial intelligence, communication and computing. They analyze current predictions, consider them in the context of modern-day life and propose predictions of their own.

headline: One Year's Flat Test Results Do Not Negate System's Progress
text: In an opinion post, an advocate for school reform says critics who seize on  new national data assessing New York City school performance as proof of failed mayoral policies are not looking at how much has improved since 2002.

headline: A Sigh of Relief at a School That Was Spared
text: A Bronx elementary school that received an F on its school progress report was among the 47 schools at risk of being closed or phased out next year. But P.S. 277 learned that it has been spared, based on the Department of Education's conclusion that its staff has the ability to make necessary improvements.

headline: Is James Murdoch Running Out of Denials?
text: In almost every Road Runner cartoon, Wile E. Coyote overshoots the edge of a cliff and finds his feet spinning in the air, frantically pawing for the terra firma that he has left behind. Those of us watching know he is about to fall, and even as he continues to flail in midair, deep inside he knows it as well.

headline: Astros Trade Melancon, a Former Yankee, to Red Sox
text: When the Yankees traded relief pitcher Mark Melancon to the Houston Astros for Lance Berkman just hours before the trade deadline in 2010, they probably did not envision Melancon winding up in the Boston Red Sox’ bullpen.

headline: Junkyard Gives Up Secret Accounts of Massacre in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — One by one, the Marines sat down, swore to tell the truth and began to give secret interviews discussing one of the most horrific episodes of America’s time in Iraq: the 2005 massacre by Marines of Iraqi civilians in the town of Haditha.

headline: A Train, Canal Street, 11:22 A.M.
text: N.Y. See: A subway rider brings his own seating, a cello and music for fellow passengers.

headline: For Amazon, Lashes and Backlashes
text: If Amazon had a secret agenda in 2011 to fuel a backlash against itself, the retailer has scored another triumph. Its refusal to collect sales tax in California despite a new law compelling it to do so prompted some well-publicized criticism not only from politicians but the tech community. Its hiring of ambulances at its Pennsylvania warehouse to wait for workers to keel over in the summer heat conjured up a Dickensian sweatshop. The retailer apparently brought its Kindle Fire tablet to market before it had all the kinks out, disappointing some of its biggest fans.

headline: In Hunt for Securities Fraud, a Timid S.E.C. Misses the Big Game
text: Does the Securities and Exchange Commission suffer from trialphobia?

headline: Lines Drawn on Antipiracy Bills
text: WASHINGTON — Type “download movies for free” into Google, and up pops links to sites like the Pirate Bay, directing users to free copies of just about any entertainment   — the latest “Twilight” installment, this week’s episode of “Whitney,” the complete recordings of the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

headline: Romney Would Like to See ‘Book of Mormon’
text: So what does Mitt Romney, perhaps the best-known Mormon in the country, think of “The Book of Mormon,” the Broadway musical send-up of his faith, complete with profanity and sexually explicit humor?

headline: The Exaggerated Impact of Bank Transfer Day
text: The numbers sounded a bit too good to be true — and it turned out that they were. The Credit Union National Association now says that about 214,000 people joined credit unions in the month or so of anti-bank fervor this fall, not the 650,000 it originally estimated. As Gov. Rick Perry of Texas might say: “Oops.”

headline: TimesCast | Putin Ally Resigns
text: December 14, 2011 - The chairman of Russia's ruling party, a close Putin ally, resigns amid accusations of election fraud.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.14
text: A view of the day in sports, including acrobatics at the Club World Cup soccer tournament and shovels at the ski jump.

headline: In Syria and Egypt, Bloggers Face Harsh Punishments
text: Updated | Thursday | 12:46 a.m. An outspoken blogger who was detained last week in Syria is now facing criminal charges, according to the human rights group she works for in Damascus, the Syrian capital.

headline: 8 Questions for the MF Global Hearing
text: Terrence A. Duffy, executive chairman of the CME Group, returns to Capitol Hill on Thursday, testifying before the House Financial Services Committee. There are certain to be fireworks.

headline: Portraits of Iraqi Pride
text: The photographer Andrea Bruce wondered if Iraqis felt optimism as the American troops left. The answer — for those who were staying — was complicated.

headline: Older to Wed, If They Marry at All
text: The median age of first marriage is at an all-time high, according to a new report from the Pew Research Center based on United States Census Bureau data.

headline: More Detail on Top Incomes
text: The Times recently published an article noting a significant decline in the incomes of the top 1 percent.

headline: Prioritizing Pakistan
text: The Op-Ed columnist Bill Keller explains the United States’s need to repair its troubled relationship with Pakistan.

headline: New Jersey Company Is Given Jail Contract It Lost
text: Over the summer, Essex County, N.J., abruptly canceled plans for a contract with a private company to house federal immigrant detainees after questions were raised about the sole bidder, a company with close ties to Gov. Chris Christie. But after county officials conducted a new round of bidding in October, the same company was again the only participant, and on Wednesday night, county officials unanimously approved the contract.

headline: Secret Military Documents, Straight From an Iraqi Junkyard
text: BAGHDAD — Several weeks ago, we heard that a local businessman had purchased some trailers from a closing American base.

headline: Searching for Apps Is Finally Getting Easier
text: At the start of this year, app-related search engines and stores were too big a mess for the mobile software industry to leave as is.

headline: Former Ukrainian President’s Murder Charge Is Dismissed
text: MOSCOW — Criminal proceedings were dismissed Wednesday against the former Ukrainian president Leonid Kuchma in the killing 11 years ago of a prominent investigative journalist critical of his administration.

headline: After Russian Vote, U.S. Pledges to Raise Concerns ‘Forcefully’
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration plans to continue speaking out “forcefully” about human rights violations in Russia, even after Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin responded angrily to criticism of his country’s elections by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, a top State Department official said Wednesday.

headline: Michael Bublé Stays on Top
text: This week on the music charts, Michael Bublé’s holiday album holds strong at No. 1, beating out new releases by the Black Keys and Amy Winehouse, and the party-rockers of LMFAO reclaim the top slot for the most downloaded track.

headline: Kayak Defends Cutting Ties to ‘All-American Muslim’
text: Kayak, a company that has run commercials on “All-American Muslim” — the reality series on the TLC cable channel that has become a source of controversy in the debate over Muslims in the United States — defended its decision to stop advertising on the show in the future, even as it admitted, “we handled this poorly.”

headline: Newly Released Books
text: Four prolific writers — Paul Theroux, Jeffrey Zaslow, Randall Silvis and Roberto Bolaño — are joined by two first-timers: a comic novelist and the nonfiction chronicler of a New York religious community.

headline: Fox Rebound Not Enough to Fully Eclipse CBS on Tuesday
text: Fox was barely able to retain its Tuesday night foothold with the 18-to-49-year-old demographic, tying CBS in that ratings category most prized by advertisers. “Glee” and “New Girl” both halted recent ratings slides and remained steady for Fox when compared to last week in the 18-to-49 demo and drew 7 million and 6.8 million total viewers respectively.   Those Fox shows faced off against new episodes of “NCIS” and “NCIS: Los Angeles” on CBS for the first time in three weeks.

headline: Torres Brings Upbeat Personality to Depleted Mets
text: Andres Torres knows the Mets were betting he would have a bounce-back year when they acquired him from San Francisco along with Ramon Ramirez this month in exchange for Angel Pagan.

headline: Judge Allows MF Global to Continue Using Cash on Hand
text: A federal judge on Wednesday approved a request by MF Global to continue using about $21.3 million of its cash on hand, allowing the bankrupt brokerage firm to continue operating under Chapter 11.

headline: TimesCast | December 14, 2011
text: A preview of an interview with Mitt Romney; the chairman of Russia's ruling party resigns; and Bill Keller on why the United States must repair relations with Pakistan.

headline: The Caucus Hairstylist
text: Cathy Jorgensen, who runs a salon in Des Moines, talks about getting regular visits from prominent politicians in town to compete in the Iowa caucus.

headline: TimesCast | December 13, 2011
text: Jerry Sandusky waives his right to face his accusers in a preliminary hearing; and a rare glimpse at life inside Myanmar's capital.

headline: Browns Say Medical Staff Missed Hit on McCoy
text: Mike Holmgren, the president of the Cleveland Browns, said Wednesday that quarterback Colt McCoy was not tested for a concussion after taking a hit to the head during a game last week, in part because the medical staff was tending to other players and did not see the play.

headline: TimesCast | December 12, 2011
text: Mikhail Prokhorov, a Russian billionaire, plans to run against Vladamir Putin for president; and Occupy Wall Street protesters picket Goldman Sachs.

headline: New Services at Univision and Hulu Focus on Latino Viewers
text: Viewers who don’t get up early enough to watch the latest installment of the morning show Despierta América on Univision will now be able to watch clips from the show on their mobile phones.

headline: Tip of the Week: Sneaking a Peek at Your Desktop
text: For Windows 7 users, passing the cursor over the Show Desktop button (that thin vertical sliver on the far right side of the Taskbar) is a handy way to glance at the computer’s desktop, even with a screen full of open windows. But for those who accidentally brush the mouse over the button and get distracted by the disappearing documents on the screen, there is a way to disable the Show Desktop button — just right-click on the Show Desktop button and remove the checkmark next to “Peek at desktop.” Later, if you want to restore your peeking powers, right-click the Show Desktop button again and re-select the option.

headline: The Giving Spree | Alison Mosshart
text: Who: Alison Mosshart,  lead singer of the Kills.

headline: Organizing Communities to Improve Schools
text: A WNYC program looks at local community groups and their organizing efforts to help schools in struggling neighborhoods. A professor says the most successful models he studied were those that developed deep roots in the community and helped parents push for change in a collaborative way to improve education for their children.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Fear and Desire’
text: “Dr. Strangelove” it’s not.

headline: A Hairstylist Grooms Hopefuls, With a Trim
text: DES MOINES

headline: Prewar Sports Cars Valued at $12.4 Million to Be Auctioned at Goodwood
text: Collectors who favor prewar sports and competition cars would rarely be mistaken for poseurs. Cars of that type are rare, visceral, demanding to own and drive, and prohibitively expensive to buy. Add to these the challenge of weeding out the cars that may not be what they seem, and it’s easy to see a giant “keep out” sign for casual collectors.

headline: British Cities Suggest Themed Trips
text: With the multitudes flocking to London next year for the Olympic Games, some of Britain’s other offerings may get overlooked. The British Heritage Cities Web site provides a reminder in the form of eight new themed itineraries to Bath, Carlisle, Chester, Oxford, Stratford and York.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Congo, Belgium and India.

headline: Mayor Criticizes Judge for Releasing Murder Suspect
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Wednesday criticized the Brooklyn Criminal Court judge who allowed the man accused this week of killing a police officer to be released from custody without bail in an earlier drug case.

headline: Carine Roitfeld’s Daughter Builds Her Own Empire
text: Unveiled at a party Tuesday night at the Kiki de Montparnasse shop, the collection of lace-embellished, lace-panel, vintage-style slips, kimonos, satin corselets and fancy underpinnings.

headline: Building an Empire of Her Own
text: THE din at Le Grainne Cafe, a popular bistro in Chelsea, subsided just long enough to make out the words of a matron at a corner table. “I love your boots,” she told the young woman seated nearby, her glance traveling covetously from her neighbor’s instep to the tops of her thighs.

headline: Getty Museum’s Acting Director is Leaving
text: David Bomford, who has been acting director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles since 2010, will be returning to his home in London where he plans to pursue research, scholarship and writing, the institution announced on Tuesday. Mr. Bomford joined the Getty in 2007 as associate director for collections and was named its acting director after Michael Brand resigned in 2010, citing differences with James N. Wood, who was then the president and chief executive of the Getty Trust, the umbrella organization that oversees the museum. Mr. Wood died later that year and was replaced by James Cuno, the former director of the Art Institute of Chicago.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Congo, Belgium and India.

headline: For Fashion Start-Ups, a Bridge to Investors
text: IN a setting reminiscent of a speed-dating bar scene, but with no promise of even a first date, much less a long-term relationship, more than 20 fledgling fashion companies pitched their talent, their drive and their ideas to an audience of potential investors at the Fashion Institute of Technology last week.

headline: What You Get for ... $480,000
text: ST. PAUL, MINN.

headline: Among Unknowns Who Tested Positive, Braun Stands Out
text: The few dozen names on the list don’t ring a lot of bells. Humberto Cota? Kelvin Pichardo? Mark Rogers?

headline: Four Pranksters, Giving as Good as They Get
text: It seems as if the punked-and-pranked genre of television ought to be dead by now, but four New York guys prove that it isn’t in “(Impractical) Jokers,” a gleefully idiotic show that has its premiere Thursday night on TruTV.

headline: Online Sharing: The How, What and When of 2011
text: It’s Wednesday. That means it is the most popular day for users to share on the Web.

headline: Homes for $480,000
text: A two-bedroom house in St. Paul, a two-bedroom condo in Philadelphia and a three-bedroom house in downtown Dallas.

headline: You Change It, You Buy It
text: Major League Baseball’s new collective bargaining agreement, which is expected to be ratified on Thursday, covers many familiar topics: revenue sharing, drug testing, video replays and so on.

headline: A Classic Refocused for the Big Screen
text: Onstage in “The Nutcracker” Fritz, the brother of the child heroine, is never alone. You see him in the company of his sister, his parents, his friends and the mysterious visiting magician Drosselmeier. On Tuesday, however, in the live high-definition cinema broadcast of George Balanchine’s production for New York City Ballet, there were moments when he — vividly performed by 9-year-old Maximilian Brooking Landegger — filled the vast screen all by himself. Naughty, impulsive, vulnerable, he became more funnily irresistible than ever.

headline: Putting Political Reform Right Into the Pockets of the Nation’s Voters
text: In “Republic, Lost” Lawrence Lessig — a Harvard Law School professor and a leading advocate of applying the principles of open Web access to less technical forms of creative expression, like music, writing, and the visual arts — makes an extraordinary leap of faith.

headline: The Philharmonic’s ‘Messiah,’ With Bright Voices and Little Vibrato
text: The great German tenor Peter Schreier and the New York Philharmonic do not share an extensive history, but what they have done together over the years has been noteworthy. Having made his debut as a soloist with the orchestra in 1973 in Dvorak’s Stabat Mater, Mr. Schreier returned just three times in that capacity: in Britten’s “Serenade” and Bach’s “St. John Passion” and “St. Matthew Passion.” In 1998 the Philharmonic presented Mr. Schreier in recital with the pianist Andras Schiff, who was appearing with the orchestra at the time.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. We have cheap temporary blinds. Is it worth investing in better window coverings before selling?

headline: Carrier IQ Denies It Is Under Investigation
text: 3:10 p.m. | Updated Adding formal comment from Carrier IO.Carrier IQ, which makes software that monitors mobile phone users, says it is not being investigated by the Federal Trade Commission, despite a report in The Washington Post that said the federal investigators were looking into the company.

headline: The Caucus | Interview With Mitt Romney
text: The former Massachusetts governor sits down with The New York Times to discuss Newt Gingrich’s challenges and the status of his own campaign.

headline: Smoothed Inflation
text: One thing that becomes obvious when you look at inflation data is that the numbers bounce around a lot, not just from month to month but from year to year. One way to try to get past the noise is to use one or another definition of core inflation, which I think is necessary if you want to catch underlying inflation trends early. But to get a historical picture, it’s good enough just to use longish averages.

headline: Scene City: Meryl Streep as the ‘Iron Lady’
text: Anne Hathaway, Ellen Barkin, Alan Cumming and other loyal subjects pay tribute to the Queen of Hollywood.

headline: Curtsying Before a Queen
text: MARGARET THATCHER led Britain as its prime minister once upon a time, but it’s Meryl Streep who lords over Hollywood. And in a show of her unimpeachable reign, Ms. Streep attracted an impressive stream of loyal subjects for the Tuesday premiere of “The Iron Lady,” her latest Oscar vehicle, in which she stars as Ms. Thatcher.

headline: How to Make Dining Stools From Egg Cartons
text: Jen Turner, an architect and designer, and Andrew Wagner, the director of Krrb.com, bundle industrial-size egg cartons from Chinatown restaurants to create six stools.

headline: ‘Homeland’ Inches Tensely to Its Finale
text: Showtime’s “Homeland,” which many critics have praised as the most riveting new drama of the television season, will reach its finale on Sunday night in an episode that the president for entertainment for the network, David Nevins, said “will have the fans of the show howling.”

headline: Methane Time Bomb in Arctic Seas – Apocalypse Not
text: Dec. 19, 1:44 p.m. | Updated below |A very important research effort has been under way during recent summers in the warming, increasingly ice-free shallows off Russia’s Siberian coast. There, an international array of scientists has been investigating widening areas of open water that are disgorging millions of tons of methane each year.

headline: An Audience Gets Pawed, but It’s All for Art’s Sake
text: In certain circles “The Shining,” not the Stanley Kubrick film but the performance work by Yvonne Meier, is a thing of downtown dance lore. As Ishmael Houston-Jones, adviser to a new production, pointed out in a pre-performance discussion, many have heard about it but far fewer have actually seen it. And since only 11 audience members are admitted to each show, it’s probably going to stay that way.

headline: Great Escape | Miami Heat
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: When Child Care Subsidies Disappear, Care is Hard to Find
text: How can you be a working parent without child care? Day care, preschool, after-school programs: without them, or some alternative, a parent of younger school-age children can work only from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., and a parent of even younger children can’t work at all.

headline: Emptying a Castle to Head to the Condo
text: It makes perfect sense that Candy Spelling, the widow of the hugely successful producer Aaron Spelling and former resident of a notoriously huge Los Angeles house, would see her life in terms of old Hollywood glamour.

headline: Michael Kors Stock, Like His Frocks, Is Selling Fast
text: 8:29 p.m. | Updated

headline: Windsor Custom at the Ainsworth
text: The kind of place designed for men who pay attention to the kind of details other men will notice, preferably with envy.

headline: Custom Shirts, With a Shot on the Side
text: “DO you think gingham is waning in popularity?” Brian Anderson, a principal at a private equity firm, asked as he shuffled a stack of fabric swatches in the sitting room of Windsor Custom, a clothing shop decorated in navy blue and beige to resemble the rec room of a Hamptons cottage. He considered them, quite intensely. A two-ply cotton herringbone. A sateen cotton dobby. A basket-weave oxford. Each was a slightly variant shade of pink.

headline: French Mitt Romney, Part Deux
text: Earlier today, I asked readers to help me think about a new negative political ad, in which Mitt Romney babbles about the 2002 Olympics in French while liberal statements he’s made over the years flash across the screen. I found the ad — payback for the 2004 mockery of John Kerry’s foreign language skills — funny. But I also criticized it for implicitly furthering the idea that a bit of culture, actually a  bit of French culture, is a liability.

headline: United States Women Win 2 Events in Beijing
text: At the first SportAccord World Mind Games Championship in Beijing — which include chess, go, checkers and Chinese chess as well as bridge — four countries were invited to compete in each bridge division, women’s and open. The tournament comprises team, pair and individual competitions.

headline: Gingrich, Lecturing on Brain Science, Faces Protesters
text: IOWA CITY – Newt Gingrich, in full professorial mode, stood at a lectern in front of a whiteboard decorated with his campaign signs on Wednesday and told an auditorium of college students that brain science research was not only “fascinating,” but “a way to fix the budget” over the next decades.

headline: Yankees Said to Bid for Darvish
text: Major League Baseball announced that at least one team, which it did not name, submitted a posting bid for the Japanese star pitcher Yu Darvish by the deadline late Wednesday afternoon. It is believed that at least a few teams, most notably the Texas Rangers and the Toronto Blue Jays, submitted bids to win the right to negotiate a contract with Darvish, the 25-year-old ace of the Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters.

headline: Camp Life in the Dry Valleys
text: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier fed streams.

headline: On Queens Block, Losing a Link to Louis Armstrong
text: Selma Heraldo lived the entirety of her 88 years in a white, two-story house on 107th Street in Corona, Queens, and her life may have been very different had she not gained new next-door neighbors in 1943 — Louis Armstrong and his wife, Lucille.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Amazon, Algorithms and Angry Birds
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors at The New York Times have been reading on the Web. For more Scuttlebot, go to the right-hand column of this page.

headline: 1892, Now It’s Online
text: THE ultimate pleasure of taking an online dip into the entirety of the Vogue archives — every issue since 1892 has been digitally scanned, page by page, and made available through a pricey new subscription site — is the sensation that it gives of falling into a fashion time machine and being shot out into different eras at random.

headline: Lam Research to Buy Novellus Systems for $3.3 Billion
text: 8:47 p.m. | Updated

headline: Sales at DwellStudio and Others
text: FTF Design Studio is reducing prices on all trays and accessories by 20 percent, through Wednesday (a small flat tray, regularly $335, is $268; the Umami tray, regularly $145, is $116); 137 Fifth Avenue (20th Street), (212) 925-0847, ftfdesignstudio.com.

headline: An App With Friends in High Places
text: THERE’S a new addiction in Hollywood, apparently, but this one comes without the court-ordered 30-day rehab. Words With Friends, the Scrabble-like app, is not just popular, it seems, but cool among tastemakers in the entertainment industry and beyond.

headline: Lawmakers Offer Bipartisan Plan to Overhaul Medicare
text: WASHINGTON — A Democratic senator, Ron Wyden of Oregon, and a Republican member of the House, Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin, unveiled a bipartisan plan on Wednesday to revamp Medicare and make a fixed federal contribution to the cost of coverage for each beneficiary.

headline: All I Want From Santa (See List)
text: WHEN it comes to holiday gifting, everyone says it’s the thought that counts. But when Jeminah Buot and her family kept getting the same gifts over and over again — like four stainless steel water bottles one year — they decided maybe “the thought” wasn’t enough.

headline: Looted Dishes Return to Iraq
text: Federal marshals took custody of a collection of Saddam Hussein's dinner plates used in an art project by Creative Time in order to return the dishes to Iraq.

headline: Letters
text: Underarms Accord

headline: Turning Egg Cartons Into Stools
text: MY history of trash collecting goes way back. Long before I was the director of Krrb (a kinder, friendlier, hyper-local version of Craigslist) or the editor of ReadyMade (the magazine, now defunct, that billed itself as the bible of reuse for Generations X, Y and Z), I was a skateboarding teenager in California trolling the Central Valley suburbs for building materials for ramps. Even now, living in Manhattan, I keep my eyes open for anything tossed to the curb that might be turned into something beautiful or useful.

headline: A Procession to the Post Office, Carrying Envelopes Full of Hope
text: Following a custom that is emerging at high schools across the city, more than 70 seniors at Washington Heights Expeditionary Learning High School walked together from the school to the post office to mail their college application envelopes, stuffed with test scores, recommendation letters and essays.

headline: What Is College For?
text: The Stone is featuring occasional posts by Gary Gutting, a professor of philosophy at the University of Notre Dame, that apply critical thinking to information and events that have appeared in the news.

headline: Egypt’s Rural Voters Get Their Turn in Elections
text: GIZA, Egypt — Egyptians turned out to vote again Wednesday with a new confidence in a promised transition to civilian democracy amid signals that the ruling military council may be backing off its efforts to extend its power.

headline: Beauty by the Bite
text: SUE DEVITT, an Australian makeup artist whose clients have included Sarah Jessica Parker, Jennifer Lopez and Keira Knightley, is known for her sumptuous eye shadows and seaweed-infused foundations. But in February, Ms. Devitt and Tanya Zuckerbrot, the official dietitian to the Miss Universe Organization, are scheduled to appear on QVC to introduce a new beauty product that you don’t massage, smooth or brush onto your face. You eat it.

headline: Beyond the Passé in Tech Gifts
text: No 7-year-old ever said, “The holidays are so stressful!” When you’re young, the end of the year is always thrilling.

headline: Shaun White on Design and Skater Culture
text: Shaun White, the professional snowboarder and skateboarder, and his brother, Jesse, have designed boards and performance clothing and gear for Burton, and what they call “off-mountain” clothing for Target, for more than three years. Later this month, Target will introduce his latest creative endeavor: the Shaun White home collection, a line of bedding, lighting and home accessories inspired by skating, snowboarding, travel, music and art.

headline: Keeping Lamp Design Simple
text: By day, Dino Sanchez is an associate creative director at Frog Design, but the 34-year-old Brooklynite has always had an entrepreneurial side. He started a typeface company called Orange Italic shortly after graduating from Carnegie Mellon University and, more recently, began producing a few of his own lighting designs.

headline: A Williamsburg Penthouse Marked With Memories
text: HOLLISTER AND PORTER HOVEY are sisters and bloggers known for their sense of style: their loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, layered with memento mori and vintage-store portraits, has attracted scores of admirers online. Still, they had never decorated anyone else’s home.

headline: A Top Goldman Executive to Retire
text: Milton R. Berlinski, who runs the group at Goldman Sachs that caters to private equity firms, is retiring at the end of the year, according to an internal memo.

headline: Bringing Warmth to a Glass-and-Steel Condo
text: Hollister and Porter Hovey, sisters known for their new-vintage style, were hired to decorate an apartment at the Edge, in Williamsburg.

headline: Oscar Hopefuls’ Campaign Strategies
text: The trophy race that culminates in the Oscars is moving into high gear this week, with a slew of critics’ groups and precursor awards, like the Screen Actors Guild and the Golden Globes, announcing their nominees. Soon enough it will be clear — or clearer — who will have to start picking out gowns and pretending not to have practiced their acceptance speeches.

headline: A High-Level Collaboration on a SoHo Loft
text: HOLDING open the door to her fourth-floor loft in SoHo, the choreographer and dancer Elizabeth Streb tried not to laugh at the sounds of exertion as a visitor struggled up the last steep flight of stairs.

headline: A Play That Unfolds in a Real Town House
text: For the last week and a half, Alice, the monstrous hostess played by Zoe Caldwell in the play “Elective Affinities,” has been welcoming theatergoers into the living room of her luxurious Fifth Avenue town house. Though the location is a secret (ticket buyers receive an e-mail with the place’s address), it’s a real living room, in a real brick-and-limestone town house built in the late 19th century. Embedding the audience in a living room was crucial to the play, said the producers, but finding one was a challenge.

headline: The Last-Minute Gift That’s Sure to Please
text: It may be better to give than to receive — but there’s nothing worse than ripping off colorful wrapping paper to reveal some gym socks, the oh-so-obviously regifted scented candles or a CD box set of any kind.

headline: The Holiday Gaffes That Keep Giving
text: DESIGNERS get especially excited about decorating during the holiday season, and last year, Nicole Fuller decided that what she wanted, in the Manhattan apartment she shares with her husband, Clarence, and three Maine coon cats, was a Christmas tree covered entirely in white feathers — a swan tree, she called it.

headline: Shopping for Children’s Beds
text: The industrial designer Jason Miller, who has a 17-month-old daughter, searched for children’s beds.

headline: Children’s Beds
text: JASON MILLER, the industrial designer who is chief executive and creative director of the lighting company Roll & Hill, believes that when designers become parents, one of two things happens.

headline: Wood Bowls With a Midas Touch
text: After learning a technique known as water gilding from a master gilder in Hamburg, Germany, Michou Osterwald applied it to some surprising objects: hand-carved African wood bowls.

headline: A Very Modern Teddy Bear
text: “Mr. Tedi is getting a big head,” Annika Jermyn said, on hearing of the attention being paid to her creation, a very modern-looking teddy bear with, yes, a large head.

headline: With Latest Network Agreements, the N.F.L. Outdoes Even Itself
text: With its consistently high ratings and its solid grip on the American sports psyche, the N.F.L. knows that broadcast and cable networks will spend ever-rising sums to carry its games.

headline: Preservationist’s Home Movies: A Lifetime of Images as a Sweeping Visual Diary
text: For more than a half-century, the filmmaker, artist, poet, critic, programmer and ecstatic theologian of cinema Jonas Mekas has been viewing the world through a camera, often in the form of visual diaries. A restless image maker, he seizes moments of beauty and life as it happens in work that bridges outer and inner, the self and the other. The leap across this great divide is crucial: in contrast to the iEverything, me-centric ethos, his movies (initially shot in film, more recently digital) have been at once a way into the world and into his own self. “I make home movies, therefore I live,” he says in his 1969 film “Walden.” “I live, therefore I make home movies.”

headline: Uptown Can Be a Downer
text: Everything about my neighborhood was sketchy. But at least it wasn’t boring.

headline: Euro Zone Deal Runs Into Second Thoughts
text: PARIS — The deal reached at the emergency European summit meeting in Brussels last Friday was supposed to cement a consensus for better fiscal discipline and reassure the financial markets about the European Union’s resolve. By Wednesday, it was clearly not convincing investors.

headline: NBA League Pass Fans Think They’re Paying More for Less
text: Thanks to the N.B.A. lockout, the regular season is 20 percent shorter this season. As part of the new collective bargaining agreement, the players are taking a 12 percent pay cut. And fans who buy NBA League Pass, which lets them watch nearly every game on television, the Internet and their mobile phones, will pay at least 7 percent less.

headline: Live Nation Buys BigChampagne, Analyzer of Consumer Data
text: In a bid to expand its ability to analyze large amounts of consumer data, Live Nation Entertainment, the music giant that includes Ticketmaster, is buying BigChampagne, a small but influential company that monitors online media consumption.

headline: Japan May Declare Control of Reactors, Over Serious Doubts
text: TOKYO — Nine months after the devastating earthquake and tsunami knocked out cooling systems at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant, causing a meltdown at three units, the Tokyo government is expected to declare soon that it has finally regained control of the plant’s overheating reactors.

headline: Not Blessed With Fast Feet, Manning Escapes Heat With Quick Wits
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — By any measure, Eli Manning is not a mobile quarterback. He is slow. He is awkward. He is, as his father, Archie, said, “not a runner.”
