text: ALTHOUGH it was evident that the final year of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company would be historic, there was no knowing which of his dances in 2011 would prove most rewarding in performance. Who would have known that “Quartet” (1982) would reveal itself to be an enduring masterpiece at the company’s Joyce Theater season in March? Robert Swinston, the company’s director of choreography, now dancing the role once inextricably linked to Cunningham himself onstage, kept the drama’s ambiguities alive on many levels.

headline: Metropolitan Museum Provides a Trove of Images for Google Goggles
text: Over the past year visual-art obsessives have been having a field day with the feature of the Google smart-phone app called Google Goggles, which allows a user to shoot a picture of something – a painting, a photograph, a poster – and in seconds see an identification of the image and a list of search results for more information about it.

headline: 2011 in Rhyme and Headlines: The ‘Year in Rap’ and Our Annual News Quiz
text: The Year in Rap: 2011 from Flocabulary

headline: Off the Charts: Few Are Fired, or Hired
text: The number of private sector workers who were laid off or discharged over the last 12 months is the lowest for any similar period since the government began collecting the statistics in 1990. The rate of hiring also remains low, but has improved since the recession ended in 2009. The number of workers quitting their jobs — a sign of confidence that they can do better elsewhere — has also risen. The number of job openings relative to the number of unemployed workers is down from the peak, but remains far above prerecession levels.

headline: A New Generation Comes Into Focus
text: ONE evening at a performance by American Ballet Theater at City Center this fall, the dancers took their places. But as the curtain rose on Twyla Tharp’s “In the Upper Room,” the fog — part of what gives this galvanic work its heavenly setting — was thick enough to create white-out conditions. Still, within the haze was a body that danced like a ribbon.

headline: Moments to Cherish, Filled With Discovery And Somber Farewell
text: IT’S been almost a year since I saw Sarah Michelson’s “Devotion” at the Kitchen in January. But her searing dance, a collaboration with the New York City Players’ artistic director Richard Maxwell, shines more brightly in my mind than most of the work I’ve seen since.

headline: The Driver Market and a Roundup of Other Racing News
text: The so-called “silly season” in Formula One, where the teams name their drivers for the following season, used to happen in the summer. This year it was delayed until after the season ended, and a couple of seats have just been claimed.

headline: The Driver Market and a Roundup of Other Racing News
text: The so-called “silly season” in Formula One, where the teams name their drivers for the following season, used to happen in the summer. This year it was delayed until after the season ended, and a couple of seats have just been claimed.

headline: Disregard That ‘Past Due Invoice’ From the College Board
text: At a time when the College Board is already under scrutiny, as in the SAT testing fraud investigation on Long Island, the organization that oversees the high-stakes college entrance exam has inadvertently raised students’ anxiety on another front.

headline: The Clipper Makes Her Rounds
text: “You’d be amazed at what people walk around with,” said Serena Merrill.

headline: Group Clears Path for a Third-Party Ticket
text: To those who bemoan the lack of better choices in presidential elections, third-party fantasies come easily at this stage in a campaign. End hyper-partisanship and Washington dysfunction: Vote Bloomberg-Petraeus in 2012!

headline: Beyond Eeny Meeny Miny Moe: Sorting Out the G.O.P. Field
text: I woke up this morning feeling grateful not to be an Iowa Republican. If I were, I’d feel obligated to participate in the caucuses on Jan. 3, a truly depressing prospect. The contenders for the G.O.P. nomination – seven of them now that Herman Cain self-immolated – have given speeches, schmoozed diners at diners, and run TV ads. They’ve also participated in thousands of debates, which— like last night’s season finale— have amply demonstrated that no one on stage with a remote chance of winning is remotely suited to leading this country.

headline: May the Best Dog Actor Win
text: The staff of The Hollywood Reporter continues with its hard-hitting, link-baiting coverage of this year’s animal stars.

headline: ‘Bonnie & Clyde’ Will Close on Dec. 30
text: “Bonnie & Clyde,” the composer Frank Wildhorn’s latest bid for Broadway success after several flops, won’t end his unlucky streak. Producers announced on Friday that the show, starring Jeremy Jordan and Laura Osnes, will close on Dec. 30.

headline: At a Meeting Spot for Occupiers, Signs Prohibit Signs
text: Updated, 1:45 p.m. | Soon after the Occupy Wall Street protesters built an encampment in the financial district in mid-September, organizers looking for a less conspicuous place to gather began holding certain meetings inside a public atrium at 60 Wall Street.

headline: Standouts in a Solo Setting
text: IT seems that a recital should be a breeze for a singer. Unlike in opera, there are no ill-fitting costumes; there is no awkward directorial concept to pull off. It’s just you, a piano and the music.

headline: Administration Proposes Wage Protections for Home Care Workers
text: The Times reports on Friday that the Obama administration has proposed regulations that would provide the nation’s two million home care workers with minimum wage and overtime protections. Those workers have long been exempted from coverage.

headline: Cunning Vixens, A Dark Concert And Much Glass
text: “BEST of” lists are approximate endeavors. I was sorry I couldn’t attend the Mostly Mozart Festival’s “Don Giovanni,” one of many tantalizing events I missed. But the following proved highlights of my year.

headline: U.S. Transfers Its Last Prisoner in Iraq to Iraqi Custody
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration turned over the last remaining prisoner in American custody in Iraq to the Iraqi government on Friday, a move expected to unleash a political backlash inside the United States even as the American military draws closer to completing its exit.

headline: TimesCast | December 16, 2011
text: The Army private accused of aiding WikiLeaks appears in military court; the literary legacy of Christopher Hitchens; and Nate Silver on the Iowa race.

headline: In a Sign of Labor Recovery, More Workers Are Quitting
text: THE number of Americans quitting their jobs has begun to rise, albeit from a very low level. That is a tentative sign that labor market mobility, which plunged during the 2007-9 recession, has started to recover.

headline: Impatient Protesters Convulse Syria as Russia Offers New Resolution
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Frustrated by the Syrian government’s intransigence and the Arab League’s delays in penalizing President Bashar al-Assad, hundreds of thousands of demonstrators in Syria took to the streets on Friday over the violent repression of their nine-month-old uprising.

headline: On Our Radar: Billions Needed for Texas Water Projects
text: A Texas agency reports that the state should spend $53 billion to cope with its water needs over the next half-century, building infrastructure like new reservoirs, dams and wells, but warns that droughts may prevent the state from keeping up with demand. It is also unclear how the state would come up with the money. [The Associated Press]

headline: The life and inventions of Hedy Lamarr and a sequel to “Pride and Prejudice”
text: This week, composer John Adams on Richard Rhodes’s book, “Hedy’s Folly”, about the life and inventions of Hedy Lamarr; Liesl Schillinger discusses “Death Comes to Pemberley”, P.D. James’s sequel to “Pride and Prejudice”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: The Happy Hitchens: Quotations from The Life-Lover, Too
text: That Christopher Hitchens could be ferocious there is no doubt. His friend Martin Amis called him, accurately enough, “one of the most terrifying rhetoricians the world has yet seen.” So it makes sense that many of the encomiums to Hitchens today in newspapers and across the Web reprint many of his most indelible put-downs.

headline: Land of Good Bones and Deep Pockets
text: A NEIGHBORHOOD of mansions and bakeries, museums and florists, Carnegie Hill is at once grand and intimate. As pleasantly walkable as any community in New York, its streets offer up vignettes that at times seem almost choreographed. Men sell Christmas trees from the gently sloping porte-cochère of the Convent of the Sacred Heart on East 91st Street. A high-stepping girls’ track team giggles through agility drills near the Engineers’ Gate to Central Park. Jacketed St. David’s boys and plaid-uniformed Spence girls grapple with planetoid-size burgers at Jackson Hole, as much an institution in these parts as any of the museums housed in Fifth Avenue palaces.

headline: Panetta Nudges Turkey to Rebuild Ties With Israel
text: ANKARA, Turkey — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta on Friday called for Turkey to rebuild ties with Israel in the interest of security, echoing a call he issued this month for the government of Israel to reach out to other nations across the Middle East.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 15’s Toughest Picks
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Opera Flourishing At the Extremes
text: SOME organizations that travel the classical music mainstream have undertaken innovations this year. Take, for example, the demand for fresh programming that made the Spring for Music festival of visiting orchestras at Carnegie Hall such a success. But for me the most memorable performances were by groups that specialize in the repertory’s extremes, early and new music. And thoughtful, often provocative opera productions figured prominently at both ends.

headline: A Unit, Near Last, in the Military Withdrawal From Iraq
text: The Iraq War’s small, subdued closing ceremony certainly gave the impression that there were few Americans left in the country. It was a final coda to a quietly withdrawing column of units leaving Iraq after more than eight years of war. Andrea Bruce, a photographer working for The New York Times, documented one of the last units in the exodus on the long road home:

headline: Parental Quandary: When a Friend’s Child Hits Yours
text: When families with children nearly exactly the same age come together, it can feel golden — as if the gods of friendship were shining on you. You’ll raise your kids together, play together, take trips together and watch them become lifelong companions as you yourselves stay close. For Isabel, though, it isn’t working out that way.

headline: In His Own Words
text: A selection of Op-Ed articles and letters written by Christopher Hitchens.

headline: Cheap, and Likely to Remain So
text: THOUGH millions of Vegas, Pintos and Gremlins were made during their production runs of nearly a decade, most are gone now, long since sent to the shredder.

headline: China Revokes Probation of Missing Human Rights Lawyer
text: BEIJING — China’s official news agency reported on Friday that Gao Zhisheng, a prominent human rights lawyer who has been missing for more than 20 months, will serve the next three years in prison because he repeatedly violated his probation.

headline: On Assignment in Bagan, Myanmar
text: In March, Justin Mott photographed the temples and pagodas in and around Bagan, Myanmar, just as tourists began to visit.

headline: Marcus Bachmann Outlines ‘First Spouse’ Agenda
text: LE MARS, Iowa — Laura Bush, a former librarian, dedicated herself as first lady to improving reading. Michelle Obama wants to help children become healthier.

headline: Dec. 18 — 24
text: Television

headline: A Boggle of BlackBerrys
text: OTTAWA — Research in Motion’s chief executives, Mike Lazaridis and Jim Balsillie, frightened its investors Thursday when they said the company would not have new BlackBerry phones until late in 2012. Until then, they said, RIM would heavily promote the existing lineup.

headline: Just One Look | Proenza Schouler
text: High-fashion tech-sportswear, similar to what’s been so popular this prefall season, is what Proenza Schouler’s Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez do best. Their version features taffeta workout separates like this top, shown under a silk nylon blended bungee skirt and tweed coat. Sleeping-bag-like quilted skirts and dresses, ’70s mountain boy tees and an aerial terrain view print were all inspired by the designers’ recent trip to the Himalayas. The faithful need not fret: PS 1 bags (in every shade of soil and sand) were aplenty, because let’s be real, life can’t be all hikes and bikes.

headline: Angelina Jolie Gets Some Good News at the Dentist’s Office
text: The Golden Globe nominations on Thursday drew varied reactions from nominees and non-nominees alike. Then there was the power couple Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie, who both snagged nominations. Mr. Pitt is up for best actor for “Moneyball,” while Ms. Jolie’s directing debut, “In the Land of Blood and Honey,” about the Bosnian war, is competing in the foreign-language category. Even without the controversies surrounding it, Ms. Jolie knows the film is a hard sell.

headline: Republican Candidates Mum on Iraq
text: The end of the Iraq war has been marked with speeches and ceremonies in Washington, Baghdad, Fort Bragg, N.C., and elsewhere. But it has gone almost completely unremarked on the Republican campaign trail.

headline: Beach Boys Announce Reunion Tour, Complete With Brian Wilson
text: Fifty years after they first played together, the Beach Boys announced Friday that they would release a new studio album and go on a 50-date tour in 2012, beginning with a reunion concert at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage festival in April.

headline: What Are the Best Dogs for City Living?
text: For New York City residents, apartments can be small and green spaces can be few and far in between. So why would so many want to crowd a dog (or two) into their 600-square-foot studios? Elissa Gootman’s article, appearing in this Sunday’s Real Estate section, explores the question. She writes:

headline: RIM’s Year of Misery
text: For Research in Motion, 2011 was a devastating year. Once a leader in the smartphone business, the company, which makes the BlackBerry, saw its market share shrivel. Then there was an embarrassing service failure and the botched introduction of a tablet.

headline: Dasha Libin and Dan Anderson
text: SOME couples fight for fun. Others do it out of frustration. For Dasha Libin, a Soviet émigré, and Dan Anderson, who hails from Arkansas, fighting is a passion.

headline: Bears’ Decision-Making Questioned in Light of Hurd’s Arrest
text: 3:42 p.m. | Updated The Bears have announced they have waived Sam Hurd.

headline: A Father From the Falklands Caught in an International Dispute
text: BUENOS AIRES

headline: Testing the Waters With a Smaller Vessel
text: FOR a brand that ceased to be bold long ago, Buick is making a rather audacious request with its newest car, the 2012 Verano: would you please consider it the equal of small cars from prestigious brands like Audi and Volvo?

headline: 2012 Buick Verano
text: With the Buick Verano, General Motors is betting that Americans will pay premium prices for an upscale compact.

headline: Import Fighters? No, Just Punchlines
text: ADDRESSING a group of 450 civic leaders at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan on Oct. 3, 1968, the chairman of General Motors, James M. Roche, did something almost sacrilegious for an auto executive: he talked about a future product.

headline: America’s Least Wanted
text: The import fighters that American automakers produced in the 1970s not only lost the battle, but helped lose the war. Here’s a rogue’s gallery of Vegas, Gremlins and Pintos.

headline: Middle Class, With Few Pre-K Options
text: What happens when your preschool child is obviously ready for an organized program and you are not one of the families lucky enough to make it into a public school pre-K? Some families go underground, says Soni Sangha, who writes about her experience in "The Pre-K Underground" in this Sunday's Metropolitan section of The Times.

headline: The Dismal Education
text: THE stereotypes about economists are well known: that we’re selfish Grinches; that we don’t read human interest stories because they don’t interest us; that the only reason we don’t sell our children is that we think they’ll be worth more later.

headline: At Least 10 Die as Police Clash With Strikers in Kazakhstan
text: MOSCOW — What appeared to be an attempt by local authorities to oust striking oil workers from a square in the former Soviet state of Kazakhstan went horribly wrong on Friday, ending in at least 10 deaths in clashes with the police.

headline: Aspirations in Colorado to Be a New Motor City
text: Fort Collins, Colo.

headline: What Nonprofit Groups Know About You
text: In this weekend’s Your Money column, I look at the common but not well-known science of prospect research. Hospitals, colleges and charitable enterprises of all sorts who want you to give them money have plenty of data available about your net worth, home and any fancy cars or boats and such.

headline: Caviar Migrates Beyond the Caspian Region
text: RIOFRÍO, Spain — Caviar might be perceived as one of the world’s most exclusive products, but its production is expanding far and fast.

headline: Bonds Avoids Prison Time for Giving Evasive Testimony
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Barry Bonds, baseball’s home run champion, avoided a prison term Friday when a federal judge sentenced him to 30 days of house arrest, 2 years of probation, 250 hours of community service with youth groups and a $4,000 fine for providing evasive testimony to a federal grand jury eight years ago.

headline: Taking Fund-Raising To a New Level
text: All of the nonprofit groups whose solicitations fill up your mailbox at this time of year badly want you to like them.

headline: With Olympics in View, Bopanna and Qureshi Dissolve Doubles Team
text: With the 2012 London Olympics now less than a year away, Indian doubles specialist Rohan Bopanna has replaced playing for peace with playing for gold.

headline: Still Governor, Perry Collects ‘Retirement’ Pay
text: 3:15 p.m. | Updated  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been beating the drum about cutting the pay of Congress in half — or by 75 percent under one plan — a proposal that has become a cornerstone of his presidential campaign platform.

headline: Cornell’s Bid for City Campus Gains and Stanford Bows Out
text: Click to read the updated version of this article that appears in the newspaper.

headline: Despite Delay, the 100-Watt Bulb Is on Its Way Out
text: The law to phase out traditional incandescent light bulbs was promoted as a simple, almost painless, change when Congress first passed it. By requiring that light bulbs use at least 25 percent less electricity, starting in 2012, the nation would use less energy, manufacturers would invent more efficient types of bulbs and the planet would be spared millions of tons of carbon emissions every year.

headline: Canada’s Approach to Inconvenient Art
text: Franke James is a Canadian artist with deep concerns about her country’s outsize contribution to resource waste and the building accumulation of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. Check her scrolling artwork titled “Fat Cat Canada’s Giant Litter Box” for an example.

headline: Invasion of the Head Snatchers
text: IT wasn’t the first time the fashion industry was slammed for extreme Photoshopping. But an entirely fake body?

headline: Soup’s on for the Holidays
text: To keep you warm this winter, Martha Rose Shulman, the Recipes for Health columnist, suggests blending up creamy homemade soup:

headline: Stir It Up | Miss Lily’s Variety Show
text: Miss Lily’s, the raucous Houston Street hot spot for hush puppies and jerk chicken, has put authentic Caribbean food in fashion’s favor in recent months. Now the restaurant is opening a carefully edited record shop and radio station with a juice bar next door named Variety. Serge Becker, who designed the space to serve the city’s community of artists, designers, writers and musicians inspired by Caribbean culture, sees it as a place to “talk Jamaica” and enjoy a juice and patty. Expect to catch underground notables like Brazil’s hottest rapper, Criolo, or the Chinese-Jamaican music producer Clive Chin taking to the turntables or perusing the shop’s selection of rare vinyl, apparel and limited-edition art. Miss Lily’s fine-looking staff (pictured here in the juice bar wearing the resort collections’ most optimistic prints and colors) only help to make the hangout rock steady. The Moment caught up with the girls to find out how to get their look (that hair!) and what’s in their makeup bag. Go to slide show >>

headline: ‘Empathy Gifts’ to Friends in Need
text: Paul Sullivan writes in his Wealth Matters column this week about all the solicitations for money at this time of the year. But adding a level of complication this year is that so many of us know someone who is unemployed or underemployed. And do you have any responsibility to them?

headline: TimesCast | Iowa Caucus Projections
text: With the Iowa caucuses just weeks away, the Five Thirty Eight blogger Nate Silver digs into the poll numbers.

headline: Stores ‘Pop Up’ to Make a Big Impression, if Not Big Sales
text: As the effort to encourage Americans to buy more stuff before Christmas enters the home stretch, a popular tactic in the marketing tool kit is gaining favor: the pop-up retail store.

headline: Real-Life ‘Rudy’ Charged With Fraud
text: Daniel Ruettinger may have turned his tale as one of the sports world’s ultimate underdogs into a highly profitable motivational speaking career and the movie “Rudy.”

headline: As Tension Rises in France, Harsh Talk With Britain
text: PARIS — To the long list of victims emerging from Europe’s financial crisis, make room for a new one: the “Entente Cordiale” between Britain and France.

headline: Only 9 Nations Will Be Needed To Ratify Europe’s Fiscal Treaty
text: BRUSSELS — A new treaty to impose tighter discipline among the 17 nations in the European Union that use the euro will come into force once nine countries approve it, according to a draft released Friday. That potentially reduces the threat that disapproval by one nation could scuttle the pact.

headline: What About the Boys?
text: Beyond calling for Joe Paterno’s dismissal at the start of the Penn State horror show, I have not commented on the unfolding story, which has tainted the entire Penn State football program and the college itself. The emerging details have almost defied comment.

headline: TimesCast | Christopher Hitchens
text: December 16, 2011 - The New York Times Book Review editor, Sam Tanenhaus, reflects on the literary legacy of Christopher Hitchens.

headline: With Paul and Griffin, Clippers Are a Hot Ticket
text: Basketball, more than any other team sport, is a game dominated by superstars. For every ball-passing, defensive-minded team like the 1970 Knicks or the 1977 Trail Blazers, there are two or three times as many teams that have won championships on the backs of one or two stars. The Bulls teams of the 1990s, of course, spring to mind.

headline: TimesCast | Bradley Manning In Court
text: At Fort Meade, the first hearing begins for Private Bradley Manning, the Army intelligence analyst accused of leaking military documents, cables and videos to WikiLeaks.

headline: Wheelies: The Blame-Game Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Meet the  Comedy Duo Theron & Oswalt
text: The Bagger would like to conclude our weeklong spotlight on the cast and filmmakers of “Young Adult” by sharing a few moments with its director and stars, Patton Oswalt and Charlize Theron.

headline: ‘Late Show’ Photo Exhibition
text: A writer for David Letterman’s show exhibits his photos of celebrities and a wad of gum.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, West Bank, China and Ukraine.

headline: Tying a Roast
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to stuff and tie a roast for the holiday table.

headline: S.E.C. Fraud Case Casts Dark Cloud Over Fortress
text: 9:02 p.m. | Updated

headline: The Giving Spree | Maria Cornejo
text: Who: The designer Maria Cornejo

headline: On the Market in the Region
text: A five-bedroom midcentury in Irvington, N.Y., and a four-bedroom colonial in Redding, Conn.

headline: On the Market in New York City
text: A Hotel des Artistes duplex, a Prospect Heights co-op and a NoHo co-op

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, West Bank, China and Ukraine.

headline: Another View: MF Global’s Corporate Governance Lesson
text: Michael W. Peregrine, a partner at the law firm McDermott Will & Emery, advises corporations, officers and directors on issues related to corporate governance, fiduciary duties and internal investigations.

headline: Close to Fetching Coal and Making Pizza
text: The coal oven for the new location of Grimaldi’s Pizzeria in Brooklyn has been approved by the Buildings Department, Jennifer Gilbert, a department spokeswoman, said Friday, allowing the famous pizza shop to finally plan the grand opening.

headline: Bronx School Wins $50,000 in Music Contest
text: P.S. 48 elementary school in the Bronx is celebrating being one of three grand prize winners in the "Glee Give a Note" campaign. The school will receive $50,000 in January for its music program.

headline: Just One Look | Boy by Band of Outsiders
text: This morning, Boy by Band of Outsiders showed a preppy-pretty prefall collection at the label’s Broome Street studio. There, collegiate plaids and sweet foulards on tie-neck blouses were tucked into pencil skirts and under tailored blazers and, in one instance, paired with a very Ivy League-looking velvet green suit. Here, a romantic red check peplum blouse and skirt that’s fit for eating clubs, social clubs and dance clubs alike.

headline: A Tenderloin That’s Well Worth the Tending
text: ROASTING a whole beef tenderloin can seem like the kind of thing that only a very accomplished — or mildly delusional — cook would undertake as the centerpiece to a holiday meal. Not only is it one of the priciest cuts, but it’s also one of the least forgiving.

headline: Buying and Tying a Tenderloin
text: When you’re spending this kind of money on a hunk of meat, it really makes sense to find a butcher you can trust, or at least strike up conversation with the meat carvers in the back of your supermarket. You want to make sure the fillet you are buying is well trimmed of any silverskin, which is a thin layer of white connective tissue that is as unpleasant as gristle to chew (and all gristle should be expunged as well). Then have your butcher tie up the roast so it’s easier to handle and will cook more evenly. Failing that, you can watch my latest video, above, on how to tie up a roast. It’s not hard but does take more time than, say, having someone else do it for you.

headline: Sand Toys
text: Glamis Dunes, Calif., is considered the sand toy capital of the world. Photographer Peter Bohler spent Thanksgiving weekend there with thousands of dune riders.

headline: Weekend Fare
text: Brooklyn Night Bazaar returns with more than 100 vendors and other merchants in a 40,000-square-foot warehouse space at 149 Kent Avenue (North Fifth Street) in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, from 5 p.m. to midnight Friday and Saturday. Music and drinks from local breweries and wineries will be featured. There is no entrance fee to the market space, but tickets are $10 to $20 for certain musical performances.

headline: Latest Challenge for Knicks: Their Bench
text: The Knicks upgraded their starting lineup this off-season by swapping out Chauncey Billups for Tyson Chandler — but this has made their bench less reliable. Last year Toney Douglas, Shawne Williams, Bill Walker, and Jared Jeffries were a productive group of reserves for New York. This year Douglas moves into the starting rotation, and Williams moves across the river to wear a New Jersey Nets uniform.

headline: Big Dogs Are Set: ‘Winn-Dixie’ Musical Casts Its Canine Star and His Trainer
text: William Berloni, the animal trainer who won a special Tony in June but has had trouble finding Broadway work because of the expense of using live animals, is aiming to return in a big way.

headline: Helping America Build a Better Negroni
text: This week I received a letter — yes, an actual letter, which appeared to have been composed on an actual typewriter — from a gentleman in Pennsylvania named Gene Horn. Mr. Horn had a question about the Negroni, for which, conveniently, Robert Simonson offered a recipe in a recent Diner’s Journal post about holiday cocktails.

headline: Under Attack by Soldiers, Egyptian Protesters Report From Inside the Fray
text: Updated | 7:55 p.m. As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, at least two people were killed and more than 200 were injured on Friday as military police beat up demonstrators challenging military rule and angry protesters hurled improvised explosives at the empty Parliament building.

headline: In Obama Speech on Israel, Little Mention of Palestinians
text: Less than a year before the presidential election, a pattern is emerging. The Republicans will outdo themselves to say the most provocative things they can to demonstrate they love Israel more than anyone else. And President Obama will counter by saying as little as he can about the Palestinians.

headline: In Debt Crisis, Gulf Is Yawning Between Italy and Its Politicians
text: ROME — With its elegant marble floors, ornately carved wooden ceiling and flattering lighting, the central meeting point of Italy’s Lower House is arguably one of the most beautiful political arenas in the world.

headline: WaMu, the Cost of Law school Accreditation and a Different Economy
text: This week: Jeff Sommer with Gretchen Morgenson on WaMu, David Gillen and David Segal on the cost of law school accreditation, and Christina Romer on making this time different for the economy.

headline: Artifacts | Robert Heinecken’s ‘Copywork’
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Do Working Mothers Really Prefer Part-Time Jobs?
text: The National Marriage Project released an optimistic report this week on marital satisfaction and parenthood. Because “When Baby Makes Three” was edited by the director of the project, which aims to promote marriage by identifying “strategies to increase marital quality and stability,” and by the Director of the Center for Marriage and Families at the Institute for American Values, which seeks to increase “the proportion of children growing up with their two married parents,” this is not a report that focuses on numbers showing that marital happiness decreases among parents. It’s a report that looks at why that’s not true for a “substantial minority of husbands and wives.”

headline: What Romney Knew About Medicaid
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — As Mitt Romney finished up an early morning town-hall-style meeting in Iowa, finishing up an answer on entitlement programs like Medicare and Medicaid, he offered a casual confession: “I have to admit, I didn’t know all the differences between these things before I got into government, and then got into it and understood that Medicaid is the health care program for the poor, by and large.”

headline: Millennium Hotel Loses Racial Harassment Suit
text: On its Web site, the Millennium Broadway Hotel says “everyone receives star treatment.” But one longtime employee said he was treated just the opposite, claiming that he was the victim of a long campaign of racial harassment that the hotel did nothing to stop.

headline: Flags for Civilians
text: A bit of legislation recently landed on President Obama’s desk that passed both the House and the Senate without any dissenting votes whatsoever: The Civil Service Recognition Act.

headline: Youthful Energy, Onstage and Outside
text: In “New Dances: Edition 2011,” Juilliard Dance students appear in order of class: the youngest, 2015, to the oldest, 2012. Were it not for that arrangement, it would have been tricky to tell who was the more advanced when their program opened on Thursday at the Peter Jay Sharp Theater. The dancers were all of a high caliber, and the works, all premieres by four guest choreographers, didn’t necessarily display ascending skill.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 16
text: Subjects include the return of a Christmas tradition, the killing of a police officer and the death of a woman in an elevator accident.

headline: Fishmonger’s Stew
text: Time: 45 minutes

headline: Stew, Fresh From the Fisherman
text: A JOLLY fishmonger is an inspiration. Alex Villani, well known to Greenmarket shoppers in Manhattan and Brooklyn, is just that: smiling, laughing, joking and incredibly hard-working.

headline: Key to a Great Stew: a Great Fisherman
text: It doesn’t take much in the way of ingredients to make a good fish stew, but it does need good fresh fish. Enter local fishmonger Alex Villani of Blue Moon Fish. Well known in Manhattan and Brooklyn Greenmarkets, his fish and shellfish have a loyal following. In an admirably energetic and unusual arrangement, the man catches the fish out by Mattituck on Long Island, drives it to market, and, with the help of his wife, Stephanie, sells it at his stall, all the while smiling about it.

headline: On Looting, UK Feminista and Where Feminism Went Wrong
text: Jenny Turner in The London Review of Books: “Here, in a nutshell, is the problem with feminism. Young women ‘of good character’ losing their heads and wishing they hadn’t. You feel so sorry for them, but can’t you sense what they tasted in the air as they were doing it: freedom, fury, the power — for once — of being young and strong and agile and a homegirl, the flat-out joy of getting your hands on some free stuff.” Read on.

headline: Congress to Examine S.E.C. Settlement Policy
text: 8:27 p.m. | Updated

headline: In the Tradition of a Matriarch, This Family Keeps Crooning and Caroling
text: “A Not So Silent Night,” the concert at Town Hall on Thursday, was a typical Christmastime family gathering: motley, convivial, multigenerational, jokey, affectionate, conscious of passing years and tinged with both skepticism and faith. There wasn’t any bickering, though. The family onstage happens to be packed with singers and songwriters — troupers all — and this year the next generation was resuming a tradition.

headline: Fewer Students Repeat a Grade This Year
text: A third of New York City elementary and middle school students who failed state exams last spring did not move on to the next grade this school year, a decrease from the year before, when nearly half were held back.

headline: Military Police Clash With Protesters in Cairo
text: The center of Egypt’s capital erupted in violence again on Friday as military police beat up demonstrators challenging military rule.

headline: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 18
text: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

headline: For Richard Dawkins, Traditional Christmas Carols Trump Atheism
text: Richard Dawkins may want to take God out of public life, but don’t try to take the Christ out of his Christmas carols.

headline: Surprising Histories, With Drinks
text: FROM Cairo to Manhattan to Moscow, it’s been a rabble-rousing year. Given the tumult, holiday readers may rush to wrap themselves in a few nostalgia-drenched books that offer refuge from the headlines.

headline: Chaucer and Beowulf March (or Make That Dance) to a New Turntable Beat
text: In the arts, as in so many things, time elevates.

headline: Revealing the Habits of Copyright Advocates
text: As Congress moves forward on two bills aimed at curbing online piracy, a Web site has given opponents a way to attack those lobbying for the measures by exposing their illegal downloads.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Reds
text: SantaCon, the annual street happening in which nearly 5,000 costumed participants join in a day of good cheer, eating and drinking, was last Saturday.

headline: Tough Women, Candid Candidates
text: BEST is the worst of categories, because there are so many different standards for television — “Breaking Bad” may offer the most searing performances, but plenty of seemingly high-minded people get a kick out of “Hoarders” or “Chelsea Lately.” There was a lot of good television in 2011, but it was also a year that stood out for deliciously bad entertainment as well.

headline: Do Iowa Polls Predict New Hampshire Results?
text: Jonathan Bernstein asks a great question pursuant to the release of our state-by-state forecasts today. If we want to know what will happen in New Hampshire on Jan. 10, should we be looking at the Iowa polls as well as those from the Granite State?

headline: Avoiding the Holidays? Take the Ferry
text: The Staten Island Ferry’s terminals are bereft of holiday décor this year. Commuters may grouse, but Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that the city’s Transportation Department did the right thing by skipping the Christmas trees, menorahs and holiday lights that had festooned the terminals in previous years.

headline: Chic in Review | Lanvin, the Next Generation
text: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: The Jazz Has a Lot of Pieces, but Do They All Fit?
text: The Utah Jazz didn’t exactly crash and burn following the departure of Deron Williams last season, but that in itself presents a bit of a problem. Rather than truly bottom out in their rebuilding efforts – or make a lateral move for a parallel star – the Jazz have nested in the league’s uncomfortable middle ground: Utah is bad enough to be an irrelevant element of the Western Conference playoff picture, but too good to expect a top draft pick.

headline: For Real Sweat Equity
text: AS anyone in client services knows, schmoozing can take a physical toll. All those drinks, dinners and parties mean little time to hit the gym. So why not mix work with working out?

headline: Some Early Applicants Will Wait a Little Longer
text: This is early decision notification week, and, on Thursday in particular, many a computer mouse hovered over the refresh button as students anticipated an admittance, deferral or denial.

headline: The Last Republican Debate Before the Iowa Caucuses
text: The Last Republican Debate Before the Iowa Caucuses

headline: Remember Me From Yesterday?
text: IS the high school reunion past its prime?

headline: Book Review Podcast: A Brainy Beauty and World War II
text: In this Sunday’s Book Review, the composer John Adams reviews Richard Rhodes’s “Hedy’s Folly,” about the wartime inventions of the movie star Hedy Lamarr. Mr. Adams writes:

headline: It’s Her Final Show, but Behar Keeps Thinking About Tomorrow
text: What’s Joy Behar going to do in the afternoons now?

headline: Toggling Between Life and a Dream
text: PEOPLE tell me all the time that I have a dream job.

headline: #trendingnyc: The Week on Twitter
text: Stores were packed with shoppers last weekend, Christmas trees lined the sidewalks awaiting homes and thousands of inebriated Santas staggered across Manhattan on an annual bar crawl.

headline: Auction Shows Elizabeth Taylor’s Star Still Shines
text: The New York exhibition alone was seen by more than 25,000 visitors, who came to ogle the jewels and the ancillary items.

headline: Once a Star, Always a Star
text: “MINE!” screamed the violet tags attached to towering piles of Louis Vuitton luggage on display at Christie’s, where the collection of jewelry and clothing acquired by Elizabeth Taylor over a storied and tempestuous life went up for auction last week, knocking down records right and left.

headline: A John Lennon in the World of Comics
text: The talking heads who turn up in “Method to the Madness of Jerry Lewis,” a documentary having its premiere on Saturday on Encore, really, really want us to know that Mr. Lewis is a towering figure in comedy and worthy of the respect accorded to showbiz greats.

headline: Drama, Fictional and Real, and Well-Earned Laughs
text: FROM the modest slice of the television pie that I found time to watch this past year here are 10 of my favorite shows, in alphabetical order. Not included: “Friday Night Lights,” the best show of 2010 and previous years. Six episodes in January and early February weren’t enough to qualify (and the NBC reruns don’t count).

headline: Lure of the Obscure: Shows Very Good or Very Bad
text: PERHAPS, as the end of the year approaches, you have an empty feeling inside. You have watched 14 hours of television a day, the government-recommended minimum, yet you feel as if you’ve missed something. You know who won all the reality competitions and how the various characters on “Modern Family” are related, but you haven’t been wowed or surprised or grossed out sufficiently to compensate for your investment of time, not to mention that flat screen you bought with your tax refund.

headline: Belated Acclaim for an Artist With a Restless Sensibility
text: Greenport, N.Y.

headline: A Look Back at Extended Unemployment Benefits
text: Tangled in the current Washington debate over extending the payroll tax is another thorny, but less prominent, policy issue: whether to also renew extended unemployment benefits.

headline: Letters
text: Anchors and Motherhood

headline: Stoppard’s Pirandello Lands A Bigger Stage for Its One-Night American Premiere
text: The American premiere of Tom Stoppard’s adaptation of Luigi Pirandello’s “Henry IV” may be running for one night only, but now more people will be able to see it.

headline: Sounding a Little Like Christmas
text: The Christmas repertory list for New York performing groups has long had Handel’s “Messiah” at the top and, for the more secular-minded, Bach’s “Brandenburg” Concertos presented nearly as plentifully. The Orchestra of St. Luke’s touched on this second tradition on Thursday evening, when 11 players opened its concert at Carnegie Hall with a zesty account of the “Brandenburg” Concerto No. 3.

headline: A YouTube Takedown Raises Questions Over Media Influence
text: Under what circumstances can a big media company demand that YouTube remove a video?

headline: When Japanese-Americans Were Interned in Camps
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Life Report: Frank H. Wheeler
text: The following Life Report was submitted in response to my column of Oct. 28, in which I asked readers over 70 to write autobiographical essays evaluating their own lives. This one takes the form of a letter from a father to his two sons.

headline: Belle Is Fulfilled, and Dickens Restored
text: It is possible to see “A Christmas Carol” on film or onstage a dozen times, maybe more, and yet never see one particular scene from Dickens’s original 1843 novella. It stars Belle, the young Ebenezer Scrooge’s fiancée, who broke off their engagement because Ebenezer had become so obsessed with money. She is seen talking about him casually but sympathetically with her handsome husband, in a tableau of contented domesticity with their beautiful daughter and their prettily decorated Christmas tree.

headline: Reviewing the Buick Verano
text: In Sunday’s Automobiles section, Christopher Jensen reviews the Buick Verano, a premium compact sedan that shares its architecture with its strong-selling, and more frugally priced, corporate relation under General Motors, the Chevrolet Cruze.

headline: Group Therapy: Tell Us Your Pinto, Vega and Gremlin Stories
text: Though an era of stylish, high-quality compact cars is upon the land, with American manufacturers like Chevrolet, Ford and — shortly — Chrysler producing attractive vehicles worthy of being cross-shopped against their Asian counterparts, it was not always so.

headline: ‘Lord, What Is Man,’ and Other Philosophical Tidbits for the Ages
text: Eloquent in its middle, the Welsh countertenor Iestyn Davies’s voice soars at the top of its range. Dapper and self-possessed, Mr. Davies, who made his New York recital debut at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday evening, is a singer of serenity and understatement. Even his virtuosity seems somehow modest.

headline: A Region in the Caucasus
text: To the Editor:

headline: Private Equity Buyouts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Bringing a Theater to a Beleaguered City
text: NEWBURGH, N.Y.

headline: U.S. Activist Jailed in Peru Can Go Home For Holidays
text: LIMA, Peru — A court here is allowing Lori Berenson, the paroled American who spent more than 15 years in Peruvian prisons on a terrorism conviction, to travel to the United States for the first time.

headline: Reflections on Iraq as U.S. Troops Leave
text: To the Editor:

headline: Rejuvenating Opera With an Act of Dissent
text: NEW YORK is unquestionably an international capital of the arts, but it can also be a frustrating backwater when it comes to contemporary opera. Yes, in February the Metropolitan Opera mounted John Adams’s “Nixon in China”: a groundbreaking work at its premiere 24 years ago, since embraced as canon most everywhere but here. In November the Met revived a brilliant staging of Philip Glass’s “Satyagraha,” a 1979 opera that proved its worth elsewhere first.

headline: Hummingbird Makes a Year-End Visit
text: Visitors to the American Museum of Natural History are familiar with its dioramas of stuffed fauna from around the world. On the third floor is a hall dedicated to birds of New York City, including the extinct carrier pigeon.

headline: Christopher Hitchens, Consummate Writer, Brilliant Friend
text: London

headline: Talking With Ellen Johnson Sirleaf
text: A conversation between Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, president of Liberia and 2011 Nobel Peace Prize laureate, and Alison Smale, executive editor of the International Herald Tribune.

headline: Exchanging Vows Under a Canopy, No Matter the Faith
text: WHEN Natalie Rodic Marsan, 35, a Texas native who now lives in Brooklyn, was planning her June 12, 2010, wedding on an island off Croatia, she imagined it taking place on the beach under a canopy like a huppah, the wedding covering that is a fixture at Jewish weddings.

headline: Listening to the British Rioters
text: As we come to the end of a remarkable year of protests and riots across the globe, it is not hard to feel that too little time has been devoted to digesting the meaning of what’s happened, perhaps in part because technology now makes it so easy to get caught up in following the rush of events as they unspool online.

headline: Christopher Hitchens, Book Critic
text: Even as Christopher Hitchens weakened from cancer over the past year and a half, the work he contributed to The New York Times Book Review was as strong as ever, if not stronger. The last piece he wrote for us assessed the playwright David Mamet’s account of shifting politically to the right. Mr. Hitchens made it clear that his pugnacity would be with him until the last: “This is an extraordinarily irritating book,” he began, later saying of one of Mr. Mamet’s opinions that it “has a long way to go before it can even be called simplistic.”

headline: In Beijing, Americans Win 2 Individual Events
text: The first SportAccord World Mind Games, which ended on Friday in Beijing, brought together competitors in five disciplines: bridge, checkers, chess, Chinese chess and go.

headline: Revolt Begins Like Others, but Its End Is Less Certain
text: WUKAN, China — Each day begins with a morning rally in the banner-bedecked square, where village leaders address a packed crowd about their seizure of the village and plans for its future. Friday’s session was followed by a daylong mock funeral for a fallen comrade, whose body lies somewhere outside the village in government custody.

headline: Willy Parkers, Not Just for the Locals
text: IF you haven’t eaten at Willy Parkers American Bar and Grill in the last four months, you haven’t eaten at Willy Parkers. A new chef came on board in August, bringing with him an upgraded menu.

headline: In Spin Room After Debate, Glimpses Into Campaigns’ Weak Spots
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — Mitt Romney’s criticisms became “contrasts.” Newt Gingrich’s consulting firm morphed into a “small business.” And Ron Paul’s isolationist worldview evolved into a “strong national defense.”

headline: Robust Despite the Rains
text: Despite the major problems that recurring rains caused for Long Island vintners during this year’s growing season, two leading producers are quickly releasing successful 2011 whites.

headline: Penn State’s McQueary Tells Court What He Saw
text: HARRISBURG, Pa. — A Penn State assistant football coach testified Friday that in 2002 he saw Jerry Sandusky sexually assaulting a young boy and that he reported it, in graphic detail, to Coach Joe Paterno and two senior Penn State University officials.

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Former Chiefs of Freddie and Fannie of Deception
text: 9:30 p.m. | Updated

headline: It’s a Genuine Rembrandt, but Not a Painting
text: Rembrandt used drawing in the 17th century the way 21st-century artists use photography: to record people, places and things, and as source material or preparatory studies for his works. There is no consensus on how many drawings he produced, but some estimates place the number in the thousands. A selection from his prodigious output is on view in “Drawings by Rembrandt, His Students and Circle From the Maida and George Abrams Collection,” which features more than 50 drawings by nearly two dozen artists.

headline: Inside the Spin Room
text: The “spin room” has taken on an outsized importance in a political season defined by gaffes (a brain freeze), flubbed jokes (a $10,000 bet) and factually challenged assertions (suggesting a vaccine causes mental retardation).

headline: Week in Pictures for Dec. 16
text: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the return of a Christmas tradition, the killing of a police officer and the death of a woman in an elevator accident.

headline: Appealing to Nostalgia for the Old Country
text: RUTHERFORD, N.J.

headline: Stanford Ends Effort to Build New York Arm
text: Stanford University abruptly dropped out of the intense international competition to build an innovative science graduate school in New York City, releasing its decision on Friday afternoon. A short time later, its main rival in the contest, Cornell, announced a $350 million gift — the largest in its history — to underwrite its bid.

headline: Crippling the Right to Organize
text: Stanford, Calif.

headline: Hearings Shed Light on Pollock Dispute
text: Years before federal authorities opened their forgery inquiry into a cache of Modernist paintings handled by high-end art dealers, the Knoedler Gallery agreed to refund $2 million to a client who had questioned the authenticity of one of the works, according to court testimony this week.

headline: Big Ticket | Sold for $6,100,000
text: A four-bedroom four-bath apartment on Riverside Boulevard on the Upper West Side was the biggest sale of the week, at $6.1 million, according to city records.

headline: Gifts Destined for the Table, Not the Trash
text: FRUITCAKES and plum pudding are holiday traditions right up there with inflatable reindeer and aerosol snow. These boozy variations on a theme of candied fruits, nuts, spices and extracts are generally garish and heavy-handed, a perennial favorite for re-gifting.

headline: High-Profile Romney Endorsement Is Dismissed by Gingrich Camp
text: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Mitt Romney chartered a plane from Iowa and headed south to collect one of his party’s most coveted endorsements on Friday, while Newt Gingrich returned home to Virginia — on a commercial Delta flight, with one connection — to watch his wife play the French horn at a Christmas concert.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Unusual Year-End Lists and a Spider Bot
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors picked out on the Web on Friday. For the full list, look over to the right-hand column.

headline: Indian Point: The Next Fukushima?
text: Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Amazon Says Long Term And Means It
text: In 1997, the year Amazon.com went public, its chief executive, Jeff Bezos, issued a manifesto: “It’s all about the long term,” he said. He warned shareholders “we may make decisions and weigh tradeoffs differently than some companies” and urged them to make sure that a long-term approach “is consistent with your investment policy.” Amazon’s management and employees “are working to build something important, something that matters to our customers, something that we can tell our grandchildren about,” he added.

headline: Beyond Durban
text: Startling new evidence that global carbon dioxide emissions are rising faster than ever did little to increase the urgency of the climate talks in Durban, South Africa, which concluded earlier this week. Once again, the world’s negotiators kicked the can down the road.

headline: German Baking, From Almond Paste to Zimtsterne
text: SCOTT RIVERA’S sales pitch was in high gear on a chilly Saturday morning at the New Haven farmers’ market. “If you like whole grain and rye I recommend trying our vollkorn brot,” he told more than a few customers while slicing bite-sized pieces of a dozen or so German breads, pretzels and cakes from Whole G bakery, whose name stands for whole German and whole grain.

headline: Nonprofit Companies Enjoying, Well, Profits
text: By Sunday, when the critically acclaimed Broadway drama “Venus in Fur” closes at Manhattan Theater Club’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater after a two-month run, many of the club’s 15,000 subscribers will have seen the play. Normally, that would be that: Unlike commercial producers, who aim to enrich themselves with long-running hits, Manhattan Theater Club is a nonprofit that seeks to open (and close) several shows each year for subscribers and others.

headline: Tech Talk Podcast: Election Apps
text: The presidential campaign season will soon be in full swing. Sarah Wheaton, who updates the New York Times app’s Top News section, and Jonathan Ellis, who oversaw the new Election 2012 app development, stop by to talk about the election coverage and apps.

headline: An Agreement on Spending
text: They are reviled by the right and were even kicked out of their lavish old offices on the House side by Republican leaders. But Congressional appropriators — known for handling the most basic task of the legislative branch in a centrist manner — did their jobs this week. The spending bill they wrote for the remainder of the 2012 fiscal year came together with a minimum of ideology and passed the House over the opposition of hard-liners. The Senate is expected to give its approval this weekend, averting a shutdown.

headline: At 93, Still the ‘Staff Artist’
text: IRWIN HASEN, 93, says the happiest moment in his life came early one morning in September 1955, when he had just begun drawing the comic strip “Dondi.”

headline: The Case Against Sheriff Arpaio
text: After a three-year investigation, the Justice Department has accused Joe Arpaio, the sheriff of Maricopa County, Ariz., and longtime darling of the anti-immigrant crowd, of “unconstitutional policing” and creating a “pervasive culture of bias” against Latinos.

headline: G.O.P. Debate Wins High Ratings (Again)
text: The Republican presidential debate on Fox News Thursday night continued the trend of winning huge ratings for the candidate face-offs this year.

headline: Podcast: WaMu’s Settlement, the Cost of Law School and the Pain of the Financial Crisis
text: The demise of Washington Mutual in 2008 was the biggest bank collapse in United States history.

headline: Few Hard Rules for Backup Officers
text: It is late, and the streets are dark. A violent crime is erupting. Confusion reigns. And, invariably, patrol officers on duty in New York City will need one thing: backup.

headline: Online, Then Out for a Long Walk
text: For Dennis Crowley, 35, a founder of the social networking service Foursquare, Sundays are a time to explore the city the way his company encourages users to do, seeking out new experiences and revisiting old favorites. Expeditions begin and eventually end in his Alphabet City apartment, where he lives with his girlfriend, Chelsa Skees, 30, who is a partner in a retail startup in Chelsea, and her cat, Peanut Butter, known to his more than 100 Twitter followers as @Pnizzle.

headline: An Early Holiday Hangover
text: Right now you’re probably asking yourself: What’s up with reproductive rights this holiday season?

headline: English, Once a Barrier, Opens a Door
text: For Hui Lin, 17, English has been something of a lifeline. Five years ago, she could barely speak the language, struggling to count to 10 even after finishing seventh grade at a school in Chinatown in Manhattan.

headline: The First to 700 Wins
text: Campus Magnet’s Charles Granby became the first coach in the P.S.A.L. to reach the milestone.

headline: Buyers of Stolen Gadgets Are Arrested
text: The police arrested 141 people across New York City this week on charges that they bought stolen iPhones and iPads from undercover police officers.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Holiday Tradition in Gramercy Park
text: Q. Is Gramercy Park ever open to the public?

headline: Inconvenient Income Inequality
text: Is income inequality becoming the new global warming? In other words, is this another case where the facts of an existential threat lose traction among a weary American public as deniers attempt to reduce them to partisan opinions?

headline: Creative Visions, Writ Large
text: The artist Kristin Jones is planning her first major public art project in New York City in a dozen years.

headline: Millions From Diamonds Go to Mugabe, Observers Say
text: JOHANNESBURG — Tens of millions of dollars in diamond profits — perhaps more — are being secretly extracted from state-owned mines in eastern Zimbabwe, bypassing the nation’s treasury and raising fears that President Robert Mugabe is amassing wealth to help extend his 31-year reign, according to monitoring groups, diplomats, lawmakers and analysts.

headline: With Victory No. 700 Comes a P.S.A.L. First
text: Campus Magnet Coach Charles Granby rose slowly from the visitors’ bench and peeked at the game clock Thursday night at Forest Hills High School. Time was running out on another opponent, and a small contingent of family and friends seated behind him began to roar.

headline: Health Care Law Will Let States Tailor Benefits
text: WASHINGTON — In a major surprise on the politically charged new health care law, the Obama administration said Friday that it would not define a single uniform set of “essential health benefits” that must be provided by insurers for tens of millions of Americans. Instead, it will allow each state to specify the benefits within broad categories.

headline: Like Christo, Thinking Big
text: THE artist Kristin Jones, 55, wrapped in a double layer of green velvet capes with her blond Rapunzel braid askew over one shoulder, stood in the northwest corner of Washington Square Park gazing rapturously at a 330-year-old tree known as the Hangman’s Elm. She placed a protective hand on its mighty trunk.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Greeks pondered leaving the euro and returning to the drachma, Facebook resisters gave their side, investigators dug deeper into the collapse of MF Global and Russia joined the World Trade Organization.

headline: Occupy Group Faults Church, a Onetime Ally
text: For months, they were the best of neighbors: the slapdash champions of economic equality, putting down stakes in an outdoor plaza, and the venerable Episcopal parish next door, whose munificence helped sustain the growing protest.

headline: College Football Analyst Is Weighing Senate Run
text: Craig James, the often-contentious ESPN football analyst, is contemplating a run for the United States Senate seat in Texas being vacated by Kay Bailey Hutchison.

headline: With Vows Exchanged, Break Out the Slides
text: Recently at PowerHouse Arena in Dumbo, a loft-like store for arty bibliophiles, David Friedlander, a handsome guy whose career has a 21st-century way of resisting easy description, married Jacqueline Schmidt, an ethereal redhead — a dancer once, a graphic artist now — who seems to run on earnest optimism.

headline: For the Fallen, an Esoteric, Simple Symbol of Grief
text: The locker that nobody wants to open is on the seventh floor of a massive police building on East 20th Street. Turn left out of the elevator, then walk down a hall and through a cluttered computer training classroom, to a door in the rear marked Ceremonial Unit. Another left into a little dead-end hall, and there it is, the last locker on the left, marked No. 2064. It’s as if someone wanted to make it hard to find.

headline: For the Jets, a Familiar Face in a Familiar Place
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — An unworn green practice jersey hung inside Jim Leonhard’s locker Friday afternoon. The black stool that normally sits in front of his locker had been stowed away. There was no green equipment bag for Leonhard to jam his gear into before Sunday’s game against the Eagles in Philadelphia.

headline: A Strenuous Strut Down the Catwalk
text: One by one, in gowns or tuxedos, guests at a fund-raiser on Monday night carried giant canisters of water around a catwalk in the middle of the cavernous 69th Regiment Armory on Lexington. Some women kicked off stilettos for the trek; others bore the burden in heels.

headline: Events in Connecticut

headline: Saturday: Lowest Number on a Clock
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Nope, this one just wasn’t in my wheelhouse either. I know. I’ve been whining for days, and I can only hope that the big Sunday grid is a little kinder to me. It would be a nice way to wrap up the weekend, after the past two days of J.B.F.’s (Just Barely Finished).

headline: Events on Long Island

headline: This Sunday: How Nice Can Benton Harbor Ever Be?
text: Detroit gets all the scary headlines, but there is a more desperate city in the state of Michigan, and it is called Benton Harbor. For the magazine’s cover story this week, Jonathan Mahler went there to investigate the city’s plan to revive itself with a publicly subsidized golf course and luxury-housing development in the very place where factories once provided thousands of blue-collar workers with a way of life. Slowly, since the 1960s, Benton Harbor has lost all its factories and half its population; those who remain subsist on a per capita income of $10,000. The city’s finances are so wrecked that the state government sent in an emergency manager who answers to no one locally. Putting a golf course in the midst of all this is, as Jon observes, “almost a caricature of economic disparity.”

headline: Nets May Be Just Player Away From Reviving Knicks Rivalry
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Chris Paul landed in Los Angeles, pulled on a red Clippers jersey and, in an instant, a rivalry was born where none had existed. This is how quickly reality can change in today’s N.B.A.

headline: An Epic Drawn From the Tears of Nanjing
Devils Win on Niedermayer’s Night
text: NEWARK — On the night the Devils honored Scott Niedermayer by retiring his No. 27, it was easy to understand why the current team is probably a few years away from becoming a Stanley Cup contender. Defensemen the caliber of Niedermayer do not come along often, and the Devils do not have anyone like him. Few teams do.

headline: Paul’s ‘Ground Game,’ in Place Since ’08, Gives Him an Edge
text: ANKENY, Iowa — It was four years ago that Ross Witt, a soft-spoken electrical engineer at John Deere, overcame his natural discomfort with knocking on hundreds of his neighbors’ doors during dinnertime as a precinct coordinator for Ron Paul’s campaign.

headline: Giants’ Kiwanuka Still Adjusting in Another Transition to Linebacker
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants’ selection of Mathias Kiwanuka in the first round of the 2006 draft illustrated the team’s commitment to stockpiling talent on the defensive line, which already had Michael Strahan, Osi Umenyiora and Justin Tuck. The former general manager Ernie Accorsi often said that a team could never have enough pass rushers.

headline: Frozen Carbon

headline: Access to Details on Wealthy Donors Fueled Theft Ring

headline: As Permafrost Thaws, Scientists Study the Risks
text: FAIRBANKS, Alaska — A bubble rose through a hole in the surface of a frozen lake. It popped, followed by another, and another, as if a pot were somehow boiling in the icy depths.

headline: MSG and Time Warner Face Off
text: MSG Media accused Time Warner Cable on Friday of threatening to remove its networks, MSG and MSG Plus, from its systems in the New York and Buffalo markets on Dec. 31 in a contractual dispute that could deprive viewers of Knicks, Rangers, Islanders, Devils and Sabres games.

headline: U.C.L.A. and Illinois in Women’s Volleyball Final
text: SAN ANTONIO — Thursday night’s national semifinal matches of the N.C.A.A. women’s volleyball Final Four could not have played out more differently. U.C.L.A. swept the first match of the night, 3-0, against Florida State. In the second game, Illinois and Southern California pushed their match to five sets. Illinois won the fifth set on a match point that included about 50 touches before the Illini notched the 15th and decisive point. After the exhausting conclusion of the match, the Illini did not celebrate their program’s first championship game appearance; the players lined up, shook hands with their Southern California counterparts and began preparing for their matchup against U.C.L.A.

headline: Gingrich Represents New Political Era for Catholics
text: Newt Gingrich sat beneath the soaring dome in the largest Roman Catholic church in North America, the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington, and listened as a choir that included his wife sang at an evening vespers service for Pope Benedict XVI and 300 American bishops.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: A 24-year-old shopkeeper died Wednesday, two weeks after being severely beaten up by protesters who demanded a shutdown in the Nowhatta area of Srinagar. Tariq Ahmed Bhat had refused closing down his shop. (Kashmir Live)Rajasthan: The Rajasthan police commissioner and the Jaipur Municipal Corporation have decided to relocate the city’s beggars in order to create a good impression and encourage non-resident Indians to invest in the state. The decision was made in advance of the upcoming Pravasi Bharatiya Diwas, from Jan. 7-9 (Daily Bhaskar).

headline: Mitigation Package for Colton Harris-Moore
text: The lawyers for Colton Harris-Moore, known as the “Barefoot Bandit,” filed papers detailing poverty and abuse during his childhood in hopes that the judge would hand down a lenient sentence.

headline: ‘Barefoot Bandit’ Gets Prison for Stealing From Neighbors
text: COUPEVILLE, Wash. — Colton Harris-Moore, the “Barefoot Bandit,” stood bolt upright in orange jail garb before Judge Vicki I. Churchill in the small courtroom here on Friday and was sentenced to seven years and three months in prison. His hands were folded in front of him because they were shackled, and he struggled to hold back tears as he pleaded guilty to 33 state charges including burglary and identity theft.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: In the upcoming “Don 2,” Priyanka Chopra plays Roma, a cop in hot pursuit of the mastermind criminal Don (played by Shah Rukh Khan) but also perhaps a little bit in love with him. His special name for her is “junglee bili,” or wild cat. Priyanka tells us what makes the action-thriller franchise special.

headline: Congress Passes Bill Bolstering Pipeline Safety Rules
text: A bill doubling the maximum fines that pipeline operators face for violations easily cleared the House and Senate this week, along with other provisions intended to strengthen rules on oil and gas pipeline safety that critics have faulted as weak.

headline: Analysts Say Economic Recovery Might Suffer if Tax Break Is Allowed to Expire
text: WASHINGTON — Economists are warning that the looming expiration of a temporary payroll tax cut — and the possibility that Congress will not extend it — would cause families to spend less and could sap strength from a fragile recovery.

headline: Patrick V. Murphy, Police Leader Who Reformed New York Force, Dies at 91
text: Patrick V. Murphy, the son of a New York City policeman who rose to lead the Police Department in the early 1970s, steering it through one of its rockiest periods as he instituted reforms to root out corruption in the ranks, died Friday at a North Carolina hospital. He was 91 and lived in Wilmington, N.C.

headline: Billie Jo Spears, Country Singer, Dies at 73
text: Billie Jo Spears, a singer of country songs with strong women as their protagonists, died on Wednesday at her home in Vidor, Tex. She was 73.

headline: Drum Major’s Death Ruled Hazing Homicide
text: The death of a Florida A&M University drum major last month was a homicide caused by hazing, a Florida medical examiner said Friday.

headline: Texas: Judges Push Back Primary Election Date
text: A federal three-judge panel in San Antonio on Friday pushed back the state’s primary elections from the scheduled date of March 6 to April 3, resolving one of the most pressing issues in a redistricting dispute that has thrown much of Texas politics into disarray. One option under consideration had been splitting the primary into two separate elections, a move that many Democrats and Republicans opposed, saying it would hurt voter turnout, cost counties hundreds of thousands of dollars and create logistical problems for elections officials. The parties issued a joint statement on Friday saying they were pleased with the new election schedule. The judges’ decision ordering a single unified primary came after an agreement on the election schedule had been reached by the state Democratic and Republican Parties.

headline: California: Judge Rejects Lethal Injection Protocol
text: A judge tossed out California’s newly adopted lethal injection protocol on Friday, throwing the state’s execution system into further upheaval. Judge Faye D’Opal of Marin County Superior Court in San Rafael ruled that the state had failed to justify the decision to put in place a three-drug lethal injection method, which some experts had said carries a risk of “excruciating pain,” instead of a one-drug method, which one of the Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation’s own experts had recommended. No executions have been conducted in California since 2006, when a federal judge effectively halted lethal injections, citing various deficiencies in the state’s methods. Since then, the state has revamped its execution system, including the construction of a new death chamber specifically for lethal injections. The corrections department declined to comment on the ruling.

headline: Friending the New York Scene
text: SINCE moving to Manhattan three years ago, Sean Parker, a founder of Napster and former president of Facebook, has considerably enlivened New York’s social scene.

headline: Panetta Is First U.S. Defense Secretary to Visit Libya
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Presidents from Thomas Jefferson to Barack Obama have waged war on these shores. Given such volatile relations, it is little wonder that no American defense secretary had ever set foot here.

headline: For Maryland, Distant Memories of a Track and Field Power

Some two dozen runners, jumpers and throwers strode with proud purpose, hoisting Maryland flags and moving to the pounding beat of a Parliament-Funkadelic song, blaring from a boom box, with the lyrics, “If you hear any noise, it’s just me and the boys.”

headline: A Road Trip, Mexican Style, to Watch the Cowboys

headline: Organized Chaos on the Jets’ Sidelines
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When Mike Westhoff’s mind boosts into overdrive, so do his legs. He assesses a few plays in advance of what might happen on fourth down, then darts from one end of the Jets’ sideline to the other preparing his special-teamers. Ever the perfectionist, Westhoff is not satisfied until he has looked each of them in the eye.

headline: Why Is the N.Y.P.D. After Me?
text: WHEN I was 14, my mother told me not to panic if a police officer stopped me. And she cautioned me to carry ID and never run away from the police or I could be shot. In the nine years since my mother gave me this advice, I have had numerous occasions to consider her wisdom.

headline: The Pungent Aroma of Paranoia

headline: Help Wanted
text: THE historian Walter Russell Mead recently noted that after the 1990s revolution that collapsed the Soviet Union, Russians had a saying that seems particularly apt today: “It’s easier to turn an aquarium into fish soup than to turn fish soup into an aquarium.” Indeed, from Europe to the Middle East, and maybe soon even to Russia and Asia, a lot of aquariums are being turned into fish soup all at once. But turning them back into stable societies and communities will be one of the great challenges of our time.

headline: ‘Vine Talk’ Participants Complain of Not Being Paid
text: On the syndicated public television show “Vine Talk,” the actor Stanley Tucci leads a changing cast of chefs and celebrities in a convivial round of wine tasting. But off-camera, many of the show’s participants are battling over money still owed to them.

headline: Repressing Democracy, With American Arms

headline: Self-Adoration Reaches Newt Heights
text: MARVELING over a presidential candidate’s arrogance is like noting that a hockey player wears skates. It states not just the obvious but the necessary. You can’t zip across the ice in Crocs, and you can’t thrash your way to 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue if your confidence doesn’t bleed into something gaudier. Arrogance is the grist, and arrogance is the given.

headline: Working With Medicare
text: There are many ways to rein in Medicare spending without scrapping the system and starting over.

headline: Ask David Segal About Law School
text: On the cover of this week’s Sunday Business section, The Times’s David Segal writes about how standards set by the American Bar Association can affect law schools. The association’s rules make it difficult for law schools to offer legal education without charging hefty tuition.

headline: The Believer’s Atheist
text: OF the many remarkable things about Christopher Hitchens, who died on Thursday after one of the most prolific and provocative careers in modern Anglo-American letters, perhaps the most remarkable was how much religious believers liked him.

headline: War Really Is Going Out of Style
text: THE departure of the last American troops from Iraq brings relief to a nation that has endured its most painful war since Vietnam. But the event is momentous for another reason. The invasion of Iraq was the most recent example of an all-out war between two national armies. And it could very well be the last one.

headline: The Internet Gets Physical
text: THE Internet likes you, really likes you. It offers you so much, just a mouse click or finger tap away. Go Christmas shopping, find restaurants, locate partying friends, tell the world what you’re up to. Some of the finest minds in computer science, working at start-ups and big companies, are obsessed with tracking your online habits to offer targeted ads and coupons, just for you.

headline: Are We Not Man Enough?
text: ON Friday, a federal judge in San Francisco sentenced Barry Bonds, Major League Baseball’s career home run leader, to two years of probation and community service. Mr. Bonds’s success in baseball, and his conviction for obstruction of justice earlier this year, both stemmed in part from his use of a testosterone-based balm famously known as “the cream.”

headline: The Grim Good Cheer of the Irish
text: Dublin

headline: Life Goes On, and On ...
text: A FRIEND calls from her car: “I’m on my way to Cape Cod to scatter my mother’s ashes in the bay, her favorite place.” Another, encountered on the street, mournfully reports that he’s just “planted” his mother. A third e-mails news of her mother’s death with a haunting phrase: “the sledgehammer of fatality.” It feels strange. Why are so many of our mothers dying all at once?

headline: To Stay Great, Never Forget Your Basics
text: This interview with  Geoffrey Canada, president and C.E.O. of the nonprofit  Harlem Children’s Zone, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Panning Salon
text: The record $52.4 billion spree shoppers went on from Black Friday through Cyber Monday was really just for show. Beneath the holiday spending, consumers are grouchy. You can sense their mood just by scanning the posts at consumer-review sites like Trip Advisor and Yelp.

headline: Name Withheld, but Not His Identity

headline: Arrests as Occupy Protest Turns to Church

headline: Alabama’s Second Thoughts
text: Alabama’s stance on its extremist immigration law is shifting from defiance to damage control. Gov. His retreat followed a letter from the state’s attorney general, Luther Strange, to legislative leaders suggesting that they throw out whole sections of the law to make it easier to defend in court.

text: Is marijuana safe and effective for medical purposes? Readers debate the science and politics.

text: NATO airstrikes killed dozens of civilians at sites in Libya examined by The New York Times, but NATO has largely refused to acknowledge or investigate the casualties.

headline: A Financial Crisis Needn’t Be a Noose
text: RECESSIONS after financial crises are long and severe, and the subsequent recoveries are protracted. That is the bold conclusion of “This Time Is Different,” the book by Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff, and it has become conventional wisdom.

headline: Errant NATO Airstrikes in Libya: 13 Cases
