headline: In Strikes on Libya by NATO, an Unspoken Civilian Toll
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — NATO’s seven-month air campaign in Libya, hailed by the alliance and many Libyans for blunting a lethal crackdown by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and helping to push him from power, came with an unrecognized toll: scores of civilian casualties the alliance has long refused to acknowledge or investigate.

headline: American Who Was Jailed in Peru Is Blocked at Airport
text: LIMA, Peru — Lori Berenson, the New Yorker paroled last year after serving more than 15 years in prison here on a terrorism conviction, was blocked from leaving the country for what was to have been her first visit home since her arrest, she said Saturday.

headline: Slapped Wrists at WaMu
text: WHEN Washington Mutual collapsed in 2008, it was the largest bank failure in American history. So the $64.7 million settlement struck last week by federal banking regulators and three former WaMu executives seems like small potatoes indeed.

headline: Holden Withington, Last Living B-52 Designer, Dies at 94
text: On a Friday in 1948, six aeronautical designers from the Boeing Company holed up in a hotel suite in Dayton, Ohio. They stayed put until Monday morning, except for the one who left to visit a hobby shop and returned with balsa wood, glue, carving tools and silver paint.

headline: Concussion Roster Quickly Expands Again
text: In mid-November, Brendan Shanahan, the N.H.L. vice president for player safety, reported that concussions were down almost 50 percent from the same period in 2010, a “significant improvement” he attributed to increased player awareness about the kinds of hits that cause head trauma and the enforcement of new rules against such hits.

headline: Medvedev Urges Reform of Russia’s Political System
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Saturday that the country’s political system had “exhausted itself” and must be changed, and that the Russian authorities should accept that street protests reflected “the mood of our people.”

headline: Rules to Stop Pupil and Teacher From Getting Too Social Online
text: Faced with scandals and complaints involving teachers who misuse social media, school districts across the country are imposing strict new guidelines that ban private conversations between teachers and their students on cellphones and online platforms like Facebook and Twitter.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, December 18
text: Mitt Romney makes his first Sunday show appearance this week, capping off a week in which he has conducted nearly as many interviews as he had since declaring his candidacy. He will stop by “Fox News Sunday” to talk about President Obama, the economy and the battle for the Republican presidential nomination.

text: PALO ALTO, Calif.

headline: Increasingly, Smoking Indoors Is Forbidden at Public Housing
text: AUBURN, Me. — Glenys Cushman was grabbing a quick cigarette here the other day outside her federally subsidized apartment. The rules say no smoking inside or within 25 feet of the entrance, and though she hates having to go outside, she has come to accept it.

headline: Henry Lafont, Pilot, Dies at 91; Fought in Battle of Britain
text: Henry Lafont, a French pilot who took part in a harrowing aerial escape from North Africa to fight for the honor of France after its capitulation to Hitler and who became the last surviving French veteran of the Battle of Britain, died on Dec. 2 in Trémuson, in the Brittany region of France. He was 91.

headline: Making Science Leap From the Page
text: WHEN a college textbook, “Principles of Biology,” comes out from the Nature Publishing Group in January, one place it won’t be is on the shelves of school bookstores.

headline: Kazakhstan Orders Curfew for Oil Town
text: MOSCOW — The president of Kazakhstan declared a state of emergency on Saturday in a town in the western oil-producing region of the country, where striking workers and the police fought the day before, leaving at least 11 people dead.

headline: Paula E. Hyman, Who Sought Rights for Women in Judaism, Dies at 65
text: Paula E. Hyman, a social historian who pioneered the study of women in Jewish life and became an influential advocate for women’s equality in Jewish religious practice, including their ordination as rabbis, died on Thursday at her home in New Haven. She was 65.

headline: Iraq, a War Obama Didn’t Want, Shaped His Foreign Policy
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has made good on his campaign pledge to end the Iraq war, portraying the departure of the last troops as a chance to turn to nation-building at home.

headline: Reframing the Debate Over Using Phones Behind the Wheel
text: For years, policy makers trying to curb distracted driving have compared the problem to drunken driving. The analogy seemed fitting, with drivers weaving down roads and rationalizing behavior that they knew could be deadly.

headline: Prepping for Your Annual Review
text: Q. It’s time for your yearly performance review. You aren’t expecting any big surprises, but you still feel a little nervous. How should you prepare for this meeting?

headline: Reader Comments on Bahrain
text: My Sunday column is about Bahrain, our ally in the Gulf, and the Obama administration’s proposed $53 million arms sale to the regime. As you may know from my last column, I was detained in Bahrain by riot police who also broke the camera and roughed up the video journalist with me. But, truth be told, I also have a good deal of admiration for Bahrain and what the royal family has accomplished here — the soaring living standards, the investment in education, the empowerment of women, the solid middle class. It’s just that when you educate people and create a cosmopolitan nation, you can’t continue to deny them democracy. People want more from life than fine watches and nice houses.

headline: Gunmen Attack Helicopter Carrying Mine Workers in Indonesia
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Gunmen fired at a helicopter carrying workers for the mining giant Freeport-McMoRan shortly after it took off Saturday from a town near the company’s huge gold and copper mine in eastern Indonesia, a police spokesman, Colonel Wachyono, said.

headline: Journey of a Bookworm
text: MY dad was a Marine officer who fought in the Battle of Inchon in the Korean War. He was badly injured and awarded three Purple Hearts and the Bronze Star. I grew up hearing stories about the war and how he continued to fight while hurt. He served as an example of picking yourself up after being knocked down.

headline: Secretary Expects Cuts in Marines and the Navy
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — On a trip to Afghanistan to visit Navy and Marine forces, the secretary of the Navy, Ray Mabus, said Saturday that he expected both branches to reduce their numbers after the Iraq and Afghan wars, and to return to their seafaring roots — although both will have some new areas of focus.

headline: Video Shows Egyptian Soldiers Beating and Shooting at Protesters
text: As our colleague David Kirkpatrick reports from Cairo, Egyptian soldiers chased down and beat unarmed civilians on Saturday, even while the prime minister appointed by the military “was denying in a televised news conference that security forces were using any force.”

headline: Perry Criticizes Competitors Over Earmarks
text: SPENCER, Iowa — Rick Perry accused two rivals of being excessive users of earmarks in the federal budget, describing them as part of the insider culture that he would reject as president.

headline: In the Forecasting Fog, It’s Wise to Slow Down
text: THE American economy certainly isn’t at peak strength. With unemployment at a painfully high 8.6 percent, it can’t be. But unless the economy receives another shocking blow, it isn’t in imminent danger of relapsing into recession.

headline: New England Asks: Who Has Fairest Lobster Trap Tree of All?
text: The tiny towns of Beals and Jonesport, Me., have completed their second annual holiday display: a conical tower of 1,364 lobster traps, 60 feet tall, built to withstand the powerful winds that come off the water. It is the towns’ Christmas tree, made of wire traps plucked from the sea by lobstermen who lend them to the cause.

headline: The Death of a Boy in Bahrain
text: The Op-Ed Columnist Nicholas D. Kristof visits the family of a 14-year-old boy in Bahrain whose death may offer a lesson in American foreign policy.

headline: Sunday: Again?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — What do you “gain” from doing crossword puzzles? Some people feel that puzzles makes their brain sharper, some people do them to increase their vocabulary. Others do crosswords because their commute to work would be deadly boring without them. And, of course, there’s the community: a whole tribe of constructors, editors, bloggers, solvers and commenters who regularly gather both virtually and in real life to challenge and entertain one another.

headline: Oligarchs or Not, Russians Still Flock to Furs

headline: Gingrich Survives Glare to Exploit the Spotlight

headline: Video of Occupy Wall Street Manhattan March

They came to talk about business and manufacturing and, of course, to hit hard on the dominant theme of the campaign trail: unemployment and the struggling economy.

For months, they have criticized him over a gun-trafficking investigation gone awry, with dozens of leaders calling for his resignation. headline: Redskins at Giants: Matchup to Watch

headline: Inflation Conspiracy Theories
text: One response of inflation-fearers to the absence of the inflationary outburst they’ve been waiting for is to reject the numbers, and claim that the BLS is hiding a much higher rate of inflation than the official numbers say. headline: ‘Sherlock Holmes’ and ‘Chipmunks’ Are Sluggish Leaders at Box Office
text: Bells are ringing in Hollywood, but they’re not the Christmas kind. Two big sequels, “Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows” and “Alvin and the Chipmunks: Chipwrecked,” delivered shaky results over the weekend, alarming studios about a continued downturn at the North American box office. “A Game of Shadows” (Warner Brothers) was No. 1 with about $40 million in ticket sales. Analysts had expected that film, which cost $125 million to make, to take in over $50 million; the first installment in this franchise opened with $62 million in 2009. “Chipwrecked” (20th Century Fox) was second, taking in about $23.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office data. That result was 52 percent below the opening weekend total for the last Chipmunks movie in 2009. “Chip-Wrecked” cost an estimated $80 million to make. A variety of factors could have dented interest: sequel fatigue, family film overload, higher ticket prices, a lack of overall momentum at the box office. Elsewhere, Tom Cruise’s “Mission: Impossible — Ghost Protocol” (Paramount) was a powerful third, taking in about $13 million in limited release on 425 Imax screens. That result set an Imax record and positioned “Ghost Protocol” as a potential blockbuster and career rebound for Mr. Cruise as it expands nationwide on Wednesday. “New Year’s Eve” (Warner) was fourth with about $7.4 million in ticket sales, lifting its two-week total to $24.8 million. “The Sitter” (Fox) was fifth, taking in an estimated $4.4 million for a two-week total of $17.7 million.

text: MOSCOW — Violence between striking workers and the authorities in western Kazakhstan spread over the weekend, bringing the death toll to 14, the country’s general prosecutor announced on Sunday.

headline: Don’t Scowl, Beethoven, You’re Loved
text: If we are to believe the Beethoven mythology, which is based mostly on his letters and reports from his inner circle, Beethoven had an unshakeable sense of his own importance. Unlike Mozart and Haydn he refused to defer to nobility, asserting that a composer is of greater value, in the cosmic scheme of things, than a prince. And though he had patrons among the aristocracy, he revered Napoleon, their nemesis, and dedicated his Third Symphony, the “Eroica” (“Heroic”) to him, only to remove the dedication when Napoleon crowned himself emperor.

headline: A New York Stop for Cate Blanchett, Hugo Weaving and ‘Uncle Vanya’
text: New Yorkers will have a chance to see the Sydney Theater Company’s celebrated production of “Uncle Vanya” with Cate Blanchett and Hugo Weaving next summer. The production, which received rave reviews when it appeared last August at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, will be presented at City Center from July 19 through July 28 as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, a festival spokeswoman, Eileen McMahon, said. Ms. Blanchett plays Yelena, and Mr. Weaving plays Astrov in the farcical-yet-heartbreaking production, which was staged by the Hungarian director Tamas Ascher. Ms. Blanchett’s husband, Andrew Upton, provided the actors a new English translation of Chekov’s in 1897 play in Russian.

headline: Gingrich Continues His Crusade Against Activist Judges
text: Newt Gingrich continued his crusade against activist judges Sunday, saying he would consider sending the Capitol Police or a United States Marshal to subpoena any federal judge who issued an opinion he thought was out of sync with American values. He would then encourage Congress to impeach the judge.

headline: Remembering the Words of Vaclav Havel
text: Among the tributes coming in after the death of Vaclav Havel, the playwright who helped found the Czech Republic and was its president for a decade, are several from the theater world. “There is less morality in politics with his death,” Natalia Koliada, a co-founder of the Belarus Free Theater, which had a supporter in Mr. Havel, wrote on her Twitter feed. (The company’s play “Being Harold Pinter” made Ben Brantley’s list of the best shows of 2011.) The Public Theater, which produced the American premieres of several of Mr. Havel’s plays, wrote on Twitter: “We are saddened by the death of Vaclav Havel.”

headline: Egypt News Media Clash Over Cause of Violence
text: CAIRO — On the third day of clashes between security forces and protesters in the center of the capital, a new battle broke out Sunday between Egypt’s state-run and independent media over whom to blame for the violence.

text: Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y., and Beth Palmer of Chevy Chase, Md., won the women’s teams and women’s pairs at the SportAccord World Mind Games in Beijing last week. They were particularly proud of their defense in the diagramed deal.

headline: Playoffs? Yes, Giants Still Control Their Playoff Chances
text: The Giants still control their playoff chances. If they beat the Jets on Saturday and the Cowboys in the regular-season finale, they will advance to the postseason.

headline: Fallen Opera Singer Said to Be Recovering
text: Wendy White, the mezzo-soprano injured when she fell during a performance at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, has been released from a hospital and is recuperating at home, a spokesman for the opera, Peter Clark, said Sunday. Ms. White sustained bruises in a fall from a platform eight feet above the stage, he said. It remains unclear when she will be well enough to perform again. The accident happened during Act III of a performance of Gounod’s “Faust.” Ms. White, in the role of Marthe, was walking onto a platform from a staircase behind René Pape, who was playing Méphistophélès, when a hinge securing a piece of plywood under her broke. After a half-hour break the show went on with an understudy. Ms. White is a Met stalwart who has made more than 500 appearances with the company since her 1989 debut as Flora in “La Traviata.”

headline: Gruesome and Gory, a Chaotic Fairy Tale Gone Terribly Awry
text: Don’t let the presence of toy instruments in H. K. Gruber’s “Frankenstein!!” fool you. Mr. Gruber calls the work “a pan-demonium for chansonnier and orchestra after children’s rhymes by H. C. Artmann,” but lurid and bloody, these are fairy tales for adults, closer to Grimm than to Disney.

headline: Silent Screams and Fierce Walks, as Music Sets the Scene for Dance
text: It’s a rarity to come across live music in a contemporary dance setting, but when it happens, the result is usually something more than pleasant. Whether it’s made to fit the dance or not, the presence of musicians invariably deepens the texture of choreography, lending a richer hue. Then there are those instances when the relationship adds up to little more than a couple sharing a room but sleeping in separate beds.

headline: South Korea Urges Japan to Compensate Former Sex Slaves
text: TOKYO — President Lee Myung-bak of South Korea used what was supposed to be a routine visit to Japan on Sunday to press for compensation for Korean women who were forced to work as prostitutes by the Japanese military during World War II. He called the issue a “burden” on relations between the two nations.

headline: Lightsaber Rattling in the Online Galaxy
text: Over the last third of a century no new fiction has engaged the popular imagination and become as thoroughly essential an element of mass culture as “Star Wars.” There can’t be many people anywhere who wouldn’t at least recognize a lightsaber or Darth Vader.

headline: Forced Drama, Product Placement and Star Power
text: It has been a bloated, overwrought embarrassment. It has been full of laughably excessive production numbers and clumsily manufactured drama. It may have set records for clichéd sound bites, insipid banter and shameless product placement.

headline: Just Wait Until You See What’s on the Menu
text: From my seat on the aisle in the orchestra section at the Metropolitan Opera House I saw only one family get up and leave during the third act of Engelbert Humperdinck’s “Hansel and Gretel” at its season premiere on Friday night. That seemed noteworthy because onstage, in a kitchen filled with lost children baked into gingerbread, a frumpy, gluttonous witch was compelling a little girl to help fatten her brother for the oven, between unsubtle hints that the girl was destined for the same fate.

headline: For a Big Birthday, Leading Three Groups a Night
text: Wadada Leo Smith was a force in motion during the early stretch of his concert at Roulette in Brooklyn on Friday night. Stalking the stage, busily directing the output of his Golden Sextet, he gave off an air of restless intent. The exceptions mostly came when he played his trumpet, projecting in a hard, lustrous tone. In those moments he rooted himself: shoulders squared, the bell of his horn pointing either straight ahead or toward the floor. At every juncture he seemed to mean business.

headline: Scrutiny for a Maestro and a Mezzo
text: Through no doing of the Ensemble ACJW, its concert on Friday night at Zankel Hall took on a newsier aspect than might have been anticipated. Just a couple of weeks earlier the evening’s conductor, the young Spanish maestro Pablo Heras-Casado, still relatively unknown in New York, had been named principal conductor of the Orchestra of St. Luke’s, a major fixture in the city’s musical ecosystem.

headline: Relentless Waves of Sound, Reined by Drops of Thundering Bass
text: Late in its two-plus-hour set at Madison Square Garden on Friday night Swedish House Mafia was playing its second Coldplay remix in a row, “Every Teardrop Is a Waterfall” following “Fix You,” and most of the people in the sold-out arena were bopping, as they’d been all night. The seat next to me had been occupied by at least four different people, all of whom had danced in and then danced onward.

headline: Confection Suite: Homage to the Queen of Salsa
text: At the Apollo Theater on Saturday afternoon Goya Foods provided samples, as if the lobby were a supermarket. There was free coffee and wafers with dulce de leche filling. One reliable purveyor of Latino products, promoting its brand, was sponsoring another: Ballet Hispanico.

headline: New York Public Library Is in Talks to Sell Space
text: The New York Public Library is negotiating to sell five floors at 188 Madison Avenue, the former B. Altman department store at 34th Street. The building is also home to the Science, Industry and Business Library, which is to remain there. The library would not disclose the potential price or buyer, pending a conclusion of the deal, which is expected early in the new year. Proceeds are expected to go toward a plan to transform the library’s main Fifth Avenue site into a combined research and circulating library. The space in the B. Altman building includes two floors that the library has leased out since it bought about 15 percent of the building in 1993. The other floors are used for administration; staff members there will move elsewhere. The B. Altman building also houses the City University of New York Graduate Center and the Oxford University Press.

headline: Etta James Is Terminally Ill
text: Etta James, the seminal R&B singer, is terminally ill, according to her doctor, Elaine James  (who is not related to Etta James). Dr. James told The Press-Enterprise in Riverside, Calif., that family members were told two weeks ago that Ms. James’s chronic leukemia could not be cured. “I am Southern and Christian and would just ask for the prayers of her fans and friends,” Dr. James said. “They know she’s been sick, but not how sick.” Etta James, 73, has been among the most celebrated American blues singers for decades, recording enduring hits like “At Last,” “Tell Mama” and “I’d Rather Go Blind.” She was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1993. Her career was also influenced by drug addiction, troubled love relationships and health and legal problems. In 2010 she was hospitalized for a staph infection, and it became public that she was suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, and that she had been treated for dependence on painkillers. Dr. James has cared for Etta James, above, at her home in Riverside since March 2010, and she made the statements last week outside a hearing over control of Ms. James’s $1 million estate. Donato James, her son, has been fighting in court with her husband, Artis Mills, over who will be named the estate’s conservator.

headline: Jacob’s Pillow Announces Its Summer Slate
text: Jacob’s Pillow will put on a weeklong homage to the choreography of its founder, Ted Shawn, as part of an unusual and ambitious lineup for its 80th summer dance festival in Becket, Mass. The rotating cast for the series of performances in honor of Shawn starting on July 11 will include about 20 prominent male dancers, among them Arthur Mitchell of the Dance Theater of Harlem, the tap-dance specialist Jason Samuels Smith and the former New York City Ballet principal Jock Soto. The schedule for the festival, to run from June 16 to Aug. 26, was released on Sunday. Among the other highlights of this year’s festival are a rare United States performance by the Hong Kong Ballet of Kinsun Chan’s “Black on Black”; a world premiere by the Swedish choreographer and dancer Pontus Lidberg, performed by Morphoses; and a collaboration between Jonah Bokaer and David Hallberg. This year Ella Baff, the executive and artistic director of Jacob’s Pillow, decided to break with that institution’s tradition of offering mostly new works. She programmed repeat performances of three popular dances from past festivals: Tero Saarinen’s Shaker-inspired “Borrowed Light” from 2006, Crystal Pite’s “Dark Matters” from last summer and Doug Elkins’s “Fräulein Maria” from 2009. “I hope to encourage the public to consider more contemporary dance works as classics, to be revisited in the same way that we enjoy and deepen our appreciation for classic works of music, theater and the visual arts,” Ms. Baff said in a statement. (Below, Shawn as the biblical Jacob on Pillow Rock.)

headline: Good Minus God
text: I was heartened to learn recently that atheists are no longer the most reviled group in the United States: according to the political scientists Robert Putnam and David Campbell, we’ve been overtaken by the Tea Party.  But even as I was high-fiving my fellow apostates (“We’re number two!  We’re number two!”), I was wondering anew: why do so many people dislike atheists?

headline: Monday: Where Folks Get Into Hot Water
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Today’s constructor, Richard Chisholm, has not been seen around these parts for almost a year, but he’s actually a fairly prolific puzzle maker. Mr. Chisholm has had crosswords published in The New York Times on all days of the week except for those most difficult days, Friday and Saturday. Come on, Mr. Chisholm; hit for the cycle already. Not that that makes a good constructor; hitting for the cycle is not really any more important than producing a puzzle that happens to be a pangram. It would just be fun to add another constructor to the list of those who have already done so.

headline: Back to Earth: Giants Go Flat, Imperiling Playoff Bid
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — A year ago, Justin Tuck roused the Giants from a first-half slumber against the Jacksonville Jaguars with a stirring halftime speech. Tuck, the team’s defensive captain, came into the locker room, ranted about how the Jaguars were disrespecting the Giants in their own home and challenged everyone to rise up. It was fiery and ferocious, teammates said, and the Giants responded, rallying from an 11-point deficit to win by 4.

headline: The Queen of Cable TV
text: Early in Bonnie Hammer’s first stint running a cable network, she knew something was wrong. The SciFi channel was emerging as a destination for fans of the genre, largely on her strategy of reviving the mini-series.

headline: The Road From Poverty to Health
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: Abortions for Rape Victims
text: To the Editor:

headline: Learning From the Military
text: To the Editor:

headline: Apple App Makers on Edge for Holidays
text: On Christmas morning, millions of people will unwrap new iPads, iPhones and iPod Touches — and immediately start downloading games and other applications for them. It is the biggest day of the year for app sales, which can mean big money for developers.

headline: Don’t Tax the Rich. Tax Inequality Itself.
text: THE progressive reformer and eminent jurist Louis D. Brandeis once said, “We may have democracy, or we may have wealth concentrated in the hands of a few, but we cannot have both.” Brandeis lived at a time when enormous disparities between the rich and the poor led to violent labor unrest and ultimately to a reform movement.

headline: ‘Asuka’
text: Ballet Hispanico gave the premiere of a work based on the singer Celia Cruz.

headline: Reliving the Best (and Worst) Ads of 2011
text: MANY of the best advertisements of 2011 had something in common: celebrities, whether in front of the camera or behind it.

headline: At an Iowa Church, Perry Takes On the Role of Faith in Government
text: CHARLES CITY, Iowa — First Wesleyan Church is about as far away as you can imagine from the brightly-lit debate halls and smart-alecky pundits who have bedeviled Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on his long slide from Republican presidential frontrunner.

headline: Des Moines Register Endorsement Has a Mixed Predictive Track Record
text: A couple of weeks ago we looked at the track record of candidates endorsed by The Union Leader of New Hampshire, and found that they had historically performed quite strongly. Their actual vote share in the New Hampshire primary exceeded their standing in the polls at the time the endorsement was made by about 11 points on average.

headline: A Sequence That Summed Up the Giants
text: A capsule look at the Giants’ 23-10 loss to the Redskins on Sunday:

headline: Giants Replay: Week 15
text: The Redskins hurt the Giants and their playoff hopes with a dominating 23-10 victory.

headline: Cesária Évora, Singer From Cape Verde, Dies at 70
text: Cesária Évora, who brought the music of the tiny Cape Verde islands off Senegal to a worldwide audience, died on Saturday in Mindelo, on São Vicente, her native island in Cape Verde. She was 70.

headline: Garden’s Roar Sounds Genuine as Retooled Knicks Work Out
text: The lights dimmed just before noon Sunday at the newly remodeled Madison Square Garden, and 10,500 Knicks fans, eager to see their newly remodeled team after the long N.B.A. lockout, began to roar.

headline: Bumbling Jets Cannot Contend With the Eagles
text: PHILADELPHIA — Mark Sanchez lay face down on the grass early in the second quarter Sunday, his body twisted in a position as uncomfortable as the Jets’ day at Lincoln Financial Field. He had just fumbled deep in Jets territory, facilitating a 28-point first-half outburst by the Philadelphia Eagles, and for a few seconds he remained on his stomach, as if reluctant to watch any more of what deteriorated into a grisly and comprehensive defeat.

headline: Mitt Romney’s Lucrative Continuing Relationship
text: Mitt Romney stepped down as the head of Bain Capital in 1999, but he received a share of the profits in 22 new funds created by the firm during the next 10 years. In that time, the company’s assets under management grew 20-fold.

headline: A New Children’s Book Parodies a Beloved Classic
text: Was 2011 the year of the irreverent picture book?

headline: Avoiding the Trap of Big-Time, Big-Money Sports
text: At the conclusion of a program to celebrate his return to Union Theological Seminary in Manhattan last week, the Rev. James A. Forbes Jr. spoke about an initiative to heal the spirit of America. Specifically, Forbes, who was the senior minister at Riverside Church for 18 years, called for a great awakening.

headline: Bonnie Prudden, 97, Dies; Promoted Fitness for TV Generation
text: Bonnie Prudden, whose alarm over the flabbiness of American children propelled her to become one of the most visible postwar champions of physical fitness, died on Dec. 11 at her home in Tucson. She was 97.

headline: Digital Data on Patients Raises Risk of Breaches
text: One afternoon last spring, Micky Tripathi received a panicked call from an employee. Someone had broken into his car and stolen his briefcase and company laptop along with it.

headline: Messi Not Ready to Pass the Torch
text: It is tempting to describe this year’s FIFA Club World Cup final as men against boys — so completely and easily did Barcelona outplay the Brazilian team Santos on Sunday night in Yokohama, Japan.

headline: Military Clashes with Protesters for Third Day
text: Egypt’s ruling military and the protesters who demand they immediately step down battled for a third day in the streets on Sunday.

headline: A Comic Distributes Himself
text: Louis C. K. is something of a pirate in the entertainment world, a man who has ignored propriety on his way to building a huge comic franchise. So it’s odd to see him put one of his shows for sale on the Web and politely ask fans not to rip him off.

headline: Bob Brookmeyer, Jazz Musician and Educator, Dies at 81
text: Bob Brookmeyer, who left a distinctive mark on jazz as a musician, composer, arranger and educator whose students included many of today’s leading jazz arrangers and bandleaders, died on Thursday in New London, N.H., four days before his 82nd birthday.

headline: Iraq After the U.S. Military Withdrawal
text: A look at Baghdad, Iraqi governance and regional disputes after the U.S. military withdrawal.

headline: News From the Advertising Industry
text: Accounts

headline: Aided by Amnesty Clause, Knicks Are to Sign Davis
text: Baron Davis is set to join the Knicks, continuing their rapid makeover. Davis, 32, was cut last week by the Cleveland Cavaliers, who used the N.B.A.’s amnesty clause to remove the final two years and $28.7 million of his contract from the salary cap. His Knicks contract will be for one year and $2.5 million, according to Sports Illustrated.

headline: New Digital Leader at Rodale
text: While holiday shoppers are busy buying iPads, Kindles and other e-readers, the magazine publisher Rodale is snapping up one of the executives behind Nook, Barnes & Noble’s line of e-readers.

headline: More Low-Key Than His Predecessor, NBC Sports Chief Still Aims High
text: For Mark Lazarus, the chairman of the NBC Sports Group, quail hunting offers a consuming escape — walking through fields with his sons, friends or colleagues, along with the pointers that flush the birds into the sky. The action reminds him of a vigorous round of golf rather than sitting in a blind calling for ducks.

headline: 10 Years of Assessing Students With Scientific Exactitude
text: In the last decade, we have emerged from the Education Stone Age. No longer must we rely on primitive tools like teachers and principals to assess children’s academic progress. Thanks to the best education minds in Washington, Albany and Lower Manhattan, we now have finely calibrated state tests aligned with the highest academic standards. What follows is a look back at New York’s long march to a new age of accountability.

headline: Instability a New Fear for Investors in Russia
text: MOSCOW — The street protests in Moscow that have raised the prospect of deep political reforms have had the opposite effect on the country’s stock exchange: it has plummeted faster than any other major equity market in the world over the last two weeks.

headline: Fast-Food Outlet Stirs Concerns in a Mecca of Healthy Living
text: LOMA LINDA, Calif. — In this small city, home to a large Seventh-day Adventist community, the average lifespan goes well past 80, and it has one of the highest rates of longevity in the world according to some estimates.

headline: Penalty Flags for Jets; White Flag on Season?
text: A capsule look at the Jets’ 45-19 loss to the Eagles on Sunday:

headline: After a Brother’s Death, Moving Into the Empty Space
text: NORTHFIELD, N.J. — This was to be the year that the Brenner brothers, Casey and Ryan, would receive their varsity football letters together. But on the night of the Mainland Regional High School team banquet, Ryan dressed alone for the event in his older brother’s bedroom, where he moved after Casey died in a car accident last summer.

headline: Found and Lost
text: One year has passed since the police went looking for a missing woman, Shannan Gilbert, in the marshy thickets of a barrier island off Long Island’s South Shore. They didn’t find her, but they stumbled on something baffling and horrifying: evidence of an unnoticed, uncaught serial killer.

headline: Iranian TV Airs Video It Claims Is of U.S. Spy
text: Iranian state television broadcast video images on Sunday of a man who it said was a captured American spy sent to infiltrate Iran’s intelligence services.

headline: Help for Homeless Veterans
text: The Department of Veterans Affairs and Housing and Urban Development have announced modest but real progress in the effort to house homeless veterans. A count of people living in shelters and on the street in 400 communities on one night in January found 12 percent fewer veterans than at the same time last year — 67,495, compared with 76,329 in 2010. The percentage of homeless veterans living in shelters and transitional housing was also slightly better, up by 2 percent.

headline: The Trouble With That Revolving Door
text: Last week, an inside-the-Beltway newsletter, First Street, published a unique top-ten list. It reveals which former members of Congress are among the most important Washington lobbyists.

headline: States of Conflict: A Final Update
text: A VERSION of this chart has been appearing in the Op-Ed pages every few months for eight years. The first was published eight months after the invasion of Iraq, and data from the conflicts in Afghanistan and Pakistan were added in more recent years. Gains have been made in these three countries, but violence persists and peace is by no means assured. Nonetheless, with the end of the war in Iraq officially announced last week, this will be the last of the series.

headline: Are Presidential Pardons Fair?
text: Some critics consider the selection process too subjective and opaque. How should presidents decide whom to pardon?

headline: A Melding of the Artist’s Politics and the Politician’s Art
text: With Vaclav Havel, the Czech author and playwright, it is impossible to separate the artist’s politics from the politician’s art. He was both a witness and a communicant, repeatedly exploring, in the words of the title of one of his essays, “the power of the powerless.”

headline: Channel’s Swift Rise Attracts Ads and Envy
text: Last year, the History channel had a growth spurt, gaining hundreds of thousands of viewers while most of its competitors struggled to grow at all. This year, even more remarkably, the channel did it again.

headline: Tebow and Broncos Have No Comeback for Patriots
text: DENVER — At a busy shopping strip Saturday afternoon, there was a man dressed as a robot meant to entertain and lure frantic Christmas shoppers. At one point, as a few men strolled by, the robot yelled, “Now, I’ll Tebow for you!” and he dropped to one knee and lowered his head in an imitation of the now well-known pose of the quarterback who has captivated the N.F.L. this season. The men — a few of them wearing Patriots jerseys — laughed and kept moving. They, after all, have seen pretenders before.

headline: Overhaul Brings in Baron Davis
text: Baron Davis is set to join the Knicks, continuing a rapid makeover made possible by the N.B.A.’s new amnesty provision.

headline: As Gingrich’s Star Rises, So Do His Party’s Concerns
text: WASHINGTON — From the House that Newt Gingrich once ran through the Washington establishment to state capitals across the nation, some Republicans are going public with their concerns that Mr. Gingrich would be a weak general election candidate and a drag on the party’s fortunes if he won the presidential nomination.

headline: Making a List, and Taking It to the Pawnshop
text: Children in San Mateo, Calif., whispered their wish lists to Santa Claus this weekend at Best Collateral, a pawnshop in a strip mall about 20 miles south of San Francisco.

headline: Gingrich and Romney Tack Right, but Leave a Path Back to the Middle
text: WASHINGTON — Through the long march of 2011 debates ending last week, Republican presidential candidates have leaned right — so far right, Democrats hope, that the ultimate nominee will fall next November.

headline: Lessons of the Deepwater Horizon
text: The latest investigative report on the Deepwater Horizon disaster in the Gulf of Mexico, released Wednesday, is an important reminder of industry’s past carelessness and a summons to vigilance in the future. It could not have been more timely, coming just as the Interior Department was concluding its first auction of new drilling leases in the gulf since the spill.

headline: She’s Warm, Easy to Talk to, and a Source of Terror for Private-School Parents
text: Elisabeth Krents loves eating hot fudge sundaes, reading Wilkie Collins novels and trying, often unsuccessfully, to grow tomatoes.

headline: Rules Stretched as Green Cards Go to Investors
text: Affluent foreigners are rushing to take advantage of a federal immigration program that offers them the chance to obtain a green card in return for investing in construction projects in the United States. With credit tight, the program has unexpectedly turned into a mainstay for the financing of these projects in New York, California, Texas and other states.

headline: Will China Break?
text: Consider the following picture: Recent growth has relied on a huge construction boom fueled by surging real estate prices, and exhibiting all the classic signs of a bubble. There was rapid growth in credit — with much of that growth taking place not through traditional banking but rather through unregulated “shadow banking” neither subject to government supervision nor backed by government guarantees. Now the bubble is bursting — and there are real reasons to fear financial and economic crisis.

headline: A Stranger at the Door
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: De Blasio Backs Wage Bill in a Challenge to Quinn
text: With the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, courting business leaders as she prepares to run for mayor, Bill de Blasio, the public advocate and one of her chief rivals, has thrown his support behind a much-disputed bill that would increase wages for workers in city-subsidized development projects — a move that could force Ms. Quinn to take a position on the issue.

headline: A Fraction of a Tax Cut
text: If you looked quickly at what the Senate did on Saturday, it seemed as if it agreed to President Obama’s proposal for short-term middle-class relief by extending the payroll tax cut and unemployment insurance. In fact, that’s not quite what happened.

headline: Struggling to Catch Up, a Giants Rookie Defensive Back Is Finally Benched
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — This has not been the sort of rookie season that Prince Amukamara envisioned when the Giants selected him in the first round of the draft in April.

headline: Disruptions: Wearing Your Computer on Your Sleeve
text: Technology often has a way of fixing the problems it creates. Here’s one that needs solving.

headline: Lottery Numbers
G.O.P. Contests Near, and the Pace Picks Up
text: With voting to begin in Iowa nine days after Christmas, the Republican presidential contest has become intense and frenetic. The week ahead will feature a dizzying amount of travel, wall-to-wall campaign advertising in the early-voting states and stump speeches delivered with new intensity.

headline: Along a Block in Brooklyn, Wary Residents Ponder the Murder of an Officer
text: For much of the past week, police officers have searched a block of Pine Street in Brooklyn for the bullet that killed Officer Peter J. Figoski. They have even examined tree branches and the upper reaches of nearby two-family homes, from a cherry picker. Yet the slug seems to have disappeared.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Economic Reports This Week
text: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for November (Tuesday); sales of existing homes for November (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, third-quarter gross domestic product (final), the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for November, and leading economic indicators for November (Thursday); durable goods for November, personal income and spending for November, and sales of new homes for November (Friday).

headline: Kim Jong-il, Dictator Who Turned North Korea Into a Nuclear State, Dies
text: Called the “Dear Leader” by his people, Kim Jong-il presided with an iron hand over a country he kept on the edge of starvation and collapse, fostering perhaps the last personality cult in the Communist world even as he banished citizens deemed disloyal to gulags or sent assassins after defectors.

headline: In a Study, Judges Express a Bleak View of Lawyers Representing Immigrants
text: They are often poorly prepared or make incoherent arguments in court. Some fail to present key evidence or witnesses. Others simply do not show up.

headline: Private Investment Rounds Weaken I.P.O.’s
text: Facebook’s initial public offering will grab plenty of headlines in 2012. But as Zynga’s tepid debut last week shows, multiple private investment rounds and the ability to trade shares before going public mean slim pickings when public market investors finally get their chance to own Silicon Valley’s emerging heavyweights. That is one reason the average I.P.O. this year has wound up trading about 10 percent below its offer price.

headline: Letter on Living Wage in New York City
text: Bill de Blasio, Public Advocate for New York City, writes in support of passing a Living Wage bill for the city’s economic development projects.

headline: For Election Year, MTV Drops ‘Choose or Lose’ Slogan
text: After nearly 20 years of “Choose or Lose,” MTV is changing the name of its election season campaign.

headline: Buyout Profits Keep Flowing to Romney
text: Almost 13 years ago, Mitt Romney left Bain Capital, the successful private equity firm he had helped start, and moved to Utah to rescue the Salt Lake City Olympic Games and begin a second career in public life.

headline: Jets Replay: Week 15
text: A look at the Jets’ 45-19 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles.

headline: Even at 6-8, Philadelphia Keeps Alive Its Hope of Winning the N.F.C. East
text: PHILADELPHIA — Judging from the empty seats at Lincoln Financial Field, there is a vacancy of hope among many Eagles fans near the end of this maddening season.

headline: Pakistani Crisis Prompts Leader to Race Home
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A tense showdown between Pakistan’s powerful army and its besieged civilian government brought President Asif Ali Zardari hurrying back from Dubai early on Monday, after weeks of growing concerns by his supporters that the military has been moving to strengthen its role in the country’s governance.

headline: Air Force Drone Operators Report High Levels of Stress
text: WASHINGTON — Nearly half the operators of drone aircraft have high levels of job-related stress, mostly linked to long and erratic work hours because of a tremendous increase in the use of the aircraft, the Air Force said in a new study.

headline: Private Torment Trumps Terrorism
text: No government mole was unmasked, and the C.I.A. officer Carrie Mathison (Claire Danes) was not vindicated. The finale of “Homeland” wasn’t entirely satisfying, but it did end with a jolt. Sgt. Nicholas Brody (Damian Lewis) failed to blow himself up; it was Carrie who ended up on a hospital bed, twitching under a round of electroshock treatment.

headline: Corrections: December 19
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/19/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/19/2011

headline: Sports Replay: Dec. 18
text: The day in sports, featuring pro football, including two firsts, pro basketball and women’s handball in Brazil.

headline: Word of the Day | frantic
text: frantic •\ˈfran-tik\• adjective

headline: After Yearlong Competition, Mayor Is Said to Pick Cornell for Science School
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg plans to announce on Monday that he has chosen Cornell University to create a new science graduate school on Roosevelt Island, capping an intense yearlong competition in his ambitious bid to spur a boom in New York City’s high-tech sector.

headline: Exonerated of Murder, Texan Seeks Inquiry on Prosecutor
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — A Texas man wrongfully convicted in 1987 of murdering his wife is scheduled to be officially exonerated on Monday.

headline: Many in U.S. Are Arrested by Age 23, Study Finds
text: By age 23, almost a third of Americans have been arrested for a crime, according to a new study that researchers say is a measure of growing exposure to the criminal justice system in everyday life.

headline: M.I.T. Expands Its Free Online Courses
text: While students at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology pay thousands of dollars for courses, the university will announce a new program on Monday allowing anyone anywhere to take M.I.T. courses online free of charge — and for the first time earn official certificates for demonstrating mastery of the subjects taught.

headline: Little to Show for Strong Work Ethic and a Degree
text: Abdulla Chowdhury was telling the story of how he took his young daughter shopping recently for a winter coat, and the memory was enough to make him bury his head in his hands. In his wallet had been a $20 bill. On the coat rack, many options sure to please his daughter. But the cheapest coat cost $50. So the money stayed in his pocket and the coat remained on the rack. The moment crystallized one of Mr. Chowdhury’s worst fears: his inability to provide for his two children the way his parents had provided for him.

headline: Monday Matchup: Steelers at 49ers
text: Steelers at 49ers, 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: 49ers by 3

headline: Kim Jong-il, North Korean Dictator, Dies
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader who realized his family’s dream of turning his starving, isolated country into a nuclear-weapons power even as it sank further into despotism, died on Saturday of a heart attack while traveling on his train, according to an announcement Monday by the country’s state-run media.

headline: On North Korean State Television, News of the Leader’s Death and Floods of Tears
text: Updated | 12:55 p.m. As our colleagues Choe Sang-hun and David Sanger report, Kim Jong-il, the mysterious and mercurial dictator of North Korea, has died. The news rippled across the globe Sunday night after the country’s official news media proclaimed the leader dead by way of a black-clad television announcer who appeared to be holding back tears.

headline: Coming to Amritsar, the Pod Car
text: Bangalore, Kolkata and Delhi may have the Metro, but Amritsar will soon have the Pod.

headline: Kim’s Death Inspires Worries and Anxiety
text: LONDON — The death of Kim Jong-il provoked uncertainty, anxiety and calls for a peaceful succession on Monday as governments within the region and beyond awaited some signal from North Korea about its nuclear intentions and the prospects, if any, for a new relationship with the world beyond its borders.

headline: North Korea’s Elusive Leader
text: Called the “Dear Leader” by his people, Kim Jong-il, the son of North Korea’s founder, remained an unknowable figure.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 19, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Dec. 19, 1997 | The Film ‘Titanic’ Premieres
text: On Dec. 19, 1997, James Cameron’s $200 million epic “Titanic” opened in American theaters. The film went on to gross more than $1.8 billion worldwide, a record that stood until 2010, when Mr. Cameron’s “Avatar” surpassed it.

headline: An Urbanizing India Faces Natural Disaster Risk
text: The number of people exposed to natural disasters is expected to more than double to 1.5 billion by 2050, with 200 million of them in India, because of rapid urbanization and the extreme weather stemming from climate change, according to the World Bank.

headline: Saudi Prince Invests $300 Million in Twitter

headline: As Violence Continues, Egyptian General Blames Protesters
text: CAIRO — After four days of street fighting with protesters that has left 13 people dead, Egypt’s military rulers faced calls on Monday from the United States, the United Nations and a newly united front of Islamist and liberal political leaders to stop the violence.

headline: Dining During a Roman Holiday
text: Contrary to popular belief, visitors to Rome during the winter holidays are not doomed to eat in tourist traps or at McDonald’s. Many worthy restaurants throughout the city will be open during Christmas and New Year’s, albeit on abbreviated schedules. To handle the busy holiday season, many restaurants offer large, prix fixe tasting menus and, with a bit of planning, one can eat very well, for a price.

headline: Why Playoff Tiebreaker Favors  Jets Over Bengals
text: As most Jets fans know by now, the Jets will almost certainly make the playoffs if they win their last two games and finish 10-6. Cincinnati is the only other playoff contender that could finish 10-6, but the Jets would most likely win the fourth tiebreaker, strength of victory. Those odds only increased when San Diego defeated Baltimore on Sunday night. Here is how it would break down.

headline: For Green Groups, a Shift in Tactics
text: In The Times’s Sunday Review section, I wrote about the generational leadership change that big environmental groups are undergoing and how it is affecting their strategies. Several leaders and observers I interviewed noted that in an Occupy Wall Street era, some people have little patience for the notion of courting corporations and policy makers to seek their cooperation. They want to apply direct pressure.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 19
text: Bonnie Hammer’s attention to detail and programming instincts at NBCUniversal networks like USA has made her possibly the “most important executive” in cable television, Bill Carter writes, and a critical piece of Comcast’s takeover of the company last year. In her career, she identified Bob Vila as a host, taught Vince McMahon how to build story arcs into wrestling and made USA a powerhouse with shows like “Royal Pains” and “Burn Notice.” Yet the job she really wanted – turning out NBC’s dismal primetime – somehow has escaped her. Mr. Carter writes:

headline: Paul Moves Into Lead in Iowa Forecast
text: Our Iowa forecasts, which are designed to be quite aggressive, have had a big reaction to the new Public Policy Polling survey published late Sunday evening. The poll showed Newt Gingrich’s support slipping badly in Iowa and Ron Paul moving into the lead.

headline: Ad Spending Slowed to a Crawl in the 3rd Quarter, Report Finds
text: Like traffic on the way to the beach on a summer Friday afternoon, advertising spending in the third quarter barely moved, according to a report to be released on Monday morning.

headline: Daily Report: An Apps Holiday
text: People who leave their Christmas shopping for the final hours are not the only ones feeling anxious these days. Developers of apps for Apple products are also stressed out, Jenna Wortham reports in Monday’s New York Times.

headline: Last-Minute Tinkering, Then Into the Oscar Race

The film was a late entrant in the Oscar race, and subject to high speculation because of it, though a review embargo was in effect until yesterday. (David Denby didn’t jump the gun on “the Daldry.”)

headline: Young Heir Faces Uncertain Transition in North Korea
text: TOKYO — With the abrupt death of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, the fate of his isolated, nuclear-armed regime has dropped into the hands of his youngest son, Kim Jong-un, who is such an unknown that the world did not even know for sure what he looked like until last year.

headline: Despite Defeat, Tebow Is Playing Better
text: When he was winning in dramatic fashion, Tim Tebow was often criticized for his poor statistical performances. In defeat on Sunday, he played one of his better games, statistically and otherwise, with 2 touchdowns and 93 yards on the ground, and 194 passing yards.

headline: Communication Tools That Can Lead to Trouble
text: The Times reports that many educators, school boards and districts -- including the city's Department of Education -- are struggling to find a  balance to protect students from inappropriate behavior by the grown-ups in their lives using Facebook, Twitter and texting, while also allowing teachers enough freedom to take advantage of the social media tools that, after all, are how children communicate nowadays.

headline: China Exerts Influence Nurtured Over Decades
text: BEIJING — China, North Korea’s foremost ally, appears to be moving quickly to try to ensure stability in a crippled and isolated nation now facing a leadership transition fraught with dangers.

headline: Bi-Lo to Pay $9.50 a Share for Winn-Dixie

headline: Monday Reading: Save Your Elite Flier Status While You Can
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Irish Competitiveness (Wonkish)
text: More abut Ireland: one of the reasons it has been touted as a great success story for austerity is the fact that unit labor costs have fallen sharply, suggesting that Ireland is well along in the process of “internal devaluation”.

headline: The Plight of China’s Favored Sons
text: ZHUHAI, China — In the rural Chinese town where Li Yiming grew up, the gossip mill starts to turn if a man is still single at 25. As he nears this milestone, the 23-year-old Li, an assembly-line worker in the coastal city of Zhuhai, is despondent. He knows he’ll never earn enough at any factory to win the approval of his girlfriend’s parents.

headline: The Coming War for the Social Workplace
text: The hard-nosed competition for billions in corporate software spending is heading for an improbable showdown: Will the boss “like” that product prototyping cost projection?

headline: Complaint Box | Sidewalk Gum
text: I had seen the blobs before — but it wasn’t until I lost my hearing aid that I had an in-your-face encounter with them. While searching for the device, I retraced my steps — same elevator, same route, focusing like a mine sweeper, gazing left to right, right to left — but my view was blocked by chewed-up pieces of gum in varying stages of decay, from light-colored, freshly spat out, to deeply embedded, flat and black.

headline: Keynesophobia
text: Dean Baker is once again justifiably mad at Robert Samuelson. It is indeed frustrating that after three years in which Keynesian predictions have been spectacularly correct, pundits insist on reading the evidence as a rejection of Keynes.

headline: Putting Many Fingers on the Trigger
text: The body of Police Officer Peter J. Figoski will be returned to the earth on Monday after the last bagpipe and muffled drum have sounded, a farewell guided by decades of tradition. There is another, less ennobling convention, and it has been observed with zeal ever since a wretch fired a shot that took Officer Figoski’s life a week ago.

headline: Using Social Media to Teach: Keep It Transparent, Open and Safe

But by taking care to make intentional decisions about how to use social media and keep professional and private lives separate, Twitter, Facebook and texting can boost student learning and engagement. Here, a geo-leather skirt with a fire red tank over a ribbed knit shell illustrate the point perfectly.

headline: Assessing Giants Cornerback Prince Amukamara
text: Toward the end of Coach Tom Coughlin’s news conference Sunday, a reporter asked for his assessment of the rookie cornerback Prince Amukamara. Coughlin hesitated. Then he said, “It seemed like they threw the ball in that direction and we were not having a lot of success.”

headline: Awakening Streams and Mummified Seals

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Health Care Case in Late March
text: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would devote three days in late March to hearing arguments in challenges to the 2010 health care overhaul law. A decision in the case is expected by the end of June.

headline: The Queen of the Bistro Playlist
text: If you’re like me, you mourned the passing of Cesária Évora over the weekend. And if you happened to spin a few of her albums on Saturday and Sunday afternoon, maybe while roasting dinner, it’s not impossible that her songs summoned up the memory of a few excellent meals.

headline: Tacos for the Holidays
text: The holiday season can be like an ongoing house party. Children are home from school, their friends are coming by, relatives are in from out of town, and one meal follows the next. One way to meet the challenge of feeding everybody is to pick up a supply of corn tortillas (all the better if more locally made) and make a big pot of beans and some other dishes that are at home in a taco. Buy a few jars of salsa, or make your own, and your house will be taco party central during the busy holiday week.

headline: Sean Parker Struggles With Fame
text: Over the Thanksgiving holiday, I interviewed Sean Parker, a founder of Napster and a former president of Facebook, for a profile that ran in The New York Times Sunday Style section. Some of the reaction online to the article suggested that Mr. Parker was reminiscent of Steve Jobs, a founder of Apple, who died in October at 56. I believe it is too soon to make that comparison. The next five years are crucial for Mr. Parker, who has yet to prove he is an influential force in Silicon Valley.

headline: New McCartney Album Is a Trip Down Memory Lane
text: One of the enduring questions in the history of pop music is how two teenagers from Liverpool with a background in skiffle and rock ‘n’ roll became the most inventive songwriters of the last 50 years, producing an enormous variety of tunes that broke new ground for pop music both melodically and harmonically.

headline: Tattooed Heroine Metes Out Slick, Punitive Violence
text: Tiny as a sparrow, fierce as an eagle, Lisbeth Salander is one of the great Scandinavian avengers of our time, an angry bird catapulting into the fortresses of power and wiping smiles off the faces of smug, predatory pigs. The animating force in Stieg Larsson’s “Millennium” trilogy — incarnated on screen first by Noomi Rapace and now, in David Fincher’s adaptation of “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo,” by Rooney Mara — Lisbeth is an outlaw feminist fantasy-heroine, and also an avatar of digital antiauthoritarianism.

headline: Start the Pajama Party

Silky PJ’s from Creatures of Comfort? Sounds right.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.19

headline: Prague and Pyongyang
text: The deaths of Vaclav Havel and Kim Jong Il within a 24-hour span are more than a reminder of the extremes of heroism and iniquity that coexist in human affairs. They’re a reminder of how much successful political heroism depends, in the end, on the ability to prick the conscience of iniquity, and to remind even the worst regimes and most compromised authorities that there are moral absolutes which they transgress at their peril. The great success of the Velvet Revolution, like the successes of Gandhi and Mandela and Martin Luther King and so many other icons of peaceful revolution, was achieved by public argument as well as by public protest, and by the fact that the bureaucrats and apparatchiks and generals the revolutionaries were confronting weren’t willing to take the most absolute and unthinkable steps to retain their privileges and defend their power. (In David Chappell’s “A Stone of Hope,” a history of religion and the civil rights movement, there’s a fascinating account of how this worked in the white South — the way that the Christian appeals of King and Ralph Abernathy and Co. persuaded many white Christians that they had a moral obligation to stand by and let the revolution happen, rather than defend Jim Crow to the end.) When civil disobedience works, it does so by reminding the inhumane of their inhumanity, and by finding the vulnerabilities in what seem like permanently hardened hearts. In this sense, there’s a circular quality to any successful peaceful revolt: No De Klerk without Mandela but also no Mandela (as we know Mandela) without De Klerk; no Gorbachev without Sakharov and Walesa and Havel, but no Havel and Walesa (as we know them) without Gorbachev.

text: We just published an important article from Jack Healy in Baghdad:

headline: Arkansas State Raises Salary for New Coach
text: Arkansas State University’s new head football coach figures to earn at least four times as much money as his predecessor.

headline: Gap Between Romney and Gingrich Narrows
text: The latest polls for the Republican presidential race are yet another indication of a volatile election season, where large groups of voters say they could still change their minds. The survey results among registered Republicans in national polls over the last month show persistent signs of an electorate in search of a nominee.

text: April, 2013 | Updated
