headline: Staring in Awe? It’s ‘the Spielberg Face’
text: For Steven Spielberg completists even beyond Kathleen Kennedy, the Bagger would like to point you to a video essay that’s been making the rounds from Fandor.

headline: Warren Hellman, 77, Investor Who Loved Bluegrass, Dies
text: Warren Hellman, a Wall Street investor who was president of Lehman Brothers and whose passion for bluegrass inspired him to create a San Francisco music festival that draws hundreds of thousands of people a year, died on Sunday in San Francisco. He was 77.

headline: Risks: More Woes for Preemies at Preschool Age
text: Babies born only three weeks prematurely face an increased risk of behavioral and emotional problems as preschoolers, a new analysis has found.

headline: Patterns: Statins May Reduce Risk of Death From Flu
text: Statins, among the most commonly prescribed drugs for the prevention of cardiovascular disease, also appear to reduce the risk for death in patients hospitalized with the flu.

headline: Rebuffing Governor, Florida A&M Declines to Suspend President in Student Death
text: MIAMI — Rebuffing the governor, Florida A&M’s board of trustees on Monday decided not to suspend the university’s president and asserted that it would “stand firm against outside influences, no matter how well intended.”

headline: Pacers Are Poised to Get Better on Offense
text: Change is the N.B.A.’s only true constant. With that in mind, here is a look at the teams poised for substantial changes in their offensive performance:

headline: Supportive Steps After a Sexual Assault
text: Do you know what to do if you or someone close to you becomes the victim of a sexual assault? A national survey released last week by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention indicated that sexual assaults are far more common than previously believed, with nearly one woman in five reporting that she had been the victim of rape or attempted rape.

headline: The Year in Media | My Channel, Myself
text: Staff members of The Times’s media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

headline: A Matter of Time
Black Hole Forecast: A Cold Gas Cloud
text: For the past 20 years, astrophysicists have been watching stars and other space matter swirling around Sagittarius A*  (pronounced A-star), the black hole at the center of the Milky Way. But they have never seen anything sucked into it (or any other black hole, for that matter).

headline: Should Students and Teachers Be Facebook Friends?
text: Should schools regulate or ban communications between teachers and students by cellphone, Facebook or e-mail? Jennifer Preston, a Times reporter, found districts in New York State and across the country scrambling to create a social media policy in the wake of a few inappropriate relationships that included electronic communications. A district in Georgia has banned private electronic communication entirely; Missouri is revamping such a rule after teachers persuaded a judge that the proposed law was unconstitutional.

headline: ‘New Girl’ on Fox Gets a Lift From DVR Use
text: Fox received a bit of good news from the latest DVR rankings report, which includes the initial live broadcast viewership figures and DVR-playback numbers for the next seven days. For the week of Nov. 28 to Dec. 5, the freshman comedy “New Girl” on Fox not only posted the largest gain in total viewers, 3.1 million, but it also had the largest ratings increase in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic considered important to advertisers. (The show reached 10.7 million viewers, up from 7.6 million.)

headline: Honor of a Lifetime, Arriving Too Late
text: When Alfred B. Nobel created the prizes that bear his name, he decreed that they be given for work done in the preceding year. A seemingly simple provision, intuitively sensible to anyone who follows the Oscars, the Emmys or the Pulitzers.

headline: Muppet Show Continues: Museum Extends Jim Henson Exhibition
text: Not unlike the ending of a certain hit movie that found the Muppets mobbed by fans they didn’t realize they had, the Museum of the Moving Image in Astoria, Queens, has learned that a lot of people really like Jim Henson’s creations – enough that it is extending the retrospective on that artist and puppeteer by almost two months. On Monday, the museum said that “Jim Henson’s Fantastic World,” the traveling Smithsonian exhibition on the life and work of the Muppets creator, will now run through March 4; it was originally scheduled to close on Jan. 16.

headline: Closer Look at S.E.C.’s Mortgage Fraud Charges
text: The civil securities fraud charges filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission against six former executives of the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac signal an aggressive turn in the pursuit of cases tied to the subprime mortgage crisis.

headline: Regimens: A Much Quicker Way to Treat Latent TB
text: The standard treatment for latent tuberculosis infection — that is, infection without symptoms — is nine months of daily doses of isoniazid, an antibiotic. The treatment is effective, but only about 60 percent of patients carry it out completely.

headline: Genes Play Major Role in Primate Social Behavior, Study Finds
text: Social behavior among primates — including humans — has a substantial genetic basis, a team of scientists has concluded from a new survey of social structure across the primate family tree.

headline: Uranium Mining in Virginia ﻿
text: A report of the National Research Council on the scientific, technical, environmental, human health and safety, and regulatory aspects of uranium mining and processing in Virginia.

headline: Uranium Mining Debate in Virginia Takes a Step
text: WASHINGTON  —  The National Academy of Sciences delivered a long-awaited report on uranium mining to the Virginia legislature on Monday, warning that the state faced “steep hurdles” if it is to safely mine and process the nuclear reactor fuel.

headline: Leishmaniasis: Extend Friendly American Hand to Iran? Doctor Says a Vaccine Is a Place to Start
text: A leading tropical medicine researcher has proposed that the United States extend a friendly hand to Iran — not over nuclear weapons or oil or Israel or Iraq, but over vaccines.

headline: Mao’s Rockets and Modern War, Part III
text: Among the perennial tools of battlefield underdogs, the 107-millimeter rocket has a secure place. Like the assault rifle, the rocket-propelled grenade and the makeshift bomb, this class of weapon, first fielded by China and known as a Type 63, has been a consistent presence in recent wars, used by Palestinians against Israel, by Pakistani and Afghan fighters against Western and Afghan-government troops, by Iraqi insurgents and by both sides of the bitter contest this year for Libya. And that is only a partial list.

headline: Saab Bankruptcy: Long Before the Fall, Innovations Aplenty
text: Barring an unforeseen rescue, Saab‘s long, strange trip through Swedish courts and Chinese office towers appears to be over.

headline: Colleagues Recall Victim of Elevator Accident
text: At the beginning of the year, Suzanne Hart was assigned to oversee the redesign of her employer’s internal Web site, coordinating designers and technology specialists and countless others. The project could easily have taken seven or eight months.

headline: Rangers Lose Two Defensemen as Staal Gets Closer to Return
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — There was bad news and good news for the Rangers’ injury-riddled defensive corps Monday.

headline: Face Time | Tracee Ellis Ross
text: The final episode of the family sitcom “Reed Between the Lines” will air at 10 p.m. Tuesday on BET. I had a moment to chat with one of its stars and producers, Tracee Ellis Ross, a k a Dr. Carla Reed. I was excited to get the lowdown on her favorite beauty products, since I’ve always been impressed by her skin, hair, flair for fashion and fearlessness in so many things — including lip color.

headline: Exploring the Links Between Acetaminophen and Asthma
text: Is acetaminophen behind a sharp rise in asthma around the world over the past three decades?

headline: They Sure Have Earned Their Vacation, Haven’t They?
text: There have been so many games of chicken on Capitol Hill in 2011 that it seems appropriate to end the year with the most irresponsible one yet. And even though the outcome will affect virtually everyone who gets a paycheck, no one seems to know whether it will end with a crash or a deal.

headline: When Lobotomy Was Seen as Advanced
text: Most of us recall lobotomies as they were depicted in the movie “One Flew over the Cuckoo’s Nest”— horrifying operations inappropriately used to control mentally ill patients. But in the 1950s, surgeons also used them to treat severe pain from cancer and other diseases.

headline: How Hungry Mosquitoes Cool Themselves
text: Most blood-sucking insects urinate while they feed so they can avoid filling up on fluid and get more nutrients out of their meal.

headline: New Musicals Struggle at Broadway Box Office
text: Several newly opened Broadway musicals struggled to sell tickets last week, according to box office data released on Monday, as holiday tourists and others appeared to favor long-running hits like “The Lion King” and star-driven productions like Hugh Jackman’s one-man concert.

headline: Phillies Keep Rollins, but What About Cole Hamels?
text: Jimmy Rollins made his major league debut with the Philadelphia Phillies in 2000. That season, the Phillies lost 97 games, finished last in the National League East and traded their best pitcher,Curt Schilling. Two years later, on their way to another losing season, they traded their best offensive player, Scott Rolen.

headline: Romney’s Gordon Gekko Moment
text: Our colleagues have an article in today’s New York Times on Mitt Romney and his lucrative retirement agreement from Bain Capital, the private equity fund that he helped start. Mr. Romney received a share of the firm’s profits on all of its funds raised through February 2009, earning him millions of dollars that have helped fuel his political career.

headline: A Walk Through Water Before Reaching Land
text: Roughly 400 million years ago, an ancient lobe-finned fish left its watery habitat to become the first four-limbed terrestrial creature. Its descendants — which are called tetrapods and include tree frogs, blue jays and human beings — typically get around by stepping, flying or jumping.

headline: The Tree of Life Gets a Makeover
text: Darwin called it the “abominable mystery”: the reason for a sudden explosion of diverse flowering plants in the fossil record. Biologists have pondered the issue for years but were hampered by the absence of full studies of some plants and a lack of sophisticated tools for analyzing large genetic data sets. But now, thanks to a method called “functional phylogenomics,” scientists have resolved some of the enigmatic relationships of plant families, potentially opening the way for advances in agriculture.

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Korea, New York, Egypt and Philippines.

headline: Lions Come Back and Aim for a Wild Card
text: The Detroit Lions are getting quite the reputation for being kings of the comeback. Their 28-27 victory Sunday over the Raiders, in Oakland, was their fourth come-from-behind win of the season.

headline: Cornell Alumnus Is Behind $350 Million Gift to Build Science School in City
text: The donor whose $350 million gift will be critical in building Cornell University’s new high-tech graduate school on Roosevelt Island is Atlantic Philanthropies, whose founder, Charles F. Feeney, is a Cornell alumnus who made billions of dollars through the Duty Free Shoppers Group.

headline: A Schnabel Art Show Monologue
text: ANACOLUTHON comes from the Greek words for “not” and “following.” It applies to both stream-of-consciousness writing and conversations with Lola Montes Schnabel, the outgoing young artist who was having her first solo show in New York last Friday.

headline: Mediator Sits Down With City Opera and Union Leaders
text: Union leaders and management at New York City Opera met with a federal mediator on Monday morning in an effort to resolve a labor dispute that threatens the company’s season. One of the unions said the mediator, Allison Beck, the deputy director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, first met with both sides together and then separately. The union, the American Guild of Musical Artists, said in a statement that it agreed to return to negotiations on Jan. 3, just days before rehearsals are supposed to begin. The guild represents chorus members, stage managers and assistant directors. The orchestra’s union is also negotiating with the company’s management, which declined to comment on Monday, citing a news blackout requested by the mediator.

headline: A Melting Pot at the Intersection of Empires for Five Centuries
text: In its time and place, the ancient city of Dura-Europos had much in common with today’s most cosmopolitan urban landscapes. Religious, linguistic and cultural diversity characterized much of the city’s life for more than 500 years, starting at the outset of the third century B.C. in what is now Syria.

headline: GPS Watch Can Be an Unreliable Running Partner
text: I used to run with a GPS watch, and at the time it seemed like a technological marvel.

headline: A New International Theater Festival for New York
text: Thanks to festivals like Under the Radar and Coil, January is a busy month for devotees of international theater in New York. But things promise to be even more active than usual next month, when a new event called the Times Square International Theater Festival makes its debut.

headline: 'I'm in the Right Place,' Common Tells Eagle Academy Boys
text: The Grammy award-winning rapper Common performed at the Eagle Academy for Young Men in the Bronx on Monday. He said he wanted to see the school after meeting its founding principal last year at a panel on education reform.

headline: The Problem With GPS Watches for Runners
text: In her latest Personal Best column, Gina Kolata explores an all too common problem for runners who use GPS watches to track their distance and pace. Many of the watches are simply not very accurate, recording incorrect times and distances, which can be a nuisance for runners who are training for races.

headline: AT&T Ends $39 Billion Bid for T-Mobile
text: AT&T on Monday ended its effort to buy T-Mobile USA, acknowledging that it could not overcome stiff opposition by the Obama administration to form the nation’s biggest cellphone service provider.

headline: Feoktistov’s Journal: A Russian Back on American Ice
text: My name is Nikita Feoktistov. I’m a 21-year-old forward on the Russian Red Stars, an all-star team from Russia’s junior league, the Minor Hockey League, that feeds the majors, the Kontinental Hockey League. The Red Stars are on a tour of the United States to play six N.C.A.A. schools including Notre Dame and two top amateur teams.

headline: Behind I.B.M.’s Big Predictions
text: I.B.M. just issued its annual list of five predictions of developments in technology that it thinks will come true in the next five years. Like lots of predictive lists, particularly those that come around New Year’s, this is something of a pseudo-event that serves as an advertisement for the predictor’s own product or service. I.B.M.’s is no different in that regard, but it is worth looking at, both for the pedigree of who is doing the predicting, and what I.B.M.’s choices say about itself.

headline: Roiling Through an Undertow
text: The tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby has a burly but beseeching tone, and in his own bands he often pushes toward an amiable ruckus. Novela, the nine-piece band he presented at the Jazz Gallery on Sunday night, takes this predilection to its logical extreme. Drawing from “Novela” (Clean Feed), an album released in September, the group played a sprawling set of faintly episodic, heavily textured music, pausing only a couple of times to re-establish a center of gravity. The distinctive color of Mr. Malaby’s voice, on soprano as well as tenor, was often lost on a crowded canvas. He seemed totally fine with that.

headline: Special Delivery, With Teeth Marks
text: Updated, 5:58 p.m. | Senders of holiday goodies, beware: at one Manhattan post office, four-legged, scaly-tailed postal inspectors may intercept your package and render it unfit for delivery, or worse.

headline: Facial Fixers for Men
text: IT’S not as if men are allotted a whole lot of bathroom counter space to begin with. So if we are going to fight for those few extra inches, you had better believe it’s going to be for something that pulls its weight. Here are some products that are worth making room for.

headline: Following the Tune of Religion in Britain
text: The British early-music choir Stile Antico has spent the last couple of weeks touring with “Puer natus est,” a program devoted to Tudor and Jacobean Advent and Christmas music that it has also released on a Harmonia Mundi CD. The 13 singers brought these works to the Music Before 1800 series at Corpus Christi Church on Sunday afternoon, where they ended their tour with an appealingly warm, fresh performance.

headline: For a Reporter, Lingering Questions About North Korea
text: The dress code seemed a mile long.

headline: Lyrical Renegades and Free-Range Sages
text: In poetry — as in calling ballgames — it’s voice that makes the speaker memorable. Sure, it helps for a poet to be a master of meter, a lord of the poetic line. But that’s not why, say, we still read Walt Whitman or Emily Dickinson. We read him for his warm and vast-as-America hymning, and her for crabbed and cryptic messages left in a poetic bottle. Each poet here, too, writes in a vital and original voice, from a Vietnamese-American tale spinner to an alter-ego cockroach crashing headlong onto the keyboard.

headline: Nature Triumphant
text: The world grows more crowded — Earth: Pop. 7 billion — but inside Massimo Vitali’s latest large-format photographs, worlds unto themselves, really, the people are becoming fewer (and smaller). The depopulation is on display in two current exhibitions, one at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery in New York and the other at Brancolini Grimaldi in London.

headline: At Planet Green, Tilting From Ecology to Gastronomy
text: Secular, issue-oriented, do-gooder television: it’s a small niche to begin with. And on the evidence of two new shows from Planet Green — the channel started in 2008 by Discovery Communications with a focus on ecology and sustainable living — it’s getting smaller all the time.

headline: Six Great Gifts For Photographers
text: Still stuck for a gift to give your household shutterbug? Here are some of my favorite photo products from this year—as well as some perennial favorites—at a variety of prices.

headline: Pairings: Mortadella Mousse
text: With blanc de blancs Champagnes, inspiration comes easily. Pop open a tin of caviar, but also consider fat-rich cured meats and cheeses, like an irresistibly delicate, almost buttery mortadella mousse swirled on toast. I puréed diced mortadella, smoothed it with mascarpone and sharpened it with grated Parmesan. Then I recalled a mortadella spread at Osteria Morini, a SoHo restaurant that specializes in the food of Emilia-Romagna, the home of mortadella. Michael White, the chef and an owner, uses ricotta and heavy cream in his spuma di mortadella. Same idea, but I put my money on my mascarpone. I did add his fragrant touch, a pinch of nutmeg. Canapés can be served as is or, with a dusting of extra Parmesan, lightly browned under the broiler.

headline: A Toast to Versatility
text: NO doubt this column appears on first glance to be one of those dutiful end-of-the-year pieces on sparkling wines. Nothing could be further from the truth.

headline: A Landlord’s Uphill Fight to Ease Rent Restrictions
text: James D. Harmon Jr. learned the value of a house as a child, shoveling coal into the furnace of one of two Upper West Side buildings owned by his grandfather, a French immigrant who worked as a waiter. “Jimmy, you take care of your building and your building will take care of you,” his grandfather told him.

headline: Sounds in Keeping With New Galleries
text: Each program presented by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert has at its heart a thematic agenda: some small notion that links the pieces. The idea can be vague, like simplicity or craftsmanship, and it’s usually understated; the performances are comfortably chatty, but you never feel lectured to. But that daub of glue always helps to make the programs by this personable, proficient ensemble hold together, and stick with you.

headline: Q&A: Wide World Seen From Train Windows
text: AN architectural historian with a penchant for railroad stations, David Naylor has been traveling by train since the 1970s. He described the view from a train as a sort of movie, a documentary on the history of a region. “I would say that compared to the fragmented views out of car windows and the miniaturized views out of planes, the meditative view out of a train window is even better than television,” he said.

headline: Rutledge Named Chief of Charter Communications
text: Charter Communications, one of the nation’s biggest cable providers, on Monday named Thomas M. Rutledge its new chief executive, days after he resigned from his post at Cablevision.

headline: What’s Next for T-Mobile?
text: 4:00 p.m. | Updated  Adding additional comment from AT&T about spectrum.AT&T on Monday withdrew its $39 billion bid to acquire T-Mobile after facing resistance from governmental agencies that had raised antitrust concerns.

text: LOS ANGELES — Imagine a mother, Everywoman — in this case, Sandra Bullock — whose young son fervently wishes that she, and not his father, had died in the World Trade Center attacks.

headline: U.S. Backs Apple in Patent Ruling That Hits Google
text: A federal agency ruled on Monday that a set of important features commonly found in smartphones are protected by an Apple patent, a decision that could force changes in how Google’s Android phones function.

headline: ‘Homeland’ Finale Breaks Showtime Record
text: The finale of Showtime’s hugely talked about new drama “Homeland,” a favorite of critics and even President Obama, attracted the biggest audience for the series so far and the biggest for any first-year show in Showtime’s history.

headline: U.S. Considers Combating Somali Militants’ Twitter Use
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The United States government is increasingly concerned about the Twitter account of the Shabab militant group of Somalia, with American officials saying Monday that they were “looking closely” at the militants’ use of Twitter and the possible measures to take in response.

headline: Climate Panel Needs to Follow its Own Advice
text: I believe it’s time for Rajendra K. Pachauri to take a new approach to discussing climate change or leave the chairmanship of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change after nearly a decade in that position. There is an unavoidable and counterproductive blurriness to the line between his personal advocacy for climate action — which is his right as an individual — and his stature as the leader of the panel, which was established in 1988 as “a policy relevant but policy neutral organization.”

headline: Council Mandates City Alerts on PCB Dangers
text: The City Council on Monday approved a new law that requires the Department of Education to give parents and school staff regular updates on the status of PCB light fixtures and the city's actions to replace them.

headline: An Emergency, Dimly Remembered
text: I THINK a lot of flying is not enjoyable, but I still think it’s fascinating. I was in Africa earlier this year, flying around in a small plane, close to the ground, and it gave me a very visceral sense of the fact that I was in a piece of metal, hurling through the air. I liked it. It certainly was more interesting than being boxed up in a huge commercial jet.

headline: The Hereditary Principle

China’s Newest Province?

headline: Kim’s Heir Likely to Focus on Stability
text: TOKYO — The death of Kim Jong-il, the hermetic North Korea leader, threw the rest of Asia into deep anxiety Monday and reverberated across the Pacific. Friends and enemies of the nuclear-armed country fretted over whether it was now facing an unpredictable power struggle — even as the official North Korean press proclaimed that Mr. Kim’s cherubic-faced youngest son was his successor.

headline: Reactions to AT&T’s Decision to Cancel Its T-Mobile Deal
text: After nine months of AT&T fiercely defending its $39 billion bid for T-Mobile USA in public and in court, the company finally agreed on Monday to end its takeover effort.

headline: Cuts for the Already Retired
text: Retired police and firefighters from Central Falls, R.I., have agreed to sharp pension cuts, a step thought to be unprecedented in municipal bankruptcy and one that could prompt similar attempts by other distressed governments.

headline: Sprinter Leaves Humiliation Behind
text: NORFOLK, Va. — Having done the heavy lifting to restore his career and his reputation, LaShawn Merritt, the reigning Olympic sprint champion at 400 meters, came to the gym to burnish his abdominal muscles.

headline: In Kim’s Undetected Death, Sign of Nation’s Opacity
text: WASHINGTON — Kim Jong-il, the enigmatic North Korean leader, died on a train at 8:30 a.m. Saturday in his country. Forty-eight hours later, officials in South Korea still did not know anything about it — to say nothing of Washington, where the State Department acknowledged “press reporting” of Mr. Kim’s death well after North Korean state media had already announced it.

headline: State Tests Extended to About Three Hours
text: New York State math and language arts tests for elementary and middle school students will each be lengthened to about three hours beginning this April.

headline: Among Legal Ranks, Shrugs for Gingrich’s Tough Talk
text: WASHINGTON — The American legal establishment is not sure what to make of Newt Gingrich’s mounting attacks on the independence of the federal judiciary. Reactions vary from amusement to alarm. What is hard to find is approval.

headline: Reality of Having to Win Closes In
text: Two weeks ago, after the Giants lost a close game to the then-undefeated Green Bay Packers, several players talked about how their playoffs had just begun. Every game from that point forward was must-win, the players said. These were elimination games. And even though it was only December, the preparation had to feel as if it were January.

headline: Relive Rout? Ryan Stokes Rivalry Instead
text: Over the telephone Monday, Rex Ryan sounded as if it had been he who was sacked four times against Philadelphia.

headline: Amgen Plans to Team Up With Watson on Generics
text: LOS ANGELES — Amgen, the biotechnology company, is planning to develop generic versions of some best-selling drugs.

headline: For Medicare, We Must Cut Costs, Not Shift Them
text: Suddenly, everybody is talking about turning Medicare into a voucher program. It’s not a new idea. It’s been two decades since wonks first started talking seriously about “premium support” and the idea of replacing Medicare with a competitive marketplace in which older people could shop for health insurance. But the idea got new life last week when Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon, a Democrat with a long record on health care, joined Paul D. Ryan, Republican of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Budget Committee, in suggesting that such a scheme was the best way to cut health care spending while providing for the medical needs of the elderly. The plan resembles a proposal that Alice Rivlin, who was budget director under President Clinton, and Pete Domenici, a longtime Republican senator, have also recently been promoting.

headline: In Murky Republican Contest, the Clearest Target Is Gingrich
text: A furious and sustained barrage of criticism aimed at Newt Gingrich appears to be reshaping the volatile Republican nomination contest once again with just two weeks left before voters begin weighing in.

headline: German President Pressured Over Loan From Friend
text: BERLIN — By nightfall on Monday some 45 reporters had paid a visit to the law firm of Redeker Sellner Dahs here to examine copies of private financial documents belonging to President Christian Wulff, a paper trail made public by his legal team in a bid to save his reputation and his job.

headline: A Farewell to Havel in Prague
text: Updated | Tuesday | 1:13 p.m. Quietly and lovingly, Czechs bid goodbye to their former president, Václav Havel, the dissident playwright who stood firm against Communism and led his people to freedom in 1989.

headline: For Wall St.’s Big Players, the Holiday Party Is Still Over
text: Three years after the financial crisis, the Grinch still hovers over Wall Street.

headline: Frozen in Time
text: If you could fly into Nicosia International Airport, you’d arrive in a different era. The architecture, furniture and advertising all scream early Seventies. The Cyprus Airways jet plane out on the tarmac is an ancient Hawker Siddeley Trident, a British model that most carriers retired in the mid-1980s. But there are no other planes, nor any passengers.

headline: Birthday of a Nation
text: On Dec. 24, 1861, the Charleston, S.C. Courier gave an impassioned account of the first anniversary of secession, as it was celebrated in the true birthplace of the Confederacy. “The Confederate and State Flags floated over the Custom House, the Old Exchange – which connects Charleston of this day with the Charleston of Colonial history, and with the names and services of LAURENS, GADSDEN, PINCKNEY, and their compeers of 1776.”

headline: Gingrich Hires a Political Director and Announces an Endorsement
text: While his presidential campaign is suddenly facing greater challenges, Newt Gingrich has turned to a political professional, Martin Baker, who is coming on board as political director.

headline: Helping a Son Cope With Diabetes, While Juggling Her Own Challenges
text: Playtime and parties can be dangerous pastimes for Joshua Cancino-Betanzos.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Knicks Are Confident Davis Will Be Worth the Wait
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The complete data for the Baron Davis “risk-reward” graph will not be available for four weeks, maybe six, possibly eight. There are too many variables to count for the moment.

headline: Eager to Emerge From Its Slumber, but Seeing a Threat to an Idyllic Life
text: For generations, its residents say, Roosevelt Island has been New York City’s depository. The island accepted inmates, quarantined smallpox patients and even lent its earth to support the Queensboro Bridge.

headline: In Gilded City, Living Wage Proposal Still Stirs Fears
text: Let’s slip into our Louis Vuitton shoes and take a gilded stroll through Manhattan.

headline: Death of a Dictator
text: The United States and its partners have long struggled to understand North Korea, where a cruel system of fear, repression and paranoia keeps the country largely impenetrable to outsiders. They will have to work harder than ever to pierce the curtain — and manage stability on the Korean Peninsula — after the abrupt death of Kim Jong-il, the North Korean dictator, and the ascension of his youngest son, Kim Jong-un.

headline: Dan Frazer, Fretful Supervisor on ‘Kojak,’ Dies at 90
text: Dan Frazer, a character actor whose Hell’s Kitchen upbringing prepared him for a long run of roles as a blue-collar type or a cop, most notably as the beleaguered supervising officer Capt. Frank McNeil on “Kojak,” died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Firefighter, Burning, Escapes From Window
text: A firefighter whose head and back became covered in flames as he battled a blaze at a Brooklyn brownstone escaped from a third-floor window Monday morning as fire roared all around him, the authorities said.

headline: Tuesday: Like an Acrobat’s Limbs
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — Today is Tuesday, which means we have an entertaining crossword puzzle to talk about, but before we discuss that I wanted to ask those of you who are reading this whether or not you like to do the Second Sunday or Variety puzzles. I’ve asked this before; however, commentary drops off markedly on those days (I don’t know how many people actually are doing the puzzles and just not commenting on the blog) and for the life of me, I don’t know why. I was not a Variety puzzle solver when I started this job, and now I’m absolutely hooked on them. They’re worth a try, and if you want to read a particularly good explanation on what it takes to construct these puzzles by my partners-in-noir-fiction, Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, read Jim Horne’s new post here. Then come back and try one of these devilish masterpieces of construction. You might find yourself similarly hooked.

headline: Perry Ad Casts Gingrich as a K Street Man
text: The advertising assault on Newt Gingrich by his Republican opponents is getting louder, with the latest commercial from Gov. Rick Perry of Texas taking aim at the former House speaker’s career as a (don’t say lobbyist!) Washington power broker after he left public office.

headline: Father and Daughter Edit Their Relationship
text: The clunker title isn’t the only nonworking part in “Close Up Space,” a new play by Molly Smith Metzler that opened Monday night at City Center. Aside from the appealing work of a cast led by David Hyde Pierce, playing a more dour variation on the dithery persona he perfected in his years as a star of the sitcom “Frasier,” this wan comedy about (yawn) the troubled relationship between a book editor and his daughter has little to recommend it. Unfortunately it is the second dud in a row from Manhattan Theater Club at its Off Broadway space, after Zoe Kazan’s similarly undercooked “We Live Here.”

headline: After Drugs and Dark Times, Helping Others to Stand Back Up
text: SMYRNA, Del. — The taste of cocaine and the slow-motion sensation of breaking the law were all too familiar, but the thrill was long gone.

headline: Deep Pockets, Deeply Political
text: A tiny number of wealthy Americans are playing an ever-increasing role in financing our politics. This is not a good thing for a democracy.

headline: Brooklyn Senator Expected to Plead Guilty in Corruption Case
text: State Senator Carl Kruger was expected to plead guilty on Tuesday to federal corruption charges that he accepted at least $1 million in bribes to finance a lavish lifestyle, including a large home in Mill Basin, Brooklyn, where he lived with two gynecologist brothers and their mother, according to several people briefed on the case.

headline: Police Arrest a Suspect in Bizarre Queens Shooting Case
text: The circumstances of the crime were as mysterious as they were unnerving.

headline: The Middle-Class Agenda
text: Earlier this month, President Obama delivered his first unabashed 2012 campaign speech. Unlike his opponents, Mr. Obama acknowledged the ravages of income equality, the hollowing out of the American middle class. There is no hyperbole in the urgency he conveyed about “a make-or-break moment for the middle class, and for all those who are fighting to get into the middle class.”

headline: Nets Announcer Shows Flair and Hair
text: Enveloped in a cloud of pungent smoke, David Diamante puffed on a custom-blend cigar, hand-rolled in the Dominican Republic, while ticking off the various jobs he has held and hobbies he has pursued. Motorcyclist, D.J., surfer, boxing announcer. Diamante, 40, was sitting amid the leather chairs and ashtrays of his cigar bar in the Fort Greene neighborhood of Brooklyn, a few blocks from where he will perform his next adventure.

headline: Protesters ‘Deserve to Be Thrown Into Hitler’s Ovens,’ Egyptian Military Adviser Says
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, a general from Egypt’s ruling military council insisted on Monday that soldiers had not used force against peaceful protesters after a weekend of such attacks that were “witnessed by journalists, captured on video and broadcast across the Internet and on satellite television.”

headline: In Protests, Syrians Find the Spark of Creativity
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — You could call it the dance-athon to dislodge a despot.

headline: Bleeding Green: Inspirational Beginnings
text: Brian Bassett is the founder of SNY’s The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian_Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday. Leading off: Brian explains how he became a Jets fan.

headline: Syria Agrees to Allow Outside Observers, but Activists Remain Wary
text: CAIRO — The Syrian government, bowing to international pressure to end its violent crackdown on protests, signed an Arab League initiative on Monday that would send outside observers to the country within days.

headline: Here Come the Helpmates
text: Before we travel any further down the 2012 campaign trail and hear any more about what a rosy and essential mirror of the candidate his (or her) spouse provides, let’s brush up on history. We need go back only four years, to John and Elizabeth Edwards.

headline: Dyed in Blue: Wincing With Ups And Downs
text: Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday. Leading off: How he became a Giants fan.

headline: Coping With Addiction and a Mood Disorder
text: In the latest installment of the Lives Restored series, about people coping with mental illness, Benedict Carey reports the story of Antonio Lambert, 41, a self-taught ex-convict turned mental health educator who has had personal battles with crime and drug use.

headline: Palin Says It’s Not Too Late for ‘Folks’ to Jump In
text: Just as the Republican presidential field is looking particularly unsettled, Sarah Palin is back in the news.

headline: New Focus on Incendiary Words in Paul’s Newsletters
text: Emerging as a real Republican contender in Iowa, Representative Ron Paul of Texas is receiving new focus for decades-old unbylined columns in his political newsletters that included racist, anti-gay and anti-Israel passages that he has since disavowed.

headline: The Sidney Awards, Part I
text: Every year, the Sidney Awards, named for the renowned philosopher Sidney Hook, go out to some of the best magazine essays of the year. Anybody interested in being a better person will click the links to these essays, and read attentively.

headline: For Exiles, Iraq Beckons and Repels
text: BAGHDAD — Ali al-Subiahi returned from his family’s self-imposed exile in the United States to reclaim a sense of himself in a new Iraq.

headline: Should Teenagers Get High Instead of Drunk?
text: Cocaine, tobacco and alcohol use are waning, just as a record proportion of high schoolers use marijuana on a near daily basis. Is that progress?

headline: Going After Gingrich
text: More than $600,000 has been spent over the past 10 days on television ads in Iowa criticizing Newt Gingrich.

headline: Louis C.K.: Anatomy of a Bit
text: Jason Zinoman analyzes Louis C.K.'s narrative technique in his latest Internet-only comedy special.

headline: Bank of America Back Below $5
text: Bank of America’s stock price fell.

headline: Rangers Win Bid to Negotiate With Darvish for $51.7 Million
text: In successive off-seasons, the Texas Rangers watched as the aces of their pitching staff left them in free agency; first Cliff Lee, then C. J. Wilson. But now Texas is in a position to strike back with a bold international signing that could restore some punch and flair to its rotation.

headline: Louis C. K.’s Blue Collar in First Class
text: The ascension of Louis C. K. from comic’s comic to show business saint (a description used by more than one of his legion of admirers) brings with it what the comedian himself might call “white-people problems.”

headline: Corrections: December 20
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Man Accused in Officer’s Death Fights With Officers at Rikers Island
text: Lamont Pride, the man accused of fatally shooting a New York City police officer last week, got in a scuffle with correction officers at Rikers Island on Monday, the Department of Correction said.

headline: Word of the Day | alchemy
text: alchemy •\ˈal-kə-me\• noun

headline: Seattle Bans Plastic Bags, and Sets a Charge for Paper
text: SEATTLE — The City Council here voted unanimously on Monday to ban plastic grocery bags and charge a 5-cent fee on paper bags — and this time city leaders hope the ban actually takes effect.

headline: Finding Fault in the Palestinian Messages That Aren’t So Public
text: JERUSALEM — A new book by an Israeli watchdog group catalogs dozens of examples of messages broadcast by the Palestinian Authority for its domestic audience that would seem at odds with the pursuit of peace and a two-state solution.

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/20/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/20/2011

headline: Pecan Theft in Georgia
text: Nut theft has long been a reality in Georgia, where a pound of pecans — 30 nuts or so — can be cashed in for as much as $1.50 at the local buying station.

headline: Pecan Thieves in Georgia Enjoying a Windfall, at $1.50 a Pound
text: FORT VALLEY, Ga. — To an enterprising thief, or even a casual dabbler in crime, the fallen pecans that cover thousands of acres of unpatrolled Georgia nut orchards might as well be a carpet of nickels.

headline: Iran Admits Western Sanctions Are Inflicting Damage
text: Iran’s veneer of stoicism toward the Western sanctions that have disrupted its economy showed some new strains on Monday, as the deputy oil minister acknowledged a decline in domestic petroleum production because of dwindling foreign investment, and four-year-old talks between the Iranians and Poland’s biggest natural gas developer collapsed.

headline: Decision to Investigate Anti-Army Memo Is Delayed in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s Supreme Court on Monday put off a decision on whether to investigate a controversial memo in which a Pakistani diplomat purportedly sought American help to constrain the Pakistani military. The court called on the government here to provide more details in the case and set the next hearing for Thursday.

headline: In North India, an Annual Struggle With the Cold
text: Northern India’s cold temperatures will continue for several days, with fog plaguing Delhi and other cities through the week, weather forecasters say.

headline: In Philippines, Concern Grows Over Flood Survivors
text: MANILA — As the death toll from flash floods over the weekend soared to more than 900 on Monday, officials in the southern Philippines turned their attention to the survivors and the threat of disease in crowded evacuation centers.

headline: New Prime Minister Vows to Fix Spain’s Economy
text: MADRID — Mariano Rajoy, the new conservative prime minister of Spain, pledged on Monday to reduce the size of the country’s public sector, clean up its troubled banks and introduce corporate tax breaks to get Spain’s budget deficit down and revive investment.

headline: Afghanistan: Pakistani Liaison Officers Returning to Army Coordination Centers
text: Pakistani military officers have begun returning to coordination centers in Afghanistan, NATO said on Monday, calling it a sign that tensions were easing, nearly a month after American airstrikes killed 24 Pakistani soldiers. But Pakistan has not reopened the supply lines for NATO forces in Afghanistan that run through its territory. The supply lines were closed by Islamabad in the wake of the airstrikes, on Nov. 26, which infuriated Pakistani officials and put more strain on America’s troubled alliance with Pakistan. NATO forces generally get about two-thirds of their supplies in other ways, but the land route through Pakistan remains vital, and NATO asked again on Monday for the roads to be reopened to supply convoys. Pakistani officials did not immediately respond to the request. A Pakistani military spokesman, Maj. Gen. Athar Abbas, said that liaison officers were returning to the coordination centers, which are meant to ease communications among the Afghan and Pakistani armies and the NATO coalition, all of which operate near the border.

headline: Japan Picks Lockheed to Build Its Next Fighter Jet
text: TOKYO — Japan said on Tuesday that it had chosen Lockheed Martin’s F-35 jet as its next main fighter, a lift for the American defense contractor and for Tokyo’s relations with the United States amid heightened fears of instability on the Korean peninsula after the death of Kim Jong-il.

headline: Britain: Report Faults Police Response to Riots
text: The initial inadequate response by the police to last summer’s riots in London, Birmingham, Manchester and other places allowed the vandalism and looting to spread out of control, according to a parliamentary report released Monday. The report, by the home affairs committee in the House of Commons, said that the police in many areas, particularly London, had failed to take charge of the situation quickly enough, creating an “absence of a police presence” and the “sight of police officers apparently standing by” and allowing criminal behavior to occur. A spokesman for the Metropolitan Police in London said that it had already acknowledged its failures and developed new plans for dealing with future riots.

headline: Four Reasons Why Shashi Tharoor Is Wrong
text: Shashi Tharoor has set the cat among the pigeons by re-opening the old debate about whether we should abandon our Westminster-style parliamentary system and move to an American-style presidential system instead. In a long and well-argued essay in Tehelka, he carefully identifies the maladies that plague our current dispensation, most vividly on view recently in the government’s about-face on FDI in retail.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 20, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: Dec. 20, 1946 | The Debut of ‘It’s a Wonderful Life,’ at New York’s Globe Theater
text: On Dec. 20, 1946, the Frank Capra film “It’s A Wonderful Life” had a preview showing for charity at New York City’s Globe Theater, a day before its official premiere.

headline: Son Among Mourners as North Korea’s Kim Lies in State
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, catapulted into prominence after Kim Jong-il’s sudden death, paid respects at his father’s glass coffin on Tuesday, as the regime stepped up a campaign to portray the impoverished country as standing behind its young new leader.

headline: Surprising Sources of Delhi’s Air Pollution
text: Delhi’s choking air pollution has caught the attention of politicians and newswires in recent weeks.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 20, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Cowboys Find Another Agonizing Way to Lose.”

headline: Papua New Guinea’s Impasse Seems to End
text: SYDNEY, Australia — A political standoff in Papua New Guinea that left the country with two prime ministers and cabinets for more than a week appeared effectively over on Tuesday, after the governor general reversed course and threw his weight behind the government of Peter O’Neill.

headline: China Exerts Influence Nurtured Over Decades
text: BEIJING — China, North Korea’s foremost ally, appears to be moving quickly to try to ensure stability in a crippled and isolated nation now facing a leadership transition fraught with dangers.

headline: Kwaku Alston’s Rebirth in Venice
text: Kwaku Alston savored success at an early age. He photographed celebrities, legendary African-American women and even the Obama family. His schedule was packed, but his spirits were low. He thought about how to get back to basics.

headline: Taking Stock Before Iowa
text: WHO are the remaining seven contenders for the Republican presidential nomination?

headline: Dexia to Sell Luxembourg Unit to Qatari Fund for $952 Million
text: LONDON — Dexia, the Belgian-French bank that has been bailed out twice in three years, agreed on Tuesday to sell most of its Luxembourg operations to a Qatari investment group.

headline: Have You Ever Interacted With the Police?
text: A new study shows that approximately one-third of Americans have been arrested by age 23. And a black college student wrote an Op-Ed about being stopped by the police multiple times and how, he says, racial profiling has affected young people. What kinds of experiences have you and others you know had with the police?

headline: The Early Word:  Rejection
text: Today’s Times

headline: A Guide to Holiday Sweets in Madrid
text: In a nation collectively obsessed with the enjoyment of food, Spaniards make no exception for Christmas, especially those harboring a sweet tooth. With the holiday season in full swing, children and adults alike seek traditional Christmas sweets in Madrid’s bakeries.

headline: Cutting the Corporate Tax Rate Is No Economic Panacea
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Plurality of Voters in Poll Fault Cuomo on Tax Deal
text: A plurality of New York voters said Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo broke campaign promises to oppose tax increases and bring an end to Albany’s tradition of secret deal-making when he overhauled the state’s tax code earlier this month, according to a new poll released on Tuesday.

headline: The Envelope, Please: Eight High School Seniors Blog Their College Searches
text: One attends a Minnesota public high school and dreams of becoming a veterinarian. But she won’t be studying at Cornell University or the University of California, Davis, at least as an undergraduate. She crossed those schools off earlier rough drafts of her college wish list at least partly because, she says, her parents have agreed to pay only the equivalent of in-state tuition at a Minnesota public university.

headline: Who Am I? Can I Get Back to You on That?
text: Last Friday, I was taking my second trip to the campus of University of Wisconsin, Madison, to help with the seemingly impossible decision of where to go to school. My dad, an alumnus, had used his contacts at UW to request a few meetings with professors, so that I could “get a feel” for the academic life there. The first professor on the list was typical — well, a typical, middle-aged, horse-loving animal science professor. She was enthusiastic, but she warned me sternly that I may need to change my career goal.

headline: ‘Relatively Average, Nothing Special’ and Worried About College
text: Right off the bat, let me tell you: I am a relatively average student. Nothing special. I don’t have a 90+ GPA. If you want someone like that, consult my friends. I enjoy the liberal arts, English and history over the sciences — but not to the point that I stay up all night reading history textbooks in my free time.

headline: Mass March by Cairo Women in Protest Over Abuse by Soldiers
text: CAIRO — Several thousand women demanding the end of military rule marched through downtown Cairo on Tuesday evening in an extraordinary expression of anger over images of soldiers beating, stripping and kicking female demonstrators in Tahrir Square.

headline: A C.P.A. Figures Out What Business Owners Really Want
text: A few weeks ago, I received the above postcard in the mail. It didn’t hit me at first. As the owner of an advertising agency, I see a lot of in-your-face marketing efforts. But after spending a few minutes with it, I started to admire the way this service business — a certified public accountant, no less — was trying to differentiate itself from the pack.

headline: On Our Radar: Reports of Power Plant Protest in China
text: Residents of Haimen, in Guangdong Province in China, report clashes with the police in an environmental protest against the expansion of a power plant. [Agence France-Presse]

headline: Is Republican Infighting Helping Obama?
text: Has Republican squabbling given President Obama a chance to recover his political footing just as his re-election year begins?

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Lost in Translation
text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

headline: Playoff Contenders, and Super Bowl Blueprints
text: We often think of the Super Bowl winner as a dominant team that had an inevitable rise to power, but that’s not often the case. In fact, last season, the Packers surprised everybody — well, almost everybody — by winning the Super Bowl as a No. 6 seed.

headline: ‘No Plan B’ for T-Mobile
text: LONDON — Deutsche Telekom of Germany still faces long-term problems with its American subsidiary, T-Mobile USA, after the proposed $39 billion takeover by AT&T was scrapped on Monday.

headline: Morning Take-Out
text: AT&T Ends $39 Billion Bid for T-Mobile  |  AT&T on Monday ended its effort to buy T-Mobile USA, acknowledging that it could not overcome stiff opposition by the Obama administration to form the nation’s biggest cellphone service provider.

headline: Fannie Freddie Follies
text: Joe Nocera gets it right.

headline: Jefferies Reports $39 Million Profit
text: The Jefferies Group reported a $39 million profit for the fourth quarter on Tuesday, as it grappled with choppy markets that have crimped once highly lucrative trading operations.

headline: Gross Confusion
text: People have been asking me for reactions to this op-ed by Bill Gross, arguing that low interest rates are hurting the economy — an argument that he’s been making for a while now. The short answer is that I don’t understand his argument, and I suspect that he doesn’t either.

headline: Tuesday Reading: GPS Watches Can Be Unreliable Running Partners
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Vice President of Iraq Voices Sunnis’ Anger as He Denies Ordering Killings
text: BAGHDAD — As Iraq’s Sunni vice president on Tuesday angrily rebutted the government’s accusations that he had been running death squads, many people in Iraq’s Sunni minority dismissed the charges as politically motivated, underscoring how deeply alienated they have become from the Shiite-led government.

headline: Should Kids Miss School for Family Opportunities?
text: A parent writes about taking his 14-year-old daughter and 11-year-old son out of school for six days this month for a family trip to Israel -- a journey that provided them with a serious bout of experiential learning. Did he make the right decision?

headline: Six Hours of State Tests Coming This Spring
text: With increased emphasis on standardized testing a sore point (to put it mildly) for many parents and educators -- and with this year's test results also factoring into teacher evaluations --  the state's decision to extend the length of the math and language arts for elementary and middle school students was, needless to say, met with some scorn.

headline: British Tax Office Assailed for ‘Cozy’ Ties With Big Companies
text: LONDON — Goldman Sachs, Vodafone and other big businesses were treated too favorably by British tax officials, potentially costing the nation billions in lost revenue, according to a government report released Tuesday.

headline: Great Escape | Winter in Tuscany
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: CNN Talk Show Host Is Questioned in British Inquiry
text: LONDON — The CNN talk show host Piers Morgan declared on Tuesday that as the editor in chief of two British tabloids from 1994 to 2004, he knew no one who hacked phones or paid police officers for information.

headline: Markets Jump in U.S. and Europe on Positive Economic Data
text: Stocks surged on Tuesday, partly a result of positive economic data on the housing sector in the United States and brighter signals from the euro zone.

headline: Politifact, R.I.P.
text: This is really awful. Politifact, which is supposed to police false claims in politics, has announced its Lie of the Year — and it’s a statement that happens to be true, the claim that Republicans have voted to end Medicare.

headline: T-Mobile and AT&T: What’s $2 Billion Among Friends?
text: You say “po-TAY-to,” I say “po-TAH-to.” But in the case of the T-Mobile USA deal’s breakup fee, it’s a very big root vegetable.

headline: Friend Me, Follow Me or Google Me?
text: It sometimes feels like it was easier to exchange contact information with someone before the Web came along. You really had two options: handing out a business card or scribbling down a phone number. And although the Web promised to make this transaction simpler, it feels more confusing than ever.

headline: A Sentence for Stealing From Bloomberg That Doesn’t Compute
text: The wages of sin is death. It says so right there in Romans 6:23, questionable grammar and all. Death may be a tad harsh for most sins. But the concept prompts a question as to how to weigh a sin like stealing against the penalty meted out.  A political consultant named John F. Haggerty Jr. brings it to mind.

headline: Daily Report: Apple’s Victory in Patent Ruling Hits Google
text: Patent battles have engulfed the cellphone industry for years, reflecting the heated competition. An important ruling by a federal agency, United States International Trade Commission, on Monday is described as one of the most significant so far by Nick Wingfield of The New York Times. Apple won a partial victory over the manufacturer HTC that could could force changes in how Google’s Android phones function.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 20
text: New voting rules for the Academy Awards could help the movie “Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,” which will be released in Los Angeles and New York on Christmas and won’t play around the country until next year, Michael Cieply writes. The movie was shut out by Golden Globes voters, who were shown a screening at the beginning of the month; the voters said in interviews with Mr. Cieply that they were sharply divided on the movie, with some hating it, some loving it. That kind of polarity didn’t work at the Golden Globes, but it might now prove an advantage in the Oscar contest after changes in balloting for best picture have put a premium on first-place votes.

headline: Drawing Dance: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company in Paris
text: The Brooklyn artist Kenneth E. Parris III is on tour with members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, documenting, through a series of drawings and paintings, their two-year legacy tour. After 58 years the company is scheduled to disband on New Year’s Day 2012. This is the 23rd in a series of graphite drawings that Mr. Parris plans to create from the road, providing a front-row seat to the final weeks of the company’s journey. This week’s entry is from Paris.

headline: Talbots Rebuffs Buyout Offer From Sycamore
text: Talbots, the women’s fashion retailer, has rejected an unsolicited buyout offer from a private equity firm as too low. Instead, the company said on Tuesday that it would explore strategic alternatives, essentially putting itself on the block.

headline: Rabbi’s Followers Blame Aide for Missing Millions
text: Six years ago, an Orthodox rabbi and mystic who traces his lineage to King David moved to New York from Israel and amassed a notable following. Real estate titans fetched him at the airport. Members of Congress attended his Hebrew classes. Even LeBron James, who is not Jewish, borrowed a friend’s yacht to consult the rabbi in private.

headline: Wanted: A Ron Paul for Policing
text: I don’t support Ron Paul and I can’t imagine how his libertarian philosophy could possibly work, especially at a time when the crippled economy is crying out for effective government. But I appreciate the novelty he has brought to the Republican primaries, and the way he sometimes breaks with right-wing orthodoxy. When the other presidential aspirants compete to out-tough each other on foreign policy, for example, I think it’s useful to have Mr. Paul jump in and say—as he did at the last debate—that the “greatest danger” is a president who “will overreact.”

headline: American Jailed in Peru Returns to New York
text: She has captivated New Yorkers for 16 years, the daughter of Manhattan academics convicted in Peru of aiding a leftist terrorist group, famous for a fist-waving rant to television cameras that cemented her reputation among Peruvians as a dangerous radical.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: The Economist: An ambitious analysis of how “a small, unremarkable country came to dominate the world of beermaking.” That would be Belgium. Crammed with statistics, including how many different beers (1,131), the most expensive ($800 per case for Westvleteren) and how much beer Belgians consume (84 liters per year). — Glenn Collins

headline: Martin Sheen, Family (Filmmaking) Man
text: Forget about the 10: Officially speaking, 265 features are in contention for the best picture Oscar, as the Academy announced Monday. One you may not have heard much about is “The Way,” a family drama written and directed by Emilio Estevez and starring his father, Martin Sheen.

headline: Karachi Chatter
text: KARACHI, Pakistan – The phone calls and text messages began just after sunset on Sunday. “His royal highness will be returning to his palace by the sea, so you better get off the roads,” messaged one friend.

headline: The Unity Is Gone
text: CAIRO — For the last several days in Egypt, there’s been only one question on my mind: what on earth is going on here?

headline: What to Do About Asian Carp? Great Lakes States Can’t Agree
text: CHICAGO — The leaders of the Great Lakes states had come to a moment of calm, glassy waters. It was 2008, and after years of negotiation, politicians in the eight states around the lakes had reached agreement on a compact that would protect their (and their Canadian counterparts’) precious fresh water from what they saw as one of the Midwest’s biggest threats: tapping from other, water-hungry regions.

headline: Former Gingrich Aide Joins Pro-Newt ‘Super PAC’
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – A day after Newt Gingrich forcefully denounced the proliferation of outside money into the Republican presidential race, one of his longtime aides announced that he was joining a group to help Mr. Gingrich win the party’s nomination.

headline: New Leader for Urban Institute
text: Sarah Rosen Wartell, a housing expert and economic policy analyst, will become the president of the Urban Institute in February, the Washington-based research organization said Tuesday.

headline: Wheelies: The Out of Range Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Dalton Trumbo’s Screenwriting Credit Restored to ‘Roman Holiday’
text: The whimsical secret of Audrey Hepburn’s royal status may be the heart of William Wyler‘s “Roman Holiday,” but for years the romantic comedy concealed another more troubling truth: the film was missing the screenwriting credit of Dalton Trumbo, the blacklisted writer and its original author, and instead attributed his work to Ian McLellan Hunter. Now, nearly 60 years after the 1953 release of “Roman Holiday,” the Writers Guild of America, West said it had restored Trumbo’s credit following the efforts of Trumbo’s and Hunter’s sons.

headline: Provincial Officials Meet Leader of Protesters Who Took Over Chinese Village
text: WUKAN, China — Senior officials from the coastal Guangdong Province in southern China met on Wednesday morning with a leader of the protesters who have taken control of this fishing village, ratcheting up efforts to resolve an incendiary dispute over secret land sales that forced the village’s administrators to flee 10 days ago.

headline: Jefferies Crows Over Surviving a Tough Fourth Quarter
text: Shares of the Jefferies Group surged nearly 23 percent on Tuesday as stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter results helped restore confidence in the investment bank after it had been whipsawed in recent months by worries over its exposure to Europe.

headline: Lego Goes After Girls
text: How gender-specific are the gifts you’ve bought for your kids this holiday? I give myself a B in this category this year. As usual, I set out to choose gifts for each child based on his or her interests and expressed desires — and, as usual, looking back over the list of what’s getting wrapped, I see that my oldest daughter has only one thing that you wouldn’t find in the pink section of any toy store, and while my tomboy younger daughter has only gifts you could easily give to any 6-year-old (except for the colorable cardboard princess castle her sister chose for her), I’ve still given the building toy that either of my youngest children would have liked to their brother without really thinking about it — until now.

headline: ‘Barbecue Diplomacy,’ North Korea and the United States
text: HACKENSACK, N.J. – Diners were chewing on pulled pork and baby back ribs here at Cubby’s barbecue restaurant on Sunday night when the owner, Robert Egan, learned that the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il, had died on Saturday of a heart attack.

headline: Judge Again Delays Plea in UBS Trader Case
text: LONDON — The case of Kweku M. Adoboli, the former UBS trader facing fraud charges related to a $2.3 billion loss, was postponed by a month on Tuesday after his new lawyer said Mr. Adoboli needed more legal advice.

headline: Answers to Reader Questions About Law School
text: On Sunday, The Times’s David Segal concluded a series of articles about the economics of law schools, with an article on the cover of Sunday Business, For Law Schools, a Price to Play the A.B.A.’s Way. The article notes that the American Bar Association’s rules for accreditation are a significant factor in the costs of legal education, which may in turn limit the availability of low-cost legal services.

headline: NBC Will Stream Super Bowl
text: 2:14 p.m. | Updated NBC announced Tuesday that it will stream Super Bowl XLVI live on Feb. 5 from Indianapolis, as well as its two wild card playoff games on Jan. 7 and the Pro Bowl on Jan. 29.

headline: One on One: Gary Shteyngart, Author of ‘Super Sad True Love Story’
text: Gary Shteyngart is the author of the novel “Super Sad True Love Story,” a love story set in the near future that has been weirdly prescient. Mr. Shteyngart, who was born in Leningrad, often writes about American culture with a comical and satirical bent.  The following is an edited version of our interview.

headline: 49ers Show They’re Contenders
text: The first glitch came when viewers realized “Monday Night Football” was staging a game they might actually want to watch. (And more stunningly, this will happen two weeks in a row. What, the Rams already had plans for next Monday?) Considering this incredible upset, ESPN hoped viewers did not tune in while Candlestick Park had gone black. Twice. It gave the distinct impression the N.F.L. did not want an appealing game to be staged Monday night and pulled a plug. Either that, or Jon Gruden’s relentless sunniness melted the fuses.

headline: Republican Candidates Have Presidential Pedigrees
text: Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts has been called the establishment candidate of the Republican presidential primary and is dominating the endorsement race so far. A look at his family tree may explain his perceived place among the presidents: he is related to six former commanders in chief.

headline: Finding a Safe Harbor in Male Identity
text: “Such a sweet little man,” remarks a guest at a shabby-genteel Dublin hotel, referring to a waiter named Albert Nobbs. One of Albert’s co-workers describes him, less kindly, as a “freak,” and there is certainly something odd about this elfin, diffident, ginger-haired fellow, who attends to his duties with fastidious care. He is not, indeed, a fellow at all, but a woman who has lived most of her life disguised as a man. And not just any woman: this self-effacing, cautious character, whose name is also the title of Rodrigo Garcia’s lively and touching new film, is played by the dazzling and infinitely resourceful Glenn Close.

headline: Mad as Hell
text: Ellen Goodman, the Boston Globe’s Pulitzer Prize-winning former columnist, now retired, is busy these days with something called the Conversation Project, one of many nascent efforts to make the rigors of caregiving and advanced old age into a kitchen-table issue — not just a topic for policy wonks and health care professionals.

headline: Hitchens and Hell
text: Remarking on the various Christians (myself included) who expressed a hope that Christopher Hitchens would be pleasantly surprised by his journey to the undiscovered country, HotAir’s Allahpundit asks a reasonable question:

headline: Vander Plaats Endorses Santorum
text: DE WITT, Iowa — Rick Santorum, who was the first Republican presidential hopeful to visit all 99 Iowa counties in a quest to gain traction for the party’s nomination, received a lift on Tuesday by collecting a highly coveted endorsement from Bob Vander Plaats, one of the most visible leaders of the Christian conservative movement.

headline: Yale and Columbia Reimburse Gay Employees for Extra Taxes
text: Two Ivy League universities will soon begin reimbursing some of its gay and lesbian employees for the extra taxes they incur when their partners are covered by their health insurance.Both Columbia and Yale University will begin covering these extra costs on Jan. 1.

headline: Standoff Over Payroll Tax Cut Leaves Wake of Uncertainty
text: WASHINGTON — After defiantly rejecting a Senate compromise to extend a payroll tax break and jobless pay, Speaker John A. Boehner stood before the television cameras on Tuesday enveloped by scores of House Republicans. Even as a group, they seemed very much alone.

headline: The Year in Media | Putting the Oscars Back Together Again
text: Staff members of The Times’s media news department are highlighting the most significant developments this year in the industries they cover.

headline: Sharing the Rat-Infested Bounty
text: Yesterday morning began with an alarming call from our mail room. They said they couldn’t deliver a package addressed to me because it had been chewed open by rats at the Post Office. Several other packages arrived at The Times yesterday in similarly ratty condition. So I alerted Andy Newman, our City Room bureau chief, who wrote this investigative piece.

headline: Arctic Methane: Is Catastrophe Imminent?
text: In my article over the weekend about the climate risks from buried Arctic carbon, I omitted any discussion of one issue that sometimes appears in the news: methane deposits under relatively shallow seawater near the coasts of Siberia, Canada and Alaska. It was a purposeful omission because my piece focused on carbon buried on land, which presents a climate risk if it eventually emerges as methane or carbon dioxide.

headline: The Adventures of Spielberg: An Interview
text: This year’s holiday movie season brings with it a double dose of family film fare from a director well-seasoned in the genre. Steven Spielberg, long the wearer of many hats in Hollywood, is one of the few filmmakers who could potentially find both box office and awards-season success with two films released within a week of each other. The first is his digitally animated adaptation of the Belgian comic book series “The Adventures of Tintin,” which opens Wednesday. The second is his adaptation of the children’s novel (and Tony Award-winning play) “War Horse,” opening Christmas Day.

headline: Weinstein Company Moving Ahead With ‘Finding Neverland’ Musical, Its First
text: The Weinstein Company, heavyweight producers in Hollywood, is moving ahead with development of its first stage musical, “Finding Neverland,” after staged readings of the script and score in London last week that executives deemed a success. Rob Ashford, the Broadway director and choreographer (“How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying”) who is directing the work, said in an interview that the story and structure of the musical “was in much stronger shape” than at the last reading about a year ago.

headline: Men Change (Products Do, Too)
text: NOT long ago, Thomas Sullivan’s beauty routine began and ended with Irish Spring. But as Mr. Sullivan, an entrepreneur, actor, film producer and restaurant owner, approached 40, he realized his livelihood might benefit from a bit more personal maintenance.

headline: Back to Lori Berenson
text: This morning, Lori Berenson returned to New York after 16 years abroad, much of it spent in Peruvian prisons after she was convicted of aiding terrorist groups there. Last August, after she was released on parole and adjusting to life outside prison with her infant son, the novelist/journalist Jennifer Egan traveled to Lima to profile her for the magazine.

headline: More Hungary
text: Kim Lane Scheppele sends me an update on the political situation, shown below the fold.

headline: In Richmond, a London Day Trip That Fits the Frugal Bill
text: A scheduling quirk had handed me 36 hours to kill in London while en route from Oxford, England, to Portugal — a happy proposition for anyone with deep pockets. Perhaps the braised rabbit at Michelin-starred St. John and an orchestra stall seat at the Royal Opera House before retiring to a suite at the Covent Garden?

headline: Pain on Dalal Street as Markets Sink
text: The mood on Dalal Street, India’s Wall Street, has been particularly dismal since Monday, when the Sensex index on the Bombay Stock Exchange’s sunk 112 points to 15,379 – its lowest level in approximately 28 months.

headline: Pathetic Plutocrats
text: One of the disadvantages of being very wealthy may be that you end up surrounded by sycophants, who will never, ever tell you what a fool you’re making of yourself. That’s the only way I can make sense of the farcical behavior of the wealthy described in this new report from Max Abelson:

headline: Riffs: The Year in Film: Bonus Materials
text: The magazine recently featured a roundup of short Riff essays on the year in film (mini-Riffs? Li’l Riffs? Riffkins? O.K., we’ll stop now). But, as with all good things, we collected more random and curious reflections on the year past than we could ever jam into our pages. So we present these Riffs as kind of DVD extras: Bonus Materials for you to enjoy.

headline: Have N.F.L. Questions? Judy Battista Has Answers
text: Do the Eagles have momentum? What has happened to Ryan Fitzpatrick and the Bills? Is Kyle Orton better than people think? Judy Battista, the N.F.L. reporter for The Times, will answer questions from readers. Use the comment field below for your questions. Answers will appear Thursday on The Fifth Down.

headline: Successful Spanish Debt Auction
text: PARIS — Spain’s borrowing costs plummeted Tuesday at a debt auction, helping to lift the euro and stocks, as the European Central Bank began rolling out a new lending program that could encourage banks to buy euro-zone government bonds.
