headline: Eagles’ Poor Start Was Only a Flesh Wound
text: In the classic Monty Python sketch “Upper-Class Twit of the Year,” a group of bumbling aristocrats compete on an obstacle course full of challenges both athletic (leaping over books of matches) and misanthropic (kicking beggars, insulting waiters). The competitor Oliver St. John-Mollusc, “thought by many to be this year’s outstanding twit,” somehow runs himself over with a convertible midway through the race. John Cleese, as the play-by-play announcer, later says of Oliver, “He’s dead, but he’s not necessarily out of it.”

headline: Tacos With Roasted Vegetables and Chickpeas in Chipotle Ranchera Salsa
text: These winter vegetables sweeten with roasting and contrast beautifully with the chipotle-spiked cooked tomato salsa. It’s another easy do-ahead dish that can be reheated when the crowds are hungry.

headline: All 5 Aboard Plane Die as It Crashes on an Interstate in New Jersey
text: A single-engine plane on its way to Atlanta spun out of control over northern New Jersey and crashed onto a busy highway on Tuesday, killing all five people aboard — two investment bankers, and the wife and two children of one of the bankers.

headline: Classic Stage Snaps Up Christina Ricci for ‘A Midsummer Night’s Dream’
text: If the idea of Christina Ricci joining Bebe Neuwirth in Classic Stage Company’s coming production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” isn’t sufficiently tantalizing on its face value, think of it as the coming together of extended members of the Addams Family.

headline: Cracker Barrel Claims Victory Over Activist Investor
text: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store announced on Tuesday that all of its directors had been re-elected, claiming victory over Sardar Biglari, the activist investor who had sought one seat on the board.

headline: Students and Staff Say Washington Irving Was Set Up to Fail
text: UPDATED | In what has become a common refrain in the closing schools debate, students, teachers and parents at Washington Irving High in Manhattan blamed the city for sending them some of the toughest students and looking away as the school staggered under their weight. But Marc Sternberg, the deputy chancellor for portfolio planning, responds: "Our obligation is to our students, and we are not going to set them up for failure by pretending a school will suddenly make progress after years of failing its kids."

headline: Students Win for Turning Lady Liberty Green
text: Two students at a gifted and talented middle school in Brooklyn dazzled the French with their award-winning works that link the Statue of Liberty to an environmental theme. One, Hale Sheffield, a seventh grader, won a grand prize of round-trip tickets for two to Paris.

headline: Reminder: The Choice Will Be Live on Facebook Tonight (and Wednesday and Thursday)
text: Are you a student (or parent of a student?) who is still scrambling to meet the Jan. 1 deadline at many colleges? Or, are you trying to determine how best to respond to (or recover from) an early admission ruling from last week? You’ve come to the right place.

headline: Soft Tacos With Mushrooms, Cabbage and Chipotle Ranchera Salsa
text: Two nutrient-dense vegetables combine forces in this delicious filling. Mushrooms are an excellent source of vitamins and many minerals, particularly selenium, copper, potassium, phosphorous, zinc, and manganese – and they contain a powerful antioxidant called L-ergothioneine. They’re used medicinally throughout Asia for their immunity-boosting properties. They also contain more protein than most other vegetables, and their meaty texture makes them a perfect choice for vegetarians. Cabbage possesses phytochemicals like sulforaphane, which protects the body against cancer-causing free radicals, and indoles, which help metabolize estrogens. It’s also an excellent source of vitamins K and C, and a very good source of  dietary fiber, vitamin B6, folate, manganese and omega-3 fatty acids.

headline: As City Closes In on 50 Millionth Visitor, British Couple to Be Feted
text: Updated 4:42 p.m. | Spending an hour or so with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in Times Square was not part of the plan that Craig Johnson and Lucy Foulger had laid out for their wedding day.

headline: As Deutsche Telekom Ponders Options, a New Deal Is Expected
text: BERLIN — Deutsche Telekom could move quickly to seal a new alliance with another American telecommunications operator for its T-Mobile USA subsidiary following the collapse of its planned sale to AT&T, analysts said on Tuesday.

headline: Early Line on Early Admissions
When a Small Retailer Shoots Itself in the Foot with a Weak Web Site
text: Last week, my post asked whether a small retailer can compete online with the big boys.

headline: Stonyfield Farm to Open Chelsea Piers Restaurant
text: Stonyfield Farm is about to make a leap from its well-established spot in the dairy aisle to a restaurant at Chelsea Piers. The prominent organic yogurt and milk company already has one cafe in Maine, and in April its new riverside location, at West 22nd Street, will open with mac and cheese, salads and flatbread sandwiches with ingredients from farms in New York State.

headline: Looking to Streamline Airport Security Screenings
text: Travelers in the midst of another holiday season of shuffling shoeless through seemingly interminable airport security lines may find it difficult to imagine a future where screenings are not only speedy but thorough.

headline: Two Earth-Size Planets Are Discovered
text: In what amounts to a kind of holiday gift to the cosmos, astronomers from NASA’s Kepler spacecraft announced Tuesday that they had discovered a pair of planets the size of Earth orbiting a distant star. The new planets, one about as big as Earth and the other slightly smaller than Venus, are the smallest yet found beyond the solar system.

headline: Greenhill Says 2 Executives Died in Plane Crash
text: 5:51 p.m. | Updated

headline: Tolerance for Intolerance Bruises Lowe’s
text: Poor Lowe’s. The do-it-yourself chain made room in their budget for TLC’s “All-American Muslim,” a reality show about life in the Muslim American community in Dearborn, Mich., but the company ended up catching some focus for supporting a show that depicted Muslims as something besides terrorists. As it turned out, the protest was hardly broad based, with most of it coming from one guy. Still, the Florida Family Association, as David Caton’s Web site is called, claimed 65 companies agreed to stop advertising on “All-America Muslim.” That didn’t turn out to be precisely true.

headline: Listen: SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast
text: The Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta talks New York area hockey with Brian Compton of NHL.com and the agent Jay Grossman from The Puck Agency in the SNY.tv Metro Hockey Podcast.

headline: Lady Gaga and Mary J. Blige Make Oscar’s Cut, but Not Madonna
text: It’s not quite a musical year-end best-of, but the Academy’s shortlist of 39 songs that could go on to win the Oscar has enough indie, pop, country, R&B and classical stars to make critics from Pitchfork to Pazz and Jop happy.

headline: HBO Renews ‘Enlightened’ but Cancels Three Other Shows
text: A pair of Golden Globe nominations for the HBO comedy “Enlightened” may have helped it earn a second season, but three other shows on that channel – “Hung,” “Bored to Death” and “How to Make It in America” – will not be ascending to another plane and have been canceled.

headline: Landmarks Commission Approves Puck Building Penthouse
text: After three months of back-and-forth negotiating with the landlord Jared Kushner, the Landmarks Preservation Commission gave its unanimous approval on Tuesday morning to Mr. Kushner’s proposal for a residential penthouse atop the Puck Building, at Houston and Lafayette Streets.

headline: Have N.H.L. Questions? Slap Shot Has Answers
text: Are the Canucks as good as they were last season? Can the Flyers maintain their momentum? What do the Rangers need to remain competitive? Will Coach Randy Cunneyworth make a difference in Montreal? Jeff Z. Klein, the N.H.L. reporter for the The Times, and Slap Shot contributor Christopher Botta will answer questions from readers. Use the comment field for your questions, and answers will appear on Slap Shot later this week.

headline: Q. and A. With William Berloni: Which Doggy in the Window?
text: Over the weekend, readers of Elissa Gootman’s recent article offered up their suggestions for the best dogs for apartment living. People expressed great affection for their dogs’ breeds. There was even a mini-ode. Reader advice ranged from corgis to greyhounds to, of course, cats.

headline: A 50-Year Racing Career, With No Checkered Flag in Sight
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. – The driving habits of senior citizens is a favorite conversation starter among Floridians. But those exchanges tend not to include the likes of James Harvey Hylton, 77, who borrowed a friend’s Ford on Sunday morning and drove it 175.634 miles per hour and later apologized for not going faster.

text: Images of a woman beaten by Egyptian soldiers sparks protests | A sectarian political rift in Iraq | Newt and Callista Gingrich's production company

headline: Polls Find G.O.P. Electorate in Flux
text: Two polls released on Tuesday further underscore the lack of commitment among many Republicans toward a particular presidential candidate, with results once again highlighting how unsettled this contest remains two weeks before Iowans cast the first votes.

headline: In Iowa, Gingrich Calls for an End to Negative Ads
text: MOUNT PLEASANT, Iowa — Newt Gingrich again sought to beat back the barrage of attack ads eroding his lead in Iowa by trying to shame his rivals into pulling them from the air.

headline: Fed Proposes New Capital Rules for Banks
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve on Tuesday proposed rules that would require the largest American banks to hold more capital — and to keep it more easily accessible — to protect against another financial crisis.

headline: Elizabeth Taylor’s Final Legacy
text: After the last diamond-encrusted bauble had been snatched up, the last item of Dior couture sold, the last Fendi handbag handed on to a new owner, the sale of Elizabeth Taylor’s vast collections netted $156.8 million. The four days of sales at Christie’s became the most valuable private jewelry sale in history ($137.2 million) and the most valuable private collection of fashion ever sold ($5.5 million). The first online-only Christie’s sale drew 57,000 bids and reaped $9.5 million. The complete collection sold out, a testament to both the star’s magnetism and the quality of the merchandise. All the proceeds benefit the Elizabeth Taylor Trust, which manages the Taylor estate.  Taylor was well-known in her later years for her fund-raising and activism for AIDS research. A portion of the profit generated by Christie’s sale of exhibition tickets (58,000 people saw the exhibit in its international travels), event  sponsorship and the ongoing sales of “select publications,” will be donated to the Elizabeth Taylor AIDS Foundation. The auction house also raised $170,00 through the sale of a deluxe limited edition boxed set of the catalogs on the first evening of the auction, which will also go to the foundation.  Some highlights from the later sales: those Vuitton trunks, with the violet-colored tags reading “Mine!” sold for $245,500, the top figure for the accessories sale. The Andy Warhol lithograph signed and dedicated by the artist went for $662,000. A (quite hideous) beaded Versace bolero jacket featuring rhinestone images of Taylor in some of her famous roles fetched $128,500. Even rocks Taylor never actually wore went for big sums: a large gray “scholar’s rock” netted $386,500, more than 30 times its estimate of $8,000 to $12,000. Christie’s will complete the dispersal of the Taylor collections in the new year with sales of her Old Master paintings (Jan. 25 in New York), including a Frans Hals portrait (not of Taylor), and her Impressionist and modern art collection (London, Feb. 7 and 8). Chris Wilding, Taylor’s son and a trustee of the foundation, said, “My mother always acknowledged that she was merely the temporary custodian of the incredible things she owned. Today, I think she would be happy to know that her collections will continue to enrich the lives of those who have acquired pieces.”

headline: The Romance of Iowa
text: Why should the Iowa caucuses, two weeks from tonight, be the first political event of 2012?

headline: What Iraqis Think of the American Withdrawal: Diyala Province

headline: A Shady American in the Nanjing Massacre
text: Eventually, it seems, every senseless waste of life gets its own gauzy tear-jerker. That’s about the only way to justify “The Flowers of War,” in which the veteran Chinese director Zhang Yimou revisits the Nanjing massacre of 1937 by making something resembling a backstage musical, with breaks for the occasional ghastly murder or rape.

headline: The Giving Spree | Bill Powers
text: Who: Bill Powers, who is the co-owner of Half Gallery and a judge on the Bravo reality show “Work of Art: The Next Great Artist.”What He’s Giving: “I bought this Rebecca Kolsrud painting for my wife, but it will probably wind up hanging in my daughter’s room. I saw it at Karma on Downing Street in a small exhibition called “Yackety Yack Girls.” It reminds me of early John Currin paintings and it hints at Martin Kippenberger somehow, too.

headline: Caucus Click: Perry’s Expanded Message
text: When Gov. Rick Perry of Texas entered the Republican presidential race four months ago, his bumper-sticker message (and the slogan painted on his bus) was “Get America Working Again.” Two weeks before the Iowa caucuses, his campaign bus, parked outside the historic Decker Hotel in Maquoketa, Iowa, on Tuesday, reflected how faith was central to his closing argument.

headline: After Resigning, Tearful Senator Pleads Guilty to Accepting Bribes
text: In the annals of municipal corruption in New York City, the themes of graft, greed and betrayal have been familiar running mates from one century to the next, accompanying the fall of the Tammany boss William Tweed in the 1870s, the resignation of the popular mayor James J. Walker in 1932, and the bribes, appetites and suicide of Donald R. Manes, a former Queens borough president, in 1986.

headline: Romney Says ‘Super PACs’ Have Been a ‘Disaster’
text: Visit msnbc.com for breaking news, world news, and news about the economy

headline: Revisiting North Korea’s Hunger Crisis
text: The death of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il comes not only at a time of political uncertainty, but also against a hunger crisis caused by storms and floods. This year, the Reuters photographer Damir Sagolj was part of a group of journalists invited by the government – itself a rare step — to document the emergency facing the country’s farm region. As Lens republishes his images today from a post in October, we asked him for an update.

headline: You Talking to Moi? It’s the French Travis Bickle
text: Every major filmmaker seems to be delivering his own ode to classic cinema this season and Michel Gondry is no exception. The French director of “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and “The Green Hornet” has paid homage to “Taxi Driver” by remaking it, DIY-style. In other words, sweding it — a phrase and a concept borrowed from his own 2008 film, “Be Kind Rewind.”

headline: Battlefield Earth
text: Have you ever had one of those days when the news is so disturbing it makes you want to sit quietly in a darkened room? Or if you’re a liberal, make a donation to Doctors Without Borders? Or if you’re a Republican, play golf? That’s how I feel today.

headline: Ohio State Receives One-Year Bowl Ban
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Ohio State’s football team will not play in the postseason next year, and the program will lose nine scholarships over the next three years as a result of a scandal that cost Coach Jim Tressel his job in the spring.

headline: Forcella in NoHo, Pizza, Fired and Fried
text: GIULIO Adriani is still trying to make his mark on New York. Mr. Adriani, an Italian pizzaiolo, seemed ready to teach the city a thing or two about authentic Naples-style pizza when he appeared on the scene last year — here was a man with four pizza world championships under his belt, a blistering-hot wood-burning oven and a chef’s coat with his name stitched on the back just in case you forgot who was working the peel.

headline: Mixing Hanukkah and Christmas
text: It seemed like a good idea at the time, it really did. Nine years ago, when my oldest son was about 18 months old, my mother gave us a menorah shaped like a train, and I bought candles, and insisted to my husband that we light them.

headline: Mulled Wine Fumigates a Foul Recollection
text: LOVE might be blind, but that doesn’t mean it holds its nose. At least, not in the case of me, my then-boyfriend, a bloated can of surstromming (fermented herring) and a Christmas party so many years ago.

headline: Turkey Detains Dozens Accused of Having Links to a Kurdish Group
text: ISTANBUL — The police detained at least 38 people, many of them journalists, in dawn raids across Turkey on Tuesday as part of an investigation into a network accused of being the political wing of an outlawed Kurdish separatist rebel group.

text: Two of the N.B.A.’s better players since the mid-’90s, the sharpshooter Peja Stojakovic and the big man Antonio McDyess, are ending their careers.

headline: Samsung Hard Drives Now Belong to Seagate
text: Seagate Technology, a major maker of hard drives, said Tuesday that it had closed on the acquisition of the hard drive business of Samsung Electronics for $1.4 billion.

headline: The Get | Stella McCartney Hawaiian Print Jeans
text: As part of her Hawaii-inspired resort collection, Stella McCartney is introducing a number of denim pieces subtly printed with tropical palm trees, the effect of which is similar to –– but much more innovative and exciting than –– acid wash or tie-dye. Available in early January when the designer is scheduled to open two new stores, one in Miami at the Bal Harbour Shops and the other on Greene Street in Soho, the jacket and blue jeans seen here are as ready for sunny South Beach as they are the chilly streets of the Northeast. “Denim is something that’s already ingrained in everyone’s wardrobe,” says McCartney, “so we played with it to give it a new twist.” Aloha!

headline: Vevo, a Music Video Web Site, Wants to Get Into Television
text: In yet another example of the muddying of media categories, Vevo, the music video Web site set up by the two largest record companies is in talks with cable carriers to become a TV channel.

headline: Benton Harbor: An Addendum by Chris Savage
text: While I was in Benton Harbor, Mich., reporting this week’s cover article, I met a guy named Chris Savage and his wife one night for some pizza and beer. (We also went the beach and watched a pretty spectacular sunset on Lake Michigan.)

headline: BrightScope’s Top-Rated 401(k) Plans for 2011
text: Retirement would be a lot easier if all companies were as generous as Southwest Airlines is to its pilots.

headline: Miso-and-Apple-Glazed Baked Ham
text: Adapted from Paul Kahan

headline: Losing Friends on Facebook
text: Wondering why a friend or acquaintance “defriended” you on Facebook?

headline: The Benefits of Incorporating Abroad in an Age of Globalization
text: Michael Kors Holdings not only sells fashion that people crave, it has also offered shares that were a hit with investors. The company’s shareholders, including the designer himself, sold about $944 million worth of stock last week in an initial public offering that valued the company at about $4 billion.

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Korea, Egypt, the Philippines and India.

headline: Vera on Ice
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Sleep Problems in Police Officers Take Heavy Toll
text: More than a third of police officers have a sleep disorder, and those who do are more likely to experience heart disease, problems with job performance and rage toward suspects and citizens, a new study suggests.

headline: ‘Magic’ and Marvel on Broadway
text: “Magic/Bird” has its Magic. The actor Kevin Daniels will play Earvin “Magic” Johnson, the Los Angeles Lakers point guard, in Eric Simonson’s basketball-themed play “Magic/Bird,” which is aiming to open in the spring of 2012 at a Broadway theater still to be determined.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Egypt, North Korea, Philippines and India.

headline: Two Lonely People Fumbling for Love
text: “Kissing Sid James” is a very funny 80-minute play. Trouble is, it runs nearly two hours. A comedy about a lonely man and woman who spend a weekend together, the script hits its mark early and often. Yet shortly into the second act the humor begins to get recycled, and even the excellent cast can’t keep you from wishing that the writer had wrapped things up while his audience was laughing away.

headline: New York Plans Greener Zoning Rules
text: Next month community boards around New York City will ring in the year by holding hearings on a proposal that city officials say will give buildings more freedom to increase their energy efficiency and produce their own power.

headline: Reviewing Lupa
text: Most of the time for me, it’s all about the food. I can tolerate a fair amount of discomfort, indignities or inconvenience if a restaurant is serving food that is good enough, and unusual enough, to make it worth my while.

headline: Former Bishop Will Meet With Irish Abuse Victims
text: DUBLIN — A senior Roman Catholic prelate in Ireland said Tuesday that the church would arrange for victims of clergy sexual abuse in one diocese to meet with the bishop who was in charge of it when hundreds of abuse complaints were kept secret.

headline: An Osteria Competes With Its Past
text: IT’S dinner time, yet entering Lupa, the Roman-style osteria opened in 1999 by the team of Mario Batali and Joe Bastianich, is about as joyous an experience as trying to squeeze onto the subway at rush hour. You know you will be bumped and jostled, but you don’t know which direction it will come from.

headline: Seagate and Western Digital Reduce Warranties for Some Hard Drives
text: Seagate and Western Digital, which supply hard drives to most of the major computer brands, will soon reduce warranty coverage on several of their storage devices.

headline: First-Place Flyers Are Coping With Various Head Injuries
text: PHILADELPHIA — A standing-room-only crowd had already been forced to absorb an uncharacteristically merciless drubbing of the beloved Philadelphia Flyers on Saturday afternoon when a jarring replay flashed on the big screens above the ice late in the second period.

headline: With a Nod to Nowitzki, Durant Makes a Move
text: On Sunday night, in an otherwise pedestrian preseason game against the Dallas Mavericks, Kevin Durant saw an opportunity to showcase a new toy. After a switched screen pitted Durant against the far smaller Delonte West in the right midpost, Durant went to work with a familiar move:

headline: The Caucus Click: An Unconventional Endorsement
text: The Web site AshleyMadison.com, which offers a dating service for people who are already married, put up a billboard with Newt Gingrich’s picture in Bucks County, Pa.

headline: U.S. General in Afghanistan Says Troops May Stay Past 2014
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The senior American commander in Afghanistan suggested Tuesday that American forces could remain in the country beyond 2014 despite previous signals from President Obama that the bulk of troops would be withdrawn by then. The commander’s remarks amounted to the most emphatic signal to date that the United States military intended to secure a presence here, possibly for years.

headline: Gingrich Heads to Virginia for Ballot Push
text: The Virginia presidential primary is not until March 6, but Newt Gingrich is suddenly veering off the campaign trail and heading there Wednesday with urgent business: get on the ballot. The deadline is Thursday.

headline: Survey Suggests Tough Economy Is Claiming Another Victim: Regular Car Maintenance
text: Car owners who are delaying automotive maintenance have plenty of company, according to a recent poll by Consumer Reports.

headline: Last-Minute Holiday Loot for the Drinking Sort
text: I nearly set to weeping when I found a copy of the gorgeous, lavishly illustrated 1933 edition of “The Savoy Cocktail Book” at my favorite used bookshop (Dog Ears, in Hoosick Falls, N.Y.) last month. The $50 price was right (I’ve seen it listed for much more), but still a splurge, by my standards. So I considered it an early Christmas present — to myself. Any cocktail lover would be thrilled to receive such a gift, but there are easier gets that are also sure to delight.

headline: Channel Surfing: ‘Who’s Still Standing?’
text: Sure, it’s the season of joy and giving, but can’t we also spend a few moments cheering like Romans in the arena hoping to see someone plummet through the floor to a grisly, ignominious end?

headline: Chasing Sarah Palin
text: Here’s our story so far: Sarah Palin is picked to run for vice president, builds up a big fan club of disgruntled, right wing Americans and loses. She returns briefly to Alaska, but then finds the job of running a state that lives off federal dollars and oil revenue too taxing and not nearly lucrative enough. She quits, writes a smash best seller, charges who knows what for public appearances, and keeps her celebrity going by pretending for a while to be thinking about running for president.

headline: A Learning Curve as Developers Do Business in China
text: With the slowdown in commercial building in the United States, some American developers are planning projects in China, hoping to capitalize on an immense, increasingly urbanized market with a rising middle class. In recent years, annual consumer spending has been growing by about 18 percent.

headline: Protesters in Wukan Insist on Rights
text: Senior officials from coastal Guangdong Province in south China plan to meet Wednesday morning with protesters who have taken control of Wukan village.

headline: TimesCast | Iraq's Political Rift
text: December 20, 2011 - Days after the American withdrawal, Iraq's Sunni vice president denies he ordered political assassinations, attributing the accusation to sectarian political divide.

headline: TimesCast | Anger Over Tahrir Beating
text: December 20, 2011 - Thousands of women march in Cairo, sparked by the weekend beating of female protester in Tahrir Square.

headline: Sex, Drugs and E Chords While Seeking Remission
text: It would be possible to praise Joshua Cody’s memoir, “[sic],” without talking about how teeming it is with what Kingsley Amis liked to call E.S.D. — explicit sexual description. But why would you want to?

headline: Perry Dismisses Gingrich’s Complaint of ‘Negative’ Campaigning
text: DE WITT, Iowa – Gov. Rick Perry of Texas said Tuesday that he was not concerned by a complaint from a Republican rival, Newt Gingrich, that the tenor of the presidential primary race had grown too negative and indicated that he had no plans to stop drawing contrasts in the final two weeks before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Liverpool’s Suárez Suspended and Fined
text: Luis Suárez, Liverpool’s top scorer this season in the English Premier League, was suspended eight games and fined $62,000 Tuesday by the English Football Association. The F.A. found Suárez guilty of racially abusing Manchester United’s Patrice Evra on Oct. 15 in a game that ended in a 1-1 tie at Liverpool’s Anfield stadium.

headline: Intrepid Boy on the Trail of Mysteries
text: Before Indiana Jones cracked his bullwhip for some old-fashioned Hollywood fun, Tintin circled the globe in the name of European divertissement. The pen-and-ink creation of the Belgian cartoonist Georges Remi (1907-83), known better as Hergé, Tintin is the charming boy reporter and adventurer who, with his white fox terrier Snowy close at heel, has traveled the world since 1929 in action-packed yarns with titles like “Cigars of the Pharaoh.” It was only a matter of time before Tintin went Hollywood. And, yowza, has he hit it big and hard in “The Adventures of Tintin,” a marvel of gee-wizardry and a night’s entertainment that can feel like a lifetime.

headline: Mozart’s Renovations to Handel’s ‘Messiah’
text: Bringing freshness, let alone novelty, to a performance of Handel’s “Messiah” is a challenge. But the Oratorio Society of New York, under its music director, Kent Tritle, certainly did so on Monday night at Carnegie Hall with a vibrant performance of the piece in the seldom-heard arrangement by Mozart. How this fascinating version of the work came to be says much about the general attitudes toward past masters in Mozart’s day. There are lessons in this story and in Monday’s performance for hard-liners in the early-music movement.

headline: Oh Danny Boy, the Pipes, the Pipes Are Failing
text: A new report by the American Society of Civil Engineers takes a dim view of the state of the country’s 54,000 community-based drinking-water systems and its 15,000 public wastewater treatment facilities. The systems are rusty, aging and seriously inadequate for meeting future needs, the study warns.

headline: Specialty REITs, Exploiting Niche Categories, Outperform the Mainstream Players
text: Real estate investment trusts, or REITs, have largely outperformed other investment vehicles in the sluggish economy of the last few years. But one subset — “specialty” trusts that invest in real estate other than the four major groups of office, retail, residential and industrial — has been exceptionally solid.

headline: Councilman’s Aide in a Santa Suit, Wearing a Punk-Rock Past
text: Santa had a few minutes to kill before a holiday party the other evening, so he pulled up his sleeves and showed off some of his tattoos: a dragon, a sailboat and, inked across the nape of his neck, the phrase, “Meat Is Murder.”

headline: Brooklyn Student Stabbed in Head With Scissors
text: A 16-year-old student was in custody on Tuesday after the authorities said he repeatedly stabbed another student in the head with a pair of scissors in a Brooklyn high school gym.

headline: Beauty Spots
text: The holidays make it especially difficult to avoid sweets. Here are three ways to enjoy the essence of chocolate, without the calories.

headline: The Campster | Gifts for Campers
text: Jeff Thrope, who stakes out sublime weekend excursions in The Campster, recommends holiday gifts for city-dwelling campers.

headline: Songwriters Group Backs Village People Singer in Rights Case
text: The Songwriters Guild of America has entered a legal battle between Victor Willis, the lead singer of the Village People, and the publishing company that owns the copyrights to the group’s songs, saying the case is an important test of a songwriters’ right to regain control of his or her work after 35 years.

headline: Reviewing Forcella
text: With only an oven, Giulio Adriani established his reputation as a pizzaiolo in Italy and at Olio Pizza e Più in Greenwich Village. Now, at Forcella, Mr. Adriani has a fryer, too. With it, he creates his montanara pizza, a margherita with a crust flash-fried before being finished in a wood-burning oven. The crust has a crisp airiness, not to mention a thin coat of oil that has the naughty pleasure of street food; the oven gives it color and adds a little smoke. Other pizzas on the menu aren’t up to the montanara’s caliber, but you’ll do well with the classics.

headline: Piers Morgan’s B-Sides
text: Piers Morgan, appearing somewhat magisterially on video from Los Angeles before the Leveson Committee of the British Parliament, spent a rugged hour getting grilled. Mr. Morgan proved to be a good witness on his own behalf, answering narrowly and carefully about what he knew about hacking and when he knew it.

headline: China Chow, With a Look of Her Own Making
text: IF China Chow’s eyes were a little glazed over during a walk-through of the Maccarone gallery in the far West Village last week, it wasn’t because she had had her fill of art babble this fall as the host and a judge of “Work of Art: The Next Great Artist” on Bravo.

headline: Epicurious Offers 75 Random House Cookbooks Online
text: The digital cookbook has been given a new format that makes consulting it closer to handling a printed book, going page by page instead of the kind of flowing format provided for some eBook readers.

headline: Information’s Deadly Price: A Dangerous Year for Journalists
text: This is the time of year when you will read a lot of roundups of media news, but one thing  that usually doesn’t make those lists is the high price of getting some of the toughest stories.

headline: Seeing Terror Risk, U.S. Asks Journals to Cut Flu Study Facts
text: For the first time ever, a government advisory board is asking scientific journals not to publish details of certain biomedical experiments, for fear that the information could be used by terrorists to create deadly viruses and touch off epidemics.

headline: Gingrich Calls Romney ‘Dishonest’ on PAC Ads
text: OTTUMWA, Iowa — Newt Gingrich’s counteroffensive against the negative ads that have eaten away at his surge in the polls reached a new level of intensity Tuesday afternoon when he called Mitt Romney “purely dishonest.”

headline: Live Music to Return to a Storied Theater
text: PORT CHESTER, N.Y. — In the early-1970s heyday of the Capitol Theater here there were appearances by the likes of Traffic, Jefferson Airplane, Pink Floyd and Santana. The Grateful Dead logged 18 shows over an 11-month period, and Janis Joplin played her next-to-last show at the Capitol on Aug. 8, 1970, two months before she died.

headline: A Rhetorical Return for ‘YOYO’ Economics
text: Just in time for the presidential campaign season, “you’re on your own” economics — a k a YOYO — has returned to the rhetorical landscape.

headline: Concert Ranges From Happy to Happier
text: “This year, my career took an interesting turn,” the soprano Lauren Flanigan said from the stage as she greeted an admiring throng at Symphony Space on Monday evening. “Rather than murder my numerous husbands onstage, I murdered a child.” The ensuing ripple of laughter from the hall had an uncertain edge. “I know,” Ms. Flanigan continued. “I wasn’t drunk, either. I did it all by myself.”

headline: A Second Home in the Dry Valleys
text: Alia Khan, a graduate student at the University of Colorado, Boulder, writes from the McMurdo Dry Valleys in Antarctica, where she is studying ephemeral glacier-fed streams.

headline: Q&A: Turning On Windows Update
text: Q. Where do I check to make sure Windows 7 is set to automatically download and install all the new software updates from Microsoft?

headline: Climate Change and the Environment
text: To the Editor:

headline: Men Aging Gracefully
text: To the Editor:

headline: Jack Foster
text: Mr. Foster, 54, is a managing director and head of Franklin Templeton Real Asset Advisors, which is based in New York and invests in real estate stocks and funds. Real Asset Advisors is a division of Franklin Resources, based in San Mateo, Calif. Mr. Foster joined Franklin Templeton in 1987.

headline: Less Likelihood of War?
text: To the Editor:

headline: China’s High Trade Barriers
text: To the Editor:

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Counting Google+ and Facebook’s New Home
text: Here’s what the reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web. For the full list, look over to the right-hand column.

headline: Overhauling the George Washington Bridge
text: To the Editor:

headline: Nurses Accuse Equity Firm of Cutting Patient Care
text: Instead of the inflatable rat that has become ho-hum at union protests in New York, a giant three-headed dog with fangs was the effigy on display as about 250 unionized nurses rallied outside the Midtown headquarters of the private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management.

headline: Sea Scallops With Cider Glaze and Cauliflower Two Ways
text: Adapted from Floyd Cardoz, North End Grill, Manhattan

headline: An Indian Star Switches Cuisines
text: FOR the men in hard hats wielding drills, yelling into their phones or at one another, the hubbub was business as usual. But for the man with the wordless expression of joy and anticipation — the kind of face you see on Christmas morning or at a sonogram reading — this was something different.

headline: Dining Calendar: Feasting on Fish
text: The traditional Italian Christmas Eve dinner, the Feast of the Seven Fishes, is not exactly Mother’s Day, but it gets close, with special fish dinners all over town and not just at Italian restaurants. Here are some choices on and around Dec. 24 (prices do not include beverages, tax or tip).

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: Harlem Shambles, a Butcher Shop, Opens Uptown
text: Wonder why a new uptown butcher is called Harlem Shambles? The noun shamble comes from an old word for butcher shop. Timothy Forrester, who owns this bright, spacious store with his brother, Mark, brings in carcasses from local farms and does all the butchering on the premises. Everything is grass-fed and antibiotic- and hormone-free. Dry-aging is evident in the look of the deeply crimson beef; a boneless strip steak was tender, with beefy flavor.

headline: A Roast Goose Ready to Serve at Christmas
text: If Christmas brings to mind Charles Dickens and ye merry gentlemen, then dinner must be roast goose. You can let Christopher Parks, the executive chef at Guilty Goose, a brasserie-style restaurant, take care of the succulent, beautifully burnished free-range bird, with gravy and an earthy, winy dressing of brioche, goose sausage, bacon, raisins, apples and a whiff of sherry. Roasted brussels sprouts, squash purée, corn bread and, for dessert, apple crumble tart, are included in the dinner to go. Everything is easily reheated, unless, like the late Elizabeth David, you prefer your roast goose cold. Roast goose is also an Eastern European dish for Hanukkah.

headline: Jeni’s Ice Cream in Holiday Flavors
text: Jeni’s Splendid Ice Creams, a company whose particularly alluring products are worth ordering from Columbus, Ohio, has introduced new flavors, most with seasonal spicing and a touch of spirit, to embellish a holiday party. Boozy eggnog, goat cheese with Cognac figs, smoked tea and plum pudding, vanilla cedarwood and black currant lambic sorbet are some of the winners among 11 options. Dark chocolate peppermint is not so unusual, but Jeni’s is intense. Some flavors were less appealing: the marshmallow bits in the sweet potato ice cream were a tad rubbery, and the cake crumbs in the Black Forest made the texture grainy.

headline: In North Korea, an Outpouring of Grief
text: Pictures of mourning from North Korea show a blend of compulsory emotion, cultural expressions of loss and sincere, spontaneous outbursts of grief.

headline: North Korea’s Tears: A Blend of Cult, Culture and Coercion
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Among countless mourners at a public square in North Korea,  the kneeling middle-aged man in an off-white windbreaker stands out. The state broadcaster’s camera zooms in as he wails, rocking back and forth with clenched fists, his grief punctuated by the white puffs of his breath visible in the cold of the capital, Pyongyang.

headline: Abandoned Homes of the Antebellum South
text: How Mississippi’s abandoned antebellum mansions give insight into the Civil War.

headline: Kayak iPad App Now Reserves Cars and Plans Trips
text: Kayak, the plane-booking service, released an upgrade on Tuesday for its iPad app, adding car reservation and trip-planning tools while introducing a brand-new design.

headline: Living With Multiple Sclerosis, and Separated From the World by a Stairway
text: Twenty-one steps keep Diane Kessler a virtual prisoner in her home.

headline: League to Add Independent Trainer at Each Game to Check for Concussions
text: The N.F.L., reacting to the Cleveland Browns’ treatment of quarterback Colt McCoy after he was hit on the head during a game Dec. 8, will pay for a certified trainer who is not affiliated with either team to be at each game to assist in spotting and checking for concussions.

headline: Explaining Obama’s Approval Rating Bounce
text: President Obama has seen improved approval ratings in the past few weeks. His approval rating in the average of six polls tracked by Real Clear Politics now stands at 46.5 percent. That’s the highest the figure has been since July, and is up from a low of about 42 percent in early October.

headline: An Uneasy Search for Truth as Ghosts From Military Rule Start to Stir
text: BRASÍLIA — After years of wrangling with the nation’s military hierarchy, the authorities here have created a truth commission to examine the abuses of Brazil’s long dictatorship, a move hailed as a sign that Brazil could be ready for a more active role against rights abuses, not just at home but globally as well.

headline: In Canada, a Car Built in China
text: DETROIT — Chinese-made cars have quietly arrived in North America for the first time, but without the bamboo dashboards and quirky names that have adorned them at recent auto shows.

headline: Ohio: 12 in Amish Sect Charged With Hate Crimes
text: A federal grand jury in Cleveland indicted 10 men and two women from a renegade Amish sect on hate crime and assault charges in an attack on Amish rivals in which their beards and hair were shorn off, a form of religious humiliation. The sect leader, Samuel Mullet Sr., and six others were arrested in November and remain jailed. On Tuesday, those men and five other people were formally charged. According to the indictment, Mr. Mullet beat some of the rivals and forced their wives to have sex with him. The rivals had fled from Mr. Mullet’s community in Bergholz, Ohio, or had criticized the sect.

headline: Jurors Need to Know That They Can Say No
text: Washington

headline: Mitt Romney's 'Closing Argument'
text: From a Speech in Bedford, New Hampshire

headline: A Piecemeal Approach to Health Law in States
text: The Obama administration’s surprise announcement Friday that it planned to give states broad leeway to pick the benefits offered under the federal health care law offers yet another example of a gradualist approach to carrying out its signal domestic policy achievement.

headline: In New Guidelines, Officials Affirm That State’s Family Courts Are Open to Public
text: New York’s top court officials issued new guidelines this week declaring that Family Courts across the state are open to the public, restating a rule issued 14 years ago but sometimes not followed by the courts themselves.

headline: Darvish Could Provide the Strike the Rangers Need
text: Picture this scene, which could play out in two months at a spring training complex in Surprise, Ariz. Japan’s best pitcher, Yu Darvish, climbs a mound for his first bullpen session with the Texas Rangers. Among those watching are Nolan Ryan, the man with the most strikeouts in baseball history, and Greg Maddux, the man with the most major league victories of anybody alive.

headline: A Fight to Make Banks More Prudent
text: FRANKFURT — For Philipp M. Hildebrand, it was a reminder of what happens when you get between bankers and their bonuses.

headline: Rick Perry on His 'Outsider' Status
text: Rick Perry casts Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney as “insiders” at a campaign stop in Iowa.

headline: Egypt’s Military Masters
text: Five days of violent clashes between Egyptian soldiers and protesters have produced appalling images of cruelty and abuse — including a video showing soldiers stripping the abaya off a woman on the ground to reveal her blue bra as one raises a boot to stomp on her.

headline: Mets Drop Minor League Team
text: The financially troubled Mets announced Tuesday that they were eliminating their minor league team in the Class A Gulf Coast League. That move could save them between $750,000 and $800,000, according to executives with other franchises who are familiar with the cost of running those teams.

headline: Gifts for Non-Cooks
text: Americans spend less time cooking than anyone, and the amount we “cook” — some people count microwaving a pizza — has been on a long, slow decline. The reasons for this decline are varied and complex, but an increase in the average of both hours worked and television watched, coupled with the marketing of “convenience” foods, have turned cooking from a sometimes-pleasurable necessity into, for many people, an ominous-seeming choice.

headline: For Illegal Immigrant, Line Is Drawn at Transplant
text: Without treatment to replace his failing kidneys, doctors knew, the man in Bellevue hospital would die. He was a waiter in his early 30s, a husband and father of two, so well liked at the Manhattan restaurant where he had worked for a decade that everyone from the customers to the dishwasher was donating money to help his family.

headline: Video of Egyptian Women’s March in Cairo
text: As my colleague David Kirkpatrick reports, “Thousands of women marched through downtown Cairo on Tuesday evening to call for the end of military rule in an extraordinary expression of anger over images of soldiers beating, stripping and kicking a female demonstrator on the pavement of Tahrir Square.”

headline: Fish Seller Settles Harassment Suit Brought by Black Workers
text: The fishmonger M. Slavin and Sons, the company with the familiar “Eat Fish Live Longer” delivery trucks, has agreed to pay $900,000 to 31 black workers to settle a discrimination suit brought by the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.

headline: Kim Jong-il, the Sportsman
text: In the political world, Kim Jong-il of North Korea was a despot and nuclear antagonist. In the sporting world, he might have been the only guy ever to wear platform shoes, a bouffant hairdo and “Dear Leader” embroidered on his bowling shirt.

headline: Last Witness for Military Takes Stand in Leak Case
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The government’s arguments in the case against Pfc. Bradley Manning came to a dramatic conclusion Tuesday when the computer hacker who turned him in to the authorities took the stand to explain his role in the investigation, revealing at one point that he was simultaneously trading computer messages with Private Manning while sharing information from those chats with the authorities.

headline: Why ‘Solutions Journalism’ Matters, Too
text: This is a follow-up to last Friday’s column revisiting social change organizations that grew in 2011.

headline: 3 Million Could Lose Jobless Pay in Impasse
text: WASHINGTON — More than three million people stand to lose unemployment insurance benefits in the near future because of an impasse in Congress over how to extend the aid and how to offset the cost.

headline: The Jets’ Players Are Asking Themselves: Is This a Rivalry Game?
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — It happens every summer, a preseason matchup between the Jets and the Giants that allows one set of fans to brag about a victory that does not count. The elation might last an hour or two, replaced by visions of winning the games that matter against the teams that matter: Philadelphia and Dallas for the Giants, New England and Miami for the Jets.

headline: Remembering ’08 Fizzle, Romney Puts Added Emphasis on New Hampshire
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — Over the next week, as most of the Republican presidential candidates barnstorm Iowa, Mitt Romney will rumble across New Hampshire on his most elaborate campaign swing of the election: a three-day, nine-town bus tour that his campaign has nicknamed “Earn It.”

headline: Philadelphia Sportswriter Accused of Child Molestation
text: PHILADELPHIA — A prominent Philadelphia sportswriter abruptly retired Tuesday as three women and one man accused him of sexually molesting them when they were children in the 1970s, according to an investigation by The Philadelphia Inquirer.

headline: How Do You Prove You’re an Indian?
text: Los Angeles

headline: Amazon Makes the Fire Less Balky
text: The Kindle Fire, Amazon’s color touchscreen tablet, is flying off the virtual shelves, the company says. Its price tag is $200 — and that’s all many consumers think they need to know.

headline: E-Mail Clues in Tracking MF Global Client Funds
text: Federal authorities investigating the collapse of MF Global have uncovered e-mails that detail the transfers of money in the firm’s last days, including transfers that contained customer money, according to people close to the investigation.

headline: For Gingrich in Power, Pragmatism, Not Purity
Microsoft Follows Apple With Victory Against Android
text: Another day, another legal win by a member of the anti-Android axis.

headline: New York Mets Summary Term Sheet
text: An early version of the offer the owners of the Mets made to potential investors. Team officials would not say if any of the terms of the offering had changed over time.

headline: Georgia Judge Accused of Misconduct Will Resign
text: ATLANTA — In her courtroom in Brunswick, Ga., Judge Amanda F. Williams told lawyers to “sit down and shut up.” She once jailed a defendant for using the words “baby momma.” And she detained offenders “indefinitely” without access to lawyers, state judicial investigators say.

headline: $20 Million Can Buy Quality Time With Mr. Met
text: It is, understandably, not the easiest sell: $20 million to own a small, noncontrolling interest in a baseball team renowned of late for losing — on the field and at the gate.

headline: Where Communists See an Opening, Many Russians See a Closed Door
text: MOSCOW — If there was ever a moment for a Communist comeback, it would seem to be now.

headline: The End, for Now
text: With the withdrawal of the last U.S. troops from Iraq, we’re finally going to get the answer to the core question about that country: Was Iraq the way Iraq was because Saddam was the way Saddam was, or was Saddam the way Saddam was because Iraq is the way Iraq is — a collection of sects and tribes unable to live together except under an iron fist. Now we’re going to get the answer because both the internal iron fist that held Iraq together (Saddam Hussein) and the external iron fist (the U.S. armed forces) have been removed. Now we will see whether Iraqis can govern themselves in a decent manner that will enable their society to progress — or end up with a new iron fist. You have to hope for the best because so much is riding on it, but the early signs are worrying.

headline: Recalling 1988, When Jets Dashed Giants’ Hopes
text: There are precious few pivotal moments in Giants-Jets history, mostly because a majority of the meetings between the teams — particularly in recent years — have been casual preseason games, listless affairs that had about as much substance as a lecture on the last day of school.

headline: Putting Paychecks at Risk
text: If the House had actually voted on Tuesday on the two-month extension of the payroll tax cut in the Senate’s bill, there is a chance that it would have passed. There is a chance a truly ugly legislative wreck could have been avoided and that the take-home pay of 160 million workers would not be reduced in less than two weeks.

headline: Who Controls Montana’s Rivers?
text: The Great Falls Reach of the Upper Missouri River in Montana cannot be navigated by boat. In that 17-mile stretch, as Lewis and Clark documented in 1805, the river cascades down nine waterfalls. The explorers’ journals are evidence in a Supreme Court case that turns on whether the Missouri and two other rivers were navigable in 1889 when Montana became the 41st state.

headline: F.C.C. Judge Rules for Tennis Channel in Dispute With Comcast
text: For years, the Tennis Channel has hungered to be watched as broadly nationwide as other sports channels.

headline: As Further Sanctions Loom, Plunge in Currency’s Value Unsettles Iran
text: Iran’s currency, the rial, tumbled in value to its lowest level ever against the dollar on Tuesday in panic selling caused in part by the country’s increased economic isolation from international sanctions, an unbridled inflation problem and worries that government officials there are ideologically incapable of devising a workable solution.

headline: Deal Struck to Broaden Taxi Service in the City
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo struck a deal with the Bloomberg administration on Tuesday that would expand taxi service in New York by allowing livery cabs to be hailed on the street in parts of the city traditionally underserved by yellow cabs.

headline: Iraq’s Sunni Vice President Denies Ordering Killings
text: Tuesday’s TimesCast video looks at developments in the deepening political crisis in Iraq. Stephen Farrell reports that the country’s Sunni vice president, Tariq al-Hashimi, strongly rebutted accusations by the Shiite-led central government that he had ordered the assassinations of government officials. Mr. Hashimi then accused the government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of using security forces to persecute political opponents.

headline: Few Options for Lagging T-Mobile

text: WASHINGTON — An assertion by Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta that Iran could have a nuclear weapon as soon as next year was based on a highly aggressive timeline and a series of actions that Iran has not yet taken, senior Pentagon officials said Tuesday.

headline: Wednesday: Tomé or Not Tomé?
text: Administrivial Update! Happy 98th Birthday to the American-style crossword! Journalist Arthur Wynne, who is usually credited with inventing a prototype of the pastime that would spawn millions of addicts, published the first crossed-words game on December 21, 1913 in a Sunday newspaper called the New York World. Read more about the beginnings of your favorite pastime here, and don’t forget to celebrate with a PETIT FOUR made from OLEO.

He was 67.

headline: Norman Krim, Who Championed the Transistor, Dies at 98
text: Norman Krim, an electronics visionary who played a pivotal role in the industry’s transition from the bulky electron vacuum tube, which once lined the innards of radios and televisions, to the tiny, far more powerful transistor, died on Dec. 14 in a retirement home in Newton, Mass. He was 98.

headline: Somalia: Soldiers From Djibouti Arrive
text: A long-awaited contingent of soldiers from Djibouti arrived in Mogadishu, Somalia’s capital, on Tuesday to join the African Union peacekeeping force. After a few hours of confusion about where the Djiboutians would be based, about 200 soldiers wearing helmets and flak jackets marched off the plane and headed to a camp along the ocean. Djibouti had promised for years to send peacekeepers to Somalia. It is the third country to contribute combat units, along with Uganda and Burundi. Djiboutian officials say they expect to send several hundred more troops in the coming months. The total African Union force is now about 10,000 soldiers.

headline: Romney Reworks Stump Speech, but Keeps Focus on Obama
text: BEDFORD, N.H. — Mitt Romney drew some of the sharpest and harshest distinctions yet between himself and President Obama on Tuesday night, painting the upcoming election as a choice between “two destinies” — his vision of a capitalist society based on merit and enterprise, versus what he called the president’s embrace of entitlement programs and an intent “to use the invisible boot of government to bring us all down.”

headline: Lottery Numbers
Iraqi Photographers Captured the Costs of War
text: Many of the most dramatic images of the Iraq war were made by Iraqi photographers who risked life and limb. They set out to document what many hoped would be its rebirth, and kept shooting what they realized was its dissolution.

headline: Orson Welles’s Oscar Has a New Owner
text: LOS ANGELES —The Orson Welles Oscar went to the highest—and unidentified — bidder for $861,542, the Nate D. Sanders auction house said Tuesday evening. Welles received the Oscar in 1942 for his work on the script for “Citizen Kane.” It was thought to be lost and later replaced. But eventually the original turned up in the hands of a cinematographer who said he had received it from Welles as a gift, and, after a court fight, it was turned over to Welles’s daughter Beatrice. When the original first went on the block, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences went to court to try to stop the sale, but lost. Sotheby’s later tried to sell it, but ended that effort when an undisclosed reserve price was not met. And, now, finally the Oscar has been sold in an auction that, according to Sanders, included an underbid from the magician David Copperfield. “I’m proud to have represented this fantastic award to the cinema collecting community,” Nate D. Sanders, the auction house owner, said in a statement that was circulated late Tuesday.

headline: More Georgia Schools Accused of Cheating

headline: What Remains
text: Perhaps the most famous house of 1861 was, by July of that year, no longer standing. The home, called Spring Hill, belonged to Judith Henry, an invalid widow, and stood on a hill overlooking Bull Run. In the battle that engulfed the fields around Spring Hill on July 21, Henry was killed and her home destroyed, save for a few remnant beams and a section of chimney.

headline: Qaddafi Son Being Held by Rebels, Rights Group Says
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, the son and presumed heir of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, is alive and well and being held by a rebel militia outside the Libyan capital, according to an American human rights organization that was granted rare access to him. But the group said that Mr. Qaddafi had been denied access to legal counsel as he awaited trial on charges of crimes against humanity.

headline: Can You Be Good Without God?
text: A writer for a Times blog about philosophy argues that being an atheist does not mean “anything goes” — in fact, quite the opposite. What do you think? Can morality be independent of God? Can people who don’t believe in God still be as “good” as those who do? What governs your own decisions about whether and how to act ethically?

headline: Tokio Marine to Buy Delphi Financial for $2.7 Billion

headline: Tip of the Week: Getting More Info From Your Mac
text: Want more information about the items scattered around the Mac OS X desktop, like the number of items inside a folder or the resolution of an image? Just click the desktop background and go to the View menu in the Mac’s Finder. Choose Show View Options from the menu and turn on the checkbox next to “Show item info.” The desktop icons now display that additional data. If you decide that the Mac might be showing you too much information, just repeat the steps and remove the check from the box next to “Show item info.”

headline: Carbon Emission Fees for Flights Upheld
text: PARIS — The European Union’s highest court on Wednesday endorsed the bloc’s plan to begin charging the world’s biggest airlines for their greenhouse gas emissions starting Jan. 1. The move sets the stage for a potentially costly trade war with the United States, China and other countries.

headline: European Bank in Strong Move to Loosen Credit
text: After long resisting the kind of financial force Washington used at the height of the financial crisis in 2008, European central bankers on Wednesday pumped nearly $640 billion into the Continent’s banking system. The move raised hopes that the money could alleviate the region’s credit squeeze.

headline: Paring a College List from 19 to 13, With Room for Yale and Deep Springs
text: I’ve always heard that senior year is easy: a year of coasting, relaxation and (arguably) well-deserved laziness. Starting my final year at Marist School, a Catholic college prep school in Atlanta, I almost looked forward to slipping into senioritis. Yet 4 months, 1 round of final exams and 13 college applications later, it’s fair to say senior year is no pleasure cruise. On top of a challenging course load and a busy extracurricular schedule, I face some huge decisions about next year.

headline: Demonstrators Who Took Over Chinese Village Halt Protest

The protests ended after a leader of the villagers met on Wednesday morning with senior officials from coastal Guangdong Province in southern China.

headline: How ‘Bridesmaids’ Could Get a Best-Picture Nomination
text: The critics have spoken, and so have the awards watchers, and both would like to nominate “Bridesmaids” as a movie of the year. The Kristen Wiig-Annie Mumolo comedy made it to many top 10 lists, including those of the Bagger’s colleagues A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, and the American Film Institute. It earned important Golden Globe and Screen Actors Guild nominations as well, and now the experts over at Gold Derby are predicting that it has a shot at the best picture Academy Award. headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 21
text: The National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity has asked two journals, Science and Nature, to keep out details of certain research from articles they plan to publish about the spread of a deadly flu virus. The virus normally doesn’t travel from person to person, but scientists managed to make a highly transmissible form (at least in ferrets, which provide a good model of what viruses will do in people). The government board fears the information could be used by terrorists to create deadly viruses and touch off epidemics.

headline: The Holy Land of the Holy Graves
text: MODIIN, Israel — Monday afternoon, a day before the start of Hanukkah, I’m on the road from Jerusalem to Tel Aviv. I turn right where the brown signs point to the “Maccabean Graves.” I take the short unpaved road to where the Maccabees — those rebellious Jewish devotees who defeated the forces of the Greek-Macedonian Seleucid Empire around 100 B.C. — almost certainly were not buried.

headline: Attack Over a Basketball Game at Erasmus

headline: Here Come the Tour Buses, Minus the Loudspeakers, and Maybe Human Guides

text: Eight American soldiers were charged with manslaughter and other crimes in connection with the death of Pvt. headline: Leading Off: N.C.A.A. Roulette Stops on Ohio State
text: When Ohio State was finally delivered its N.C.A.A. penalties on Tuesday, there was a bit of a “Casablanca” moment in there, just about the time Athletic Director Gene Smith delivered his latest in a long string of roll-your-eyes moments and said he was shocked the powers-that-be would hand down stiffer penalties than the Buckeyes had suggested for themselves. Yes, never mind that Smith was well aware his former football coach Jim Tressel had done everything but put the N.C.A.A. rule book through a shredder and he and E. Gordon Gee had reacted so lamely it veered toward a Three Stooges routine. Nonetheless, he was shocked, Captain Renault-like, that the N.C.A.A. had found something untoward going on in Columbus.

headline: Out of Harvard, and Into Finance

headline: Ristretto | Holiday
text: The best present for a coffee lover is coffee. It doesn’t need to be expensive to be great, and if it’s a subscription for regular shipments of hard-to-find coffee from a cult roaster, it makes giving the gift all the more gratifying.

headline: Hey, Girl. Happy Holidays. To You. To Us.
text: Let’s face it, certain cultural forces are unstoppable. Harvey Weinstein’s quest to win Oscars. The disarming power of kittens in movie trailers. And Ryan Gosling. The coolest person of the year – as anointed by that frequent arbiter of raditude, Time Magazine – has also been among the stickiest, meme–wise. (Do we need to explain? Mr. Gosling provides the dreamy stare; bloggers provide the come-ons.)

headline: On Our Radar: China Demands Emission Cuts
