headline: Correcting Data Error, Realtor Group Revises Existing-Home Sales Downward
text: The organization that once said the housing boom would never bust said on Wednesday that the market collapse was even worse than it originally reported.

headline: Death Penalty Death Watch: California
text: I’ve already made my position on capital punishment clear, on the editorial page and on this blog. The death penalty is immoral: the state shouldn’t play at executioner. It’s imposed in a racially biased manner, defendants have insufficient access to reliable counsel, and it’s also impractical: It’s expensive, with convicts sitting on death row for decades, and the means of execution are often cruel.

headline: Apps to Keep Children Happy
text: WITH Christmas upon us and New Year’s just around the bend, many families are contending with long road trips and crowded flights. All those hours in the car and at the airport are bound to bring out tantrums in toddlers, squabbles among siblings and the familiar “I’m bored” from tweens.

headline: What Are the Best Apps to Keep Kids Entertained While Traveling?
text: This week in the Practical Traveler column Michelle Higgins offers a selection of fun kids apps to keep children entertained while traveling, as well as some unplugged ideas. When you are on the road, what apps have you used to keep your kids busy? How about some unplugged ideas? Share your responses in the comments below.

headline: RIM Shares Jump on Takeover Whispers
text: Speculation about suitors circling Research in Motion breathed new life into its shares on Wednesday.

headline: China Says Christian Bale Should Be Embarrassed After Assault
text: While American audiences struggle to understand the dialogue in the trailer for Christian Bale’s next Batman movie, the Chinese government has expressed itself loud and clear to that “Dark Knight” star, saying that Mr. Bale was trying to “create news” when he tried to visit a detained lawyer in China last week.

headline: New York or D.C: Whose Cheap Food Rules?
text: Few rivalries between cities start with one side pleading its inferiority. But the arena here is restaurants, not sports, and so The Washington Post set up a smackdown between D.C. and New York — and which has the better cheap food — by stipulating its challenger status.

headline: New in the Campaign Finance API: Independent Expenditures
text: The Campaign Finance API started as a service for data about presidential candidates. But as the campaign for next year’s presidential election has unfolded, it’s clearer than ever that the men and women jockeying for the Republican nomination are only a part of the action. Independent efforts, from so-called “Super PACs” to advertising campaigns funded by wealthy individuals and interest groups, play an important role in federal elections, as our reporters have written.

headline: Romney’s Big Lie
text: Suppose that President Obama were to make the following statement:

headline: The Hair Remains the Same
text: Before getting the Spielberg treatment, Hergé’s Tintin went through other visual iterations.

headline: The 12 Games of Christmas: Americans Abroad on TV
text: The last few weeks of December bring a bleak emptiness to much of the soccer world, with leagues in France, Spain, Italy, Germany, the Netherlands and other countries retreating into hibernation for extended stretches.

headline: Golly Gee
text: I have to post this every once in a while: a lot of comments are being rejected because they contain obscenities that violate Times rules. And the sad thing, based on a random sample, is that many of the comments would have been useful contributions to the discussion except for one or two words.

headline: Al Jazeera English Among Winners of DuPont Broadcast Awards
text: Three regular recipients of broadcast journalism awards, CBS, NBC and HBO, and two relatively new recipients, Al Jazeera English and The New York Times, were among those named winners of the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards on Wednesday.

headline: Zhang Yimou and the Challenges of Filming in China
text: As someone whose life was upended by the Cultural Revolution, the Chinese director Zhang Yimou, 60, has every reason to be wary of politics. But his new film, “The Flowers of War,” which opens Wednesday, is China’s submission for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film and has already picked up a Golden Globe nomination. (It’s the subject of an article in the Arts & Leisure section here.) It deals with one of the most horrific episodes in modern Chinese history: the Nanjing Massacre of December 1937, in which Japanese troops overran China’s capital, killing more than 200,000 people and raping as many as 80,000 women.

headline: Cities Face Tough Choices as U.S. Slashes Block Grants Program
text: ALLENTOWN, Pa. — It is no secret that these are hard times for cities, with tax collections down, state aid dwindling, unemployment high and foreclosures pitting many blocks. So, as he sat in his office here, Mayor Ed Pawlowski of Allentown echoed the question mayors around the country are asking: Why has Washington cut one of the main federal programs for cities by a quarter in the last couple of years?

headline: Surge in Syrian Killings Is Reported Before Visit
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian rights activists and opposition groups said on Wednesday that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad had killed at least 160 defecting soldiers, civilians and antigovernment activists over the last three days in northwestern Syria. If confirmed, the killings would constitute one of the worst spasms of violence in the nine-month-old uprising.

headline: Great Escape | Eastern Exposure
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: The Year in Media | Social Media and Egypt’s Revolution
text: The value of social media as a tool to help bring political change was displayed in dramatic fashion on Jan. 25. After the people of Tunisia in January had utilized Facebook and YouTube to help topple the regime of President Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, opposition groups in Egypt were inspired. They, too, turned to Facebook, Twitter and YouTube to help organize protests for Jan. 25, known as National Police Day — the beginning of the uprising in Egypt that brought down the government of Hosni Mubarak.

headline: The Most Popular Health Topics of 2011
text: High-protein diets and superhero workouts – those were two of the most sought-after topics on the Internet in 2011.

headline: Gingrich Condemns Senate on Payroll Tax Vote
text: DES MOINES — Newt Gingrich put a pox on all parties in Washington on Wednesday for failing to pass a payroll tax extension, but he especially condemned the Senate, where Republicans joined Democrats to vote for a two-month extension of the tax break, which affects 160 million Americans.

headline: Why Some Business Owners Think Now Is the Time to Sell
text: Looking back, Cyndi Finkle wishes she had sold her craft services company, Sunday Night Dinner, early in 2008 when the economy was booming. With a track record of 30 to 50 percent annual growth for each of the previous five years, it could have been a compelling transaction.

headline: Duo Wanted in String of House Burglaries in Queens
text: A man and a woman working as a burglary team are wanted in connection with 12 home break-ins in Astoria, Queens, most of them within the last month, the police said.

headline: Are You Thinking of Selling Your Business in 2012?
text: Is it 2012 yet? From where I sit, the Great Recession has felt like the movie “Groundhog Day,” in which Bill Murray relives the same miserable day over and over again. For those of us waiting for the business-for-sale marketplace to turn the corner, 2012 brings a number of reasons for hope, many of which are addressed in a just-published New York Times article. While the decision to sell your business should be entered into with careful thought and planning, here are five reasons you may want to get a deal done by the end of 2012.

headline: Young Star Makes a Fancy First Impression
text: MINNEAPOLIS — Charisma, he’s got. The Spanish basketball star Ricky Rubio, with his longish dark hair and fashionable facial stubble, flashed plenty of that in his first two appearances with the Minnesota Timberwolves.

headline: Unfit Salmon and ‘Plain Old Darwinian Selection’
text: Captive-born salmon waste no time making themselves at home. In crowded aquaculture tanks, they outperform wild counterparts in survival and reproduction — great news if you’re a salmon farmer. But these changes come at a cost. The more capable a salmon is of thriving in captivity, the less capable it is of succeeding in the wild.

headline: What Iraqis Think of the American Withdrawal: Babil Province
text: As American forces pulled out of Iraq, we asked Iraqis around the country three questions:

headline: The Choice Q. and A. on Facebook: A Recap, and an Invitation
text: On Tuesday, The Choice blog hosted its first live Facebook discussion about college admissions. Our guest expert was Marie Bigham, director of college counseling at the Greenhill School in Addison, Tex. She answered a series of thoughtful questions from readers on subjects like the role of recommendations in the application process, the rising cost of college and how colleges analyze transcripts.

headline: Looking Back at 2011: Retrospectives and Ideas for Teaching With Them
text: Updated | Jan. 1, 2012

headline: An Official Release for Captain Beefheart’s ‘Bat Chain Puller’
text: More than 36 years after it was recorded, Zappa Records is finally releasing Captain Beefheart’s album “Bat Chain Puller,” Billboard  and The Wire report.

headline: F.C.C. Rules for the Tennis Channel
text: On Tuesday, a Federal Communications Commission administrative law judge ordered Comcast to carry the Tennis Channel exactly as it does Versus and the Golf Channel. The ruling is particularly important because Comcast is the largest owner of cable systems in the United States. Richard Sandomir has the story here.

headline: Large Hepworth Sculpture Stolen From  Park in London
text: Thieves entered Dulwich Park in south London on Monday night and stole a large bronze sculpture by one of Britain’s much-loved artists. The sculpture, “Two Forms (Divided Circle),’’ by Barbara Hepworth, had been a familiar sight since it was installed in the park more than 40 years ago.

headline: Security in Flu Study Was Paramount, Scientist Says
text: The National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity, concerned about bioterrorism and a worldwide pandemic, has for the first time ever urged scientific journals to keep details out of reports that they intend to publish on a highly transmissible form of the bird flu called A(H5N1), which has a high death rate in people. Working with ferrets, researchers on the virus at two medical centers — Erasmus Medical Center in Rotterdam, in the Netherlands, and the University of Wisconsin-Madison — are investigating genetic changes that may make the virus more easily transmittable to people. Doreen Carvajal spoke with Ron A. M. Fouchier, the lead researcher at the Erasmus Center. An edited and condensed version of the conversation follows.

headline: ‘Layaway Angels’ Pay Off Family Accounts
text: Anonymous donors have been going into big-box stores — Kmart in particular — and paying off layaway accounts. NPR and The Associated Press picked up the story five days ago, and in it a reporter described a young father stepping up to the layaway counter with three kids behind him to pay something on his account when a “mysterious woman” approached.

headline: How Do You Glaze a Ham?
text: Bourbon, molasses and pecans.

headline: The Movement Toward a ‘Buy Nothing’ Christmas
text: As I was reading “How the Grinch Stole Christmas!”with my kids, I couldn’t help but marvel that the book (and the animated television special) endures as a holiday favorite, even as its core anticonsumerism message goes completely ignored.

headline: Thursday Matchup: Texans at Colts
text: Texans at ColtsThursday, 8:20Line: Texans by 5 ½. It only took one loss to for the euphoria of the Texans’ first-ever division title to fade into pessimism about their playoff chances. The Texans are relying on third-string quarterback T.J. Yates to remain viable, top receiver Andre Johnson’s recovery from a pulled hamstring has been slow (he has been ruled out for Sunday), top pass rusher Mario Williams (torn pectoral muscle) is long gone, defensive coordinator Wade Philips is recovering from surgery, and Arian Foster has fumbled three times in four games as the strain of carrying the offense has taken its toll.

headline: A Challenge to #Takethetest
text: A Twitter trend, #takethetest, is a hashtag that some educators and others are using to urge policy makers to take standardized tests -- and make their scores public.

headline: ‘Christmas’ Makes Michael Bublé’s Year
text: Coming soon as stuffing to a million or two stockings: Michael Bublé.

headline: An iPhone Cover Fit for the Griswolds
text: If you are into Clark W Griswold-level holiday decorating (you know who you are – your dog is wearing antlers right now), then Speck, makers of protective cases for electronic devices, has a little holiday cheer for your iPhone.

headline: Dance Theater of Harlem to Start Auditions for Revived Troupe
text: Dance companies are supposed to be shrinking, not starting up in these recessionary times. Not so at the Dance Theater of Harlem, which closed its company in 2004. Theater officials on Wednesday announced the start of auditions to create a new stripped down troupe of 18 dancers, which will begin rehearsing in August and touring in October and aims to return to a New York stage by April 2013.

headline: Countrywide Will Settle a Bias Suit
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department on Wednesday announced the largest residential fair-lending settlement in history, saying that Bank of America had agreed to pay $335 million to settle allegations that its Countrywide Financial unit discriminated against black and Hispanic borrowers during the housing boom.

headline: Freed From Jail, Russian Blogger Drives Anti-Kremlin Movement
text: MOSCOW — Free after a 15-day prison term, the opposition blogger Aleksei Navalny moved quickly on Wednesday to use his growing celebrity to promote a huge antigovernment protest, exhorting “people across the country” to turn out on Saturday and register their anger against United Russia, the party of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Consumer Electronics Show Loses Its Anchor, Microsoft
text: 2:55 p.m. | Updated to reflect comment from the Consumer Electronics Association.

headline: Apps to Put Words in Santa’s Mouth
text: You might expect folks who make iPhone Santa apps to be filled with the holiday spirit, but after testing some of their wares, I’ve concluded they might be some of the Scroogiest people around. I tried some apps similar to one I liked last year, “Talking Santa,” which let me record a message and make it appear to come from an animated Santa. I thought it would be a fun way for parents to send a message from Santa to their children.

headline: The Algonquin Curtails Its Famous Cat
text: Herding cats, as we all know, isn’t easy. So the Algonquin hotel has installed an electronic fence to keep its resident cat, Matilda, in the lobby and out of areas where food and drink are served.

headline: G.M. Claims Remedy for Squealing Brakes
text: At one time or another, most motorists register the fingers-on-chalkboard sound of squealing brakes coming from their cars. So unnerving is the sound that it can cause drivers to erroneously assume that their brakes may be on the verge of failure. On Wednesday, General Motors announced that it was working on a brake assembly that might prevent the cacophony.

headline: Vain Glorious | Hold a Candle
text: Much like your wardrobe, home fragrance is about mastering a mix of the classic and the seasonal. Keep your beloved Feu de Bois candle from burning out by taking a match to one of these festive, holiday-inspired offerings instead:

headline: The Year in Review — And Next Year in Preview
text: Gail Collins: David, this will be our last conversation of 2011. When we talk next in two weeks, the Iowa caucuses will be over. Who do you think will win? The way things are going, I have to conclude it’s going to be Steve Jobs. True, he’s no longer alive, but these days everybody seems to like him a lot. Which you certainly cannot say of any of the Republican presidential candidates.

headline: Serb Charged With Arms Smuggling in Kosovo Conflict
text: PARIS — An ethnic Serb accused of being the shadowy smuggler behind recent border clashes in northern Kosovo was arrested in central Serbia late Tuesday, a day after Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany warned Serbia that it must reach a peace agreement with Kosovo to join the European Union.

headline: Bold, Colorful Men’s Socks
text: Distinctive socks are a clever and easy way for men to add a little oomph to their look without going overboard.

headline: Lens: Iraqi Photographers Captured the Costs of War
text: Foreigners may have started the war in Iraq, but it was not only foreigners who covered its deadly battles, car bombs, civilian casualties and sectarian violence. Over on the Lens blog, Anne Barnard tells the story of Iraqi photographers who were tried, tempered and tested in the nine years since the American invasion — and who came out the other side professional photojournalists.

headline: A Simple Yes or No? It’s Not That Easy
text: SOME marriage proposals make for great theater, but in the case of Dina Kirschenbaum and Mark Thomas, a theater made for a great proposal, one of the best submitted in 2011.

headline: Coffee Gulch
text: This fall, a handful of new coffee spots opened in NoHo, turning Lafayette Street into Latte Row. Now Gasoline Alley (331 Lafayette Street, at Houston Street), La Colombe Torrefaction (400 East Lafayette Street, at East Fourth Street) and Au Breve (51 Cooper Square, at East Sixth Street) join local standbys Think Coffee (1 Bleecker Street, at the Bowery) and the always fashionable Smile (26 Bond Street, at Lafayette Street).

headline: App Smart Extra: Other People’s Apps, Now Visible to You
text: Last week’s App Smart column highlighted Web sites that help you find — and in some cases, purchase — new apps. One new Apple-related service, Crosswalk, actually lets you peek at what’s on another person’s device.

headline: Book That Became Hit French Film to Be Released in U.S.
text: The memoir that inspired the hit film “Intouchables” in France will be published in the United States next year, its publisher said. Atria Books, an imprint of Simon & Schuster, secured the rights to release the book, “Le second souffle” (the English title is “Second Wind”).

text: What happens when a presidential campaign neglects to snatch up the Web site in the candidate’s name?

headline: Railroad Stations of Yore
text: From Delaware to Buffalo to Chicago, a historical photographic essay on railroad stations from around the country.

headline: TimesCast | December 21, 2011
text: Edward Wong reports from Wukan, China | The consequences of not extending the payroll tax break and jobless benefits | Steven Spielberg's "The Adventures of Tintin"

headline: Meyer Says Ohio State Undeterred by Sanctions
text: The Ohio State Coach Urban Meyer said that he’s at peace with the news of Ohio State’s N.C.A.A. sanctions, which include a postseason ban in 2012, and is prepared to move on.

headline: Protesters Interrupt Gingrich Speech
text: After condemning the Senate for leaving town during the debate over the payroll tax, Newt Gingrich was interrupted by protesters in New Hampshire.

headline: Obama Gets a Lift From Tax Battle With Republicans
text: WASHINGTON — After a long stretch of high unemployment, legislative turmoil and, in turn, slipping public approval, President Obama seemed to regain his political footing this week with the help of House Republicans, whose handling of a standoff over payroll taxes had even leading conservatives accusing them of bungling the politically charged issue.

headline: Google Expands YouTube’s Suite of Services for Schools
text: Say the word “YouTube” to most teachers and you’ll get the type of cringe reserved for a ringing cellphone. Google, which owns YouTube, would like change that with a new network setting designed to give schools more control over what their students see when they visit the video site from a classroom or library PC.

headline: Two Roll-Your-Own-Cigarette Stores to Close
text: Two stores, on Staten Island and in Chinatown, have agreed to stop selling roll-your-own cigarettes after New York City accused them of being fronts for evading cigarette taxes.

headline: Below the Line: Green Valleys, Golden Sunsets and ‘War Horse’
text: “War Horse,” Steven Spielberg’s film adaptation of Michael Morpurgo's children’s novel (and a subsequent play based on it), will open in theaters Christmas Day. But it has the look of a movie that could have just as easily played on movie screens 50 years ago. The wide open spaces, the glowing skies, the rolling hills have the feel of John Ford films, which inspired Mr. Spielberg and his longtime cinematographer, Janusz Kaminski.

headline: South Street Seaport Museum to Reopen in January
text: The South Street Seaport Museum will reopen on Jan. 26, the institution announced on Wednesday. The museum, which has been plagued by financial problems, was provisionally taken over by the Museum of the City of New York in September, with help from a $2 million grant from the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation.

headline: E.P.A. Issues Limits on Mercury Emissions
text: WASHINGTON — The Environmental Protection Agency unveiled new standards on Wednesday sharply limiting emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants from the nation’s coal– and oil-burning power plants.

headline: Romney Teases Reporters Over Lunch
text: NEWPORT, N.H. — The plane the Romney campaign charters for reporters is nicknamed “Hair Force One,” and on Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Romney offered up his own moniker for the press bus: “This is the John Kerry bus,” Mr. Romney quipped, when a group of finicky reporters didn’t immediately jump for the submarine sandwiches he tried to pass out for lunch.

headline: Proposal Planners: If You’re Ready to Pop the Question
text: THE marriage game has no shortage of matchmakers, wedding planners, fashion stylists, floral designers and other referees.

headline: Imperfect Little Girls
text: Perfect little girls sound so good in theory: Always saying please and thank you. Always eager to please. Always pleasing with their A-pluses. But in practice, they are full of peril. They won’t leave the house until their shoelaces are tied just so — even if it takes 14 painstaking attempts. They cannot abide an error. Worst of all, according to parents’ most dire nightmares, they risk growing up to become anxious, anorexic or otherwise emotionally damaged adults.

headline: Taking the Pulse of New Hampshire Voters
text: With the first Republican nominating contests just weeks away, we are looking to take the pulse of New Hampshire voters heading into the holiday break. Do you live in New Hampshire? If you plan to vote in the primary, have you chosen a candidate? What issue is most important to you? What does the race look like from where you stand? And how does it compare to primaries past?

headline: Whitney Announces Biennial Artists
text: In recent years, some of the Whitney Museum of American Art‘s Biennials have featured over-the-top spectacle, while others have been lower key. On Wednesday, the museum announced an eclectic lineup for the 76th edition of its survey of contemporary American art, which opens March 1. The list includes Dennis Cooper, who plans to install a speaking “robot”; Andrea Fraser, who once posed as a museum tour guide as part of a performance piece; Kate Levant, who will have a hanging-fabric sculpture on display; and Nick Mauss, who is installing a velvet room. Also represented will be the experimental theatrical director and playwright Richard Maxwell; the filmmakers Vincent Gallo, Werner Herzog and Frederick Wiseman; the dancer and choreographer Michael Clark; and the rock band Red Krayola.

text: A Mayor Baldwin is not to be.

headline: Social-Minded Hip-Hop Is Making a Comeback
text: In May, when a rapper was invited to perform at the White House as part of an evening devoted to poetry, it was met with predictable conservative outrage. That the kerfuffle was over Common, the most neutered of all rappers, only underscored the bad faith beneath the squawking. Still, the episode was a reminder that rap — the idea alone — can still rattle nerves well into its middle age.

headline: Mitt Romney on the Payroll Tax Debate

headline: New Directions for the Intergovernmental Climate Panel
text: Dec. 23, 11:14 p.m. | Updated below |There’ve been a variety of reactions to my post criticizing Rajendra K. Pachauri, the longtime chairman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

text: Photographs from Czech Republic, North Korea, Russia and India.

headline: On Defense, Heat and Thunder Get Better
text: Change is the N.B.A.’s only true constant. With that in mind, here is a look at the teams poised for substantial changes in their defensive performance:

headline: City Rejects Pleas to Expedite New School in Murray Hill
text: UPDATED | One of the many overcrowding battles in Manhattan came to an unhappy conclusion for a group of Murray Hill parents after city officials rejected their proposals to open a new school a year ahead of schedule.

headline: Quiz Show Helps NBC in Ratings
text: While other broadcast networks were in full repeat mode on Tuesday night, NBC grabbed a rare prime-time ratings victory in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic with the second episode of “Who’s Still Standing?,” a new quiz show in which contestants are dropped down a hole if they give the wrong answer. About 5.8 million total viewers tuned in, and the show was up 20 percent in the 18-to-49-year-old viewership category compared with Monday’s premiere. NBC’s demographic numbers were also helped by “Saturday Night Live Presents: A Very Gilly Christmas,” which tied for the highest-rated program of the night in adults 18-to-49 and drew an average of 5.8 million total viewers over a two-hour period.

headline: CoverGirl Withdraws ‘Enhanced’ Taylor Swift Ad
text: There’s a certain Taylor Swift ad for CoverGirl mascara that you won’t be seeing in American magazines any time soon.

headline: Mercedes-Benz Introduces Gas and Diesel E-Class Hybrids
text: On Wednesday, Mercedes-Benz announced two new hybrid E-Class sedans. The E300 BlueTec Hybrid is equipped with a diesel-electric powertrain, the automaker’s first to be commercialized, while the E400 Hybrid has a more conventional gas-electric hybrid system.

headline: Director of MacArthur ‘Genius’ Program to Retire
text: 3:06 p.m. | Updated Daniel J. Socolow, the director since 1997 of the MacArthur Foundation fellowship program known as the “genius” awards, will retire sometime in the next several months, foundation officials are expected to announce Thursday.

headline: Eurofile | Le Havre in a New Light
text: Strolling along the Rue de Paris in Le Havre at dusk on an early winter day, I was mystified by the faint rosy glow of the concrete buildings around me. It couldn’t be the sun, since the sky was shrouded with low pewter clouds scuttling in off of the English Channel. Maybe the briny sea air was causing some kind of chemical reaction with the lime in the cement? I’d have to ask my friend Arnaud when I met him a few minutes later for dinner. One way or another, this gentle color blunted the brute angles of these perplexing post-war buildings. One minute, I found them harshly beautiful; the next, cold and alien.

text: Before checking out the correct answers below, give the quiz a try.

text: Mitt Romney boarded the press bus with sandwiches for the media.

text: Edward Wong reports from Wukan, China, where demonstrators have backed down after heated protests over land seizures.

headline: Romney Refuses to Criticize Boehner Over Payroll Tax Vote
text: KEENE, N.H. — At a morning campaign stop at a restaurant here, Mitt Romney said that while he supported an extension of the payroll tax cut, he was not willing to get into the “Congressional sausage-making process” and refused to criticize the speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, for siding with Republican members in blocking the Senate’s proposed two-month extension of the tax break.

headline: Yahoo to Consider Sale of Asian Assets
text: 8:18 p.m. | Updated

headline: Shopping Snapshots: Dec. 22
text: All puffed up with coats; partying in pajamas; and sparkly bags.

headline: Walgreen Facing Big Loss in Fight With Express Scripts
text: CHICAGO — The historically steady growth of the Walgreen Company’s business of filling prescriptions is likely to drop off sharply next year, as the pharmacy giant faces the imminent loss of millions of customers who use the pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts.

headline: In Ad, Ann Romney Stresses Character
text: Ann Romney, who has taken on an increasingly visible role in her husband’s campaign over the last two weeks, will appear before Iowans in a new television commercial in which she urges them to contemplate what kind of character a president should have.

headline: A Glamorous Aerie Overlooks the Brazilian Atlantic
text: On the 22nd floor of a new condo tower in an affluent Rio neighborhood, a three-bedroom has a large glassed-in veranda that mimics the contours of the building.

headline: TimesCast | Political Standoff
text: Congress' inability to pass legislation to extend the payroll tax break and jobless benefits will have significant financial consequences for most Americans.

headline: Ludlow Manor
text: HAVING savaged much of the Lower East Side, the weekend warriors who pack the area’s forgettable new clubs are surging southward. Their stronghold beneath Delancey Street might be Ludlow Manor, an entertainment triplex opened last month by Georgie Seville and Luc Carl, who appear to be cashing in their chips with this glammed-up behemoth.

headline: The Armory’s Ambitions Expand to Match Its Hall
text: Rapist Santas in the brutalist opera “Die Soldaten.” The Royal Shakespeare Company performing in a life-size reproduction of its theater. A five-story crane continuously plucking at 30 tons of salvaged clothing. A three-dimensional re-creation of Leonardo’s “Last Supper.”

headline: The Park Avenue Armory: A Home for Art and Performance
text: No longer merely the fusty home of antiques shows, the Armory over the past five years has unveiled art installations, staged dramas, presented operas and concerts and served as an outpost of the Whitney Biennial.

headline: On Flu Strains, Folkies and Faith in Science
text: I’m a huge fan of science, as is obvious given that I’ve spent my life studying it and writing about it. I think that more science and science literacy, and fostering a culture of innovation and inquiry, will boost odds of a relatively smooth ride for humanity as our appetite for resources crests.

headline: A Seasonal Cocktail: The Bitter Darling
text: I was recently asked to create a specialty cocktail for a big holiday bash. I knew I wanted it to be something special and seasonal, but the constraints posed by the party (it was held at the Center for Fiction, a lovely place, but one not equipped with a full bar or full kitchen) demanded that I keep it simple. Not a worry, as I’m inclined to keep it simple where cocktails are concerned. The classic rye Manhattan was my starting point. What if I replaced the sweet vermouth with ginger syrup? That worked fine, but something was missing. I was testing the drink in a friend’s kitchen in New Hampshire over Thanksgiving weekend. A bowlful of clementines (one of my favorite winter treats) sat on the counter. Freshly squeezed clementine juice — and a generous dousing of Angostura bitters — brought the whole thing together. It’s easy to make ginger syrup: I prepare a basic sugar-and-water simple syrup, in which I steep peeled, fresh ginger long enough that its strong, spicy bite really comes through. But you can skip this step altogether and buy the excellent ready-made ginger syrup from Brooklyn’s Morris Kitchen. As a nod to the bitters and the clementine, I christened the drink the Bitter Darling. It was a hit. And even though I invented it especially for one party, I’m sure it’ll be a mainstay of my winter-cocktail repertory.

headline: Theater Talkback: Honorable Mention for the Dishonorably Unmentioned
text: Early in my career as a critic at The New York Times, I began receiving nuisance calls from a ghost. This was before I had caller ID (or an unlisted number), and for a week or so I would pick up my phone only to hear an angry actress berating me for not singling out her performance in my review of an Off Broadway show in which she appeared as a specter.

headline: The Giving Spree | Brooklyn Decker
text: Who: the actress Brooklyn Decker

headline: A Bundle of Potential in a Ball
text: You may remember that, in the movie “Field of Dreams,” a mysterious voice in Kevin Costner’s head kept intoning: “If you build it, they will come.” It took some time for him to realize that somewhat unspecific piece of guidance really meant: “If you build a baseball diamond in a cornfield, dead players will come back to life.”

headline: More Advice for Pre-Retirees Coming to 401(k)’s
text: If you’re nearing retirement, you’re probably aware of the anxiety-inducing task that lies ahead: figuring out how to replace your paycheck with a steady stream of income generated by your investments.

headline: Ovechkin and Capitals Look for Turnaround
text: Maybe the Washington Capitals are figuring out how to turn the corner. And a good start certainly would be to get superstar Alex Ovechkin going again.

headline: Food Gifts That Matter
text: My column today offers suggestions for gifts for non-cooks. Obviously, cooking is not the only issue out there, and direct contact with friends is not the only way to change things in the food world: there is cash. There are countless worthy causes and just as many charitable institutions. If finding the cash to spare is difficult so, too, may be choosing where it will be put to best use. But if you’re thinking about making a donation this year to brighten the national or global food landscape, here’s a list of organizations where your gifts will be well spent. (No doubt there are equally worthy omissions; please add them in the comments section.)

headline: Helped by an Obama Stimulus

headline: Black Firefighters Are Permitted Door-to-Door Outreach
text: The federal court monitor charged with diversifying the city’s Fire Department is allowing black firefighters to go door to door to persuade black applicants to join the department, over objections from city lawyers.

headline: Yale Coach Resigns After Rhodes Scholarship Claim
text: For a couple of weeks in November, the story captivated even the casual college football follower, perhaps because it did not concern allegations of child sexual abuse or recruiting violations.

headline: Best iPhone Apps of 2011
text: For iPhone owners, 2011 brought a flood of new apps, but in many cases they struggled to outshine last year’s best. So rather than present a top 10 list that includes names from 2010, I’m including only apps that had their debuts this year. If you really want to turbocharge your device, combine these with last year’s picks. (Note that this list doesn’t include games, which will be the subject of a separate post on the Gadgetwise blog.) Like last year’s list, this one includes many free picks.

headline: Ferrari 250 GT Spider and Mercedes-Benz Gullwing Among Highlights at Gooding Sale in Scottsdale

headline: The Ebert and Roeper of Sci-Fi Arch Metal Bands
text: From the same site that gave you an old-school rapper’s take on “Black Swan” (favorite movie of the year, in a year where he didn’t see any other movies) comes “Rocker Reviews.” The Bagger’s pals at NextMovie have asked the members of GWAR, the costumed, sci-fi arch metal band, for their take on one of this year’s Oscar hopefuls, “War Horse.” You might think that a group that favors rampant violence and imposing visuals might identify with the movie, but they’re split, Ebert and Roeper style:

headline: Jack Klugman, After Half a Century, Returning to ‘Twelve Angry Men’
text: Thirteen years before he became famous as one of television’s great slobs, Oscar Madison on “The Odd Couple,” Jack Klugman had his breakout role in the 1957 film  “12 Angry Men” as Juror 5. He played a hardened young man who brought street smarts to the jury deliberations in a murder trial in a cast that also included Henry Fonda (as the main character Juror 8), Lee J. Cobb, and Martin Balsam. Mr. Klugman is now the only surviving actor who was on the jury – a detail much on his mind Wednesday as he spoke about his latest career move. George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., announced that Mr. Klugman – who is 89 – will play Juror 9 in a production of the stage adaption “Twelve Angry Men” there March 13-April 8, 2012.

headline: Striving for ‘Gift Parity’ for Siblings
text: How’s the pressing issue of “gift parity” going at your house? A friend just asked me how worried I am about keeping things equal under the tree. She’s caught herself buying “filler” gifts just to keep things close to equal, and she doesn’t like it.

headline: Olivier Blanchard Isn’t Very Serious
text: And when you bear in mind that the Very Serious People have been wrong about everything, that’s a very good thing. What’s even better is that as the chief economist at the IMF, he’s helping make at least one international institution less austerity-mad than the others.

headline: Piers Morgan Dodges Bullets From a Great Distance

headline: Battle Scars Napoleonic and Domestic
text: For writers and readers of historical fiction the Napoleonic wars have been a godsend, inspiring not just the odd novel but battalions and flotillas of books. There is Bernard Cornwell’s multivolume series about Richard Sharpe, the British soldier who works his way up the ranks, for example, and enough naval novels set during this period to fill a harbor: C. S. Forester’s Horatio Hornblower books and Patrick O’Brian’s 20-volume Aubrey-Maturin saga, for starters.

headline: A Game Show of Sorts, the Really Loud and Potentially Uncomfortable Sort

headline: Varieties of ‘Messiah’: Smooth and Mild or Piercing With Male Altos
text: To gaze over the classical-music landscape in the final weeks of December is to take in what can seem like an endless, unvarying forest of Handel’s 1742 oratorio “Messiah.” But if you look a little closer, it is a forest made up of many different kinds of trees.

headline: Better Ways to Wire Your Ears for Music
text: Dollar for dollar, headphones are the best way to listen to music. They pack more sonic wallop than even the most face-meltingly amazing loudspeaker system, and they do it for a lot less money. Think about it: a truly magnificent home-speaker system can cost well into the tens of thousands of dollars. A screaming set of headphones? A few hundred bucks, tops — and those in the Really Quite Good category can cost less than $100.

headline: Finding Success in a Lifelong Passion for Fighting Monopolies

headline: Guitar and Sax, Each in Exploration
text: Ben Greenberg plays guitar in the Brooklyn band Zs, but he is also the monocrat of Hubble, a project of one. He performed a short set at Zebulon in Brooklyn’s Williamsburg neighborhood on Tuesday; so did Diamond Terrifier, alias the saxophonist Sam Hillmer, also from Zs. Individually, they’re working on related forms of minimalism, an old idea, but they’re post-genre people, interested in the dirty magic of warping and transforming sounds and languages you might already know.

headline: The 9 Lives of Carine Roitfeld
text: ARRIVING at a couture show last July, Carine Roitfeld, the most famous-though-underemployed fashion editor in France, was asked for her autograph. Ms. Roitfeld signed her name on an outdated photograph and asked the young man who had handed her the picture what he intended to do with it.

headline: In the Netherlands, Goalkeeper Gone Wild
text: 11:52 a.m. | Updated  A court in Amsterdam on Thursday sentenced the man who ran onto the field and attacked the AZ goalkeeper Esteban Alvarado to six months in jail, The Associated Press reported. Because of privacy laws in the Netherlands, the attacker was identified only as Wesley van W. (kind of catchy, don’t you think?). Prosecutors had been seeking a 10-month jail term. Under terms of the deal van W., 19, will also be required to report to the police during all Ajax, AZ and Dutch national team games for two years. The match, which was suspended when AZ players were instructed to leave the field, will be replayed in full next month.

headline: Hobbled Tight Ends Put the Giants in a Bind Against the Jets

headline: Faucet Handles in French
text: Although bathroom faucets traditionally identify hot and cold with markings on the handle caps, Olivier Gossart, a Parisian designer, is trying something different. His new So faucet for the French company THG suspends the words “chaud” and “froid” inside glass cubes. “My idea was to have something like water, a transparent material that is very delicate,” he said.

headline: Nature Rendered in Glass Bowls

headline: Legos for Grown-Ups, From a Child at Heart
text: Legos will undoubtedly find their way under many a tree this holiday season. But while people usually associate the Danish toy with childhood, there is a booming community of adult fans of Lego, too. Like children, they replicas of all sorts of things with the colorful pieces: entire cities, cars, “Star Trek" characters and, in the case of David Cole, animals taxidermy style.

headline: Schrager Streamlines a Chicago Hotel
text: For Ian Schrager, “sticking to the basics” was his goal in designing Public Chicago, a hotel that opened this fall in what had been the Ambassador East, built in 1926. Working with designers headed by Anda Andrei, Mr. Schrager, a partner in the hotel, created a look that is “very, very neutral, very low-key, no flash, no design on steroids,” he said.

headline: Skis Convert Chairs Into Rockers
text: Chair skis are a nifty invention that turn regular dining or side chairs into rocking chairs. Simply place the legs of the chair into the groove of the beechwood skis, which are about 1 1/8 inches wide by 21 inches long and fit most standard nonupholstered chairs. Flexible rubber stoppers at each end hold the legs in place.

headline: The Mess I’m In
text: AS a malformed Grey Gardens sort of bachelor, I have only one fork, but, unfortunately, this one fork has gone missing in the strange coral reef that passes for my apartment. And I describe my apartment as a coral reef, as opposed to the ever-thickening nest of a hoarder, because I don’t suffer from hoarding, per se. I am at the mercy of another phenomenon — a kind of metaphysical cousin to hoarding — known as kipple.

headline: Without Regis, Kelly Keeps Up Ratings in Morning

headline: G.O.P. Is Hopeful as Race to Replace State Senator Takes Shape

headline: Racism Charges Put a Sport on Edge
text: John Terry, captain of England’s national soccer team and the powerful club Chelsea, faces a criminal charge over accusations that he made a racial slur during an October match, apparently becoming the first player to be prosecuted for remarks said on the field.

headline: Prisons and Redistricting
text: A New York State court rightly upheld a state law requiring that prison inmates be counted in their home communities rather than where they are incarcerated. The law, passed in 2010, put an end to prison-based gerrymandering, which counted nonvoting prison inmates as “residents” to increase the population of some legislative districts. That practice artificially inflated the political power of voting residents in prison districts and diluted the voting strength of voters elsewhere.

headline: Getting By, Until the Day She Couldn’t Move
text: Connie Nelson is in love with the view from her 18th-floor balcony: The glittering towers and spires of Lower Manhattan have beckoned her each day for 20 years.

headline: Abuse Allegations Leave the Hall of Fame in a Difficult Position
text: Baseball and those who cover it have increasingly had to navigate the space where the celebration of sports and the acknowledgement of its troubles intersect.

headline: California’s Lethal Injections
text: In 2006, a federal district court ordered California to stop executing people because the state’s three-drug protocol for lethal injection lacked “reliability.” Six of the 11 men executed by lethal injection in the state since 1978 may have suffered cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Constitution because the injection inflicted “excessive pain,” Judge Jeremy Fogel found. He said the state could cure the constitutional problem by being transparent in devising a new protocol and using a one-drug, anesthetic-only method (as Ohio and Washington do).

headline: The Problem of the Traveling Politician
text: Politicians have always been heavy travelers, but recent news out of Iowa takes the notion of hitting the campaign trail to new extremes.

headline: John Chamberlain, Who Wrested Rough Magic From Scrap Metal, Dies at 84
text: John Chamberlain, who almost singlehandedly gave automotive metal a place in the history of sculpture, smashing and twisting together a poetic fusion of Abstract Expressionism and Pop from fenders, fins, bumpers and hoods, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 84.

headline: Former Teammates, 2 Big Men Went Different Ways
text: When Tyson Chandler was a rookie in Chicago, tall and skinny and months out of high school, he and his aspiring front-line co-star, Eddy Curry, would be summoned to the office of Jerry Krause, the Bulls’ longtime general manager, for a twice-weekly chat.

headline: Tsunami Reveals Durability of Nissan’s Leaf
text: DETROIT — Nissan inadvertently gained some valuable insight into the durability of its electric car, the Leaf, when about two dozen of them were destroyed in the tsunami that ravaged Japan in March.

headline: Iraq’s Latest Battle
text: No one expected the dangers and tensions in Iraqi politics to vanish after the last American troop departed. But at least Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, a member of the Shiite majority, might have made an effort to step up to the challenges of creating a future for Iraq based on democratic principles. Instead, he is showing a greater interest in reprisals against the Sunni minority than in encouraging inclusion.

headline: Toward Healthier Air
text: Resisting strenuous last-minute lobbying by some of the nation’s biggest utilities, the Obama administration announced on Wednesday a final rule requiring power plants to reduce emissions of mercury and other toxic pollutants by roughly 90 percent within the next five years.

headline: A New Location in the New Year for Breakingviews
After Plea, Mayweather Receives 90 Days in Jail
text: The unbeaten welterweight boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. pleaded guilty Wednesday in Las Vegas to reduced charges of domestic violence and harassment.

headline: Labor Board Adopts Rules to Speed Unionization Votes
text: The National Labor Relations Board announced on Wednesday that it had adopted new rules that would speed up unionization elections, its last major policy decision before it drops to two members and can no longer make new decisions. It approved the rules in a 2-to-1 vote.

headline: In New Campaign, Esurance Equates Trust With Efficiency
text: IN an advertising world where lizards and bubbly sales representatives extol the virtues of automobile insurance, one company has decided on a more pared down approach.

headline: Bloggingheads: A Christ-Free Christmas
text: Amy Sullivan, left, of Time and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org discuss the religious vs. secular meanings of Christmas.

headline: Christmas, Over Our Dead Bodies
text: The sign outside the Cathedral School on the Upper West Side read “School for Children of All Faiths,” but it was also, at least for me and my brother, a school for children of no faith whatsoever. I think our parents, a non-practicing Jew and an agnostic Lutheran, chose it because they liked that we would have to wear uniforms, which would make their mornings less of a trial, and because the idea of entrusting our religious education to professionals might mean that we actually got one.

headline: For Democrats in Hawaii, Unease in an Oasis
text: HONOLULU — Hawaii should be a happy outpost for the Democratic Party. It has a Democratic governor. Democrats overwhelmingly control the Legislature. It has Barack Obama in the White House and all the prestige that brings, most recently an Asia-Pacific economic summit meeting with the president as its host, packing this city’s streets, restaurants and hotels with international leaders.

headline: Housebound for the Holidays
text: Right now, you are probably asking yourself: What exactly is going on with Congress? What’s all this yelling about a tax increase? Also, are they shutting down the government again? Because I was really planning to spend my Christmas camping out in a national park.

headline: A New Kim. A New Chance?
text: On my first trip to North Korea in 1989, I made a nuisance of myself by randomly barging into private homes. I wanted to see how ordinary North Koreans actually live, and people were startled but hospitable.

headline: Signs Point to Economy’s Rise, but Experts See a False Dawn
text: WASHINGTON — As the fourth quarter draws to a close, a spate of unexpectedly good economic data suggests that it will have some of the fastest and strongest economic growth since the recovery started in 2009, causing a surge in the stock market and cheering economists, investors and policy makers.

headline: For Georgia Tech, Home Has a Distant Feel
text: ATLANTA — Georgia Tech’s Jason Morris was driving on Interstate 85 on the outskirts of this city before the basketball season started when he passed the Gwinnett Center.

headline: Officials Seize Counterfeit Holiday Goods and Make Numerous Arrests
text: While counterfeiters are well known for cashing in during the holidays on high-price items like fake Chanel bags, this year they have put more energy into the lower end — expanding into Christmas lights, plastic Angry Birds toys and National Football League jerseys.

headline: Rags to Riches
text: The Times accompanies Indian entrepreneur Ashok Khade as he revisits his native village, where he was of the lowest caste.

headline: Scaling Caste Walls With Capitalism’s Ladders in India
text: PED, India — On his barefoot trudge to school decades ago, a young Ashok Khade passed inescapable reminders of what he was: the well from which he was not allowed to drink; the temple where he was not permitted to worship. At school, he took his place on the floor in a part of the classroom built a step lower than the rest. Untouchables like him, considered to be spiritually and physically unclean, could not be permitted to pollute their upper-caste neighbors and classmates.

headline: Jacob Goldman, Founder of Xerox Lab, Dies at 90
text: Jacob E. Goldman, a physicist who as Xerox’s chief scientist founded the company’s vaunted Palo Alto Research Center, which invented the modern personal computer, died on Tuesday in Westport, Conn. He was 90.

headline: Thursday: Year of the Battle of Pollentia
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — See that title up there? Yeah, I couldn’t answer it, either. I think I can say without reservation that this is my least favorite type of clue. Not only is it a Roman numeral (CDII, in case you were wondering), which are never great entries in my humble opinion, but it’s a Roman numeral indicating a battle that I think is somewhat obscure unless you happen to be a Visigoth. On the other hand, it apparently has its own Facebook page, so who am I to argue?

headline: Gingrich Throws Down a Debate Challenge to Romney
text: ARLINGTON, Va. — Newt Gingrich threw down a “debate me in Iowa’’ challenge to his chief Republican rival, Mitt Romney, on Wednesday night, hours after Mr. Romney said in a television interview that Mr. Gingrich should stop complaining about negative advertising.“I’ve challenged Governor Romney to meet me for 90 minutes in Iowa next week, anywhere, anytime, timekeeper, no moderator,’’ Mr. Gingrich told supporters during a quick pep talk at a Marriott Hotel here.He went on: “And we’ll bring all of his negative ads and show them for free and he can explain them, and we’ll find out tomorrow whether he likes the heat and wants to come in the kitchen, or whether he is just another normal national politician with clever consultants and a lot of money and no willingness to stand up and tell the truth.’’

headline: Projects Hit Hard by Slashed Grants
text: Mayors around the country are asking, Why has Washington cut one of the main federal programs for cities by a quarter in the last couple of years?

headline: Lottery Numbers

text: On a rainy Wednesday in Brooklyn, one might have expected some enthusiasm for a new law that next year will allow livery cabs to be hailed on the street in northern Manhattan and the four other boroughs. Instead, some who work with livery cabs were skeptical about the effect the law might have, while those in the yellow cab business worried about its potential impact.

headline: Young Ranger Rebounds With Help From Richards
text: As usual, Michael Del Zotto had dinner at a Manhattan restaurant Wednesday night with Brad Richards. The meal, on the eve of the Rangers’ game against the Islanders at Madison Square Garden, has become a ritual for the teammates. They also live in the same downtown apartment building. For Del Zotto, a third-year defenseman, Richards’s guidance is a primary reason he is flourishing after a season so disastrous, he could not even dismiss it as a sophomore slump.

headline: After Fatal Standoff, Agency Rues Not Doing More
text: SAN ANTONIO — One September morning last year, a sheriff’s deputy in Kleberg County on the South Texas coast interviewed a woman who had been living on a beach with her two children.

headline: Before a Brutal Death, a Reputation for Generosity and Eccentricity
text: She has come to be known for the brutal way in which she was killed: set ablaze inside an elevator, burned alive just feet from her apartment door.

headline: Health Fears Over Suspect French Breast Implants Spread Abroad
text: PARIS — Health officials in at least a half-dozen countries are grappling with the intense anxiety of tens of thousands of women who received breast implants that were made in France with substandard silicone — and that have been rupturing at unusually high rates.

headline: In Final Preseason Game, Frontcourt Gives Knicks a Reason for Optimism
text: The games will matter soon — sooner than anyone would prefer — and the Knicks will accept that cold reality with a mix of trepidation and self-assurance. They are too new to be entirely comfortable, but talented enough to feel secure.

headline: Economy Contributes to Slowest Population Growth Rate Since ’40s
text: WASHINGTON — The population of the United States grew this year at its slowest rate since the 1940s, the Census Bureau reported on Wednesday, as the gloomy economy continued to depress births and immigration fell to its lowest level since 1991.

headline: What Does $40 Mean to You?
text: After House Republicans rejected a Senate compromise to extend a payroll tax cut, the White House took the fight to Twitter with the hashtag #40dollars.

headline: A Big Difference in Home Sales

headline: India’s Boom Brings Fortunes to Some Dalits
text: India is home to a “tiny but growing class of millionaires from the Dalit population,” Lydia Polgreen writes in a long feature article in The New York Times today.

headline: In Islamic Law, Gingrich Sees a Mortal Threat to U.S.
text: WASHINGTON — Long before he announced his presidential run this year, Newt Gingrich had become the most prominent American politician to embrace an alarming premise: that Shariah, or Islamic law, poses a threat to the United States as grave as or graver than terrorism.

headline: Gingrich Says He’s Ready to Take the Heat
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — A look of utter disbelief crossed Newt Gingrich’s face Wednesday when a reporter told him that Mitt Romney had suggested earlier that Mr. Gingrich could not stand the heat of a presidential campaign.

headline: Foes of Hungary’s Government Fear ‘Demolition of Democracy’
text: BUDAPEST — In less than two years as a member of the Hungarian Parliament, Timea Szabo says she has looked on helplessly as the ruling Fidesz Party has used its two-thirds majority to tighten its grip on the news media and the courts, redraw parliamentary districts in its favor and pack the constitutional court with supporters. On Jan. 1, a new “majoritarian” Constitution written and ratified by Fidesz takes hold.

headline: Sports Replay: Dec. 21
text: The day in sports, including World Cup skiing in Austria and the Arab Games in Qatar.

headline: Where Crèches Once Stood, Atheists Now Hold Forth
text: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — The elaborate Nativity scenes rose in a city park along the oceanfront here every December for nearly six decades. More than a dozen life-size dioramas depicted the Annunciation, Mary and Joseph being turned away at the inn and, of course, the manger.

headline: Henry E. Catto Jr., Who Served 4 Presidents, Dies at 81
text: Henry E. Catto Jr., who was tapped by four Republican presidents for high-profile jobs including director of the United States Information Agency, chief Pentagon spokesman and ambassador to Britain and El Salvador, died on Sunday at his home in San Antonio. He was 81.

text: NYT Front Page for 12/22/2011

headline: Fixing Up Embassy, Congo Republic Raises Hackles in Capital
text: WASHINGTON — The Republic of Congo is no stranger to strife. Civil wars have battered the central African nation since its independence, neighboring Angola sent troops over the border in 1997, and a militia known as “ninjas” waged a guerrilla campaign for years.

headline: Border Fence Blocks Bears in Migration, Study Finds
text: GILA BEND, Ariz. — The much-ballyhooed border fence has not just made it more difficult for illegal immigrants to slip across from Mexico into the United States. It has also become an obstacle, researchers say, for migrating bears.

headline: A Review Is Ordered of Finances in Detroit
text: Michigan officials ordered a formal review of the City of Detroit’s finances on Wednesday after a preliminary examination by the state found “probable financial stress.”

headline: Burnt Body Identified as That of Missing Brooklyn Coffee Shop Owner
text: When the proprietor of a Brooklyn coffee shop was reported missing nearly two months ago, his neighbors fanned out to look for him. Storefronts and subway stations were plastered with signs. A Facebook group popped up looking for clues, and local blogs and newspapers followed the case.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Watch: It’s Still a Toss-Up
text: It’s all over now but the star-studded finale.

headline: Venezuela: Another Plea to Free a Judge
text: The American linguist Noam Chomsky, a prominent source of intellectual inspiration for President Hugo Chávez, made a new appeal on Wednesday for the release of María Lourdes Afiuni, a judge arrested two years ago by the secret intelligence police. The detention of Judge Afiuni, who was given two additional years of house arrest in December, has raised concern over the erosion of judicial independence in Venezuela. In July, Mr. Chomsky requested clemency for Judge Afiuni, who was arrested after she released a Venezuelan businessman from detention. The new appeal, made in a public letter to Mr. Chávez, detailed the death threats and other abuses suffered by Judge Afiuni during more than a year in a women’s prison, and her inability now to leave her home. “After more than two years in custody, there are no guarantees of a fair trial,” Mr. Chomsky wrote. “I am convinced that Judge Afiuni has suffered enough.”

headline: Israel Accuses 4 Countries of Meddling in Its Affairs
text: JERUSALEM — In a highly unusual response to criticism from European nations on the Security Council, the Israeli Foreign Ministry bluntly accused the countries of “interfering with Israel’s domestic affairs” and warned that they risked making themselves “irrelevant.”

headline: Cairo Clashes Seem to End
text: CAIRO — The death toll from the weekend’s clashes between the military police and protesters demanding the end of military rule rose to 15 on Wednesday, but the five days of street fighting appeared for the moment to come to an end.

headline: Bleeding Green: Giants Fans Owe Coach a Break
text: Brian Bassett is the founder of SNY’s The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian_Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

headline: A Medical School More Like Hogwarts
text: It’s been clear for several years now that while aspiring doctors may start medical school as happy and as healthy as their non-doctoring peers, four years later they aren’t.

headline: YuleBlog: Goal’s M.L.S. Gift Guide
text: Children may be the gift that keep on taking, but when it comes to the season of giving, there is nothing quite like a dreaded trip to the mall — though these days the Internet has evolved into an electronic mall beyond compare.

headline: California: Nurses Plan One-Day Strike Over Contracts
text: Thousands of nurses plan to hold a one-day strike on Thursday over contract disputes between the California nurses’ union and two health care organizations. About 4,000 nurses employed by Sutter Health, based in the San Francisco area, will walk off the job at eight hospitals unless a deal is reached. Around 2,000 nurses from a Long Beach hospital system also plan to strike. More than 23,000 California nurses staged a one-day strike in September. The nurses were locked out at Sutter hospitals after the strike, and one patient died when a replacement nurse administered an incorrect dosage of medicine. Sutter plans to bring in replacement nurses on Thursday and Friday. A Sutter spokeswoman said care would not be compromised.

headline: Dyed in Blue: Giants Fans Weigh In on Ryan
text: Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

headline: Word of the Day | cubicle
text: cubicle •\ˈkyü-bi-kəl\• noun

headline: Massachusetts: Harvard Yard Reopening After Protest
text: Harvard University said it would reopen Harvard Yard to the public on Thursday, six weeks after Occupy protesters set up tents there. Citing security, the university closed the yard to everyone but students and employees after an encampment went up there in early November. The protesters removed most of their tents this week.

headline: Ad Watch: Attacking Rivals, in Black and White
text: Make Us Great Again, the deep-pocketed independent political action group supporting Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, is on the air in South Carolina and Iowa with an ad highly critical of Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich.

headline: Bears, Dolphins and the Animal Stories We Tell
text: Ever since Peter Singer’s “Animal Liberation” laid the groundwork for modern animal advocacy more than 35 years ago, it has been a central tenet of the movement that we go ethically astray when we let emotional proximity to humans and a handful of nonhuman species trump the obvious interests of other animals. Although animal rights proponents haven’t always embraced Singer’s brand of utilitarianism, they have generally followed his rejection of emotionalism, reserving particular scorn for the sentimentality that allows people to lavish money and attention on pets while happily eating cows and pigs — mammals every bit as intelligent and capable of suffering as dogs and cats — which lead tortured existences before arriving on our plates.

headline: Blasts Rock Baghdad as Political Crisis in Iraq Deepens
text: BAGHDAD — A series of explosions ripped through Iraq’s capital on Thursday, an ominous turn for a country reeling from a deepening political and sectarian crisis that erupted after the departure of the United States military. It was Baghdad’s deadliest day in more than a year.

headline: News Quiz | Dec. 22, 2011
text: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on today’s paper.

headline: U.S. Report Faults Two Sides in Deadly Pakistan Strike
text: WASHINGTON — A United States military investigation has concluded that checks and balances devised to prevent cross-border mishaps with Pakistan failed to avert a deadly NATO airstrike last month in part because American officials did not trust Pakistan enough to give it detailed information about American troop locations in Afghanistan.

headline: Dec. 22, 1864 | Gen. Sherman Offers Savannah as a ‘Christmas Gift’ to President Lincoln
text: On Dec. 22, 1864, as the Civil War entered its final months, Union Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman sent a message to President Lincoln notifying him that he had captured the city of Savannah, Ga., thereby completing his 300-mile “March to the Sea” that had begun in Atlanta on Nov. 16.

headline: Test Yourself | English, Dec. 22, 2011
text: The question was written by Shannon Doyne. It comes from the article “Not Without My Pet.”

headline: A Conversation With: Sachin Pilot
text: In recent months the Indian government held meetings with Internet intermediaries like Facebook and Google, and asked them to prescreen user content and remove things that might be incendiary or objectionable, inspiring an outpouring of complaint and a rebuff from these companies. On Dec. 15, the government appeared to step down from that position, telling these companies in a meeting that there would be no censorship of Internet content.

headline: Beyond Santa: Holiday Traditions Around the World
text: WHERE, on weekends leading up to Christmas, do two caves offer caroling sing-alongs?

headline: No One Is Above the Law
text: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of “13 Bankers.”

headline: Black and White, and Black All Over
What’s Your Favorite Holiday Food Memory?
text: Nine writers for the Dining section and many Times readers shared their favorite holiday recipes and remembrances. When you think back on holidays meals past, what stands out most? Does your family have traditional dishes that you look forward to each year? Or does one particular meal stand out in your memory?

headline: The Early Word: Benefits
text: In Today’s TimesPresident Obama has benefited politically from the fight between House and Senate Republicans over how to work with Democrats and the White House to extend a payroll tax cut and jobless benefits, Jackie Calmes writes. But, she reports, whether the clash ultimately turns out to be a plus for Mr. Obama hinges on the economy’s performance.

headline: ‘The Kid Who Likes English Class’ Wonders What to Do About College
text: My best friend asked me last week, “Where are you even applying?” and I avoided her question.  Mostly because I just don’t want to talk about college.  These applications have been hanging over my head for months and I’m still not finished, still not done mulling over them.  Even with my best friend I don’t want to talk about it.  It makes me anxious to think about what I still have left to do before the Jan. 1 deadline.

headline: Autodromo: Watches From Brooklyn, Keeping Time in Italian
text: Two years ago, Bradley Price was driving his red 1983 Alfa Romeo GTV6 2.5 when inspiration struck.

headline: Shop Delivers Deals and Donations in Prague
text: Beer can already be found for less than a euro a half-liter in Prague, and many of the city’s attractions are free, but now it’s even easier to find a good deal here: the city has become home to a true thrift shop, where you can root out buried bargains as well as find a home for items cluttering your closet or suitcase.

headline: Aspiring to Be First in the Family to Attend College, and Pay for It, Too
text: I sit at my desk with my right hand anxiously tapping in rhythm to my iTunes, my left hand twirling the baby hairs that stick out of my ponytail, and my leg shaking of restless leg syndrome.

headline: The False Promise of Biometrics
text: NEW DELHI — Earlier this month, just two days after my grandfather and I received a summons to register for India’s national unique identification (UID) program, a sweeping initiative launched with much fanfare, a parliamentary committee ordered a review of the project, effectively freezing it.

headline: British Airways’ Parent Wins Lufthansa’s BMI
text: PARIS — British Airways and the Spanish carrier Iberia beat out Virgin Atlantic on Thursday in the bidding for British Midland International, the unprofitable airline being sold by Lufthansa of Germany.

headline: How People Shopped Online This Holiday Season
text: Little time remains for online shoppers to have gifts delivered in time for Christmas, and sales numbers for online shopping this season are arriving. The trends are clear: shoppers spent much more money online this year than last year, and they did a lot of their shopping on tablets like the iPad.

headline: At Presidency’s 11th Hour, Medvedev Proposes Systemic Change
text: MOSCOW — It finally happened: President Dmitri A. Medvedev, the man who was supposed to embody the aspirations of young middle-class Russians, has outlined a concrete and substantive agenda for political change. In his last state of the nation speech before leaving office, Mr. Medvedev recommended returning to the direct election of governors, removing officials’ wives and children from the leadership of lucrative corporations, and creating a public television station protected from the Kremlin’s manipulation, among other changes.

headline: Week 16 N.F.L. Game Probabilities: Giants vs. Jets
text: It wasn’t too difficult to pick a game to highlight for New York Times readers this week. The Giants take on the Jets, with both teams  in the thick of their playoff races. The path for the Giants goes through the N.F.C. East division championship, while the path for the Jets can lead only to the A.F.C.’s sixth-seed wild-card berth.

headline: A Dressmaker Tries to Deliver the Right Dress at the Right Price
text: As she works to get a handle on pricing, Susan Parker, a member of our business group, weighs the competing interests of art and commerce. On the one hand, Ms. Parker, who owns the dressmaker Bari Jay, is thrilled with her creative designer and credits her with much of the company’s turnaround. The designer, Kristine Eikenbary, takes her inspiration from higher-end fashion. “Her designs are gorgeous,” said Ms. Parker.

headline: Christmas Tree Care, With an Audience
text: This is the time of year when you hear all the stuff that you are supposed to do to maintain your Christmas tree after you win the nine-rounder to force it into place without poking a hole in the ceiling or electrocuting yourself when you string up the lights.

headline: Innocence Is Trampled, but a Bond Endures
text: There is no combat in the early scenes of “War Horse,” Steven Spielberg’s sweeping adaptation of the popular stage spectacle, but the film opens with a cinematic assault as audacious and unsparing as the Normandy landing in “Saving Private Ryan.” With widescreen, pastoral vistas dappled in golden sunlight and washed in music (by John Williams) that is somehow both grand and folksy, Mr. Spielberg lays siege to your cynicism, bombarding you with strong and simple appeals to feeling.

headline: Hard to Grasp, but Harder to Say Farewell
text: Not long before his 80th birthday in 1999 the choreographer Merce Cunningham went back to his hometown, Centralia, Wash., and spent some time with his brother Jack, a lawyer. After they talked about old acquaintances, Jack suddenly asked, “Merce, when are you going to make something the public likes?”

headline: Coordinated Explosions Kill Dozens in Baghdad
text: A series of explosions shook Baghdad early Thursday, killing at least 63 people.

headline: Rushing to Get Your Expenses Done? Join the Club
text: On Tuesday, I was sitting down to file for some work-related expenses after receiving yet another e-mail reminder of the inferno that awaits employees who are delinquent on such things. Moments later, a different e-mail landed in my inbox — this one from Concur, a company that runs an online expense management system for businesses — telling me that Tuesday, Dec. 20, was expected to be the busiest day of the year for filing for expenses.

headline: Trucking Trout to Their Native Streams
text: In an innovative conservation effort, biologists on the Clark Fork River are using genetic testing to help get bull trout back to their natal streams to spawn.

headline: Societe Generale’s Investment Banking Chief Steps Down
text: LONDON — Michel Péretié, head of Société Générale’s corporate and investment banking division, is leaving the French bank to pursue other opportunities.

headline: Online Sales of Louis C. K. Special Cross $1 Million Mark
text: Though the comedian Louis C. K. may not seem like the kind of guy who derives much joy from the holiday season – let alone anything else – Santa Claus has brought him an early Christmas gift. In an interview on Wednesday’s broadcast of “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” Louis C. K. said he had grossed more than $1 million from his online comedy special, “Louis C. K.: Live at the Beacon Theater,” after 10 days on sale, and would be donating part of that money to charity.

text: Though the year is drawing to a close, there is no end in sight for cloud fever.

text: Late Thursday afternoon, the Indian government introduced the Lokpal Bill in the lower house of Parliament, which would create an all-powerful nine-member anti-corruption ombudsman agency. The law will be debated next week.

headline: Daily Report: New Uses for Skype
text: In Thursday’s New York Times, Julie Scelfo writes about how Skype, an eight-year-old technology, is being used in new ways in growing numbers of American homes. The Darvick family of Birmingham, Mich., for example, celebrates what they call “Skypanukkah,” to observe the Jewish holiday; with family members spread out in three different cities, they light the Hanukkah candles together through video chat.

headline: State Is Investigating Pearson Foundation Trips
text: In the news on Thursday, the state attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, is investigating whether the Pearson Foundation, the nonprofit arm of Pearson Education, acted improperly to influence New York State officials to obtain lucrative state contracts when it paid for trips and other perks.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 22
text: It’s been a busy year for Carine Roitfeld, who was replaced last December as the powerful editor of French Vogue by a former friend, Emmanuelle Alt. There have been wild parties she has hosted, fashion magazines and ads she has collaborated on, and talk of starting a new magazine. Ms. Roitfeld, Eric Wilson writes, “has taken every opportunity to demonstrate the value of her brand, post-Vogue,” and concludes: “Rarely has the stock price of a fashion figure shown such resilience, after taking a severe blow to the side, since Lady Duff-Gordon survived the sinking of the Titanic.”

headline: DealBook: Yahoo to Consider Sale of Asian Assets
text: The board of Yahoo is considering a sale of the bulk of the company’s valuable holdings in the Alibaba Group of China and Yahoo’s Japanese affiliate, report Evelyn M. Rusli and Michael J. de la Merced on DealBook. They write that Yahoo would sell the properties back to their majority owners in a complicated transaction that values the stakes at about $17 billion. Read the entire post.

headline: Brussels Hotel Offers Tintin Tie-In
text: A high-end hotel in Brussels, Tintin’s stomping ground, is offering two new packages and four themed rooms to celebrate the popular comic book hero. The promotion — from the Hotel Amigo  —  is timed to correspond with the release of the film “The Adventures of Tintin: The Secret of the Unicorn,” which opened on Wednesday in the United States.

headline: Winter Wonders | Cold Front
text: Reality check: it’s December. And chilling weather has (finally) forced women to break out the big ones — the fur and shearling coats. Here, the pop singer Kylie Minogue wears a quilted puffer with a cozy collar and a pair of black leather boots; the actress Rooney Mara picks up lunch in a cloud-like cocoon with a full bell silhouette; and the designer Ashley Olsen keeps it classic in a full-sleeved fur with an elegant rust-colored scarf and dark navy handbag.

headline: What We’re Reading

headline: Anticorruption Bill Provokes an Outcry in India
text: NEW DELHI — India’s government introduced long-awaited legislation on Thursday to create an independent, anticorruption agency, provoking a loud outcry from opposition parties and some civil society activists who attacked the measure from all directions.

headline: House Republican Floats 3-Month Payroll Tax Extension
