headline: The Concussion Issue, From a Player’s Point of View
text: Chris Pronger, Sidney Crosby, Claude Giroux, Milan Michalek and now Jeff Skinner. The list of superstars having the dreaded label of being out indefinitely with a concussion continues to grow. By far, this has been the lead story in the N.H.L. over the last year. It began when Sidney Crosby was found to have a concussion in January. It took a backseat for a short while as Crosby returned to play in late November, but before anyone got comfortable, a slew of great players, including Crosby, have been sent to the press box to watch games, out indefinitely with concussions after all taking blows to the head.

headline: Buzz Over Who’s Not in North Korea Picture(s)
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Researchers scrutinizing North Korea’s official images and lists of mourners paying respects to Kim Jong-il have noticed two conspicuous absences: the elder brothers of Kim Jong-un, the appointed heir.

headline: Sebastian Currier: Piano Sonata, Other Works
text: Laura Melton, pianist (Naxos 8.559638; CD).

headline: New and Unpopular
text: Congress is closing out 2011 with an 11 percent approval rating, and a 17 percent yearly average. Those are both record lows—Gallup conducted its first Congressional job approval survey in 1974, and never before have Americans been so united in their dissatisfaction.

headline: High Notes and Low Points for Classical Music
text: THIS holiday season brings a set of gifts for the world of classical music, in the form of the highly uncoveted and arbitrarily granted Special Awards for 2011. It was a year of financial hardship for the arts (what year isn’t?), especially for many opera houses, symphony orchestras, festivals and chamber music organizations, but high points also abounded. The following 10 prizes are bestowed in no particular order.

headline: The Met’s Gleeful Baroque Mash-Up
text: THE Oxford English Dictionary defines a pastiche as “a medley of various ingredients; a hotchpotch, farrago, jumble.” The word is derived from the 13th-century Latin “pasticium,” a savory Mediterranean pie filled with whatever is left over in the kitchen. A modern analogue, pastitsio, can be found at every Greek diner in the land.

headline: Let Them Eat Kulfi: France Escapes to Fantasy India
text: The French have found a way to cope with the unrelenting bad economic news in Europe: escape to India. Not the real India but a fantasy land far removed from the realities of sinking currencies and credit-rating downgrades.

headline: A Flat Year Overall for Crime in New York
text: The picture of crime in New York City in 2011 is shaping up as virtually a mirror image of the year before, according to police statistics.

headline: Regulator Fines Barclays Capital Over Subprime Mortgages
text: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said on Thursday that it had fined Barclays Capital $3 million for misrepresenting information about subprime mortgage securities the bank had sold from 2007 to 2010.

headline: Class Parent: Giving Back to Teacher
text: How do you raise enough for a respectable gift for the pre-K teacher without making anyone feel bad? The writer, a co-class parent, also shares her Uncle Billy/Mr. Potter moment when an envelope of cash goes missing.

headline: A Voter’s Advice to Romney: Changing Your Mind Is a Good Trait
text: BETHLEHEM, N.H. — Mitt Romney came to the Elks Lodge here Thursday morning for coffee and conversation, but he left with a piece of unsolicited advice from a voter on how to spin his perceived flip-flops.

headline: On Our Radar: India’s Growing Nuclear Sector
text: The rapid expansion of India’s nuclear energy sector, which is expected to triple in size by the end of the decade, is stirring anxiety about insufficient regulatory safeguards, construction in quake zones and the displacement of farmers and other landowners. [The Sydney Morning Herald]

headline: 36 Hours: Cambridge, Mass.
text: Even with the winter chill settling in, Cambridge, a city of bookstores, art houses and eclectic bars, is an ideal place to visit despite the cold.

headline: Dear FloFab: When Your Guest Wants to Preview the Menu
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: Steve Jobs to Receive a Grammy
text: Steven P. Jobs was not a musician, and opinions are mixed about whether the invention of iTunes will be good for the recording industry in the long run, but his mark on how music is distributed appears indelible, and so the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences has decided to give him a Grammy award in February.

headline: The Get | Visnja Brdar Power Ring
text: The diamond pattern on this hand-carved rock crystal and white gold “Power” ring ($14,000) may look like a snowflake, but it actually represents the sun. “The energy of the sun is the most powerful force on earth,” says the New York-based jeweler Visnja Brdar. “I wanted to create a piece that reflected that energy. When I wear it, I radiate and feel that anything is possible.” Known for graphic simplicity and fastidious pavé work, all of Brdar’s pieces have uplifting themes like Love, Courage, Freedom and Faith. She may as well have called this one Perseverance, since it took two years to make. “I finally found a way for the crystal to appear as if it is floating on the finger. It is perfect.”

headline: Croatia’s Monumental Provocateur
text: ASK the Croatian artist Sanja Ivekovic about her work, and she is likely to minimize her role in it. “It is not a genius that is making art but the collaboration of many people,“ she declared this month, speaking in heavily accented English, as she strode into the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art. “We should be grateful not to God for giving us our talent but to the people who support us.”

headline: 36 Hours: Cambridge, Mass.
text: WHEN the leaves have fallen and the winter chill has set in, many small cities slip into a prolonged hibernation. But Cambridge barely misses a beat. During the holidays, tree branches are strung with tiny white lights, and local theater productions celebrate the season. A city of bookstores and coffeehouses, art-house cinemas and eclectic neighborhood bars, the People’s Republic of Cambridge has traded its Puritan past for a dynamic, cosmopolitan present. Spread out along the tree-lined shore of the Charles River, the city is a dense collection of grand Federal and Greek Revival mansions and modest century-old bungalows, modern office towers and brick dormitories. Nicknamed Boston’s Left Bank for its bohemian image, Cambridge is easy to caricature, but hard to dislike.

headline: Hungary in the News
text: The news section, that is. Good article, confirming Kim Lane Scheppele’s points and adding some color to the story.

headline: Welcome Back, Clippers
text: While it’s hard to admit that the N.B.A. got anything right in its hubris-fueled lockout, we can take consolation in the fact that what turned out well was entirely unintentional. Even better: it will cost the owners money. Yes, what we got out of that petulant billionaires’ spat was a shorter N.B.A. season and one that’s starting at a festive time — although playing so many games on Christmas Day is most decidedly festive overkill, and all of those people selling hot dogs and directing parking lot traffic really should have the day off.

headline: 36 Seconds in Cambridge, Mass.
text: Cambridge is a city of bookstores, art-house cinemas and eclectic neighborhood bars.

headline: ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Announces Its Broadway Cast
text: Technically, “Jesus Christ Superstar” offers a stylized retelling of the story of Easter, up to the Crucifixion, and the Passover seder that was the Last Supper. But the producers of the coming Broadway revival of that Andrew Lloyd Webber/Tim Rice musical are using the Christmas season to announce the cast, which will keep intact the lineup from its La Jolla Playhouse incarnation in San Diego and retain most of the performers who originated the production at the Stratford Shakespeare Festival in Ontario, Canada.

headline: This week Ben Ratliff, Jon Pareles and Nate Chinen discuss some of the most memorable songs of 2011.
text: This week Ben Ratliff, Jon Pareles and Nate Chinen discuss some of the most memorable songs of 2011.

headline: Take Christopher Plummer’s Advice
text: The Bagger spent some time with Christopher Plummer recently, over a couple of glasses of Far Niente, a California chardonnay he knew well. Of course Mr. Plummer, with a six-decade stage and film, career, has some words of advice for younger performers, should they ask.

headline: The Music They Made
text: A musical collage of the musicians and songwriters who died during 2011.

headline: Principals Protest Tally: 1,088
text: The number of principals who have signed a letter objecting to the state's system of teacher evaluations has grown to 1,088, with more New York City public school principals joining the protest.

headline: Apps and Games for Traveling Kids
text: The Practical Traveler of The Times’s Travel section, Michelle Higgins, knows what it is to be a practical traveling parent. She’s provided a list of apps for iPads, iTouches and iPhones, along with a few offline games and tricks, that should help keep kids busy in cars and on planes during holiday trips. Some of her favorites are also mine (like any form of travel desk, Zingo to Go and Scribblenauts) and some I plan to check out (I have a daughter who will love My Playhome, and I’m certain Highlights Hidden Pictures would be a hit).

headline: At the Laundry, Rooting for a Clean Game
text: RUTHERFORD, N.J. — On Saturday afternoon at MetLife Stadium, there will be a large (and loud) contingent of Jets fans wearing green. The Giants fans, clad in blue, will surely be heard, too.

headline: Photographing the Unseeable
text: This week, nytimes.com published the final installment of the Lives Restored series, which profiled people who are functioning normally despite severe mental illness. Written by Benedict Carey and photographed by Damon Winter, the series also includes five videos that were produced by Nick Harbaugh, Nancy Donaldson and Soo-Jeong Kang and shot by Mr. Winter.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘In the Jewish Synagogue at Newport’
text: Today’s Poetry Pairing matches the Emma Lazarus poem “In the Jewish Synagogue at Newport” with a 2009 article, “A Synagogue Despairs of a Sweeter New Year.”

headline: Drinking Over a Show’s Demise, First Round on the House
text: They gathered in a darkened bar in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, long faces concealed by longer beards, to say goodbye to the show that called their borough home.

headline: Spanish Man Arrested in Leak of Madonna Single
text: Spanish police have arrested a 31-year-old man and charged him with stealing a demo version of one of Madonna’s songs and illegally posting it on the Internet, Reuters reported. The police identified the man only by his initials: J.M.R. He was arrested in Zaragoza, charged and released, pending a trial. Investigators described him as an avid Madonna fan.

headline: Cleverest List of Theatrical Moments
text: ASKED to recall unforgettable moments from the year in theater, one writer after another for The New York Times suggested scenes from Jez Butterworth’s “Jerusalem,” which won Mark Rylance a Tony Award for best actor last spring. Stipulated: “Jerusalem” was full of memorable moments. Stipulated: The Times’s critics Ben Brantley and Charles Isherwood already named it among their Top 10 shows of the year. Further stipulated: No “Jerusalem” here. But much else to remember, some of it surfacing in the smallest and most offbeat of places.

headline: House G.O.P. Leaders Agree to Extension of Payroll Tax Cut
text: WASHINGTON — Bowing under intense pressure from members of their own party, House Republican leaders agreed Thursday to accept a temporary extension of the payroll tax cut, beating a hasty retreat from a showdown that Republicans increasingly saw as a threat to their election opportunities next year.

headline: Case Study | On Beheading Bubbly
text: Though we like to think of ourselves as a humble people who disdain ostentatious display, there are those occasions that encourage, nay, demand the chest-thumping, post-touchdown hubris inherent in our species. One of these is the presentation of a frosty bottle of Champagne. It’s like a convoluted Myers-Briggs test for personalities. Many people open such a gift, even on New Year’s Eve, with the gravity of a monk, showing the respect and discretion due a vinous masterwork. But there are those more excitable oenophiles, whose personal standard — “What Would Pirates Do?” — dictates freeing the bubbly soul by lopping off the bottle’s neck with a saber.

headline: Arab League Delegates Arrive in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As violence continued around Syria, delegates from the Arab League traveled to Damascus on Thursday to start monitoring the government’s promise to end its violent suppression of the nine-month-old uprising. The visit is intended to set the ground rules for a mission that is supposed to bring hundreds of observers to Syria in the coming weeks.

headline: Two New Client Libraries: Times Wire and Campaign Cash
text: Now that we have 13 APIs to use, it’s time for some client libraries, too. Our APIs get a lot of use internally and on NYTimes.com, often in small parts of a larger project or to power a single interactive. In most of these cases we’ve resorted to pulling data directly from endpoints rather than writing clients to help manage the task. But we’re excited to release Ruby libraries that make it easier to interact with two of our APIs.

headline: Coughlin, Ryan, Tebow: Answers for Readers

headline: ‘Twas the Week After Layoffs
text: What a great year it’s been on Wall Street! Zooming bank profits, rock-solid job security, widespread appreciation on Main Street for financiers and a European economic outlook as bright as Rudolph’s nose.

headline: The Choice Q. and A. on Facebook: An Invitation to Juniors, and a Recap
text: Thursday night on The Choice blog’s Facebook page — facebook.com/nytimesthechoice — we’ll host our final, hourlong admissions Q. and A. of the week (and the year). And we’d like the main (but by no means only) theme to be this one: What college admissions homework might high-school juniors (and their parents) assign themselves over the holiday break, and what should their priorities be right after New Year’s?

headline: Concord Monitor Endorses Huntsman
text: Even as Mitt Romney and Newt Gingrich grab the headlines with a nasty slug-fest, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is quietly working New Hampshire in the hope of pulling a come-from-nowhere upset in the nation’s first primary.

headline: The Subtle ECB
text: A number of people have asked me for my reaction to Floyd Norris’s piece today on Europe. It’s a good summary of the argument many people are making about why the European situation looks less dire right now than it seemed a few weeks ago.

headline: Stephen Daldry, Director’s Director
text: Not all of the awards buzz has faded for “Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,” Stephen Daldry’s 9/11 Oscar bait. Mr. Daldry, whose three previous features (“The Hours,” “The Reader” and “Billy Elliot”) were all Oscar nominees or winners, will receive the director of the year award from the Palm Springs International Film Festival, it announced today. In a statement, Harold Matzner, the festival chairman, said that Mr. Daldry would be honored “for this haunting film and for all of his achievements as a director’s director.”

headline: Popcast: The Best Songs of 2011
Students Say No to Healthful School Fare
text: The Los Angeles Unified School District broke new ground earlier this year when it started phasing out junk food and offering students healthful new fare. The decision by L.A. Unified, one of the largest districts in the nation, to swap out corn dogs and chocolate milk for quinoa salads and vegetarian curries was seen as a move that might inspire other districts across the country to do the same.

headline: Hearing in Soldier’s WikiLeaks Case Ends
text: FORT MEADE, Md. — The military hearing against Pfc. Bradley Manning closed on Thursday, with lawyers and onlookers alternately portraying the young soldier as a traitor who acted with premeditation and as an emotionally troubled whistle-blower.

headline: Taking the Plight of Homeless Veterans as His Own
text: I went for a run after eating Thanksgiving dinner this year, and by the time I got home, I couldn’t stop thinking about how incredibly thankful I was to have a roof over my head and a warm bed to sleep in. My hands stung, and my feet were numb from the bitter cold. I started to think about how blessed I was to be sheltered from our brutal Minnesota winters.

headline: Rhapsody, Veteran Streamer of Music, Reaches a Million Subscribers
text: Digital services like Spotify that stream millions of songs by subscription have made some of the music industry’s biggest news this year. Facebook and taste makers like Rolling Stone have embraced these services as the future of music listening, while artists and record companies have fretted about whether they hurt download sales.

headline: Apps for Wine Lovers on Your Gift List
text: Technology and the Internet have not yet infiltrated the dining room or the wine cellar the way they have the living room. But Gary Vaynerchuk, the online wine reviewer, recommends a few online gifts for wine lovers this season.

headline: The Lives They Lived
text: This year seemed to have more than its fair share of iconic deaths, but this is not a greatest-hits issue. Instead, we gravitated to those with an untold tale. Ira Glass of “This American Life” edits a special section devoted to ordinary people.

text: When it comes to holiday tipping and gifts, workers who scrub our floors tend to get more than people who educate our children, according to a survey from Consumer Reports.

text: The panel found as many different styles as there were shades of pink, but less complexity than in ordinary Champagnes, leaving them to question what made the rosés so popular.

text: As the French government makes plans to expand Champagne country, farmers and landowners await the decision of whether their land qualifies — and increases in value 200 times over.

But the idea has not faded in the Republican primaries.

text: LONDON — The outlook for financial stability in Europe has worsened since September as Europe’s debt crisis started to affect the financial system and economic growth prospects, Mervyn King, the vice chairman of the European Systemic Risk Board, said Thursday.

headline: 5 Tips for Teachers to Navigate Facebook's Features and Risks

Facebook's consultant for education offers concrete tips -- how to set your privacy restrictions, where to click to get 'help' -- for using the social media tool, and provides some suggestions for using it safely in teaching.

headline: Turkey Lashes Out Over French Bill About Genocide
text: ISTANBUL — Turkey halted diplomatic consultations and military dealings in a major rupture with France on Thursday after the lower house of the French Parliament approved legislation making it a crime to deny that the Turkish Army committed genocide against Armenians in the early 20th century.

headline: Romney Says He Won’t Release Tax Returns
text: 4:17 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney, who is one of the wealthiest men ever to seek the presidency, said on Wednesday that he had no intention of releasing his tax returns if he became the Republican presidential nominee, breaking with a long tradition in both parties.

headline: In Europe, Juggling Image and Capital
text: LONDON — Stung by souring loans and troubled government bond portfolios, many European banks are being forced by regulators to raise money to build up their cash cushions against future losses.

headline: How Smart Is This Bird? Let It Count the Ways
text: By now, the intelligence of birds is well known. Alex the African gray parrot had great verbal skills. Scrub jays, which hide caches of seeds and other food, have remarkable memories. And New Caledonian crows make and use tools in ways that would put the average home plumber to shame.

headline: Biodiversity in Turkey, at Risk Yet Largely Ignored
text: A new paper by biologists in Turkey and the United States warns that while Turkey’s rich biodiversity is unique and globally important, it remains poorly researched and faces growing threats, especially from development.

headline: For Saab Owners and Would-Be Buyers, What to Expect of Warranties, Recalls and Fire Sales
text: The bankruptcy of Saab Automobile leaves owners, dealers and would-be customers with plenty of questions and some unpleasant answers.

headline: A Call to Protect Humble Fish, for Seabirds’ Sake
text: When people talk about the environmental effects of salmon aquaculture, they usually focus on water pollution and the spread of disease to wild fish stocks. But there is another big problem: It takes more than a pound of fish to produce a pound of salmon.

headline: Brussels: The Chocolate Trail
text: CHOCOLATE — like fashion, wine and finance — has become a complex cultural phenomenon. There is basic chocolate for the masses, artisanal chocolate for purists and avant-garde creations for connoisseurs. In Brussels, a polyglot city at the geographic and cultural crossroads of Europe, you get it all.

headline: Sampling the Chocolates of Brussels
text: Exploring the city’s pralines, chocolatiers and cacao history.

headline: Candidate-Peeping in New Hampshire
text: IN a presidential campaign dominated by televised debates and YouTube videos, there’s one place where you can still find old-fashioned retail politics in action: New Hampshire. As the state’s Jan. 10 primary approaches, candidate-peepers will have plenty of chances to see presidential hopefuls up close as they visit town halls, school gyms and American Legions from Nashua to North Conway.

headline: Week 16 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich are here to help you with your fantasy football team. The Sablich brothers will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Life in Hotels
text: To the Editor: Regarding “My Life in Hotels” (Dec. 4), add one more tip to your excellent piece. This from a friend and hotel executive: hotel blankets are not cleaned with each change of sheets. Strip the bedspread, stow it, call housekeeping and request an additional sheet to “top sheet” your bed. A little gratuity to the housekeeper usually ensures that your bed will be freshly top-sheeted when the room is serviced.

headline: Parental Quandary Resolved: When a Friend’s Child Hits Yours
text: The real quandary last week wasn’t, perhaps, what a parent should do when a friend’s child hits yours and that friend has more excuses than actions, but how a parent should do what obviously must be done: stop the hitting. Isabel and Sharon (not their real names — all names in quandaries are changed and identifying details changed) became friends when their kids were quite young, and as they grew, Isobel saw Sharon’s kids (both boys, aged 4 and 6) bullying her 4-year-old daughter, with hitting and pushing and even a shove off a bike.

headline: N.B.A. Season Preview
text: The Knicks have improved, the defending champion Mavericks have not, but in the end, N.B.A. reporter Howard Beck believes that the Thunder and Heat will meet in the finals.

headline: Elder Bush Tells Paper Romney Is ‘Best Choice’

headline: Parts of Immigration Law Blocked in South Carolina

headline: Video: N.B.A. Season Preview

headline: A Youngster With a Key, a Word and a Quest
text: In the years since Sept. 11, that day has been revisited infrequently on American screens and with a circumspection that can feel like reluctance. Some moviemakers have probably shied away from the subject for fear of offending viewers; others, like Michael Moore, who directed “Fahrenheit 9/11,” haven’t worried about alienating a general audience because they’ve played to a specific constituency, giving their viewers what they wanted to see and hear. “Extremely Loud & Incredibly Close,” a new Sept. 11 movie, takes a different tack from most of its predecessors by treating that day not as an occasion for personal sacrifice, for national mourning or reflection, but as kitsch.

headline: Nazareth as an Eating Destination
text: THE bartender at Misk, a new restaurant and concert space in Nazareth, Israel, hurriedly scrolled through YouTube videos. His search was projected on a large screen, a new addition to the Ottoman-era white stone building. At last, he found a dance remix of an Arabic birthday song, and as the frenetic opening chords filled the room, a waitress strode out holding a cake fizzing with 18 sparkler candles.

headline: The Republican Cul-De-Sac
text: There are any number of things I’d rather be doing 72 hours before Christmas than writing about the payroll tax debate, but it’s an important window into the continuing policy dysfunction afflicting the Republican Party. The problem, to be clear, doesn’t lie in the particular stance that the House Republicans have taken over the last week, insisting on a full-year extension of the payroll tax cut rather than two-month extension agreed to in the Senate. (On the merits, the House is right to want a full-year extension, the Senate’s punt was an embarrassment, and the compromise that may be in the offing looks like better policy than a purely short-term deal.) Rather, it lies in the fact that we’ve been having drawn-out negotiations about the issue at all. Republicans should have just taken yes for answer, embraced a bipartisan tax cut, declared victory and gone home for Christmas. Instead, a Republican Party that blithely voted to extend the Bush tax cuts without any offsets suddenly became very, very concerned about “paying for” a far more modest measure, and a G.O.P. that’s supposedly committed to the lowest possible middle class tax burden decided that it needed to extract concessions from a Democratic president in exchange for supporting … a middle class tax cut.

headline: Joe Cipolla, Milan, Italy
text: It’s not quite a pairing to rival the spaghetti western, but it’s not far off: In Navigli, a trendy neighborhood in Milan, one of the most popular restaurants is an American-style steakhouse. With red-and-white-checkered tablecloths, walls crowded with black-and-white photos and a butcher counter up front, the five-year-old Joe Cipolla approximates a vintage meat-and-potatoes joint.

headline: Justice Dept. Approves Merger of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Borse
text: The Justice Department approved on Thursday the proposed merger of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Börse, but required the sale of the German exchange’s stake in Direct Edge Holdings within two years.

headline: If Car Companies Were Run Like Tech Companies …

Its business models would look absurd in any other industry. Can you imagine what the world would look like if another industry worked like the tech industry? Like, say, cars?

He was the only Republican in the Senate to vote against the war in Iraq and against extending the Bush tax cuts in 2005. He went to blacksmith school in Montana. headline: Little Ratings Momentum as ‘X-Factor’ Heads Into Finale
text: Although the first season of “The X Factor” was never the 20-million-viewer juggernaut that Simon Cowell, its creator-producer-judge, had promised, the singing competition has still been a success for Fox, with an average of 10.9 million viewers tuning in live for each episode. (Factoring in the audiences that watched the show on DVR in the following seven days, that number grows to 12.4 million.) But network executives are probably a little concerned with the lack of ratings momentum heading into the finale, which was evident on Wednesday night, when the final performance show was essentially flat when compared to last week, despite almost no original competition from the other networks. The 90-minute episode averaged 11.1 million total viewers, up slightly from 10.7 million last Wednesday, but down just as slightly in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic segment.

text: From Virginia to San Francisco, a photographic tour of some of America’s whiskey distilleries.

headline: Proud Penny Pincher’s Guide for Surviving the Tough Times
text: This time of year one’s thoughts turn toward family, friends, the best rum to decant into eggnog and — if you are like me, three years out of five — the vertiginous mountain of debt on your credit cards, and the financial reckoning that is breathing into your nostrils, a bit like a wolf.

headline: Rye Is Back, With Flavors of Americana
text: IN gold-rush-era San Francisco, bars lined every block of the Barbary Coast, the area where pioneer mixologists — back when they were called bartenders — honed their craft. Rye whiskey was their staple. A hundred years later, a visitor would have been lucky to find one or two rye labels on the shelves of bars in major American cities; bourbon had taken over as the American whiskey.

headline: Coming to a Bookstore Near You!
text: A video for the upcoming cookbook “La Tartine Gourmande,” based on the blog of the same name, made us wonder whether cookbook trailers — picture a movie trailer, but with charming kitchens and light jazz swapped in for post-apocalyptic underworlds and techno — are slowly becoming as widespread as trailers in other corners of the publishing world.

headline: Outspoken Afghan Rights Official Ousted
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — There have been few causes that Ahmad Nader Nadery, the prominent Afghan human rights activist, shied away from over the past decade: he spoke out on the killings of civilians by NATO and Taliban forces, on election fraud by President Hamid Karzai’s supporters, even on land grabs by rich and well-connected Afghans whose houses now dominate central Kabul’s broken streets.

headline: Is Americans’ Religious Freedom Under Threat?
text: In airports, classrooms and doctors’ offices, Christians and religious minorities say, Americans are falling short of the founders’ First Amendment ideals.

headline: Gingrich Wraps Up Virginia Swing
text: RICHMOND, Va. – Former House speaker Newt Gingrich used a stop here Thursday to criticize President Obama and Senate Democrats, and draw contrasts between himself and his rivals for the Republican nomination.

headline: Dayne Crist to Kansas
text: The former Notre Dame quarterback Dayne Crist announced on Twitter Thursday that he would be playing his final college season for Charlie Weis at Kansas, an unlikely reunion of two men attempting to resuscitate their once high-profile careers.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Iraq, Russia, Hungary and Iowa.

headline: A Very Hairy Christmas
text: Our favorite holiday card this year! It shows Hunter Musi, the son of the photographers Vincent J. Musi and Callie Shell.

headline: Comments About the Lives They Lived Issue Here, Please
text: We tried a few new things with this year’s Lives They Lived issue. For starters, we invited Ira Glass and his producers at “This American Life,” the wonderful radio show we all love, to guest-edit a special section. We invited readers to submit their own photographs and stories of loved ones, which succeeded beyond our highest expectations. We compiled a series of famous last tweets. Finally, we did a bit of the old thing, and commissioned some of our favorite writers, including John Jeremiah Sullivan, Maureen Dowd, Dwight Garner and Michael Paterniti, to write short essays.

headline: Mandatory Office Party and ‘Night of Dirty Songs’
text: The average holiday office party can be divided into two parts: awkward conversation with co-workers before the booze kicks in, and even more awkward conversation with co-workers after it does. That’s why the Miser tends to bow out early and head to parties where letting loose is less likely to damage professional reputations.

headline: Messrs. Lonely-Hearts, in an Unhip Gay Bar
text: A good man is hard to find, especially in this city. But is it harder or easier to find one than to find a good bar? And is it ever even possible to find such a man in such a bar?

headline: The Caucus Click: Bachmann Goes From Bus to Bike
text: Representative Michele Bachmann visited the National Motorcycle Museum as part of her  99-county tour of Iowa before the Jan. 3 caucuses.

headline: TimesCast | Bombings in Baghdad
text: Amid growing sectarian tensions, a series of coordinated bombings across Baghdad kill at least 63.

headline: Gotta Dance? Swing on Over
text: THERE are swinging parties in Manhattan nearly every night. The trick is in knowing where to find them.

headline: The Book of Books: What Literature Owes the Bible
text: The Bible is the model for and subject of more art and thought than those of us who live within its influence, consciously or unconsciously, will ever know.

headline: TimesCast | Italy's Deep Spending Cuts
text: As Italy's new government passes strict austerity cuts, holiday shoppers and merchants in Rome react.

headline: A Modern-Day Ark, With Children, Animals and Even Romance
text: Cameron Crowe may be the last of the Hollywood romantics. He’s best known for his stories about love and longing, for films that immortalize the moment when characters bare their hearts, as when John Cusack serenades a girl with a boom box in “Say Anything” and Renée Zellweger tells Tom Cruise he had her at hello in “Jerry Maguire.” These are images of such excruciating sincerity that they invite, almost demand cynicism. Yet it’s their openness that makes them work. And while his films depend on the familiar image of the couple in love, these are relationships that exist within a larger tribe, a band, a family and now, with “We Bought a Zoo,” a menagerie.

headline: She’s Gorgeous, but a Nasty Hostess
text: A ways into Johannes Wieland’s “new you,” the performer Eva Mohn turns to the audience and asks bitingly, “Are you all waiting for that dancing part?” Well, she says, “It’s not going to happen,” then adds, “Sorry.” In fact, there is dancing to come, some of it excellent, but the self-reflexive comment, the defensive and contemptuous lie, is more characteristic of this 2008 work, which made a repeat appearance at the Merce Cunningham Studio on Wednesday.

headline: At George Washington, a New Team Steps Into the Starting Blocks
text: George Washington High School in Manhattan has a long history as a track and field powerhouse, dating to the 1940s. But in the 1990s, amid budget cuts and declining interest, the team disbanded. Now, with support from the Armory Foundation, the team has been re-established, and students are once again on the run.

headline: Seasons Greetings
text: Brent Clark’s Photos of Christmas

headline: Tonight Is Tango Night
text: Marc Hussner and Kristina McFadden, dance instructors from Philadelphia, perform at tango night at the You Should Be Dancing studio in Manhattan.

headline: Giving Santa a Bad Name
text: WHAT could provoke a boy to cry hysterically and scream that he hates his parents? In one case, it was getting a Hello Kitty sweater for Christmas.

headline: Preserving Artifacts of Anti-Semitism
text: Anti-Semitic propaganda used to be mass-produced and available in the guise of home accessories. Manufacturers in Europe and the United States caricatured Jews as shabby, greedy and menacing, and put these depictions on cigar boxes, candlesticks, trays, tiles, walking sticks, puppets and board games.

headline: Better Heard Than Seen? A Cheeky Quiz Show Tests a Hotter Medium
text: The NPR program “Wait Wait ... Don’t Tell Me!” has always seemed like the news satire show that wished this were still 1952. It is content with a somewhat sleepy pace, and it delves no deeper than improvised quips can go.

headline: Artists Equipped With a Social Conscience
text: One of many artistic casualties of the McCarthy-era blacklists was the Photo League, a New York school and salon for amateur and professional photographers. Progressive in its politics and uncompromising in its aesthetics, the league was the place to be if you had a hand-held 35-millimeter camera and a left-leaning social conscience — and particularly if you believed, to borrow a bit of contemporary parlance, that photography was fine art for the 99 percent.

headline: To Share and to Sip
text: Some of my cousins and I, who have more disposable income, enjoy fine wines. I take a “treat” bottle to holiday meals and several nice budget bottles. This holiday, I brought a $200 bottle, which a wine-enthusiast cousin praised. My brother, who knows nothing of wine, proceeded to drink half of it and exclaim, “Tastes just like the $3 bottle to me.” Is there a polite way to ask nonoenophiles to drink the less expensive wine and let the wine lovers enjoy the special bottles?

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Thoughts on the I.P.O. Market and Steve Jobs on Gaming
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web.

headline: A Native Culture’s Reach, Both Visual and Emotional
text: “Kindred Spirits: Native American Influences on 20th Century Art” at the Peter Blum Gallery in SoHo closes out the New York gallery year with a great group show. This superb yet fraught exhibition creates a vortex of history, visual culture, language and ideas that is both heartbreaking and exhilarating. It seems almost impossible to straighten out, but that may be what makes it so valuable.

headline: Remembering Pina Bausch
text: Images from the life and career of the choreographer Pina Bausch.

headline: 3-D Tribute to Artistic Impulse
text: One of the interesting and unexpected film stories of 2011 is about 3-D, which simultaneously lost commercial potency and gained artistic credibility. Those who dismiss the format as the industrial gimmick (and excuse for price gouging) that it frequently is may need to reconsider now that a handful of certified auteurs have given it a try. Steven Spielberg and Martin Scorsese, grand old men of baby-boomer Hollywood, have made 3-D children’s tales (“The Adventures of Tintin” and “Hugo”), which is certainly noteworthy. More remarkable, perhaps even astonishing, is that Werner Herzog and Wim Wenders, stalwarts and survivors of the iconoclastic New German Cinema of the 1970s, have used 3-D in new documentaries.

headline: Getting Personal
text: A lovely, bust-length portrait painted by Francesco Francia in 1510 pictures a winsome, long-haired boy of 10 named Federigo Gonzaga. Dressed in a black gown over a white chemise and sporting a jauntily tilted cap and a bejeweled gold necklace, he holds the pommel of a sword and gazes dreamily off to his left. Under blue sky and fair-weather clouds, a pastoral sward extends behind him to a city in the far blue haze.

headline: Stage Shows With Back Stories
text: RARELY does a Broadway show become one of the biggest cultural news stories of the year. But “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark” had more offstage intrigue than any production in recent memory — as well as a record-setting budget of $75 million, six delays to its opening night and the gold-plated creative team of U2’s Bono and the Edge and the director Julie Taymor. So it’s no surprise that from beginning to end Spidey dominated the year in theater news. But his wasn’t the only story (just about a third of them, in this modest account):

headline: Marching to Their Own Drummers
text: ENCASED in pouches with a small speaker attached to the outside, iPhones dangled from belts and wrists. They emitted dings and chatters as some 60 people began strolling along the High Line on Wednesday night.

headline: Campaign Finance Law Survives Another Court Challenge
text: A New York City law that limits campaign contributions from individuals and entities that have business dealings with the city survived another legal challenge on Wednesday, when a federal appeals panel ruled that the law did not violate the free-speech and equal-protection provisions of the United States Constitution.

headline: How to Trim Spending on Medicare
text: To the Editor:

headline: New York, Home to the Arts
text: To the Editor:

headline: Seeking a Million Trees, With at Least That Many Stories
text: Outdoor performances can be the worst. For this one, a jackhammer almost drowned out Jerry Stiller’s opening lines:

headline: Electromagnetic Threat
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kids and Teachers, Online
text: To the Editor:

headline: In a Fractured Society, Ethnic War Kindles Both Hatred and Desire
text: “In the Land of Blood and Honey” tells the story of two acquaintances who become enemies, lovers and each other’s mirror during the Bosnian war. The movie opens in 1992 right before the fighting started and soon after Ajla (Zana Marjanovic), an artist and a Muslim, goes on a date with Danijel (Goran Kostic), a cop and a Bosnian Serb. Recently acquainted, the two meet up at a club, where they fall into each other’s arms, dance and flirt, nestled in an exuberant, raucous humanity, a communion that abruptly ends when a bomb detonates inside the club. The old world falls away and in its place there is dust, blood and Ajla and Danijel staggering toward their newly divided worlds.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Yes, Perry Has Lured Business to Texas. But How Many Jobs Created Is in Dispute.
text: As Gov. Rick Perry pushes his job creation initiatives on the presidential campaign trail, he often touts the Texas Enterprise Fund, an economic development program that the governor’s office says is bringing 59,000 jobs and $14.7 billion in capital investment to Texas.

headline: Swinging Parties
text: A look at Manhattan’s swing-dance demimonde.

headline: Send In the Food Trucks
text: AN urban farm off the East River. Artisanal food and crafts sold out of recycled shipping containers at the Dekalb Market. Smorgasburg and the Brooklyn Flea on the Williamsburg waterfront.

headline: The Renaissance Portrait
text: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: A Hero With a Snout and a Tender Heart
text: Set during the political volatility of between-the-wars Italy, Hayao Miyazaki’s animated 1992 adventure “Porco Rosso” introduces an unlikely hero: a portly, chauvinistic seaplane pilot with the head of a pig and the heart of Rhett Butler.

headline: Dispensing With the Penthouse
text: THE sluggish economy took its toll on Absolutely Wild Event Design, a party planning and flower business run by Peter Cunningham and Paolo Mizrahi. The two men, partners in business and in life, began to have second thoughts about their steep rent — $6,100 a month.

headline: Egyptian Military Adviser Calls Attack on Woman Justified
text: An adviser to Egypt’s military rulers said in a newspaper interview published on Thursday that a brutal attack on a female protester by Egyptian soldiers on Saturday was justified because the woman had insulted the army.

headline: When a Monster Plied the West Side
text: THOUSANDS of kids are going to find model train sets under the tree on Christmas morning — freight trains, circus trains, Wild West trains, military trains, express trains, commuter trains. ... But one train setup you won’t see is a replica of the street-level freight line that plied the West Side from 1846 to 1941. The line killed and mutilated hundreds of people, and its path well earned the name Death Avenue.

headline: Getting Back in the Black
text: THOUGH the threat of foreclosure has eased a little in the last 18 months, more than 2.6 million households are at least 60 days delinquent on their mortgage payments, according to Hope Now, a nonprofit coalition of lenders and agencies.

headline: Bollywood Baddie Is Ready to Take On Europe
text: If “Mission: Impossible” and “Ocean’s Eleven” had a bombastic, funny and slick cousin, it might be “Don 2.”

headline: Q & A
text: When the Trees Block the View

headline: A Cat Knows a Thing or Two About Scoops
text: It’s a Christmas present for cat lovers. “Miss Minoes,” the tweaked title of a 2001 Dutch film by Vincent Bal, is being given an American theatrical run (dubbed into English), and it’s a pleasantly quirky, family-friendly fable with lots of meowing.

headline: Offstage Improvements for Goodspeed
text: EAST HADDAM VILLAGE

headline: Philanthropy by the Rest of Us
text: Charlottesville, Va.

headline: Newt Gingrich, the Happy Warrior
text: Newt Gingrich, the Happy Warrior

headline: A Pair of Buds Both Eco- and Ear-Friendly
text: Thinksound’s ms01 headphones don’t make much of an impact – but that’s not necessarily a bad thing.

headline: Gay and Vilified in Uganda
text: Kampala, Uganda

headline: Monks of Burma
text: Portraits of Burmese Monk Life

headline: Sometimes Just a Salary Is Not Enough to Live On
text: Gov. Rick Perry has opened a whole new realm of campaign finance.

headline: 2011: A Year in Pictures
text: The Times has gathered what it believes are the best photos of the year.

headline: The Battle for Los Angeles Rejoined
text: LOS ANGELES — If the last shall be first and the first shall be last, that day seems to be coming for this city’s two N.B.A. teams. Of course, the passage is biblical where the time frame is eternal — which was how long it seemed it would take the lowly Clippers to match the Lakers, local lords of all they surveyed.

headline: After Charging 8, Army Is Scrutinized on Hazing
text: Under Army rules, a superior is allowed to subject a soldier to certain kinds of “corrective measures,” including “verbal reprimands and a reasonable number of repetitions of authorized physical exercises.”

headline: Electric Grid in Texas Faces Multiple Challenges
text: Will the lights stay on in 2012? Texas electricity experts cannot say for certain.

headline: Retailers Are Slashing Prices Ahead of Holiday
text: Half off at the entire store at Ann Taylor. Sixty percent at Gap. Forty percent off almost everything at Abercrombie & Fitch.

headline: The Post-Truth Campaign
text: Suppose that President Obama were to say the following: “Mitt Romney believes that corporations are people, and he believes that only corporations and the wealthy should have any rights. He wants to reduce middle-class Americans to serfs, forced to accept whatever wages corporations choose to pay, no matter how low.”

headline: Michigan City Turns Down Millions of Dollars, Saying Federal Money Is Not Free
text: Cats lie down with dogs.

headline: Social Fixer Makes Facebook More Fun and Functional
text: If you spend a lot of time on Facebook, you probably have a small list of petty gripes about the site’s user interface. Why does Facebook show me posts I’ve already read? Can I break up my giant News Feed into smaller sections? And please, please, can someone make that scrolling ticker in the upper right corner stop moving before it drives me insane?

headline: For Transgender Detainees, a Jail Policy Offers Some Security
text: For as long as she can remember, Maribel said, she has felt that she was different. She was born a boy in Mexico, and came to the United States at 16. Two years later, she started taking hormone pills and later underwent some operations to become physically the woman she always believed herself to be.

headline: Exxon Spars With Iraq Over Lack of Payment
text: The turmoil in Iraq after the United States troop withdrawal is extending to its vital petroleum industry.

headline: For Burress and Gilbride, Jets-Giants Is a Reunion
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — When Plaxico Burress left prison in June after serving 20 months on a gun charge, the Giants began an awkward courtship in an attempt to bring him back. Kevin Gilbride, the offensive coordinator, was one of Burress’s biggest supporters.

headline: The Sidney Awards, Part II
text: Book tours are lonely, yet after spending four months promoting his novel “Freedom,” Jonathan Franzen went to an island 500 miles off the coast of Chile to be alone. He got at least one thing out of it, a profound essay in The New Yorker called “Farther Away,” the winner of another of this year’s Sidney Awards.

headline: How to Control Libya Missiles? Buy Them Up
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The United States is discussing with the Libyan interim government the creation of a program to purchase shoulder-fired, heat-seeking missiles from militia members and others who gathered them up during the war, American government officials said.

headline: Colleges Fail to Complete Required Safety Plans
text: More than three years after the fatal shootings at Northern Illinois University prompted a state law requiring colleges and universities to put safety plans in effect, few of Cook County’s 63 higher-education institutions have filed them and many may not have made them public.

headline: Fighting to Hold On to a Gift From Santa
text: This story begins with a letter from a 13-year-old girl composed so long ago that its opening lines speak of a technology almost never heard of today.

headline: The House Backs Down
text: For a full year, House Republicans have replaced governing with confrontations that they allow to reach the brink of crisis, only then making extreme demands in exchange for a resolution. On Thursday, that strategy crumbled. Battered by public opinion and undermined by more reasonable Senate Republicans, the House’s leaders backed down and signed off on a deal to continue the payroll tax cut and unemployment insurance for two months.

headline: Rules Eased on Gun Sales to Noncitizens
text: WASHINGTON — The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives is relaxing restrictions on the sale of guns to noncitizens because Justice Department lawyers have concluded that the rules had no legal basis, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Do We Hate the Rich or Don’t We?
text: Here’s an example of how the results of polls taken at the same time can be given exactly opposite interpretations.

headline: Soldiers’ Choice
text: So this is Christmas, season of peace, time to reflect on the people coming home from a war that most Americans say was not worth it, and those still fighting in another war that raises new doubts by the day.

headline: Get Tougher on Assad
text: At the end of a tumultuous year in which strongmen across the Middle East were toppled, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria is still standing, still killing his people. And leaders in Russia, China and Arab states still haven’t done enough to pressure him to stop. The United Nations says more than 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have died in the brutal government crackdown in nine months of protests.

headline: A Soldier’s Death
text: Private Danny Chen was alone when he died. The Army says he shot himself in a guard tower in Kandahar Province, Afghanistan. But, in an extraordinary case alleging criminal culpability in a suicide, it has charged eight soldiers in connection with his death, saying they bullied Private Chen into killing himself. Seven enlisted men face counts that include involuntary manslaughter, negligent homicide and assault. One officer, a first lieutenant, is charged with dereliction of duty.

headline: Dismay, Then Disbelief at Arrest of N.F.L. Player
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Sam Hurd they thought they knew grew up here, in the shadow of the Alamodome. His family still lives in the house on Indiana Avenue, the one with chipped white paint, cracked windows upstairs and a speedboat marooned in the backyard.

headline: A Tip of the Hat to the Master Mapmakers, and They Kept It Legal
text: Black, white and Latino factions in the Chicago City Council are feuding over boundaries for a new ward map necessitated by population changes. It could force an expensive election referendum.

headline: Iraq Needs New Premier, Top Sunni Politician Says
text: WASHINGTON — As Iraqi and American officials struggled to contain the political crisis in Iraq, Iraq’s Sunni vice president said on Thursday that the prospects for creating a genuine power-sharing arrangement with Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki were so dim that Iraqi political factions should search for another Shiite politician to serve as prime minister.

headline: Black Women Enlisting at Higher Rates in U.S. Military
text: Black women are enlisting in the military at far higher rates than are white or Hispanic women, and they now represent nearly a third of all the women in the armed forces, a new study by the Pew Research Center has found.

headline: Timely Aid for Europe’s Banks
text: This week, the European Central Bank, under the energized leadership of Mario Draghi, took the desperately needed step of injecting hundreds of billions of euros into the Continent’s tottering banking system.

headline: Blindsided by Financial Crisis, and Trying to Rebuild
text: To Tahesha Calder, her bond with her young son was slipping away. It seemed as if whenever she had a chance to see him, he was asleep.

headline: F.C.C. Seeks to Ease Media Ownership Rule
text: The Federal Communications Commission is preparing to relax a longstanding rule that limits the ability of companies to own both a newspaper and a television or radio station in the same local market.

headline: Onward Christian Soldiers
text: Alongside the great armies mobilizing for war across the North in the fall of 1861, another organization, which would likewise have a great impact on the lives of American soldiers, got started in New York City. At a meeting of the city’s Y.M.C.A. chapter, 36 delegates passed a resolution establishing the United States Christian Commission.

headline: Haiti: President Retires Raunchy Singing Act
text: President Michel Martelly will not perform again as his alter ego, Sweet Micky, after all, an adviser said Thursday. Mr. Martelly, who before his election in April had a long career as a singer known for dressing in drag and disrobing on stage, had said in September he would retake the stage on Dec. 23 to raise $10 million for education. But an adviser said the concert had been postponed indefinitely “due to the holiday season and the complexity of organizing such an event.”

headline: Local College Hoops Fans Must Look Around
text: Journalistic objectivity is put to the test whenever Marquette University plays basketball. I went to school in that gritty, lively patch of Milwaukee just south of the late, great Avalanche Bar, and it was a life-altering experience.

headline: Communities in Two States Are Puzzled Over a Killing
text: His body was found on the edge of a 70-acre apple orchard, slowly burning amid the brush, twigs and trash just off the shoulder of a rural road in Pennsylvania.

headline: Facebook Gives Users a Primer on Ads
text: Millions of users who visited their Facebook pages on Wednesday may have noticed a light blue banner that read: “About Ads: Ever wonder how Facebook makes money? Get the Details.” Clicking on a link in the text took visitors to a page that explained why Facebook users see the ads they see.

headline: The Year in (New York) Pictures
text: Compelling photographs from New York and the region including Occupy Wall Street, the 10th Anniversary of September 11th terrorist attack, and Hurricane Irene.

headline: Preparations Different for a Home-and-Home Contest
text: Before every Giants and Jets home game, the visitors’ locker rooms at MetLife Stadium are prepped for that weekend’s influx of out-of-town behemoths. Plates of food are ordered. Laundry accommodations are made. A staff of attendants is dispatched to help deal with everything from corralling the endless wads of athletic tape to mopping up sweat stains.

headline: Using Google’s Data to Reach Consumers
text: THE viruses that Google researchers usually focus on are those that strike computers, but in recent years, they have studied those that infect people, too.

headline: New Law School Sues Bar Association
text: A law school in Tennessee that was denied accreditation by the American Bar Association sued the organization on Thursday, accusing it of antitrust violations and of depriving the school of due process.

headline: Comparing the Liu Inquiry to a Soldier’s Hazing
text: Chinese-American leaders came to the defense of the embattled city comptroller, John C. Liu, on Thursday, comparing the federal inquiry into his campaign fund-raising to what has been called a hazing campaign before the death of Pvt. Danny Chen.

headline: China: Confrontation Over Coal Plant Enters 3rd Day
text: Police officers and protesters concerned about environmental pollution from a planned coal-fired power plant confronted each other for a third day in Haimen, Guangdong Province. The protests began Tuesday when thousands of people blocked an expressway to demand the local government cancel plans to build the plant. The police fired tear gas to try to disperse the crowd, according to a local resident reached by telephone. Chinese news organizations reported that officials said they would suspend the project. But on Thursday, police officers armed with tear gas guns sealed off the highway as a group of protesters faced them. Some news agencies reported that there were some arrests. Haimen is 90 miles from Wukan, a fishing village that evicted Communist Party officials and the police over a land dispute. Leaders there announced Wednesday they were halting their protest.

headline: When Tears Flow in Court, It’s Pass a Tissue and Just Wait for the Agony to End
text: Courthouse regulars know the signs: the trembling fingers, the sniffle, the telltale blow of the nose.

headline: Many Ski Areas Lack an Essential Ingredient
text: WEST DOVER, Vt. — There were far too many skis on hand this week at High Altitude, a rental shop on the road to Mount Snow here, and Andrew Glover, the manager, was far too lonely.

headline: Nationals Get Starter; Cardinals Land Beltran
text: Two significant moves reignited baseball’s hot stove after it had seemingly cooled in advance of the holiday weekend.

headline: Stores Remove Formula After Boy Dies
text: Two major retail chains, including Walmart, have removed certain packages of Enfamil, a popular brand of infant formula, from thousands of stores after a Missouri infant who consumed the product died from a rare bacterial infection.

headline: Friday: Man of Steel
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Interesting looking grid, yes? We’ve seen similar ones before; in fact, it reminds me somewhat of this Frank Longo puzzle from 2004 (Across Lite, Solution). That’s O.K. There are only so many permutations of design possible in a 15×15 grid, after all, and it’s what’s on the inside that counts, right?

headline: Nurses Plan Walkout at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt
text: Nurses at St. Luke’s-Roosevelt Hospital will go on strike on Jan. 3 unless last-ditch negotiations succeed in bridging a divide over wages, according to leaders in the New York State Nurses Association, which issued a 10-day strike warning early Thursday on behalf of 1,300 registered nurses at the hospital.

headline: Shopping for Presents While Most Are Asleep
text: The tourists had long vacated Times Square, leaving the streets there and to the south nearly empty; even the halal food vendors on 34th Street had packed up their kebabs for the night. Yet there it was: The sound of Christmas carols emanating from outdoor speakers at Herald Square, an aural enticement for the faithful to come to shop, regardless of the hour.

headline: Lottery Numbers
For $101,000, the 12 Days of Christmas Are Covered
text: Giving the holiday presents of a French hen, a milking maid, a leaping lord or even a partridge in a pear tree is rather unlikely in this day and age. But the gifts from the favorite holiday carol “The 12 Days of Christmas” are lighthearted clues to how the economy is faring.

headline: The Lure of the Hedge Fund, Despite Poor Performance
A Victory Considerably Aided by the Other Side
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama did not win much substantively with his victory Thursday over House Republicans in their showdown over extending payroll tax cuts and unemployment aid for two months. But he got a lot politically: a big start toward retiring the perception — fair or not, and even among Democrats — that in a pinch with the other party he will inevitably surrender.

headline: Wukan Journal
text: After a land-dispute protest which attracted media from around the world, life in Wukan, China, seems to have returned to normal for now.

headline: Oil Spill Moves Toward Nigerian Coast
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — An oil slick roughly 350 square miles in size from a Royal Dutch Shell platform is slowly making its way toward the southern Nigerian coast, threatening wildlife and widespread shore pollution, Nigerian officials said Thursday.

headline: Financial Aid Changes Game as Ivy Sports Teams Flourish
text: The eight Ivy League colleges, renowned for their academics, were also once among the country’s highest-achieving athletic institutions, with national champions and multiple prominent and ranked sports teams.

headline: New Models of Implants Not Better, Study Finds
text: A new study suggests that the recent technology for artificial hips and knees did not perform any better than older, less expensive designs.

headline: Canny Villagers Grasp Keys to Loosen China’s Muzzle
text: WUKAN, China — As journalists and bloggers began trickling into Wukan last week, residents decided to put to use a two-story house, once the home of a family that left for Hong Kong some time ago. They turned it into the de facto press center of this fishing village of 13,000.

headline: Silent Night (or Two) for Attack Ads
text: WASHINGTON — Santa Claus is bringing a very special present for Newt Gingrich this weekend: a bit of relief.

headline: Rangers Capitalize on Islanders’ Mistakes

headline: Thousands of Dollars of Work Offers Shaky Assurance
text: Craig Irving just bought a 1920s bungalow in the Rockridge neighborhood of Oakland last October “and the house starts to move,” he said. The fact that his new house had been seismically retrofitted — a common procedure to reinforce older buildings in the Bay Area against possible earthquake damage — had been a selling point, he said, but even so his first thought was, “Please don’t let this be the big one.”

His accusations threw a spotlight on swirling rumors that the military might have plotted a coup after being humiliated by the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

headline: Fire at Home in Texas Ends Former Iraq Commander’s Run for the Senate

It was a prayer book one of his children had given his wife. He found what appeared to be a blackened, soggy rag. Unfolding it, he realized he was holding his daughter’s baptismal dress.

headline: After Missing Out Last Year, 7 States to Share Almost $200 Million in Education Grants
text: Seven states that narrowly lost out in last year’s Race to the Top school improvement competition will share nearly $200 million in the latest round of winners announced Thursday by federal education officials.

headline: Year in New York Pictures
text: NEW YORK has always been too big an idea to be rendered successfully in a single image: simultaneously cruel and generous, dazzling and demeaning, unbearably vibrant and — as it waits to see what path a tropical storm will take — suspensefully calm. But one thing that almost every New York moment has in common is a surprise of some sort. Some surprises are dreadful. An 8-year-old boy named Leiby Kletzky was supposed to walk the seven blocks back to his home in Borough Park one day in July, but he never made it. Other surprises were joyful. Same-sex couples did not go into the year thinking they would have the right to marry before the summer was out. Felix Ramirez and Peter Vargas of the Bronx had already been together 24 years by the time they were wed at City Hall. (Or at least near it.)

text: unfettered •\ən-ˈfe-tərd\• adjective

headline: Don Sharp Dies at 89; Director Who Revived Hammer Horror Film Company
text: Don Sharp, a veteran film director who had never watched a horror movie until Hammer Films — the English studio described, usually admiringly, as dripping cinematic blood — enlisted him in the mid-1960s to help revivify its presentation of Gothic terror, died on Sunday. He was 89.

headline: Doe Avedon, Fashion Model and Actress, Dies at 86
text: Doe Avedon, a bookish beauty reluctantly transformed into a high-fashion model at the hands of a visionary photographer, Richard Avedon — a story that inspired the 1957 musical “Funny Face,” about a bookish beauty (Audrey Hepburn) reluctantly transformed into a high-fashion model at the hands of a visionary photographer (Fred Astaire) — died on Sunday in Los Angeles. She was 86.

headline: North Korea Warns South to Show ‘Respect’ for Kim Jong-il
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea urged South Korea on Friday to “show proper respect” over the death of its leader, Kim Jong-il, calling the South’s decision to express sympathy for the North Korean people but not to send a government delegation to Mr. Kim’s funeral next week “an unbearable insult and mockery of our dignity.”

headline: Arab Spring
text: THE BREATH AND HUM of democracy seemed almost a libidinous thing in parts of the Middle East, but, in truth, the body heat had been simmering for years. The protests took hold in Tunisia in late 2010 after the street vendor Mohamed Bouazizi set himself on fire. The kindle caught and the spirit of his self-immolation lit a fuse across the region. A wave of protests struck Algeria, Egypt, Yemen, Jordan. Almost as soon as protesters in Cairo were being herded away from Tahrir Square, they were dancing at the news of Mubarak’s resignation. Ruling families began to fall. Power-transfer treaties were brokered. Parliaments were dissolved. Monarchs locked their gates and boarded their windows. In Libya, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi was ousted and killed. NATO planes streaked a sky so blue it seemed it to speak of other Septembers. Faces, too, were lit by a new blue light. It was the era of the revolution down through the wires: time was collapsed and geography shrunk by the use of social networking. The whole world was indeed watching, listening, e-mailing. Some in the media lost their lives for the art of the images that emerged — the photographs didn’t just capture singular moments, but they looked backward and forward at the same time, at what has happened, and what is yet to come. The light from the Arab Spring rose from the ground up; the hope is now that the darkness doesn’t fall.

headline: Occupy Wall Street
text: “WE ARE THE 99 PERCENT.” It was so much beyond a local slogan: the louder it was spoken, the more it began to say. My job, my streets, my economy, my riot, my skin. Cities shook their souls out. The yearning went global. Some protesters poured gasoline into bottles and lighted the sky with fire. Others unfurled hammocks under light poles. The idea was to be seen, to be heard, to be tweeted. The year 2011 was an evanescent spectacle of anger. Every corner was a world, and every world had its corners. The bankers stood back, the corporations hushed a moment, the politicians held their breath, and the cops took out their pepper spray. It might have begun in Wisconsin, had its adolescence in Greece, and shattered the night in London, but it lost and won its innocence in Zuccotti Park. Suddenly, a tent had as much meaning as a tower. Kids from all over the country boiled collard greens in the courtyard of commerce. The city’s bureaucrats tried frantically to barricade them in, or out — nobody seemed sure which. The anger rolled all the way down to Wall Street and the markets shivered a moment. When cold weather kicked in, the tents began to disappear and the anger diffused, but the images remained, another sort of fire in flight.

headline: The Nation
text: SOMETIMES there is a necessity for anniversaries, even for things that cannot be forgotten. The memorial services for 9/11 were remarkable for their grace and dignity. The falling water, beside the reflecting pools, spoke volumes. While the Republicans fumbled for their own sort of memory — trying somehow to bring back the apparent ease of the Reagan years — the rest of the country drove down a street of foreclosed homes. We were all, in some way, looking for a brand-new roof.

headline: The World
text: THOSE WEREN’T JUST tank lights leaving the desert behind. That was the darkness of a nearly nine-year war made visible. The soldiers moved through the sandstorms, and landed back home in the United States to deal with the continuing legacy of American foreign policies. In 2011, Barack Obama’s promises were finally beginning to find their way onto the front pages. A spectacular nighttime raid found Osama bin Laden in Abbottabad, Pakistan. The helicopters landed. The weight of the past was kicked up in the dust. Author of a decade of killing, Bin Laden had endpages that were quick and sharp. He was shot dead, buried at sea, and the White House held its breath: it sounded so much like a sigh of joy, exhausted and necessary. The soldiers continued their journeys: it was a big world they were returning to. The seven billionth baby was born, starting global discussions on issues of environment, health and technology. Europe teetered on the edge of ruin, stunned by even more economic philandering. In the fall, lights were lit for Kim Il-sung and a regime that has hidden its face. In Norway the island of Utoya heard gunshots among the trees. Parts of Africa were dealing, yet again, with an almost impossible hunger and thirst. But stories and images are always new, no matter how old the theme. The surprise of the world is that it can still surprise us.

headline: Nature
text: THE WATER ROSE. And rose. Soon there were traffic lights flipping, doors tumbling, tatami mats spinning in the current. Cars began to float alongside washing machines, computers, people. The incredible could occur. And then the tsunami seemed to wash away the last vain dream of the 20th century: the nuclear answer. The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant went into meltdown and watched its poisons filter out to sea, and what remained is what we all must live with: the democratic rage of nature. No matter what we do, we cannot regulate how we are shaped by weather. We look for calm, but there is always an inevitability of storm. The images from Joplin, Mo., were pure with grief. A snowstorm paralyzed Tulsa, Okla. The Souris River shed more than a tear. The streets of Bangkok were almost apocalyptic during floods. There were droughts, earthquakes, wildfires scattering animals like dice. So, the question, then, is ancient: How with such rage shall beauty hold a plea? Rescuers in Turkey put their fingers on part of the pulse when they managed to pull 2-week-old Azra Karaduman from the rubble. Her mother and grandmother also emerged safely. She was tiny and voiceless, yet she said so much.

headline: Milestones
text: A PHOTOGRAPH is sometimes a perfect testament to the notion that we can’t afford to lose our delight. While the news, and its makers, might dwell on what we’ve lost, we occasionally still witness the most remarkable music: marriages, journeys, longings, births and returns. Every now and then, the ground just won’t show its shadows.

headline: In Russia, the Bhagavad Gita Has a Date in Court
text: A Siberian court is scheduled to hear arguments for and against banning the Bhagavad Gita at the end of the month.

headline: The Arab Spring, Seen From Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Last week, a photograph of Dilma Rousseff’s terrorism trial in 1970 circulated on the Internet, sending shockwaves across Brazil. She was 22 and an active member of a guerrilla cell fighting the dictatorial regime of the day. In the shot, young Dilma looks pretty and clean-faced, like a freedom-fighter girl taking on a gerontocracy of mighty generals.

text: On Dec. 23, 1986, the experimental airplane Voyager, piloted by Dick Rutan and Jeana Yeager, completed the first nonstop, around-the-world flight without refueling. It landed safely at Edwards Air Force Base in California.

Following are three coffee entrepreneurs who give the traditional afternoon kaffee and kuchen new verve.

headline: Indian Flavors: Daniel Boulud’s Quail with Garam Masala
text: Daniel Boulud might be famous for his French cooking, but he seems equally taken by Indian flavors. The chef and owner of 13 restaurants including Daniel, his eponymous Michelin three-starred eatery, spent several hours before a recent interview with India Ink creating a green curry using the distinctly Indian black salt and pomegranate powder. His plan is to use the saucy base to enliven rabbit, which is a staple in his native France and can be bland on its own, he said. “I am a huge fan of Indian food and incorporate spices from India into my cooking whenever I can,” he said.

headline: Mourners in Prague Honor Havel

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 23
text: News Corporation is in talks to hire a Washington lawyer, Gerson Zweifach, to be its next general counsel, as the company handles the legal fallout from the phone-hacking scandal in Britain, Bloomberg News reported Thursday night. He would replace Lawrence Jacobs, who resigned in June to pursue other opportunities.

headline: Streep Dons Thatcher’s Armor
text: WHAT do you do after turning yourself into Julia Child, a bold, occasionally bossy woman who changed the way people think about food? You turn yourself into Margaret Thatcher, of course, an even bolder and bossier one, who changed the way people think about Britain. This is what Meryl Streep does in “The Iron Lady,” which opens Friday in New York. In yet another of her miraculous impersonations, which has already been nominated for a Golden Globe award, she seems even more Thatcher-like than Mrs. Thatcher, so that after the movie if you go back and look at photographs of Mrs. Thatcher in her prime, you can’t help feeling that they’re a little off. She no longer looks like herself.

headline: Daily Report: The Boycott Against SOPA Supporters
text: The biggest news Friday is the battle in the tech world  between those who are proposing a boycott of everyone who supports the Stop Online Piracy Act and those who think that tactic is an affront to free speech. Congress would give companies some teeth to fight Web sites that publish pirated songs and movies. Opponents of the bill decry it as censorship. Edward Wyatt wrote about the bill in The New York Times several days ago.

headline: Challenging Hip-Hop’s Masculine Ideal
text: HIP-HOP is primarily a celebration of black masculinity. Sure, there have long been significant black female and white male figures, but the majority of the conversation in hip-hop is and has always been about the actions, thoughts, feelings and ethos of black men. But this hegemony cannot last forever. Eventually the throne will have to be shared. The world of hip-hop has some diversity: Eminem, Mac Miller and Nicki Minaj now; the Beastie Boys, Lauryn Hill and Missy Elliott in the past. We have respected rappers of South Asian descent: M.I.A. and Heems from Das Racist. But what about the American white woman? Could she ever rock the mic for real?

headline: Back When Mother, Too, Knew Best
text: TO baby boomers of a certain age Donna Reed was a sunny-bright television fixture for eight seasons, the perfect mom — at least according to the prevailing values of the day — radiantly gliding down the staircase every week to answer the beckoning phone, its ringing augmented by an impossibly perky musical theme fittingly titled “Happy Days.”
