headline: Friday Reading: Students Say No to Healthier School Fare
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Their Noonday Demons, and Ours
text: By some miracle, you set aside a day to tackle that project you can’t seem to finish in the office. You close the door, boot up your laptop, open the right file and . . . five minutes later catch yourself thinking about dinner. By 10 a.m., you’re staring at the wall, even squinting at it between your fingertips. Is this day 50 hours long? Soon, you fall into a light, unsatisfying sleep and awake dizzy or with a pounding headache; all your limbs feel weighed down. At which point, most likely around noon, you commit a fatal error: leaving the room. I’ll just garden for a bit, you tell yourself, or do a little charity work. Hmmm, I wonder if my friend Gregory is around?

headline: Roberto Bolaño Plays With History
text: Roberto Bolaño is one of the most prolific of dead writers: some half a dozen books in Spanish and at least twice that in English since his death (at the age of 50) in 2003. Of course he didn’t write these works in the afterlife, even if such a feat is no doubt every author’s fantasy; the bulk of the posthumous material is drawn from the beginning and middle of his career, before the Spanish publication of “The Savage Detectives” in 1998 turned him into an international phenomenon. The amount of unpublished work tells a story. We read these previously missing early texts differently because we have the later ones. It is also possible that the early work will help us with the later work. (This is likely to be true of the still untranslated “Sinsabores del Verdadero Policía,” published in Spanish this year, which Bolaño was working on from the 1980s to his death. Literally, a sinsabor is something that lacks savor, but idiomatically the word means a minor unpleasantness — a fluent literary version of the title might be “The Troubles of the True Policeman.”)

headline: Finding My Religion
text: Books about God tend to fall into two categories: objective inquiries into the nature of belief and personal tales of spiritual awakening. One type explores history, creation myths and religious ritual. In the other, the author typically undergoes a crisis — a terminal illness, the death of a loved one, an onset of existential dread — that causes him to confront his life’s emptiness, coming to realize that there is something out there greater than himself.

headline: Why We Lie
text: In 1995 I traveled to the University of California, Santa Barbara, for the annual meeting of the Human Behavior and Evolution Society, which turned out to be a pep rally for psychologists, anthropologists and others who view humanity through the lens of evolutionary theory. Attendees heard Darwinian takes on lust, love, infidelity, status-seeking, mental illness, violence, patriotism, politics, economics and religion, as well as keynote addresses from such luminaries as Richard Dawkins and Steven Pinker.

headline: How Insomnia Feels
text: It’s hard to ignore the force of the sentences in Blake Butler’s new book, “Nothing: a Portrait of Insomnia.” Best known for his fiction, Butler is obsessed with the possibilities of syntax, and the most obvious feature of “Nothing” is a lyric and intellectual buffer overflow that results in long, often interestingly ungrammatical sentences, sometimes stretching over six pages. The most ornate of these is adorned with footnotes, a nod to David Foster Wallace, to whose memory the book is dedicated. As such the book draws attention to its own linguistic surfaces in ways that most memoirs never attempt.

headline: The Caucus | Romney Campaign Ramps Up
text: Ashley Parker reports from New Hampshire on the week with Mitt Romney as the campaign shows its organizational might.

headline: The Enlightenment’s True Radicals
text: In recent decades, Jonathan I. Israel writes, the Enlightenment has emerged as “the single most important topic, internationally, in modern historical studies, and one of crucial significance also in our politics, cultural studies and philosophy.” That is a large claim for a movement of 18th-century thought, and many will find it exaggerated, if not self-serving, seeing that its author, a professor of history at the Institute for Advanced Study in Prince­ton, N.J., has devoted the last decade of his life to exploring that very subject.

headline: Paul Nelson: Bad Boy Rock Critic
text: Paul Nelson, a propagandist committed to some dubious values, had a gift for imbuing disreputable, even dangerous ideas with discomforting grace. You might almost say he was the Leni Riefenstahl of rock criticism. One of the first writers of the post-Elvis era to take the popular music of his time seriously, he never liked black music and thought the blues were overrated, negligible in comparison with the work of overtly cerebral and conspicuously poetic artists of the ’60s and early ’70s like Bob Dylan and Jackson Browne. Nelson revered Browne. He subscribed, both in his writing and in his life, to the macho outcast myths of noir movies and pulp fiction, and he seemed blind to the importance of the great female artists nearly absent in his writing, like Joni Mitchell and Aretha Franklin. Nelson loathed the music of Patti Smith.

headline: Five Seasons and a Movie: Fans Raise Money for German ‘Office’ Film
text: While devotees of the struggling sitcom “Community” gather in Rockefeller Center and don fake beards in hopes of convincing NBC to keep that show on the air, fans of Germany’s equivalent of “The Office” are actually reaching into their pockets to see the series continue: They have raised about $1.3 million in an online campaign to produce a movie based on the German show, which is currently in its fifth and final season, The Hollywood Reporter said.

headline: Caucus Video: The Romney Campaign Ramps Up
text: Ashley Parker reports from Mitt Romney’s New Hampshire bus tour about the campaign showing its organizational might.

headline: Harry Kessler’s Fin de Siècle Diaries
text: Count Harry Kessler (1868-1937), whose diaries provide an unusual guided tour of belle époque and early-20th-century artistic and high life in Berlin, Paris and London, was born in Paris to great wealth. A lifetime of extravagant spending and the Depression took their toll. After a long and painful disease, he died impoverished and solitary in Pontanevaux, a village in the Beaujolais region of France.

headline: Hard Rock in Las Vegas Plans a Three-Day New Year’s Celebration
text: Celebrating New Year’s Eve in Las Vegas isn’t a novel concept, but the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Las Vegas is offering a fresh way to ring in 2012. The hotel has scheduled three days of events, beginning on Dec. 30, that emphasize its musical roots. The hip-hop star Drake, the alternative singer Corey Taylor, the heavy metal band Guns N’ Roses and a popular local band, Sin City Sinners, are all scheduled to perform.

headline: The Most Dangerous Girl in Mexico Goes to America
text: Luis Alberto Urrea spent nearly 20 years researching his family history for his enchanting 2005 novel “The Hummingbird’s Daughter.” Out of old letters, historical documents and oral histories emerged the fantastical story of the author’s great-aunt Teresa, a Mexican saint and revolutionary who was the illegitimate daughter of Tomás Urrea, a wealthy landowner, and a Yaqui Indian woman known simply as Cayetana, or the Hummingbird. By the final wrenching pages of that novel, Teresita, as she’s called, has by presidential decree been declared the Most Dangerous Girl in Mexico. Banished from the country, she and her father are put on a train headed north to the United States.

headline: Paying for the Payroll Tax Cut
text: So House Republicans have decided to go along with a two-month extension of the payroll tax cut.

headline: Last Exits in Brooklyn
text: Nobody knows a man better than his ex-wife. So Moe Prager’s ex-wife, Carmella, is wise to this veteran private eye, accepting the fact that no matter how many times he marries, his first love will always be Brooklyn. “When you die, they should just bury you right here, under the boardwalk,” she tells him in HURT MACHINE (Tyrus, $24.95; paper, $15.95), Reed Farrel Coleman’s latest book in a series heavily saturated with local color. Since Prager has recently been told he has stomach cancer, that day may come sooner than Carmella thinks. But this stubborn old shamus is determined to do two things before his ashes are consigned to the sands of Coney Island: Attend his daughter’s wedding, and find the person who murdered Carmella’s older sister, Alta.

headline: Editors’ Choice

headline: Inside the List
text: THE USUAL SUSPECTS: Tom Clancy’s fans like to describe his macho geek-boy thrillers as prescient, citing among other things his 1994 novel “Debt of Honor,” in which a deranged pilot crashes a 747 into the Capitol. On Sept. 11, 2001, Clancy himself played up the overlap on CNN, without mentioning that the book is a ludicrous alarmist fantasy about a corporate-controlled Japan making war on America. In other words, it was less prescient than derivative: “Rising Sun,” Michael Crichton’s version of “The Japanese are coming!” had been a best seller two years before. In a telephone interview on “Charlie Rose” later on 9/11, Clancy again seemed out of the loop. As Rose’s panelists talked about Osama bin Laden and the possibility of military retaliation, Clancy jumped in petulantly. “Saying ‘Osama bin Laden,’ ” he insisted, “is like Claude Rains in ‘Casablanca’ saying, ‘Round up the usual suspects.’ He’s simply the usual suspect. But there has been no definitive information linking him to this event. Until there is, talking about him is just a waste of air.” Later on the program, as the former National Security Adviser Samuel Berger tried to answer a question, Clancy’s disembodied voice floated over the set. “Why is there a car in our driveway?” he asked, apparently forgetting he was wired for sound.

headline: Up Front
text: Michael Wood’s first three books about literature concerned a Frenchman (Stendhal), a Latin American (García Márquez) and a Russian emigrant to America (Nabokov). If this sounds like the start of a bar joke, it also confirms Wood’s commitment to cultural diversity — as does the fact that between Stendhal and García Márquez, he also found time for a book about film, “America in the Movies.” In a recent e-mail, Wood recalled that when Wilfrid Sheed reviewed that book in 1976, he “said I had a grasshopper mind. It wasn’t a compliment but it’s not untrue, and one can make some sort of virtue even out of bad habits.”

headline: MF Global Trustee Seeks Money From British Arm
text: The trustee liquidating MF Global’s trading operations said on Friday that his office was seeking the return of more than $600 million from the failed firm’s British arm, potentially setting up a cross-border fight over customer money.

headline: Paperback Row
text: GATHERING EVIDENCE: A Memoir, by Thomas Bernhard. Translated by David McLintock (Vintage International, $16.95.) Bernhard, the Austrian playwright and novelist who died in 1989, describes his harrowing childhood in Nazi-dominated schools and the bouts of pneumonia and tuberculosis that shaped his lifelong obsession with death. This volume includes “My Prizes,” translated by Carol Brown Janeway, a series of acerbic essays that recall Bernhard’s literary awards and muster moral outrage against the idea of state-sanctioned art.

headline: A Recap From the Third (and Final) Night of the Choice Blog’s Live Chat on Facebook
text: On Thursday night, Jennifer Wong Christensen, the co-director of college counseling at Marin Academy in San Rafael, Calif., and the former director of admission at Claremont McKenna College, concluded the third installment in The Choice blog’s series of live chats on our Facebook page.

headline: John Horgan on Robert Trivers’s “The Folly of Fools” and best-seller news.
text: This week, a conversation with John Horgan about “The Folly of Fools” by Robert Trivers; Christopher Beha on a number of new books about our relationship to animals; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

headline: Farewell, Pumpkins of Kane Street? They Did Not.
text: We bid adieu to the pumpkins of Kane Street, an array of  100 carved by Jane Greengold of Cobble Hill, Brooklyn that have become a local Halloween tradition. The horrific decay of the pumpkins has reached a tipping point on the scales of good taste so rigorously upheld by City Room. This will be our final installment of the series.

As he told investors in 2008, “We feel very fortunate to have dodged a significant number of bullets, landmines and other incendiary devices during this dramatic year.”

headline: For the Colts (and Maybe Andrew Luck), a Rewrite
text: Just when you thought you had the script for this N.F.L. season all figured out, things started going awry. The first taste of this was when the Packers, on a mesmerizing march to a perfect season, tripped over the dreadful Chiefs. And now, at the bottom of the standings, the actors are no longer dutifully playing their parts. Somewhere late in the fourth quarter of Thursday night’s game against the Texans, the Colts went full ad-lib on us with a game-winning touchdown drive in the final minute, led by quarterback Dan Orlovsky, who almost no one realized was even a member of the Colts’ cast.

headline: Two Gifts
text: Gift-giving can be tricky for older people and their caregivers. The seniors often don’t need more Stuff — they have enough pajamas, dusting powder and flannel shirts to last a literal lifetime. When my dad left his apartment to move to an independent living facility near my sister and me, we found shirts and sweaters we’d given him for birthdays and Hanukkah years before, still in gift boxes. Oh well.

text: Of all the sticky quandaries in the parenting world, divorce, especially when it comes with questions of custody, must be the stickiest, and it only gets stickier when a new spouse enters the picture. This week’s quandary comes from one such “new spouse” and stepparent. Four years (and two children) after her marriage, she’s not sure if she and her husband have done the right thing by letting her stepchildren spend every holiday with their mother.

headline: Coverjunkie Gets a One-Time-Only Magazine

And now he has produced a one-time magazine of the same name. It’s packed with more than 200 magazine covers (including some of ours) and commentary from some of the world’s leading art directors and designers. It’s a great tool for magazine junkies, students and readers alike. You can order it here.

headline: New Directors Flesh Out Black America, All of It
text: EARLY in Dee Rees’s film “Pariah” it journeys into a Brooklyn strip club where scantily clad young black women gyrate to a sexy, foul-mouthed rap song. Lascivious customers leer, toss money and revel in their own unbridled lust. It is a scene that could have been in any of “the hood movies” that once proliferated or even a Tyler Perry melodrama in which Christian values would be affirmed after this bit of titillation.

headline: Business Is in the Bag
text: Carolina Herrera Baez, not to be confused with her mother, the designer Carolina Herrera, has been a quiet influence in her family’s atelier for most of her life. But it isn’t until now that she could call herself a designer. Two years into her post as a consultant for her mother’s CH Carolina Herrera collection, Herrera Baez is introducing her own accessory: the Mini Matryoshka bag — a bucket tote made of Goya leather that comes in seven different Bauhaus-inspired colorblocks, like canary yellow and grass green, or Piet Mondrian-esque red and black. Though there’s much in the capsule that can be credited to her mother — “She has a small purse philosophy,” says Herrera Baez by way of explaining why, for example, the bag is the compact size that it is. “You carry only what is essential” — the bag’s graphic look and feel are entirely original. “Sometimes, great ideas on paper are just that,” says Herrera Baez. “The ability to fine tune an aesthetic in tandem with intuition is a good trait for any designer to have.” Tuck that one in your tote.

headline: Crossing the Delaware, More Accurately

Mr. Weber has a passion for the kinds of stories that often don’t appear in the mainstream media, and he tells them in full. You can find his books at bruceweber.com.

text: The recession had an uneven effect on different parts of the United States, and the recovery has also varied sharply. The best performing states tend to have oil production, which has benefited from high oil prices, while the worst have included areas where mortgage lending was particularly excessive before the credit crisis began.

headline: For Mullin Museum’s French Masterpieces, a Bespoke Homecoming at Rétromobile

headline: Best Apps for Children – End of Year Edition
text: Giving your child an iPad or iPod Touch as a gift this year? Preload it with some quality apps before you wrap it. That way you’ll increase your chances for a positive first impression. Here’s a fresh batch of suggestions, arranged from young to old.

headline: In a Hymn, Words of Courage That Ring True Long After a Soldier Son Returns
text: The Christmas cards I’m sending this year feature a photograph of two Border collies and several ducks in a snowbank. The dogs and the ducks appear perfectly at ease and content in each others’ company, and a caption above the picture reads, “And on Earth, Peace.” I love the picture and the reference to Luke 2:14. But, it has occurred to me that the picture might not actually be compatible with its quoted Scripture. Border collies are not, after all, lions who lie down with lambs. Rather, Border collies are defenders of lambs against lions.

headline: Eligible for Best Score, Names From Hollywood and Malayalam

headline: Your Best Meal of 2011
text: As we put together our lists of our favorite restaurants of 2011, we’re curious about the best meal you had this year. Tweet us at @nytimesdining using the hashtag #bestmeal2011. We’ll cull some of the highlights and feature them here next week.

headline: Lessons Learned in Congress, or a Sign of Things to Come?

headline: Another Collapse at Pompeii Renews Fears About Its Fate
text: Mount Vesuvius preserved the city of Pompeii in ash nearly 2,000 years ago, but current neglect of this Unesco World Heritage site in southern Italy is taking its toll. A courtyard column of a Roman house collapsed on Thursday, the latest in a series of crumbling artifacts at the site, Reuters reported. Last year there were other collapses, including part of what is known as the House of Gladiators. The damage played a role in a no-confidence vote against Culture Minister Sandro Bondi earlier this year. Although Mr. Bondi survived the vote, he ended up resigning in March.

headline: A Short Winter Break on The Choice
text: Like many of you, The Choice blog is going to take a few days off to spend time with family during the holidays. We’ll still publish any big admissions news should it break — and we’ll keep updating our early-admission acceptances chart, in the event any more data flows in. We’ve also got at least one essay scheduled for the week after Christmas, intended to provide some holiday food-for-thought for seniors who might be contemplating a gap year.

headline: Opera Boston to Shut Down
text: Opera Boston, a small company known for innovative works, is shutting down because of financial problems, the board said in a statement on Friday, according to news media in Boston. The company this season had scheduled three productions, Berlioz’s “Be’atrice and Be’ne’dict” in October and Tippett’s “The Midsummer Marriage” and Bellini’s “I Capuleti e I Montecchi” in the winter and spring. The company commissioned the opera “Madame White Snake” from the composer Zhou Long, who was given the 2011 Pulitzer Prize in music for the work. The company faced an “insurmountable budget deficit,” the board said. “We find ourselves in a financially untenable situation, and the responsible thing is to work with our creditors and cease operations.” The company will close Jan. 1.

headline: ‘X Factor’ Leads to $42 Million Payday for Simon Cowell
text: For one of the most hyped television shows of the year, “The X Factor” may have had disappointing ratings, but the show still turned out to be a big payday for Simon Cowell, its creator.

headline: New Frontiers in Economic Barbarism
text: I’ve written quite a lot about the way much of the macroeconomics community has descended into a Dark Age, forgetting the things they used to know. I was originally set off by the way some economists were propounding Say’s Law — the idea, refuted 75 years ago, that all income must be spent and hence that supply creates its own demand — as a profound insight, somehow missed by three generations of economists.

headline: Hostesses Slip Into Something a Little Practical
text: WHITHER the hostess gown? Archaeological study of this now-defunct garment, popular from the 1930s to the 1970s (according to the Vintage Fashion Guild), reveals that the American lady of the house used to greet her dinner guests not in Lululemon yoga pants and a clammy tank top, but a billowing, brightly colored maxi-dress, often with a forgiving waistline, or no waistline — sort of a cross between an evening formal and a bathrobe.

headline: A Very Merry Un-Christmas to You

headline: After Skirting the Sun, Comet Lovejoy Provides a Cosmic Show
text: Several days after newly discovered Comet Lovejoy streaked through the Sun’s atmosphere (see video above), it provided a glorious pre-holiday display for astronauts aboard the International Space Station. NASA has posted an informative description of the comet’s journey and its discovery earlier this month by Tom Lovejoy, an amateur astronomer in Australia.

headline: One More Life We Loved

Or he will become the sole major Republican candidate to never have been among the Iowa front-runners this year (outside of Jon M. Huntsman Jr., who did not really try).

headline: Broadway Hits Gold in Buffalo
text: BUFFALO — “The Addams Family” musical will close on Broadway next Saturday without earning back its $16.5 million capitalization during its 22-month run, a disappointment to the producers. Yet the national tour production of “The Addams Family” was a hit this month at Shea’s Performing Arts Center in Buffalo, grossing $995,000 in a week, more than most shows pull in on Broadway — including “The Addams Family,” which hasn’t earned that much money in a week since April.

It was a festive yet slightly chaotic atmosphere in a typically serene region of natural wonder.

headline: Italian Cuisine, Guided by a Native
text: IT sounded so intriguing. Margherita Aloi, the daughter of a winemaker and farmer from a small town in the Piedmont region of Italy, who attended the Culinary Institute of Barolo, was chosen by the New York restaurateur Pino Luongo to cook at his new, wildly successful Manhattan restaurant, Le Madri. It was 1989 and she was just 18. Mr. Luongo had the novel idea of staffing Le Madri, which means “the mothers,” with a rotating cadre of Italian women, each cooking her regional specialty. The young Ms. Aloi was hired as the fresh-pasta maker.

headline: Wage Floor Is Increasing in 8 States in New Year
text: Eight states will ring in the New Year with a higher minimum wage, under state laws that require wage floors to keep apace with inflation. San Francisco, one of the few cities that sets its own minimum wage above the federal level, is also raising wages for the lowest-paid workers in the new year. It will become the first big city in the country to require companies to pay their workers more than $10 an hour.

headline: Fewer to Celebrate Christmas in Sudan After South’s Split
text: KHARTOUM, Sudan — Hanging from the wall of Bishop Ezekiel Kondo’s living room — a few blocks from a silver-coated dome marking the tomb of Sudan’s 19th-century Muslim leader, the Mahdi — are a cross, pictures of fellow clergy members and a photo of him with the former archbishop of Canterbury above a small plastic Christmas tree.

headline: Not Exclusively Chinese, but Mostly
text: A FAMILY sits around a table in a Chinese restaurant on Christmas in the climactic scene from the 1983 movie “A Christmas Story.” It is a scene that is repeated every year on Long Island and elsewhere: for those who do not celebrate the holiday — or who do, but who have had enough of it — there’s not a lot to do on this day but go to the movies or have a meal out. And just try to find a non-Asian restaurant open on Christmas.

headline: U.S. Reverses Decision to End Farming Reports
text: The government is back in the business of counting sheep. And mink and goats and catfish and lots of other things that are raised on farms.

headline: Egypt: Protests Against Military Spread Beyond Cairo to New Cities
text: Protests calling for an end to military rule broadened from Cairo to other cities on Friday as thousands turned out in anger at widely circulated images of soldiers beating and stripping female demonstrators during a crackdown last weekend. It was the biggest outbreak of demonstrations outside the capital since the current wave of protests against the ruling military council began Nov. 18. Several thousand protesters gathered in Tahrir Square in Cairo, and significant protests were reported in Alexandria, Suez, Luxor and elsewhere.

headline: The Race to the Right
text: The toxic effects of right-wing extremism in Washington were vividly on display during the payroll-tax fiasco — even to the right wing. On the campaign trail, though, those lessons are being ignored. The leading Republican presidential candidates are overtly competing for the title of Most Conservative, distorting their own records and advocating increasingly radical positions.

headline: Cuba: 2,900 Prisoners Pardoned
text: Cuba has pardoned 2,900 prisoners and may release dozens of foreigners serving jail sentences as a “humanitarian gesture,” President Raúl Castro said Friday. The amnesty will not include Alan Gross, an American contractor whose arrest two years ago has strained relations between Cuba and the United States.  Cuba’s vice foreign minister, Josefina Vidal, told The Associated Press that Mr. Gross was “not on the list.” The prisoners, who were pardoned by the Council of State, Cuba’s highest governing body, include women, the ailing and people over 60, Mr. Castro said in a speech to Parliament. Those released would also include some convicted of crimes against the state who had served a large part of their prison sentence with good behavior. He said the government would also release 86 foreign prisoners from 25 countries, provided that their governments agreed to repatriate them.

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Next Big Task
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s success on big issues like same-sex marriage shows that he can get things done. His top priority now should be to clean up Albany’s pay-to-play culture, beginning with a thorough overhaul of the campaign fund-raising system.

headline: Rehberg and His Broad Push to Help the Mining Industry
text: Representative Denny Rehberg, Republican of Montana, has collected large amounts of campaign contributions from the mining industry, following a series of steps the congressman has taken to help this industry.

headline: At Choir Practice, Fiddling While Drums Boomed
text: We had a backstage pass for a rehearsal for one of the most celebrated birthday concerts of the year: Midnight Mass at St. Patrick’s Cathedral. On Wednesday, we were invited to slip between the pews and ride up in a hidden elevator to a loft to watch the choir prepare.

headline: This Eclectic Season
text: Surely there is a Christmas tree, somewhere in this land, decorated with zombie ornaments or figurines from Battlestar Galactica. Just as surely, someone will be celebrating the holiday traditionally, with real candles burning on a real tree, in Scandinavian fashion. In some houses, Bob Dylan’s “Must Be Santa” is playing in a loop with Rosemary Clooney, Asleep at the Wheel and the choir of King’s College, Cambridge. On Christmas Eve, some will read the Grinch aloud, some will read David Sedaris and many will re-read the first verses of the second chapter of Luke, only to be moved by their beauty all over again.

headline: The Netherlands: Court Upholds Fine for Dumping Waste in Africa
text: An Amsterdam appeals court on Friday upheld a criminal fine of 1 million euros, about $1.3 million, for Trafigura, one of the world’s largest commodity traders, for the Dutch portion of an episode that ended with a shipload of toxic waste being dumped in the open in Ivory Coast. At least 16 people were killed and thousands near the dumping areas were sickened, the Ivory Coast government said. The court found Trafigura guilty of concealing the dangerous nature of the sludge, a mix of oil-products waste and caustic chemicals, when its ship, the Probo Koala, delivered its load to the Netherlands in 2006 for treatment and disposal. After deciding it would be cheaper to dispose of the load elsewhere, Trafigura then illegally exported the waste to the Ivory Coast, the court said. The company, which has denied wrongdoing, has paid Ivory Coast a settlement of close to $200 million. A spokesman for the company called the decision disappointing but did not say if the company would appeal to the country’s highest court.

headline: Logging In With a Touch or a Phrase (Anything but a Password)
text: Passwords are a pain to remember. What if a quick wiggle of five fingers on a screen could log you in instead? Or speaking a simple phrase?

headline: Finding the Unique in You to Build a Better Password
text: Sophisticated hackers can now crack into an account in one second. Using automated password-cracking software, hackers can crack 1,000 accounts in 17 minutes, according to Imperva, a data security firm.

headline: The Week’s Business News in Pictures
text: Municipal retirees in a Rhode Island city agree to a possibly precedent-setting pension cut, merchants slash prices in what may be a desperate effort to move excess inventory and security experts are at work in both airline screening and electronic identification.

headline: More Retailers Pull Formula From Shelves
text: Kroger, Safeway and Walgreen joined retailers removing Enfamil Premium Newborn formula from stores as regulators tested whether the product caused the death of a newborn. Mead Johnson’s stock fell 5.1 percent to $65.29, after plunging 10 percent on Thursday when Walmart pulled the formula. Supervalu also has withdrawn the formula, a spokesman said. Officials screening samples of the formula and water used to prepare it said results might not come until next week. The newborn tested positive for Cronobacter sakazakii, an environmental bacterium that can be fatal. Another child infected with the bacterium in Missouri had also been given formula, though officials said on Friday that the baby, who survived, ingested other types of products as well. The brand of formula given to the second baby was not disclosed.

headline: As Nets Try to Fill Hole in the Middle, the Coach Puts On a Happy Face
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As Nets Coach Avery Johnson sat down in a chair after practice Friday, a reporter asked him a simple, ice-breaking question: how are you feeling?

headline: ‘Willis Reed Tunnel’ Is Gone; Jersey and Memory Stay
text: Willis Reed had heard a few weeks ago that the Madison Square Garden tunnel he made famous in 1970 by merely walking through it was gone. He isn’t mad, or in mourning.

headline: Clash Over Regional Power Spurs Iraq’s Sectarian Rift
text: BAQUBA, Iraq — The governor has fled this uneasy city. Half the members of the provincial council are camped out in northern Iraq, afraid to return to their offices. Peaceful protesters fill the dusty streets, though just days ago angrier crowds blockaded the highways with burning tires and shattered glass.

headline: Saturday: Where the Show Must Go On
text: SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — If you are skilled enough to start a Saturday puzzle at 1 Across (as opposed to just looking for any toehold), you might have been surprised by the entry there today. We’ve seen a clue like “X-ed” or “X-ed out” many times before, but always clued in some way that refers to something being crossed out, or perhaps as a rudimentary signature. We’ve never seen it clued as SPREADEAGLE. What a way to wake up on a Saturday.

headline: Gathering to Mourn the End of a Show That Celebrated Brooklyn
text: The show did not pander, fans said. It did not condescend. It showed Brooklyn, they insisted, for what it was — a place, apparently, with unlicensed private detective work, armies of baby strollers and a bearded superhero whose most salient superpower, acquired after a below-the-belt run-in with the third rail of a subway, cannot be described in a family newspaper.

headline: Deflections and Lundqvist Send Rangers Past Flyers and Into Division Lead
text: Stu Bickel played the third game of his N.H.L. career Friday night, dressing as a defenseman for the Rangers, a team that has been running low on defensemen. He ended the game without a goal, and his face was battered and bloody.

headline: Newt Gingrich and Rick Perry Fail to Qualify for Virginia Primary Ballot
text: 3:09 a.m. | Updated Newt Gingrich will not appear on the Virginia presidential primary ballot, state Republican Party officials announced Saturday, after he failed to submit the required number of valid signatures to qualify.

text: Dear devoted fans of a certain 1946 Frank Capra holiday movie: Relax. The holiday production at Long Wharf Theater has done absolutely no harm to the original. In fact, it has added another layer of nostalgia.

text: They fume about each other’s egos, moods and stunts. They have not appeared together at a single news conference all year. Each of their successes, real or perceived, can provoke envy or resentment in the other.

headline: Diverging Paths of Victims Can Hit Dead Ends
text: “I would know it,” Esther Davis told me back in May, a few days after thieves had made off with her wrought-iron gate that squeaked open and shut on Vanderbilt Avenue in Brooklyn for almost all of her 53 years. Adding to her frustrations was the fact that the thieves stole a bunch of gates that day; she was one of many victims standing in front of brownstones, shaking their heads.

headline: From a Tiffany, Treasures on Canvas
text: AS a teenage aesthete, Louis Comfort Tiffany started making trips abroad to paint in the 1860s, paid for with his inheritance from the family jewelry business. For six decades he regularly took long vacations to sketch. In the Middle East, he painted camel caravans, pyramids and mosque doorways. On trips around America, he set up his easel at Long Island cow pastures, Yellowstone canyons and Pacific Northwest redwoods.

headline: Corrections: December 24
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Slowly Circling a Hallowed Patch
text: Nelson Corporan arrived at Rockefeller Center 20 years ago as a teenager looking for work. Since then, Mr. Corporan, 38, who emigrated from the Dominican Republic at age 15, has been entrusted with perhaps the city’s most cherished stretch of ice: the center’s skating rink. On Christmas Day, as on most Sundays, Mr. Corporan will drive his white Oldsmobile to Midtown before trading it in for a Zamboni. He lives in Washington Heights with his wife, Kamalich, 37, who works in a beauty salon; their children, Brian, 14, and Brianna, 11; and two parrots.

headline: City’s Taxi Fleet Violates Disabilities Act, Judge Rules
text: New York City’s fleet of taxi cabs violates part of the Americans With Disabilities Act by not sufficiently providing for customers who use wheelchairs, a federal judge ruled on Friday.

headline: Where the Hot Chocolate Does a Triple Axel
text: Madonna was not careening around the outdoor skating rink at the Standard Hotel — she’s more likely to materialize upstairs at the Top of the Standard, the celebrity magnet formerly known as the Boom Boom Room — but she and her ilk are well-represented on the piped-in soundtrack. On a recent Friday night, the mood was festive at the Kaffeeklatsch, the pop-up Alpine snack hut and rinkside cafe, at 848 Washington Street, where the shrieks of amateur skaters skidding, sliding and occasionally going boom, were also part of the entertainment. Admission is $12, rental skates are $3, heat lamps keep the crowd warm, and après-ski couture capped by furry hats is the prevalent attire. Grandma’s hot chocolate is served with a twist: fortifying shots of bourbon, brandy, whiskey and whatnot — Dutch courage for skittish skaters.

headline: Medicaid Cuts Are Part of a Larger Battle in Maine
text: AUGUSTA, Me. — At a town hall meeting in the rural western part of the state last week, a woman asked Gov. Paul R. LePage if he could confirm a worrying rumor she had heard: that poor out-of-staters flock here because the public benefits are so generous.

headline: Cache That Trash
text: Q. Coming from Boston, where the sanitation trucks pull in between buildings to make pickups, I am mystified at why people enjoying an evening out in New York have to share the sidewalks of this sophisticated city with great mounds of garbage bags and the rats they attract. That’s what alleys are for. Why are there so few of them in much of Manhattan?

headline: Bloomberg Predicts Fair Deal if Health Insurer Gets For-Profit Status
text: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday that he expected an agreement would be reached to satisfy the city’s concerns about a plan backed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to allow a major nonprofit insurer to be converted into a for-profit company.

headline: John Lawrence, Plaintiff in Gay Rights Case, Dies at 68
text: John G. Lawrence, whose bedroom encounter with the police in Texas led to one of the gay rights movement’s signal triumphs, the Supreme Court’s 2003 decision in Lawrence v. Texas, died at his home in Houston on Nov. 20, his partner said on Friday. He was 68.

headline: James Ramseur, Wounded in ’84 Subway Shooting, Dies at 45
text: James Ramseur, one of four teenagers who was shot by Bernhard H. Goetz, the so-called subway vigilante, in one of the most highly charged and widely publicized criminal cases of the 1980s, died Thursday in the Bronx. He was 45.

headline: Only Questions Follow the Arrest of a Decorated Soldier in the Murder of a Stranger
text: WILMINGTON, Del. — In a completely random act of violence, the police say, Staff Sgt. Dwight L. Smith drove into a stranger as she was walking her dog in a stately Wilmington neighborhood on Monday morning, put the woman into his vehicle and then killed her with blows to the head, according to the criminal charges.

headline: For Me, a Beer. For My Phone, Some Juice.
text: APP goCharge Finder

headline: Obama Challenges Provisions in Budget Bill
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama signed a budget bill on Friday, he issued a signing statement claiming a right to bypass dozens of provisions that placed requirements or restrictions on the executive branch, saying he had “well-founded constitutional objections” to the new statutes.

headline: Racing in Bars, Going Nowhere Fast
text: THE bicycle swung wide left under Alexander Barouh as he furiously pedaled to the end of his 500-meter sprint, bringing gasps from the crowd standing only a few feet from his front wheel.

headline: With Paul on the Rise in Iowa, Gingrich Takes Aim
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Newt Gingrich turned his fire on Representative Ron Paul of Texas on Friday, saying that his Republican opponent had to answer for political and investment newsletters that included racist, anti-gay and anti-Israel passages that Mr. Paul has disavowed.

headline: Did You Give the Doorman Enough?
text: In recent years, New Yorkers fortunate enough to indulge worries over domestic compensation have been besieged with more and more advice and debate every December — from newspapers, magazines, parenting blogs, real-estate blogs — on how much to tip the people who take care of our children, open our doors, adjust our radiators, park our Priuses. And yet there is little to suggest that this mountain of charts and bullet points has eased the tension. What economists cite as the vexing information asymmetries central to these transactions appear to have been rectified hardly at all.

headline: Wenger Says He’s Considering Adding Henry on Loan; Lindpere Talks Europe
text: Thierry Henry was in London two weeks ago to be honored as part of Arsenal’s 125th anniversary celebrations. But could he be going back next month for a longer stay?

headline: Sounding Quiet Dissent About a Holiday Perennial
text: Bil Browning and his boyfriend were homeless. To protect the identity of the boyfriend (now ex-boyfriend), Mr. Browning will not say specifically where, just that it was in “southern Indiana,” about 20 years ago. But he is very explicit about who refused to give them shelter.

headline: Highlights From the James Kalm Report
text: The painter Loren Munk, working under the alias James Kalm, has made more than 900 videos documenting the New York art world. Here are some selections.

headline: Via YouTube, Leading Tours of the City’s Art Scene
text: WHEN Loren Munk began furtively filming New York City gallery and museum openings in 2006 — “working undercover,” as he put it — he was regularly kicked out by security guards and threatened with legal action for copyright infringement.

headline: Newswallah: Bollywood Edition
text: Raj Kapoor: From Jan. 6-16, The Museum of Modern Art in New York will showcase one of Hindi cinema’s most iconic filmmakers, Raj Kapoor. An exhibition titled “Raj Kapoor and the Golden Age of Indian Cinema” will screen new prints of eight Raj Kapoor films, including “Awaara” (1951), “Barsaat” (1949) and “Bobby” (1973). The exhibition is curated by Noah Cowan, artistic director of TIFF Bell Lightbox. He tells us about Raj Kapoor’s enduring legacy.

headline: Newswallah: Bharat Edition
text: Jammu and Kashmir: Farooq Abdullah, the federal minister for new and renewable energy, on Wednesday accused the media of creating “China phobia.” He was responding to a question about reports suggesting that China was building bunkers along the Jammu and Kashmir border. (Kashmir Live)

headline: Harlem’s Maestro of Gospel Music
text: IT is no idle boast for Edgar Kendricks: The man can sit at any piano or organ in Harlem and summon a legion of church ladies in big hats to fill the pews and serve as his choir.

headline: Events in Westchester
text: Seasonal

headline: Events on Long Island
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in Connecticut
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Events in New Jersey
text: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Bleeding Green: Protecting the Outside Is the Jets’ Bright Side
text: Brian Bassett is the founder of SNY’s The Jets Blog. You can follow him on Twitter at @Brian_Bassett. He and Ed Valentine of Big Blue View will be writing about the Jets and the Giants in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

headline: Dyed in Blue: Alive Until the End? That’s the Giants’ Way
text: Ed Valentine is the editor of Big Blue View, a Giants blog. He and Brian Bassett of The Jets blog will write in the days leading up to the Giants-Jets game on Saturday.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,839 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Friday:

headline: North Carolina: Edwards Legal Team Asks for Delay
text: Lawyers for former Senator John Edwards asked a federal judge on Thursday to delay his criminal trial because he had “unexpectedly encountered a medical issue” and they needed more time to prepare his defense. Jury selection was scheduled to begin next month in Greensboro. Mr. Edwards is accused of violating campaign finance laws by using donors’ money to support his pregnant mistress during his 2008 presidential campaign. The lawyers did not explain the nature of the medical issue publicly, but said they had filed confidential information to the judge. Prosecutors filed a response, asking the judge, Catherine Eagles, not to delay the trial.

headline: A Fateful Christmas Meeting
text: On Christmas morning 1861, the steps of all three Lincoln sons could be heard pounding on the floorboards of the White House. The eldest, Robert, had recently arrived home from Harvard, to join his brothers, 8-year old Tad and 11-year-old Willie. The reunion of the Lincoln clan was a bright spot on what was proving to be a less than cheery Christmas. The Union had lost several key battles, while the Confederacy seemed no closer to collapse. Then, before the president could sit down to Christmas dinner with his family, he had yet another matter to attend to: deciding whether the Union could risk war with Britain.

headline: Car Bomber Kills Soldiers in Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A suicide car bomber drove a vehicle packed with explosives into a building used by paramilitary forces in northwestern Pakistan early on Saturday, killing at least six soldiers and wounding 11 others, police officials said.

headline: Bill Cunningham | New York on Display
text: During New York City's holiday shopping season, there is more on display than just fashion. The major department stores showcase their artistic talents through their window displays.

headline: The Weekend Word: Blocked
text: Today’s Times

headline: Calculating Playoff Odds for Jets and Giants
text: “There’s some more important things that go into it, because basically, you’re out of the playoffs if you lose this game, either team is.”  Rex Ryan, Jets coach, earlier this week.

headline: Vast Rally in Moscow Is a Challenge to Putin’s Power
text: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of citizens converged in Moscow on Saturday for the second huge antigovernment demonstration in a month, an early victory for activists struggling to forge a burst of energy into a political force capable of challenging Vladimir V. Putin’s power.

headline: Kim Jong-il Son Cleared as Top Military Commander
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea broadcast television footage on Sunday of the top military brass flanking the country’s young new leader, Kim Jong-un, as they paid their respects to Mr. Kim’s father, who died of heart attack a week ago, and vowed their allegiance to his chosen successor.

headline: Part of the Team
text: The Long Island RoughRiders play sled hockey, a sport developed for wheelchair athletes. This team includes players with intellectual as well as physical challenges. And they're good. Really good.

headline: Joe Nocera Gets Mad
text: And it’s a beautiful thing to see.

headline: Plenty of Disgrace and Distress in a Year of Sports Headlines
text: In a sports year unlike any other, success was too often soured by scandal or sadness, upset or injury, litigation or violence.

headline: Exchange Rates and Wages
text: A followup to my post about modern Chicago economists forgetting what Milton Friedman knew: recent events have actually given us a dramatic demonstration of the reality of nominal wage stickiness. Here’s a graph I’ve shown before:

headline: TimesCast | 2011: The Year in Media
text: December 23, 2011 - A look back at the growing intersection between social and mainstream media.

headline: For Mets, Vast Debt and Not a Lot of Time
text: The finances of major professional sports teams exist largely as the secrets of privately held companies, except for the community-owned Green Bay Packers, who report their profits without a hint of resistance.

headline: Fiscal Policy Works
text: Via Brad DeLong, there’s a paper by David Romer (pdf) summarizing recent research on fiscal policy, inspired by the crisis and aftermath. And his conclusion is not at all what you hear on the talk shows; it is that there is now overwhelming evidence that fiscal policy does in fact work when it’s not offset by monetary policy. And since we’re now in a liquidity trap in which conventional monetary policy has no traction, that’s the world we’re in.

headline: New Rules for the Ways We Watch
text: For the last year, media pundits like me have been running around screaming our heads off about falling skies and collapsing paradigms, and yet as 2011 comes to an end, the sky is still there.

headline: The Year in Media | A Conversation
text: The signs of social change were everywhere to see in 2011, and new-media tools were instrumental to that change, whether in Cairo or Lower Manhattan’s Zuccotti Park. But as Bruce Headlam, The Times’s media editor, David Carr, and the Media Equation columnist, discussed this week in a video recap of the year, the business of media didn’t change quite as quickly. But, there’s always next year.

headline: Beaten, and Beaten Up, the Packers Try to Cope
text: On NBC last Sunday night, Tony Dungy — who led the Indianapolis Colts to a victory in Super Bowl XLI — said that if he were the coach of the Green Bay Packers, “I’d be worried right now.”

headline: A Basketball League Where Steinbrenner and 3-Pointers Started
text: In 1961, the N.B.A. was a far cry from the corporate behemoth that finally opens play on Sunday after bickering for months over billions in revenue. The league was 15 years old but still trying to find its way in a landscape dominated by baseball, football, boxing and college sports. That season, the Philadelphia Warriors star Wilt Chamberlain scored 100 points against the Knicks in Hershey, Pa., in front of barely 4,000 people, with no television crew, not even reporters from The Philadelphia Inquirer or any New York newspapers.

headline: For Miami Heat, High Hopes but Lower Volume
text: The official restart of the Miami Heat begins on Sunday with far less noise than a year ago, when a team constructed on superstar intrigue evoked breathless predictions and sputtering vitriol in equal measure.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: To the Sports Editor:

headline: N.B.A. Should Honor Its History and Learn From It
text: After a long and avoidable delay, the N.B.A. finally opens its 2011-12 season Sunday. The new season brings two anniversaries worth noting. One you will probably hear quite a lot about: the 50th anniversary of the 1961-62 season. The other, the 35th anniversary of the Oscar Robertson Rule, maybe not so much.

headline: Mapping Your Drive And the Odd Stops on It
text: Ever get to the end of a road trip and realize you were just a few miles away from the shoe of the world’s tallest man but you missed it? Maybe not, but On the Way, a new online travel site for road trippers, was designed to help find such unusual attractions. When you enter your start and destination, the program will populate a map of your route with restaurants, museums and less traditional tourist sites using programming interfaces like Google Places, Foursquare, Yelp and Lonely Planet’s Points of Interest. It can help you find a Starbucks between New York and Washington, but it’s better for local alternatives like Miss Shirley’s Cafe in Baltimore.

headline: Gingrich Ballot Failure Highlights Challenge to Campaign
text: Newt Gingrich had declared confidently the other day that he would get his name on the ballot for the Republican primary in Virginia. In fact, he said he already had the requisite 10,000 signatures plus an additional few thousand for safety’s sake and would probably collect even more at events in Arlington and Richmond.

headline: Capital Holiday
text: Many lawmakers have made their way home for the holidays, but that hasn’t stopped the nation’s capital from putting on its seasonal best.

headline: Playing on Sleds, With Just as Much Heart
text: When the Long Island RoughRiders play hockey, they use two sticks, wear no skates and keep their faces three feet from the ice.

headline: Before Recruiting in Ivy League, Applying Some Math
text: The Ivy League, which is experiencing an athletic revival with several teams ranked nationally, is a doggedly atypical N.C.A.A. Division I sports conference. For starters, the eight members are virtual heretics in the landscape of American big-time college sports for fielding about 280 teams in 35 sports without athletic scholarships. The league also restricts activities like off-season practices, discourages weekday games and prohibits postseason play in football.

headline: Paul’s Influence Doesn’t Just Depend on Him
text: Ron Paul is quite clearly capable of winning the Iowa caucuses. But if Mr. Paul wins Iowa, what happens next?

headline: Deconstructing Santa
text: In Brent Clark’s series “Season’s Greetings,” Dec. 25 is an excuse for over-the-top consumerism characterized by excessive decorating, sometimes whimsical, at other times verging on the surreal.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
text: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — The Puns and Anagrams puzzles by Mel Taub are, to me at least, like a palate cleanser between dinner courses: They are a pleasant, refreshing break in between the Saturday brain-breaker and the big Sunday grid, and I’m kind of fond of them, but I’m glad they don’t come up too often. I don’t believe I’d want to make an entire meal of them. As always, your mileage may vary.

headline: Sydney to Hobart With a Teenager at the Helm
text: James Spithill was the first Australian helmsman in nearly 30 years to win the America’s Cup, at the helm of BMW Oracle Racing in 2010. He is perhaps the finest match racer in the world, a hard-driving competitor who is quick to embrace the risks that go with maneuvering one rich man’s expensive toy at high speed within arm’s length of another rich man’s expensive toy.

headline: Gingrich’s Ballot Miss Could Shake Voters’ Confidence
text: Newt Gingrich declared confidently the other day that he would get his name on the ballot for the Republican presidential primary in Virginia. In fact, he said he already had the requisite 10,000 signatures and an additional 2,000 to 3,000 for safety’s sake and would probably collect even more.

headline: Assad Trades Blame With Protesters for Bombings in Syria
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Thousands of people attended funerals in Damascus on Saturday for the victims of two powerful bombs that exploded outside government security buildings the day before, as human rights activists reported a large-scale assault on a restive city by government troops.

headline: Pentagon Finds No Fault in Ties to TV Analysts
text: A Pentagon public relations program that sought to transform high-profile military analysts into “surrogates” and “message force multipliers” for the Bush administration complied with Defense Department regulations and directives, the Pentagon’s inspector general has concluded after a two-year investigation.

headline: For the Parents, Simple Pleasures
text: Like a lot of dutiful adult sons and daughters, my friend Margaret braved the airport this week. She and her family are spending Christmas with her elderly parents in South Carolina.

headline: Murder Cases Put Questionable Evidence to Test
text: Undigested bits of mushrooms and tomatoes from Christine Morton’s last meal — a celebratory birthday dinner she had with her husband — were still in her stomach when the medical examiner performed his autopsy in 1986.

headline: The Unspeakable: A Canadiens Coach Not Knowing French
text: Of all the professional sports teams in North America, probably none have the political resonance of the Montreal Canadiens. Beyond their more than 100 years of tradition and their 24 Stanley Cups, the Canadiens are the standard-bearers of a people, a culture and a certain idea about Quebec. Anything involving le club de hockey Canadien can easily end up being about French and English.

headline: A Quake-Scarred Nation Tries a Rural Road to Recovery
text: PAPAYE, Haiti — For months after the earthquake that struck the capital, Manel Laurore pulled shattered bodies from his neighbors’ homes, hunkered in fetid refugee camps and scrounged for food and water.

headline: Getting a Helping Hand After Giving Back to the City
text: Sami Steigmann gave the Australians fair warning. He told them that he grew up in Transylvania.

headline: Silent Night? Not With Us
text: PIVOTING from a life less loud into all the talk at my family’s Christmas gathering is like stepping off a plane from the wintry north into the heat of the tropics. I’m shocked for a second or two. Disoriented for several more. Then warmed and thrilled. Those are the feelings that last.

headline: Leadership Lessons From the Shackleton Expedition
text: A HUNDRED years ago this month, the Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen and four teammates became the first men to reach the South Pole, arriving in triumph five weeks ahead of Robert Falcon Scott. The Amundsen crew would return safely to its base, but, heartbreakingly, Scott and his four British companions died on the return journey.

headline: A Victorian Christmas
text: WASHINGTON

headline: Neediest Cases | Where Are They Now?
text: Before receiving help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Andrés Zambrano kept his love of literature and theater a secret.

headline: A Boom for Bourbon
text: Sales of bourbon are rising rapidly, helped by premium small-batch and single-barrel products and flavor infusions like honey, cherry and spice.

headline: Bourbon’s All-American Roar
text: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

headline: The Cratchit Tax Credit
text: AT Christmastime, we like to tell stories about resilient families. The Cratchits of “A Christmas Carol,” for instance, who subsist on love, hope and 15 shillings a week. The Baileys of Bedford Falls, who survive wars, bank runs and bankruptcies because they have friends, one another, and a guardian angel watching out for them. The first couple of the New Testament, who manage to cope with a supernatural pregnancy, a murderous king and the necessity of delivering a child in the bleak midwinter, half-out-of-doors and far from home.

headline: Verizon’s Worrisome Cable Deals
text: AT&T’s decision to drop its bid for T-Mobile is a victory for the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission, which steadfastly opposed a deal that would have locked the wireless market into a duopoly and been bad for consumers. But the battle to defend competition in telecommunications is hardly over.

headline: Deportation Without Representation
text: In deciding who may stay and who must leave this country, the deportation process for immigrants tolerates unfairness at every turn. Current laws have denied basic due process protections to people held in immigration detention. And now, a new report in the Cardozo Law Review reveals a severe shortage of competent legal assistance for tens of thousands facing deportation. The study examines cases in New York, but New York is hardly unique in this failing.

headline: The Miracle and the Means
text: Some years it would be nice if there really were a Santa Claus. Imagine it. No lists, no shopping, no gift-wrapping, no bills, no shipping costs, an extremely low carbon footprint — and on Christmas morning the miraculous appearance of presents that find just the right balance between desire and a sort of disciplinary justice.

headline: Injustice in Murder Cases
text: In most American counties, some indigent criminal defendants are represented by a public defender, and others by a private court-appointed lawyer. A new RAND study focusing on Philadelphia exposes a vast difference in how clients fare depending on the kind of lawyer they are assigned.

headline: When Regime Change Came With a Whimper
text: On the evening of Christmas Day 20 years ago, my wife and kids went to Moscow’s Red Square to round out a day of holiday cheer. I had to stay in The Times’s office because Mikhail Gorbachev had resigned that morning and was making a televised address in the evening.

headline: Foreclosure Relief? Don’t Hold Your Breath
text: THROUGHOUT the foreclosure crisis, Washington has done little to help people hang on to their homes. All those programs that were supposed to help — HAMP, HARP, Hope for Homeowners — have mostly failed.

headline: Every Team Should Have a Devil’s Advocate
text: This interview with  Ori Hadomi, C.E.O. of   Mazor Robotics, a medical technology company based in Israel, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: No Progress on H.G.H. Testing
text: The stalemate on human growth hormone testing in the N.F.L. is no closer to being resolved after a proposal by the players union to the league, and a Congressional committee involved in the issue, that would not include testing during the regular season.

headline: France Télécom in Deal to Sell Swiss Mobile-Phone Unit
text: France Télécom agreed to sell its Orange Switzerland mobile-phone unit to the London buyout firm Apax Partners for 1.6 billion euros, or $2.1 billion, the first major step in the chief executive’s plan to unload slow-growing European operations.

headline: Capital Holiday
text: Many lawmakers have made their way home for the holidays, but that hasn’t stopped the nation’s capital from putting on its seasonal best. More Photos

headline: Letters: A.B.A. Standards and Law Schools
text: To the Editor:

headline: Which Teams Will Have the Stamina for a 66-Game Sprint?
text: One crucial aspect of the lockout-shortened 2011-12 N.B.A. season will be the hectic 66-game pace. Which teams will have the legs to keep up, and which teams will be worn out?

headline: Letters: A Student’s View on E-Textbooks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Don’t Forget Wingnut Welfare
text: Steve Benen asks why Congressional Republicans were willing to pursue what looked like a “suicidal” political strategy in the payroll tax fight. But he somehow fails to mention an important factor: reliable conservatives are assured of a safe landing even if they are defeated.

headline: If These Moms Can’t Find It, They Invent It
text: EIGHT years ago, Tamara Monosoff came up with an invention that she was sure mothers like herself would appreciate: a device that prevents children from unspooling toilet paper from the roll. But she had no idea how to transform the concept into a marketable product.

headline: Sunday Dialogue: Reading Books in the Digital Age
text: Readers discuss the choices to be made in the digital age: buy books online or at the local bookstore? Read e-books or paper books?

headline: Providing Sustenance in Detroit
text: At Focus:HOPE, a nonprofit has been providing food to the poor for more than four decades.

headline: Publishers vs. Libraries: An E-Book Tug of War
text: LAST year, Christmas was the biggest single day for e-book sales by HarperCollins. And indications are that this year’s Christmas Day total will be even higher, given the extremely strong sales of e-readers like the Kindle and the Nook. Amazon announced on Dec. 15 that it had sold one million of its Kindles in each of the three previous weeks.

headline: At Detroit Food Bank, Founders Are Gone, but a Mission Endures
text: DETROIT

headline: From the Fed, a Shield Against Europe
text: AS the euro zone mess unfolds, another financial crisis may be coming our way. The conduit could be some spillover effect from across the Atlantic — whether in derivatives or money markets — or maybe some under-the-radar surprise.

headline: A Flurry of Changes
text: Nine of these 10 teams made major attempts to reshape their rosters.

headline: Menu Misnomers, and Other Grousings
text: FOR the second consecutive year the Haggler steps aside and cedes the podium to the comedian, storyteller, author and ranter extraordinaire, Adam Carolla. If you’re not listening to his podcast, “The Adam Carolla Show,” you’re missing out on some peerless, portable entertainment — and the chance to hear a truly original mind complain, muse and theorize for a couple of hours a week.

headline: The Finds of the Lost Decade
text: WITH only a week left in 2011, the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index has a dubious distinction: its performance has been far worse than that of a basic basket of bonds in the last 12 years. But while betting on a large-cap stock index may not have paid off over that time, it would be wrong to assume that this has been the case for all sectors of the market.

headline: First a Prosecutor, Now a Defense Lawyer
text: I  DON’T know many people who’ve had one job their whole life. Today, most people change jobs more than once, and usually several times. Maybe they stay in their field, or perhaps they enter a related one. More rarely, they might do something totally different.

headline: Forces Loyal to Yemeni President Fire on Protesters
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Government soldiers opened fire on a giant demonstration in Yemen’s capital on Saturday, killing at least nine protesters in the worst violence since President Ali Abdullah Saleh agreed to give up his post more than a month ago.

headline: A New Side of Science
text: MY grandparents emigrated from Japan to California for a better life. My mother was 10 when the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, and she and her family were sent to an internment camp. We have a photo of the notice that was posted on a utility pole in their neighborhood, instructing people where to report.

headline: The Dear Leader Is Dead, Again
text: Chicago

headline: The Caucus Click: The Week in Pictures
text: Photographs from Iowa, New Hampshire and Virginia

headline: Protesters Gather in Moscow
text: Tens of thousands gathered on Saturday for the second huge antigovernment demonstration in a month.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 25
text: The Sunday talk shows will revisit some of the biggest political stories of the year and weigh in on what could come back to haunt – or help – some candidates in 2012.

headline: Singing the Gospel, in Harlem Churches
text: Edgar Kendricks has been a staple in Harlem gospel circles for more than 40 years, and still cuts a flashy figure on the street, with his unique wardrobe.

headline: Mental Health Centers Are Hit Hard by Cuts
text: Some of Chicago’s most vulnerable citizens — those who depend on public financing for mental health services — face a new year that may bring less of something they deeply need: help.

headline: Ripple Effects of Center Closings Will Continue for Many Years
text: James Warren writes a column for The Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Stating Their Case and Silencing Jets
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants were disgusted to arrive at MetLife Stadium on Saturday morning and see the four Super Bowl logos outside their locker room concealed by black curtains. When their kicker, Lawrence Tynes, pulled back the curtains, someone with the Jets came by to yank them over again.

headline: Italy Tries Raising the Social Stigma on Tax Evaders
text: ROME — On a recent morning, Maurizio Compagnone, an employee of Italy’s internal revenue service, stood before a classroom of middle school students in a leafy neighborhood here, preaching the virtues of paying taxes.

headline: The Haves’ Children Are Healthier Than the Have-Nots’
text: Every Monday, Sycamore Valley Elementary in Danville challenges its students to run a “Smile Mile” together after school. Some parents even run with their children. Photos of the student joggers’ grinning faces are posted in the cafeteria. On a recent Monday afternoon, there were 41 smiling faces on the wall.

headline: Trump Quits G.O.P.
text: Donald J. Trump has withdrawn from the Republican Party to retain the ability to run as an independent candidate in the 2012 presidential election, his political adviser confirmed on Friday.

headline: Royalists Step Up Campaign to Stifle Criticism of the Monarchy in Thailand
text: BANGKOK — At the entrance to a neighborhood in Bangkok’s garment district, an unambiguous message hangs on an archway decorated with an image of Thailand’s king.

headline: Video of Protests in Russia
text: Updated | Sunday | 2:10 p.m. As my colleagues Ellen Barry and Michael Schwirtz report, tens of thousands of Russians filled a street named for the Soviet dissident Andrei Sakharov on Saturday, demanding fair elections.

headline: At Harvard, a Master’s in Problem Solving
text: A few years after Mitt Romney graduated from Harvard Business School, he returned to share a simple, timeworn lesson in an unusual way.

headline: Wolfgang Oehme, a Free-Form Landscape Architect, Dies at 81
text: Wolfgang Oehme, a landscape architect who drew from a palette of feathery grasses and black-eyed Susans to create what he called “horticultural explosions,” free-form landscapes that some called exemplars of “the new American garden,” died on Dec. 15 at his home in Towson, Md. He was 81.

headline: Playoff Picture Clear for  Giants, Complex for Jets
text: After a victory over the Jets on Saturday, the Giants have a path to the playoffs that is easy to understand. If they beat the Cowboys next Sunday, they’ll win the N.F.C. East and they’re in. If they lose, the Cowboys are in and the Giants are out. (The Eagles were knocked out by the Giants’ victory.)

headline: Notes From Mitt Romney’s 1978 Presentation
text: Clayton Christensen’s notes from a 1978 presentation given by Mitt Romney to a Mormon student group at the Harvard Business School.

headline: Robert Easton, Hollywood’s Henry Higgins, Dies at 81
text: Robert Easton, a character actor turned accent coach to the stars, who transformed Drew Barrymore into Amy Fisher, Ben Kingsley into Meyer Lansky and Gregory Peck first into Josef Mengele and later into Abraham Lincoln, among other feats of articulatory alchemy, died on Dec. 16 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

headline: Paul-Emile Deiber, Actor Who Became an Opera Director, Dies at 86
text: Paul-Emile Deiber, an actor and director with the Comédie-Française for nearly three decades who brought his dramatic expertise to a second career as an opera director, died on Dec. 14. He was 86.

headline: Sunday: Ain’t He Sweet?
text: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — The tree has been decorated, the presents have been opened, the eggs have been nogged, and the wassails have been, well … wassailed. To those who celebrate, I hope you had a very happy Christmas.

headline: Life and Death in a Baghdad E.R.
text: BAGHDAD — I did really want to cry, but the tears wouldn’t come down.

headline: Pupi Campo, Cuban Bandleader and ‘the Rumba Maestro,’ Dies at 91
text: Pupi Campo, a Cuban bandleader who brought rippling syncopation to Jack Paar’s “Morning Show” on CBS television in the early 1950s and to his long career in nightclubs around the country, died on Dec. 12 at a hospice in Las Vegas. He was 91.

headline: Image Tarnished by Scandals, Washington Council Overhauls Ethics Rules
text: WASHINGTON — It was a sunny Friday morning when federal agents in bulletproof vests and F.B.I. windbreakers pulled up to the brick home on a quiet cul-de-sac. As spectators watched from across yellow police tape, the agents loaded an S.U.V. and a motorcycle emblazoned with decals onto a flatbed truck and took them away.

headline: Many Rules Surround Beekeeping in the Bay
text: When Round Rock Honey decided to expand its Beekeeping Academy beyond Texas, its first stop was San Mateo County. Through Groupon, the company signed up nearly 1,000 new students in just a few days.

headline: Manicures and Compassion for ‘Throwaway People’ in the Tenderloin
text: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Brewster/ Rutledge Garden
text: The east slope of Bernal Hill, which was settled in the 1860s by Irish farmers and dairy ranchers, has stayed true to its roots and now has an abundance of community gardens utilizing the steep hillsides, including this 8,750-square-foot spot. There are 35 city-owned community gardens in San Francisco, overseen by the Parks and Recreation Department and run by volunteers.  LOUISE RAFKIN

headline: Escape to Hawaii, After a Tricky Week in Washington
text: KAILUA, Hawaii — For President Obama, simply going on vacation these days seems to demand the theatrics of a Houdini-like escape from the padlocked box of Washington.

headline: State Still Footing the Bill for Perry Security Detail
text: Gov. Rick Perry was near the height of his popularity when he barnstormed California in September to raise money for his presidential bid and to participate in his first nationally televised debate.

headline: U.S. Embraces a Low-Key Response to Turmoil in Iraq
text: WASHINGTON — As Iraq erupted in recent days, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was in constant phone contact with the leaders of the country’s dueling sects. He called the Shiite prime minister and the Sunni speaker of the Parliament on Tuesday, and the Kurdish leader on Thursday, urging them to try to resolve the political crisis.

headline: In the Battle of the Maps, Republicans Win Either Way
text: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: Florida Looks for Curbs on Some Legless Invaders
text: MIAMI — To live in South Florida is to make peace with flying cockroach behemoths, brigades of lizards that dart across walls (bedroom and otherwise) and frogs the size of cannonballs that loiter on driveways.

headline: Female Patrons of State Arts Share Inspirations
text: A lot of female patrons have worked to establish the arts and culture scene in Texas, from Ima Hogg, whose influence was widely felt in the Houston art community, to Velma Fuller Kimbell, who endowed a remarkable portion of her fortune to building Fort Worth’s Kimbell Art Museum. Six women, all part of the giving program Texas Women for the Arts, continue the tradition. Here they share their early arts inspirations and the museums, collections and venues that travelers should not miss.

headline: The Neediest Cases | Sami Steigmann
text: Sami Steigmann, 72, survived a Nazi camp in Ukraine and volunteers as a way of giving back to a city that has helped him.

headline: Flop and Then Flip for a Touchdown for Jerome Simpson
text: Jerome Simpson’s amazing flip for a touchdown — he somersaulted over an Arizona Cardinal at the goal line and stuck the landing in the end zone — is one of the most dazzling touchdowns in N.F.L. history.

headline: Nice View, and the Profits Surpass All Horizons
text: The owners of the Empire State Building like to promote it as the most famous office building in the world.

headline: Harsh Political Reality Slows Climate Studies Despite Extreme Year

headline: Ruling by Justice Dept. Opens a Door on Online Gambling
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has reversed its long-held opposition to many forms of Internet gambling, removing a big legal obstacle for states that want to sanction online gambling to help fix their budget deficits.

headline: Romo Goes Down, and Cowboys Fall
text: ARLINGTON, Tex. — His right hand wrapped in a bandage, the Dallas Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo stood on the sideline looking like a prizefighter who had thrown his last punch. Romo’s throwing hand had crashed into a Philadelphia Eagle’s helmet shortly after the Giants had beaten the Jets, which actually rendered Saturday’s result here meaningless.

headline: A Look at Who’s on Top as the Season Wraps Up
text: Think of how many dollhouse and train sets were botched in the assembly process by exhausted, irate football players Saturday night. Here is what happened in Saturday’s games and what it means for the regular season’s final week.

headline: Life on the Tournament Circuit Is Often Off the Beaten Track
text: Traveling is part of the life of a chess player. Sometimes the destination is glamorous — London or Gibraltar — but elite tournaments are often held in out-of-the-way places that do not top many tourist lists.

headline: Coughlin Jokes About Injury, and Refuses to Gloat
text: After a week of trash talk from Jets Coach Rex Ryan, Tom Coughlin refused all opportunities to gloat following the Giants’ victory on Saturday. He said of his sideline injury,  “I will end up on NFL Films forever.” Here are excerpts from his postgame news conference. The full transcript is at Giants.com.
