headline: Violet Captured for Treatment in Washington Square Park
text: Violet, the red-tailed hawk who has been suffering from a crippling leg injury, was captured for treatment on Saturday in Washington Square Park.

headline: Giants Are Far From Perfect, but Defense Makes Them Good Enough
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants players have talked all season about wanting a “complete” game. They have vowed, over and over, that they will deliver a “total team effort.” They have stressed — even this week, amid the verbal flotsam and jetsam of a Giants-Jets rivalry game — that there is no other way for them to play.

headline: After Week of Taunts, Final Word Is Anything but Friendly
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After a week of breathless banter and rehashed rhetoric, the back and forth between the Giants and the Jets — which by Friday seemed to border on the nonsensical — ultimately reached a nasty conclusion.

headline: Sunday’s Matchup: Bears at Packers
text: Bears (7-7) at Packers (13-1) 8:20 p.m., Eastern; NBCLine: Packers by 13 Packers right tackle Bryan Bulaga (knee) is out. Left tackle Chad Clifton (back) is easing his way back after missing two months; he has been limited in practice and is unlikely to play. The primary backup tackle, Derek Sherrod, is out for the season with a broken leg. Green Bay’s injury situation became so dire in its loss to the Chiefs that T.J. Lang took snaps at right tackle, a position he had never played, even in practice. “It’s next guy up,” Coach Mike McCarthy said of the injuries, which is all well and good, except that the next guy might be Jerry Kramer. Health problems on the line can easily become health problems for Aaron Rodgers, but the Bears have played so badly in the wake of the Jay Cutler-Matt Forte injuries that the Packers could put a cardboard Rodgers cutout in the pocket and it would make little difference.

headline: Andrei Cimpian and Joseph Robinson
text: Andrei Cimpian and Joseph Paul Robinson were married Friday in Auburn, N.Y. Florence M. Riley, a town justice of Sennett, N.Y., officiated at the home of Carmela Spoto, Dr. Robinson’s maternal grandmother.

headline: Molly Gomolin and David Katz
text: Molly Elyssa Gomolin and David Benjamin Katz were married by Rabbi Kenneth N. Hain Thursday at Carlyle on the Green in Bethpage, N.Y., with Rabbi Elie Weissman taking part.

headline: Alison Christie and Joseph Roby IV
text: Alison D. Christie and Joseph Roby IV were married Wednesday evening in an outdoor ceremony at the Gulf Stream Golf Club in Gulf Stream, Fla. David C. Tassell, a Florida notary public and a friend of the bride’s parents, officiated.

headline: Eagles  Look Dangerous, but It’s Too Late
text: “I’m happy for Jason Garrett for having an opportunity to possibly take his football team to the playoffs. And Tom Coughlin. I wish we were there.” Andy Reid, Eagles coach, after his team was knocked out of the playoffs.

headline: Rome for the Holidays
text: The traditional inauguration of the Christmas season got underway early this month in Rome, but travelers can visit vestiges of those early celebrations, and still take in a few more ceremonies, after the gifts have been opened.

headline: Pulling Back Curtain on Ugliness of Giants-Jets
text: “They got a big-mouthed coach, a big mouth and a big-bellied coach that talks too much and now it’s finally time to shut up.” Brandon Jacobs, on Rex Ryan.

headline: Suicide Bomber Strikes Funeral in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber attacked a funeral in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, killing at least 20 people, officials said, in what appeared to be the Taliban’s latest strike against Afghans who have ties to the national government.

headline: We Like Sheep
text: Merry Christmas.

headline: Nigerian Group Escalates Violence With Church Attacks
text: A series of Christmas Day church bombings rocked Nigeria on Sunday in what appeared to be a coordinated assault by a radical Islamist sect with suspected training links to Al Qaeda, raising the sect’s violent antigovernment struggle to a new and more dangerous level that the Nigerian authorities seem powerless to contain. At least 25 people were killed.

headline: Japanese Leader to Focus on N. Korea During Visit to China
text: BEIJING — Prime Minister Yoshihiko Noda of Japan arrived in Beijing on Sunday for a two-day state visit that was originally aimed at improving bilateral ties, but is now expected to focus on the uncertainty over North Korea’s intentions after the death of Kim Jong-il.

headline: Sudan’s Government Says Powerful Rebel Leader Is Dead
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — Khalil Ibrahim, a powerful Sudanese rebel leader who once mounted a daring and near-successful raid that took his fighters from the sun-blasted deserts of Darfur to the doorstep of the capital, Khartoum, died on Saturday from wounds he received in battle, the Sudanese government said.

headline: Lax Security Exposes Voice Mail to Hacking, Study Says
text: BERLIN — It may be tempting to view the illegal interception of telephone voice mails, a practice that has roiled Britain and the News Corp. media empire of Rupert Murdoch, as an arcane tool employed by scofflaw journalists with friends in Scotland Yard.

headline: Retreat of Glaciers Makes Some Climbs Tougher
text: Three decades ago, when Mick Fowler climbed the north face of the Eiger in the Swiss Alps, he used crampons and ice axes to haul himself up sheer walls of snow and ice.

headline: The Book Beyond the Book
text: That sound you hear is the wrapping being torn off of millions of Kindles and iPads. When those devices are fired up and start downloading texts, it will be the greatest shift in casual reading since the mass market paperback arrived six decades ago. Will this dislocation destroy the traditional book? Will it doom the traditional independent bookstore? Will Amazon and Apple control the distribution of thought and culture in America? All these questions will be played out imminently.

headline: Woman’s Daughters and Parents Killed in Connecticut Fire
text: STAMFORD, Conn. — The three children and the parents of a well-known advertising executive were killed when a predawn fire tore through the family’s Victorian house in a neighborhood overlooking Long Island Sound.

text: A. O. Scott looks at the relationship between humans and the natural world in Terrence Malick’s war drama.

headline: Bombings in Nigeria
text: Boko Haram, a radical Muslim sect waging an increasingly sophisticated sectarian fight, claimed a series of attacks.

headline: Classic Newsstand Gets Ready to Roll
text: Few newsstands merit a cameo role in a major motion picture, but the octagonal structure with a gracefully tapering roof at Columbus Circle is such an echt newsstand that Woody Allen cast it in “Bullets Over Broadway.”

headline: Reads and Reactions
text: In this holiday edition: holiday greetings and gratitude, plus Ron Paul’s surge and Christmas number crunching.

headline: The Year in Arts Portraits
text: Artists, actors, filmmakers and musicians by photographers from The New York Times.

headline: For Joplin, a Love Letter in Ruins
text: JOPLIN, Mo. — As this rebuilding city races to finish clearing the rubble from the deadly tornado last spring, one irreparably broken structure has been allowed, for now at least, to remain.

headline: A Memorial Still Stands, but Barely
text: Since the tornado that cut through Joplin in May, several monuments have emerged. But as rebuilding continues, the community is wondering what to do with one that is, itself, rubble.

headline: Disruptions: Norelco on Takeoff? Fine. Kindle? No.
text: The Federal Aviation Administration has its reasons for preventing passengers from reading from their Kindles and iPads during takeoff and landing. But they just don’t add up.

headline: For One Day, the First, the Knicks Have Just Enough
text: There was joy again at Madison Square Garden on Sunday, a blend of holiday cheer, pent-up expectation and the thrill of the N.B.A.’s belated return after a long, strange off-season. The joy gave way to anxiety, then a bit of nastiness.

headline: The Netherlands: Court Releases Rwandan Rebel Leader
text: A Rwandan rebel leader was released Friday by the International Criminal Court in the Hague after almost a year in detention and returned to his home base in Paris, the court said. Callixte Mbarushimana, a former United Nations computer technician, had faced charges of war crimes and crimes against humanity but pre-trial judges threw out his case last week in a 2-1 decision, saying that the evidence against him was not sufficient to warrant a trial. Prosecutors appealed in vain this week to stop his release, saying he was the main political leader of the violent Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda. The rebel movement, which operates from a base in the Democratic Republic of Congo, has unleashed a terrorist campaign in the region which thousands of civilians have been raped and killed. He was the first person to be released by the international court.

headline: $42 Million Payday For Simon Cowell
text: “The X Factor” may have had relatively disappointing ratings in its first season, but the show generated a big payday for Simon Cowell, its creator, below. According to corporate filings in Britain Mr. Cowell made about $42 million through a deal with Sony last year that established a joint-venture company for his entertainment businesses, including “The X Factor,” The Guardian of London reported. For its 50-percent share in the company Sony paid about $49 million and turned over its ownership stakes in two of Mr. Cowell’s other entertainment properties. Mr. Cowell received $42 million of that money by handing over the shares of another company under his control. On Thursday, when Melanie Amaro, a 19-year-old from Florida, was crowned the first winner of “The X Factor,” 12.4 million viewers tuned in. That fell short of the 20 million that Mr. Cowell once predicted for the show.

headline: Demi Lovato Blasts Disney Over Jokes
text: The actress and singer Demi Lovato, who sought help last year for an eating disorder, criticized the Disney Channel, her former employer, on Friday over televised jokes about that condition. “Eating disorders are not something to joke about,” she wrote on Twitter in all-capital letters after hearing a character on the show “Shake It Up” say, “I could just eat you up, well, if I ate.” Ms. Lovato, right, was the star of the Disney Channel’s “Sonny With a Chance” until the spring, when she told People magazine that being in front of a camera “would make me nervous.” She is now concentrating on a music career. One of her fans told her about a similar comment made on “So Random,” which succeeded “Sonny With a Chance,” and Ms. Lovato shared it with 5.3 million followers. A Twitter account operated by Disney Channel replied to Ms. Lovato two hours later, “We hear you and are pulling both episodes as quickly as possible and re-evaluating them.” The channel’s account added, “It’s NEVER our intention to make light of eating disorders!”

headline: Tempting Targets for Itaú in 2012
text: Itaú Unibanco in Brazil bills itself as “the Global Latin American Bank.” Thing is, it’s not. Or at least, it’s not yet. That may change in the coming year. Itaú’s solid finances, robust market valuation, searing ambitions and a wealth of opportunities from the misfortunes of global rivals make it the bank to watch in 2012.

headline: Crystal Bridges
text: Images from the museum in Arkansas.

headline: The Muses of Insert, Delete and Execute
text: The literary history of the typewriter has its well-established milestones, from Mark Twain producing the first typewritten manuscript with “Life on the Mississippi” to Truman Capote famously dismissing Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road,” pounded out on a 120-foot scroll, with the quip “That’s not writing, that’s typing.”

headline: Young Artists, Playing With the Stars
text: Unlike students in most other fields, fledgling musicians never really take vacations from their training. They can’t. If they stop practicing for a few weeks simply because school is out, they will only need to work harder to get back in trim. Besides, setting aside their instruments is not, typically, what they want to do. Every winter about 60 musicians between 15 and 22 years old put their winter vacations to good use by coming to Manhattan for the New York String Orchestra Seminar, a 10-day program in which they are coached by a starry roster of soloists and chamber players.

headline: Fans’ Notes, Rapturous and Otherwise
text: Sports are like life, simplified. The rules are enforced instantly and on the spot. Winners are clearly declared. In the stadium there’s delightful relief from the real-world trial of sifting enemies from allies: if they’re wearing your team’s uniforms, they’re good guys.

headline: Under the Bouffant, a Sewer Mouth on Go-Go Wings
text: A once proud and subversive warrior tribe that deified freakdom, drag queens have become awfully mainstream. Tame transvestites are now passing for Kardashians, while biological women all over television are communing with their inner drag divas on shows like “Mad Fashion,” “RuPaul’s Drag U” and “The Real Housewives of You Name It.”

headline: The Less Obvious Defense Brought Victory in Bulgaria
text: The International Bridge Press Association gives annual awards for excellence both at the table and away from it. The winners receive a lot of publicity, but some of the deals that did not gather sufficient votes are worthy of print inches.

headline: Christmas Dinner in Baghdad
text: Members of The Times’s Baghdad Bureau — Tim Arango, Jack Healy and Michael Schmidt — made Christmas dinner for a group of fellow journalists, tweeting along the way. Here’s the holiday as tweeted; scroll down to the bottom of the post to read them from this morning onward.

headline: Dallas Celebrates Past; Miami Enjoys Present
text: DALLAS — Emotion etched on his face, Dirk Nowitzki appeared alone in his thoughts as he soaked in the moment. Delayed by the N.B.A. lockout, the Dallas Mavericks were unable to commemorate the franchise’s first title until Sunday, when they again held aloft the Larry O’Brien Trophy and raised their championship banner.

headline: Monday: Train That Doesn’t Skip a Stop
text: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — O.K., now that we’ve all finished our holiday meals and gingerbread cookies, it’s time to start burning some serious puzzle calories. I see you all out there, lazing on the couch. Sharpen those pencils! Take a lap! Get those knees up!

headline: A Year of Disappointment at the Movie Box Office
text: LOS ANGELES — With five days left in 2011, ticket sales in North America are running about $500 million behind last year — despite higher prices — prompting a round of soul searching by studios trying to determine what went wrong and how best to proceed.

text: While the rest of Europe’s big leagues are resting, teams play in Britain to bumper crowds this week because tradition, and demands of TV.

headline: No Auctions Set for This Week
text: In observance of the Christmas holiday, both the stock and bond markets will be closed on Monday. The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: A Village in Revolt Could Be a Harbinger for China
text: BEIJING — China’s state-run media have had a field day this autumn with Occupy Wall Street, spinning an almost daily morality play about capitalism gone amok and an American government unable or unwilling to aid the victims of a rapacious elite.

headline: Appearing Frail, Pope Offers Prayers for Peace on Christmas
text: ROME — Offering his annual Christmas Day message on the state of the world, Pope Benedict XVI on Sunday prayed for peace in the Middle East and Horn of Africa and offered prayers for flood victims in Southeast Asia.

headline: Afghanistan Low on News Agenda
text: The 10-year-old war in Afghanistan remained just a blip on the American news media’s radar in 2011.

headline: Knicks Photo Replay: Dec. 25
text: Carmelo Anthony scored 37 points, including two free throws with 16 seconds left, as the Knicks survived a seesaw season opener against the Celtics.

headline: In North Korean Mourning, Succession Clues
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea broadcast television footage on Sunday of the top military brass flanking the country’s young new leader, Kim Jong-un, as they paid respects to Mr. Kim’s father, who died of a heart attack on Dec. 17, and vowed allegiance to his chosen successor.

headline: The Art of the Possible: Christmas Dinner in Baghdad
text: BAGHDAD – Nobody can guarantee you a peaceful Christmas dinner in Iraq. Things explode. Riots break out. Angry politicians quit the government. As a reporter roosting in Baghdad over the holidays, all you can do is plan a menu, start cooking early and be ready to abandon your turkey if mayhem erupts.

headline: Monday Night Matchup: Falcons at Saints
text: Falcons (9-5) at Saints (11-3), 8:20 p.m. Eastern, ESPN

headline: A Welcome Change: Her Only Worry Is Her Dog
text: Marisol Santiago was worried about the hard, teardrop-shaped spot under her dog’s eye. The dog, Princess, is a schnauzer, and tends to get infections. Ms. Santiago, 42, cleans the spot each day with hot water and disinfectant, but cannot afford to take Princess to the veterinarian.

headline: In Beck’s Shadow, Rise of ‘The Five’
text: When Fox News and Glenn Beck broke up in June, the network’s chairman, Roger Ailes, knew he could not put any single man or woman in that 5 p.m. time slot, lest he or she be compared to Mr. Beck or be pummeled in the press if the ratings tumbled.

headline: In N.B.A., Games Begin, but Time Will Determine Who Won
text: The reality of the new N.B.A. season is a testament to a simple but profound truth learned the hard way by 435 players during a contentious lockout: progress depends on risk and sacrifice.

headline: Californian With an M.B.A. Follows His Heart to Brazilian Funk
text: NOVA IGUAÇU, Brazil — The train to this city on Rio de Janeiro’s edge carries passengers from the urban underclass chasing dreams big and small: teenagers trying out for a soccer club, a maid studying to be a nurse, a knife salesman plying his trade in the aisles.

headline: Rio Funk, American Style
text: Los Angeles native Alex Cutler left behind a life of American affluence to follow his dream in the funk music scene of Rio’s gritty slums.

headline: Robert Morvillo, Legal Pioneer, Dies at 73
text: Robert G. Morvillo, a prominent New York trial lawyer who pioneered the practice of white-collar criminal defense and whose client list included colorful celebrities, powerful politicians and billionaire businessmen, died on Saturday at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 73.

headline: Seeing City in Need, Southern Baptists Plan Growth
text: As a Southern Baptist, Freddy T. Wyatt knows he is a minority in New York. But, he said, that was exactly what prompted him to move to the city from Clarksville, Tenn.

headline: U.S. Firms See Opportunities in Europe’s Woes
text: As Europe struggles with its debt crisis, American businesses and financial firms are swooping in amid the distress, making loans and snapping up assets owned by banks there — from the mortgage on a luxury hotel in Miami Beach to the tallest office building in Dublin.

headline: Robert Ader, Who Linked Stress and Illness, Dies at 79
text: Dr. Robert Ader, an experimental psychologist who was among the first scientists to show how mental processes influence the body’s immune system, a finding that changed modern medicine, died on Tuesday in Pittsford, N.Y. He was 79.

headline: With Christmas Morning, the Rare Serenity of Long Ago
text: At 8 in the morning, a scrap of paper blew across an apocalyptic Times Square, and Costantino Gava, a tourist from Italy, stood amid an archipelago of abandoned red cafe tables. He looked about at the vast circus of neon lights winking allure at no one, and snapped another picture of the desolation.

headline: Falcons Have Had a Winning Strategy for Fitness
text: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga. — When Coy Wire signed with the Atlanta Falcons in 2008, he considered himself in the vanguard regarding fitness techniques.

headline: Christmas Morning
text: The stillness of the city on Christmas morning

headline: Cee Lo Strikes Gold, Without a Gold Album
text: Ducking through a crowd of tourists at Rockefeller Center, the singer Cee Lo Green took a breather during rehearsals for NBC’s annual tree-lighting concert on Nov. 30. But between a shopping detour at Swarovski Crystal and last-minute talks with the show’s producer, there wasn’t much time to rest.

headline: The Anti-Entitlement Strategy
text: Mitt Romney wants to stigmatize most “safety net” spending – the array of social insurance programs from Medicare to food stamps to unemployment compensation to free school lunches — as a form of welfare that is “cultivating government dependence.”

headline: Collapse by Lakers Gives Win to Bulls
text: LOS ANGELES — Longtime stars of N.B.A. Christmas programming, the Los Angeles Lakers left hearth and home for the 14th season in a row, sent into a colder world that no longer sees them as sprinkled with stardust.

headline: A Living Wage, Long Overdue
text: New York City provides hundreds of millions of dollars a year in taxpayer-financed subsidies to private developers. It is only right that the jobs created by those projects pay a decent wage. The Fair Wages for New Yorkers Act, widely known as the living-wage bill, would nudge these employers in the right direction.

headline: A Showcase for Stars and Big-Market Rivalries
text: Happy New Year, Knicks fans, even if it still is 2011. Your team’s resolution to be resourceful, tough and smart when it matters most was unwrapped in the final minutes of what felt like Game 5 against the Celtics on Sunday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Expanding Internet Domains
text: Come January, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers plans to allow businesses, nonprofits and others to apply for their own “top-level domain” with their own online suffix, like the familiar .com and .org suffixes that now rule the Internet.

headline: Manning Loses His Hot Hand, and Doesn’t Have Much Time to Find It
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Of all the questions lingering over the Giants as they prepare for a winner-take-all game against the Dallas Cowboys — including “will Coach Tom Coughlin need crutches on the sideline?” — the most critical one is obvious: which Eli Manning will show up Sunday night?

headline: Fairness for Home Care Aides
text: Evelyn Coke spent 20 years as a home care aide helping the elderly and the sick, but she did not live to see fair labor laws applied to her work.

headline: U.S. Prepares for a Curtailed Relationship With Pakistan
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — With the United States facing the reality that its broad security partnership with Pakistan is over, American officials are seeking to salvage a more limited counterterrorism alliance that they acknowledge will complicate their ability to launch attacks against extremists and move supplies into Afghanistan.

headline: Love on the Spectrum
text: Jack Robison and Kirsten Lindsmith, two college students living in Greenfield, Mass., discuss how autism affects their lives and relationship.

headline: Buckle Up on Buses
text: The curbside bus industry has become a booming inter-city phenomenon offering cheap fares in hard times — but also a crash fatality rate seven times that of mainline carriers based in terminals, where maintenance and safety checks are more common.

headline: Putin’s Children
text: IN the waning days of the Soviet Union, I spent a lot of time in a cluster of apartment towers along the Moscow River, contemplating what seemed to me an essential question about the future of our cold-war adversary: Could Russia grow an authentic middle class? Not a privileged class, favored wards of the state, but independent achievers who would be the engine and the evidence of upward mobility.

headline: Springtime for Toxics
text: Here’s what I wanted for Christmas: something that would make us both healthier and richer. And since I was just making a wish, why not ask that Americans get smarter, too?

headline: For Jets, Faint Hope and Ebbing Glory
text: Toward the end of his first year with the Jets, Rex Ryan offered what by now has become a familiar refrain — a bold, but incorrect, prediction. He proclaimed their season over after a crushing loss to Atlanta, but fortune smiled on the Jets, who benefited from an improbable confluence of events to make the playoffs.

headline: Hackers Breach the Web Site of Stratfor Global Intelligence
text: While the rest of the world engaged in merriment and good cheer, hackers used the holidays to attack a United States research group that puts out a daily newsletter on security issues.

headline: For Start-Ups That Aim at Giants, Sorting the Data Cloud Is the Next Big Thing
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The idea of big data goes something like this: In a world of ever-increasing digital connectivity, ever larger mountains of data are produced by our cellphones, computers, digital cameras, RFID readers, smart meters and GPS devices. The huge quantity of data becomes unwieldy and difficult for companies and governments to manage and understand.

headline: Baby Formula Is Called Safe
text: Mead Johnson Nutrition said on Sunday that tests it conducted on samples of its Enfamil baby formula tied to a Food and Drug Administration investigation found no presence of bacteria. The company called the product safe.

headline: Salt Lake's Superheroes
text: A band of self-proclaimed superheroes takes to Salt Lake City streets at night looking to fight crime, except, of course, when it’s too cold.

headline: Expansion Plans Divide School and Son of Its Former Headmaster
text: Each weekday morning, the headmaster of St. David’s School stands at the front door of the all-boys school on East 89th Street, heartily welcoming his students with a smile and firm handshake.

headline: Crusaders Take Page, and Outfits, From Comics
text: SALT LAKE CITY — Red Voltage and two of his masked crime-fighting colleagues were approaching an intersection here in Utah’s capital on a recent evening, walking night patrol on foot, when a car suddenly slowed next to them. The night was bitterly cold, laced with a wispy stew of fog that might or might not conceal a thousand dangers. The car’s window rolled down.

headline: Alliance Formed Secretly to Win Deal for Campus
text: The first secret meeting took place last March, in a place no one would suspect: Beijing. For the second, in July, they holed up in the Cornell Club of New York, rather than a hotel where they might be noticed by outsiders.

headline: Joseph Farrell, Who Used Market Research to Shape Films, Dies at 76
text: In the 1987 film “Fatal Attraction,” a psychopathic woman terrorizes a married man with whom she has had a one-night stand, making more and more threatening gestures toward him and his family until her violent demise becomes inevitable.

headline: 2011: The Year in Sports
text: Times editors and reporters share memories from the sporting year.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Memories From the Year in Sports
text: Reporters and editors for The Times recalled the people, teams and moments that made the past year memorable. Readers can share their favorite moments of the year below.

headline: Near Dallas, 7 Found Shot to Death Amid Their Unwrapped Gifts
text: Police officers responding to a silent call from someone who dialed 911 in a Dallas suburb on Sunday morning found seven people dead in an apartment, all shot shortly after opening their Christmas presents. The gunman, who was wearing a Santa suit, was among the dead, the police said, and the seven appeared to be related.

headline: N.B.A. Photo Replay: Dec. 25
text: A look at season-opening games played in Dallas, Los Angeles and Oklahoma City.

headline: Hamas Leader Leaves on Tour of Arab Nations to Seek Support
text: JERUSALEM — Ismail Haniya, the Hamas prime minister of Gaza, left the isolated Palestinian enclave on Sunday to seek regional support for his Islamic movement in his first foreign trip since uprisings spread across the Arab world a year ago.

headline: Corrections: December 26
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: A Watchdog for Conservative Ideals
text: PHOENIX — Clint Bolick looks like any other high-powered lawyer, for the most part. But glance down at his index finger, which sports a scorpion tattoo, for first-hand evidence of his unconventional streak.

headline: Slimming Down
text: DEAR DIARY:

headline: Paul Disowns Extremists’ Views but Doesn’t Disavow the Support
text: The American Free Press, which markets books like “The Invention of the Jewish People” and “March of the Titans: A History of the White Race,” is urging its subscribers to help it send hundreds of copies of Ron Paul’s collected speeches to voters in New Hampshire. The book, it promises, will “Help Dr. Ron Paul Win the G.O.P. Nomination in 2012!”

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/26/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/26/2011

headline: E-Reader Help From New York Public Library
text: Anticipating a flood of library patrons who received e-readers as holiday gifts, the New York Public Library will offer a free service for instructing users how to download e-books, library officials said. Free e-books are available for members of the New York Public Library and can be downloaded remotely without a visit to the library. Patrons can visit nypl.org/ebookcentral for instructions on downloading e-books and other digital materials, including video and music. The library will also offer in-person assistance from Jan. 4 to Jan. 13 at the Stephen A. Schwarzman Building and the Mid-Manhattan Library at 455 Fifth Avenue. Nearly 22,000 e-books are available at the New York Public Library, a number that has been growing rapidly along with the widespread adoption of e-readers.

headline: Navigating Love and Autism
text: GREENFIELD, Mass. — The first night they slept entwined on his futon, Jack Robison, 19, who had since childhood thought of himself as “not like the other humans,” regarded Kirsten Lindsmith with undisguised tenderness.

headline: Twofold Goal in Iowa for G.O.P. Hopefuls
text: The political universe in the coming week begins and ends with the borders of Iowa, where the six contenders for the Republican nomination will race toward the Jan. 3 caucuses. Their dual mission: persuasion and organization to lay the groundwork for a strong showing.

headline: Modernizing Attack Ads by Using Old Videos
text: It seemed innocuous enough at the time. The Democratic speaker of the House and one of her Republican predecessors cozy up on a love seat arranged for them at the bottom of Capitol Hill. They look into the camera, then at each other, and declare that they are really not all that different when it comes to caring about global warming.

headline: From Russia With Lightness
text: MOSCOW — Every night last week, writers, artists, actors, ad men, office managers and assorted others climbed the stairs to the fifth floor of a converted factory building in Moscow to make a statement. Pavel Bardin, a well-known young film director, had set up a camera in a conference room there. Everyone who came in — some by invitation, some having found out about the filming from friends or Facebook — wrote his or her name and vocation on a length of masking tape, and named his or her reason for planning to attend what would be a giant protest on Saturday, the 24th.

headline: Pain and Glory From Down Under
text: For an Indian fan, test cricket in Australia is about waking up at 5 a.m. in order to watch the first session of play with the television on mute so as to not wake the rest of the family. It is about watching the Boxing Day test match in Melbourne and soaking in the tradition even if it is from thousands of miles away. It is about wondering how something as ubiquitous as the wind can be called “the fremantle doctor” during test matches in Perth.

headline: In Shillong, Carols and Dohneiiong for Christmas
text: Christmas comes early in the northeastern city of Shillong, where traditional local food mixes with Christian carols and fruitcake for a unique holiday celebration.

headline: Complete N.F.L. Playoff Possibilities
text: Green Bay clinched home-field advantage throughout the N.F.C. playoffs with a victory over Chicago on Sunday night. The defeat knocked the Bears out of the playoffs and handed a playoff spot to Atlanta. Here are the up-to-date playoff possibilities after the game, via The Associated Press:

headline: U.S.: Roster Rumblings and Ramblings
text: Now that Jurgen Klinsmann has named his roster for the United States soccer team’s January training camp and for its two friendly matches against Venezuela and Panama, it’s time to roll up our sleeves, stare at the list and start reading between the lines.

headline: In London, a Taryn Simon Show Nears Its End
text: For four years, Taryn Simon traveled the world photographing 18 family bloodlines and their related stories. The resulting images document victims of genocide in Bosnia, a polygamist family in Kenya, the alleged body double of Saddam Hussein’s son, Uday, Filipino farmers and miners, children with no known bloodline from a Ukrainian orphanage, and many more.

headline: Utopian Capitalism
text: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

headline: Q&A: Finding a Port With Power
text: Q.

headline: Five Killed in Latest Baghdad Bombing
text: BAGHDAD — A suicide bomber driving a car packed with explosives attacked a checkpoint in front of the Iraqi Interior Ministry on Monday morning, killing 5, wounding 39 and roiling a country unsettled by a political crisis and a wave of deadly bombings just days ago.

headline: New North Korean Leader Meets South Koreans and Assumes Leadership of Party
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the new leader of North Korea, met Monday with a private delegation of prominent South Koreans, his first face-to-face encounter with any visitors from the estranged South since assuming the top spot a week ago when his father’s death was announced.

headline: Sony to Cease Its Flat-Screen Partnership With Samsung
text: TOKYO — In a bid to streamline its unprofitable television business, Sony said Monday that it would sell its stake in its flat-panel screen venture with Samsung Electronics, cutting its production capacity at a time when outsourcing has become the norm for manufacturers.

headline: Ex-Players Sue Over Concussions; Current Players Hide Them
text: “In a series of interviews about head injuries with The Associated Press over the last two weeks, 23 of 44 NFL players — slightly more than half — said they would try to conceal a possible concussion rather than pull themselves out of a game.”

headline: When Modernity Trumps Tradition
text: JOHANNESBURG — The Southern Africa Report recently ran a story alleging that as part of an annual ceremony called Incwala King Mswati III of Swaziland has sex with a bull beaten into semi-consciousness. I have no way of confirming the report. But it did serve to raise what is a very real issue in this part of the world: the clash between tradition and modernity.

headline: What Rex Ryan Said After the Jets-Giants Game
text: Reviewing Rex Ryan’s comments to reporters after the Jets lost to the Giants on Saturday.  The full transcript is below, via Jets.com.

headline: Crystal Bridges, the Art Museum Walmart Money Built, Opens
text: BENTONVILLE, Ark. — By just about any measure, the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art, which opened last month in this small town in northwest Arkansas, is off to a running start. The dream-come-true of Alice Walton, an heir to the Walmart fortune, it is characterized by people both inside and outside the museum as a work in progress, with plenty of room for improvement. But there it stands, a big, serious, confident, new institution with more than 50,000 square feet of gallery space and a collection worth hundreds of millions of dollars in a region almost devoid of art museums.

headline: China Jails Writer for Subversion
text: Chen Xi, a liberal Chinese writer, has been sentenced to 10 years in prison on a charge of inciting subversion of the state, according to reports by news agencies on Monday that cited Mr. Chen’s wife, Zhang Qunxuan.

headline: Japan Panel Cites Failure in Tsunami
text: TOKYO — From inspectors’ abandoning of the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant as it succumbed to disaster to a delay in disclosing radiation leaks, Japan’s response to the nuclear accident caused by the March tsunami fell tragically short, a government-appointed investigative panel said on Monday.

headline: The Best in Culture
text: A collection of the year’s best in art, dance, music and film.

headline: Celery Root-Potato Purée
text: Time: About 30 minutes

headline: For New Year’s, a Bit Fancy, but All Relaxed
text: THOUGH it can be great fun to go out for New Year’s Eve, this year I’m staying home. I’m not in the mood to fight the crowds, but I’ll happily cook for a small group of friends and celebrate around the table for hours.

headline: How to Celebrate at Home
text: There are many ways to celebrate New Year’s Eve, some pious, some raucous, no doubt everything in between. Festivities take place high above the twinkling city, in humble taverns, and in the street. (And there is always a meditative yoga option for those seeking purity and abstinence.)

headline: Path Is Cleared for Yemeni Leader to Get Care in U.S.
text: HONOLULU — The Obama administration has decided in principle to allow the embattled president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, to enter the United States for medical treatment, subject to certain assurances, two administration officials said Monday.

headline: Debt and Growth in the G7
text: I’ve written fairly often about the often-cited Reinhart/Rogoff claim that terrible things happen to economic growth if the ratio of debt to GDP exceeds 90 percent. It’s a claim that has been pretty thoroughly debunked – yet it continues to circulate among Very Serious People as a known fact. Anyway, I was looking at some debt data, and thought that it might be useful to look at debt of the major advanced economies since World War II, and see what gets picked out by the 90 percent criterion.

headline: A Visual Feast in an Undersea Twilight Zone
text: It was an extraordinary day for me. To understand why, it may be useful to explain a bit about my research. Using advanced closed-circuit mixed-gas rebreather technology, my colleagues and I have spent the past two decades traveling the tropical Pacific Ocean to to document life that occurs below the realm of scuba divers. The environment that I focus on — tropical reef habitats at depths of about 200 to 500 feet — has variously been referred to as deep coral reefs, mesophotic coral ecosystems and the coral-reef “Twilight Zone.”

headline: Syria Observers Urged to Hurry to Homs, Where Death Toll Keeps Rising
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — At least 30 people were killed in fighting in the rebellious Syrian city of Homs on Monday, spurring France to join with residents and opposition figures in urging observers from the Arab League to quickly visit the city.

headline: Monday Reading: Apps to Entertain Children  While Traveling
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: A Plan for 2012 That You’ll Actually Follow
text: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog. His new book, “The Behavior Gap,” will be out in January.

headline: The Best in Design
text: The best in design this year on The Moment blog.

headline: Discussion on Caste, Heated as Always
text: Writing about caste in India often generates a heated response, and “India’s Boom Creates Openings for Untouchables,” a recent article in The New York Times about successful Dalit, or “untouchable,” entrepreneurs, was no exception. Readers weighed in on social mobility in India today and the role caste continues to play in the country, often in stark and argumentative terms.

headline: Numberplay: Uncertain Return
text: ‘Tis the season to be grateful for the remarkable conversations we’ve had here at Numberplay — and for the creative and generous readers that make it all happen. Some of the most beautiful puzzles are ones that emerge in the middle of the week once things really get rolling. Here’s one of my favorites.

headline: Contaminated Milk Is Destroyed in China
text: BEIJING — China’s largest dairy company, the China Mengniu Dairy Company, says it has destroyed a batch of milk contaminated with a substance that can cause liver cancer.

headline: Dark Clouds Descend on Broadway (Can You See Any Glints of Silver?)
text: Sorry, Tiny Tim, there’s no getting around it: This week represents the beginning of one of the unhappiest seasons on Broadway, when struggling plays and musicals prepare to close once the tourists leave town. One show will finish on a high note – Hugh Jackman will conclude his limited run on Sunday with roughly $14 million in ticket sales in just 10 weeks – while others will end at a loss. The $6 million flop “Bonnie & Clyde” will close Friday without recouping any of its money and “The Addams Family” will exit on Saturday without earning back all of its $16.5 million capitalization.

headline: Rare but Grudging Judicial About-Face in Bias Case
text: “It’s a nice Christmas present, isn’t it?” said U. W. Clemon, Alabama’s first black federal judge.

headline: Romney Pushes Economic Agenda in New Ad
text: CHICAGO — Mitt Romney won’t arrive back in Iowa until Tuesday evening. But his campaign began the final week before the caucuses with a new television advertisement stressing his conservative economic credentials and promising to get rid of President Obama‘s health care program.

headline: Merry Christmas Roundup (Featuring Jenson’s Horrible Ad)
text: There is not much new in the world of Formula One racing, as the teams finally take a real break and prepare for the new year and the testing of new cars, which begins in February. This is when the media receives a slew of Christmas greetings from the teams and other F1 related people, like circuits and promoters. Now, then, is also the time for me to wish this blog’s readers a merry Christmas, and a thanks for another year of faithful readership.

Now, then, is also the time for me to wish this blog’s readers a merry Christmas, and a thanks for another year of faithful readership.

headline: La Churreria to Open in NoLIta
text: You cannot eat just two, or even four or five — skinny, crispy churros still warm from the fryer, that is. Though New York has no shortage of restaurants and street vendors offering these fluted fritters that are popular in Spain and Latin America, a new bakery, La Churreria, will specialize in them.

headline: Tiniest of Spiders Are Loaded With Brains
text: Tiny spiders have brains so large that they fill up their body cavities and extend into their legs, a new study reports.

headline: Bony ‘Sixth Toe’ Helps an Elephant’s Stance
text: Their feet may look like solid, flat-bottomed tree trunks, but elephants actually stand tiptoed, more like dogs or deer.

headline: Kings of the Track Share Traits With Speedy Cats
text: The foot and ankle structure of human sprinters resembles that of cheetahs and greyhounds, a new study reports.

headline: Shiny Patches in Maine’s Streambeds Are Bright Sign for Salmon
text: WASHINGTON COUNTY, Me. — Ernie Atkinson waded up Old Stream on a warm fall afternoon, peering through polarized sunglasses to scan the streambed. Before long, he pointed out a place where the bottom looked different.

headline: Israel Risks New Turkish Ire with Recognition of Armenian Genocide
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli Parliament on Monday held its first public debate on whether to commemorate the Turkish genocide of Armenians nearly a century ago, an emotionally resonant and politically fraught topic for Israel, founded on the ashes of the Holocaust and trying to salvage frayed ties with Turkey.

headline: Portraits of the Southwest in the Shadow of Drought
text: The intense, deep blue skies of the American Southwest, skies that have drawn painters and photographers for a century or more, are a product of the region’s extremely dry air.

headline: In Madrid’s Heart, Park Blooms Where a Freeway Once Blighted
text: MADRID — Even on a chilly Thursday afternoon in December, the old men, engulfed in cigar smoke and reading newspapers, were sitting around chess tables under tall pines. Nearby, a young woman had strung her line between the trunks of two mulberry trees to practice tightrope walking.

text: Images of the new park in Spain.
