headline: Lucky Foods to Ring in the New Year
text: I love the fact that beans, lentils and greens symbolize prosperity in the New Year in places as disparate as the American South and the South of France. I wonder if it’s really because lentils and beans are round like coins and swell when they cook, or if it’s because that’s about all anybody can afford to eat after the excesses of the holiday season.

headline: Science and Censorship: A Duel Lasting Centuries
text: “We have consultations, which of the inventions and experiences which we have discovered shall be published, and which not; and take all an oath of secrecy for the concealing of those which we think fit to keep secret; though some of those we do reveal sometime to the State, and some not.”

headline: Sodium-Saturated Diet Is a Threat for All
text: Maybe you think you don’t have to worry about salt. After all, you don’t have high blood pressure, you’re not overweight and you exercise regularly.

headline: Little Rascals in a Secret Garden
text: Researchers may have neglected middle childhood until recently, but authors and screenwriters have long revisited the grade school years in their work. Below, a sampling, compiled by Gregory Cowles, an editor at The New York Times Book Review.

headline: Lives Overlap on the Track in McCarren Park
text: Aristotle believed circular motion to be a distinguishing characteristic of perfection. If you have ever seen a world-class runner cruise around a track, you may well agree that a body curving in motion is a sight of beauty.

headline: The Hormone Surge of Middle Childhood
text: VIEWED superficially, the part of youth that the psychologist Jean Piaget called middle childhood looks tame and uneventful, a quiet patch of road on the otherwise hairpin highway to adulthood.

headline: Video: How to Shuck an Oyster
text: Bivalve purists would say the best thing to serve with freshly shucked oysters is absolutely nothing. The plump mollusks slide delightfully down the gullet dressed in their own juices, no embellishments needed.

headline: Graceful Moves, for a Boy Made of Metal
text: PHILADELPHIA — What makes an automaton tick?

headline: Your Favorite Quotes About Childhood
text: In today’s Science Times, Natalie Angier explores the science and the mystery of middle childhood, a time between toddlerhood and the teenage years when a young brain learns awareness, friendship and responsibility.

headline: Scenes From McCarren Park in Brooklyn
text: The track at McCarren Park, which is dear to the people of Greenpoint and Williamsburg, Brooklyn, caters to the needs of the physically curious, the committed and the compulsive.

headline: Risks: Blood Pressure Tests May Not Be Enough
text: A single blood pressure test, or even several readings over a short period of time, may not be enough to gauge the risk of developing cardiovascular disease.

headline: Prevention: Beer and Martinis: As Healthy as Wine?
text: Many studies have found an association between the moderate consumption of alcohol and increased longevity, and some have found evidence that wine has a more beneficial effect than other alcoholic drinks.

headline: Gingrich Unlikely to Get on Virginia Ballot
text: 6:03 p.m. | Updated  Continuing to smart from its failure to get on the primary ballot in Virginia, Newt Gingrich‘s campaign said it would explore ways to persuade the Republican Party of Virginia to bend its rules and allow Mr. Gingrich and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who also failed to qualify, to join the only two names now on the ballot: Mitt Romney and Ron Paul.

headline: Recalling a Trip to North Korea Before the Death of Kim Jong-il
text: Mun Ho-yong placed the bouquet of flowers at the foot of the towering outdoor portrait of Kim Il-sung, the founder of North Korea. Then he turned to the Chinese businesspeople and tourists, and to the foreign journalists. “Now please bow to our leader,” he said.

headline: A Note On The Ricardian Equivalence Argument Against Stimulus (Slightly Wonkish)
text: There have been a lot of shockingly bad performances among macroeconomists in this crisis; but if I had to pick the one that is most startling, it is the way freshwater economists have demonstrated that they don’t understand one of their own doctrines, that of Ricardian equivalence.

headline: Patterns: HPV Vaccine Is Not Linked to Promiscuity
text: A survey has found that girls ages 15 to 19 who are vaccinated against human papillomavirus, or HPV, are no more likely to be sexually active or to have more partners than unvaccinated girls.

headline: In Blow to Government, Sadr Followers Call for New Elections
text: BAGHDAD — A powerful political group led by the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr called on Monday for Parliament to be dissolved and early elections to be held, the first open challenge to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki from within his Shiite coalition in an escalating political crisis.

headline: U.S. Report Faults NATO Delays on Pakistan Strike
text: WASHINGTON — A military investigation has concluded that it took about 45 minutes for a NATO operations officer in Afghanistan to notify a senior allied commander about Pakistan’s calls that its outposts were under attack, one of several breakdowns in communication that contributed to airstrikes that killed 26 Pakistani soldiers last month.

headline: Playoffs? Some Battling for No. 1 Pick
text: Three playoff spots, and numerous seedings, will be determined on the final day of the regular season Sunday. But for a longer-term effect on the N.F.L., look to the otherwise meaningless game between the Jacksonville Jaguars and the Indianapolis Colts.

headline: The Toughest Seed
text: Q. How can plant seeds — tomatoes, for example — survive the digestive processes of birds and other animals and thus be spread in their droppings?

headline: Eighteenth-Century Play to Get First North American Performance
text: “The London Merchant,” a tragedy from 1731 that was one of the first British dramas to focus on the middle and working classes – and that has apparently never received a professional production in North America – will be performed Jan. 6-28 at the Theater at the Church of Notre Dame in Morningside Heights in Upper Manhattan. Written by George Lillo, “The London Merchant” is about the downfall of a young apprentice who is led astray by a prostitute. It was highly popular in the 18th century. The Storm Theater Company and Blackfriars Repertory Theater will jointly produce the work, directed by Peter Dobbins, Storm’s artistic director. A spokesman for the production, Pete Sanders, said on Monday that the producers had done research on the history of the play and could not find evidence that it had been performed professionally in the United States or Canada.

headline: Killing on Oxford Street Mars Boxing Day in London
text: The annual British day of bargain-hunting was cut short in London on Monday, as a young man in London was stabbed to death just after noon.

headline: ‘Wonderful Life’ Lifts NBC in Holiday Ratings
text: Television programming has its own holiday traditions, and they were reflected in the Nielsen ratings over the weekend. An encore telecast on NBC of “It’s a Wonderful Life,” the 65-year-old Christmas stalwart, was the No. 1 program in all ratings categories on Saturday, with 4.6 million total viewers. It was the most-watched film on any of the broadcast networks since April.

headline: Malaria: World Health Organization Says Deaths Have Dropped 25 Percent in Last Decade
text: Malaria deaths have fallen by more than 25 percent in the last decade, thanks to a coordinated attack on the disease, but that progress remains fragile, the World Health Organization announced this month.

headline: Faceless
text: Dori Frame has a neurological disorder called prosopagnosia. She cannot recognize human faces, and even close friends and relatives can look unfamiliar to her.

headline: Have We Met? Tracing Face Blindness to Its Roots
text: Close your eyes. Picture your closest friend. Maybe you see her blue eyes, long nose, brown hair. Perhaps even her smile.

headline: Preliminary Returns and Concerns for Contending Teams
text: Any self-proclaimed N.B.A. contender can piece together an effective starting lineup, but several of the teams gunning for the league’s top tier face serious issues with their benches. Now that the season has officially begun, those depth concerns shift out of the hypothetical realm and become the harsh reality for teams on the cusp. Thanks to a helter-skelter schedule, depth is more important than ever, and teams like the Lakers, Clippers, Celtics and Knicks will have to find ways to balance their strong starting lineups with unremarkable reserves.

headline: A World Without Faces
text: Imagine being unable to recognize your children or your closest friend. You can see their faces perfectly fine, but if you passed them on the street you wouldn’t be able to place their unique eyes, nose and ears.

headline: Patient Voices: Multiple Sclerosis
text: What is it like to be told you have a disease that may rob you of your sight and ability to walk? Eight men and women speak about life after a diagnosis of MS.

headline: New Drugs Raise Hope for Patients With M.S.
text: Three years ago, Kristie Salerno Kent, a singer-songwriter, was standing in a security line at the airport on her way home from a gig when her legs went numb. “From the waist down, it felt as though I was trying to walk through a bowl of oatmeal,” said the 38-year-old musician, who has multiple sclerosis.

headline: Poisoning Kills More Than Car Crashes
text: In 2008, for the first time in nearly 30 years, more people died of poisoning than in car crashes. Poisoning is now the leading cause of injury death, and 90 percent of poisonings were caused by drugs.

headline: Poof to Life as You Knew It
text: Based on the admittedly flimsy evidence of films like “The Darkest Hour,” the best defense against invading aliens is to be as attractive as possible. Being one-dimensional doesn’t hurt, either, even if that particular character flaw can be safely blamed on whoever is responsible for the screenplay — in this case, Jon Spaihts. Given that he is also one of two writers credited on Ridley Scott’s much anticipated 2012 film (and possible “Alien” prequel) “Prometheus,” it is to be hoped that his lazy ideas were not equally apportioned between the two projects.

headline: Scholars Retract Another Study Linking Virus to Fatigue Syndrome
text: For the second time in a week, a key study suggesting a link between a retroviral infection and chronic fatigue syndrome has been retracted.

headline: Tough Choices This Hanukkah (Holiday) Season
text: Last Tuesday was the first night of Hanukkah, and my 14-year-old son sang in his all-male high school’s holiday concert. When my children were enrolled full-time in a Jewish day school, they would head to the gold-domed State House in Boston and perform an annual Hanukkah concert. Every year the same tin-eared politician would lurch forward with a boxer’s stance and proclaim, “When you shake my hand, wish me a Merry Christmas instead of a happy holiday!”

headline: Mechanical Memory
text: The Maillardet automaton’s motions are controlled by dozens of slowly rotating brass disks. These disks contain all the data necessary for its lifelike movement and drawings — in effect, they serve as a mechanical form of read-only memory.

headline: A Rapper’s Regional Appeal and an Actress’s Musical Birthright
text: WEBBIE

headline: Nigeria Arrests 2 in Blast That Killed 26 in Church
text: LAGOS, Nigeria — As Nigerian officials announced arrests Monday in connection with the deadly bombing of a church on Christmas Day, American officials and analysts said the violence underscored the increasing ability of a shadowy Islamist insurgency to carry out complex strikes against multiple targets, complicating the fight against it.

headline: A Look Back, and Ahead, at Pemberley
text: Pemberley, Jane Austen fans will recall, is the large Derbyshire estate owned by Fitzwilliam Darcy, who weds Elizabeth Bennet at the end of “Pride and Prejudice,” and in “Death Comes to Pemberley,” P. D. James’s surprising new sequel to that novel, it becomes the scene of a murder.

headline: Israel TV Station’s Troubles Reflect a Larger Political Battleground
text: JERUSALEM — An Israeli television station reported last spring on numerous trips Benjamin Netanyahu had taken as an elected official to Paris, London and New York before becoming prime minister in 2009. Accompanied by his wife, he flew first class and stayed in baronial hotel suites. Mrs. Netanyahu had her hair styled and her wardrobe dry-cleaned. The bills, displayed on screen, were paid for by wealthy friends.

headline: The Name Is Distinctive, But the Role Is Generic
text: LOS ANGELES — “How to Rock,” a forthcoming series on Nickelodeon, follows a simple rule for children’s television: if it’s not broken, then copy it.

headline: Bard College Names New Theater Director
text: Bard College has announced that Gideon Lester, a former associate artistic director of the American Repertory Theater, will succeed JoAnne Akalaitis as its director of theater programs, a position that will expand under Mr. Lester to include taking productions to its Fisher Center for the Performing Arts and the Bard SummerScape festival there. Ms. Akalaitis, a longtime director of experimental productions and a former artistic director of the Public Theater in New York, is stepping down as head of the theater department after 14 years. Mr. Lester, now co-curator of the Crossing the Line arts festival in New York, teaches at Columbia University.

headline: Helping Immigrants Get the Lawyers They Need
text: To the Editor:

headline: Poverty and Obesity
text: To the Editor:

headline: Indian Pt. and Fukushima: Alike or Not?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Free-Spirited Invention With Instruments Centuries Old
text: You can count on Frederick Renz and the musicians of his Early Music New York to offer a Christmas program unlike anything else the city’s music world has to offer. Some years it is a theatrical piece, like Mr. Renz’s reconstruction of the 12th-century “Play of St. Nicholas”; in others, like this one, it draws on rarely heard sacred works, carols and instrumental pieces from across Europe, presented in an orderly procession that traces changing approaches to the Christmas story and the evolution of Western harmonic and rhythmic practice.

headline: S.&P., on Credit Risk
text: To the Editor:

headline: Penny-Wise and No Fools in Stores
text: On Monday, the day after Christmas, TLC’s cameras were cruising Forever 21, Lane Bryant and GameStop stores in Florida and California for a future episode of recession-era entertainment: “Extreme Couponing.”

headline: Pakistan Prime Minister Says No Plans to Dismiss Military Chiefs
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani on Monday denied news reports that he was planning to dismiss the country’s army and intelligence commanders in the aftermath of tensions that have emerged over a controversial memo that claims the civilian government had sought American help in constraining the powerful Pakistani military.

headline: Graphic: Going Negative in Iowa
text: The run-up to the Iowa caucuses has seen deeply negative advertising. Some Republican presidential candidates, particularly Ron Paul and Rick Perry, are spending heavily to criticize their opponents and President Obama. Outside groups, like the “super PACs” that support certain candidates, and independent groups, like Crossroads GPS, are also doing their part.

headline: Turtles Show Way to Prosperity
text: The turtles in a large aquarium in a Midtown window often bring passers-by to a halt, even those used to seeing the unexpected.

headline: Don’t Go After Military Pensions
text: Washington

headline: Santorum Hunts for Birds and an Endorsement, but Leaves Disappointed
text: ADEL, Iowa — Wearing blaze orange, including a cap stamped with the letters “N.R.A.,” Rick Santorum announced on Monday that he had failed to meet expectations during a pheasant hunt with one of Iowa’s leading conservative legislators.

headline: Political Struggle in Congress Delayed, Not Resolved
text: WASHINGTON — When Congress handily passed a bill to set payroll tax rates, jobless benefits and Medicare doctors’ fees for the next two months, it seemed to end an epic political struggle between President Obama and Republicans on Capitol Hill. In fact, that was just the beginning.

headline: In New Ad, Perry Attacks His Rivals for Serving in Congress
text: Rick Perry, the governor of Texas, released a new ad on Monday as the Republican primary campaign began to ramp up again after the holiday.

headline: Want a New You? Change Your Name
text: IN June, my band performed at a party at a Lower East Side boutique that specialized in wool ankle cuffs and sheer tunics. A few weeks later, we were playing in Brooklyn when a man approached me and said, “I just thought you might like to know that a friend I brought to your last show changed her name to Alina Simone.”

headline: Rangers’ Staal, Still Battling Concussion, Is Cleared for Contact
text: Defenseman Marc Staal, who continues to recover from a concussion after a clean, but vicious, hit by his brother Eric on Feb. 22, was cleared for contact and took hits during the Rangers’ practice Monday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: Midlife Crisis Economics
text: The members of the Obama administration have many fine talents, but making adept historical analogies may not be among them.

headline: TV Prices Fall, Squeezing Most Makers and Sellers
text: It’s a great time to buy a television, and Ram Lall, a television salesman, isn’t happy about it. In a basement showroom of J&R, the huge electronics store in Lower Manhattan, Mr. Lall says the days of making big money from televisions are in the past. Pointing to a top-of-the line, 55-inch Sony television, Mr. Lall said it would have sold for $6,000 a few years ago. The current price? $2,599.

headline: Keeping Students From the Polls
text: Next fall, thousands of students on college campuses will attempt to register to vote and be turned away. Sorry, they will hear, you have an out-of-state driver’s license. Sorry, your college ID is not valid here. Sorry, we found out that you paid out-of-state tuition, so even though you do have a state driver’s license, you still can’t vote.

headline: Markets Rise While Dollar Loses Ground
text: Among the stock markets that were open worldwide on Monday, most climbed, while the dollar maintained losses against higher-yielding peers amid speculation that the United States economy would continue to recover.

headline: Law to Find Tax Evaders Denounced
text: Legislation meant to help the United States government locate overseas assets of American tax cheats created little stir when it was quietly slipped into a jobs bill last year.

headline: A Push to Tie New Drugs to Testing
text: ChemGenex Pharmaceuticals found out the hard way how important it is to have a trustworthy companion.

headline: In China, Power in Nascent Electric Car Industry
text: GUANGZHOU, China — Three years ago, as part of its green-energy policy, the Chinese government set an ambitious goal: by the end of 2011, the nation would be able to produce at least 500,000 hybrid or all-electric cars and buses a year.

headline: In Europe, Securities Overseer Spreads Gospel of Streamlined Regulation
text: PARIS — Steven Maijoor, the chairman of Europe’s new securities regulator, has been piling up the frequent flier miles.

headline: Dealing With China’s Troubles
text: China’s economy seems to be in trouble, which could be a very big problem for the world unless China’s leaders and trading partners ensure that economic strains in the world’s largest exporting nation do not lead to trade confrontations around the globe.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Social Media in the 16th Century and Online Piracy
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors found on the Web over the holiday weekend. The full list is at the right.

headline: After 123 Years, Manischewitz Creates Kosher Food for Gentiles
text: IN recent years, Jews who keep kosher rejoiced when popular foods that had been off-limits gained kosher certification, from Oreo cookies in 1997 to the Tootsie Roll in 2009.

headline: For Jackson, Leading Warriors, Not Knicks, Was Meant to Be
text: Just before the tip-off of his first game as Golden State’s coach on Christmas night, Mark Jackson looked behind him and spotted his children. Then he looked across the floor and saw his wife.

headline: As Inquiry Widens, Comptroller Is Busy Showing That All Is Calm
text: By most accounts, John C. Liu, once considered a top contender for mayor in 2013, has been badly damaged by the federal investigation into whether illegal donations were funneled into his campaign treasury. But one would never know it watching him go about his days.

headline: A Range With Unwelcome Moving Targets
text: The live training exercises that take place on a nearly two-million-acre bombing range prepare military pilots for battle, but can be halted by illegal immigrants trying to cross the nearby border from Mexico.

headline: Strafing Mock Targets, but Holding Fire, Too
text: BARRY M. GOLDWATER RANGE, Ariz. — It was like a scene out of Iraq, back when American fighter jets crisscrossed the skies there, or out of Afghanistan, where air-to-ground combat continues. But the F-16 fighter jets that roared across the desert the other day with bombs exploding underneath them were, in fact, over Arizona.

headline: As Indonesia Grows, Discontent Sets in Among Workers
text: JAKARTA — As a flare-red sun set, a group of laborers in their 20s and 30s gathered on the bare floor of a battered house wedged beneath power lines in an industrial part of Jakarta. They were members of a confederation of multisector workers, one of the largest trade unions in Indonesia, whose slogan is “Young, brave, militant.”

headline: A Member of the House Who Rents Out Rooms
text: Among her colleagues, Representative Carolyn B. Maloney is known as a fiery liberal from Manhattan, a rebel and a bit of a showman (she once appeared on the House floor in a burqa to draw attention to the mistreatment of women in Afghanistan).

headline: Airlines Are Retrenching, and Alternatives Are Slim
text: THE coming year will be a time of reckoning in business travel, as airlines reduce service at many airports and prospects fade for practical alternatives to flying, including the long-term promises of high-speed rail.

headline: The Military Mind’s Take on Civilian Flights
text: I ACTUALLY enjoy business trips. I really like not being in charge or in control. I can get work done, read a book, or just sit and think without being disturbed. Even though I’m the chief executive of a software company, I almost never fly first class or business class. I’m a coach guy. If I get an upgrade, don’t get me wrong, I’ll take it. But most of the time I’m sitting in the back of the plane.

headline: Year That Began Like a Dirge for San Diego’s Organist Ends in Joy
text: SAN DIEGO — On the best days, loyal fans say, it is possible to hear the thundering organ three miles away. Weighing nearly 100,000 pounds with more than 4,500 pipes, it is nearly the largest outdoor organ in the world.

headline: Citigroup May Yet Benefit Its Investors
N.B.A.’s Opening Games Bring High TV Ratings
text: Four of the N.B.A.’s five Christmas games generated higher viewership this year over last year, perhaps not a surprise because they opened the lockout-shortened season.

headline: Airfares With Less Fine Print
text: Advertisements that make airfares seem enticingly low will soon lose that asterisk pointing to a dense paragraph of additional taxes and fees that make a cheap ticket much more costly.

headline: Million-Dollar Visas
text: The federal government’s investor visa, created in 1990, gives foreigners a chance at green cards if they invest $1 million to build a business in the United States that creates at least 10 jobs. Investing in an area with high unemployment would cut that price in half.

headline: Clearer Bank Account Terms
text: Consumer advocates are rightly pressuring the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to require banks to disclose important terms on checking accounts like the monthly fee in easy-to-understand forms. JPMorgan Chase has voluntarily adopted a new, straightforward disclosure policy. Other banks that have been resisting this policy should follow Chase’s lead.

headline: Teetering Jets Lament Lack of Balance on Offense
text: Get past Rex Ryan’s bluster, all those proclamations and pronouncements, and what endures is a mantra he has long preached: players and coaches are judged on wins and losses.

headline: Ship’s Espresso-Fueled Mission: Laying Cables Beneath the Hudson
text: For several minutes on Thursday, Al Figueroa was up to his neck in mud nearly 70 feet below the swift-moving surface of the Hudson River.

headline: One Game In, Knicks Seek Extra Players
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — One game into the truncated 66-game season, with the Knicks already hampered by injuries, Coach Mike D’Antoni was asked Monday about the possibility of Nate Robinson’s return to the team to help out at the guard spot.

headline: The Old Order Changeth
text: I will not be attending the Modern Language Association meeting in Seattle (Jan. 5-8), but I have read through the program to see what’s going on and what’s no longer going on in literary studies.

headline: Whose Tea Party Is It?
text: Newt Gingrich’s brief turn as presidential front-runner was only the latest paroxysm of a tumultuous Republican primary season. What’s going on? Tensions within the Tea Party help explain the volatility of the Republican primary campaign, as candidates seek to appeal to competing elements of the Tea Party with varying success.

headline: In Fire’s Rubble, Signs of Grandfather’s Last Heroic Act
text: After a career dedicated to keeping others safe, Lomer Johnson was happy to indulge another passion in retirement: dressing up as a department store Santa, heeding the wishes of children, even if he could not always fulfill them.

headline: Andrew Geller, Modernist Architect, Is Dead at 87
text: Andrew Geller, an architect who embodied postwar ingenuity and optimism in a series of inexpensive beach houses in whimsical shapes, many of them in the Hamptons, and who helped bring modernism to the masses with prefabricated cottages sold at Macy’s, died on Sunday in Syracuse. He was 87 and lived in Spencer, N.Y.

headline: Economic Downturn Took a Detour at Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — When Representative Ed Pastor was first elected to Congress two decades ago, he was comfortably ensconced in the middle class. Mr. Pastor, a Democrat from Arizona, held $100,000 or so in savings accounts in the mid-1990s and had a retirement pension, but like many Americans, he also owed the banks nearly as much in loans.

headline: Documents Appear to Contradict Gingrich’s Account of First Divorce
text: New court documents that have emerged seem to contradict Newt Gingrich’s account of how his first marriage ended. On his campaign Web site, under the heading “Answering the Attacks,’’ the Gingrich campaign maintains that it was his first wife, Jackie Battley Gingrich, the mother of the couple’s two daughters, who sought a divorce in 1980.

headline: Glass’s Road to Redemption
text: Early next week, a lawyer will file a brief with the California Supreme Court, arguing that his client has the good moral character to be admitted to the California bar. His client is Stephen Glass.

headline: A Soldier in the West
text: A force of Creek and Seminole warriors emerged from rugged hills in Indian Territory and fanned out across frozen Texas ground on Christmas Day 1861. They formed a long line and watched, quietly from a distance, as newly arrived Confederate soldiers pitched tents and organized camp in the bitter cold.

headline: Lynn Samuels, a Brash Radio Talker, Dies at 69
text: Lynn Samuels, whose brash political opinions and unrestrained New York accent made her an unmistakable voice in the male-dominated world of political talk radio, died on Saturday at her apartment in Woodside, Queens. She was 69.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Fiscal Crisis Takes Toll on Health of Greeks
text: PERAMA, Greece — The free clinic here opened about a year ago to serve illegal immigrants. But these days, it is mostly caring for Greeks like Vassiliki Ragamb, who was sitting in the waiting room hoping to get insulin for her young diabetic son.

headline: Greece’s Deep Cuts
text: As Greece is forced to make steep spending cuts, many families are falling into poverty and face losing healthcare coverage.

headline: Toughness of Coughlin Rubs Off on Giants
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — After running back D. J. Ware crashed into Tom Coughlin’s left leg in the Giants’ victory over the Jets on Saturday, the Giants players reminded Coughlin of a saying he has used to motivate them, “No toughness, no championships.”

headline: An Unusual Straight Talker Is Back in Good Voice and Looking at City Hall
text: Long ago, as a young reporter in the depths of the 1991 recession, I was assigned to cover the release of the mayor’s management report, that bible of all things municipal.

headline: Tuesday: Start of a Cry by Juliet
text: TUESDAY’S PUZZLE — The artist Winslow Homer was a 19th-century American landscape and maritime painter who began his career as a magazine illustrator and lithographer. Eventually, his interests expanded to both oil and watercolor painting, and his success was so great that he was able to give up his illustration career and paint full time. His most famous works captured the lives of the men and women who worked near the seaside, as well as children at play.

headline: Currency Agreement for Japan and China
text: BEIJING — China and Japan have agreed to start direct trading of their currencies, officials announced during a visit here on Monday by Japan’s prime minister, Yoshihiko Noda.

headline: Easing Restrictions on Gun Permits
text: States across the country have made it easier for people to obtain permits to carry concealed guns

headline: A 9th-Grade Dropout Returns to School
text: Reading her notes on the No. 3 train, Tamara Gonzalez did all she could to push the doubts out, out, out of her mind. Yes, it was only a quiz, but it had been a while since she had taken one. And then there was the matter of her “advanced” age.

headline: Kazakhstan: President Fires Son-in-Law
text: The president of Kazakhstan, Nursultan Nazarbayev, who has appointed several relatives to government jobs in the Central Asian nation, fired his son-in-law Monday from one of them: manager of the country’s sovereign wealth fund. Timur Kulibayev, who is married to Mr. Nazarbayev’s second daughter, lost his job after at least 16 people died in violence between striking oil workers and the police this month.

headline: Afghanistan to Disband Irregular Police Force Set Up Under NATO
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — President Hamid Karzai has taken steps to disband a little-known, irregular police force financed by the American military with members in at least four northern provinces. Some members of the force are former militiamen and thugs known as much for extorting money from ordinary citizens as for intimidating insurgents and upholding the law.

headline: Nets Begin Rebuilding Project With a Win
text: WASHINGTON — Symbolic of a transition year, the Nets opened their season on Monday night with an up-and-down performance.

headline: Guns in Public, and Out of Sight
text: Alan Simons was enjoying a Sunday morning bicycle ride with his family in Asheville, N.C., two years ago when a man in a sport utility vehicle suddenly pulled alongside him and started berating him for riding on the highway.

headline: Rangers Blank Islanders for Fifth Straight Victory
text: The puck skipped across the ice Monday to Rangers defenseman Michael Del Zotto, who looked up and saw only Islanders forward Frans Nielsen standing in front of him. Suddenly, Nielsen was behind Del Zotto, who spun Nielsen around as if he were Dorothy Hamill.

headline: A Growing Divide Between Congress and Constituents
text: Members of Congress experienced a 15 percent jump in net worth from 2004 to 2010.

headline: Romo Is Feeling Better, So Dallas Is, Too
text: IRVING, Tex. — Swelling remained in quarterback Tony Romo’s bruised right hand Monday, and the Dallas Cowboys, while optimistic, said they were not sure if he would practice Wednesday.

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/27/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/27/2011

headline: Debate Persists on Deadly Flu Made Airborne
text: The young scientist, normally calm and measured, seemed edgy when he stopped by his boss’s office.

headline: G.O.P. Race Still Unsettled in Sprint to Iowa Caucus
text: DES MOINES — Mitt Romney and his allies are making an assertive final push this week to increase his chances of a strong finish in the Iowa caucuses, the outcome of which could help determine the length of the Republican presidential nominating battle.

headline: How Can Romney Lose?
text: The conventional wisdom on the Republican nomination race has once again shifted. In the span of just two weeks, Mitt Romney has gone from seeming quite vulnerable to the near-inevitable Republican nominee. The odds attributed to Mr. Romney winning the nomination at the betting market Intrade, which closed at a low of 42 percent on Dec. 13, had shot up to 72 percent as of Monday night.

headline: The Whole Family Under One Roof?
text: What's so bad about adult children moving back in with their parents?

headline: Shifting Debate Over Lokpal
text: Today the lower house of Parliament begins what is expected to be a very passionate debate on the Lokpal Bill, which would create an anti-corruption ombudsman.

headline: Madrid Río
text: Images of the new park in Spain.

headline: Emerging Freedoms in Myanmar
text: Paula Bronstein has been traveling to Myanmar to take photographs for almost 20 years, so she’s accustomed to the feeling that she was being followed everywhere. Mind you, it’s not paranoia when you’re actually being followed .

headline: 11 Detained Over Attack at a Store in London
text: LONDON — Eleven people between 16 and 22 years old were in custody on Tuesday after a fatal stabbing 24 hours earlier shut down London’s main shopping street during one of its busiest days of the year, a move that prompted frustrated consumers to surge against police lines and a police officer to fire a stun gun.

headline: North Korea Asks South to Restore Deal to Spur Investment
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Tuesday that it wanted to restore scuttled agreements with South Korea that could channel extensive investments from the developed South into the impoverished North. The request was conveyed in the first official interaction with visitors from the South since the death of the North’s leader, Kim Jong-il.

headline: As Jan. 1 Application Deadline Nears, an Argument for a Yearlong Breather
text: Robert Clagett is a former dean of admissions at Middlebury College and former senior admissions officer at Harvard College.

headline: Top 10 N.F.L. Trends on the Field
text: The problem with many  “Top 10 Stories of the Year” articles is that they focus on drama and hype. Reading about Ndamukong Suh’s stomping incident or the Jim Schwartz-Jim Harbaugh postgame scuffle or the public’s reaction to Tim Tebow is entertaining, but it won’t make anyone a smarter football fan. For those who prefer analysis, here are the top 10 trends and developments that took place between the sidelines in the N.F.L. this season.

headline: In Berlin, Urban Spas to Combat the Winter Chill
text: Berlin’s harsh winters can chill its residents to the bone, and the decrease in daylight hours can render the season truly grueling. To fend off the depression that the season can bring, Berliners find a respite in the city’s saunas and public bathhouses. The following are distinctive yet each carries Berlin’s own brand of cool:

headline: How Politics Came to Dominate Payroll Tax Debate
text: Bruce Bartlett held senior policy roles in the Reagan and George H.W. Bush administrations and served on the staffs of Representatives Jack Kemp and Ron Paul. He is the author of the coming book “The Benefit and the Burden: Tax Reform – Why We Need It and What It Will Take.”

headline: Q&A: Another Way to Restart TiVo
text: Q.

headline: Lower House of Indian Parliament Passes Anticorruption Measure
text: NEW DELHI — After a day of high political theater, India’s Parliament moved closer on Tuesday to passing landmark legislation to create an independent anticorruption agency, even as the activist Anna Hazare sought to rally public support for his own anticorruption demands by beginning a three-day hunger strike in Mumbai.

headline: Japan Recommends Temporary State Control for Tokyo Electric
text: TOKYO — The Japanese government told the operator of the ravaged Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant on Tuesday to consider accepting temporary state control in return for a much-needed injection of public funds, in effect proposing an interim nationalization of the struggling utility.

headline: This Year in Small Business: The Best Reads
text: Until I started writing this weekly column, I never realized how many things can affect my small business. And I never realized how many smart people there are writing about and interpreting these things to try to help people like me better understand them. Of all of the pieces I reviewed this year, here are the best.

headline: Challenges Emerge as Arab League Observers Begin Work in a Syrian City
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A team of observers from the Arab League traveled to the embattled Syrian city of Homs on Tuesday in a visit that quieted days of fierce violence but also provided hints of the potential challenges of a group trying to monitor a withdrawal of the government’s security forces in towns across the country.

headline: Parliament Kicks Off ‘Fight of the Year’
text: India’s Parliament kicked off “the year’s capstone political fight” on Tuesday with the Parliamentary discussion of the Lokpal Bill, Jim Yardley and Vikas Bajaj write in The New York Times.

headline: Philippine Floods Put Popular Leader to Test
text: Shortly after more than 1,200 people were killed in one of the worst disasters in recent Philippine history, the glamorous starlet Valerie Concepcion cooed about President Benigno S. Aquino III, who is affectionately known as P-Noy.

headline: The View from Penn State: A Scandal, a Fight, and a Bowl Game to Play
text: 9:09 a.m. | Updated Between an intra-team fight and a $5.17 theft, in addition to the scandal surrounding the university, Penn State has a whole lot of distractions in its way as it prepares to face a high-powered Houston offense.

headline: 340-Ton Sculpture Versus Immovable Bureaucracy
text: LOS ANGELES — There was a time when what has become known here simply as the Rock — the 340-ton boulder that the Los Angeles County Museum of Art is installing as a major piece of outdoor art — was supposed to begin its nine-day trip from a quarry in Riverside, Calif., in August. With little fanfare, that date slipped until September. And then October. And now ... .

text: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)
