headline: Frustration and Hope at Hazare’s Fast in Mumbai
text: Kushal Malde, a 23-year old who works at an Indian bank in the Bandra Kurla Complex.

headline: On Our Radar: Philippine Flood Toll at 1,250
text: The death toll from flash floods in the Philippines is hovering at 1,250, but scores of people are still missing. Tens of thousands are displaced in and around the port cities of Iligan and Cagayan de Oro. [CNN]

headline: Sanchez and Eli Manning, a Year 3 Comparison
text: Rex Ryan stood by Mark Sanchez on Monday, saying he has “a huge amount of confidence in him.”

headline: The Core, Not Rotten
text: There have been many news reports the past few days about declining inflation — very different from this time last year, when warnings of higher inflation (and higher interest rates) abounded. As I’ve written many times, events amount to another win for the IS-LM model and the concept of a liquidity trap.

headline: Three of Five Advocates for Chinese Village Released
text: BEIJING — Three of five village advocates who had been abducted by men in plain clothes and detained by the police during a prominent confrontation between local officials and irate residents of a coastal village in south China have been released, a village spokesman said on Tuesday.

headline: Remembering a Dean of the White-Collar Bar
text: Robert G. Morvillo, a prominent New York trial lawyer who pioneered the practice of white-collar criminal defense and whose client list included colorful celebrities, powerful politicians and billionaire businessmen, died on Saturday at his home in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 73.

headline: Shallow Be Thy Name
text: Karl Smith says something true:

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 27
text: Lighter posting because of the holiday week.

headline: Daily Report: Trouble for TV Makers Is Good for Consumers
text: In The New York Times on Tuesday, Andrew Martin writes about the market for television sets, where prices have continued to fall, to the delight of consumers and the chagrin of manufacturers. There is little money to be made in televisions, in part because companies like Sony and Samsung ramped up production capacity for flat-screen sets just before the economic downturn, causing a glut. Online retailers and low-cost set makers have also put pressure on profit margins.

headline: Can a Sports Team’s Ill Fortunes Be Foretold in Its Name?
text: Developments in the New York sports world over the holiday weekend lead to a conclusion that has been bubbling for a while, and now seems inescapable: If you root for a team whose name ends in “ets,” you’re swimming in a sea of troubles.

headline: Architect of Russia’s Political System Under Putin Is Reassigned
text: MOSCOW — The Kremlin on Tuesday announced the reassignment of Vladislav Y. Surkov, the architect of the highly centralized political system that has come under waves of protest from middle-class Muscovites over the last month.

headline: Van Halen Looks Ready to Jump Into Reunion Tour
text: The reunion they said would never happen, already happened once before but didn’t happen in time for a Grammy Awards nomination concert, appears to be happening (again). The classic lineup of Van Halen, including David Lee Roth and the brothers Eddie and Alex Van Halen, and what remains of their colossal 1980s-era hair looked as if they were poised to regroup for a new concert tour after the appearance of videos that were posted on the band’s Web site, www.van-halen.com. The black-and-white segments, set to parts of the Van Halen songs “Jump,” “Panama” and “Hot For Teacher,” show the bandmates rehearsing and goofing around while a ticker on the bottom of the screen reads: “Van Halen on Tour 2012″ and “First tickets on sale Jan. 10.” No other information was immediately available.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: National Geographic Traveler: Melina Gerosa Bellows voyages to Mexico to investigate the world (and taste the honey) of a stingless, endangered bee that, in ancient Mayan culture, was viewed as a mystic emissary. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: The Best in Books
text: A selection of 2011’s best posts on books from The Moment blog.

headline: Gingrich Once Sided With Romney on Health Care
text: Before Newt Gingrich was locked in a bitter rivalry with Mitt Romney for the Republican nomination, he offered high praise for the health care law that Mr. Romney signed in 2006 as Massachusetts governor.

headline: Helen Frankenthaler, Abstract Painter Who Shaped a Movement, Dies at 83
text: Helen Frankenthaler, the lyrically abstract painter whose technique of staining pigment into raw canvas helped shape an influential art movement in the mid-20th century and who became one of the most admired artists of her generation, died on Tuesday at her home in Darien, Conn. She was 83.

headline: In the Barber's Chair
text: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, joins William C. Rhoden and others in a barbershop in Harlem for a talk about the safety of the pro game and other issues.

headline: Iranian Court Begins Trial of U.S. Man
text: An Iranian court began hearings on Tuesday in the trial of a man who appeared on state television this month and confessed to being an American spy sent to infiltrate the intelligence services of Iran.

headline: Video: Roger Goodell in the Barber’s Chair With William C. Rhoden
text: Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, joins William C. Rhoden and others in a barbershop in Harlem for a talk about the safety of the pro game and other issues.

headline: No Relief in Report on Housing
text: The latest housing report indicates that further declines are in store for the weak American market, or at best a period of long, slow recovery.

headline: Tuesday Reading: How Government Austerity Affects Health Care
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: In Iowa, the Campaign Begins. Really.
text: DES MOINES — If there was a time to start paying attention to the Republican presidential contest, this is it.

headline: EDF of France to Increase Stake in Italian Utility
text: MILAN — The French utility EDF, Europe’s biggest power generator, said Tuesday it would raise its stake in the Italian energy company Edison, as it seeks to secure a bigger foothold in the country.

headline: MetLife to Sell Bank Unit to GE Capital
text: MetLife announced on Tuesday that it had agreed to sell the bulk of its retail bank deposits business to GE Capital, as it seeks to focus on its core insurance business.

headline: After 1,500 Years, an Index to the Talmud’s Labyrinths, With Roots in the Bronx
text: The Talmud is a formidable body of work: 63 volumes of rabbinical discourse and disputation that form Judaism’s central scripture after the Torah. It has been around for 1,500 years and is studied every day by tens of thousands of Jews. But trying to navigate through its coiling labyrinth can be enormously difficult because the one thing this monumental work lacks is a widely accepted and accessible index.

headline: The Times Names a New Deputy Managing Editor
text: The New York Times said Tuesday that it was promoting its longtime design director, Tom Bodkin, to deputy managing editor, the latest change to the masthead since Jill Abramson took over as executive editor in September.

headline: America Is Not Exceptional
text: Uh-oh — Mitt Romney is going to go after me. Maybe I’d better get out of the country and start an apology tour …

headline: Middle Childhood Is Peak Time for Learning
text: Parents have long loved “middle childhood,” that period from the end of toddlerhood to the teens. In the past in this country, and even now in many remote or agricultural societies, middle childhood marked the moment when children became useful; for modern, Western parents, it marks the time when children become truly fun (and easier) to have around.

headline: Leading Off — Saints Had Eye on Record, and Little Else
text: The Miami Dolphins, past and present, have been taking their knocks. They lost the first seven games of the season, their starting quarterback and eventually their coach, Tony Sparano. The Green Bay Packers fell short of duplicating the 1972 squad’s perfect season, but now another of the Dolphins’ lifetime achievements, Dan Marino’s single-season passing record, has fallen.

headline: The Not-So-Beautiful Game
text: ISTANBUL — “Welcome to hell!” was how Istanbul fans once greeted foreign soccer teams. But now it’s Turkey’s top team that finds itself in a small hell of its own making. Not only is a recent match-fixing scandal threatening the country’s premier league, but it has also forced the governing Justice and Development (AK) Party into scoring against itself. The party that was elected in 2002 as the new broom to sweep Turkey clean looks like it’s sweeping dirt under the carpet.

headline: Gains in Colon Cancer Show a Racial Gap
text: Advances in screening, diagnosis and treatment of colon cancer mean fewer people are dying of the disease today than they were 20 years ago. But not everyone is benefiting equally.

headline: A Countdown of Sam Sifton’s Top 10 New Restaurants of 2011
text: The Times’s restaurant critic for much of 2011 lists his favorite new places of the year — a strong one for smart-casual cooking.

headline: Sam Sifton’s Top 10 New Restaurants of 2011
text: FOLLOWING is a list of my favorite new restaurants among those that I reviewed in 2011, before stepping down as critic in October. It suggests a strong year for smart-casual cooking, the sort of food that takes a lot of work to prepare but is often served by people in untucked shirts and flash sneakers. Of course there were exceptions. Chief among them is a restaurant that narrowly missed inclusion here: the elegant Ai Fiori, which Michael White opened in the Setai Hotel. (Ai Fiori recently lost its chef, Chris Jaeckle.)

headline: Lampert’s Hit-or-Miss Portfolio
text: After reporting disappointing holiday sales, Sears announced on Tuesday it would shut up to 120 stores nationwide, another blow to the billionaire investor Edward S. Lampert‘s dream to transform the beleaguered retailer.

headline: The Get | Oscar de la Renta Headphones
text: In one of the season’s coolest (or coziest, depending how you look at it) collaborations, these fox fur headphones from Beats by Oscar de la Renta combine the designer’s love of music with the fluffy earmuffs seen in his most recent holiday collection. Frivolous? Maybe. Fabulous? Beyond.

headline: ‘Hand to God’ to Return for 8 Weeks, Possibly Longer
text: The creators of “Hand to God,” a well-reviewed, recently shuttered Off-Broadway production that revolves around a demonic sock puppet, are in talks with several producers about a possible commercial run of the play in New York, according to people involved in those discussions. Meanwhile, the head of the nonprofit theater where “Hand to God” ran this fall disclosed that it would return there for an eight-week encore this winter.

headline: Iran Threatens to Block Oil Shipments, as U.S. Prepares Sanctions
text: WASHINGTON — A senior Iranian official on Tuesday delivered a sharp threat in response to economic sanctions being readied by the United States, saying his country would retaliate against any crackdown by blocking all oil shipments through the Strait of Hormuz, a vital artery for transporting about one-fifth of the world’s oil supply.

headline: In New Hampshire, Romney Saves His Attacks for Obama
text: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — As attention turns to Iowa’s caucuses, Mitt Romney scheduled two stops in New Hampshire on Tuesday morning, reaching out to voters in a state where he is considered the front-runner before heading off to Iowa later in the day.

headline: Adult, Autistic and in Love
text: Parents of children on the spectrum spend more time than many parents worrying about what lies in their children’s future. We all worry about jobs, economics, relationships, education — but parents of children with autism worry about those things on a more basic level. For many, it’s not “will my child get a good job” but “will my child be able to hold any job?” Not “will my child have a happy relationship” but “is there any kind of romantic partnership in my child’s future?”

headline: More of Your Best Meals of 2011
text: Readers continue to tweet their best meals of the year, with a few themes emerging: eye-opening meals encountered on vacation in Italy and Spain, pizza places through the continental United States, and several nods to restaurants like Per Se and Eleven Madison Park (our critics agree).

headline: Pew Feature Illustrates Banks’ Transaction Infractions
text: An arm of the Pew Charitable Trusts have been gaining some traction with its campaign to get banks to disclose fees associated with checking accounts in clear, simple language. One bank practice that Pew thinks is especially important for banks to clearly explain is the order in which they process transactions, which can affect the number of fees you pay if you overdraw your account.

headline: Street Style: Winter Hats
text: The best of readers’ street style for the week of Dec. 19.

headline: AMC’s ‘Hell on Wheels’ Will Keep Rolling for Second Season
text: Though “Hell on Wheels” may not match the ratings-increasing power provided by the undead hordes of its AMC sibling “The Walking Dead,” its own shambolically attired characters will be back for a second season, the cable channel announced on Tuesday.

headline: Warming Up Short Days and Long Nights in Iceland
text: It was pitch black at 8:30 a.m. on a frigid Icelandic morning, but at least there was no snow falling. Though cloud cover the night before had scuttled my chance to see the Northern Lights, my plan for a 36-hour road trip from Reykjavik, ending a great four days in Iceland, was in full effect.

headline: Leaders of Arctic Methane Project Clarify Climate Concerns
text: Dec. 29, 9:28 a.m. | Updated below |I’ve been in touch with Natalia Shakhova and Igor Semiletov, the intrepid Russian researchers, based at the International Arctic Research Center in Fairbanks, Alaska, who for more than a decade have been leading an important international project analyzing methane plumes rising from the seabed in the shallow Arctic waters spreading north from eastern Siberian shores. (Here’s video of Shakhova describing the methane releases and their work.)

headline: TimesCast | December 27, 2011
text: The Times’s Baghdad bureau chief, Tim Arango, looks back at the year in Iraq | Steven Erlanger reports from Paris on the challenges for the euro in 2011.

headline: Slicing Costs, and Still Serving
text: You see them all across the country, in shopping malls and street corners, suburban towns and city centers: zombie restaurants.

headline: House Freshmen Set Voting Record
text: House freshmen, including those elected in special elections in 2011, on average missed the fewest votes of any class of first-year lawmakers since at least 1990, the earliest that the House of Representatives published electronic voting data.

headline: Video Shows Observers in Syrian City as Protests Swell
text: Updated | 5:43 p.m. As our colleague Kareem Fahim reports, Syrian forces cleared tanks from areas of Homs, residents said, as Arab League observers arrived on Tuesday to monitor pledges by the government to end the violence that has gripped the restive city.

headline: Pro-Gingrich Group Kicks Off Ad Campaign
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Newt Gingrich has been aggressively outspent by rivals on television and radio ads that have done serious damage to his standing in polls, especially here in Iowa. But a new independent “super PAC” supporting Mr. Gingrich plans to spend more than $1 million in the next seven days on TV, radio and digital spots, most in Iowa ahead of the Jan. 3 caucuses.

headline: The Party Continues, but Those Who Know Are Already There
text: LOS ANGELES — Getting to this party took commitment. The chosen had to R.S.V.P. early to get on the guest list but were not told where they were going. The address came later, by e-mail: Be at a dimly lighted parking lot just east of the Los Angeles River at 1 a.m. They lined up at a corrugated steel fence, shivering in their furs and leather jackets on the chilly December night.

headline: Why Nobody Will Play Nice With Windows Phone 7
text: Microsoft’s Windows Phone 7 software has a unique, modern design that many say is superior to Android’s more rugged, computery look. But a former Microsoft employee says looks alone are not enough to make Windows Phone succeed.

headline: Nebraska Senator Won’t Run Again
text: 8:24 p.m. | Updated The full report of this article is available here.

headline: New Hope for Multiple Sclerosis Patients
text: After decades of slow progress, the range of treatments for multiple sclerosis may now be on the verge of a turning point. As Laurie Tarkan explains in today’s Science Times, patients now have several promising new drug options to help them ease symptoms of the disease:

headline: Update: Lok Sabha Passes Lokpal
text: The lower house of Parliament made speedy work of the Lokpal Bill, voting late Tuesday night to approve it, though a second vote to give it constitutional status failed. The votes happened even as three minority parties, the Left Front, the Samajwadi Party and the Bahujan Samaj Party walked out of the discussions.

headline: Safety Agency Investigating Rust Problems on G.M. and Ford Vans
text: Owners complaining of what they saw as rust-related safety problems have prompted the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to open separate investigations into vans made by General Motors and Ford.

headline: Obama to Nominate Two for Vacancies on Fed Board
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Tuesday that he would nominate Jeremy C. Stein, a Harvard economist, and Jerome H. Powell, a former private equity executive, to fill the two vacant seats on the Federal Reserve’s board.

headline: Dunderdon Workshop: Winter’s Reality Check
text: I DON’T do winter. Not that I leave town, mind you, but I try to dress in February as I do in October or April, maybe hiding a layer or three. No cold snap can freeze my mind to the point where I feel like bundling up beyond all shape recognition. Bulk bad. Slim good.

headline: Fatal House Fire Linked to Embers Discarded From Fireplace
text: The deadly fire that roared through a stately Victorian home in Connecticut near the water early Christmas morning has been tinged with heart-wrenching details.

headline: More on the Nursing Home Exodus
text: The intensifying federal effort to move people out of nursing homes and into the community has brought both consternation and applause among readers here.

headline: The Worst C.E.O.’s of 2011
text: Sydney Finkelstein is a professor of strategy and leadership at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth College and the author of the bestselling book “Why Smart Executives Fail.”

headline: Deals Appear to Avert Nurses’ Strikes at Two Hospital Centers
text: 9:38 p.m. | Updated A nursing strike has been averted at two of Manhattan’s busiest hospital centers, as union and hospital negotiators reached tentative deals over pay and benefits, officials involved in the talks said Tuesday.

headline: Toyota Introduces Compact Hybrid to Japanese Market
text: On Monday, the Toyota Motor Corporation introduced a compact gasoline/electric hybrid vehicle for its home market. The car, which will be sold as the Toyota Aqua in Japan, was introduced at a Tokyo news conference and will eventually be available in other markets, including the United States, as the Prius C.

headline: Cuban Free Agent Is Next Hot Commodity
text: Now that the Texas Rangers have won the right to negotiate with the Japanese pitching phenom Yu Darvish, Major League Baseball has turned its attention to Yoennis Cespedes, a captivating Cuban outfielder with a running back’s body whom scouts have been following for years.

headline: Middle childhood, censoring bad news on avian flu and the science behind a character in the movie “Hugo.”
text: Middle childhood, censoring bad news on avian flu and the science behind a character in the movie “Hugo.”

headline: Sorghum Speaks With a Sweet Drawl
text: ATLANTA

headline: Sam Rivers, Jazz Artist of Loft Scene, Dies at 88
text: Sam Rivers, an inexhaustibly creative saxophonist, flutist, bandleader and composer who cut his own decisive path through the jazz world, spearheading the 1970s loft scene in New York and later establishing a rugged outpost in Florida, died on Monday in Orlando, Fla. He was 88.

headline: The Defeatism of Depression
text: A number of people have asked me to weigh in on David Brooks’s piece today. Sorry, not gonna do a tit-for-tat. Let me instead just make a more general point.

headline: Off the Menu
text: Opening

headline: In Motion
text: Andrea Mohin’s 1011 Dance photos

headline: Univision Finds Ratings Success
text: Against a full slate of repeats on the big four broadcast networks, the Spanish-language network Univision emerged as the highest-rated channel in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic on Monday night, according to Nielsen data. The two-hour finale of the telenovela “La Fuerza del Destino” (“The Strength of Destiny”) averaged 5.4 million total viewers and trailed only a repeat of “Two and a Half Men” on CBS in the 18-to-49 category. Elsewhere, NBC’s new quiz show “Who’s Still Standing?” continued to pull in respectable numbers with its highest viewership total, 6.9 million.

headline: Santorum Takes Aim at Paul in Iowa
text: MASON CITY, Iowa – Rick Santorum urged voters in Iowa on Tuesday to think for themselves and not jump on the Republican bandwagon that suggests only a certain few of the party’s presidential candidates could defeat President Obama.

headline: Dining Calendar
text: We’ll All Scream

headline: 2011: Year in Iraq
text: The Times’s Baghdad bureau chief, Tim Arango, examines the year in Iraq.

headline: Two New Jersey Democrats to Face Each Other
text: Get ready for some Democrat-on-Democrat infighting in New Jersey. Representative Steve Rothman, a Democrat whose 9th District has been upended by redistricting, will face off against a fellow Democrat, Representative Bill Pascrell Jr., who currently represents the state’s 8th District.

headline: Wheelies: Having ‘Cars’ on the Mind
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: New Yorkers’ Life Expectancy Reaches 80.6 Years, Higher Than National Rate
text: The life expectancy for babies born in New York City reached 80.6 years in 2009, the highest level recorded and one that surpasses the national life expectancy rate, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday.

headline: 2011: Year for the Euro
text: Steven Erlanger evaluates the year for the European Union’s debt crisis.

headline: In Eugene, They Love a Fashion Statement
text: EUGENE, Ore. — The Rose Bowl uniforms for the University of Oregon were revealed Tuesday by Nike.

headline: Bachmann and Perry Make Final Appeal to Social Conservatives
text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — Michele Bachmann on Tuesday accused her Republican rivals of being “confused” about abortion and gay marriage as she sought to make a final appeal to social conservatives in Iowa before the Iowa caucuses next week.

headline: Mobile App Downloads Set Records on Christmas
text: While some customers couldn’t rely on Best Buy to deliver their goods on time for the holidays, mobile app stores didn’t disappoint. Christmas day downloads of Apple iOS and Android apps more than doubled compared to years past, shattering records, according to a report.

headline: Ten of the Best Inexpensive Restaurants of 2011
text: Here are 10 of the best restaurants of the year from $25 and Under and the Dining Briefs:

headline: Ten of the Best Inexpensive Restaurants of 2011
text: Best Pizza in Williamsburg, Agua Fresca in East Harlem and other standout restaurants from $25 and Under and the Dining Briefs.

headline: A Drum Mecca Prepares to Close Up Shop
text: For years Drummers World on West 46th Street was a destination for percussionists of all stripes. Numerous jazz drummers made trips there. Roadies for famous touring bands stopped by. People involved with Broadway productions bought instruments. Even members of symphony orchestras traveled to the shop to find equipment.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, India, China and Iowa.

headline: Sports Replay: Dec.27
text: Hockey and soccer and other sports from around the world on Tuesday.

headline: For Wall Street Deal Makers, Sometimes It Pays to Be Bad
text: Instead of awarding F’s for the worst deals and deal-making of the year, I am going to focus on two of the year’s biggest buyouts. The first: J.Crew’s $3 billion buyout by its chief executive, Millard S. Drexler, and the private equity firms TPG Capital and Leonard Green & Partners. The second: Del Monte Foods’ $5.3 billion acquisition by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, Vestar Capital Partners and Centerview Capital.

headline: Our Top Ten Photo Books of 2011
text: It was not unlike a political caucus. The candidates — in this case, nearly 100 photography books published this year — took over every inch of available counter space in the photo department, where they were carefully scrutinized by a group of opinionated voters, each of whom was given just 10 Post-it notes as ballots. Impassioned speeches were made. Votes were cast: a few books grew polychromatic bouquets of Post-its — each voter had his or her own individual color — while others sprouted single lonely Post-its. Votes were changed: worthy candidates, including the likes of Diana Vreeland and Gerhard Richter, were abandoned. Finally, after weeks, a group of winners emerged. Like all campaigns, it was brutal. Here are the 10 victors, in no particular order.

headline: Occupy the Caucus Is Ready to Go in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — As the Republican presidential candidates make their final pleas to voters across Iowa, a local offshoot of the Occupy Wall Street protests here has traded in tents for its own campaign office.

headline: Knicks Claim Former Harvard Guard Off Waivers
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Jeremy Lin, a Harvard-educated point guard and N.B.A. summer-league sensation, is joining the Knicks. His stay may be short.

headline: Could Chicken Be the New Monkey Someday?
text: When the Wildlife Conservation Society set out to study bush meat consumption in Gabon, researchers reluctantly had to rule out some sites. Especially in the rainy season, it became hard to gain access to some rural communities. Washed-out roads grounded trucks in the muck, and precarious mountain passes were in some cases too risky to navigate.

headline: Holiday Spirit Doesn’t Extend to Serious-Themed Shows on Broadway
text: Ticket sales for serious-minded Broadway shows were akin to a lump of coal last week during the run-up to the Christmas holiday, according to an analysis of weekly show grosses released on Tuesday.

headline: With Essays on Democracy, Chinese Blogger Stirs Debate Among Reformers
text: A popular writer, race-car driver and heartthrob stirred intense debate this week in China with three short political essays that drew fire from democracy advocates, including the dissident artist Ai Weiwei, while appearing to hearten the Chinese authorities.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from Pakistan, India, China and Iowa.

headline: Ways to Get Guests to Say, ‘Ooooh!’
text: Modest luxuries add panache to holiday entertaining. Guests will not miss the caviar if you garnish and season canapés, desserts, ceviche and even drinks with Cocktail Pearls, glistening globules of flavor and color about the size of salmon roe. The pearls are made with fruit pulp treated with xanthan gum and sodium alginate, those essentials of the molecular pantry. So, no surprise, they are from Spain. Versions in strawberry, apple-ginger and lemon-lime add bright sweetness. Shallot-vinegar, lemon-pepper and chile are sharp and tangy.

headline: When the Family’s Foodies Visit New York
text: IF it’s Tuesday, this must be Jean Georges, and the end must be nigh.

headline: Iraq in 2011: Troop Departures and Power Struggles
text: For Iraqis and Americans, 2011 was marked by the issue of whether the United States military would stay or leave. In Tuesday’s TimesCast, The Times’s Baghdad bureau chief, Tim Arango, looks back at the process of deciding that question, and at other news from the year in Iraq.

headline: Tremont
text: 51 Bank Street (West Fourth Street); (212) 488-1019, tremontnyc.com

headline: Whitehall Bar and Kitchen
text: 19 Greenwich Avenue (West 10th Street); (212) 675-7261; whitehall-nyc.com

headline: Times Co. Agrees to Sell Regional Newspaper Group
text: 6:00 p.m. | Updated The New York Times Company announced on Tuesday that it had reached an agreement to sell the company’s Regional Media Group to Halifax Media Holdings, of Daytona Beach, Fla., for $143 million in cash.

headline: A Year of Acquired Tastes
text: NO doubt about it, I’ve had the privilege of drinking some spectacular wines in 2011. Most astounding of all was a summer evening that I spent with the sort of great old Burgundies that I never imagined I would see in the first place and that I never expect to drink again.

headline: A Brooklyn Girl Who’s Just Not Frilly
text: Don’t be put off by the harsh title of “Pariah,” the stirring coming-out story of a virginal 17-year-old African-American lesbian living in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. The teenager, Alike (pronounced ah-LEE-kay), dresses like a boy when out of her parents’ sight and endures a fair share of barbed, homophobic remarks, but she is not viciously persecuted.

headline: Southern Farmers Vanquish the Clichés
text: ST. MATTHEWS, S.C.

headline: Italy to Play U.S. in February, Italian Coach Says
text: The United States national team will face Italy in an exhibition game in February, according to Italy Coach Cesare Prandelli.

headline: Shlomi Reuveni
text: Mr. Reuveni, 44, is the senior managing director of Brown Harris Stevens Select, a luxury new development marketing group that he helped establish in 2007. Before joining Brown Harris Stevens, Mr. Reuveni was a broker for the Corcoran Group for about 12 years. He began brokering deals as a teenager.

headline: If Cave Men Told Jokes, Would Humans Laugh?
text: You may think you know someone who thinks like a Neanderthal. You may even think you know someone who is a Neanderthal, or at least part one. Chances are you’re right about both. Webster’s definition of Neanderthal is unflattering: “suggesting a cave man in appearance or behavior.” (The definition of cave man: “One who acts in a rough primitive manner, esp. toward women.”)

headline: Life Expectancy Rises for New Yorkers
text: Want to add years to your life? Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a suggestion: Move to New York City.

headline: Shifts in Health Care Delivery Stimulate a String of Property Deals
text: MedRite Urgent Care has a bustling office on Second Avenue and 49th Street, packed with professionals in suits rushing to have their blood drawn between meetings and neighborhood residents who like the convenience. The clinic, which provides checkups, drug testing and other primary and urgent medical care for walk-in patients, opened in February.

headline: Reviewing Mas (la grillade)
text: A couple of years ago while traveling in Spain I had two life-changing meals. One was at El Bulli, a restaurant some of you may have heard of, which no longer exists. The other was at Asador Etxebarri, in the little Basque town of Axpe, about as far from El Bulli in spirit as you can journey.

headline: The Power of Smoke and Flame
text: WOOD, fire, smoke and flesh. It doesn’t get any simpler, more elemental or more prehistoric than this fundamental equation.

headline: South Florida Poised for Birth of Casino Gambling
text: MIAMI — When the Florida Legislature returns from its holiday recess, it will consider a bill to allow three Las Vegas-style casino resorts to be built in the southern part of the state. Lobbyists for the gambling industry have swarmed Tallahassee, trying to ensure that the bill passes.

headline: Sources of Debris in Artificial Hips
text: Data from orthopedic registries in England and Australia shows that standard all-metal replacement hips are failing at rates two to three times greater than ones made of metal and plastic. Metal wear is the principal culprit. But researchers say such wear can happen in differing ways that can contribute to the early failure of various hip models.

headline: Change Remains a Constant in ‘Nutcracker’
text: Despite cast changes, Act I of “The Nutcracker” is more or less the same at every performance. Because of cast changes, Act II is almost never the same. If you attend several “Nutcracker” shows a season, you go to see the cast changes in Act II. And yet it is Act I that is the more miraculous: Tchaikovsky’s score, permitting only two or three tiny breaks for applause before intermission, is constantly on the move, answering the scale and subject of the story with a fluency that breaks the mold of 19th-century ballet.

headline: Questions About Motives Behind Stratfor Hack
text: When hackers used the Christmas holiday to attack Stratfor, a security group based in Austin, Tex., they initially said they were aiming to steal the credit card numbers of its clients and use them to make $1 million in donations to charity.

headline: Gingrich Strikes Economic Themes in Hitting Romney
text: DYERSVILLE, Iowa — Newt Gingrich introduced a new theme to his sharpening contrast to Mitt Romney: that he was a founder of supply-side economics that brought the country prosperity under Ronald Reagan and can do so again — but not if Mr. Romney is the nominee.

headline: Bound for Local Glory at Last
text: TULSA, Okla. — Oklahoma has always had a troubled relationship with her native son Woody Guthrie. The communist sympathies of America’s balladeer infuriated local detractors. In 1999 a wealthy donor’s objections forced the Cowboy Museum in Oklahoma City to cancel a planned exhibition on Guthrie organized by the Smithsonian Institution. It wasn’t until 2006, nearly four decades after his death, that the Oklahoma Hall of Fame got around to adding him to its ranks.

headline: A Crude, Rude Christmas Tale
text: When it comes to Christmas movies, the French prefer naughty over nice any day. “Le Père Noël Est une Ordure” (whose literal translation would make George Bailey blush, so “Santa Stinks” will have to do), a much-loved 1982 farce finally having its American theatrical premiere at the Museum of Modern Art, is a fine example. Crude, rude and with more foul language than a Gordon Ramsay marathon, this smutty staple could give even the most hardened Francophobe a few guilty giggles.

headline: A Thug Talks and Talks, and Scribbles
text: In a nondescript motel room somewhere along the border between Mexico and the United States, a former hit man — a “sicario” — for the Mexican drug cartels speaks. Unquestioned and uninterrupted, this black-garbed thug regales us with 20 years’ worth of kidnapping, torture and cold-blooded murder, all the while scribbling compulsively in a large notebook.

headline: Mitt Romney’s New Hampshire Stump Speech
text: Mitt Romney’s full New Hampshire speech.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Touch Screens and Floating Incubators
text: Interesting things that Bits reporters and editors found on the Web. More here.

headline: Pro-Romney Group Makes Post-Iowa Ad Buy
text: Even if Newt Gingrich, a former House speaker, pulls out a victory in the Iowa caucuses next week, Restore Our Future will be waiting.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,840 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

headline: In Lawsuit, Perry Challenges His Exclusion From Virginia Ballot
text: Gov. Rick Perry of Texas filed a federal lawsuit on Tuesday challenging his exclusion from the Republican primary ballot in Virginia, a state known for having some of the most restrictive ballot access rules in the country.

headline: Two Artists Who Embraced Freedom
text: It is strange that the sculptor John Chamberlain and the painter Helen Frankenthaler should have died within a week of each other — he on Dec. 21, and she on Tuesday — considering that they occupy such similar positions within the history of American art. Both emerged in the 1950s and provided crucial links between art styles, specifically helping to forge the transition from Abstract Expressionism to what lay beyond.

headline: Bettye Danoff, Founding Member of L.P.G.A., Dies at 88
text: Bettye Danoff, one of 13 founding members of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, which began as a hardy, poorly paid band of women who traveled the country for the chance to play the game, died on Thursday in McKinney, Tex. She was 88.

headline: Making Themselves Heard in a Changed Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — The day after a lumbering line of whooping, high-fiving American soldiers drove out of Iraq and into history, the 30 million Iraqis they left behind woke to a bright cold day filled with echoes of nearly nine years of war.

headline: Karzai Agrees to Let Taliban Set Up Office in Qatar
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — After prodding by his American and European backers, President Hamid Karzai dropped his opposition to allowing the Taliban to set up an office in the Persian Gulf state of Qatar, saying on Tuesday that he could abide by such a step if it was what the United States wanted.

headline: Battling Anew Over the Place of Religion in Public Schools
text: JEFFERSON, S.C. — It has been nearly 50 years since the Supreme Court ruled that officially sponsored prayer in public schools violated the separation of church and state.

headline: Nelson to Quit the Senate, Giving G.O.P. an Advantage
text: WASHINGTON — Senator Ben Nelson, the embattled two-term Democrat from Nebraska, said Tuesday that he would not seek re-election in 2012, giving Republicans a decided advantage in their drive to win his Senate seat and a leg up in their effort to bring the Senate under Republican control.

headline: Crowded Sidelines Leave Coaches Nowhere to Run
text: Marv Levy can vividly recall the play some 40 years later: a sweep to the right, Bears linebacker Dick Butkus running full speed toward the sideline, then Levy landing on his back. The feared Butkus had bowled over Levy, then an assistant coach just starting his career in the N.F.L., when his momentum carried him out of bounds. It became one of Levy’s favorite war stories.

headline: State Threatens to Pull Millions for Schools in the City and Elsewhere
text: New York State’s education commissioner threatened on Tuesday to withhold tens of millions of dollars in federal grants to struggling schools in New York City and nine other districts statewide if they do not prove by Saturday that they will carry out new evaluation systems for teachers and principals.

headline: Work Habits, Once Questioned, Are a Key to Newton’s Success
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Fake smile. Selfish. The next JaMarcus Russell.

headline: Enticing Doctors to Endorse a Weight-Loss Program
text: WHEN Medicare announced in November that it would begin paying for obese patients to undergo physician-supervised treatment for weight loss, it was welcome news to the Center for Medical Weight Loss, a company offering an obesity program adopted by doctors throughout the country.

headline: Finding Hospice Care for the Dying
text: To the Editor:

headline: Spinoffs Become a Favored Strategy
text: In corporate finance, this will go down as the year of the spinoff. Activity is on pace to hit $230 billion, which is six times last year’s total and approaching a whopping 8 percent of global deal activity, according to Citigroup. With rocky economic conditions unlikely to give executives much reason to go shopping, 2012 could bring still more splits.

headline: Rapes on the Rise in Somalia
text: This year, tens of thousands in Somalia have died from famine, with countless others cut down in relentless combat. Now Somalis face yet another widespread terror: an alarming increase in rapes and sexual abuse of women and girls.

headline: Perry Changes Position on Exceptions for Abortion
text: OSCEOLA, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry said Tuesday that he had undergone a “transformation” on the issue of abortion and now believed that there should be no exceptions made for rape, incest or the life of the mother.

headline: Despite Warning, Dickey Readies for Climb
text: Pitcher R. A. Dickey is leaving next Tuesday for a climb of Mount Kilimanjaro despite the Mets’ request that he not make the trip, which is designed to benefit a charity that helps poor and desperate people in Mumbai, India.

headline: Madrid Joins Cities Replacing Concrete With Greenery
text: I have to make note of the fascinating article by Michael Kimmelman in The Times describing Madrid’s ambitious reinvention of what Kimmelman describes as a “crippling gash” of aging riverside highway lanes as a green swath that one resident calls “new lungs.” (The video above, produced by the city, provides background on the project.)

headline: Beginning Iowa Push, Romney Focuses on Obama
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa — Kicking off a three-day bus tour through Iowa, where he is making an aggressive push before next week’s caucuses, Mitt Romney on Tuesday offered a sharp contrast between himself and President Obama while not even mentioning his rivals for the Republican nomination.

headline: Hit by Injuries, Knicks Add Former Harvard Guard
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — On the third dizzying day of this most unusual season, the Knicks added a player, rushed through a practice and boarded a cross-country flight, to play three games in four nights, in their only visit to the Pacific time zone.

headline: Bacteria 1, F.D.A. 0
text: Earlier this month, the Maine-based grocery chain Hannaford issued a ground beef recall after at least 14 people were infected with an antibiotic-resistant strain of salmonella. Chances are this is the first you’ve heard of it. After all, it’s not much compared to the 76 illnesses and one death back in August that led Cargill to recall almost 36 million pounds of ground turkey products potentially contaminated with drug-resistant salmonella. The particulars get confusing, but the trend is unmistakable: our meat supply is frequently contaminated with bacteria that can’t readily be treated by antibiotics.

headline: Helen Frankenthaler Dies at 83
text: Helen Frankenthaler, the lyrically abstract painter who became one of the most admired artists of her generation, died on Tuesday at her home in Darien, Conn. She was 83.

headline: Contemplating Official Mercy: No Small Task
text: As Andrew M. Cuomo comes to the end of his first year as governor, it’s a moment to remember that he has yet to exercise one power that does not require him to argue with Sheldon Silver in the State Assembly, haggle with Dean G. Skelos in the Senate, box with Michael R. Bloomberg in City Hall or fence with the public employee unions.

text: DAVENPORT, Iowa — When Mitt Romney introduces himself to voters, he has a peculiar habit of guessing their age or nationality, often incorrectly. (A regular query: “Are you French Canadian?”)

headline: With Gas Drilling Next Door, County in New York Gets an Economic Lift
text: HORSEHEADS, N.Y. — At the Glamour and Glow boutique in the local mall here, crystal necklaces and fake fur vests have been hot-ticket items the last year.

headline: Obama to Ask for $1.2 Trillion Increase in Debt Limit
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will ask Congress this week for $1.2 trillion in additional borrowing authority, which would raise the federal debt limit to $16.4 trillion and avoid the need for further increases before the 2012 elections, administration officials said Tuesday.

headline: Juggling a Long Commute and 2 Children With Disabilities
text: Late one afternoon, Marlene Minto sat her two children down at the dining table and stood over them as they began their homework. A nurse’s assistant, she still had on her scrubs, with her ID card hanging from a green clip shaped like a frog. It was early into what she could call her second shift.

headline: Lottery Numbers
Republican Rivals Unleash Broadside on Paul in Iowa
text: MASON CITY, Iowa — The Republican presidential candidates sharpened their criticism of Representative Ron Paul on Tuesday in an effort to keep his support from growing among voters who are frustrated with government and may be inclined to send a message to the Washington establishment by supporting him in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: For Somali Women, Pain of Being a Spoil of War
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The girl’s voice dropped to a hush as she remembered the bright, sunny afternoon when she stepped out of her hut and saw her best friend buried in the sand, up to her neck.

headline: The High Cost of Failing Artificial Hips

headline: A Snapshot of the Race for the Senate
text: The electoral implications of the impending retirement of Senator Ben Nelson of Nebraska are fairly obvious. This is bad news for Democrats, who were already going to have a difficult time holding on to their narrow 53-47 advantage in the upper chamber.

headline: Appealing to Evangelicals, Hopefuls Pack Religion Into Ads
text: DES MOINES — There is Rick Perry, a stained-glass window and a large illuminated cross over his right shoulder, looking more preacher than politician. An aerial shot of a soaring church steeple zooms into focus a few seconds later. Then — blink and you’ll miss it — a picture of Mr. Perry, the Texas governor, with his arm around Mike Huckabee flashes on the screen.

headline: S.E.C. Wins Delay in Citigroup Fraud Case
text: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court granted an emergency ruling late Tuesday that temporarily halted proceedings in the Securities and Exchange Commission’s case against Citigroup. The decision will allow the court to consider an appeal of a lower court’s decision to throw out a $285 million fraud settlement between the commission and Citigroup.

headline: Miami Beckons, and Brazilians Come Running With Cash

headline: Miami Has a Hearty Oi (Hello) for Free-Spending Brazilians
text: MIAMI — Even in a city that has embraced so many waves of Latinos that it is jokingly referred to as the only South American capital in North America, no one group has been as courted and pampered as the Brazilians.

headline: ‘Silence of the Lambs,’ ‘Bambi’ and ‘Forrest Gump’ Added to National Film Registry
text: Hannibal Lecter is going away for a long time — and so are Bambi, Forrest Gump and the adorable moppet played by Jackie Coogan in a classic Charlie Chaplin feature: the movies featuring these characters are among the 25 works that have been added to the National Film Registry, the Library of Congress is to announce on Wednesday.

headline: Wednesday: Go Head to Head
text: WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — If you’ve ever been a victim of identity theft, you know there’s nothing funny about it. People’s credit and entire lives have been ruined by this crime, so I was a little concerned about the potential reaction to the theme of this puzzle. On the other hand, it’s just a crossword puzzle, and just another deletion theme, so let’s talk about it from that perspective.

headline: Israeli Girl, 8, at Center of Tension Over Religious Extremism
text: BEIT SHEMESH, Israel — The latest battleground in Israel’s struggle over religious extremism covers little more than a square mile of this Jewish city situated between Jerusalem and Tel Aviv, and it has the unexpected public face of a blond, bespectacled second-grade girl.

headline: After Weak Holiday, Sears to Shut 120 Stores

headline: CarMax Accused of Failing to Disclose Aspects of Cars’ History
text: A Maryland judge is being asked to find CarMax, the automotive retailer, in contempt of court for failing to abide by a 2008 class-action settlement. That settlement required that consumers be given a clear warning when a used vehicle offered for sale was once in a rental fleet.

headline: Honoring All Who Saved Jews
text: IN December 1942, when I was 13 years old, German troops occupied my hometown. Within days, our house was commandeered as an officers’ mess hall. I soon had a yellow star on my dress, setting me apart from many of my childhood friends. The men of our family were ordered into forced labor. My happy life had vanished.

headline: Court in Egypt Says Rights of Women Were Violated
text: CAIRO — An administrative court ruled Tuesday that the Egyptian military had wrongly violated the human rights of female demonstrators by subjecting them to “virginity tests” intended to humiliate them.

headline: Nets and Fans Silenced in Home Opener
text: The Nets have won more than 50 games only once during their tenure in New Jersey. A 106-70 loss in their final home opener before their move to Brooklyn reminded fans why.

headline: An Operator of Group Homes Keeps State Aid Despite Faults

headline: Disparities in an Oil Boomtown
text: An oil boom has caused money to to flow by the barrelful into Mountrail County in North Dakota, transforming a sleepy community once proudly situated in the middle of nowhere into an unexpected oasis of prosperity.

headline: A Great Divide Over Oil Riches
text: STANLEY, N.D. — Just like everybody else around here, Fred Evans spent his life coaxing a good enough living out of the earth. He grew wheat, ran cattle and, during a couple of short-lived bursts of activity, worked on the drill rigs searching for oil across the northern prairie.

headline: Where a Qaddafi Son Once Played, Ex-Rebels Wait and Wonder
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — Sometimes the young fighters gather under a date palm next to the empty swimming pool to joke and strum the guitar. When it rains, they retreat indoors to play foosball in an improvised game room inside their favorite hangout, a ransacked house where one of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s sons once lived and entertained.

headline: Mr. Paul’s Discredited Campaign
text: Ron Paul long ago disqualified himself for the presidency by peddling claptrap proposals like abolishing the Federal Reserve, returning to the gold standard, cutting a third of the federal budget and all foreign aid and opposing the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

headline: Wall Street Meets Reality
text: Wall Street reported nearly $3 billion in losses in the third quarter of 2011, reducing profits through September to $9.6 billion, which was well below forecasts, according to a recent analysis by the New York State comptroller. The comptroller estimates that Wall Street banks and smaller brokerages may cut some 10,000 jobs in New York City by the end of 2012.

headline: Giving Yemen a Chance
text: The Obama administration is reportedly preparing to admit President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen into the United States for medical treatment. It is not an easy call. But admitting Mr. Saleh, under strict conditions, offers the best hope for speeding his exit from power and ending the repression that has cost hundreds of Yemeni lives.

headline: Cancer Found in President of Argentina
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner of Argentina has thyroid cancer and will undergo surgery on Jan. 4 before taking a three-week absence from office, her spokesman said Tuesday in a televised address.

headline: The Grand Game of Getting to Work
text: Eight-thirty in the morning and the subway is full. Straphangers — strapless for years now — brace themselves against stainless steel poles and overhead rails and almost half the heads on the train are bent, pewlike, over small electronic devices. You can tell who is reading and who is not by the use they make of their thumbs. (This is a grand era for thumbs.) The ones who are thumbing might be scrolling or texting or even writing an e-mail message. But many of them are gaming their way to work.

headline: Joining Trend, College Grows Beyond Name
text: After a century firmly anchored in Boston, Northeastern University is branching out — becoming Southeastern, Northwestern and perhaps Western and Midwestern as well.

headline: What Do Iowans Want in a Candidate?
text: The G.O.P. candidates are focusing on the economy, but Iowa is doing just fine. So what are voters there looking for?

headline: Getting It Right
text: Dissatisfaction and disappointment have pervaded the Republican presidential campaign. Pundits pining for a game-changing candidate have been repeatedly let down, and voters have pinballed from one unsatisfactory option to another, with infatuation giving way to disillusionment every time.

headline: An Uneven Oil Boom in North Dakota
text: As some North Dakota residents cash oil royalty checks worth tens of thousands of dollars a month or more, many of their neighbors are resigned to receiving almost nothing.

headline: The Year in Fitness
text: If all the Phys Ed columns published this year have a single message, it is that now is a fine time to own a body. The diverse exercise-related experiments published in 2011 and covered in this space each week suggest that it’s possible to retain your cognitive powers, muscle mass, running speed and waistline, even as you age, and that a little exercise can go a long way in terms of physiological benefit. Recent, important science even tells us that coffee, chocolate and beer enhance exercise performance, which is fortunate, since I have no plans to give up any of those. As most of us prepare our exercise resolutions for 2012, now seems an ideal time to review the past year in fitness science and the lessons it contained, both encouraging and cautionary.

headline: North Korean Mourners Line Streets for Kim Jong-il’s Funeral
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Jong-un, the designated dynastic heir in North Korea, walked alongside the hearse carrying the body of his father, Kim Jong-il, through snow-covered downtown Pyongyang on Wednesday, leading a state funeral that provided early glimpses of who is serving as guardians of the young, untested leader.

headline: ‘As It Is’ Focus of Bhagavad Gita Trial
text: The Bhagavad Gita was first translated into Russian in 1788, but if a court in the Siberian city of Tomsk rules against it this week, one version of the ancient Hindu text will be added to Russia’s 1,057-item list of banned material deemed extremist.

headline: Will China Outsmart the U.S.?
text: Three months before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Angus Echols, a member of DuPont’s executive committee, began shaping the chemical giant’s plans for the coming decade. The U.S. would soon be at war, he explained in a series of memos and high-level discussions, and the company needed to aid the effort. But it also needed to think far ahead. When the war ended, Echols argued, women would want to buy cheap stockings. And where was DuPont on this crucial matter?

headline: Newt Gingrich’s Glory Days
text: It was just after dawn in Coralville, Iowa, the week before Christmas, and I asked the young waitress at the hotel restaurant if she would kindly direct Newt Gingrich to my table when he arrived. She looked uncertain.

headline: Breathing In Music, Photographing Dance

headline: Tip of the Week: The Silver Screen on Your Screen
text: As the year winds down and the rest of the Oscar-contending movies hit theaters, it may take extra effort to keep up with what is playing where (and when). For serious film buffs, the Flixster add-on for Google’s Chrome browser pulls in a list of all the latest releases, trailers, show times and theaters near your location, plus new movies arriving soon or on DVD.

headline: Polling Gridlock in Iowa Could Produce Last-Minute Momentum

headline: Jets’ Long-Shot Chance Is Put at 9 Percent
text: Jets fans know it doesn’t look good, and we’re here to put a number on that feeling: According to NFL-Forecast.com, the Jets have a 9.3 percent chance of advancing to the playoffs.

headline: The Best of the Boss
text: Here at You’re the Boss, we believe that most small-business owners are really good at a few things, the things that allowed them to get their businesses off the ground. Inevitably, however, most owners are unprepared for the dozens of other tasks that are essential to running a business. We hope to help with those. But we don’t try to make it look easy.

headline: Indian Activist Calls Off Fast but Vows to Keep Fighting

headline: Military to Lend $1 Billion to Bolster Egypt’s Currency
text: CAIRO — Egypt’s military rulers are lending $1 billion to the central bank to prop up the country’s flagging currency, offering evidence of both the precarious state of the economy and the military’s singular status within it.

headline: A Day With the Bridges
text: The exercise routines and diets of Janice and Adam Bridges, who have lost about 165 and 110 pounds and struggle daily to keep the weight off.

headline: The Fat Trap
text: For 15 years, Joseph Proietto has been helping people lose weight. When these obese patients arrive at his weight-loss clinic in Australia, they are determined to slim down. And most of the time, he says, they do just that, sticking to the clinic’s program and dropping excess pounds. But then, almost without exception, the weight begins to creep back. In a matter of months or years, the entire effort has come undone, and the patient is fat again. “It has always seemed strange to me,” says Proietto, who is a physician at the University of Melbourne. “These are people who are very motivated to lose weight, who achieve weight loss most of the time without too much trouble and yet, inevitably, gradually, they regain the weight.”

headline: Are Polls During the Holidays Less Reliable?
text: The Iowa caucuses are six days away, and the latest polls were more than a week ago — a lifetime when opinions are so volatile. Later this week, fresh surveys of Iowan Republicans may be released, but those occurred during the holiday week, when voters are hard to reach and distracted.

headline: A Parade of Sharks, Dazzling Yet Diminished
text: Cocos Island is perhaps best known for an abundance of large marine animals, sharks in particular. Most iconic of these are the vast schools of scalloped hammerhead sharks, which can be found by the hundreds at various sites in the waters around the island.

headline: The Problem
text: Richard Koo has another paper on balance sheet recession out (pdf), with good charts for a number of countries. I still have some differences with him over monetary policy — I still don’t understand why he doesn’t see debt-eroding inflation as something helpful in dealing with debt overhang — but his view of the sources of our Lesser Depression is completely right.

headline: Holiday Surprise: Hollywood Is at Work
text: LOS ANGELES — Gone are those glory days when everyone who was anyone in Hollywood decamped to Aspen or Kahala for the holidays, leaving a few nobodies (and some underpaid journalists) to keep the home fires burning.

headline: Daily Report: Clicking ‘Checkout’ While Under the Influence
text: In The New York Times on Wednesday, Stephanie Clifford reports about the phenomenon of alcohol-induced online shopping. Reliable data is scarce, but one comparison-shopping site says that nearly half the people it surveyed in Britain had shopped online after drinking.  And online retailers suspect that enough shoppers buy online goods in the evening while they are drunk, or even just tipsy, that they are aiming promotions for later hours, hoping to tempt buyers after the bars close.

headline: Colosseum May Be a Fixer-Upper but It’s Not Collapsing, Italian Officials Say
text: ROME — Italian archaeology officials on Wednesday played down Italian news reports that chunks of masonry had been falling off the Colosseum. “Nothing has collapsed” at the Colosseum “since the 18th century,” said a statement issued by a department of the Culture Ministry responsible for Rome’s archaeological sites. The Colosseum, the first-century A.D. arena, is Italy’s most popular tourist draw.

headline: Wednesday Reading: Life Expectancy for New Yorkers Reaches All-Time High

headline: The 1 Percent? That’s So 2011. It’s the 6 Percent You Should Be Worried About.

Sure, some might brand them greedy, but even in New York City, where, thanks to the financial-service industry, they are particularly well compensated, they receive only 33.8 percent of the total income, kindly leaving two-thirds for the rest of us.

headline: Why Lost Pounds Come Back
text: In this week’s New York Times Magazine, I explore new research that helps explain why most dieters who lose weight end up gaining it all back.

headline: Ask a Railroad Station Expert
text: As part of this week’s Q&A, David Naylor, an architectural historian and author of “Railroad Stations: The Buildings That Linked the Nation” (Norton), took readers’ questions on railroad stations. He is no longer taking questions.

headline: NYSE and Deutsche Borse Extend Merger Deadline
text: Deutsche Börse and NYSE Euronext have extended the deadline to complete their $9 billion proposed merger to March 31, amid resistance from European regulators.

headline: Williams Looking for Teammates and Continuity
text: One year ago Deron Williams was in his sixth season for the Utah Jazz, and his career was the picture of continuity.

headline: Design Flaws Cited in Deadly Train Crash in China
text: BEIJING — Chinese investigators delivered a long-awaited report on Wednesday on the deadly July 23 high-speed train crash in the eastern coastal city of Wenzhou, citing a string of blunders, including serious design flaws in crucial signaling equipment.

headline: Paul Comes to Iowa, Swinging
text: DES MOINES — As he arrives in Iowa today, Ron Paul is continuing to wage his expensive television campaign against Newt Gingrich and Mitt Romney with a new advertisement that dubs them part of “the Washington machine.”

headline: A Welcome Role Reversal
text: Generally speaking, children like their parents to be all-knowing and to fear nothing — they want them to be paragons of authority, capability and calm. Nonetheless, it can be hugely satisfying, reassuring even, to see Mom shriek at the sight of a mouse or Dad throw a tantrum over a traffic jam.

headline: Chasing Presidents in Blue Frye Boots
text: For more than 15 years, Helene Cooper, a White House correspondent for The New York Times, has followed American presidents and diplomats to places like Beijing, Tripoli, Kandahar and Jerusalem. Here, some packing wisdom from an international road warrior.

headline: Insider Travel Tips From Campaign Reporters
text: TRAVEL is one of the great perks of being a journalist — over the years, my job has taken me to places like Los Angeles, Paris and Saudi Arabia. But when I began covering Mitt Romney’s presidential bid five months ago as a member of The New York Times political team, I suddenly found myself shuffling through airport security several times a week.

headline: How to File an Auto Insurance Claim
text: The Consumer Federation of America estimates that more than 325,000 auto accidents will occur during this year’s holiday travel period, resulting in more than 200,000 claims filed with the nation’s insurance companies.

headline: The Israeli TV Report on Gender Segregation That Sparked Protest
text: As my colleague Isabel Kershner explains, an Israeli television report on a girl who was harassed by ultra-Orthodox men for not being dressed modestly enough sparked a protest against gender segregation on Tuesday night in the town on Beit Shemesh.

headline: Apropos Appropriation
text: ONE recent afternoon in the offices of the Midtown law firm run by David Boies and his powerful litigation partners, a large black clamshell box sat on a conference table. Inside were raucous, sometimes wildly funny collages of photographs and magazine pages handmade by the artist Richard Prince, works of art that have become the ur-texts of one of the most closely watched copyright cases ever to rattle the world of fine art.

headline: Big City Book Club: Up Next, Alfred Kazin
text: When the Big City Book Club reconvenes for its next online literary discussion on Jan. 10, we will be talking about Alfred Kazin’s “A Walker in the City,” the writer’s 1951 memoir of growing up in Brownsville, Brooklyn.

headline: Dark Days Behind It, Central Park Pulses at Night
text: For as long as most New Yorkers can remember, the rules have been clear: Enjoy Central Park by day. Keep out at night.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Cut 580 Jobs in New York
text: Morgan Stanley will slash 580 jobs in New York as part of a broader wave of layoffs underway at the bank, according to a public filing.

headline: Perry Hits Obama on Lack of Military Parade
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has plenty of criticism for President Obama on the campaign trail: he typically hits Mr. Obama for the decision to delay a major pipeline project, for the ballooning federal debt and for much, much more.

headline: Why Books Are Better Than e-Books for Children
text: Do you read to your children from your iPad or other device, or encourage them to use an e-reader to read to you? Many of us do, at least on occasion — even I, who wrote here some weeks ago that I rarely read on my own iPad anymore because I want my children to see me reading books, recommended an app for creating fun picture books for travel last week. If you have a tablet or e-reader, why not add it to your child’s reading repertory as well?

headline: After the Holiday Rush, Time for Reveries
text: Today, the lake is smoothly white at nearly noon, glowing in the pale winter sunshine, with grey-blue shadows of clouds stretched across its further reaches. Minute diamonds glitter from within the white snow on our sloping front field, crossed with long ski tracks and the wallows marking falls and wrestling sessions (with one’s inner ski-demon). Earlier this morning the wind on the lake blew up great billows of loose snow, but the air is still now. I thought I heard a snowmobile, which was a surprise since there really isn’t enough snow yet to ride out on one.

headline: Bishops Say Rules on Gay Parents Limit Freedom of Religion
text: Roman Catholic bishops in Illinois have shuttered most of the Catholic Charities affiliates in the state rather than comply with a new requirement that says they must consider same-sex couples as potential foster-care and adoptive parents if they want to receive state money. The charities have served for more than 40 years as a major link in the state’s social service network for poor and neglected children.

headline: The Best Jazz of 2011
text: Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen, jazz critics for The Times, discuss the best jazz artists and albums of the year.

headline: Ralph Rucci’s World, Times Two
text: YOU might expect a book on the designer Ralph Rucci to have a scholarly appreciation by the fashion historian Valerie Steele; swooning testimonials from society clients of Mr. Rucci’s like Deeda Blair and Susan Gutfreund; and romantic color plates of his high-wire dresses by a princeling photographer on the order of, say, Patrick Demarchelier.

headline: Stone Links
text: A gathering of recent philosophy-related links.

headline: Romney on Ayatollahs, and Parenthood
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Mitt Romney drew a standing-room-only crowd, with a line winding out the door, as the sun was still rising outside Elly’s Tea and Coffee House here Wednesday morning.

headline: A Day With the Bridges
text: The exercise routines and diets of Janice and Adam Bridges, who have lost about 165 and 110 pounds and struggle daily to keep the weight off.

headline: One More What-if for Jets Fans
text: The beleaguered, blustery coach of the Jets takes the podium for his midweek news conference, his team coming off a critical loss and facing depressingly long playoff odds of their own making. He faces down the skeptical news media, a glint of defiance in his eyes, firm resolve in his lower jaw, bear claw and stale coffee on his breath. He did not give the following speech, but the world would be a lot more fun if he had:

headline: Photographers Without Borders
text: var data;function jsonSlideshowCallback(response){data = response;}NYTD.options = {source: data,cropType: 'blog480',appendTo: 'fullScreenSlideShow',showHeadLine: 'false', renderstyle: "embeddedSlideShowTmag"}

headline: Donna Hanover to Make Broadway Debut in ‘Gore Vidal’s The Best Man’
text: As first lady of New York City during much of the 1990s, Donna Hanover – the former Mrs. Rudolph W. Giuliani – surely developed an opinion or two about the ferocity of the City Hall press corps. This spring, in an instance of art imitating life, she’ll have a chance to show what she thinks of the Fourth Estate when she makes her Broadway debut playing a presidential campaign reporter in the revival of “Gore Vidal’s The Best Man,” the producers announced on Wednesday.

headline: Pilot Got Permission to Fly Higher Just Before I-287 Crash
text: Updated 4:36 p.m. | Minutes before a single-engine plane crashed onto Interstate 287 in northern New Jersey last week, its pilot radioed air-traffic control to say that he was in “icing conditions” and requested clearance to climb higher, according to a preliminary report from the National Transportation Safety Board.

headline: More Views on Climate Risk and Arctic Methane
text: In trying to clarify what’s known, unknown and learnable about the possible contribution to global warming from vast methane deposits beneath Arctic seas, I reached out to a host of scientists working on this question. I also received a lot of reader input, as you can see from the comment threads in the string of posts on this important issue. Here’s a roundup of some additional views from the scientific community and one filmmaker focused on question:

headline: Apropos Appropriation
text: A key to the photo collage:

headline: Leaving Animals Out of the Cosmetics Picture
text: THE actress Kristin Bauer, of “True Blood” fame, has an annual ritual when she visits her family home in Racine, Wis.: She takes a black marker and scribbles on the sides of specific products and cosmetics, “Tested on animals.”

headline: 5 Businesses That Failed to Survive Trials of 2011
text: It has been another tough year for many small businesses. One in four, according to the National Federation of Independent Business, believes the biggest problem is weak sales. No matter what other challenges they face, said William Dunkelberg, the federation’s chief economist, “the key to everything is cash coming in the front door.”

headline: TimesCast | December 28, 2011
text: Mark Mazzetti on the death of Osama bin Laden and the impact on diplomacy with Pakistan | Ken Belson on Japan's nuclear disaster.

headline: Coming to Detroit Auto Show, a New Model That Mows Lawns
text: Features of the new CTX, to be introduced at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit next month, includes automatic traction control, electronic fuel management, cruise control and a console with cupholders. But it’s not a car or a truck: it’s a lawn tractor.

headline: At Funeral of Kim Jong-il, U.S.-Made Limos Stand Out
text: Kim Jong-il hated the United States. But an American carried him to the grave.

headline: Viacom Told to Pay $383 Million Over Rock Band Video Game
text: Viacom is disputing a decision by court-appointed arbitrators that it pay $383 million to the former shareholders of Harmonix Music Systems, the video game studio behind Rock Band and Guitar Hero.

headline: Scheduling Partnership Links Pac-12 and Big Ten
text: In a time of instability and uncertainty on the college sports landscape, the Pacific-12 and the Big Ten announced an innovative scheduling agreement Wednesday that links the two conferences and shows they have no imminent plans for change.

headline: Feoktistov’s Journal: Christmas, and a Game, in Vermont
text: We spent Christmas Day in Burlington, Vt. There wasn’t much to do, of course, as mostly everything was closed. We had another intense two-hour practice on Christmas, preparing for the tougher part of our journey beginning this week with games against three Division I college teams – the University of Vermont on Tuesday, Yale on Wednesday and Northern Michigan on Friday.

headline: Tracking Belgian Weapons in Libya
text: Watching the disintegration of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s military and government was in some ways like watching an arms show featuring more than a half-century of conventional weapons. During his decades in power, the Libyan leader and his generals amassed a vast store of weapons, stockpiling them across the desert nation in depots that, as Colonel Qaddafi lost his hold on power, changed hands. All manner of weapons were paraded out. (The colonel’s militias and military units, while they lasted, held on to much of the choice stock.)

headline: Lanterns Show an Industry’s Potential
text: KHADODA, India — In sunny India, the ideal would be to harness solar power for both the nation’s utility grid and for the rooftops of homes, businesses and factories.

headline: The Times E-Mails Millions by Mistake to Say Subscriptions Were Canceled
text: 7:02 p.m. | Updated The New York Times mistakenly sent an e-mail on Wednesday to more than eight million people who had shared their information with the company, erroneously informing them that they had canceled home delivery of the newspaper.

headline: In Solar Power, India Begins Living Up to Its Own Ambitions
text: KHADODA, India — Solar power is a clean energy source. But in this arid part of northwest India it can also be a dusty one.

headline: Magic Owner Breathes New Life Into Dwight Howard Rumor Mill
text: Dwight Howard’s time in Orlando is fleeting. Although Otis Smith, the Magic’s general manager, has stressed that there’s no urgency to deal Howard, the best big man in the game, it’s only a matter of time before Howard lands on some other team’s roster to cement that team’s future and delight its fans. Smith and the Magic will be left to pick up the pieces and reshape a franchise otherwise lacking in elite talent.

headline: Yankees Give Former Red Sox Reliever a Shot
text: Hideki Okajima joined the Boston Red Sox in 2007, the same year a far better known Japanese pitcher named Daisuke Matsuzaka became a member of the team. Matsuzaka was 15-12 that season and helped the Red Sox capture a World Series title, but Okajima was a significant contributor, too.

headline: Noise Level Rises Over Iran Threat to Close Strait of Hormuz
text: Iran and the United States elevated the belligerent tone between them on Wednesday over an Iranian vow to close the Strait of Hormuz, a vital Middle East waterway for oil tanker traffic, if Western powers attempted to make good on their threat to stifle Iran’s petroleum exports.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.28
text: A view of the day in sports included muddy cyclists, shadowy skiers and a controversial finish in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race.

headline: Agency Smackdown, Round 2: A Critique of  ‘the Nuclear Party’
text: The chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, whose four fellow commissioners complained about him to the White House, saying that he had been withholding information from them and wielding too much power, drew a spirited defense on Wednesday from a predecessor at the agency.

headline: Latinos Support Obama, Despite Deportation Policies
text: Although Latinos strongly disapprove of President Obama’s immigration policies, which have brought high numbers of deportations, they would favor him by wide margins over a Republican candidate in the presidential race, according to a poll released on Wednesday by the Pew Hispanic Center, a nonpartisan research group in Washington.

headline: What to Expect in White-Collar Crimes in 2012
text: The career of Robert G. Morvillo, the dean of the white-collar defense bar who died Saturday, highlights how white-collar crime has risen to prominence. His obituary in The New York Times pointed out that in 1973, when he founded a law firm specializing in the defense of executives and corporations in criminal cases, large New York firms shunned the practice because it was “considered déclassé.”

headline: 2011: The Death of Osama bin Laden
text: Mark Mazzetti assesses the death of Osama bin Laden and the repercussions for America’s relationship with Pakistan.

headline: 2011: Japan's Nuclear Disaster
text: Ken Belson takes a look at Japan’s failure to contain the Fukushima plant after the Tsunami.

headline: Ex-New Mexico Governor Seeks Libertarian Nod
text: SANTA FE, N.M. — Former Gov. Gary Johnson announced Wednesday that he was dropping his bid to become the Republican candidate for president and had decided instead to seek the Libertarian Party’s nomination.

headline: Same Old Songs Atop Billboard Chart
text: For the obsessives who keep close watch on the music charts, this time of year can be repetitive. Driven by holiday shopping, the same few hits tend to dominate week after week.

headline: Crosby’s Absence Causing New Concerns
text: Sidney Crosby, the Pittsburgh Penguins’ star captain, is a stealth presence these days. He is not on the ice at games or practices, and remains quite silent in the news media about what is going on with him. He sustained a concussion from two hard hits over a two-game span at the start of 2011 and was sidelined for nearly 11 months.

headline: ‘Occupy’ in Iowa Vows to Respect State’s Influential Role
text: DES MOINES — For the people who say they speak for Iowa’s 99 percent, protecting their state’s status as a political power broker is paramount.

headline: Oysters Rockefeller
text: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to broil oysters with a rich, herbal sauce.

headline: Video: How to Make Oysters Rockefeller
text: In this video, I demonstrate how to broil oysters with a rich, herbal Rockefeller sauce. Below is the recipe. If you don’t feel like shucking your own oysters but still want all the good, sweet flavors of shellfish swathed in garlic-caper-watercress butter, you can take a shortcut and make what I like to call Cheater’s Oysters Rockefeller.

headline: Italy’s Lower Rates Ease Borrowing but Not Governing
text: ROME — Financial market pressure on Italy eased temporarily on Wednesday, with borrowing rates on some government-issued debt dropping by half. But the political pressure on the government of Prime Minister Mario Monti remained high — and was rising.

headline: A Look Unanchored to the Past
text: IT takes a lot of moxie to hold your own on the air against a scarlet ibis, but Ann Curry has done just that, entertaining an extravagantly feathered guest earlier this year on the “Today” show, her own emerald dress a foil for its plumage.

headline: Commercial Introduces Gay Marriage as an Issue in the Iowa Caucuses
text: DES MOINES — The National Organization for Marriage, a leading social conservative group that is opposed to giving same-sex couples the right to marry, is striking out at Representative Ron Paul with a new television advertisement, a move intended to blunt the Texas congressman’s rise in the polls a few days before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Award Time for Ideas That Shine
