text: Yes, it’s the end of the year, and you know what that means: plucking shredded gift wrap off the rug, making New Year’s resolutions and learning to stop writing “2011” on personal checks.

headline: Paul Questions the U.S. Military Presence on Korean Peninsula
text: NEWTON, Iowa — Ron Paul on Wednesday questioned the United States’ long military presence on the Korean Peninsula even as the death of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-il raised concerns about the region’s stability.

headline: The Best Parties of 2011
text: The most memorable parties and events of 2011 featured in Scene City.

headline: Yankees Were Aware Rodriguez Sought Medical Treatment in Germany
text: When Alex Rodriguez informed the Yankees last month that he was interested in traveling to Germany to pursue a fairly new medical procedure, they were understandably concerned.

headline: Political Promotions in Russia Appear to Belie President’s Promise of Reform
text: MOSCOW — President Dmitri A. Medvedev has responded to the street protests in Moscow with proposals for political reform, but his recent personnel appointments seem to tell a different story: top posts went to former officers in the K.G.B. and long-serving loyalists of his political mentor, Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Problems of Reading Comprehension
text: Oy. David Adolfatto seems so determined to take a swipe at me that he can’t actually read straight.

headline: Women Shop, Men Stockpile
text: Stylish New Yorkers reflect on their wardrobe hoarding.

headline: Hollywood Copyright Dispute Still Flaring
text: LOS ANGELES — Anyone who thought the nasty legal fight between the Penske Media Corporation, owner of the Deadline.com Web site, and Prometheus Global Media, owner of The Hollywood Reporter, wouldn’t get nastier just wasn’t thinking.

headline: U.S. Pulls Public Relations Advisers From an Afghan Government Media Center
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Until this week, a little-noticed part of the United States’ war effort here included teaching Afghan officials the art of public relations — mainly, how to give news conferences — at an American-financed government information center.

headline: More On The Burden Of Debt
text: I suspect that I may have been too cryptic in my post on the real burden of debt. So let me give you a thought experiment that may help clarify matters.

headline: A Romantic Journey Through a Vanished Land
text: Maps are supposed to clarify, but the map of East Prussia at the start of Max Egremont’s “Forgotten Land: Journeys Among the Ghosts of East Prussia” is a muddling haze, with place names in German, Russian, Polish and Lithuanian and boundary lines that resemble a palimpsest.

headline: Care for Violet, New Friend for an Old Mate
text: Violet the red-tailed hawk is safe, but she is not likely to return to Washington Square Park, said Robert Horvath, a raptor rehabilitator with Wildlife in Need of Rescue and Rehabilitation, the nonprofit organization that is caring for the bird.

headline: 2011’s Top 10 Apps for Android Phones
text: In 2010, Android apps were rarely in the same league as their Apple counterparts, so beyond the entrants in last year’s Top 10 list, there was a steep drop-off in quality.

headline: President Obama and Hillary Clinton Top the List of Most Admired
text: Four years ago, Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton were battling each other for the Democratic presidential nomination. Now, Mrs. Clinton is President Obama’s secretary of state, and together they top the lists as the Gallup poll’s most admired woman and most admired man of 2011.

headline: Networks on Cruise Control With Post-Holiday Repeats
text: It was another low-key post-holiday night for television on Tuesday as the broadcast networks filled the schedule with more repeats. CBS was the No. 1 network over all in viewers and tied Univision for the top spot in the 18-to-49-year-old demographic.

headline: Montefiore Nurses May Strike on Jan. 10
text: In an unexpected move, nurses at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx said Wednesday that they would strike on Jan. 10 if they could not resolve issues involving staffing levels and salaries.

headline: Cable Channels Set to Begin Election Year Coverage
text: 5:17 p.m. | Updated America’s trifecta of cable news channels, Fox News, MSNBC and CNN, are just about ready to show off their election year staffs.

headline: Early-Adopter Pilots Drive Volts and Leafs
text: The first person to take delivery of a Chevrolet Volt was Jeff Kaffee, a retired airline pilot. Mr. Kaffee was only first in line. A number of other current or former pilots are owners of either the Volt or the Nissan Leaf.

headline: Rick Perry's Stump Speech
text: Dec. 27, 2011 - A sample of Rick Perry's final pitch to Iowa voters before the Jan. 3 caucus.

headline: Do You Know a Small Business That Failed This Year?
text: Even in good times, the survival rate for small businesses is discouraging — about half fail within five years, according to the Small Business Administration. Unfortunately, 2011 was another tough year. We’ve just published an article by Eileen Zimmerman about five businesses that didn’t make it. Behind every failed business, there’s a story.

headline: For Guys, a Great Find Is Often Multiplied
text: WOMEN shop, men stockpile. That’s one theory, anyway, of how men buy clothes differently from women. If women see shopping as an opportunity, a social or even therapeutic activity, the thinking goes, then men see it as a necessary evil, a moment to restock the supply closet.

headline: Leaders of New Play Institute Move From Arena Stage to Emerson College
text: In a boost to Emerson College’s ambitions to be a force in theater, the two leaders of the American Voices New Play Institute – an influential national player in conversations and research about playwriting – will move next year from Arena Stage in Washington to become part of ArtsEmerson, the Boston college’s two-year-old theater programming arm.

headline: Ruggiero, Women’s Hockey Pioneer, Retires
text: Angela Ruggiero, a four-time Olympian who played more games in a Team USA sweater than any other hockey player, announced her retirement from the United States Women’s National Team Program on Wednesday.

headline: The Cat Walk
text: Jackson Galaxy, a cat behaviorist and television personality, teaches The Times’s Stephanie Clifford how to walk her cat on a leash.

headline: Gingrich Ribs Romney at Iowa Chocolate Factory
text: ALGONA, Iowa — Sometimes the gods of campaign scheduling smile on you.

headline: Perry Further Refines Position on Abortion
text: INDIANOLA, Iowa — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Wednesday clarified his evolving position on abortion rights, saying that while he now favored a ban on abortions in cases of rape and incest, he still supported an exception in cases where a woman’s life would be at risk.

headline: Ready to Address the Hangover
text: AFTER a night of hard partying in Manhattan to celebrate his impending fatherhood, Alex Fleyshmakher woke up the next day with a roaring hangover.

headline: RokkCity
text: WHEN Culture Club, the 1980s-themed bachelorette haunt, relocated to Midtown, fans might have expected lots of Debbie Gibson and early Madonna. But Red Hot Chili Peppers and techno? Those are the sounds coming from RokkCity, a separate rock ’n’ roll-themed lounge that opened this month underneath the ’80s behemoth, in a bid for a younger crowd.

headline: Observers Confronted With Anger, Gunshots and a Dead Child in Syria
text: Updated | 8:26 p.m. On its second day of work in the Syrian city of Homs, a team of observers from the Arab League dodged bullets and was confronted by angry residents, who displayed the dead body of a child they said had been killed by government forces.

headline: Quail Hybridization in Mexico
text: Jennifer Gee, a biologist at the Claremont University Consortium and the University of California, Riverside, writes from the tropical dry forest near Álamos, Mexico, where she is studying Callipepla quail in collaboration with Jennifer Calkins.

headline: A Stone Farmhouse With Cottages in the Welsh Countryside
text: Formal gardens with a pagoda and a gazebo, and private fishing rights along a stretch of the River Dee.

headline: House Hunting in ... North Wales
text: A RESTORED FARMHOUSE AND FIVE HOLIDAY COTTAGES IN NORTH WALES

headline: New Iowa Poll May Understate Paul’s Support
text: I’m not always a big fan of dissecting individual polls — mostly because there are liable to be a plethora of them in Iowa and New Hampshire over the next several days and their errors will tend to be mitigated as more are added to the average.

headline: The 75 Things New Yorkers Talked About in 2011
text: IT was a year in which the words “till death do us part” took on new, life-changing meaning for thousands of gay New Yorkers and significantly less for one overexposed Kardashian.

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Korea, the West Bank, India and Iowa.

headline: App Smart Extra: Top 10 New iPhone Gaming Apps for 2011
text: I love video games as much as the next guy, as long as the next guy doesn’t spend hours a day grinding through the upper levels of Call of Duty or the latest Super Mario creation. So for casual mobile gamers, as promised in this week’s App Smart column, here’s a list of my top 10 new iPhone gaming apps for 2011.

headline: Mayor Says Crime Is Down in 2011, With an Asterisk
text: With only a few days left in the year, major crime in New York City has risen in 2011 — up less than 1 percent from the previous year, but up nonetheless, according to the latest Police Department data.

headline: Homes for $379,000
text: A two-bedroom condo in Louisville, K.Y., a four-bedroom house in Milwaukee, and a three-bedroom contemporary house in Portland, Ore.

headline: What You Get for ... $379,000
text: LOUISVILLE, KY.

headline: A Clearance on American Icons
text: “GIVE me some sugar,” Santamaria Liriano said last Friday, reaching out for a hug. “I’m going to miss you so much.”

headline: Deeply Hated, but Present: A U.S. Touch at Kim’s End
text: Kim Jong-il hated the United States. But an American carried him to the grave.

headline: Polonia Closes, an East Village Fixture
text: An East Village staple for 28 years, Polonia has closed after its landlord raised the rent more than threefold.

headline: Familiarity Breeds Hollywood Sequels
text: LOS ANGELES — Moviegoers might think of next summer as a test. The results will tell whether Hollywood should bother to have an original thought.

headline: Cuts in Grammys Draw Grumbling but Little Action
text: When the group that organizes the Grammy Awards abruptly announced last April that it was cutting nearly a third of the award categories and eliminating trophies for smaller genres like Latin jazz and zydeco, it did not take long for the protests to start.

headline: Romney Enjoys the Growing Crowds in Iowa
text: CLINTON, Iowa — Since landing in Iowa, Mitt Romney has been experiencing the problems of a candidate surging in polls — and they are not bad problems to have.

headline: Cunningham Fostered Serendipity in Set Design
text: Daniel Arsham was barely aware of Merce Cunningham in 2005, when he got a call telling him that he was being considered as the set designer for the next work by Cunningham’s dance company. Mr. Arsham was 25 and just two years out of art school at the Cooper Union. “I knew him from my studies,” he said recently, “but as a passing name.” A few months later Mr. Arsham — who at first didn’t even know the concept of “stage right” — was at work on the set for Cunningham’s 2007 piece “eyeSpace.”

headline: Could Age Be an Issue for Ron Paul?
text: DES MOINES — Is Ron Paul too old to be president?

headline: With Enough Winners, Skip the Esoterica
text: There are some deals, especially when one is looking at all 52 cards, that suggest a complicated line of play when there is a much simpler one available.

headline: The Houses of the Hopefuls
text: EVEN in an era of the two-year presidential campaign, with debates that seem to come as regularly as dinner, there remains that nagging question: never mind the packagers, handlers and strategists; what are these candidates really like? The hunt goes on for insights and stories to provide an unfiltered view of their true character.

headline: The Candidates’ Homes
text: Where Newt Gingrich, Representative Michele Bachmann, Mitt Romney and other G.O.P. candidates lay their heads.

headline: Onstage Memories: Concert Highs of 2011
text: Recordings are forever. Concerts — even in the era of YouTube and the tour-documentary DVD — are fleeting experiences, subject to many nonmusical variables. But they can transform reputations and careers. Here the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recap their most memorable performances of 2011, in order of importance.

headline: From North Korea, an Altered Procession
text: Postscript | In addition to the European Pressphoto Agency, both Reuters and Agence-France Presse transmitted the altered photograph shown above, at right, on Wednesday. The original Lens post, below, should have noted that E.P.A. was not the only agency to release the image. Both Reuters and A.F.P. issued a kill on the image after the Lens post was published. “Reuters strongly suspects that this handout picture from K.C.N.A. was manipulated at source,” Reuters noted in a picture kill notice transmitted Wednesday evening. A.F.P. sent a mandatory kill statement over the wire on Thursday. “This picture was altered from the source and not by A.F.P.,” the statement read.

headline: Fire Pits
text: Winter is the season of the fire pits, those vessels, often made of ceramic or iron and fueled by wood or gas, that lovers of the outdoors set up in chilly weather for heat and light and charm. Joe Doucet, an industrial designer based in New York City and an admirer of the bowls, owns a house upstate that sits on 10 acres. He’s thinking about incorporating such a pit into the landscape.

headline: Shopping for Fire Pits
text: Joe Doucet, an industrial designer, searched for fire pits to set up in chilly weather.

headline: Pulls and Knobs With an Artisan’s Touch
text: Liberty Hardware of Winston-Salem, N.C., is best known for mass-produced cabinet knobs, pulls and hooks that are carried by major retailers. But for its latest collection, called HomeGrown Hardware, the company has joined with artisans on a range of items like the iron rings pictured.

headline: In Mexico City, a Design Playhouse
text: When DFC first appeared six years ago, this decorative-accessories company stood out for over-the-top designs that were not traditionally tasteful and did not play to any trends. Now its goods — made in Mexico with age-old techniques that often lead to unconventional results — are on display at DFC’s first store, in Mexico City.

headline: Nine Lives, One Leash
text: THERE are outdoor cats and there are indoor cats. When I brought home Mac, a 4-year-old orange tabby, from a shelter last year, I realized I had acquired a demanding combination of the two.

headline: Sales at Artemide, the MoMA Store and Others
text: Gus Modern will take 15 percent off furniture and accessories in January (the Atwood sectional, pictured, originally $3,199, will be about $2,719; the Carmichael Loft sofa, normally $1,999, about $1,699); gusmodern.com.

headline: Ceramics That Are Imperfect on Purpose
text: Ayumi Horie developed a technique for making earthenware pieces without water while she was a student at Alfred University in western New York State. Today, this 42-year-old potter creates plates and bowls using the nontraditional method because it “allows for spontaneity and a kind of gestural quality that is harder to get when clay is wet.”

headline: An Indian Writer Finds His Anchor on the Reservation
text: When David Treuer was offered a teaching job at the University of Southern California last year, he made a promise to himself before accepting and moving his family from Minneapolis to the West Coast: He would keep a home — “an anchor,” as he put it — on the Leech Lake Indian Reservation in northern Minnesota, where he grew up.

headline: Market Ready
text: Q. My apartment has plenty of closets but no room for a desk. Would converting a closet into a home office help me sell the place?

headline: Saying Shhh! to a Squeaky House
text: JAPANESE royalty once built homes with floors so squeaky that no intruder could evade detection.

headline: A Lamp for Art Lovers
text: Ronan Bouroullec said that the new Piani lamp that he and his brother, Erwan, have designed can draw attention to art the way a pedestal does. “I think this could be a lamp for a collector,” he said, “someone who collects very nice small objects and can display something beautiful under the light. Maybe a small Inuit sculpture.”

headline: In Costa Rica, Palms, Tiles and Cane
text: Islita, Costa Rica

headline: Local Authenticity in a Slice of Costa Rica
text: A Dallas couple used local materials, like dried palm leaves, in their multi-building home on the Pacific coast.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., S.E.C. Pressed Groupon on Accounting
text: Ahead of Groupon‘s highly anticipated initial public offering in November, the Securities and Exchange Commission repeatedly pressed the daily deals giant to defend its business model and its accounting measures, according to comment letters recently disclosed.

headline: News Is Good for Santorum and Bad for Gingrich in New Polls
text: New polls in Iowa and New Hampshire suggest that Newt Gingrich is losing support in both states while Rick Santorum is gaining traction in Iowa and Mitt Romney is solidifying his lead in New Hampshire.

headline: Baylor Basks in Heisman’s Glow
text: Robert Griffin III figures that the reality of his winning the Heisman Trophy will truly sink in sometime after Thursday night’s Alamo Bowl against Washington. But after he returned to Baylor’s campus in Waco, Tex., following the award ceremony in New York and watched video montages of the reaction to his victory, he quickly understood that his achievement would reach far beyond the statue.

headline: Third-Party Groups Are Gearing Up in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Iowa mailboxes and airwaves are already thick with advertisements paid for by super PACs closely aligned with individual candidates, like the pro-Romney Restore Our Future and the pro-Perry Make Us Great Again.

headline: Romney Turns to Supporters He Considers a Natural: Business Leaders
text: CLINTON, Iowa — Kenneth Maass, a farmer in Remsen, Iowa, keeps a busy schedule: monthly meetings for the Plymouth County Farm Bureau, for the Northwest Rural Electric Cooperative and for his church, a Lutheran congregation where he serves as chairman. At each of these get-togethers, Mr. Maass, 75, makes a point of extolling what he sees as Mitt Romney’s many virtues.

headline: Prediction: You Will Meet Many Jaydens and Isabellas
text: This makes three in a row for Jayden. Two straight (and three out of four) for Isabella. More disturbing news for Michael and Ashley.

headline: A Haven for Dissent in Bahrain, Where Lattes and Tear Gas Mix
text: MANAMA, Bahrain — The police cars were lined up across the street, staking out a hub of subversive activity. Their focus was not some underworld hangout, but a coffee shop, Costa Coffee, in a shopping mall.

headline: Toxic Coffee in Bahrain
text: A coffee shop serves as a makeshift command center for some opposition leaders of Bahrain's stumbling pro-democracy movement. As a result, police often attack it with tear gas.

headline: On Trail, Gingrich Strains to Show Nice-Guy Side
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Concluding a luncheon speech here to a Rotary Club, Newt Gingrich held his arms out to his sides and unleashed a most un-Newt-like gesture to his audience: a pantomime of a big group embrace.

headline: Jennison’s Jayhawkers
text: In a December 1861 letter to his sister, the Union soldier Daniel B. Holmes wrote that he and his fellow members of the Seventh Kansas Cavalry lived “quite well, not from what we draw from the commissary but what we jayhawked.”

headline: Bipartisan Agreement: Obama Isn’t Schmoozing
text: WASHINGTON — Air Force One had just landed in Manchester, N.H., on a brisk Tuesday morning last month when President Obama made an admission to Valerie B. Jarrett, his close friend and senior adviser.

headline: E*Trade’s Baby Creates the Most Online Buzz
text: MARKETERS take many approaches to selling their products, from fake talking babies to real rap stars in commercials. But for many, generating the elusive online buzz is the ultimate goal.

headline: Violence Flares in Syria Despite Observers’ Visit
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violence continued to flare in the Syrian city of Homs on Wednesday, despite the presence of Arab League observers who are supposed to be monitoring a withdrawal of government forces from the city.

headline: Despite RIM Takeover Talk, Hurdles Would Be High
text: OTTAWA — For beleaguered investors in Research in Motion, the drastic collapse of the company’s share price through 2011 eventually became a cause for optimism. In December, shares of the BlackBerry maker spiked on reports that several technology titans could be suitors.

headline: The Year in Live Pop
text: The pop and jazz critics of The New York Times recapped their most memorable performances of 2011.

headline: Truth and Facebook
text: To the Editor:

headline: Billionaire Shifts Attention From Mets to Dodgers
text: Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire hedge-fund manager, explored buying a minority stake in the Mets earlier this year. Now he wants to buy all of another marquee franchise, the Los Angeles Dodgers.

headline: In Challenging S.E.C. Settlement, a Judge in Wisconsin Cites a Court in New York
text: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Wisconsin has challenged the Securities and Exchange Commission over a proposed settlement of fraud charges against a publicly traded company, citing as a precedent the agency’s pending case against Citigroup.

headline: The Jury’s Duty When the Law Is Unfair
text: To the Editor:

headline: Homeless Veterans
text: To the Editor:

headline: Kirk Douglas on Trumbo
text: To the Editor:

headline: Verizon’s Cable Agreements: A Boon to Competition
text: To the Editor:

headline: Gingrich Campaign Says It Has Raised Almost $9 Million
text: LE MARS, Iowa — Newt Gingrich’s campaign said on Wednesday that it had raised close to $9 million in the last quarter of the year, a significant improvement over the six-figure sum it raised over the summer, reflecting a flood of small donors who responded to Mr. Gingrich’s debate performances and propelled his surge to the top of polls this month.

headline: Giants Have Home Field, but It’s Been a Disadvantage
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For the Giants, Sunday’s prime-time game against the Dallas Cowboys should be a dream scenario: home-field advantage and needing only a win to make the playoffs. Instead, MetLife Stadium could be a setting where Giants fans may be reaching for a bottle of Pepto-Bismol or a stiff brew.

headline: Romney Jabs at Paul, Who Strikes Iowa Chord
text: DES MOINES — Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign swept confidently through Iowa on Wednesday, beginning a three-day bus tour and raising questions about the national security positions of Ron Paul, whose libertarian-leaning small government message appears to have struck a chord with Republican voters here.

headline: Weapons Sales to Iraq Move Ahead Despite U.S. Worries
text: BAGHDAD — The Obama administration is moving ahead with the sale of nearly $11 billion worth of arms and training for the Iraqi military despite concerns that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki is seeking to consolidate authority, create a one-party Shiite-dominated state and abandon the American-backed power-sharing government.

headline: Los Angeles Vote to Decide on Condoms in Sex Films
text: LOS ANGELES — Come June, voters here will have a chance to cast their ballots in the presidential primary. Along with their presidential preferences, they will be asked to decide whether actors in pornographic films should be required to wear condoms.

headline: Romney’s Iowa Office Draws Protesters
text: Seven protesters were arrested outside Mitt Romney’s campaign office in Des Moines on Wednesday afternoon, in the first of what the local Occupy movement says will be a week of demonstrations leading up to the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Instead of Work, Younger Women Head to School
text: Workers are dropping out of the labor force in droves, and they are mostly women. In fact, many are young women. But they are not dropping out forever; instead, these young women seem to be postponing their working lives to get more education. There are now — for the first time in three decades — more young women in school than in the work force.

headline: On Staten Island, a Team Resurfaces as Relevant
text: Dan Hurley did not give his team much time to savor its first victory over a ranked opponent in 33 years. By 11:30 a.m. Tuesday, Wagner’s holiday was over and another relentless two-hour practice was under way.

headline: China: Strike at a Korean Factory
text: About 8,000 workers at an electronics factory in the southern city of Nanjing have been on strike this week against what they call low wages from their South Korean employers, according to a statement on Tuesday by China Labor Watch, an advocacy group based in the United States. Caijing, a Chinese newsmagazine, reported some details of the strike on Wednesday. The workers are angry that their year-end bonus equals only a month’s pay, while Korean workers are getting a year-end bonus equal to six months’ salary, according to the statement from the labor group. The strike began Monday. On Wednesday afternoon, according to Reuters, there were indications that workers might accept an offer by employers of two months’ salary as a bonus. The factory makes electronics for a unit of LG Group, a South Korean company.

headline: What We Think About When We Think About the Court
text: Wherever I go these days, someone is bound to ask me how I think the Supreme Court will rule in the challenge to the Affordable Care Act, set for argument over three days during the last week in March. My response, that I expect the court to uphold the law, predictably evokes an expression of disbelief verging on pity for my display of such naïveté. “Won’t the justices just vote their politics?” my questioner invariably asks.

headline: MF Global Scrutinized on Money Move
text: Federal authorities investigating the demise of MF Global think that the firm began improperly moving customer money to a middleman on Oct. 27, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Russia: Jet Skids Off Runway
text: A Russian-made passenger jet of a type that is known to be accident-prone skidded off a runway and caught fire on Wednesday while landing in fog in Osh, Kyrgyzstan, injuring about 31 people. After another jet of that type, a Tupolev, crashed in Russia last June, killing 44 people, President Dmitri A. Medvedev said most of the airplanes should be taken out of service by Jan. 1.

headline: Before a Funeral, Rending Choices on How Best to Tell the Stories of 3 Short Lives
text: In any other context, the choices might seem trivial: purple flowers or pink, this family photo or that one, large teddy bear or small.

headline: Jets Upbeat Knowing They Need a Victory and Lots of Help
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Facing one of the most important games of his career — even for someone who has played in two A.F.C. championships — Mark Sanchez on Wednesday summoned his past. From ski cap to warm-up pants, Sanchez wore red and black, the colors of his alma mater, Mission Viejo High School.

headline: 14 Muslim Leaders Plan Boycott of Breakfast With Mayor
text: A group of Muslim leaders plans to boycott Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s annual interfaith breakfast on Friday to protest what it calls the unfair surveillance of Muslims by the New York Police Department.

headline: Oakland’s Mayor Wrestles With Occupy Movement
text: The first woman and first Asian American mayor of Oakland, Calif., Jean Quan, has been criticized for her handling of the Occupy Oakland movement.

headline: Oakland’s Reins Blister a Mayor Raised on Protest
text: OAKLAND, Calif. — Days after Jean Quan was elected mayor in the fall of 2010, the Oakland police put a wheel clamp on her silver Prius while it was parked outside City Hall. She cursed her husband for not paying the family’s parking tickets and braced for the embarrassing news articles.

headline: City Schools Missing Out on Aid for Special Needs
text: New York City has failed to recover tens of millions of dollars in Medicaid reimbursements for services it provided to special-needs students in recent years, as the Education Department has struggled to adapt to new rules imposed after a devastating federal audit forced the city to return money it received for claims it could not properly document.

headline: Oil Prices Predicted to Stay Above $100 a Barrel Through Next Year
text: The United States economy managed to cope this year despite triple-digit prices for barrels of oil. The lessons may come in handy, economists say, because those prices will probably be sticking around.

headline: Iraq: Exiles to Leave Camp
text: About 400 members of an Iranian exile group agreed Wednesday to leave a camp in eastern Iraq, another step in international efforts to end a tense, sometimes violent, impasse between Iraq’s government and the 3,400 people inside Camp Ashraf. The plan would move the residents to a former American military base in Baghdad, where they would ultimately relocate outside Iraq. The camp is populated by members of the Mujahedeen Khalq, or People’s Mujahedeen, a group that has fought in years past to bring down the Iranian government. The Iraqi government wants to close the camp. On Wednesday night, three rockets struck the camp, but there were no immediate reports of casualties, Iraqi security officials said.

headline: Iowa State Has Found a Stabilizing Presence
text: Early Tuesday night, Iowa State football coach Paul Rhoads peered through the glass panes of a suite at Yankee Stadium and witnessed yet another first in a three-year run filled with breakthroughs. Before a Pinstripe Bowl dinner, his players were given a tour of the majestic ballpark, where they will play Rutgers on Friday.

headline: Top Bachmann Aide in Iowa to Support Paul
text: DES MOINES — The top Iowa adviser to Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota announced Wednesday night that he was jumping ship to support the candidacy of Representative Ron Paul of Texas.

headline: A Future Memo From Goldman
Lottery Numbers
Scott Stringer to Dennis Walcott on Medicaid
text: Letter from the Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, to Schools Chancellor Dennis M. Walcott criticizing the city for failing to consistently apply for Medicaid reimbursements.

headline: New York City Principals’ Union on SESIS
text: An article from the principals’ union December newsletter listing problems with the education department’s database for its special education program, the Special Education Student Information System (SESIS).

headline: New York State Dept. of Health Letter to Dept. of Education
text: Letter from the New York State Department of Health to the New York City Department of Education alerting of the city’s use of the wrong form to apply for reimbursement for speech therapy services.

headline: My Dad and I Walked Into a Bar …
text: Most regulars at neighborhood bars come by their nicknames through easily distinguishable physical qualities (Goiter Eddie, Curly Pat, Jimmy the Hat, One-Arm Joe). If that fails, a nickname can be created on the basis of ethnic origin (English Billy, Irish Mike), or a profession (Eddie the Actor, Rodger the Dodger — a defense attorney). But in the entire history of nicknaming, there was only one regular called “Tara’s Father,” and that was my dad.

headline: Corrections: December 29
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: The Year in Questions
text: A quiz to test your memory of the memes like the stories that you find in the pages of The Times.

headline: Dan Fouts, the Man Before Brees and Marino
text: When Drew Brees completed his final throw Monday night against the Atlanta Falcons to give him 5,087 passing yards this season, he broke Dan Marino’s 27-year-old N.F.L. record.

headline: Thursday: They Can Be Batted and Rolled
text: THURSDAY’S PUZZLE — When was the last time you sat down to a good game of Scrabble? David Steinberg is back today, and he has a word challenge for us that will make us really think. I’m going to reveal it after the jump, so if you are still solving, come back when you’re done.

headline: Women Departing Labor Force
text: The percentage of young women enrolled in school now exceeds that in the labor force.

headline: The Part-Time Job That Left Him Laid Low by Fraud
text: It is hard to imagine John Parker working as a bouncer. He is soft-spoken and easygoing, more teddy bear than bruiser.

headline: Getting Ahead in Dharavi
text: As many as a million people live and work in Dharavi, a sprawling slum in Mumbai, India.

headline: An Industrial Slum at the Heart of Mumbai
text: Dharavi may no longer be Asia’s — or even Mumbai’s — biggest slum, but it is still its most iconic. By some estimates, the slum is home to one million people in an area about two-thirds of Manhattan’s Central Park. Land that once was on the outskirts of Mumbai has now been swallowed by the city and has been subject to multiple rehabilitation attempts since the 1970s.

headline: In One Slum, Misery, Work, Politics and Hope
text: MUMBAI, India — At the edge of India’s greatest slum, Shaikh Mobin’s decrepit shanty is cleaved like a wedding cake, four layers high and sliced down the middle. The missing half has been demolished. What remains appears ready for demolition, too, with temporary walls and a rickety corrugated roof.

headline: Feel Free to Ignore Iowa
text: Only days until the Iowa caucuses! Can you believe it? Less than 8,000 minutes to go!

headline: As Winter Classic Approaches, Rangers Slump to Loss
text: WASHINGTON — The Rangers insisted they were not looking ahead to the next week’s Winter Classic. All of those HBO cameras filming their every move had not swelled their heads.

headline: Republicans Shake More Hands Using Social Media
text: When Iowans search for information on politics on the Web, Mitt Romney’s tutorial on how to caucus pops up.

headline: Newest Knick Out to Prove He’s Not Just a Novelty
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Jeremy Lin’s 18-month ride through the N.B.A. could best be described as exhilarating, emotional, stressful, agonizing and sobering, more or less in that order.

headline: Marching Orders for Paul’s Volunteers: Do Shave, Don’t Tweet
text: DES MOINES — Ron Paul’s college-aged volunteer army — a core of the powerful ground organization that is the envy of rivals — is descending on Iowa from around the nation to coax people to the state’s Republican caucuses as he seeks to pull off what only months ago seemed like an unthinkable victory here on Tuesday.

headline: Adrienne Cooper, Yiddish Singer, Dies at 65
text: Adrienne Cooper, an American-born singer, teacher and curator of Yiddish music who was a pioneer in the effort to keep the embers of that language smoldering for newer generations, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 65.

headline: Justice and Prosecutorial Misconduct
text: Michael Morton was exonerated by DNA evidence this month after being wrongfully convicted of murdering his wife and serving nearly 25 years in prison in Texas. In seeking to prove Mr. Morton’s innocence, his lawyers found in recently unsealed court records evidence that the prosecutor in the original trial, Ken Anderson, had withheld critical evidence that may have helped Mr. Morton.

headline: Satyadev Dubey, Playwright Who Modernized Hindi Theater, Dies at 75
text: Satyadev Dubey, a producer, director and playwright who inspired generations of Indian actors and other playwrights, died on Sunday in Mumbai. He was 75.

headline: Another Year for Weapons
text: The F.B.I. reports that gun dealers submitted the names of almost half-a-million customers in the six days before Christmas, with December on its way to surpassing November, which had a record tally of 1,534,414 names submitted for background checks for criminal convictions and mental health issues. Only a little more than 1 percent of buyers are typically rejected by federally licensed gun dealers. No one knows how many more firearms were purchased through the gun-show loophole that enables black marketeering.

headline: Whose Welfare?
text: When will the Internal Revenue Service crack down on the secret political money already flooding the 2012 campaign from partisan operatives ludicrously claiming to be “social welfare” activists under the tax law?

headline: About Those Gift Cards
text: As you ponder your holiday haul, it is time to consider the particular oddity of the gift card. Four out of five American consumers bought gift cards this holiday season, according to the National Retail Federation. Spending on the cards jumped to $27.8 billion, a 10 percent gain from 2010.

headline: The Caucus | The Ron Paul Army Mobilizes
text: Dec. 29. 2011 - The presidential campaign for the Texas congressman is bringing in volunteers from around the country to organize voters in Iowa.

headline: Should Lori Berenson Go Back to Peru?
text: Many Peruvians think the U.S. citizen jailed for aiding Marxist insurgents won't finish her sentence. Some Americans feel she has served her time.

headline: A Conversation With: Yoko Ono
text: Artist Yoko Ono brings her first-ever show to India in mid-January, a multi-city tour titled “Our Beautiful Daughters” that is expected to include a live performance and brand-new work created just for India. Ms. Ono’s last visit to India was in the 1970s, when she came with husband John Lennon.

headline: An Indian Government Success: Solar Power
text: While the Indian government has missed many of its development goals in recent years, there is one area where it is on track: harnessing solar power.

headline: What We Can Learn From Old Animals
text: It is not hard to argue that we live in a youth-centric culture, one in which young age and beauty are almost synonymous. And that obsession does not end with humans. Puppies and kittens melt hearts; images and videos of baby animals flood the Internet. But rarely does an image of an animal in old age ignite the same interest and adoration.

headline: Bloggingheads: North Korea’s Choice
text: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com debate the future of North Korea.

headline: Ron Paul’s World
text: Earlier this week, Newt Gingrich, the former House speaker, said that he would not vote for his fellow presidential candidate Ron Paul should Paul become the Republican nominee. The immediate cause of this dissension – highly unusual in a party primary – was the repugnant newsletters that Paul published from the late 1970s until the mid-1990s, which contain a raft of bigoted statements. Paul has denied authorship and implausibly claims not to know who wrote them.

headline: In Dharavi: Misery, Work, Politics and Hope
text: Jim Yardley examines the multi-layered reality of India’s largest slum, Mumbai’s Dharavi, in the latest installment of India’s Way.

headline: At Huge Rally, North Koreans Declare Kim Their Leader
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The declaration on Thursday that Kim Jong-un is now the “supreme leader” of North Korea was an emotional turning point for the hermetic country — reaffirming support for the young heir after nearly two weeks of national mourning for his father, Kim Jong-il.

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/29/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/29/2011

headline: Knicks’ Strengths Vanish, and So Do Hopes of Winning
text: OAKLAND — Carmelo Anthony would have saved the Knicks with a timely jumper, if only he could have made any. Tyson Chandler might have saved them with a timely rebound or blocked shot, if only he could have stayed on the court.

headline: From Dharavi, Another View of India
text: For much of the past year, our reporters in India have been doing some deep-dive reporting for a series we’ve called “India’s Way.” Today, we’re publishing a long piece by Jim Yardley about the Dharavi slum in Mumbai. We hope to publish another article in a few days about private education in India, and one or two others early next year.

headline: The Year in Questions
text: Like a circle in a spiral, like a wheel within a wheel, never-ending news is spooling off a never-ending reel ... Now a quiz is set to test you and your memory of the memes ...

headline: Peace? Process?
text: MOUNT GILBOA, Israel — Having spent Hanukkah seeing more friends this year than usual, I was able to canvass our conversations for a fair number of topics beyond kids, health, real estate and other standard catching-up fare.

headline: Q&A: Publishing Your Own E-Book
text: Q.

headline: Borghese Treasures Return to Rome
text: When Napoleon acquired 695 ancient statues from the Borghese family collection in 1807, flabbergasted contemporaries called the act “an indelible shame.” The collection was born two centuries earlier when Cardinal Scipione Borghese, nephew of Pope Paul V, made it his life’s work to bring together the masterpieces available to him. He assembled more than 2,000 pieces, including antique statues, sculptures by Bernini and canvases by Raphael, Caravaggio and Titian.

headline: Mike Pereira Is ‘Not a Fan’ of Jon Gruden
text: When he was the overseer of officials for the N.F.L., Mike Pereira frequently fielded calls from angry coaches who wanted explanations for calls that went against them. Bill Belichick once saw him and sympathetically told him he looked run-down. “You never win, do you?” Belichick said, according to Pereira.

headline: The Early Word: Seesaw
text: In Today’s Times:Hundreds of Ron Paul’s college-age volunteers descended on the Hawkeye State on Wednesday with barely a week left until the Iowa caucuses. Richard A. Oppel Jr. writes that members of Mr. Paul’s “army” arrived under a cloak of secrecy and with strict rules for comportment as they prepare to coax likely caucus-goers into voting for Mr. Paul, a 76-year-old veteran Texas congressman who is drawing supporters for his libertarian and antiwar views.

headline: Week 17 N.F.L. Probabilities: Importance of Seeding
text: The path into the playoffs for the Giants is clear enough. Win and they’re in as the N.F.C. East champion. The Jets’ path to an A.F.C. wild card is much more complicated, and more dependent on the fortunes of other teams, including the Bengals, the Titans, the Broncos and the Raiders. The only other unsettled playoff berth is the A.F.C. West championship, which will go to  the Broncos or Raiders.

headline: Recipes for the Semi-Vegan
text: Many vegan dishes, like fruit salad and peanut butter and jelly, are already beloved. However, the problem faced by many of us is in imagining less-traditional vegan dishes that are interesting and not challenging. Here are some more creative options to try.

headline: The Electric Current Fizz
text: Vigorously shake over ice:

headline: The Perfect Hair of the Dog
text: It is sometimes the case that on the morning of Jan. 1, I arise bleary-eyed from a brief sleep with those famous final words of Beckett’s “Unnamable” on my mind: “You must go on, I can’t go on, I’ll go on.” Fortunately, I’m not reflecting on the whole messy enterprise of life itself. I’m concerned with drinking. Can I, should I, really keep going after a season of festive drinking that ended a little too festively?

headline: No Meat, No Dairy, No Problem
text: Among your other resolutions — do more good? make more money? — you’ve probably made the annual pledge to eat better, although this concept may be more often reduced simply to “lose some weight.” The weight-loss obsession is both a national need and a neurotic urge (those last five pounds really don’t matter, either cosmetically or medically). But most of us do need to eat “better.”

headline: The Year When Rock Just Spun Its Wheels
text: Every week since the end of May the band Sublime With Rome has had at least one song, sometimes two, on Billboard’s Rock Songs chart or its Hot Modern Rock Tracks chart, often both. The most successful have been “Panic” and “Take It or Leave It,” both true to the band’s mission to reincarnate the band Sublime, whose singer, Brad Nowell, died in 1996, and whose ska-lite Sublime With Rome both covers and, in its originals, shamelessly apes.

headline: Carrie Brownstein, Riot Grrrnup
text: Carrie Brownstein, the exuberant pixie rocker, says that if she had to live as one of the characters on her cult-hit sketch comedy series, “Portlandia,”­ she’d be Toni, the depressed and passively sadistic feminist bookstore owner. This is not an obvious choice. Best known for her guitar heroics in Sleater-Kinney and, more recently, in her third band, Wild Flag, Brownstein, 37, is often found wearing bright red lipstick, a fashionable shag and skinny jeans. Toni, by contrast, favors burlap sacks and never smiles.

headline: Stratfor Hackers Claim Another Attack
text: Hackers who said they attacked Stratfor Global Intelligence service, a security research group based in Austin, Tex., over the weekend have claimed a second target: Special Forces, a veterans-owned Web site that sells military-inspired merchandise and gives away a portion of profits to charity.

headline: The Puzzle of Rising Methane
text: In an article the other day about thawing permafrost, I mentioned that no signal had emerged in the atmosphere to suggest a sharp rise in methane emissions from the Arctic. But that does not mean all is stable with methane in the air — quite the contrary, in fact.

headline: Google+ Gains Traction, Researcher Says
text: Google’s mission to compete with Facebook in social networking may be gaining speed.

headline: China Proceeds on Plan for Disputed Yangtze Dam
text: BEIJING — The Chinese State Council has removed a crucial roadblock to building one of the nation’s most contentious hydroelectric dams, dealing a decisive defeat to environmentalists critical of the project — and showcasing the clout of one of the most powerful and ambitious politicians in China.

headline: 2 Are Killed by an Afghan in Uniform
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — For the second time in a week, a man wearing an Afghan Army uniform attacked NATO personnel on Thursday, this time gunning down two members of the French Foreign Legion in eastern Afghanistan before being fatally shot.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Occupy Geeks and Electronics in the Air
text: Here’s what the tech reporters and editors of The New York Times found on the Web:

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 29
text: If at first you succeed. … The list of the top-grossing films of 2011 is, more or less, a list of sequels, starting with the top film, “Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2,” which is the final sequel in a long series. Those results are a product of “a flight to financial safety that has been building for a decade,” Michael Cieply writes. It appears that 2012 will not be so different, with the major studios planning about 10 sequels or “reboots” (that is, a familiar series that begins again, from the top).

headline: Lokpal in the Rajya Sabha: Who Hates What
text: Deliberations were heated Thursday in India’s Rajya Sabha, or upper house of Parliament, over the Lokpal bill, which would create an anti-corruption body of ombudsmen in India. The United Progressive Alliance, or U.P.A., does not have a majority in the Rajya Sabha, unlike in the Lok Sabha, so the bill will have a more difficult time passing.

headline: European Fiscal Zombies
text: Dean Baker is unhappy at seeing yet another article asserting as fact something that is actually just something fiscal hawks imagine: the claim that Europe’s problem economies were running up government debt before the crisis.

headline: Arab League Visit Has Led to More Violence in Syria, Activists Say
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian security forces opened fire on demonstrators in a Damascus suburb on Thursday morning, activists said, killing several people and dashing hopes that Arab League observers might help stem the bloodshed.

headline: The Best in Men’s
text: The roundup of our favorite stories of 2011 in men’s fashion.

headline: How Dallas Should Attack Giants’ Pass Defense
text: Jonathan Bales is the founder of DallasCowboysTimes.com, a site dedicated to film study and statistical analysis of the Cowboys.

headline: The Best They Have To Offer
text: My Campaign Stops column this week finds something nice to say about every candidate for the G.O.P. nomination:

headline: The Unspoken Diagnosis: Old Age
text: Dr. Alexander K. Smith is a brave man.

headline: Bucking Solar Predictions, India Surprises Itself
text: When the Indian government embarked on an ambitious solar power project two years ago, I wrote that its goals seemed farfetched. Since then, things have changed significantly, and as I note in Thursday’s paper, analysts say the project’s goal of having 20,000 megawatts of solar capacity by 2020 seems well within reach.

headline: Thursday Reading: Your Body Is Trying to Keep You Fat
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: Daily Report: A Legal Battle Over a Twitter User’s Identity
text: Twitter once again finds itself at the center of a conflict over the right to anonymity on the Web, this time in a case involving a sympathizer with the Boston offshoot of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

headline: A Warm Update to a Chilly Arctic Ballad
text: [On Sept. 3, 2016, the second of the two Franklin expedition ships lost in the Arctic was located in a remote bay.]

headline: Turkish Airstrikes Kill Smugglers Mistaken for Kurdish Separatists
text: ISTANBUL — The Turkish military said Thursday that it had accidently killed at least 35 Turkish cigarette smugglers in airstrikes after mistaking them for separatist fighters in the Kurdish border region with Iraq, infuriating many of Turkey’s long-oppressed Kurds. Most of the dead were between 17 and 20 years old.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Details: Tips from mixologists on how the home bartender can try to master a few of those cocktails made with egg whites. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: Bitter Twist in Louisiana Family’s Long Drilling Fight
text: ERATH, La. — It began as a landlord-tenant dispute, Louisiana style.

headline: Teenage Obesity Linked to Poor Mother-Child Bond
text: Researchers from Ohio State University analyzed data from a study following nearly 1,000 children from infancy through the ninth grade and found that children who were “insecurely attached” or otherwise showed signs of a poor maternal relationship before age 3 were more likely to be obese at 15.

headline: Where Credit Is Due, and Eagerly Taken
text: It is the nature of politicians and bureaucrats to summon microphone- and pencil-holders when they have good news and to content themselves with, at best, a printed statement — issued perhaps at 6 p.m. on a Friday after everyone has gone home — when developments reflect poorly on them. That the public has a stake in tidings both glad and sad is usually ignored as an inconvenient detail.

headline: Polarizing Leader Fades Into the Twilight
text: The best thing about “The Iron Lady” may be that viewers going into the theater with strong views, pro or con, about its subject, the former British prime minister Margaret Thatcher, are likely to emerge in a state of greater ambivalence, even confusion. Those who know or care little about her will also be confused, but for different reasons.

headline: In Cheetah Mystery, Florida Sanctuary Stands by Its Chimp
text: A Florida animal sanctuary on Thursday stood by its claim that a chimpanzee that died there over the weekend was featured in the classic Tarzan movies of the 1930s, despite the skepticism of some experts who believed it was unlikely that a chimp could live to be more than 80 years old.

headline: Cappuccino, but Maybe Not Support
text: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — Newt Gingrich’s “jobs and growth” bus tour is visiting small businesses across Iowa to highlight the economic challenges of entrepreneurs, who the candidate argues will benefit from his calls to repeal “Obamacare,” the Dodd-Frank financial regulation law and onerous environmental mandates.

headline: Iowa G.O.P. on Guard Against Voting Disruptions
text: Although organizers for the Occupy movement in Iowa say there are no plans to disrupt voting during the 1,774 caucuses next Tuesday night, Iowa state Republican officials are not taking any chances.

headline: Egypt Raids Offices of Nonprofits, 3 Backed by U.S.
text: CAIRO — Security forces shut down three American-financed democracy-building groups and as many as six other nonprofit organizations on Thursday, in a crackdown that signaled a new low in relations between Washington and Egypt’s military rulers.

headline: South Africa’s Conscience Reflects
text: The South African playwright Athol Fugard will have four major New York theater productions this season.

headline: Impatient? It May Be Hurting Your Credit Score
text: Remember when you were a kid and your parents harped on the importance of “delayed gratification” to get ahead in life? (You know: Put that birthday money in the piggy bank and save for something nice, instead of blowing it all now on Milky Way bars.)

headline: Carrie Brownstein Starter Kit
text: For those who don’t already know and love Carrie Brownstein, there’s a lot to catch up on. The writer-actress-rocker has two current projects: the TV sketch comedy series, Portlandia, and her new band, Wild Flag. She was also the guitarist for her much-loved former band, Sleater-Kinney. To get you up to speed on her oeuvre, we asked Brownstein to assemble some of her favorite clips.

headline: The Provider Will See You Now
text: I can’t quite remember when the term “provider” slipped into the hospital lexicon. It was perhaps 10 years ago, when our hospital started hiring physician assistants and nurse practitioners to share the clinical load. In contrast to the regular staff nurses, who cared for the patients in conjunction with the doctors, physician assistants and nurse practitioners would see patients independently, the way the rest of the doctors did. So there needed to be a term that would include all three groups – physician assistants, nurse practitioners and doctors — who could have primary responsibility for patients.

headline: Hotel Restaurant Menus That Don’t Grow Stale
text: Hotel restaurants often reinvent themselves to keep up with food trends. At a time when new is the norm, though, some long-standing restaurants are sticking to tried and true.

headline: 36 Hours: Trinidad
text: Creole culture, waterfalls and partying galore.

headline: ‘Whoops’ Is the Latest Ad Attacking Gingrich
text: With less than a week before the Iowa caucuses, a “super PAC” supporting Mitt Romney in the Republican presidential nomination contest is taking another swing at Newt Gingrich, the latest in a weeks-long string of attacks on the former House speaker.

headline: Closing In on Africa’s Bush Meat Trade
text: For people in West and Central Africa, eating just one kind of bush meat might be compared to dining on roast turkey night after night in the United States. People may enjoy eating it on Thanksgiving and Christmas, notes the conservationist John Fa, “but it’s not something I want to eat every single day of my life.”

headline: 36 Hours: Trinidad
text: TRINIDAD is not piña colada territory. That’s part of its allure: Unlike virtually every other Caribbean island, the oil-rich country seven miles off Venezuela is not driven by tourism — which means that in lieu of sunbathing hordes and “Yah, Mon” T-shirts, you’ll find miles of unspoiled beaches and waterfalls visited by locals; a Creole culture with roots in Africa, India, Europe and China; and a bustling capital city offering some of the Caribbean’s most electrifying night life. Partying, after all, is a national tradition in Trinidad, home to an annual Carnival that is the region’s biggest and, lately, most star-studded (last year, the actors Idris Elba and Malik Yoba showed up). That, along with recent restaurant and hotel openings and trendy Trini ambassadors — from the rappers Nicki Minaj and Theophilus London to the “Project Runway” winner Anya Ayoung Chee — might just turn Trinidad into the next “it” island.

headline: 36 Seconds in Trinidad
text: A tour of Trinidad, the larger of the two islands that make up the nation of Trinidad and Tobago, in the southern Caribbean.

headline: The Top of the Class in Deal-Making
text: It is that time of the year again, when we award the Deal Professor A’s, the grade for the best deals and deal makers of 2011. Here are the highlights (with a few grades of F as well), in alphabetical order:

headline: The Top 10 Reasons to Make (and Love) Top 10 Lists
text: 1. The position of Arts and Entertainment Co-Editor of The Tower Times carries a certain amount of responsibility. When I filled that role at my Wisconsin high school, there was one task that I treasured above all else. I got to write an end-of-year Top 10 list.

headline: Wheelies: The TV Commercial Edition
text: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Marvel Wins Court Battle Over Rights to Ghost Rider
text: A federal judge in New York has ruled that Marvel Entertainment owns the rights to Ghost Rider, a supernatural character possessed by a spirit of vengeance who first appeared in 1972. The character was the subject of a lawsuit by a writer seeking to cash in on lucrative movie rights, according to a report by The Associated Press. United States District Judge Katherine Forrest threw out on Wednesday the four-year-old claims by ruling that Gary Friedrich, a freelance writer, gave up all ownership rights when he signed checks including language-relinquishing rights to the predecessor companies of Marvel Entertainment.

headline: Alibaba Taps Lobbying Firm
text: The Alibaba Group, the fast-growing Chinese Internet company, has hired an influential lobbying firm in Washington as it navigates a potential takeover bid for Yahoo.

headline: Curtains Up for Chicago Stages
text: WHEN times are tough, the arts suffer more than most. Pinched pocketbooks — both corporate and individual — force institutions to give up ambitious plans to focus on simply staying afloat. But in Chicago, three theaters have recently opened on the north side of the city, seemingly defying economic logic.

headline: London Underground | Architecture in Print
text: The last few years have seen a new generation of alternative publications and editorial talent emerge, and London is very much a part of the scene. This month saw the release of the fourth issue of P.E.A.R. (Paper for Emerging Architectural Research). Printed on newspaper stock, this zine (included in “Archizines,” a show I curated at the Architectural Association School of Architecture) was started by the editorial collective of Rashid Ali, Matthew Butcher, Julian Krueger and Megan O’Shea, with the designer Avni Patel, in 2009. A few issues in, they have really hit their stride. “The paper aims to re-establish the fanzine as a primary medium for the dissemination of architectural ideas, musings, research and works, and to present the complexity and variety of architectural practice,” O’Shea explains. “We actively seek to publish thinking that wouldn’t ordinarily be seen in the mainstream architectural press, and we are interested in showing that the architectural is concerned with more than just architecture.”

headline: The Candidates on Executive Power
text: The New York Times submitted a set of questions to each of the major presidential candidates about their views on the scope and limits of the powers they would wield if elected. Here are their answers in full.

headline: Red Sox Add a Closer and Some Anxiety
text: In the first real move of the Ben Cherington administration, the Red Sox appear to have secured a top closer, Andrew Bailey, for a reasonable price. But for Boston fans, famous for their worries and complaints, the new object of their obsession will be Bailey’s right elbow.

headline: Criticism of Undercover Operation Aimed at Smartphone Thefts
text: To combat a surge in the theft of handheld electronic devices, which contributed to a high rate of grand larcenies in the city this year, the Police Department devised Operation Take Back, aimed at anyone seeking a stolen iPhone or iPad.

headline: Illuminating the Legacy of a Fallen Father
text: BERKELEY, Calif.

headline: An L.A. Landmark, Angeli Caffe Is Closing
text: It was just a neighborhood restaurant. But starting in the mid-1980s, from its small perch in Los Angeles, Angeli Caffe helped popularize a new kind of California-Mediterranean cuisine, spawned a cookbook and launched the reputation of its owner and chef, Evan Kleiman.

headline: Romney Campaigns Hard in Iowa as Caucuses Near
text: 1:42 p.m. | Updated  DES MOINES — After all the hemming and hawing about whether Iowa would be a critical element of his bid to be the Republican nominee, the question for Mitt Romney is now moot.

headline: Occupying the Arts, a Seat at a Time
text: THE Juilliard School’s inviting 275-seat Paul Hall was nearly packed recently for an early-evening concert, a free 60-minute Liederabend program on which four gifted student singers, each paired with a comparably gifted pianist, sang songs by Schumann. Classical music has struggled for a long time to fight the perception — an unfair perception — that it is elitist and inaccessible. But here was a program that didn’t even require tickets. People just showed up.

headline: TimesCast | December 29, 2011
text: An unlikely command center for Bahrain's antigovernment protest movement | The Beirut bureau chief, Anthony Shadid, on the year of the Arab Spring.

headline: From a Marine’s Side of the Camera
text: When Finbarr O’Reilly, a Reuters photographer, embedded with my squad of Marines in Afghanistan last October, I strategically positioned myself between him and my men, to keep them out of trouble. I based my decision on experience and preconceived notions regarding combat journalists. On the first night, I questioned him for hours about his upbringing, his background and his political outlook on the war, to get a better feel for who he was. It appeared that he wasn’t a bad guy after all. We shared a lot of views. But I remained cautious. You can never judge a book by its cover.

headline: Brooklyn Towers, and a Debate Over Preservation
text: From the vantage, say, of Court and Joralemon Streets, Brooklyn feels like the big city it is. This is Downtown, with an upper-case D: tall buildings, crowded sidewalks, public monuments, intersecting lives — seasoned with urgency and purpose.

headline: With $30 Billion Arms Deal, U.S. Bolsters Saudi Ties
text: HONOLULU — Fortifying one of its key allies in the Persian Gulf, the Obama administration announced a weapons deal with Saudi Arabia on Thursday, saying it had agreed to sell F-15 fighter jets valued at nearly $30 billion to the Royal Saudi Air Force.

headline: Huge Trove of Titanic Artifacts to Be Auctioned
text: Thousands of artifacts salvaged from the Titanic’s watery tomb in the North Atlantic will be sold in a winner-take-all auction scheduled for April, the centennial of the luxury liner’s sinking, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Unhappy Honda Owner Taking Case to Small Claims Court
text: Heather Peters of Los Angeles is taking a novel approach to addressing her legal grievances against Honda for what she says are the fuel economy shortcomings of her Civic Hybrid. She says she is opting out of a proposed class-action lawsuit settlement and instead is suing the automaker for up to $10,000 in small claims court.

headline: The Joy of Quiet
text: ABOUT a year ago, I flew to Singapore to join the writer Malcolm Gladwell, the fashion designer Marc Ecko and the graphic designer Stefan Sagmeister in addressing a group of advertising people on “Marketing to the Child of Tomorrow.” Soon after I arrived, the chief executive of the agency that had invited us took me aside. What he was most interested in, he began — I braced myself for mention of some next-generation stealth campaign — was stillness.

headline: Four Undefeated Basketball Teams Left
text: The number of undefeated teams in college basketball continues to shrink to a precious few, as Indiana and Louisville lost Wednesday. Four teams remain perfect: No. 1 Syracuse is 14-0, No. 20 Murray State and No. 6 Baylor are 13-0, and No. 8 Missouri sits at 12-0.

headline: Hollywood-Style Tricks on the Cheap
text: A couple of weeks ago, my 12-year-old daughter sought my advice about a video she wanted to make. Her concept was so elaborate and involved so many scenes, I doubted it was even doable — unless she used a green screen and filmed the whole thing in the basement.

headline: New Ad Urges Iowans to Caucus for Palin
text: The underground movement to draft Sarah Palin into the Iowa caucuses has moved onto television, with a group called Sarah Palin’s Iowa Earthquake running ads across the state.

headline: Verizon Wireless Adds $2 Fee for Some Bill Payments
text: 3:47 p.m. | Updated  Adding analyst comment.

headline: A Forgotten Prayer, Answered
text: ON a cold March night nearly two years ago, not long after we had learned that the baby I was carrying had all his chromosomes in a sequence that spelled health and wholeness, I was lying in bed next to my husband marveling at this unlikely turn of fortune when I remembered Chimi Lhakhang.

headline: Auction Houses See Increase in High-End Contemporary Art Sales
text: Big-box stores may be worrying about their sales on Black Friday, Mega Monday and all the days in between, but sellers of high-end contemporary art seem to have done well this year. On the evidence of some auction results, at least, the market for such art rose significantly as jittery investors put their money into art instead of stocks, Bloomberg News reported.

headline: India’s Novel Solar Auctions Fuel Boom
text: When the Indian government embarked on an ambitious solar power project two years ago, I wrote that its goals seemed farfetched. Since then, things have changed significantly, and as I note in Thursday’s paper, analysts say the project’s goal of having 20,000 megawatts of solar capacity by 2020 seems well within reach.

headline: Hotel Review: Mr. C Beverly Hills in Los Angeles
text: UPSHOT

headline: Elite Flier Status
text: To the Editor: Re “Save your Elite Flier Status While You Can” (Practical Traveler, Dec. 18), I was seven segments short on Continental to get platinum status (you need 90 segments or 75,000 miles), so I did a crazy mileage run last weekend to get to platinum. All in all, the flights cost $350. The flight attendants were looking at me as if I was nuts, because for each pair of cities, I flew back and forth with the same crew. Saturday was Houston to Dallas to Houston to Austin to Houston; and Sunday was from Dallas to Houston to Austin to Houston. Ah, the crazy things we do to retain status.

headline: Activists Document Raids on Civil Society Groups and a Protest in Cairo
text: Updated | 8:01 p.m. As my colleagues David Kirkpatrick and David Goodman report, “Egyptian security forces stormed the offices of 17 nonprofit groups around the country on Thursday, including at least three democracy-promotion groups financed by the United States, as part of what Egypt’s military-led government has said is an investigation into ‘foreign hands’ in the recent outbreak of protests.”

headline: S.&.P. Outlook on Citi Field Bonds Sours
text: The Mets know things are not great at Citi Field. Attendance dropped again last season as they finished with a losing record for the third consecutive season. Revenue fell from virtually every source.

headline: Your Best Meals of the Year: From New York, to Tuscaloosa, to a Singapore Cafe
text: Here’s one last batch of readers’ best meals of the year, though if you continue to share them on Twitter with the hashtag #bestmeal2011, we’ll keep on retweeting. Below you’ll see a shout-out to a barbecue joint in Austin, Tex.; a reader torn between lunch at the French Laundry and lunch at In-N-Out burger the next day; and, at Annisa in Manhattan, an aged ribeye with escargot, “earthy funk the likes of Bootsy Collins.” Here’s to good eating in 2012.

headline: California’s Delta Ecosystem Is Healthier, For Now
text: The ecosystem of the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet has been in the legal equivalent of an intensive care unit for four years. But just before Christmas, an upbeat report came in, showing that a year of copious rain and snow had significantly improved.the delta’s condition.

headline: In Pennsylvania, a Quick Shot of Peace, on a Budget
text: LATE in November I arrived at the Jesuit Center in the reclusive hills of Wernersville, Pa., on a blindingly dark and stormy night to begin a silent five-day retreat. Such a scenario might have compelled someone more compos mentis to turn around. But that was the point. As a 43-year-old mother of three wrung out from three years of panic attacks triggered by the specter of financial ruin, I needed a solid period of quiet to recombobulate. Cheaply.

headline: The Burden of Debt, Again Again
text: I admit to having been surprised by the reaction to my two posts on the burden of debt. I thought I was saying something that would be obvious once it was pointed out; instead, many of the comments were baffled, and quite a few were utterly enraged.

headline: Hoping to Avoid Turf Troubles, Yanks Call Up Tougher Sod for Pinstripe Bowl
text: Less than seven minutes into a football game between Rutgers and Army at Yankee Stadium on Nov. 12, the grounds crew hustled onto the field and stepped on several large divots of turf that had become dislodged near one end zone. It was at about that moment that Lonn Trost cringed.

headline: A Classic American Boat Weds a Contemporary Japanese Engine
text: The classic and highly prized wooden speedboats made by Chris-Craft have long been fitted with potent automobile engines, including small-block Chevy V-8s and Chrysler Hemis. Now, Infiniti has joined with Nashville State Community College and Freeport Boat Outlet of Maine to customize a 1962 Chris-Craft Holiday and equip it with a 400-horsepower 5.6-liter V-8 from an Infiniti QX56 S.U.V. It’s the kind of pairing of classic and contemporary that has always been part of the automotive scene, but has perhaps been more rare in the world of boats.

headline: A Slump Is A Good Time To Invest In Infrastructure
text: Multiplier issues aside, funding is cheap, and many of the resources you would use would otherwise be unemployed. There’s really a compelling argument that we should be doing a lot of public investment right now.

headline: Series: Firepower
text: Articles in this series explore gaps in gun laws and their impact on public safety.

headline: Popcast: The Best Jazz of 2011
text: In the last of three year-end wrap-up shows, the music critics Ben Ratliff and Nate Chinen listen to and discuss some of the best jazz of 2011.

headline: A Public Marriage Proposal? Think Again
text: My girlfriend’s parents are giving a big brunch party on Jan. 2, the federal holiday. I’d like to surprise my girlfriend by asking her to marry me in front of all the guests. We’ve been going out for six months, and I’m ready to make the commitment. The new year feels like the perfect time. But do I have to get her parents’ permission to ask during the brunch? In case it matters, they like me. Ben, Florida

headline: Man Who Tried to Extort Letterman Is Hired by Newsmagazine
text: Robert Joel Halderman, the “48 Hours” producer who pleaded guilty last year to having tried to extort David Letterman, has been hired by a competing crime newsmagazine, “On the Case With Paula Zahn,” which is shown on the Investigation Discovery channel.

headline: New Game Plan: Smelling the Roses
text: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Back in 1986, when Urban Meyer was a graduate assistant at Ohio State, he shared an office the size of “a little furnace room” with five of his peers, his primary duty the cutting and splicing of 16-millimeter film.

headline: Long Faces at the Palace, a Beloved Diner Set to Close
text: One by one, they all came in, arriving one last time to have a turkey club sandwich and to say goodbye to another Queens diner.

headline: Growing Old With Sex on Their Minds
text: Why did Alan Bennett give the title “Smut” to this admittedly slight but always enjoyable and often hilarious pair of novellas? Maybe it’s a coy apology for a book that celebrates several varieties of sexual activity, a subject he has said was barely mentionable in lower-middle-class Yorkshire, where he was raised. Maybe it’s a defiant cry from a writer who has accused his younger self of being bashful, diffident and very, very repressed. Maybe the title is wry, rueful, ironic, nostalgic and mischievous — all of which “Smut” itself turns out to be.

headline: ‘24/7’ Episode 3: A Festive Mood as the Winter Classic Nears
text: Much has been made about the fracas between Jets Coach Rex Ryan and Giants running back Brandon Jacobs after the Giants’ victory on Christmas Eve. Turns out, Ryan’s comeback was taken straight out of Flyers Coach Peter Laviolette’s playbook.

headline: A House Divided by Exasperation
text: “A Separation,” a tightly structured, emotionally astute new film from Iran, begins with a couple, at odds and in distress, arguing in front of a judge. Simin (Leila Hatami) wants to leave the country with her daughter, Termeh (Sarina Farhadi), and Simin’s husband, Nader (Peyman Moadi), insists on staying at home in Tehran to care for his frail and elderly father, who suffers from dementia and needs constant attention. Quite possibly there is more at issue than practical domestic arrangements — there are hints of suppressed anger in Nader’s demeanor, of long-simmering exasperation in Simin’s — but an Iranian courtroom may not be the best place to discuss intimate marital matters.

headline: Vain Glorious | New Hair’s Eve
text: When it comes to hair, this holiday time can be frustrating. Spring trends are not yet relevant, and most fall and winter looks have been exhausted. So what to wear to ring in the New Year? An up-do that embodies the best of both seasons.

headline: After Frustration and Sorrow, Season of Revival for Gaborik
text: Marian Gaborik, who is second in the N.H.L. in goal-scoring, has been smiling a lot lately. Long just a step away from stardom, he seems finally to have become a marquee player for a Rangers team newly arrived in hockey’s spotlight.

headline: Coming Soon: The Letter That Sank Mark Hurd
text: There’s another installment coming in one of Silicon Valley’s stranger soap operas.

headline: Neighborhood Joint | Taqueria Tlaxcalli
text: A Bronx restaurant serves authentic cuisine in a borough that is home to a growing population of Mexicans.

headline: ‘Like Home,’ if Home Is Mexico
text: IT used to be that authentic Mexican restaurants were a kind of urban legend in New York. And transplants from California and Texas, to say nothing of Puebla and Mexico City, still stalk the city’s cantinas, often with disappointing results, and trade tips about the best — places like Taqueria Tlaxcalli in Parkchester, a diverse expanse of urban blocks in the Bronx.

headline: What We Collect
text: From Beatles memorabilia to Barbie dolls, people collect a range of objects. What drives people to collect objects? And when does collecting become a problem?

headline: V.I.P. Perks, Secondhand Stores
text: SEPARATE lines had formed outside a 6,000-square-foot warehouse in Long Island City, Queens, on a Saturday: one for general admission, one V.I.P. A man with a clipboard started checking names. Then the select few were in, and the masses continued to wait their turn. They had another hour to lean, shivering, against the wall.

headline: Dear FloFab: My Check Has a Tip Tacked On
text: Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining dilemma? Ask FloFab.

headline: A New Verizon Fee for Some Bill Payments
text: Our colleagues on the Bits blog have a post of interest to our readers, too. It says that Verizon Wireless plans to begin charging a $2 fee on Jan. 15 when customers use their credit cards to make a one-time payment online or over the phone.

headline: Lens: From a Marine’s Side of the Camera
text: Over on the Lens blog, Sgt. Thomas James Brennan writes about the close bonds that form during battle, even between soldiers and the combat photographers documenting them. When Finbarr O’Reilly, a Reuters photographer, embedded with Sgt. Brennan’s squad of Marines in Afghanistan last October, he was a little guarded around the man with the camera. But the war didn’t give him time or space to hold onto those feelings. And conversations with Mr. O’Reilly, coupled with the closeness of battle, forged a bond between the men that continues to today. A bond was cemented with the commonalities the men shared, as Sgt. Brennan notes:

headline: Look Out, _____ Is the New Grunge!
text: FEAR not, rockists: all is not lost. Just because the mainstream, as buffeted by major labels, has been resistant to new ideas for several years doesn’t mean it can’t be infected. Bubbling below the mook-rockers, the ’90s revivalists and the toothless oldsters are plenty of microscenes, any one of which could be seized upon by A&R executives looking to reboot their labels’ approach to rock. Here are a few of the most promising options.

headline: Making Fun of Hipsters for a Living
text: Magazine writer Elizabeth Weil on the new season of "Portlandia" and meeting the show's co-star Carrie Brownstein in Portland, of course.

headline: An Indoor Park and Mini-Golf in a Bar
text: Normally this time of year finds the Miser making a gigantic list of possible resolutions. (There are always many to choose from.) But with vacation extending into the first week of January, the plan is to ease into the new year with some mildly active fun that won’t require facing the cold reality that the holidays are over.

headline: They Say the Noen Lights Are Bright on Brodaway
text: Thanks to the Arts for Transit program, there are moments of genuine delight to be found in the New York City subway. There are also delightful surprises that have nothing to do with artistic intent.

headline: Leaping Off the Pages in the Himalayas
text: Diversity in the comic book industry — whether in the characters’ adventures or in the creators who devise them — is a topic that inspires a gnashing of teeth. Why aren’t there more female creators? Why aren’t there more series with minority leads? When different cultures are represented, how can it be done without that whiff of tokenism?

headline: Factory Jobs Gain, but Wages Retreat
