text: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Manufacturers are hiring again in America, softening a long slide in factory employment. But for a new generation of blue-collar workers, even those protected by unions, the price of employment is likely to be lower wages stretching to retirement.

headline: Bill to Create Anticorruption Agency Stalls in India
text: NEW DELHI — India’s coalition government failed on Thursday to push through legislation to create an independent anticorruption agency, after an exhausting day of parliamentary speechmaking, political posturing and backroom negotiations could not produce a deal, possibly stalling the bill for months.

headline: Parental Quandary Resolved: After a Divorce, Who Gets the Children for the Holidays?
text: Last week, Nina (all names and identifying details have been changed) asked our parenting crowd source for advice about a question she’s been struggling with for some time. When her husband and his first wife divorced, his now ex swore he’d never see the children on a holiday, and in the eight years since, she’s made good on her promise. During that interval, he met Nina, they married, and had two children together. He’s never objected to his ex-spouse’s claim to his children for the holidays (or even her constant pulling them back from other arranged visits), but Nina wondered if maybe he — they — should. What if her stepchildren (now 11 and 15) think they weren’t wanted?

headline: Showcasing Composers’ Versatility
text: The holiday season is usually hectic for the New York Philharmonic, and this year the orchestra’s December schedule has been particularly diffuse, with “Messiah” performances, chamber performances and a pair of “Contact!” concerts built around H. K. Gruber’s “Frankenstein!!” The orchestra took last week off, but its New Year’s Eve concert — a Bernstein and Gershwin program — is still ahead. So for the subscription series that began on Wednesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, Alan Gilbert led works by Haydn, Schubert and Ravel — a thoroughly settled, mainstream selection, you might think, until you looked more closely.

headline: Foreign Aid Worker Is Killed and Colleague Is Wounded in Somali Capital
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A foreign aid worker was shot dead and another was wounded by a former colleague at their office here in the capital on Thursday, according to officials and witnesses, adding to a series of attacks on humanitarian workers and journalists that has underscored the dangers of working in this war-torn country.

headline: On Our Radar: Scientists Appeal to G.O.P. Candidates
text: Less than two weeks before the New Hampshire primary, 50 scientists in that state call on Republican presidential candidates to accept the overwhelmin” scientific evidence on the human role in climate change and to support action to rein in greenhouse gas emissions. Their statement follows a similar appeal from scientists in Iowa. [E2Wire.]

headline: Samoa Sacrifices a Day for Its Future
text: The Pacific island nation of Samoa and its even tinier neighbor Tokelau are skipping Friday this week, jumping westward in time across the international date line and into the shifting economic balance of the 21st century.

headline: Russians Rally for Activist in Hopes of Inspiring a Movement
text: MOSCOW — Opposition leaders trying to sustain the momentum of their upstart protest movement gathered about 200 people on Thursday for an unsanctioned rally in central Moscow in support of a jailed activist they are hoping to turn into a cause célèbre.

headline: For Hollywood, More Year-to-Year Reasons for Concern
text: LOS ANGELES — A little math, albeit fuzzy, may explain why executives at film studios, both big and small, are having a nervous holiday (and actually spending time in the office, as mentioned earlier).

headline: The Top 10 Top 10 Lists of 2011
text: 1. Top 10 Films of John Waters (Artforum). A near-perfect list, iconoclastic and personal, but loaded with great, weird, wild, Watersian movies. The No. 9 curveball? Amid the art films, apocalypse comedy and Bieber concert film, a quiet, heartbreaking AIDS documentary.

headline: The Most-Commented Posts of 2011
text: As 2011 comes to a close, City Room takes note of the events that proved irresistible to readers, attracting the highest volume of reader comments. The Occupy Wall Street protests, former Representative Anthony D. Weiner’s lewd social networking habits, and the posts tracking the drama of Violet, Bobby and Pip, the red-tailed hawks and the subjects of the Hawk Cam, dominated our list.

headline: 2011: Arab Spring
text: A look back at the year of change in the Middle East with the Beirut bureau chief Anthony Shadid.

headline: Truck Drivers for Romney?
text: MASON CITY, Iowa — Mitt Romney came to Mason City to stand before a faux “Music Man” backdrop of River City, Iowa, and give an answer diplomatically worthy of the musical’s con man — or, at least, a typical politician.

headline: An Election Year Dawns Without Keith Olbermann
text: 6:05 p.m. | Updated  Keith Olbermann, who came to Current TV this year to remake the channel and compete against his old home, MSNBC, is sitting out the biggest political nights of the season.

headline: A Working Vacation
text: The Biggest Loser Resort offers participants a picturesque setting in Ivins, Utah, to tackle losing weight.

headline: My Week at the Biggest Loser Fat Camp
text: “COME on guys! Three more minutes and Day 2 is over!” screamed Sharon, our six-foot trainer, punching the air with her fists and tossing back her slick black hair, which perfectly matched her shiny black tracksuit.

headline: Spare Times for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Around Town

headline: Movie Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Movies

headline: Pop and Rock Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Pop

headline: Theater Listings: Dec. 30 — Jan. 5
text: Theater

headline: Jazz Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Jazz

headline: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Classical

headline: Technology Headlines 2011
text: A recap of the year’s major technology headlines and a gear roundup that includes digital-audio amplifiers and a solar-powered keyboard.

headline: London’s Beloved Bus Returns, With an Update
text: The streets of London were brightened this holiday season by a very new, very red addition. The first running prototype of the new double-decker bus, a modern version of the classic Routemaster, drove across the city the week before Christmas.

headline: Tackling Beethoven and the ‘Firebird’
text: What choreography in 2012 whets the appetite in advance? It’s dismayingly hard to know. The choreographers Mark Morris, Alexei Ratmansky, Paul Taylor and Christopher Wheeldon will all present premieres in New York. But while Mr. Morris and Mr. Taylor are capable of real greatness, and Mr. Ratmansky and Mr. Wheeldon are the most important choreographers in ballet today, experience has taught us that each can disappoint.

headline: Photo Replay: Dec.29
text: A view of the day in sports included ski jumping in Germany and cricket in Australia.

headline: Dance Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Dance

headline: Pop Will Thrive in Greenwich Village
text: There’s little need to wait for two of 2012’s most promising events. Thanks to the intrepid Association of Performing Arts Presenters, which braves January in New York City for its annual convention, a brigade of jazz and world-music performers converges in downtown Manhattan next weekend. On Jan. 6 and 7, the Winter Jazzfest shares five Greenwich Village clubs within a three-block radius, each presenting half a dozen acts nightly. Then, on Jan. 8, Globalfest offers a dozen acts on three stages in Webster Hall in the East Village. First-rate music awaits those willing to endure scrimmages at doorways and chatty audiences.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Art

headline: Spare Times: For Children, for Dec. 30-Jan. 5
text: Prospect Park Audubon Center

headline: Pictures of the Day: North Korea and Elsewhere
text: Photographs from North Korea, Turkey, Bahrain and Iran.

headline: From Cage at His Briefest to Wagner at His Longest
text: John Cage is an anomaly among contemporary composers for a great many reasons, not the least of which is that his name and some of his conceptual notions are more widely known than his music. His most famous score is silent — or at least people think it is. Actually, that work — “4’33” ” — was composed for Maverick Concerts, a summer festival near Woodstock, N.Y., held in an open shed, and Cage’s hope was that listeners would focus on the natural sounds that filtered into the concert space as the piece was performed. Obviously, the piece works in indoor halls as well, once you understand how to approach it.

headline: A Second Chance for TV’s Season
text: New TV shows are liable to pop up any time these days, but over the last few years January has solidified its position as the start of television’s second season. There are probably more series making their debuts or having their season premieres next month than there were during the official start of the 2011-12 broadcast network season in September. A quick scan turns up more than 70.

headline: The Met to Present Entire ‘Ring’ Cycle, and More
text: You cannot fairly assess a production of Wagner’s “Ring” until you see the entire cycle of four operas. Wagner buffs will finally get that chance this spring when the Metropolitan Opera presents the director Robert Lepage’s new production of the “Ring” in three complete cycles in April and May. This ambitious venture is rightly the most anticipated event of the Met season. First, “Götterdämmerung,” the last installment, will be introduced on Jan. 27, with Fabio Luisi, the Met’s principal conductor, on the podium. The pros and cons of Mr. Lepage’s work in the first three operas have been heatedly discussed, and the debate will surely continue.

headline: Soundtracks for a Year’s Last Parties
text: Another year down, another drop of the ball, another chance to get it all right.

headline: Not Just New Games, but Also New Systems
text: Once upon a time, the winter months were sleepy in game land. Not anymore. Early 2012 will bring the release of not only some closely watched games, but also a major new portable hardware system. And Nintendo has said it intends to introduce its successor to the Wii, the Wii U, some time after May.

headline: From Outlaws to Presidents in a Year That Was Filled With Curious Treasures
text: Specialty museums closed by the dozen this year, in fields as rarefied as New Jersey farming and Arizona mining, and their collections were stored away or split up. But broader institutions and their benefactors still had spare cash to make high-profile purchases. Here are six of 2011’s most intriguing auction lots that emerged on the market and are now already on view or will be soon.

headline: ‘Like Home,’ if Home Is Mexico
text: It used to be that authentic Mexican restaurants were a kind of urban legend in New York. And transplants from California and Texas, to say nothing of Puebla and Mexico City, still stalk the city’s cantinas, often with disappointing results, and trade tips about the best — places like Taqueria Tlaxcalli in Parkchester in the Bronx.

headline: A Cold Mountain Village Where Heartbreak Is Everybody’s Business
text: The small, hardy community in the Rocky Mountains that gives “Angels Crest” its name is a rough-hewn working-class town of grain elevators and meat-and-potatoes eateries where everyone knows everyone else’s business. Ethan Denton (Thomas Dekker), the film’s main character, is a 21-year-old father who works in an auto parts shop and is raising his 3-year-old son, Nate, singlehandedly. The child’s mother, Cindy (Lynn Collins), a bitter and promiscuous alcoholic much older than Ethan, keeps her distance.

headline: AMR’s Shares to Be Grounded
text: AMR, the parent company of American Airlines, disclosed Thursday that its shares would be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange before the market opens on Jan. 5.

headline: Revivals and Retellings, Some Served With Blood
text: SHAKESPEARE IN BROOKLYN

headline: Cathy Horyn Recounts the Year in Fashion
text: The best and worst of 2011, from the Alexander McQueen exhibit to John Galliano’s topple.

headline: A Judge Who Reshaped the Corporate Landscape
text: Many judges are lucky to handle just one era-defining case during their tenures on the bench. In his 16 years as a federal bankruptcy judge, Arthur J. Gonzalez has handled three.

headline: The Santorum Surge in Iowa and Beyond
text: The extent to which Rick Santorum has gained in Iowa polling is not entirely clear. Although two polls have him with 16 percent of the vote, two others that were in the field at the same time have him at 10 and 11 percent, respectively.

headline: In Panama City, Colorful Red Devil Buses Yielding to Paler, Safer Kind
text: PANAMA — Here comes the Diablo Rojo, the Red Devil bus blasting its air horn and fishtailing around a fellow “demon” just in time to claim Irma Betancourt and other morning commuters. Suffice it to say the Red Devils earn their name.

headline: Meatball Recipes
text: Recipes for classic Italian meatballs, global alternatives and updated takes on a cherished form.

headline: Honda Tells Dealers Not to Sell Used Models Until Air Bag Is Fixed
text: Honda has told its dealers not to sell some used models until they carry out a recall to fix an air bag defect the automaker has linked to 18 injuries and two deaths.

headline: Specters and Shades of Black in 2012 Films
text: The most widely anticipated question in cinema for 2012 may well be this: Has “The Woman in Black” (a ghost story starring Daniel Radcliffe and scheduled for release in February) ever dated any of “The Men in Black 3” (coming in May)? Also, what are we to make of the appearance, weeks apart, of “Declaration of War” (January) and “This Means War” (February), neither of which, incidentally, is about war?

headline: Yankees Hats Are Everywhere, Even North Korea
text: Yankees caps are everywhere these days, perhaps even on planets yet to be discovered.

headline: Some Favorite Things Not Hanging on a Wall
text: Last year around this time, three art critics for The New York Times chose a few of their favorite paintings on long-term display in New York museums and wrote about them. The hope was to bring some attention to works that are often overlooked in the city’s constant deluge of art-viewing possibilities. This year we’re doing it again, but with the focus shifted to three-dimensional objects.

headline: At Sears, Excessive Confidence Has a Price
text: Becoming very rich can show that you are a genius.

headline: Saints Could Be a 13-Win Team Without a Bye
text: After a streak of coin flip futility earlier this season, are the Saints headed for another dubious distinction?

headline: Republican Candidates Campaign in Iowa
text: Voters have readily acknowledged that their decision will be driven as much by personal chemistry as political positions, as much by biography as policy.

headline: Judge Blocks California’s Low-Carbon Fuel Rule
text: A federal judge on Thursday blocked enforcement of a California regulation favoring producers of gasoline, diesel fuel and biofuels whose methods generate fewer greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Mansionlike Luxury, Without the Bother
text: IT is when you go pre-prewar — that is, before World War I — that you get to the richest lode of apartment luxury. That could be anything from the Dakota (1884) to 998 Fifth Avenue (1912), in part because they were designed before experience taught developers how to cut corners.

headline: How Low Can Rates Go?
text: IF your New Year’s resolutions include buying a house or refinancing, the Federal Reserve has you covered. It has committed to keep long-term interest rates low through next year, so a 30-year mortgage will be pegged about where it is now — 4.32 percent in New York — at least through spring, said Frank E. Nothaft, the chief economist at Freddie Mac.

headline: Perry’s Presidential Campaign Gaffes Put Texans on the Defensive Yet Again
text: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: GTT ★
text: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Space Plan From China Broadens Challenge to U.S.
text: BEIJING — Broadening its challenge to the United States, the Chinese government on Thursday announced an ambitious five-year plan for space exploration that would move China closer to becoming a major rival at a time when the American program is in retreat.

headline: Q & A
text: Setting a Date for a Board Meeting

headline: A Larger Place (Couch Must Fit)
text: FOR most of her eight or so years in New York, Amber Field lived only on the top floors of walk-up buildings.

headline: Lingerie on 6; Lobster on 9
text: MAYBE it was that scene between Kris Kringle and Alfred, the people-pleasing porter, in “Miracle on 34th Street”: lunch at a cafeteria in Macy’s.

headline: Serving With Saddam’s Ladle
text: IT was Friday before dusk and my husband had corralled our three children — showered, in good clothes and on notice for good behavior — to sing Sabbath prayers. I broke away for a moment and ran upstairs to my computer to check the status of a shiny treasure looted from the devil.

headline: Looking Past the Potato
text: ON a trip to Italy last year, Carol Festa and Tom Geppel of Mattituck savored the pecorino and ricotta in Tuscany. Back home on the North Fork, motivated by an increasing involvement with the sustainable farming and local food movement, they leased farmland and bought 13 hardy Icelandic sheep.

headline: Too Many Stops, but Leave Mine!
text: Nick Rougley, a student housing coordinator at the Art Institute of San Francisco, commutes every day from the Fillmore to Civic Center. Sometimes he takes the No. 5-Fulton Muni bus for the mile-long trip. Sometimes he walks. The bus is so slow, said Mr. Rougley, “It’s really almost the same as walking.”

headline: 2011: The Year of the Turndown
text: EVEN as 2011 was a year of stable prices and steady sales in Manhattan real estate, it may go down in history as a banner year for co-op and condo board vetoes.

headline: Standing Still
text: Three critics choose their favorite sculptures and three-dimensional objects in New York City.

headline: Who’s Parking Where? City Doesn’t Know, but It Hopes to Find Out
text: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

headline: Violet the Red-Tailed Hawk Is Dead
text: Violet, the red-tailed hawk whose intimate family life in a nest overlooking Washington Square Park was chronicled on a live-streaming webcam, delighting more than a million viewers with the sacred spectacle of nature, died on Thursday. She was believed to be about 5 years old.

headline: Bachmann Strikes Thatcher Comparison in Iowa
text: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Representative Michele Bachmann, trying to keep her campaign alive in the waning days of the race in Iowa, highlighted a theme she has been using lately, comparing herself to Margaret Thatcher, the conservative British prime minister during the 1980s who was known for her steely toughness.

headline: Haiti’s Tragic History
text: For the better part of two centuries, outsiders have been offering explanations that range from racist to learned-sounding — the supposed inferiority of blacks, the heritage of slavery, overpopulation — for why Haiti remains the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere. None of these work: nearby Barbados has a greater population density, and about 90 percent of its people are descended from slaves, yet it outranks all but two nations in Latin America on the United Nations Human Development Index. Neither Barbados nor any other country, however, had so traumatic and crippling a birth as Haiti.

headline: Filene’s Basement Closes in Boston, and Shoppers Mourn
text: BOSTON — On the final day of the farewell sale at Filene’s Basement on Boylston Street here, Andrew Eisenmann made a funereal trip from the store to his double-parked car, pushing a clothing rack he had just purchased for $40.

headline: $68 Million Settlement Proposed for 10 Children Fraudulently Adopted and Abused
text: Lawyers for 10 disabled children who were fraudulently adopted by a Queens woman more than 15 years ago and subjected to years of abuse have proposed a $68 million settlement in a civil rights lawsuit filed on their clients’ behalf, according to a confidential court filing.

headline: Graphic: How the Weather Turns Out in Iowa
text: On “Fox News Sunday,” Mike Huckabee claimed that if the weather is bad in Iowa this Tuesday, Representative Ron Paul will win the state caucuses over Mitt Romney, whose supporters are not as dedicated. Current forecasts predict the weather will be relatively balmy, with no chance of rain or snow — which, according to Mr. Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, will favor Mr. Romney.

headline: Romney, Eye on Paul, Digs In as He Bets on Iowa
text: DES MOINES — With days left before voting begins in Iowa, Mitt Romney has fully embraced the state that spurned him four years ago, betting that heightened expectations for his performance at the Republican caucuses here on Tuesday will not undercut his chances of a strong start to the presidential nominating contests.

headline: The Caucus Click: Campaigning Across Iowa
text: By all accounts, the 2012 presidential race is supposed to hinge on the troubled American economy and the overriding anxiety of a restless electorate. However, voters have readily acknowledged that their decision will be driven as much by personal chemistry as political positions, as much by biography as policy. More Photos »

headline: Failed Adoptions Create More Homeless Youths
text: Lamar West has lost parents twice in his life. The first time was when he was 4; the second was a month before his 18th birthday. The circumstances differed, but the outcomes did not.

headline: Spain: King’s Son-in-Law Summoned to Court Over Fraud Allegations
text: A high court in Spain issued a summons Thursday to the son-in-law of King Juan Carlos as a suspect in a spreading fraud scandal that involves millions of dollars in public money given to his private foundation. A judge in Palma, Majorca, called on the son-in-law, Iñaki Urdangarin, 43, to face questioning on Feb. 6 about allegations that he used his royal credentials to secure multimillion-dollar contracts for his foundation, the Noós Institute, to organize sports and tourism events. After he was named as a formal suspect on Thursday, the Spanish palace and a number of government institutions issued careful comments offering “respect” for the decision of judges. The king has taken a number of steps to keep a distance from his son-in-law, whose family did not spend Christmas Eve with the royal family for the first time in years.

headline: In G.O.P. Field, Broad View of Presidential Power Prevails
text: WASHINGTON — Even as they advocate for limited government, many of the Republican presidential candidates hold expansive views about the scope of the executive powers they would wield if elected — including the ability to authorize the targeted killing of United States citizens they deem threats and to launch military attacks without Congressional permission.

headline: Finding Optimism in a Longer View of Equities
text: Savers confident enough to believe better times will return within a few years should hope the gloom lasts a bit longer.

headline: David Axelrod Is at Home Waging What May Be His Last Campaign
text: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

headline: Jildy App Sorts Your Facebook Friends for You
text: You’re in line for coffee. You really want to check your family’s Facebook posts to see if there’s anything you need to know about, but they’re lost among status updates from friends. You never did spend the time to create a group of just your relatives, so there you are, thumbing through your iPhone’s entire news feed.

headline: Amid 31-Game Losing Skid, Towson Focuses on Future, Not Futility
text: TOWSON, Md. — A large crane swayed above the construction site for Towson University’s new basketball arena Wednesday, a glimmer of hope for the future.

headline: Contract Deadline Nears for 22,000 Office Cleaners in City
text: The owners of 1,500 office towers in New York City, most of them in Manhattan, are preparing for a possible strike at midnight Saturday, lining up thousands of workers to replace union employees who clean the buildings during overnight shifts.

headline: Names of the Dead
text: The Department of Defense has identified 1,844 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

headline: Police Stop-and-Frisks
text: To the Editor:

headline: Wall St. Can’t Carry the City
text: To the Editor:

text: To the Editor:

headline: New Ford Fusion Will Warn Drivers Who Drift
text: The Ford Motor Company offered on Thursday a taste of some advanced technology that will be featured in the all-new Fusion, which is scheduled to be introduced at the Detroit auto show in January. The technical tidbit is a tracking system that can help prevent drowsy or inattentive drivers from wandering out of their lane. While similar technology has previously been offered on some automobiles, Octavio Navarro, a Ford spokesman, said in a telephone interview that the Fusion would be the first affordable nonluxury vehicle to offer this type of system.

headline: California: Court Allows Elimination of Redevelopment Agencies
text: The State Supreme Court ruled Thursday that Gov. Jerry Brown and the Legislature had the right to eliminate local redevelopment agencies, redirecting more than $1 billion to help close a huge budget gap. The state began authorizing the agencies in the 1940s to subsidize construction in rundown areas. After the Legislature voted to abolish them this summer, several cities and agencies sued, saying the state had no right to the funds. The court said that abolishing the agencies was “a proper exercise of the legislative power vested in the Legislature” and that the government could “establish or dissolve local agencies and subdivisions as it sees fit.” The Legislature also approved a plan allowing cities to reorganize the agencies if they agreed to use the money for state obligations this year, but the court ruled that plan invalid, effectively eliminating the nearly 400 agencies.

headline: Vermont: Storm-Hit Roads Reopened
text: State officials on Thursday reopened the last stretch of state highway still closed after flooding from Hurricane Irene in August. About seven miles of Route 107, a busy east-west road connecting Bethel and Stockbridge, was opened. State officials say all 500 miles of state roadways damaged during the storm have now been repaired.

headline: Loading Up on Stock Options
text: When the financial crisis depressed stock prices, many companies saw an opportunity to grant a large number of options to their executives — so that if the share prices recovered, the executives would reap windfalls.

headline: 12 Arrested at Occupy the Caucus Protest
text: DES MOINES — An air of irritation surrounding the Occupy the Caucus movement crept in Thursday as 12 protesters, including a 14-year-old girl, were arrested for blocking the doors to the Iowa Democratic Party headquarters.

headline: For a Corn Chip Maker, the New Spokesman Is the Product Itself
text: AT the Fiesta Bowl on Monday, the game’s sponsor, Tostitos, will have a new endorser — a “spokesbag” puppet in the form of a chip bag with arms, a mouth and a generous dollop of swagger — to humorously convey the message that it is the tortilla chip brand that enlivens social gatherings.

headline: A Growing San Antonio Shakes Off Sleepy Label
text: SAN ANTONIO — In 2008, after 15 years as the Alamo City’s largest corporate resident, AT& T announced it was moving its headquarters to Dallas — and taking 700 executives along with it. In the past, that San Antonio’s first Fortune 500 company had outgrown its home might have seemed an insurmountable blow for this city with a pre-existing inferiority complex. But these days, it is not easy to shake the city’s confidence.

headline: Deep Thoughts for the Giants Against Dallas
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — For seemingly as long as the Giants have played football, the running game has been the bedrock of their offensive philosophy. That is, until this season.

headline: 4 U.S. Makers of Towers for Wind Turbines File Complaint Over China’s Steel Subsidies
text: WASHINGTON — Four domestic companies that make most of the steel towers for wind turbines in the United States filed a trade complaint against China and Vietnam on Thursday, seeking tariffs in the range of 60 percent. The action is a significant new skirmish in an emerging green energy trade war.

headline: Billing Both Legislature and Campaign? Prove It.
text: In politics, one man’s mistake is another’s opportunity. Now that Representative Joe Driver, Republican of Garland, has been sentenced for “double dipping” — billing both his campaign and the State Legislature for the same expenses — opposition researchers in this primary season are scrambling for other cases.

headline: Disputed Voting Turns Church, a Kremlin Ally, Into Its Critic
text: MOSCOW — Among the thousands of Russian voices raised against the Kremlin this month after parliamentary elections widely dismissed as fraudulent, perhaps the most surprising was that of Patriarch Kirill I, the leader of the Russian Orthodox Church, who defended popular protests as a “lawful negative reaction” to corruption.

headline: Paul’s Stance on Foreign Policy Divides Many Traditional G.O.P. Voters
text: DES MOINES — This month, a wealthy Republican called up two officers who served as platoon leaders in Iraq and Afghanistan with a proposition: He would lend them his private jet, and they would fly around Iowa to Representative Ron Paul’s campaign events in the weeks before the Jan. 3 caucuses, telling reporters at each location that the congressman’s foreign policy and military positions were dangerous and naïve.

headline: An Artist Whose Compulsions Have Their Upsides
text: Ed Loftus, an Oakland artist known for his hyper-realistic graphite drawings, sat in a cafe in downtown San Francisco last week talking about how he had become obsessed with his hair. “It sounds nuts, but all I could think about was getting my hair cut,” he said. “It’s like: I should get my hair cut. When am I going to get my hair cut? Why am I thinking about getting my hair cut? I wish I could stop thinking about getting my hair cut.”

headline: Jamaica Comes Alive With Airport Arrivals
text: A steady stream of travelers dragging wheeled suitcases and speaking a Babel of tongues is helping revive downtown Jamaica, a vibrant hub of Queens that weathered several gloomy decades of decay and crime.

headline: 2011 Was a Good Year for Causes of Gays
text: Although the court fight over same-sex marriage in California is unresolved, lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender advocacy groups scored major legislative victories in 2011.

headline: Record Low Set in Deaths From Traffic, Mayor Says
text: Those who long for the simpler days of trolley cars and horse-drawn carriages should take pause: traversing New York City’s busy streets is now far safer for pedestrians and drivers alike.

headline: Santorum Events Reflect Rising Iowa Numbers
text: CORALVILLE, Iowa — As Rick Santorum pondered something almost unthinkable a couple of weeks ago — a respectable finish in the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday — he urged a gathering of about three dozen potential voters to resist the impulse to play it safe.

headline: For Metta World Peace, a New Name and Outlook
text: EL SEGUNDO, Calif. — World Peace is possible. Just check the box score.

headline: An Uproar on the Web Over $2 Fee by Verizon
text: The Web lit up with howls of protest on Thursday as word of a planned new Verizon Wireless fee spread wildly — and somewhat inaccurately.

headline: Lottery Numbers
As Supply Dwindles, Organic Milk Gets Popular
text: There is a shortage of organic milk across the country, and it has become so bad in areas like the Southeast that Publix stores from Florida to Tennessee have put up signs in dairy cases anticipating the shopper’s frustrated refrain: “Where’s my organic milk?”

headline: An Ill Young Woman and the Aunt Always by Her Side
text: Linda Torres says that Carmen Estrada, her aunt, spoils her, even when money is tight. When Ms. Torres was 12, her favorite band was ’N Sync, so Ms. Estrada scraped together the money to take her to see the group in concert.

headline: Corrections: December 30
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Lessons in DNA and Mercy
text: In 2006, during a debate in the race for state attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo criticized his opponent for having failed to give a DNA test to a man who was in prison for a murder that he turned out to have had nothing to do with. A few years before that, Mr. Cuomo spoke at a party for a book written by a man who had spent 12 years in prison for having handled $500 in a drug sting.

headline: Closing In on the Climb of a Lifetime
text: R. A. Dickey, the Mets pitcher, will climb Mount Kilimanjaro in January. He’s doing it in part to raise awareness for the Bombay Teen Challenge, an organization that rescues and cares for women and girls in Mumbai who are at risk of being abused and exploited. His posts will appear occasionally in Bats.

headline: Italian Premier Outlines Plan to Stimulate Growth in a Struggling Economy
text: ROME — Prime Minister Mario Monti on Thursday presented in broad terms his government’s master plan for Italy, which he called “Grow Italy.”

headline: Bringing Home the Bacon
text: When I was 4 years old, I remember sitting in a diner for lunch with my mom and brother, blissfully eating one of my favorite foods, a B.L.T.  A couple of hours later I began to come down with the flu and spent much of the afternoon throwing up.

headline: Schottenheimer Weathers Criticism With Smile
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Brian Schottenheimer bounded up to the lectern Thursday afternoon, smiled and even asked the first question: “How’s everybody doing?”

headline: Gov. Chafee Declines
text: Gov. Lincoln Chafee of Rhode Island took a principled position when he refused an order from a federal court to transfer a prisoner to federal custody for prosecution because that would expose the prisoner to the death penalty. As Mr. Chafee said in a statement, that is “a penalty consciously rejected by the State of Rhode Island, even for those guilty of the most heinous crimes.”

headline: Friday: Holder of Legends
text: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Have you ever started filling in a long answer based on the crossings, with little awareness of what the complete entry might be, but as you scribble and the answer dawns on you, you can feel the smile spread across your face? That’s what happened to me as I filled in 3 Down. I wound up laughing out loud at UP THE WAZOO, but it was the first time I think I was actually aware that the writing and the smiling were happening at the same time.

headline: Why We Collect Stuff
text: What drives people to collect things? And when does collecting become a problem?

headline: Iran and the Strait
text: Iran’s threat to shut the Strait of Hormuz — one-fifth of the world’s oil trade passes through there — if the United States and Europe press ahead with new sanctions is unacceptable. The Obama administration is right to signal, in deliberately moderated ways, that Washington will not back off if Tehran ever attempts to carry it out.

headline: Darker Nights as Some Cities Turn Off the Lights
text: HIGHLAND PARK, Mich. — When the sun sets in this small city, its neighborhoods seem to vanish.

headline: Abrupt Shift in Leadership at a Hospital in Brooklyn
text: The chief executive of a troubled Brooklyn hospital has been abruptly dismissed, less than a month after a task force set up by the administration of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo outlined a plan to carry out a major reorganization of how hospital care is delivered in Brooklyn.

headline: The School Lunch Barometer
text: The economic downturn is driving more and more families into the ranks of the poor and the “near poor” who barely make it from paycheck to paycheck. This pattern is chillingly clear from the rising numbers of formerly middle-class children now qualifying for free or low-cost meals under the federally financed school lunch program.

headline: Judge Says S.E.C. Misled Two Courts in Citi Case
text: WASHINGTON — The federal judge overseeing the Securities and Exchange Commission’s fraud case against Citigroup became even more direct in his criticism of the agency’s actions on Thursday, accusing the commission of misleading both his court and the federal court of appeals.

headline: Charlie Morgan’s Battle
text: There is nothing theoretical about the ongoing pain inflicted by the Defense of Marriage Act, the 1996 law that bars the federal government from recognizing same-sex marriages. Ask Charlie Morgan, a chief warrant officer in the Army National Guard, based in New Hampshire.

headline: Howard Shows Nets Just How Much They Could Use Him
text: ORLANDO, Fla. — If there was any doubt about how much the Nets need a player of Dwight Howard’s caliber, especially now, a season before their move to Brooklyn, he punctuated that point with a violent blocked shot early in the first quarter of Thursday night’s game, airmailing the ball from beneath the basket into the fourth row of the courtside seats.

headline: Letter That Led to Downfall of Hewlett Chief Surfaces
text: The June 2010 letter that led to Mark V. Hurd’s downfall as the head of Hewlett-Packard paints a portrait of an executive who pressed a contract employee for sex, touched her inappropriately and asked her to spend the night with him.

headline: Evelyn Handler Dies at 78; Led Two Universities
text: Evelyn Handler, a cell biologist who, as the first woman to serve as president of Brandeis University, set off an acrimonious debate over the university’s Jewish identity when she secularized some campus traditions in hopes of attracting more non-Jewish students, died Dec. 23 in a pedestrian accident in Bedford, N.H. She was 78.

headline: Finding the Cleanup Crew After a Messy Hack Attack
text: In the film “Pulp Fiction,” Harvey Keitel plays the Wolf, a fast-talking and meticulous man who is called in to deal with the aftermath of an accidental shooting.

headline: Going Home Again
text: Rod Dreher grew up in St. Francisville, La., a town of about 1,700 people 30 minutes northwest of Baton Rouge. He left for college and then lived in Washington, New York, Miami, Dallas and Philadelphia, working as a writer for various magazines, a newspaper and a foundation.

headline: Letter to Mark Hurd Alleging Harassment
text: A copy of a letter sent in June 2010 by Gloria Allred, an attorney, to Mark Hurd, who was then the chief executive of Hewlett Packard, alleging harassment of her client, Jodie Fisher.

headline: Voters Examining Candidates, Often to a Fault
text: DES MOINES — Jonathan Gabhart, a 21-year-old college student from Spencer, Iowa, is leaning toward voting for Ron Paul because of the Texas lawmaker’s unpolished speaking style — a “high-pitched, squirrelly voice,” as he put it. “He seems like a real person because of his eccentricities.”

headline: The Allred/Fisher Letter vs. Emails sent by Jodie Fisher
text: A timeline of e-mails that Jodie Fisher apparently sent to Mark Hurd, the former chief executive of Hewlett Packard, contrasts the events outlined in a letter that accuses Mr. Hurd of sexual harassment.

headline: Keynes Was Right
text: “The boom, not the slump, is the right time for austerity at the Treasury.” So declared John Maynard Keynes in 1937, even as F.D.R. was about to prove him right by trying to balance the budget too soon, sending the United States economy — which had been steadily recovering up to that point — into a severe recession. Slashing government spending in a depressed economy depresses the economy further; austerity should wait until a strong recovery is well under way.

headline: For N.F.L., Concussion Suits May Be Test for Sport Itself
text: The long debate over the National Football League’s handling of concussions is reaching the courts in a flurry of lawsuits, raising the possibility that dozens of former players will go before juries to outline the league’s medical practices and describe long-term cognitive problems they say were caused by the sport.

headline: Should the World of Toys Be Gender-Free?
text: Berkeley, Calif.

headline: Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, Environmental Advocate, Dies at 81
text: Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff, a Georgian aristocrat and a lifelong New Yorker who became an environmental watchdog in posts in and out of government, died on Monday in his home on the Upper East Side. He was 81.

headline: Tax Benefits From Options as Windfall for Businesses
text: The stock market’s rebound from the financial crisis three years ago has created a potential windfall for hundreds of executives who were granted unusually large packages of stock options shortly after the market collapsed.

headline: Answers to the Year in Questions
text: UTTERANCES

headline: Holiday on Monday — New Year’s Day (Observed)
text: NEW YORK

headline: How the Candidates Roll
text: While the G.O.P. hopefuls are all making their final tours around early voting states, their modes of travel — and their entourages — vary widely.

headline: Today’s Cable Guy, Upgraded and Better-Dressed
text: The cable guy is becoming sleeker and more sophisticated, just like the televisions and computers he installs.

headline: Bryant’s Advice for Alex Rodriguez
text: LOS ANGELES — Before Alex Rodriguez flew to Germany to undergo a cutting-edge medical treatment, he consulted someone he knew and trusted to give him sound advice: Kobe Bryant.

headline: Judge Blocks a California Fuel Regulation
text: SAN FRANCISCO — A federal judge on Thursday blocked enforcement of a California regulation favoring producers of gasoline, diesel fuel and biofuels whose methods generate fewer greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: Neophyte Runs Into Realities of Politics
text: Alderman Ameya Pawar’s recent fund-raiser featured a praise-filled speech from his most prominent constituent, Mayor Rahm Emanuel. The event, on Dec. 13, capped a storybook year for the political neophyte, who upset the Emanuel-backed candidate in the mayor’s home 47th Ward in the City Council election in February.

headline: Chaos at Midnight, Hung Lokpal
text: An “exhausting day of parliamentary speechmaking, political posturing and backroom negotiations could not produce a deal,” on the anti-corruption Lokpal Bill, Jim Yardley writes in the New York Times.

headline: This Blagojevich Listens, but He Acts Up a Lot, Too
text: Blagojevich, who was transferred two years ago from Illinois to Michigan, feasts on three square meals per day with a daily jog around the paddock, his unusually thick mane glinting in the sunlight.

headline: TCW Settles Suit With Its Former Star Investor
text: One of the year’s most contentious white-collar employment disputes came to an end Thursday, as Trust Company of the West, the California-based mutual fund, announced that it had settled a lawsuit with its former star investor, Jeffrey E. Gundlach.

headline: NYT Front Page for 12/30/2011
text: NYT Front Page for 12/30/2011

headline: Our Smartest and Dumbest Columns of 2011
text: Some of my favorite columnists and bloggers have started something called a prediction audit, which looks back at their year of writing and evaluates which of their articles seem to have been the most and the least prescient.

headline: Bryant Masterfully Guides Lakers Past Knicks
text: LOS ANGELES — The faces have changed many times over, the uniforms recycled for one hopeful crew of Knicks after another, all of them fated to witness the same inevitable result: Kobe Bryant, rising above them, wielding the basketball as a weapon and a taunt.

headline: Shooting Dharavi, A Photographer’s View
text: Adam Ferguson, a photojournalist who has spent most of the past three years covering Afghanistan, returned to India, where he first worked in 2007 to photograph Dharavi for The New York Times’ recent story. He spent a week taking pictures in Dharavi and another 10 days shooting a video that will be on our Web site.

headline: Harper Save the Queen
text: MONTREAL — Hanging a portrait of the head of state in embassies and consulates abroad is the sort of thing most countries do as a matter of routine. For Canada, though, the move has proved controversial, not least because the country’s head of state lives thousands of miles away, in London.

headline: Kim Jong-un Named Leader of North Korean Army
text: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea announced on Saturday that its new leader, Kim Jong-un, had officially been named supreme commander of the country’s powerful army, a day after the country warned that it would not soften its stance toward South Korea.

headline: Israeli Strike Kills Gaza Militant
text: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military killed a radical Palestinian militant in Gaza on Friday and seriously wounded another one in what it said was the thwarting of a rocket attack into southern Israel.

headline: Let’s Start Paying College Athletes
text: Mark Emmert, the president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, the almighty overseer of American college sports, likes to think of himself as a reformer. A few months ago, after he’d been on the job for a little more than a year, he pushed through a series of improvements, including slightly higher academic standards for college athletes, a full-scale review of the N.C.A.A.’s fat rule book and a new provision giving universities the option of offering four-year scholarships. The current one-year deals are, believe it or not, renewable at the discretion of coaches, who can effectively cut injured or underperforming “student athletes,” as the N.C.A.A. likes to call them.

headline: Kim Geun-tae, South Korean Democracy Activist, Dies at 64
text: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Geun-tae, one of South Korea’s best-known pro-democracy activists, whose constant smile belied his mental and physical struggle with the aftermath of torture he suffered from a past military dictator’s spy agency, died here on Friday. He was 64.

headline: Wyden-Ryan’s Unrealistic Assumptions
text: Laura D’Andrea Tyson is a professor at the Haas School of Business at the University of California, Berkeley, and served as chairwoman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Clinton.

text: Six points from around the Web, with an extra point from The Fifth Down:

text: The longtime Fifth Down commenter Walt Bennett, a Jets fan from Harrisburg, Pa., weighs in on a Jets offense that is in disarray:

headline: When a Fast Fails: Lessons From Gandhi
text: Even Mohandas K. Gandhi, the architect of the Indian obsession with the hunger strike, did not always succeed in his fasts — although success was, admittedly, measured by Mr. Gandhi’s own standards.

headline: Week 17 Matchups: A Playoff Handshake
text: Cowboys (8-7) at Giants (8-7)Sunday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Giants by 3

headline: Is Lokpal Jinxed, or Was This a Serial Killing?
text: Nine times in the past four decades, a Lokpal bill to create an anti-corruption ombudsman  has been introduced in India’s Parliament, and eight times the bill has died. In its most current incarnation, the bill is in intensive care.

headline: Obama and Republicans Seek to Define 2012
text: DES MOINES – The 2012 presidential election, Mitt Romney said on Thursday, “could be our last chance” to save the United States from Greece-like bankruptcy.

headline: Democrats Keep Focus on Romney
text: DES MOINES — If Mitt Romney wins the Iowa caucuses and goes on to eventually snag the Republican nomination, the prize for the best crystal ball may go to none other than the Democratic Party.

headline: Medical Aid Group Vows to Stay in Somalia After Fatal Attack
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — A day after two of its foreign workers were gunned down by a former colleague, a medical aid group vowed on Friday to continue working in Somalia. The attack was the latest in a series on humanitarian workers and journalists, underscoring the dangers of operating in this war-torn country.

headline: Sportcraft Files for Liquidation
text: 10:16 a.m. | Updated

headline: Daily Report: The Mark Hurd Saga Continues
text: In Friday’s New York Times, Quentin Hardy reported on yet another chapter in the saga of Mark Hurd, the former chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. A Delaware court ruled Wednesday that the letter that led to Mr. Hurd’s resignation on Aug. 6, 2010, could be made public. The court did not release the letter yet, but the document was obtained by The Times from someone close to the case.

headline: Hackers Release More Data From Stratfor
text: 1:41 p.m. | Updated  Adding analysis of the data release.

headline: Ukraine Sends Opposition Leader to Remote Prison
text: MOSCOW — The Ukrainian authorities abruptly transferred the jailed opposition leader Yulia V. Tymoshenko to a prison camp about 300 miles east of the capital on Friday, a move that her supporters suspect is intended to cut off her access to the press and the public.

headline: For Entrepreneurial ‘Change Agents,’  a Green M.B.A.
text: As we noted in a post in August about a new survey, an increasing number of colleges are beginning to offer courses or entire programs devoted to green business practices in response to growing demand.

headline: The Breakfast Meeting, Dec. 30
text: The job of cable TV installer has become an increasingly sophisticated, Amy Chozick writes, as the products offered by cable companies have become more intricate. Many now have backgrounds in engineering and computer science, all the better for installing, and explaining, products like cloud-based cable boxes and iPad apps that let subscribers set recording times remotely.

headline: Thousands Rally in Syria to Prove Their Discontent to Arab Monitors
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Tens, and possibly hundreds, of thousands of people defied a continuing government crackdown to fill the streets of several Syrian cities on Friday, intent on showing visiting monitors from the Arab League the extent of opposition to President Bashar al-Assad.

headline: Former Insider Indicted in Chinese Corruption Scandal
text: BEIJING — A former fugitive accused by the Chinese authorities of being responsible for one of the nation’s biggest corruption scandals was indicted on Friday after he was said to confess to bribery and smuggling, according to state news organizations.

headline: The Best in Travel
text: The best travel posts of 2011, from utopian retreats to urban adventures

headline: For Cunningham Dance Company, Contentment and Finality at Armory
text: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company is ending its 58-year career this week by looking forward as well as back: time present contains time past and time to come. There were to be six performances of a 50-minute Event at the Park Avenue Armory. I wrote this after the two performances on Thursday; there were two more on Friday, and the last two will be on Saturday.

headline: Wall Street Ends Back Where It Started
text: Like a roller coaster returning to the platform, the stock market in the United States ended the last day of trading in 2011 just about where it started the year. But what a wild ride it was in between.

headline: Friday Reading: Municipal Cutbacks Leave Residents in the Dark
text: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

headline: High-Tech Tools, Primeval Wonders
text: Some days ago here, in a rich biodiverse ecosystem off the Costa Rican coast, we had planned to take another step closer to my lifelong dream of fully integrating advanced closed-circuit rebreather technology with a sophisticated submersible to leverage the strengths of each for exploring the coral reef “twilight zone” — that is, coral-reef habitat at depths of about 200 to 500 feet.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Chicago Reader: It seems like the perfect cooking ingredient for the close of a year: ash. — Jeff Gordinier

headline: At a Brooklyn Music Store, Resolving to Adapt
text: A cheery holiday card from Tati and Gerry at Ansonia Records rests on the counter of Manny Rivera’s Brooklyn music store, hidden behind a pile of compact discs, domino sets and assorted tropical knick-knacks. It’s a nice, personal touch in a business that has long since lost it.

headline: Reports Describe Deadly Clash in Restive China Region
text: BEIJING — Police officers killed seven people they accused of being kidnappers in a remote mountainous area of Xinjiang on China’s turbulent western frontier, according to state-run news organizations on Friday.

headline: 52, and Still Working the Streets
text: LIKE many single mothers, Barbara Terry, 52, scrounged for baby sitters and leaned on her own mother while raising her four children and working the night shift.

headline: In Common
text: Lance Cpl. Benjamin Whetstone Schmidt was killed in Afghanistan on Oct. 6. He was a 24-year-old native of San Antonio, a Marine scout sniper and a son of proud parents. Like many others, Corporal Schmidt volunteered for the combat tour that cost him his life because, as he explained to his friends and family, he wanted to go back to protect his fellow Marines.

headline: Romney Releases New Ad in New Hampshire
text: Mitt Romney has a new ad in New Hampshire, highlighting a theme that dovetails with the messages of his previous ads by focusing on optimism. The ads counterbalance what has been a negative barrage of advertisements by the Restore Our Future “super PAC” supporting Mr. Romney. Those ads have been sharply critical of Newt Gingrich and Gov. Rick Perry of Texas. Mr. Romney is back in New Hampshire Friday as he tries to maintain a lead in the polls in that state.

headline: Australia by Sail, Manning My Own Ship
text: THE Whitsunday Passage was looking rough. The trade winds had picked up around dawn and were whipping 20 knots from the southeast while the ebbing tide carried the water in the opposite direction. The conflict between these two forces of nature had filled the channel with burly 10-foot waves — a sea of bouncers determined to prevent our sailboat from reaching the Whitsunday Islands off the coast of Queensland, Australia.

headline: Blue Screen At Dawn
text: OK, not quite at dawn — but I did start my day with the blue screen of death, and a computer that is apparently pining for the fjords.

headline: A Classic Cocktail with a Thai Twist
text: Maybe you’re not the kind of drinker who leaps to the assumption that a spirit — rye, for instance — can be made even better if the bartender just keeps dumping in more ingredients.

headline: A Yen For Yen
text: The FT has an article noting the strength of the yen against the euro, which it attributes to the yen’s “enduring status as a haven against the global financial turmoil.” Well, yes — Japan is seen as safe, despite its high level of debt, just like all the other advanced countries that have retained their own currencies.

headline: Week 17 in Fantasy Football: Favorable and Unfavorable Matchups
text: Jason and Justin Sablich will provide fantasy football advice throughout the season on this blog and on Twitter (@5thDownFantasy).

headline: Memorial Service Held for Woman Set Afire in Elevator
text: Deloris Gillespie loved bargains, and when she found a good one — milk at half-price, soap at a discount — she bought in bulk and shared with her friends. She gave gifts to everyone, but would not accept any for herself. And when she shared recipes, ingredients were included.

headline: Goodbye to the Gowns, the Glamour and the First Person Plural
text: Does anyone need a gown?

headline: 2011: Stories That Changed the Way We Parent Now
text: If there’s yet been a year without a full slate of news stories that change the way I think about myself as a parent, it must have predated my time in that role. This year had more to offer in that respect than most of us wanted. Parenting-related topics led Facebook’s most-shared list. There were thousands of articles about family published in 2011. You may feel as if you read them all — but how many really changed you?

headline: Puddin’ by Clio Opening in the Village
text: Clio Goodman grew up in a family of serious cooks, so it was only natural that she would try her hand at a culinary career. After graduating from the Culinary Institute of America, she worked at Danny Meyer’s restaurant group and for Daniel Boulud.

text: UPSHOT

headline: When You Root, Root, Root for a Team That’s Not From Home

headline: New Poll Confirms Gingrich’s Slide
text: The latest poll of likely participants in the Republican Iowa caucuses confirms Newt Gingrich’s slide as Mitt Romney and Representative Ron Paul lead the pack.

text: LONDON

text: Culver City, Calif.

headline: Working-Class Blues and R&B Royalty
text: Don’t change the calendar yet. This Playlist is the last gasp of 2011, a final handful of albums released through the year that almost got away. Almost.

headline: 30 Years Later, Revisiting ‘Brideshead’
text: REVIEWING Evelyn Waugh’s “Brideshead Revisited” in 1946, Edmund Wilson found himself “cruelly disappointed.” After a promising start, he wrote, Waugh abandoned his usual comic motif for a “mere romantic fantasy,” shot through with “shameless and rampant” snobbery and characters both “implausible and tiresome.”
